name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Before we come to the Dutch Presidency's programme of activities, I must confront you with a point of order.  You are aware that the Conference of Presidents decided to ask the Committee on Home Affairs and Civil Liberties to look into the situation in Denmark with regard to the legislation on social assistance for refugees there. At the request of the Conference of Presidents, I have asked the Committee on Home Affairs and Civil Liberties to look into the matter. The coordinators of the committee decided by a majority not to discuss the matter directly, but only at one of the next meetings.  Mr Lamberts then contacted me with his group's request that, by a majority of Parliament – spontaneously – even without consideration in the LIBE Committee, the matter should now, for today or tomorrow, put the matter on the agenda of the plenary session, which we could do. I then consulted all the political groups in the House to see if there was a majority in favour of this. The clear majority of the political groups have replied to me until this morning that they see no need to put the matter on the agenda today. That is what I have to tell you here.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, obviously, there are many people who do not want to discuss the situation in Denmark. I think it is a question of credibility for the European Union and, for this body, of the fair treatment of States.  Yesterday we spent considerable, and justified, time on the situation in Poland. We have in the past devoted considerable and justified time to the situation in Hungary. We have a situation that is developing in Denmark which I think requires us to debate it.  We have offered the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs the opportunity to discuss this before a possible plenary debate. I note that the leaders of this committee have been on the clock and want to put it off, knowing full well that the measure will have been adopted by then in the Danish Parliament. I therefore insist and simply ask you, as president , and you tell me that you have consulted with the leaders of the political groups, to put the proposal to a vote, because I know that within the political groups, not everyone wants to postpone this debate. I therefore think that the best way to ensure this is to have a vote now on the agenda of the situation in Denmark for this session and to put this proposal to a roll call and we will see. Everyone will decide: if we lose, we lose, if we win, we will put this item on the agenda.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I strongly support Mr Lamberts' request. I must also say that I am already very irritated and astonished. The Conference of Presidents has virtually repealed the request made by the Greens at the conference to deal with the issue this plenary week, following the intervention of some group chairmen under the condition that the LIBE Committee meets last Monday. However, it has always been clear that the full request applies to this being discussed during this sitting week, unless the meeting of the LIBE Committee or the LIBE coordinators is held. That is why we should vote here now. We should note how real the situation is here. I have to say once again that the political core of the refusal in the LIBE Committee to meet practically this week and to allow a debate now is obviously that there should be no signal from this Parliament to make a clear announcement before the decision is taken in the Danish Parliament. That is the crucial point!

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, my Group agrees that it is very important to discuss this matter, contrary to what Mr Lamberts thinks. I have been told that even the Danish Government is very eager to come here and discuss with the European Parliament – they were even ready to come this week – and yes, it is important to discuss it before the vote takes place in the Danish Parliament, but I think it is a bit artificial to push for a debate here, this week , in this plenary.  There is an opportunity on Monday, there is another meeting of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) and I would ask you, President, to contact the Chair and coordinators of LIBE again and ask them to consider it to be included on the agenda for Monday.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the I presented the POSITION of the PPE-DE at the beginning of the agenda on Monday. We now have a new state of affairs, namely that our experts in the House, our colleagues from the LIBE Committee, the coordinators, that is, those who have been appointed by the political groups as experts on internal issues, have consulted and have come to the conclusion that there is no urgency to discuss the issue. I think that the Greens should also simply respect the fact that the experts see no urgency in our House. We have normal meetings that are now to be held, namely the Committee on Home Affairs. The Danish Government has expressly announced that it will be happy to come and be available for debate. That is why we should simply let colleagues do the work. I would like to say today that this legislation in Denmark is about the question of putting asylum seekers on an equal footing with the Danes, because even Danes who have money are not entitled to social assistance. It is about nothing more and nothing less. Mr. President! I would like to say that if, in future, Mr Lamberts and the Greens, we play up as the Upper Parliament in any legislation that is going on in Europe and try to teach everyone else what green ideology means, then we are damaging the European project – then we are damaging the European project! My group has respect for what is being done in the Danish Parliament. (Applause)

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: for the ECR Group. Mr President! It would be a totally unreasonable demonstration of power on the part of the European Parliament if we started to intervene in the internal Danish legislative procedure. Firstly, Denmark has a record in this whole area, which has recently been reconfirmed by the electorate. Secondly, if it were to be examined whether Or not Denmark is truly a democracy, it would be the European Commission and Mr Barroso. Mr President, I would like to say to Mr Timmermans, not the Green Group in the European Parliament, who was to open investigations. Thirdly, this is a proposal which has not yet been adopted in the Danish Parliament. However, we know from the first reading in the Folketing that this is a proposal that enjoys immediate broad support. It is an ALDE party that has tabled the proposal. It is supported by the S&D party in Denmark. It is supported by the EPP party in Denmark. And it is supported by the ECR party in Denmark. So perhaps we should respect national democracy rather than playing over-referees down here and assessing what is good and bad in the individual Member States.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, my group prefers to maintain the decision of the Conference of Presidents and to support most of the coordinators of the LIBE Commission, who have decided to deal with this matter prior to the debate in plenary. However, I do not necessarily share some of the arguments that have been expressed above. I believe that the situation in Denmark certainly deserves an in-depth debate in this Parliament and, precisely because it deserves an in-depth debate, I believe that it should not be a spontaneous debate, but must be a rigorous debate in the LIBE Commission and, subsequently, in Parliament's plenary.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen! I think that is clear. We have an opinion here in this House. Mr Lamberts wants us to vote on it now for a debate on the matter in plenary today or tomorrow. Mrs Veld has proposed that the Committee on Civil Liberties should revisit the matter next Monday. These are the two different proposals. I believe that there is a clear majority in this House in favour of Mrs Veld's proposal. I think you can see that. I know, Mr Lamberts, that you are against this – i was quite clear. But it is the President's job to see how the majorities are here in plenary. Before we proceed to the vote on this – and I shall put the motion to the vote in Veld first – Mr Gollnisch has raised a point of order.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, my point of order is based on Articles 152 and 154 of it. I believe that, in any event, Mr President, no vote on this proposal would have been immediately possible.  Indeed, Article 152 of our regulation is perfectly clear: the agenda of the session must be adopted at the beginning of the session. It is true that there is a possibility of amendment under section 154, that is, an emergency motion. However, it must first be announced by the President, then translated into all official languages and can only be discussed at the meeting following the President's announcement. In any event, therefore, the procedure that has been followed or which was likely to be followed so far was contrary to the rules of our institution.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Gollnisch, you always read the Rules of Procedure intensively, but you do not understand them properly. The situation is clear: the President may propose to change the agenda. This right is conferred on the President. So I can propose spontaneous changes to the agenda. That is why I asked the political groups yesterday for feedback on what the group's opinion is on this point. This consultation has resulted in a clear majority, which has also been reflected here. The majority is not in favour of spontaneously changing the agenda today. That is why I have not yet proposed it. It is another question whether a Member of this House asks that the House recommend that a committee deal with the matter. That is the request made by my colleague in Mr Veld, which I can accept without any problems, because it is also the more far-reaching amendment.  That is why my recommendation is that we should vote on the motion tabled by colleagues in The First Minister.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, since this was the proposal made by the Conference of Presidents, I would like us to put it to the vote first, and therefore that you, as President, first put to the vote the proposal to hold the debate here in plenary. Moreover, it is also chronologically the normal order. Then, if this proposal is rejected, then you could put Madame in 't Veld's proposal to a vote for the LIBE committee to deal with it next Monday.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Lamberts, I understand your position, but I disagree. If the house has a motion that aims for a committee to deal with it again before the plenary itself is discussed, I must first put it to the vote. If this does not find a majority, but the majority thinks that we should now vote on the fact that we are debating directly here without a committee, then I will put it to the vote. That is quite clear. But the request of Mrs. Veld goes further. The request is that the LIBE Committee will be invited to discuss it again next week Monday. I shall now put it to the vote. (Parliament adopted the motion)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission on the Dutch Presidency's programme of activities (2015/2963(RSP)).

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, it is an honour to address you today, as Prime Minister of the country that for the next six months has the privilege of holding the Presidency of the EU Council. It is a fine tradition that each new Presidency outlines its plans before this Parliament. And it is also entirely logical, because the European Parliament is where all the lines of the EU converge, so we will be working together closely over the next few months. The Dutch Presidency looks forward to this opportunity, I can assure you. Together with you, we will work hard to achieve as much as possible for the people of Europe. How we see the EU depends in part on when and where we were born. I was born in 1967 and, living in The Hague, my family’s conversation at the dinner table often revolved around politics and society, including the latest developments in European cooperation. Like the first direct elections to the European Parliament in 1979 – a discussion I can still remember. I was only 12, so I could not vote yet, but I did feel somehow it was a big deal. After all, for my parents’ generation, European cooperation was linked directly to history. For that generation, above all, it meant ‘nie wieder Krieg’ – no more war. For younger generations, Europe does not carry the same emotional charge – if at all. The reality is that many people are slowly but surely growing sceptical about the EU. The way they see it, the EU interferes in their lives for no good reason, while achieving few results. Its benefits seem far removed from everyday life. At the same time – rightly or wrongly – the irritation people feel about rules made in ‘Brussels’ is never far away, and I believe there is only one way to counteract this: we need to achieve concrete results and make sure they are visible, and we need to stick to areas where the EU can achieve more than Member States can by themselves. In short, Europe must be relevant to people’s daily lives. Over the next few months, the Netherlands wants to help to make that happen. It is clear that the Netherlands is taking over the Presidency of the EU in difficult times. We are seeing a massive influx of refugees, fleeing a bloody conflict that is happening all too close by. The situation on our eastern border is also complex and fragile, and the EU’s relations with Russia are troubled. The barbaric attacks in Paris have shown once again that we cannot take our free and democratic way of life for granted. And all this is going on while Europe is recovering from the worst economic crisis since the Second World War. Far too many people are still unemployed. None of these problems can be solved by a single country acting alone: the countries of Europe share a big responsibility. Against this backdrop, the Netherlands has been preparing intensively for the Council Presidency. Two months ago, for example, I welcomed a delegation from this Parliament at the Hall of Knights in The Hague’s Binnenhof, at the heart of our parliamentary democracy. It was a successful, productive visit, and we addressed a number of pressing issues, but there was also a historical symbolism to the occasion, because the Hall of Knights played a special role in the early history of European cooperation. In 1948 it was the venue of the Congress of Europe, which would go down in history as the dawn of the European Community. The Congress was attended by 750 delegates from 26 European countries: politicians and academics, artists and journalists, philosophers and business leaders. They included great Europeans whom we remember to this day, from Konrad Adenauer and Jean Monnet to Altiero Spinelli and Paul-Henri Spaak. The event’s honorary chairman was Winston Churchill, who spoke passionately about the importance of cooperation based on common values, common economic interests and common security needs: three pillars that have lost none of their relevance today. The Congress in The Hague laid the foundations for the Council of Europe, the European Coal and Steel Community and the Treaty of Rome. It even discussed – only three years after the end of the Second World War – the idea of a monetary union, a single market without borders and a representative assembly. It was a conference full of lofty ideals and grand institutional visions, and in the decades that followed, those ideals and those visions would slowly but surely take concrete form. One of the Dutch delegates was Foreign Minister Dirk Stikker. Fifty years ago, when he published his memoirs, Stikker looked back at the early days of European cooperation, which he called ‘an age-old dream’. He wrote, ‘It has been attempted by conquerors, pondered by philosophers, sought by scholars, and sabotaged as well as extolled by politicians – often at the same time. It is not a simple thing, to be accomplished with a bit of good will and the stroke of a pen.’ This is the tradition in which we stand today. ‘Europe’ is a large, complex, shared project that can only move forward one step at a time. I do not believe that anyone in those early years could have imagined quite how complex the project would be at times – both technically and politically. But the founders might also have been pleasantly surprised at many of the things the Member States have jointly achieved over the years: our free and open democratic systems; the unprecedented prosperity and welfare enjoyed by Europeans today; the power of our single market. We can be proud of these achievements, but we must be vigilant, because they need to be maintained. This is the tradition in which we will fulfil our duties as Presidency holder. The tradition of cooperation that transcends what countries can achieve alone. The tradition of working step by step, Schritt für Schritt, towards a goal. We must be committed and determined, but also pragmatic and realistic. That is the approach we want. I promise you that we will put our long Dutch experience of coalition-building and consultation to full use. There is plenty for us to build upon. Take the political priorities of the European Commission under the leadership of Jean-Claude Juncker, or the strategic agenda of the European Council. And let us not forget the calculation made by this Parliament that we are missing out on EUR 1.25 trillion a year by not making full use of the single market, for example in the digital domain. In short, Europe does not need new lofty ideals or grand visions. It needs results. It needs to deliver. And for that, we first need to follow up on what we have agreed. Keeping promises and sticking to agreements should be the new normal for Europe. A deal is a deal. That’s a key principle for the Dutch Presidency. Of course, I say that partly in the light of the most urgent issue we face at the moment: the continual flow of refugees from Syria, Iraq and other countries. It is crucial that the agreements we made with Turkey last year are carried out fast, to relieve the pressure on our external borders. It is crucial to offer refugees a humanitarian alternative to risking their lives at sea in flimsy boats. We need safe reception in the region. It is also crucial that we get Europe’s borders under control, especially in Greece. And that the ‘hotspots’ we have agreed on are put in place. We must also get the registration of refugees sorted out as soon as possible so that every Member State can play its part.  We are all in this together. It is precisely at difficult times like this that we need that shared sense of responsibility. Let me be clear: the current numbers are not sustainable. We are running out of time. We need a sharp reduction in the number of refugees in the coming six to eight weeks. So it is both logical and necessary that we devote a lot of time and energy to the refugee crisis in the month ahead. That is a priority, and the Netherlands Presidency will give it as much focus as possible. At the same time, I would like to commend the European Parliament on its study of ‘The Cost of Non-Europe’, which I mentioned a moment ago. Because however pressing many issues are, we cannot lose sight of our long-term goals in areas like innovation, economic growth and job creation. We are putting the economic crisis behind us, and the European economy is finally picking up again. But one in ten adult Europeans is still out of work, and that is simply too many. And for young people it is very hard to get a foot in the labour market door. So it is good to see the European Parliament mapping ways of getting more people in work. A key goal of the Dutch Presidency is to move forward with all existing initiatives, plans and projects aimed at innovative growth and more jobs, and of course enhancing the stability of the eurozone will remain a focus of those efforts. But above all, we must seize the existing opportunities in our internal market. The figure I mentioned before – EUR 1.25 trillion – is double the size of the Dutch economy. It would mean millions of jobs for millions of people. We cannot ignore that opportunity. How could we explain that to future generations? I believe that the Commission, the Council and you – the Members of the European Parliament – broadly agree on what we want to achieve here. The Dutch Presidency will do all it can to foster a good working dynamic, and to ensure that the institutions can work together as effectively as possible for the sake of all those in Europe who are desperately trying to find work: above all, our young people. The debate on the future of our European institutions is going on – in one way or other – in almost every Member State. I believe there is growing consensus that the EU needs to focus on areas where cooperation is either essential, such as the migration issue, or clearly adds value, such as the single market. ‘Focus’ includes cutting back on the excessive regulations that restrict people and companies. Our Presidency fully endorses the Commission’s priorities and work programme, which are founded on these principles. It is also good that we are debating the Union’s future so openly, and I say that, of course, with particular reference to the position of the United Kingdom. The UK is a very important partner. Leaving the EU would be bad for the UK and bad for the EU, but we should never reduce that debate to the question of ‘more or less Europe?’ The question is how to build a better Europe: a Europe that makes the best choices and achieves the most benefits for its people.  Certainly, in some areas, the EU needs to step back and the Commission is now addressing this to good effect, but there are also areas in which we are not yet making the most of EU cooperation. The perfect example is of course the single market, which is not only an engine of economic growth and innovation, but also the cement that binds us together and makes us strong. That is why we need to keep a deeper and fairer single market high on the agenda. When it comes to deepening the market, I am thinking mainly of services and the digital market: two sectors that are almost completely untapped, even though most Europeans earn their living in one or the other. We need to facilitate online shopping in other Member States, attune legislation to the digital age, and tackle unfair geo-blocking. In the market for services, the Dutch Presidency will also be pressing for States to reduce the number of regulated professions. But I am also thinking of the challenges and opportunities in the area of energy and climate change. At last month’s successful summit in Paris the EU presented a strong, united front. In the follow-up process, it is now vital that we make full use of the single market’s innovative potential. That is something the Dutch Presidency wants to take forward. We also need to make sure that all workers receive equal pay for equal work in equal circumstances. Yes, it is a question of fairness, but not of fairness alone, because a fairer single market will help maintain support for free movement, and will help guarantee that the market functions properly. So this issue will also get a big push during our Presidency. Dirk Stikker was right: European cooperation is not a simple thing, accomplished with a bit of goodwill and the stroke of a pen. In many cases, the EU does not have ready-made solutions for the problems we face. Every country has its own interests and considerations, and negotiations can be tough. It is a bit like a football match: it is not the style of play that matters, but the final result. And as we all know, Europe scores most of its goals in injury time.  Europe has shown that it can tackle some major crises. The financial and economic crisis prompted us to step up oversight of our banks and to place our currency on a more solid footing. We have taken a common line on Russia’s actions in Ukraine, and we have closed a deal with Turkey on the refugee crisis. Step by step we are moving forward. That is in keeping with the European tradition, and it is in that conviction that the Netherlands is looking ahead to its Presidency. Our first and most important ambition in the months to come is to be a good and effective Presidency: one that makes sure that all 28 Member States can play their part. One that serves the process effectively, and takes account of everyone’s interests. But also a Presidency with the ambition to achieve concrete results. We can only do that by working closely with the European institutions, and above all, the European Parliament. The Netherlands looks forward to working with all of you. Indeed, it is only by working together that we can solve the problems facing the Union. Let us do so with the same resolve shown by Sir Winston Churchill when he addressed the Hall of Knights in The Hague in 1948: ‘We cannot rest upon benevolent platitudes and generalities,’ he said. ‘Our powers may be limited, but we know, and we must affirm, what we mean and what we want.’ In other words, there is a job to be done, so let’s get to work.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr President of the Commission. Mr President, Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. When Mark Rutte first presented the Dutch Presidency's programme to me two three months ago, I thought to myself: the Dutch have a capable Prime Minister, because the man can read thoughts. Because he said exactly what the Commission thought he should be presenting. I note that there is a great deal of agreement between the Dutch Presidency's intentions and the intentions of the European Commission, as presented in our own work programme in recent years and months. Prime Minister, you are taking over the Presidency of the European Union at a time when the European economy is visibly recovering and is getting its face back. The European economy will grow by 2% this year – 2% is not enough. Unemployment is down to 9.2% – this unemployment rate is too high.  But both the European Union and the euro area are no longer among the last in the class. Nevertheless, we must remain vigilant and we must strengthen the growth forces that exist in the European economy, give them muscles, give them legs. That is why we have launched the European Investment Plan. To date, EUR 50 billion of effective investments have been found in our balance sheet. 47 major infrastructure projects have been launched, more than 81 000 small and medium-sized enterprises are benefiting from this European investment plan, and we are only just beginning, because there is still a long way to go before we reach the 315 billion capital expenditures that we have written in the logbook. Investment only takes place when the regulatory density decreases: better regulation. This is also one of the main highlights of the Dutch Presidency. The Commission is in the process of putting into practice this catalogue of intentions, which we had given ourselves at the beginning of our mandate.  Led by Frans Timmermans, the first Vice-President, the Commission has ensured that the regulatory landscape has been scoured. We withdrew more than 100 initiatives from the previous Commission and we actually only envisaged 23 new initiatives per year. So there is a significant reduction, a reduction in the density of regulation. The European economy, like the people, needs less regulation so that more happens in life.  The Dutch Presidency is well advised to tackle some of the main points of the European Commission's action programme very deliberately. This is true of the Digital Single Market, the Energy Union, the Capital Markets Union. All three points are within the framework of the completion of the European Economic and Monetary Union, because the European Economic and Monetary Union is also an economic union. The European economy needs these modernisation surges exceptionally urgently. It would also be advisable for the Dutch Presidency to enthusiastically rush to complete the European Economic and Monetary Union and, above all, the Banking Union. A good example of showing that we are serious now would be to approach the issue of common European deposit insurance with a courageous step. I can only support the Presidency in its intention, if it has it, and i would like to share my good wishes. Videmment, la crise des réfugiés laquelle le Premier ministre a fait référence occupe nos esprits. Je ne voudrais pas répéter, devant vous, ce que j'ai dit hier deux reprises en pléni re, mais il est évident – tout comme le Premier ministre l'a dit – que nous devons redoubler d'efforts pour faire en sorte que les décisions que nous avons prises au niveau du Conseil des ministres et du Conseil européen  Il en va de méme pour l'application du plan d'action conjoint que nous avons négocié avec la Turquie. Il est urgent que toutes les dispositions de ce plan d'action soient mises en éuvre concr tement dans les semaines venir. Cela m'améne reconsidérer devant vous tous les probl mes gravitant autour de l'espace Schengen. Je veux répéter ici, comme je l'ai fait hier et avant-hier, que Schengen est menacé parce que nous avons un comportement qui se caractérise par sa légéreté. Nous fermons l'une apr s l'autre les fronti éres en Europe. Lorsque nous les aurons toutes fermées, nous constaterons que le co t économique du non-Schengen est considérable.  Rappelez-vous qu'il y a 1,7 million de travailleurs transfrontaliers en Europe. Souvenez-vous du fait qu'il y a 57 million de mouvements de transports routiers transfrontaliers. Rappelez-vous que le co't est énorme. Rien que sur le pont entre le Danemark et la Suéde, la réintroduction des contr les aux fronti res comporte un co t de 300 million d'euros. Les pénalités, sous forme de délais d'attente aux fronti res pour le transport routier, se chiffrent trois milliards. Le non-Schengen a donc un co't. Si les fronti res sont fermées, si le marché intérieur commence souffrir des conséquences non ma trisées, parce que non ma trisables, de la réintroduction des fronti res, il est évident que viendra le jour o nous nous demanderons s'il nous faut vraiment une monnaie unique si nous n'avons plus de marché intérieur et si nous n'avons plus de libre circulation desvailleurs. Tout se tient et tous les éléments doivent faire l'objet d'une analyse détaillée.  Si nous voulons sauvegarder Schengen, il faut de toute urgence nous doter d'un syst me de contr le des fronti res extérieures et c'ti res. La Commission a fait une proposition et je voudrais que le Conseil et le Parlement se pressent et accél rent le rythme de l'examen de ce texte. Je sais que le gouvernement néerlandais en fait une priorité en demandant aux ministres des affaires intérieures et de la justice de se réunir au moins une fois par mois pour pouvoir accélérer ces travaux. La Commission vous présentera, au cours des semaines venir, un texte sur la migration légale, parce que nous pensons que des fronti res intérieures s'res, des fronti res extérieures sécurisées et la migration légale sont trois choses qui vont ensemble.  Monsieur le Président, Mesdames et Messieurs, apr s avoir pris la parole hier deux fois sur le méme sujet, et par peur de me répéter, je terminerai ici mon introduction ce débat. Thank you voor uw aandacht. Veel succes.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Europe must deliver! I would like to begin by signalling to you, as the new President-in-Office of the Council, the full support of the European People's Party. We want to deliver together with the new Presidency. However, I have to go straight to the house, because, unfortunately, from god's point of view, there is a major problem on the Council side, namely the question of credibility. You pointed out in your introductory remarks, in your outlook on the presidency, that a deal is a deal. Now, however, we are faced with the question of the fact that it has been agreed in the Council to offer Turkey EUR 3 billion in order to create conditions on the ground, that people do not have to flee, and the money does not come together. Brussels is delivering, the Commission and we in the European Parliament are providing the money in a fast-track procedure, and the Council is not delivering. That is why, Prime Minister, the most important task is to restore credibility, to implement in the Council the issues that have been decided upon. (Applause) The priorities are right. Jean-Claude Juncker has said that. The issues of the eurozone that you are taking up, the internal reform process that Europe needs in order to create competitiveness in order to remain strong in a globalised world, are on the table. I am grateful to you for continuing to do so. I believe that the facets of the internal market are extremely important, that we strengthen it. I would ask you to talk not only about the new legislative issues, such as the internal energy market, digital, but also in the Councils about implementation, about the implementation, that what is decided in Europe is also carried out at national level. That, too, is on the table. And then there are two major issues that concern us: one big issue, of course, is migration. Yesterday, Donald Tusk said here in the European Parliament that we have two months to go – you are also talking about a similar scale – to get the issues under control. In this respect, your Presidency faces a huge challenge and also a great responsibility to defend the Schengen area, to uphold the Schengen idea and to implement it. I would also like to assure you, on the part of my group, that we are also open to a fast track procedure on the legislative issues that Jean-Claude Juncker and the Commission have put on the table – I am addressing only two: safe third countries and the Frontex issue. We want to achieve results quickly. These issues must be concluded during the Dutch Presidency. This includes security issues. We have done PNR and data protection. But there are other issues. Yesterday, the Commission presented a proposal to exchange data in the area of criminal records, which aims to improve networking in the exchange of data between judicial authorities in the case of criminal offences in Europe. Here, too, we assure you that you will be able to work quickly. The last major topic is the economy, economic development. We are hopeful going into 2016, as Jean-Claude Juncker rightly said. But we have to stick to it. For us, this is about trade policy. We will be talking about CETA in the next few weeks, about trade relations with Canada. We will continue to have TTIP on the table. In the negotiations, my group fully supports the Commissioner responsible. We want these agreements. We stand by the fact that trade policy creates jobs and thus also creates the future. I also hope that you can convince your citizens in the Netherlands that the agreement with Ukraine is a trade agreement. It is not a question of Ukraine's accession to the European Union, it is about trade policy. I hope that we will be able to convince the citizens of the Netherlands of this. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which All of this, taken together, is already big enough. But the big question, of course, is how we convince people of our project. And a new presidency is an opportunity for that. I would therefore like to thank you for the introduction you have chosen today and the message you have brought with you. The first message to convince people of the European project is that we must give answers, we must deliver on the substance and try to clarify people's everyday issues with our contributions at European level. This pragmatic approach is important first of all. And the second thing you have said today, and for which I thank you, is your introduction to the speech, namely to reflect how Europe was talked about decades ago, even with a story, with a narrative about Europe, not just facts, facts, facts, but emotion. And perhaps we need to talk more about it, about the emotions that resonate with Europe. When you spoke about the criticism of Europe that we all share, in terms of bureaucracy and so on, our populists were loud. They applauded, they were happy because they felt confirmed. But they then became quieter and quieter in the course of your speech, because then you talked about the big issues of our time, about Russia, about securing peace, about how we create the economy, how we create jobs for the citizens. Then the populists become quiet, because they then know that their approach does not work, that they have no answers for the future of our continent. And that is why let us tell this story, this story, that it is better for Europe to work together. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Blue card question. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, here is the opportunity for Mrs Weber to tell us about a chapter that she did not address this morning, she always deals with it: she has not spoken badly about Italy, the government and the Democratic Party and President Renzi, so if Perhaps Now I will give her an extra minute to deal with this chapter too, which you always deal with. If not, Mrs Weber, could you tell us about nord stream, which never says so, Nord Stream and the double standards that you and your country have, those who are wary of Russia during the day, at night they make agreements with us.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Danti, if you will allow me, unlike you, I am not speaking here as a normal Member of Parliament, but as the leader of the Group of the European People's Party, in which I have the honour of being chairman. On the Renzi issue, I would like to point out once again that I have raised this. I believe that if we in the Council pledge EUR 3 billion for Turkey, if all the Heads of State or Government meet in Brussels and decide on EUR 3 billion for Turkey, if all the Heads of Government are present, then I think it is quite normal that this should then also be implemented by the finance ministers. That is a normal approach for me. I wanted to express nothing more and nothing less, and I will continue to say so in the future.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Prime Minister, your Presidency will be at a decisive crossroads over the next six months: to be jointly responsible, although I do not want to, for the further decline of the European project or to be the protagonist, as you said, of its relaunch. Our group, the Group of The Party of European Socialists, wants to help you. It wants to help it on the road to recovery and to support economic recovery, as Mr Juncker said, it is not enough to strengthen the internal market, we need a change of pace in economic and social policy and we expect the Member States to commit themselves to strengthening the investment plan. We must also immediately lay down the conditions for the Union's fiscal capacity.  The Member States must be put in a position to invest. That is why we always insist on the concept of flexibility. It is not a musical refrain, it is a real opportunity to invest, to create an economy, to create new jobs. Flexibility which, as Juncker said, must also apply to refugees. We will then have to move forward with the banking union and approve the European deposit guarantee. On taxation, we expect a breakthrough to support the Commission's efforts.  We cannot be obsessed with the dogma of regulating public budgets and then allow multinational companies to take hundreds of billions of euros out of the public purse. Taxes must be paid where profits are made, and that is why we are asking the Dutch Presidency to support the proposals contained in the Ferreira-Theurer report. First of all, we want rapid approval of public country-by-country reporting and social Europe and environmental sustainability. Here, too, we need a shot, social dumping is a disaster. Our group wants your Presidency to be remembered for its decisive contribution to the adoption of a good Labour Mobility Package. We look forward in the coming weeks to the presentation by the Commission of this package and, above all, to the revision of the Posting of Workers Directive. For us – and we remind Mr Juncker that he is sensitive – this is a red line and is part of the pact on the basis of which we voted for the European Commission. On the refugee crisis, solutions are on the table and the European Commission has put them on the table, I must not remind you of them, as Mr Juncker mentioned just now. The stalemate created by some Member States must be overcome, and I want to say this to you, I want to say this to Tusk, it is hours, not days, not weeks, that must be spent convincing the states that have been rebellious and reluctant, because then spring comes and the situation will become even more difficult. Even on Schengen, the signals coming from some Member States are not at all encouraging. I hear talk of mini-Schengen. I see Member States reintroducing border controls. These are bad choices, ineffective choices and even harmful, as Juncker said, to the European economy.  I will conclude by concluding that Europe must not close in on itself. I call for a humanitarian corridor to be open in the next few hours to save syrian cities in the grip of frost and hunger. We must look far beyond our borders and on so many dossiers such as conflict minerals, Europe can show that it is a great force for change. Prime Minister, good luck and good work. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Raymond FINCH
text: blue-card question. – Mr Pittella, in this huge shopping list you have just given you did not mention TTIP. What are you going to do? Is your Group, as we know, going to support TTIP, which as we all know is a bosses’ charter, or are you going to stand against it and stand with the workers of Europe?

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Answer to a blue card question. My dear colleague, you are not very attentive to parliamentary work, because our group has also made its views clear on TTIP. We don't vote for anything in a closed box. The conditions apply to us and one of the basic conditions is the review of the arbitrage system. If there are different conditions, we will consider voting in favour, otherwise we will vote against.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the Dutch Prime Minister and I were both born in the same year, in the same month, in fact within a day of each other. We have seen the EU change much in our lifetime, and in your speech, Prime Minster, you laid out the road along which the EU has travelled over time. But now we are at a fork in that road, and by the end of your Presidency we will determine which fork to take. Will we take the road that sees our migration crisis continue, fudges decisions over the eurozone and sees a country, my country, possibly vote to leave? Or will we take the EU along the road to recovery, to a reformed EU that allows our citizens to harness the spirit of enterprise, to create jobs and growth? And at that fork in the road stands a traffic cop for the next six months, and that will be you, Prime Minister. And it is great to see that there are still some real market liberals left in the ALDE group rather than the pseudo-socialists that we see lined up in this Parliament. But your Dutch Presidency is right to focus on the key to recovery, the economy. Because if the European Union does not have innovative and growing economies, we cannot offer opportunities to young people who want a job, we cannot provide the resources needed to tackle the situation in Syria and the refugee crisis, we cannot tackle any of the other challenges we face. So your priority of cutting red tape that ties down businesses is one that the European Conservatives and Reformists Group welcomes. But we have seen all too often how presidencies become so desperate to get legislative agreements on their report card that they agree to any old rubbish. So my group will judge your Presidency not on the quantity but the quality of legislation that we see passed in the next six months. We will look to you to remove obstacles to trading across the single market, especially the digital single market. We will look to you to advocate enforcement of existing rules such as the EU Stability and Growth Pact. And, as well as a digital single market, we will look to you to quickly move on proposals on capital markets and energy proposals. We hope that the Dutch reputation for pragmatism will ensure that these proposals will not simply create more bureaucratic regulatory unions. In capital markets we do not necessarily need another union but transparent, efficient capital markets that allow entrepreneurs to access alternative sources of finance and not rely on banks alone. For energy, rather than focus on a bureaucratic union, we should be looking to interconnect energy grids, diversify supply and improve energy efficiency and conservation. But, as we look ahead today, your greatest challenge will be the refugee and migration crisis, and as you try to find solutions we hope you will rely less on imposed solutions and instead focus on cooperation and countries taking responsibility. Any leader that sends out an open invitation to all, regardless of whether they are genuinely fleeing persecution and war or seeking to queue-jump the legal migration channels, needs to take responsibility for the impact on their country and other countries. Those countries that are failing to protect the Schengen zone’s external borders need to live up to their responsibility. And all of us here and in the Commission should be helping countries to cooperate, to find solutions that are fair to Member States, to find solutions that are fair to their neighbours, and to find solutions fair to the people seeking asylum. We will certainly see one referendum during your Presidency; we may see two. The outcome of both of these referendums may depend on whether we can show the people that we are listening to them and that we can offer them solutions and not more problems. It is a heavy burden on your shoulders, and we in the European Conservatives and Reformists look forward to working with you to tackle the crisis with better solutions, to allow countries to cooperate better, and to steer the EU in a better direction. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: blue-card question. – Mr Kamall, you spoke about the need for a reformed Europe. Unlike yourself and the Dutch Prime Minister, I am unfortunately old enough to remember the last referendum, under Harold Wilson’s Labour government, when we had a few inconsequential, cosmetic changes which were paraded as a great reform and nobody can now remember what they were. In terms of reform do you not think it is a major omission from Mr Cameron’s list of reforms that he does not want to restore the supremacy of Parliament and have the ability to reject unwanted law? Are not all his reforms meaningless without that central key reform, which is we take back supremacy of law to our own Parliament? Do you agree or disagree? (Applause)

name: Syed KAMALL
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Batten, I was brought up to be tolerant to those more elderly and to have respect for the elderly, and I can understand why your memory fails you. You certainly do not remember the details of the 1975 referendum and actually, you may not remember some press reports last week in the UK media that in fact said that David Cameron, the Prime Minister, is looking at ideas on how to reassert the supremacy of the British Parliament. Maybe it is your listening skills. But what I would say to you, Mr Batten, is please, at the end of the day, whatever your view, we have plenty of time for the debate, at the end of the day it is the British people who will decide whether to stay or to leave the EU.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – For example, Prime Minister Rutte has already experienced what we experience here every month. That is the internal debate in Britain. I think there is more debate here than in the British Parliament, Mark. Anyway, so be it. You see, Britain could not do without European democracy. Where else would they be able to have their debates if we did not have the European Parliament?  The Dutch Presidency is coming and expectations are always high. It is not for nothing that there is a Treaty of Amsterdam and a Maastricht Treaty. I am not proposing, of course, that a new treaty be concluded immediately under the Dutch Presidency. I don't think that's realistic. But, of course, we have great hope that the Dutch Presidency can do something about the deep crisis in which Europe has been caught. I see - as you have also mentioned - three priorities. The top priority, of course, is the refugee crisis. What you said is almost exactly the same as what President Tusk said yesterday: 'We have two months, otherwise Schengen is dead'. I wonder if Schengen is not already dead. If there are border controls in Slovenia, hungary, Austria, Denmark and Sweden, and if there is any addition to Germany, then there is really nothing left of Schengen. I know that on 18 February you are planning a special summit on the Brexit story. Perhaps we should have an extra summit on the refugee crisis rather than Brexit. Because that's urgent. As Jean-Claude Juncker has said, we are waiting with the European Parliament for the european border and coast guard proposal. We're done. We have proposed to follow a fast track procedure. Manfred Weber repeated it this morning. The problem is when the Council is going to say yes and so I have one request to you. Because that's where it starts. There are 3 000 refugees a day arriving in Greece (which shows that the agreement with Turkey is still not working optimally). So that seems to me to be the priority. Mr. President, the second priority is the internal market. I would like to tell you, Mr Kamall, that I agree completely with you but your voting pattern is a little bit different. Yesterday we voted here on the harmonisation of spectrum in the Langen report, but we voted against the ECR, against harmonisation of spectrum. Yesterday we voted about one regulator in the digital market, we voted against the ECR on that issue. They want the digital market, a harmonised digital market, but they don't want it to be Europe that creates the digital market. It has to become the digital market 'spontaneously'. Well, a digital market doesn't come spontaneously; a digital market comes if you have the right legislation on the European level in place and we encourage you, Prime Minister, to come forward in the tradition of Jan Willem Beyen, the first Dutch person who defended the idea in the 1950s to have a customs union, an internal market.  We all know only 35% of the internal market exists; 65% is still closed: digital, telecom, capital markets. All this is closed; services are closed. My proposal is that the Dutch Presidency should agree on a timetable, so that in 2019 we have a full opening of the internal market. That should be a big achievement, because the actual growth we have – I agree with Mr Juncker on this – 1.5–2% is mainly expansive monetary policy by the ECB: low interest rates, low oil prices and a weak euro. We need, structurally, this fully-fledged internal market, and I hope then that the voting pattern of Mr. Kamall and his Group is going to be a little bit different than yesterday. Not only words, but also action, Mr. Kamall. Finally, the Brexit: I think you did a fantastic thing in your introduction, Mr Rutte. You have effectively given the greatest British statesman as an example: his speech in the Hague, but moreover his intervention in 1946 in Zurich at a university where he said that not only for economic but for geopolitical reasons, Britain has to remain in a united Europe. The Soviet Union may have disappeared, but in the me time we have Putin – one of the friends of Mr Farage – and while the threat in the Middle East may be different, in the meas we have terrorism. So, let us make a deal with Mr Cameron, and it has to be a deal with balance – we have interests too – and let us not forget that only a united Europe is in the geopolitical interest not only of Britain, but of all European states. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Verhofstadt, I would like to thank Mr Verhofstadt for his I can now organise a lottery here. Her speeches almost trigger floods of blue cards. (Mr Verhofstadt agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Vicky FORD
text: blue-card question. – Mr Verhofstadt, I wanted to ask you about the internal market. We have heard the Dutch Prime Minister talk about the need to unlock that economic benefit, that EUR 1.25 trillion, from further cooperation on the single market. We have heard the Socialists say that they do not really care about it: I am glad that they are so rich that they can leave that money untouched. The problem is so often that we try to unlock that benefit but just replace 28 regulations with an even more expensive one at European level. Do you therefore promise that your group will not vote for legislation that adds more cost? Will you commit to a burden reduction target to reduce red tape, and will you not add more costs through more social legislation, more legislation on our shared economy and more legislation and more costs on data, for example? Do you promise to commit to reducing costs for our economy?

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: blue-card answer. – I do nothing else than to try to reduce costs and reduce bureaucracy here in this House, with the new interinstitutional agreement I have negotiated, also in the name of your Group, Ms Ford, with the two other institutions, and with Mr Timmermans. But, that said, I think that often it is better to have one simple European directive instead of 28 different national regulations. Take for example, Ms Ford, the case of Spotify. Spotify went to the US instead of rolling out as a Swedish company. It needed to go to the United States instead of Europe because it had to comply with 28 national regulations, 28 different regulations. So one European rule is far better and less costly than 28 different national ones.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the You, Mr Rutte, have taken a long look back in history and flirted a bit with the complexity of the EU's development. I understand you to want to manage the Union in practice during your Presidency. You also pointed out that you were taking a step back and– to put it somewhat ironically – I did not even know that you were borrowing from Lenin, in his strategic work: two steps forward, one step backwards. We have converted this a little: two steps sideways and one step back. I do not think that this will give the necessary answer as to how the EU can really become suitable for everyday use. What do you say to people? Do you think it is important for the citizens of the EU how the profits of the banks increase and how a part of the population is increasing wealth and an ever-increasing proportion is increasingly excluded, also feels socially excluded and, in the end, also postulates a defence against the European Union.  Yesterday we had a discussion with the Polish Prime Minister. That was clear. Looking at our Member States in Eastern Europe, we should make it clear that there is more to it than just saying that we must continue the radical reforms of the market and then believe that we can create high-quality jobs with them.  The cat bites its tail. That will not work. That has nared so far. This has led to the growth of precariousness. That is the point that needs to be discussed. I just cannot accept that you are simply thinking this way: carry on as before, perhaps a little slower. The tension that was also felt here yesterday was made very clear by the Polish Prime Minister. Anyone who has listened carefully has realised that it is not about an EU that is evolving, it is about a Europe of nation states. That is something else. I would ask you, in your responsibility as President of the European Union, to counteract this for the coming weeks and months. Then I ask you the question of migration. What does this mean: a deal is a deal and we have six to eight weeks? What does that mean? After six to eight weeks, is the Union prepared to pat Turkey on the fingers and say what you are doing in south-eastern Turkey, that is not possible? Is it not acceptable for us to accept that you are waging an aggressive fight against people, against civilians, in a part of this country, in the reduction of the number of refugees?  For example, they could provide a very specific action, a small piece of the puzzle, also for combating the causes of flight. For example, by taking the warlords the sources of money. Finally, by monitoring trade in raw materials as it has actually been agreed by the OSCE. Then, during your Presidency, let us start negotiations on the regulation on raw materials for conflict and quickly reach an agreement. Parliament has already laid very good foundations for this.  Please also set more ambitious targets for the fight against climate change. You also have the opportunity to do so, you have the opportunity and you have the support of Parliament on this point. One final question. I do not want to be rude, but I have to ask them: what are you going to do with the results of the referendum on the agreement with Ukraine? You as President of the European Union, when the majority of citizens in their country ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Mr Rutte, welcome to our Parliament. I often hear you say that the EU does not really need a vision, but it does need results. I ask you one question: "Would you ever have become Prime Minister of the Netherlands if you did not have a vision for your future?" I don't think so. If Europe is now in serious trouble, it is precisely because of a lack of vision. We are creating a monetary union without a fiscal and a social Union. That can't work. We are creating a Union with free movement without a common asylum, migration and border policy. This may not work and that shows that there is a lack of vision rather than a lack of results. There are very important Dutch citizens in the European Union: Frans Timmermans is there, the highest official is a Dutchman, you are a Dutchman, the head of the Eurogroup is a Dutchman. And what kind of vision do I hear? Jeroen Dijsselbloem says: "Forget Schengen, we need a mini-Schengen." And when I hear your comparison between the European Union and the Roman Empire, I think this view may be wrong. Anyway, you're right. Let's talk about results. Will it be under the Dutch Presidency that Schengen will fall apart? Without a well-functioning registration and a distribution schedule, it will not work. I know that the challenge is very great and I hear you say that this is a priority for you, but results are now needed in this area. Will it be under the Dutch presidency that one of the largest countries leaves the EU? We have already discussed it and I will not say more about it. Will it be during the Dutch Presidency that the EU-Ukraine agreement be shot down? I expect you, as Prime Minister of the Netherlands, to stick your neck out to win that campaign and not just play D66 or GroenLinks. You have a responsibility there, Mr. Rutte.  We need results. You have listed COP21. That is also very important. I note that an agreement has been reached there to limit global warming to a maximum of two degrees and, if possible, to one and a half degrees. This means that Europe must revise its objectives because all our legislation is aimed at the two-degree target. That's where work is needed, and I expect you to do it.  Finally, I will use my last minute to talk about something you have not mentioned. The Netherlands will not be a European champion in football this year. But the Netherlands is a European champion in another area that you have not mentioned and that is tax avoidance. There are others who compete for this title, but the Dutch may be European champions in this field.  I see that Portuguese companies that do not have any activity in the Netherlands are moving to your country in a 'legal' or totally artificial way. I see that Lithuania's largest supermarket chain, called Maxima, is moving to the Netherlands, which has no activity in your country. How long will the Netherlands be considered a team player by the other 27 Member States if the Netherlands continues to steal money from its neighbours? I find this totally unacceptable. I hear nothing of your priorities for a more common approach to business taxation. The Commission has taken a number of initiatives in this area, but you are not saying anything about them. This means that the Netherlands has no interest in this. By the way, I've visited you several times. I have seen Eric Wiebes, I have heard Dijsselbloem and nothing has been said about that. You keep playing against the others and you are certainly not alone, but this game must be stopped.

name: David BORRELLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Dutch Government has set out three principles underlying its action over the next six months: focusing on the essentials, innovative growth and jobs, connecting institutions and citizens. Now a Europe capable of focusing on the essentials is a Europe capable of governing the fundamental variable of political action: time. yes, the time, the time that requires us to act quickly to stop climate change. Europe faces the challenge of two major reforms. The one for a circular economy and the one for the reduction of CO2 emissions. The circular economy can become a real engine for changing the European economic model, but it must be adequately supported to express this strength and balanced with all economic and social actors, in particular European SMEs, who will have to adapt to this transformation. Time, what is too often lacking to save the many lives of desperate people trying to reach our shores. The creation of a European Border Guard and a strategy that will be able to implement the relocation mechanism in practice is therefore welcome as soon as possible. The time to prevent two generations, those of the over-50s and the distrusted young people, from being permanently excluded from the labour market. We are calling for innovative growth, driven by the strategy for a digital single market, but also participatory growth that puts citizenship income at the centre. It is clear that your Presidency is at a difficult time. You will have to make good use of the instruments of a good European Presidency, namely: the ability to mediate, to bring the outstanding legislative dossiers to a successful conclusion, to be flexible in order to be ready in the face of unforeseen emergencies. However, it will be necessary to be able to act in the interests of all the citizens of the Union, not just those who belong to this or that latitude. Trade-driven liberalism, like the one some countries would like, is not sustainable unless it is accompanied by a strong regulatory framework on made in and trade defence instruments. But there is no trace of the unblocking of these dossiers in the programme of the Dutch Presidency, which, on the other hand, looks at the issue of WTO recognition for China. It is no longer time to decline Europe's priorities by country. What is needed today is a unity of purpose in a Europe that is increasingly spreading between economic and political blocs with different vocations. The evaluation of the semester at your helm will be done on this, good work.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. I congratulate Mr Juncker on this new President of the Council of Ministers: a true executor of EU policy, a pragmatist with no vision. A president who has proved himself not to shy away from throwing elderly people out of the care home, to put the sick on the street, and then to fill the vacant buildings with the warm welcome welcomed migrants. A grey cog in the EU machine of evil, which wishes Muslims a happy Ramadan but is silent when his friends in Cologne's Station Square sexually assault hundreds of women. It is nice to have such a president, who is only too happy to pay billions to Brussels, send billions to corrupt countries such as Greece and Ukraine and contribute to the billions that are disappearing into the pockets of ankara's beast. The Netherlands has drawn up a list of priorities. It wants an innovative Union, a Union that is limited to the main issues, a Union that connects. And do you know what this means? More European Union, more banking union, more tax union, more Union in external border security, more Union in energy supply, more Union in the accession of corrupt countries, more Union in bringing in refugees, more Union in the depletion of pension funds and more Union in plundering savings accounts for bankrupt banks. So what result can we expect from this 62 million Dutch Presidency? More European Union. But also an even wider gap between politicians and citizens, who want to go in a completely different direction, an even bigger economic mess in the Member States, which are bursting socially and financially under the pressure of millions of unemployable and unintegrable migrants, yet more disruption of thousands of lives of women who have been sexually assaulted and raped by testosterone bombs from Muslim countries and, above all, more Islamic culture. And I mean honor killings, female circumcision, gang rape, Jew hatred, beheadings, stonings and attacks. Because for the road watchers under my ear, since 11 September 2001 there have been more than 22 000 Islamist attacks with more than 125 000 dead.  That is why I have the following proposal for Mr Rutte: stop hanging around here. Return to The Hague as soon as possible, pre-emptively lock up all male asylum seekers, legalise pepper spray so that women can protect themselves, introduce administrative detention for potential terrorists and, above all, close national borders to stop this terror threat. But, Mr Juncker, you don't have to fear all this under this President.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Mr President, I just wanted to ask Mr Rutte why he did not listen to a single word that my colleague here said. Is it because you are frightened that Geert Wilders may take over your position in 2017? I suggest you listen, otherwise you are out the door.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The blue card is to ask questions of the Members who have spoken, not to ask the question to the President of the Commission.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, the Dutch Prime Minister takes over the Presidency of the European Union at a time when more and more citizens feel a disenchantment with the actions of the European elite and indeed the increasing drive of these institutions to interfere in the decisions of sovereign governments, as seen in this house both yesterday and today. In the United Kingdom we await with interest the outcome of our Prime Minister’s renegotiation – a renegotiation much flaunted by him, but underwhelming to most of us. At the core of the EU’s problems is that European leaders are selling their people short, ignoring the need for substantial and radical reform. Mr Rutte, you listed the problems and many had hoped to see a greater willingness to face these concerns head-on under the Dutch Presidency. In a poll published last weekend in the United Kingdom the ‘leave’ campaign was six points ahead. The wave of euroscepticism that abounds – not just in the United Kingdom, but in many other Member States – cannot be ignored forever. In the United Kingdom we look forward to the next six months, not just because of the Dutch Presidency but because of the opportunity for real democratic accountability.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: I am somewhat ashamed to say that it must come from the Belgians to remind you that we speak our mother tongue in this house. Now I know that we Dutch people are very proud that we speak many foreign languages. We even have an expression for this in the Netherlands: "do a Frans Timmermansje". But I think you can be a little more proud of your mother tongue and I will speak to you in Dutch.  I will also thank you in Dutch, Mr Rutte, for starting your speech with the story that there are simply things that you do better together in Europe than as a Member State alone. After the dark brown business card issued by Mr De Graaff here in the Netherlands, I am grateful to you for starting your speech. Because it takes courage in that soured Dutch discussion about Europe to say, "We can't do everything on our own, some things you do better together".  I'll give you another tip: don't mention the "F"-word! And I mean football. I am surrounded here by colleagues who do go to the European Championship. If you are going to draw football parallels with every speech you make over the next six months, I have a very difficult life and my colleagues in this House have a very difficult existence. So maybe it's best not.  You have understood from the reactions of colleagues that your words are weighed. Statements about a mini-Schengen of a Member State or five or six lead to major question marks here. Just as this House expects you to do everything you can to win the Ukraine referendum and perhaps provide clarity on what you are going to do. In the case of a 'yes' it seems clear to me. But what do you do in the case of a "no"?  Then I come to migration, the crux of the discussion. You are talking about sharp reduction here. You are talking in the Netherlands about reducing the inflow to zero. Zero seems unrealistic to me, but I share your ambition to limit this intake, otherwise the support is lost in the municipalities and among the citizens who are now working hard to arrange reception.  My question to you is: what are you going to do in concrete terms? You pride yourself on concrete results. What are your concrete intermediate steps over the next six months to get that done? Do you support the proposals on return, about a coastguard, which the European Commission has made? And what can we pay you for in six months? Good luck!

name: Paul TANG
text: – The Dutch Prime Minister has warned against the 'fat me'. There are plenty of examples where selfishness shoots through and turns into scum, ranging from the middle finger of angry motorists to bonuses for failing bankers. The 'fat me' can also be seen in Europe. There are examples of this: fences against refugees, untaxed profits to tax havens, harrowing working conditions by sham BVs. As president, the Netherlands does not always have the issues to choose from. There are unavoidable issues where a president can only be pragmatic in bringing parties and countries together and turning words into action. Because, indeed, time is running out.  But pragmatism alone will not suffice. We also need a fight against the 'fat me' and for a working Europe. A Europe in which citizens can count on independent judges and free media, not only within our borders but also in Ukraine and Turkey, in which faith or origin does not make anyone suspicious in advance, as Mr de Graaff has just done, in which sovereignty of countries does not become the ability to flicker problems over the fence with the neighbours. The Netherlands has a long tradition of harboring differences in faith and origin. This is a Dutch tradition, Mr. de Graaff, and yet, despite these differences, we know how to work together. In this tradition, the PvdA delegation will also see the Dutch presidency. We very much want to see a Dutch President who understands that Turkey cannot reduce the flow of refugees to zero as long as the Syrian conflict drags on and who understands that refugees must have perspective through work and education. We would like to see a President who is committed to tackling sham schemes and discrimination in the labour market, who is at the forefront of combating tax avoidance. This point has been raised several times. The Netherlands is at least European champion there. And we would like to see a president who will help to develop the Paris agreement. These are choices from man to market, these are choices for a working Europe and against that 'fat me'.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: – As a basketball player, I take note of your comment on football, but we do have one thing in common: we want to achieve results. That is, of course, what Europe is all about. The credibility of the European Union is at stake. There is a lot of discussion, but when it comes to implementation and enforcement, there really is not enough going on. Let the Netherlands reverse and change that.  I am thinking, for example, of human rights and, in particular, religious freedom, Pakistan. We are about to review the system of general tariff preferences for developing countries. It is a country like Pakistan that benefits enormously from this. But what do we see in Pakistan? Minorities such as Hindus, Ahmadis and Christians are systematically oppressed by these so-called blasphemy laws. Even in small incidents, blasphemy is thrown into battle and people disappear into prison, with Mrs Asia Bibi as the most famous victim. She has been given a death sentence!  We need to stop that abuse. The Netherlands must push Pakistan to truly comply with human rights and religious freedom. If this does not happen, this system of tariff preferences for Pakistan will be shelved.  Then there are the refugees: we are, of course, dealing with a major issue within Europe, namely the refugees. How are we going to restore Europe's credibility? We must distribute refugees fairly among all Member States. Solidarity is needed. Put that at the top of the agenda! And let us provide concrete solutions.  Take Calais, a fairly well-organized problem. And what do we see there? For years now thousands of people have been living there who want to move on. Truck drivers are threatened, cabs are pulled open, cargo destroyed. Just take such a concrete example. Now organize an extra summit about that in a few weeks. Then you can achieve concrete results.  And speaking of transport, I am also thinking of a very different but relevant point: the unfair competition of airlines such as Emirates, Easyjet and Qatar Airways. They are subsidized by their states and can therefore fly at dump prices. We can no longer compete with KLM! Now tackle such a point in Europe together with other airlines!  So, Mr President, it is ultimately about honouring, maintaining. Maybe not so sexy, but you get results with that and with that you can restore credibility. Finally, two points. Correct the mistake, Mr Rutte, made during the last Dutch presidency in 2004. That is when the European Union started accession negotiations with Turkey. Stop that! Neither Much of Turkey nor its capital is located in Europe. And besides, we see that there's a police state there. Opponents of the regime awaits either the gummy bat or prison. We have to stop that. Stop turkey's accession! Point two, you rightly said it, Brexit. Make every effort to prevent a Brexit. A Brexit would be disastrous and we must prevent it together. Good luck. Let's build credibility!  [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, you have spoken of the importance of the refugee crisis. At the same time, you propose to stop negotiations with Turkey. I ask you specifically: how do you then see the resolution of the crisis if you exclude a partner like Turkey from this problem? And secondly, what do you think: shouldn't the President, the Prime Minister of the Netherlands have to tell us something about the fact that every country is now making its own border? Basically, Schengen is on the verge of dissolution. I didn't hear the president's position. What do you think?

name: Peter van DALEN
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, we are now getting a combination. Turkey is needed, money is given, EUR 3 billion, and accession negotiations are intensified. In this way, Turkey will then be inseated into the European Union. I don't want that! I would think you were on my side, because it is from a socialist group that I would expect you to be against a police state, against a country like Turkey, where opponents are waiting for the gummy bat or imprisonment! Let us agree with Turkey on an improved partnership, but absolutely not on accession. Don't get started!

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Welcome, Mr. Rutte, it's a pleasure to see you here. You are right to say that citizens are sceptical about the European Union because of too many rules, and they are also very irritating. But, Mr Rutte, that is not why the citizens are turning away from the European Union, they are turning away because they do not see the European Union performing when it comes to the eurozone crisis, the refugee crisis, terror, and so on and so on. But the real problem is not the EU. It is the national governments that, every time, torpedo every solution in an endless series of summits where there is a lot of talk but no action. You want to be pragmatic, I totally agree. So let us stop the theoretical discussions about national sovereignty and produce results. So no cosmetic and symbolic things, but real reforms of the EU. By removing school milk subsidies, we will not tackle the major challenges. So use your good contacts with David Cameron to work together towards a stronger, more decisive Europe, because that convinces the citizens and in both of us countries will be able to vote in the coming year. I'm assuming that both you and Cameron will pull out all the stops to convince people.  Finally, during the Dutch Presidency, the mid-term review of the multianne financial framework takes place and most citizens say: 'What?
