That is the TOTALLY archaic inefficient EU budget, which is fixed for seven years, so that we cannot even respond to unforeseen circumstances, such as the refugee crisis. That is completely absurd. I hear that the European Commission has put the plans for an ambitious reform on ice and I am counting on the Dutch Cabinet to do everything possible for a radical reform of the European budget, because the next opportunity, Mr Rutte, is not until 2026. You have our support for far-reaching reforms for a stronger and more effective Europe.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: – Also, for my part, a warm welcome to Mr Rutte. Unfortunately, the Dutch Presidency presides over the crises. We know Prime Minister Rutte as someone who is averse to vistas and wants to tackle the problems practically. Still, I ask for vision. The crises do not come out of the blue, but have a similar cause.  In recent years, the European Union has been a toy for large companies, not Europe of and for citizens. This became very clear when the citizens of the Netherlands and France voted no to the European Constitution in 2005, but that constitution was pushed through the Treaty of Lisbon. But there is more: the British are becoming an increasingly federal Europe, even though they have made it very clear from accession that they do not want it. And now there is a threat of Brexit. When internal border controls were abolished, no one was told that there would be an asylum policy at European level. I reject the attitude of those Eastern European Member States that do not want to take in asylum seekers. But I do understand that people feel robbed there. Add to this the dictates to Greece, to Portugal and Ireland, while the imbalances in the euro area continue to exist. When the euro was introduced, that was not mentioned. While the Brussels bubble knew full well that the euro would lead to a huge transfer of financial and economic powers.  Mr Rutte, you now have a great opportunity to restore the public's confidence in Europe. And not via a nice app, as Minister Koenders suggested this week, but by finally taking the Dutch electorate seriously when a referendum on the treaty with Ukraine is held in the Netherlands on 6 April. Tell the Dutch voter that you are going to make sure that the treaty with Ukraine does not enter into force if there is sufficient turnout and the majority say no.  A little vision doesn't hurt.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Welcome, Prime Minister Rutte. We hope for a successful Dutch presidency. I would like to start with a quote: "We are committed to strengthening economic growth. We must create jobs in Europe and reduce backlogs." You will probably think: well, that is a bit of our presidency. That was Balkenende, July 1, 2004. In fact, since every presidency, every president has put jobs and growth first . We have to deliver that, and confidence in Europe will be all right.  Perhaps we should remember that this increasing Euroscepticism and the turning away from Europe is because of something else. It's a lack of credibility. Wonderful stories in Brussels or Strasbourg, but in the meantime at home in Berlin, in Paris, in The Hague keep your own story in which you drop off against Brussels or Strasbourg. In this sense, it is nice to hear that you think the European Parliament is so important, because I have not heard you say that very often in The Hague.  Let's go to the credibility problem. Europe has a credibility problem in Greece. As the economy is cutting back, Juncker's investment plan in Brussels has been cut to a minimum amount. In Poland, we have a credibility problem. By talking about values now and talking about a Union of values, but in the meantime continue with Nord Stream, also the Netherlands. In France, by leaving test balloons on mini-Schengen that France doesn't even belong to. What kind of credibility is that? In Portugal, by talking about balanced budgets in Portugal, but in the meantime luring the 20 largest companies to Amsterdam to get their income there without any economic activity. In our neighbouring countries, by talking about reception in the region, but in the meantime cutting back on development cooperation and transferning EUR 0 to the UN Food Programme, which has been promised. Or in the Netherlands by constantly talking about the transfer of sovereignty, which we do not want when it comes to the EU, but in the meantime want to give away tons of sovereignty when it comes to TTIP. That's credibility!  It is time for the Netherlands to show leadership to become truly credible. That means relocating, more than that 50, transferring the money that we promised, stopping Nord Stream 2, really going to a social Europe where we tackle our own trade surplus and not just look at the deficits in the south, but also our surplus in the north, and finally in the Ukraine debate, really campaigning. Not only because the association agreement is a trade agreement, but also because it is important for Ukraine that it is not a political plaything between Russia and Europe. That is a credible Europe. That is the leadership of the Netherlands that we need during this presidency. (The speaker shall respond to a "blue card" question in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, I have a question for my colleague Bas Eickhout. It's about Europe. But what created Europe? Europe was peace and adequate food, food security, and you need farming, family and family farms and a liveable countryside. I have a specific question for Mark Rutte through you. When it comes to the Netherlands and Europe, is it just about market and innovation? The money has to go to the farms. How do you view that, considering that we are on the way to 2020, the common agricultural policy? How do we work together to keep the security? And when it comes to nature policy, the Birds and Habitats Directive, how do we ensure that farmers are not expropriated and that we maintain in Europe the certainty that farmers, family and family farms will continue to exist?

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: "blue card" answer. – Mr Schreijer, always up for a nice agricultural debate. Let me start with the CDA. You have been advocating for years the liberalisation of agricultural policy. Increasingly the market and mainly producing food to export. If then that global price market is farmers, you suddenly want money. What is it, CDA? Liberalisation or indeed agricultural policy at European level? I do not remember, but the CDA has completely lost its way on this issue.  And about nature in the Netherlands: the real reason why farmers are so under duress at the moment is mainly the expansion of roads, business premises and all that kind of business, much more than nature. You should start looking at the right enemy instead of your obsession with Natura 2000.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: – Mr President, as we welcome the Dutch Prime Minister, Mr Rutte, to the hot seat of the six-month revolving Presidency, I would like to take the opportunity to address him. Mr Rutte, I note you are a keen historian because you were quoting Winston Churchill for us this morning, and indeed Mr Verhofstadt backed you up. You are quite right, post-war Churchill did encourage integration, especially between France and Germany, but he made it absolutely clear at all times that the United Kingdom should not be a part of it and I would like you please to acknowledge that. I also very much doubt that, 50 years after his death, Churchill would approve of the club the way it is, because he was a democrat.  This EU faces an existential crisis. Indeed, there is an outbreak of a contagious disease. It is not a new one; the Greeks first came across it a couple of thousand years ago. The virus in its new form began in Denmark in the early 1990s, but was put down with a heavy German hand. There have been a couple of outbreaks in Ireland, but substantial European money again cured the outbreak. But the red alert in 2005, when the contagion swept across the Netherlands and France, frankly has never gone away, and I think now we have simultaneous outbreaks of the disease. In Denmark it now looks to be wholly irreversible and, in my own country, despite decades of our political establishment denying its existence, a recent opinion poll showed that sufferers may now be actually in a majority. What surprised me about your speech, as the Dutch Prime Minister, is that you did not mention the fact that 427 000 of your own citizens have outed themselves in public, declared themselves to be carriers, called a referendum for 6 April and encouraged the rest of the country to join in. I suppose it must be embarrassing for you.  The diagnosis, by the way, will not be popular in this House: the disease is called democracy. People want to have a say on their future. Mr Juncker here says that there will be a continental crisis if the Dutch vote no. Well I’ll drink to that, is all I can say. When you add to that Schengen, and when you add to that people’s utter revulsion at what happened in Cologne, I think that you are going to have a very, very hot time over the course of the next six months.  Whether we can, the peoples of Europe, break this Union between now and the end of June, I do not know. But I will tell you what, we going to have a damn good go.  (Applause from UKIP Group)

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The previous speaker, Nigel Farage, and I are not in the same group, but I can say one thing: of course he is right.  Today, the European Union has reached a negative culmination of all its developments. In the economic sector, in the field of currency, social affairs, labour market, security. Never before has Europe functioned as badly as it does today. Of course, the three anti-EU groups in the House are right: EFDD, ENF and ECR. All the critical voices that are being put forward here are voices of concerns and fears of the citizens across Europe. We had a Europe that worked. A Europe of sovereign states that has gone into a good future here in friendship with each other on an equal footing. But it is only from the path of central government that Europe has taken a negative turn – and strife has entered Europe. I would just like to say: Poland, Hungary, Denmark, the procedure that is now being opened. I do not want to mention the many negative voices of southern Europe towards Germany and Austria in the course of the whole currency crisis. This is not a Europe that can work. This is not a Europe of friendship and a positive future. This is a Europe of bickering and strife. We should correct all the negative developments in the area of the currency. I have nothing against a common currency if it worked. The only thing is that the euro is not working. The euro destroys prosperity, the euro destroys purchasing power, and so the euro should be divided into two zones, perhaps – or a return to national currencies.  It worked. Also the question of Schengen. I would not mind if we could leave borders open. The only fact is: it doesn't work. Organised crime is spilling over into the countries of Western Europe. We have a wave of refugees and a wave of illegal migrants that allow terrorism to come to Europe. Therefore: suspendIng Schengen, pulling up borders again. Of course, Britain is right to hold a referendum now. I maintain that votes should be held in all the Member States, because Europe cannot function if it does not reach people's hearts and brains again, but on the contrary drifts more and more apart.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Today we have seen the presentation of the Dutch Presidency's programme, which is based from the outset on deception. Because, how can you say, Mr President, we are seeing an influx of refugees fleeing bloody wars? It is real that 80% of refugees are not fleeing wars, but are fleeing poverty – they are economic refugees. This, of course, results in a very different policy. We do not need humanitarian aid to make it possible for them to come to Europe better, but we must help these refugees in their home countries so that they have a perspective there, and do not have to flee again. We have not heard anything about this. We have not heard anything about how you intend to maintain security and order in Europe. The events of Cologne must give you something to think about. What do you want to do about Cologne not repeating itself elsewhere in Europe? Schengen and Dublin are de facto out of force. By when do you want to restore order in Europe?

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! The Dutch Presidency is at a time when two important issues will be resolved. Firstly, the European Parliament will, during the Dutch Presidency, develop its position on the revision of the financial perspective. We are aware that, according to the procedures, the first move belongs to the European Commission, but Parliament will not wait and be ready around the month of June, and we therefore draw attention to this and hope that the Dutch Presidency, even if it is not on the programme, will be a partner in these discussions.  Secondly, there is a significant interest in the Dutch Presidency on the issues of cities and urban areas. With great interest, a group of Members dealing with urban issues observes the preparatory work and activities of the Dutch Presidency. I am referring to the urban agenda, but also to the preparation of the Meeting in Amsterdam, which is to end with the 'Amsterdam Pact' document. The announcements and the first draft of this document are very interesting, interesting and show that the Dutch Presidency draws attention to one of the most serious problems of the European Union, namely issues relating to cities and urban areas and the opportunities and problems that exist in this area. We look forward to concrete proposals from the Dutch Presidency on cities.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, the Dutch Presidency will be confronted with the daunting challenge of responding to the refugee crisis and protecting the Schengen area. But you can be sure that if you want European citizens to be united in this great undertaking, you also need to ensure much stronger recovery. Much stronger recovery means, to start with, an ambitious strategy for growth and jobs, updating Europe 2020 and making the best use of the energy transition and the digital revolution. This is definitely needed. But let me say that the single market is important but it is not enough. You need to ensure that the investment plan will be implemented much more swiftly. You also need to tackle the difficult problems of tax avoidance and tax evasion in Europe. We can no longer go on with the unfair competition between multinationals and SMEs, between Member States. We need to support the Commission action plan on tax policy and make sure that we have full transparency, we have country-by-country reporting and we ensure that taxes are paid where profits are made.  But then we also have another problem, namely the euro area. The euro-area crisis is still there. We cannot be mistaken about this. It is still there which means that the problem is not only stability, but bringing convergence upwards – upward social and economic convergence. To do this you need to make sure that all members of the euro area have similar investment conditions. This will depend on completing the banking union and on providing a proper fiscal capacity for the euro area. This is also an important roadmap for the Dutch Presidency to push for.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. It is not difficult today to say what the priorities of the Dutch Presidency should be, because the problems to be solved by the European Union on its way are too much. Of course, we are all aware of which of them today focuses the most attention on the citizens of the Union. This is the need to find a sensible compromise on the immigration crisis – a compromise that will replace the existing policy of forced relocation. We are wiser today about the events of Paris. We know the plight of drivers in the Calais area or do we already know, despite attempts to self-censor the media, what happened on New Year's Eve in Cologne and other European cities. After all, it is worth using these experiences. I would also like to say to our Dutch partners that one thing in the labour market certainly does not have to worry about, although probably after yesterday's debate in this House they already know this – Polish democracy, Prime Minister, is doing great.

name: Johannes Cornelis van BAALEN
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome the Dutch Presidency and I will continue now in Dutch, my own language. It is vital that we stay sober and that we defuse the refugee crisis. This is, however, based on the law on humanity towards those who have to flee violence and, of course, also in respect of the interests of society that the refugees must take in. And that means that guarding the Schengen external borders is vital.  Because then we can distinguish between genuine asylum seekers and refugees, between people who pretend to be and migrant workers who are not allowed to mingle as asylum seekers or refugees in these large streams. There are other solutions for that.  Mr President, protecting external borders also means making it easier to deal with criminals and terrorists. In the case of open external borders, the state can no longer protect its citizens. The abandoning of Schengen is an economic disaster and that is why we must act. I am sure you will remember all those lorries for the borders. Citizens will no longer be able to travel freely. There has been a lot of talk about Sir Winston Churchill. Churchill looked the enemy in the eye and knew he had to make deals with aggressive states. This means that we must force Putin to respect international law and withdraw from countries where he should not be. In the mea-time mh17 disaster, the Government said "those responsible must come to justice" and we need Britain within the European Union to make that possible. (The speaker shall respond to a "blue card" question in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Protecting the Union's external borders – do you not think that before we look for new instruments, first of all we should continue the policy of combating illegal immigration, combating it at sea and strictly, as we have announced, combating it where the mafia of people smuggling operates? Until now, our actions have been very rachitic, not only naval action, but even diplomatic efforts to obtain a UN mandate on this issue. Do you agree with me?

name: Johannes Cornelis van BAALEN
text: "blue card" answer. – That is what my speech came down to. This means that we will indeed implement the plans that lie with the Commission. If the Dutch Presidency achieves this, it will be a successful presidency!

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: – Welcome Prime Minister. Many Dutch people have lost faith in Europe. That is no wonder, because you said it: "Promise makes debt" and politicians rarely do what they promise. Europe also lacks ideals. Because the only shared value we still seem to have is the euro. And money doesn't make you happy. If you look closely at European policy, you can see that Europe is doing everything for the euro and for the single market. Also The Netherlands! The Netherlands thus looks like a market trader who wants to protect his trade missions and his euro and his money. But Europe is not the market master here, Mr President.  We see that single market and the desire for money in all association agreements and free trade agreements again. That is not Europe's goal, is it? The Prime Minister said that we do not need new ideals, but without ideals you have no vision. How do you know what course to take if you don't know where you want to go? Mr President, I have no idea where this Dutch Presidency wants to go. Because if you look at the concrete plans and the concrete promises that have been made to us over the past week, for example, the only one who was very clear is Minister Van Dam, who said that 'animal welfare is a high priority for the Dutch Presidency'.  But what will the Netherlands do? Wouldn't it be nice if that were made quite clear? Wouldn't it be nice if the Netherlands ensured that romanian stray dogs were no longer killed and persecuted? That there will be an end to the unsedated castration of pigs and that the long animal transports will be shortened? Mr President, that would be very nice.  Do as you promise and put an end to the suffering of animals.  I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: – Mr President, we can only wish the Prime Minister well for this Presidency because Europe faces several challenges. I would like to draw to his attention that the issue of economic and monetary union must stay on the table of priorities. I can only warn you, Prime Minister, that the euro crisis is not over but is only contained by the ECB’s actions. If we have another economic challenge at international level, the instability could come back. We have the Five Presidents’ Report, which has never been seriously discussed in the Council. So something you could do is put this report on the table, because this table is not only about a common deposit insurance. It is much more. We know that we have to integrate further to make the euro work. Please use your Presidency to tackle these challenges. Finally, I agree with what several Members have said. In order to stabilise the belief and secure the trust of the people we cannot afford one-sidedness. We should no longer speak simply about less regulation and the common market. Making achievements in that direction is important in order to have better regulation and the chance of a common market, but we must also be effective when it comes to Europe’s values of social justice, environmental protection and democracy. So please do not be one-sided, but serve everybody who has doubts about the state of Europe.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Welcome to the European Parliament, the Dutch Presidency. It will be a very interesting six months ahead of you. One of the topics will be the referendum on the Association Agreement with Ukraine – very interesting given that the agreement starts in January already. Mr Juncker, with the threat of crisis hanging over him, is urging Dutch voters not to vote against the agreement as it could open the doors to a continental crisis, according to Juncker. What a fantastic attitude towards democracy to call on the voters of the Netherlands how to vote from the EU.  Immigration will also be a hot topic. Sweden and the Netherlands are quite similar. Finally, in Sweden, the government has realised that border controls needed to be reintroduced. What is the state of your country, with a forecast of 90,000 new arrivals in 2016? It has developed into a contest between elite politicians in this House about who is most kind-hearted on the issue of immigration, but none of you take responsibility for the development and impact it has in your home countries.  What is the future, for example, for the european Union. Netherlands and Sweden? We have many debates all the time on job creation for European citizens. So how is it possible to deliver lies about creating jobs for all new arrivals when we are not even capable of creating jobs for our own people?  (The speaker agreed to answer a question ("blue card") in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Olaf STUGER
text: "blue card" question. Mr Lundgren has briefly mentioned the referendum, and through his words I still hear a little fear as to whether that will end well. At the moment, the camp of 'no' voters is prepared to do only one thing to motivate the people of the Netherlands to vote no and that is to put Mr Juncker's face on the posters. That in itself should be enough, then the Netherlands knows where it is. But underneath that we can still, and I am very briefly, say how he conducts his politics, namely, with a small number of decisions, making things so complex that we can't go back. Is that, Mr. Lundgren, that might give you a little comfort?

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: answer ("blue card"). Of course, the EU will try, with what it can, to influence the citizens of the Netherlands to vote as they wish. That is the development we have seen getting worse and worse all the time. It is a development that is not in line with democracy and I believe that it should stop. The EU should not interfere and try to control how Member States vote on issues relating to their own countries.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President of the Netherlands, I shall begin my speech by apologising to you. I am sorry because you are starting here today with your government and with your members this semester and you see such a spectacle. There is a Europe that is telling you, that everyone here is telling you what to do, Europe telling you what to do, and there will be fifty of us in here. That is to say, this is the Europe that is concerned about the next Six Months of the Netherlands. And that's something that doesn't work. While you were talking, I saw women wearing lipstick, who obviously looks at her mobile phone, who thinks about her cabbage, who perhaps has coffee out here who drinks, but is not worrying about Europe's real problems. So I would advise you to do this: in Italy there is a film called "Quo vado", which made the record of receipts, made by a gentleman named Checco Zalone, and in fact his name is Luca Medici, and by the director Nunziante, who speaks of the flaws of the Italian reforms putting them in a joking tone, but who has made it clear exactly how Italy works. Do it yourself, I invite Zalone to do the same thing about Europe and you watch this film, because you will understand how so often all politicians talk, the rulers talk, but then they do exactly the opposite of what they say and people are not stupid. I am a mayor of an Italian town, but ordinary people – not here who seem to be on Mars, it feels like they are on Mars here – ordinary people want concrete solutions. It seems to be like in those construction sites on the highway where it says "We work for you" and one arrives on the highway, there are kilometers of queue and in the construction site either there is no one or there are two people who run two buckets. This is today's Europe. As with illegal immigrants, but can we say months ago 'we will stop tens of thousands of illegal immigrants' and after months we have sorted two hundred illegal immigrants? But is this the Europe that works? This is the Europe that is not working! This is a Europe of failures! So I wish you the magic wand to solve some problems.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, you are taking over the presidency of the Council at a critical juncture. Many believe that 2016 is the year of all dangers for the European Union. We are talking about the risk of an explosion because of the possible exit of the United Kingdom, but also because the interests of the Member States have never been so divergent between them. And above all, as you alluded to, people are increasingly refusing to enslave themselves to this Euro-globalist super-state that has been being built on them little by little for 60 years and which they are increasingly living as a shackle. This Europe is coming to the end of its contradictions, and one of them is to ensure that in Brussels, governments come to say and do things very different from what the peoples elected them for. For example, your own government, Mr President, was proposing, not two months ago, a geographical and regulatory tightening of the Schengen area. But today, you're going to have to defend exactly the opposite. And Slovakia, which will follow suit, will go in the same direction, while today it is challenging in the Court of Justice the quota of migrants that one would like to impose on it. There must be a time when we will have to choose: either to serve the peoples, or to serve the "European Union" institution, which they are increasingly disavowing.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Council, Parliament expects the Dutch Presidency to place the tax reform of multinational companies very high on its agenda.  For years, multinationals have been able to compete with tax between our states in order, in many cases, not to pay almost all of the taxes normally earned for the profits they made in Europe. All our Member States have played this little game, in which the Netherlands has been particularly effective. That time is over, as is the time of bank secrecy, and for the same reason. Our public opinion can no longer stand it. That is why the G20, the OECD, the European Commission, whose efforts I welcome, and Parliament have opened up the whole dossier with a simple philosophy on our part: yes to tax competition, but let us now apply to taxation the principles and rules that we apply in all other areas of the Union , and I know that the Netherlands is particularly keen on it - fairness, transparency and loyalty, whereas today, in this area, darkness, disloyalty and injustice prevail.  We must act at two levels: at EU level, it is a question of agreeing on a common definition of taxable benefit, and then we can compete fairly on rates, as we have done for 40 years for VAT. At the global level, we need to agree with each other and with our partners on the OECD recommendations. Starting next week, the European Commission will adopt a comprehensive package on this issue. We expect the Dutch Presidency to be able to reach a political agreement before the end of June, and we also expect the cooperation we hope for from it in the committee that I have the honour of chairing in the European Parliament.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the What does the Dutch Presidency want? I want to focus on a few aspects of the Committee on Home Affairs. You want a Council position on the European Border and Coast Guard, and cooperation with third countries is also important to you. But are you really striving for European solutions, or is it the old wine in new bottles? Border and Coast Guard. Yes, our external borders are European borders. Improved border control, in compliance with humanitarian and international obligations, is a shared European responsibility. But what exactly will be the task for the states without an external border in the future? After joint control comes the shared responsibility for arriving refugees. I have so far lacked clear and binding statements. The third countries: do you want to support countries of origin and transit so that they can take in people or offer them a perspective and thus reduce the number of refugees? Or do you seriously want to develop the number of refugees arriving in Europe against zero, for example in cooperation with Turkey? That would be denial of one's own responsibility and foreclosure with visibly catastrophic consequences. There are reports of violations of the ban on deportation, arbitrary detentions and even repatriations to Syria. I expect your Presidency to send out clear signals for a responsible refugee policy inside and outside the EU. Political leadership is needed in the Council. Get it done, then we'll support you! And, Mr Rutte, a general remark: Europe is relevant to people's everyday lives, but this is not always clearly stated in the Member States. (The speaker refused to answer a question about the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: – Dear Prime Minister Rutte, ladies and gentlemen, put your feet on the ground and do not blindly take flight forward. Successive crises have only increased disillusionment and distrust of European cooperation. And frankly, you can't blame people. To keep calling blindly for 'more Europe' is by no means the solution. "Europe where necessary, national (and I would like to add regionally) where possible" is the motto of the Dutch Presidency. This is the only correct attitude. Not pretending that Europe is the solution to everything, but showing the necessary modesty. An open debate, without taboos. In Flanders, the Dutch are known for this. This is the only way european cooperation can demonstrate its relevance. (The speaker shall respond to a "blue card" question in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question. – You said that less Europe is needed. I will tell you that yesterday the first asylum seeker has been freeze to death in Lapland. More and more asylum seekers are coming from the eastern border, from Russia. Corrupt people have collected payments. Does this border control not require more Europe – you categorically say that less Europe is needed – in order to save lives?

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: "blue card" answer. No, what I have said is 'Europe where necessary and national where possible'. Certainly in the refugee crisis there is indeed a role for Europe, certainly, among other things, the stronger control at the external borders is something that we will only be able to do something about with strong European cooperation. But that does not mean that we will always have to have a European solution for any problem. That's what I said.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Mr President, you both know this and you say it all the time, the challenges have never been so great: the question of the economy and jobs, of course, the migrant crisis, the refugee crisis, the terrorists, the destabilization of the world, Syria, Libya, and all this at the doorstep of our European Union. In the face of these crises and challenges, European citizens have a right to expect their European political leaders to show courage, will and determination, take decisions, stick to them and finally govern effectively. But what do we have in front of us- apart from the two of us, of course - ? We have a Council that does not make decisions, or so little, and when it makes them, does not respect them. We have a pullback, a governance crisis and a decision-making crisis. We all know what to do. We are talking about Schengen. You will only save and we will save Schengen if we finally make the decision to control our external borders ourselves. This is an example and we can go on for a long time. I ask you and the political leaders to move forward and take decisions, otherwise populism will continue to grow in the European Union.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the Dutch Presidency's programme unfortunately forees the continuation of the same policies that have led the peoples of Europe to the deep crisis. Strengthening repression measures, border controls, fences, i.e. the creation of a 'Fortress Europe' against refugees, and the continuation of the same neoliberal policies of harsh austerity will further exacerbate the humanitarian crisis. That is why we are calling, Prime Minister, on the Dutch Presidency to promote a humanitarian approach to the management of refugees, to promote measures for social development, to combat unemployment and to tackle inequalities in Europe. As far as Turkey is concerned, we insist that the hypocrisy of the European Union, which considers the country a safe destination and insists on strengthening it financially, must stop, at a time when Turkey is not taking any measures to support refugees and continues to violate the human rights of its people every day. With regard to the Energy Union, we expect some of the positions expressed in the European Parliament's report to be implemented, namely to promote measures to combat energy poverty and to exploit the natural gas deposits of the Eastern Mediterranean to enhance the Union's energy security. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Mr Sylikiotis, Turkey certainly does not respect its engagements, nor does Greece guard its border – the external border of the European Union. This is a crisis for the European Union: it is a crisis for the Schengen area, it is going to be a crisis for the euro currency and then it will be a huge crisis for the European Union. We have to stop it now. Do you not think that we have to guard and defend the external borders of the European Union in order to preserve this wonderful organisation for Europeans?

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), "blue card" answer. Mr President, first of all I would like to say that the crisis will not be addressed if we simply expect the Member States at the forefront to manage these problems. The crisis is a problem for the whole Union and countries such as Greece must be supported in order to be able to deal with the serious problems posed by the refugee crisis. As far as Turkey is concerned, I think that the European Union has the mechanisms to impose its policies on Turkey, so that it first respects human rights, respects civil liberties, but also manages the refugee flows that arrive in the country on the basis of a humanitarian approach.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the Prime Minister that in times of Euro-scepticism like ours what is missing for me in his programme are specific measures and policies in order to face in new ways the challenges before us. Our inability to respond to the new challenges in new institutional, political and cultural ways is probably our biggest weakness, which cannot be overcome with old recipes and mere goodwill. We have to abandon and not fall back into our rigid old, much too old and well known, manners. We have to appeal to citizens, groups and nations, to seek and find new paths of dialogue and co-existence.  That is why the Union should without any reluctance count on the contribution of still stateless nations like those I represent here – Scotland, Wales, Catalonia or the country of Valencia. They can definitely bring closeness, enthusiasm and efficiency to the European project. Indeed the future of Europe depends not on each being apparently innovative but on each being really innovative. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Congressman, I'm sorry. You have had some thoughts about the new challenges, and I agree with the ones you are evicting. However, I respectfully ask what you think of the new phenomenon that, if we draw one or two more fences here towards Eastern Europe, whether it is the German border, the Austrian border, the Border with Slovenia, the Croatian border, then what challenges will we face in the Balkans, where there are otherwise non-EU member states, but where refugees will build up?

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: blue-card answer. – I do not think these are new challenges. These are also very old challenges, because the problem of immigration is a very old problem in Europe. We have to solve these problems in a different way, in a new way. That is what I propose.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I must warn all my fellow Members that from now on it is no longer possible to accept the blue cards because we are twenty minutes late and a great many speakers have been scheduled.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: – Mr President, the rape and sexual abuse of women by male Muslim gangs – usually in crowds to protect the perpetrators, and carried out as a punishment for women in public – is now happening in Europe, thanks to Angela Merkel’s and the EU’s policies. It has been happening in Muslim countries for years. Amongst the migrants that we have waved through into Europe, there will be fundamentalist Islamics and some Daesh supporters, and we are going to see more of this behaviour. In the North of England over the last twenty years, groups of Pakistani men have subversively and systematically raped young white girls, and some have been convicted, while some Labour-run councils have turned blind eyes to these crimes for the fear of rocking the multiculturalism boat – and that is according to one of their own MPs. Every person in this Chamber and every UK politician should stand up against this and put women and children first and forget their own politics.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Prime Minister! Am I going to tell you something new by saying that the citizens of Europe want to know what you personally want and the Dutch Presidency, and thus the European Union, to do about the growing influx of migrants? I'm asking you to answer that question. I do not want to make the mistake of asking you and answering it, but we are waiting for your answer to this question. We are also waiting for your answer on how long the silence in the European Union will last on The Black Night of Europe, 31 December 2015, with everything that has happened in Cologne. Do you wish to explore this and even address the growing violence against women by migrants? And do you want to address the situation of lorry drivers in Calais? Do you wish to find a solution to this? I look forward to your answers.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: – Mr President, Mr President-in-Office Rutte, welcome to Parliament on a difficult and difficult time for Europe. It is up to you to take the witness at a time when Europe is experiencing some kind of difficulties, which you have not stopped describing. Undoubtedly, the biggest challenge is the refugee crisis. The channeling of migration flows is an objective that requires a complex response and will not be solved without addressing the causes of the migration flow. We must also provide an effective response to contain and manage the flow of refugees from Syria, ensuring in their management a correct balance between the different Member States. Responses to this challenge must be addressed from a common and European perspective. During this Presidency we will also have to fight the call for themselves 'Islamic State' both outside and within our borders.  But providing an adequate response to these challenges must not be a closing of one of the Union's precious achievements: Schengen — the free movement of people and goods, and the elimination of internal borders. We cannot allow them to damage the foundations of the European project, and in this case President Juncker's repeated warnings must be heeded. Let us continue him, because, in our view, he is in possession of a truth that affects us all.  The current geopolitical framework of the European Union and its Member States is defined by increasing instability and, in these circumstances, the 2016 European Council will analyse the work done to renew the overall foreign and security policy strategy.  Mr President, you talked about the economy and talked about important things. I believe that the mention of the development of economic and monetary union, and in particular also the establishment of capital union, is also very important. Spain is strongly committed to its position in the European Deposit Guarantee Scheme, where it has a firm position and also a European character.  We don't have much time, Mr. President. Simply count on Spain in a loyal and constructive way so that this crisis, in which we have multiple problems, we can take advantage of it and it is an opportunity.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his I agree with you that Europe must focus on the key elements of policy. This undoubtedly includes trade policy. In your Presidency, we certainly have the opportunity to keep the traffic lights on green for fair trade policy – in two directions. On the one hand, on strengthening development in less developed countries. You got off to a good start with the major conference on global value chains in Amsterdam, and we must continue to do so.  We will have the question of revising the generalised tariff preferences during your Presidency. We must also look more precisely at the fact that we are strengthening precisely where fair value chains are called for, where fair production and compliance with workers' rights and environmental standards are guaranteed. We will also talk about the raw materials for conflict. I hope that together we can ensure that raw materials used in the European Union ensure fair working conditions in their countries of origin, and that is binding. Then there is the other dimension: the question of strengthening our industrial development depends on fair trade policy.  That is why, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, break the deadlock in the Council and make modern trade defence instruments a reality! It is not acceptable that we have been waiting for a Council position since April 2014. We also need a clear perspective on the debate on china's market economy status, so that we can continue to use our trade defence instruments after December 2016 in such a way as to eliminate dumping. Here, too, let us develop a sensible perspective together. I am confident that we can bring fair trade policy forward in your Presidency.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: – Prime Minister, i would like to begin by first and fore If you are only one of the well-targeted priorities: to introduce genuine European Union border controls and to put an end to the possibility for migrants to cross borders – and wherever they still travel in transit – then your Presidency could already be called a success. If you succeed in putting an end to the senseless efforts of some Member States and the European Commission to introduce a quasi-automatic or other similar system of forced realisation for asylum seekers, this would be another step forward and the Presidency would be even more successful. Because from this distribution it makes no sense! Someone has usurped the right, on behalf of the European Union, to decide on the choice of a migrant himself on which Member State to acquire refugee status. Moreover, contrary to his own will and, in the end, this will not prevent these migrants from walking within the European Union, because they will go to the country for which they have paid for and have invited them. And then it can only be stopped by the introduction of internal borders that will crush Schengen. And finally, if you also manage to stop the Nord Stream 2 gas project in your energy priority, then your Presidency would just be great!

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr President, Prime Minister Rutte, I would like to thank mr Rutte for his work on this I have three wishes for your Presidency. I'm at the back of the middle here if they want to see where I am. Three wishes to your Presidency, which also fit with what you have mentioned as priorities. You first said that there is the cost of non-Europe. First of all, I am referring to air transport, because I am a transport politician. There are a great deal of costs, for example because we do not have a single European sky.  There is a problem: Gibraltar is called. Basically, I would very much like you to be able, during your Presidency, to see that we are not leaving out sovereignty issues, because that is another matter – a diplomatic task – but really sees how we can improve people's connections. That is one thing. The second is the Coast Guard. The European Coast Guard. As Guy Verhofstadt has said, this would be urgently needed in order to actually better protect our external borders. As I am at sea, I am committed to maritime policy and the maritime economy. Blue growth is a great potential. The Netherlands has a long coastline. I hope that we will work well together on this and I think we will get good results.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, the deepening of the single market is presented as the panacea of all evils – unemployment, poverty or the absence of growth. It turns out that this deepening, in addition to boosting the attack on state rights, public services and social functions, is one of the driving forces of growing inequalities between Member States – in fact, like common policies, the euro and economic and monetary union, a relentless machine of divergence.  The instrument that could mitigate this divergence or, desirably, contradict it – the European Union budget – has been reduced to poverty, is the lowest ever. There is no idea that the situation could change during the Dutch presidency, although it would be imperative to make a mid-term review, which would substantially increase that budget, especially when it is already understood who the Juncker plan will serve – primarily the major powers and their economic groups.  In a eurozone still mired in the crisis, the problem of the periphery's debts, which are among the largest in the world and have long demonstrated its unsustainability, continues to be ignored. As far as refugees are, the European Union continues to show one of its most inhumane faces.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I agree that migration and international security are at the top of the Dutch Presidency's priorities. After Paris, after Cologne, after the daily bulletin it is certainly the priority of priorities. You said, Mr Rutte, that we need to reduce the number of refugees over the next two months, that the current numbers are unsustainable. Share. The real problem, however, is the external borders. So we must work quickly with the Coast guard and the border guard, make the hotspots work and we must make the conditions of refugees in the countries of first reception livable. Commissioner Kristalina Georgieva also said this recently. If 70% of the children who escaped the Syrian massacre do not go to school in the refugee camps, then if we take away from the younger ones a normal life expectancy, the families move. But you see, Mr Rutte, you will then have to explain well to certain governments and also to certain political parties the difference that there is between these refugees, these families and the illegals, pardons, economic migrants as the politically correct wants. Because he sees the confusion is precisely between this, between refugees and illegal immigrants, which means that among migrants we have 75% male presence in some countries, in others we get to 85, in some cases to 90% of men. This is a problem that we had put under the carpet and that exploded in Cologne. We are facing enormous problems and we are facing them, as you said, during the most dramatic economic crisis of the post-war period. However, we must resolve this situation, otherwise we will not solve the problems of the economic crisis either, because this situation is faltering Schengen and with Schengen the single market. It's a very high price. I would like to close with regret: we could have voted in this plenary on PNR, that is to say the passenger data register, and I hope that we will do so in the next plenary session. I wish you good work and that your pragmatism will guide you.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Mr President, Minister, after reading the programme of the Dutch Presidency, I would like to welcome your Presidency's ambition. But will you be consistent about its budget implications? You cannot ignore the fact that we have just voted on a 2016 budget to the maximum of its flexibilities. So yes, we must realize - if I read you - our security with our civilian and military defence assets and at our borders. But with what credits? So yes, our growth needs EU-funded research projects, but do you know that 86% of good projects are rejected for lack of resources, not accessibility, as you write. So yes, we need to work on the next multi-year financial framework, but we cannot ignore the revision of the current framework, not only because the revision is included in the MFF - a deal is a deal, as you said - but also to continue the fight against youth unemployment, whose commitment credits are suspended for 2016 , to revive European research, which is a condition for growth, to finance our common security measures, and everything I cannot say in a minute.  I will go on to say that when we do not pay EUR 17 billion in bills, flexibility is not enough: we must find new revenue for the Union.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: – Mr President, rarely has there been a tougher time than the EU is facing now, so it is a tough time to hold the Presidency: a security crisis, a migrant crisis, a Europe in need of economic recovery and renegotiations with the UK. But I am an optimist and I think we can overcome these challenges. I am encouraged by the Dutch Presidency’s key proposal to chair a Union that focuses on the essentials. It may not be the most dynamic of aims for a Presidency, but doing less and doing it better, and aiming for simplicity over grand gestures, is the key to good lawmaking and finding the necessary solutions to our collective challenges.  As rapporteur for the migrant relocation mechanism, I encourage a sensible and measured approach to the upcoming proposals for Dublin, the Schengen code, resettlement and security. I hope that this is a Presidency that will also deliver the better regulation for a better Europe that we all seek.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Welcome the Prime Minister from the Netherlands to the European Parliament. As always, I am happy when liberals are in a leading position in Europe. Especially at this time, it is important that we have liberals in heavy positions, because we see a wave of neo-nationalism pouring in over Europe and we know that the recipe for creating conflict, it is more of nationalism and that is economic stagnation. It creates associal contradictions. This makes us set groups against each other. The migration challenge that we face is very much due to the fact that we have not been able to resolve these issues at European level. Because we take the amount of people who come – with the financial capacity we have, we could have handled this responsibly and humanistically.  Instead, today we are talking about building borders around Europe, we are talking about building borders between the EU Member States and that is a direct consequence of neo-nationalism and economic stagnation. I am very hopeful that the Dutch Presidency will be able to guide us through both economic and migration and security policy challenges.

name: András GYÜRK
text: - Prime Minister! My fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. As the people's party leader in parliament's report on the Energy Union, I welcome the fact that forward-looking climate and energy policy is one of the priorities of the Dutch Presidency. I agree that you want to prioritise the achievement of sustainability objectives and the implementation of the tasks arising from the 2015 Paris Climate Summit. At the same time, I think that when we talk about energy policy, we must also talk about protecting the international competitiveness of European industry. European energy-intensive industries are at risk as a result of high energy prices, administrative burdens and inadequate trade policies. That is why I welcome the fact that the Commission is organising a conference in mid-February on the challenges facing energy-intensive industries, and I trust that this meeting will have tangible results. At the same time, I call on the Dutch Presidency, in addition to climate policy, to give due emphasis to industrial and trade policy considerations. A good example of this is the proper management of industries exposed to carbon leakage in the ongoing reform of the emissions trading system. Or, in the longer term, examining the possibility of carbon adjustment at borders. When making trade policy decisions, efforts should be made to ensure that products from third countries which are more competitive than those produced in Europe only because they have to comply with less stringent environmental or e.g. labour protection standards cannot break into european markets. Prime Minister, I would like to thank you for your In my view, only a combination of climate, industrial and trade policy aspects can ensure Europe's economic growth and serve to create additional jobs.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Prime Minister Rutte for an impressive speech with a historical sweep, which reminded us that Churchill was among those who launched the process of European integration, something the current crop of British Conservatives seem to have forgotten. But, Prime Minister, you went on to focus criticism, where it seems that you agree with them, on the alleged problem of excessive regulation that the European Union inflicts on Member States. There are three things wrong with that analysis. First, the Union only ever has legislation if national ministers in the Council have agreed that it is necessary to have common rules. Second, when we get it right, common rules are an exercise in cutting red tape for businesses by having a single set of rules, instead of 28 divergent ones. Third, those rules are about making our market fair. We have common rules to protect consumers, to protect workers, to protect the environment and to ensure fair competition. When we get it right, appropriate regulation is not a burden, but is an asset.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In his history lesson on 9 September 2015, President Juncker enlightened us: refugees and refugees are part of Europe. After the events on New Year's Eve 2015 on Cologne Cathedral Plate, President Juncker also has to relearn – that was a ministle. But I would like to underline a sentence from Junker's history lesson: we need more Europe in our asylum policy. We need a common stringent right of asylum in Europe. For two reasons: if the right to asylum in the EU differs, one will be played off against the other. Accompanying laws have been formed around the asylum laws, which can undermine the primary right of asylum and thus rendie ineffective. I would like to see a strict asylum law, especially for those who really need asylum to survive. We must help the people who need our help most. Prime Minister, you are making a name for yourself in Europe if you tackle and complete the task of a common right of asylum.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: – Mr President, the Netherlands takes over the Presidency of the European Union at a time historic for European integration. We face challenges that will or will not strengthen the European Union's ability to turn difficulties into opportunities and come out stronger after a crisis. In this context, if the Netherlands succeeds in being a mediator in reaching compromises, but has the courage to firmly defend our common European achievements, a decisive step forward will be taken.  In this regard, there are four points: in the area of migration – it is important to go beyond emergency measures. We're talking about long-term ones. It is good that the Presidency is concentrating on the relocation mechanism. But I'd like to hear more about the list of safe countries of origin. The priority must also be the preservation of Schengen and the admission there of countries, such as Bulgaria, which successfully guard the borders.  In the field of counter-terrorism, the main obstacle remains the prudence of countries to cooperate and exchange data. What will the Presidency do to encourage the exchange of information between national security services and European databases? Interoperability is needed, but also mutual trust. The other issue relates to the role and need for greater visibility of the European Counter-Terrorism Coordinator. Does the Presidency intend to take steps in this direction? Two more questions – trafficking in human beings. 2016 is key: the Commission's strategy expires; progress reports and implementation of the Directive in this area. This issue must be clearly distinguished at the same time, but also treated on an equal footing with the other equally scary phenomenon as the fight against migrant smuggling. Finally, I cannot help but share with you, Prime Minister, my disappointment at the failure to include in your programme the only legislative file on gender equality, namely the Women's Directive on company boards. I would like to believe that we will not move away from the final positive decision during your presidency.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Council, the Dutch Presidency begins at a time when, under the Luxembourg Presidency, much has been done on the issue of the fight against terrorism, particularly with the negotiations that have been initiated to get the PNR adopted. A whole aspect - the fight against the financing of terrorism - remains to be cleared. On this subject, I have not heard from you a determination or direction clear enough. Can you tell us what you intend to do under your presidency in this area? In the same way, I imagine that your Presidency will not remain insensitive to the decision that the European Commission has taken on an existing tax system in Belgium. Indeed, in this area, consistent and echoing the work carried out in this European Parliament by the TAXE Committee in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal, it seems to me that much is to be done and done, not only in the European Union as a whole, but also in your country. You could use your Presidency to lead by example, including to respond to the constant demands of this European Parliament to have the country-by-country declaration adopted under good conditions, that is, made public.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the Prime Minister that we know that we are in a very difficult time, we are under pressure, but this pressure can be used as the way finally to get good decisions. I hope, Prime Minister, that good decisions will come from your Presidency in months to come.  Let me mention two areas. Firstly, unlike Mr Lambert, I believe the commitments of your Presidency to tackle the programme of taxation in Europe. Due to work done by the Commission and Parliament, we can make and achieve huge progress in months to come and I hope your finance minister will share the commitment presented at the meeting of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) and will push it through. At the same time I want to remind that the anti-BEPS directive that is currently being prepared by the Commission is only a partial solution to the problem. I would like to ask you to show commitment and dedicated energy to getting support for the CCCTB project in the Council and I hope you will succeed.  More importantly for our citizens, let me talk about migration. On migration we just do not need words and meetings, we need solutions. We have good proposals, we have good tools and we just have to implement them. Let me mention all of them or most of them: protection of the borders, a list of safe countries, treaties with our neighbours, better law enforcement, a repatriation programme and fair sharing of the cost. I would kindly ask you to really act on time. We need a quick solution for a better future, not just meetings, not just declarations, but a solution. I hope you will use your experience and your credibility to secure the necessary agreement in the Council.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i should like to wish the Dutch Presidency every success, with the expectation that it will really be able to build that point of common interest, the point of common European interest on the major issues, starting with the issues of migration, and also be able to ask the Council to be a serious institution, that is to say an institution that does what it has decided to do before the eyes of the citizens in its conclusions. , because europe's credibility is at stake. We are calling for action to be made against the break-up of Schengen, because this is the beginning of further break-ups, the destruction of other milestones in the European Union, as Mr Juncker reminded us this morning. We also ask you, Mr President, to pay particular attention to certain issues in your programme. I start from that of innovation also linked to the research plan. We all know here in this House about the great battles we have had that our multiannual budget has made few qualifying choices. One of them is Horizon. We have invested a lot of resources there because they apply to science, they apply to social challenges, they apply to industry, to competitiveness and to economic recovery. You must, let us say, make an assessment, a simplification, half of this Horizon plan, but also, in my opinion, a large concentration of objectives. Let us not lose one of the few key choices in this European budget and make the most of it. We trust in this work of the Presidency and we will support it.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, I would first like to greet the Dutch Presidency on its programme. It is a very ambitious programme and one that is on the essentially right path. I would just like to highlight two aspects. The first has to do with the issue of refugees and therefore with the problem of migration, and here, frankly, I would like to see a greater commitment by the Dutch Presidency to the creation of a border guard and a coast guard, because I think that is the essential pillar, on the one hand, to defend our borders, but to create also what will be the embryo of a security policy and even a Union defence policy European. If we have this force, which is a partly military force, partly police, working – and unfortunately the results of the December Council were deceiting – I think we can take a big step forward in protecting our borders and defending the status of refugees, and even migration policy for the Union. The second aspect is a more negative aspect and has to do with the issue of international trade. I note that there is no room for Mercosur in the priorities of the Dutch Presidency. Mercosur made its offer to the European Union last year. How can the Dutch Presidency leave behind countries such as Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay? How can there be a bet here, as we see, in the case, for example, of Mexico, in the renegotiation, and whether it is creating the most important commercial space in Latin America, and the EU is completely in paralysis?  This is strange, especially coming from the Dutch Presidency, which has historical relations with Brazil and which has the space of Suriname and the Dutch Antilles right on this front. It is strange that a country with this tradition has forgotten Mercosur.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Prime Minister, you are right: the EU must finally reach its everyday lives, and it must do so positively. European everyday life also means not living in poverty, having a good job and also one from which one can live. In order to dispel people's doubts about Europe, fairness must be the leitmotif of your Presidency. In concrete terms, this means combating poverty, fair mobility of workers and the principle of equal pay for equal work. We need the mobility package as soon as possible, including a revision of the Posting of Workers Directive. The loopholes that allow exploitation and undercutting competition must finally be closed. This also applies to the Digital Single Market. The protection of workers is just as important here, and it must be just as important as economic freedoms. The problems are well known. Go on them! It is important that we continue to inspire the people of Europe with the European project.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Mr. President of the Dutch Government, your presidency comes at a difficult time when Europe is full of worries and facing a crisis inside and out. Expectations are high, and we expect European unity, but also European resolve. We have understood your priorities and, of course, above all, a comprehensive approach to migration and international security. Instability outside the European Union certainly increases security risks including terrorism. You are aware that the events in Paris have intensified concerns about these problems. Strict control of our borders is certainly necessary, and it conditions that you firmly implement the migration package presented by the Commission.  I personally believe that Schengen will survive, but you should take into account that some EU Member States, such as Croatia, from which I come, still stand up to meet the Schengen criteria, and we are talking about its abolition and how it is threatened. It is certainly necessary to establish the preservation of the external border, implement an action plan with Turkey, because it is evident that there is no other solution. I support your second priority, Europe as an innovator and creator of new jobs, and I especially turn here in terms of youth employment. I also support your third priority - sound finance, a strong eurozone. Take care of tax policy. Your activities regarding small and medium-sized enterprises and competitiveness in relation to multinational companies are expected. Your long-term climate and energy policy goal is also clear - therefore, a combination of short- and long-term goals can lead to a good presidency.  I wouldn't want to forget the gender equality you don't mention in your program about women's participation on company boards. I consider it to be one of the most important pillars of society. You may have achieved these criteria in the Netherlands, but obviously in the EU we have not yet achieved this.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - Prime Minister! You have put together an excellent professional programme covering all important issues. "Business as usual" would say, but the situation is not. It is perhaps the biggest crisis in the history of the European Union. The culture and politics of populism and shut-in are on the rise. Europe has become divided again, as if the Berlin Wall never collapsed – Western Europe, Eastern Europe. See, Prime Minister, what is happening in the Eastern European member countries. For these countries, the European Union was once an example and a hope, and today they turn their backs on it and despise fundamental European values. At the same time, millions of Europeans feel that they have been let down by the European Union, that there is not enough political and moral courage in the Union to confront populist governments to defend what we have been building for almost 60 years to defend our fundamental values. What do you say to these citizens, what do you say to them? I am a great admirer of the Netherlands, and I hope with all my heart that you will have the strength and courage to face this challenge.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, both we and Prime Minister Rutte have a lot of important challenges ahead, and we risk forgetting that some of these challenges are more important than others. Prime Minister, your Presidency’s most important challenge will be very fundamental: to keep the Union together. Everything that we have been able to achieve is in some way challenged at a time of many centrifugal powers in the Union and in Europe. Member States that are not following the rules should be forced to stick to the rules, not by making the European Parliament a political court, but by ensuring that we follow the legal procedures. The refugee situation must be dealt with; the well-functioning border controls; an asylum process that we need in order to ensure that everyone can and will take their responsibilities. We need to ensure that the British, when they vote, have every opportunity and every reason to vote in order to stay in the European Union. We all know who would be the most happy ones if Europe is disintegrating, and we have no reason to make those dark forces happy. You need to stick to a strong European Union regarding the challenges we have to the European peace order coming from Russia. A lot of people say that we should go back to business as usual and I can support that, but we cannot do that until business is as usual, and that means that Russia needs to respect European and international laws and agreements. They need to stick to the rules that make it possible to have business as usual.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Prime Minister, reviving growth and employment is, together with the refugee crisis, the Union's main priority. As Mr Juncker said, economic recovery is under way, but it is still insufficient. I welcome the dutch presidency's programme to continue the project of capital market union and the completion of the banking union, starting with the European deposit guarantee scheme. Capital market union and banking union are essential for growth and stability and it should be remembered that risk sharing through capital and credit markets is in itself a means of reducing it. Further steps, if reasoned and balanced, to reduce risk can be examined, but anticipating solutions before and outside the Basel international framework would be unacceptable and counterproductive. Finally, we need to know that, especially in the face of the crisis in emerging markets, the Union must strengthen its domestic demand. Fiscal consolidation must be sustainable and not sink the recovery, and countries with more fiscal space must use it. And the more use they make, the more credible they will be in asking others to respect the rules.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). Mr President, I believe that the Dutch Presidency has significant challenges ahead of it and that it must certainly give priority to the refugee problem. For us it was not and is no surprise that Turkey, once again, has not complied with what has been agreed. Quite rightly, the Commissioner of the European Union, Mr Hahn, also pointed out that Turkey once again does not respect and recognise what has been agreed. But tell me when Turkey has complied with what has been agreed. Is it when Turkey signed the Ankara Protocol on its cyprus obligations which it has so far refused to implement? Is it when, completely ignoring the principles and values of the European Union, it violates human rights not only within Turkey but also outside Turkey and especially in Cyprus? When he maintains an occupying army on European soil? When he has never, ever respected and respected any agreement in the European Parliament? I believe that, also on the refugee issue, the characterisation appropriate to the issue of Turkey in relations with the European Union is attributed in just one word: mockery. It is a mockery of what has been agreed, because while the European Union has approached and opened Chapter 17 for Turkey, Turkey has written what has been agreed in the oldest of its footwear. He didn't respect and didn't recognize anything. If one examines the geography of the region, then one will see Turkey's enormous responsibilities for the refugee crisis. The Turkish-Syrian border is a long way, hundreds of kilometres away, from the Greek coast, and yet Turkey is letting refugees unchecked to get there. This is Turkey: instead of helping to solve the refugee crisis, it is hitting and flattening the Kurds who are the only ones who are actually fighting against terrorism. I will call on the Dutch Presidency not only to press but also to persuade Turkey to fulfil its cyprus obligations towards Cyprus. I will call on the Dutch Presidency to strengthen the President of the Republic of Cyprus, Nicos Anastasiades, and to support his sincere intentions to solve the Cyprus problem. I will ask her to stand and stand even at this late moment in a Country member of the European Union which is being invaded by a country with which we want to cooperate and which we want to consider to be a reliable partner. Turkey – judging by its actions – was not, is not and cannot become a reliable partner of the European Union.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Mr President, the Dutch Presidency has a chance to bring real and positive change on two issues that I would like to highlight. First of all, a continuing development of the Energy Union. Central to this is to ensure continued development of renewable energy sources and linking the electricity market of Europe better and closer, to bring costs down for European citizens and companies. The North Sea offers Europe an unparalleled opportunity to generate 8% of our electricity supply from wind and other renewables by 2030, while at the same time realising savings of EUR 5 to 13 billion a year. In short, I believe the Dutch Presidency should bring the countries surrounding the North Sea together and go for that vision. Finally, I think we need to deliver on the fight against tax fraud. In 2016, Europe needs to deliver on the conclusions of the European Parliament TAXE 1 Committee. The Council especially must now recognise a need for across-the-board country-by-country reporting. We need to fight tax fraud; we need tax justice now.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. The Presidency always has ambitious priorities and then life verifies its real objectives. It seems to me that, firstly, the Presidency will have to deal with the problem of migration and, in particular, the sealing of the European Union's external border. This is a prerequisite for maintaining the free movement of persons and goods, and thus of the common market as a whole, and for maintaining the Schengen area. The potential costs of decommissioning the Schengen area – both for citizens, for businesses and for the transport services sector and many others – have been presented, inter alia, by President Juncker. The second key political issue will be negotiations on the UK and a potential Brexit. The changes negotiated will affect not only the European Union-Uk relationship, but also the future of the Union as a whole. It is important to remember that they are acceptable to all members, all parties and all countries, and not to undermine the foundations on which the European Union is founded, such as the right to social benefits for those who work as migrants in the UK. Thirdly, we must answer the question of what to do next with European climate policy after the COP in Paris. The European Union has the most advanced climate policy, but not everyone shares it. We want to be a leader, but not everyone wants to acknowledge that. After the summit, the time has come to make this policy real, which does not mean that we are not to be ambitious, but that excess ambition will often harm the economy, if only by carbon leakage, which threatens the European Union industry. Fourthly, I would like to draw attention to the need to work on the circular economy (recirculating economy) package, a project that has great potential for significant remodelling of the Union's economy. Fifthly, the review of the Multiannual Financial Framework. The question is, will we maintain the existing rules? Won't there be pressure for irrational changes?

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: – With some of the things you have said, I agree, in particular that Europe must be relevant, that Europe must deliver results, but also that Europe must keep its promises.
