I want to talk about a very important promise. You have spent half a sentence on it, but last year, at the end of 2015, we signed an improbably important climate agreement in Paris, in which the European Commission played a very important role. I do have a question about that. Over the next six months, it will be very important to turn that agreement in Paris, which is ambitious - because we really want to be no more than one and a half degrees - into our own objectives. The objectives we have previously agreed will be insufficient and need to be strengthened. I wonder whether, as the Dutch Presidency (because you do not have such a very good track record on climate) you will have the courage and strength to make these adjustments and to set up an ambitious climate policy.

name: Pavel POC
text: – Prime Minister, you are not the first Presidency on the agenda to force the European Commission to finally set criteria for endocrine disruptors. I am begging you, I hope that you will be the Presidency that will finally help us push this through, because these substances are killing us. They are killing the European population, and I am glad that the environment remains among the big problems of migration and the like. Thank you for that, we will be happy to help you, help us as well. I am terribly satisfied that it is in your will to address the issue of antimicrobial resistance. If we don't solve it, our health systems are going to lose antibiotics, and the pressure that's going to be on them is incredibly enormous. As far as your priority of sound European finances is concerned, Prime Minister, perhaps it would be enough for the practice of mailbox companies and tax agreements to end in holland. All you have to do is start at home.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: – Mr President, Mr Prime Minister, Mr de Grandes spoke on behalf of Spain. I won't be so wea way. I am not going to speak on behalf of a country, but I think I can reproduce here the feeling of a large part of Spanish and European citizenship. And it is the need for us to be able, among all, to solve the great crises that Europe has today. Here we have talked about the refugee crisis, there has been talk of the fight against terrorism, but there are also fundamental issues which, since your Presidency, you will have a great responsibility to resolve. Let's talk about the need to push the social agenda forward. Let us talk about economic reforms to enable fair growth, to enable job creation, and that we can return the missed opportunities to so many people who are waiting for concrete and urgent action from us. Nor do we forget that the policy of equality is fundamental: the policy of equality between men and women — half the European population — the directives which are now blocked in the Council and which you will have a great responsibility to take forward.

name: Clare MOODY
text: – Mr President, Europe represents hope for the future of Britain, whether it is about trade, protecting workers’ rights, the environment, our security or maintaining a powerful voice in the world. Your priorities demonstrate the reason why Britain’s future should be in the EU. I welcome the commitment to delivering fairness in the workplace and the importance of investment into research and innovation as well as the need to teach new skills for the fast-evolving digital economy. Our future lies in a knowledge economy with fairly rewarded and fairly treated workers. The EU’s investment in research provides for new materials for manufacturing, for breakthrough treatments for cancer, and creates jobs in the vibrant digital sector. I look forward to the work of the Dutch Presidency and what it will deliver to reinforce Britain’s place in the EU. (Applause)

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Prime Minister, I welcome the ambitious programme of the Dutch Presidency of the European Union and its ability to choose. These are four priorities, but there are four priorities which, in order to be dealt with with results, involve mobilising all resources and agendas of the European Union. Responding to migration challenges and security threats is a strongly interlinked priority with the confidence of a successful commitment to innovation and job creation. At the same time, innovation and job creation will benefit from the leadership taken in the implementation of the Climate Agenda, approved in Paris, and from the commitment to the energy tradition and the digital revolution. But I would like, Prime Minister, to point out a flaw in the priority of your presidency: trade treaties. The Netherlands has a strong tradition in trade treaties. Progress in the transatlantic partnership and Mercosur was very important. I call for Mercosur to be a priority of the Dutch Presidency.

name: István UJHELYI
text: - Dear Prime Minister, If the Polish Prime Minister, the Hungarian Prime Minister, had given the same responsible speech from that chair yesterday, a few months ago, based on European values, we would be facing fewer problems here in the European Union. I liked the speech, but I still have to ask you something you didn't tell me about. Because I am one – as a Hungarian – a member of the 105 million new EU citizens' communities, I am one of those who is concerned that we are reading nothing for weeks or months other than that the Dutch Presidency is planning to take concrete steps for a two-speed Europe – a Europe of the core and marginalised countries in the party that are sidelined. Mr President, do you plan to take such steps? Because then we're going to be in a very difficult situation. Because instead of some irresponsible, populist Heads of Government in Central and Eastern Europe, they cannot punish these 105 million citizens. Give me an answer to that.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Finally do something about Europe. This was just written to me by my fellow citizen of Slovenia on Twitter.  The beginning of your presidency, Mr Prime Minister, is crucial, perhaps even groundbreaking. It will be up to you where Europe goes, and you have taken over the Presidency in difficult times.  You yourself said that we are running out of time, so I expect you to put your colleagues very clearly before the fact that, without the measures in place, schengen will not be operational, there will be exceptional economic and political damage.  I didn't hear you mention the Western Balkans. In the face of all the difficulties facing the region on the road to the Union, stability and already fragile relations are being greatly 2009, and I call on you to do more to help the region, including on the Macedonian-Greek border. And when I mention the economic damage. We need jobs, we need growth. You'll do a lot by smzing tax fraud and oasis, reducing regulation so that they can take a hard time with small and medium-sized businesses. I wish you the best of luck, but above all very determined leadership!

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: – Mr President, tax fraud by multinationals on a grand scale, social dumping and refugees being treated beyond all principles of fundamental rights: those are the challenges of your Presidency right now, and all those problems cannot be solved at national level – not in the Netherlands, not in Austria, not in Poland. You said you were born in 1967, being part of an optimistic generation, so use your time in the Presidency to work on the willingness of Member States to ensure they do not act selfishly, narrow-mindedly and trying to find solutions at national level. It is absolutely strange to find solutions at national level concerning the refugee crisis. We have to do that all together, and it is your responsibility right now to take this chance again and repeat it to work against tax fraud, social dumping and those national refugee crisis solutions.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President of the Commission. Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is I have been allowed to speak here three times this week in this House. Prime Minister Rutte has been asked so many questions that I think it is appropriate for me to give him my speaking time.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone very much. There have been so many questions that I feel awful for the fact that I can only try in 10 minutes to answer a couple of them, but I can assure you that I made many notes. We will study them carefully, so nothing will be lost. Everything will be studied. Not everything will be taken on board – that will be difficult – but there have been many insights which we will make full use of in making a success of our Presidency.  First of all, thanks to the President of the Commission for his words of encouragement and support. I think one of the issues he highlighted is the question of Schengen and how we proceed with it. There were also questions from Mr Lamberts, from Mr de Grandes Pascual, from Ms Toia and others on this, and this all has to do with the question of how we deal with the refugee crisis in the coming weeks. I think we have to do two things at the same time. We have to make a success of the package, the proposals the Commission put forward on border control, on a voluntary settlement scheme and some of the other proposals, to bring them forward as soon as possible. It will not happen in the next six to eight weeks; we will need more time to do that, whilst at the same time for the next six to eight weeks we have to make sure that we get the current influx of refugees under control.  How should we do this? There were many questions from Ms de Lange, Ms Sippel, Ms Gardini, Mr Rangel, Ms Šuica and many others – Mr Zimmer, Mr Verhofstadt. It is my intention to work, with the Commission and with my colleagues on the Council, very closely with Turkey to make a success of the Turkey-EU agreement. It needs to be seen to deliver in terms of lowering the numbers very considerably in the next six to eight weeks, while at the same time we have to make a success out of the relocation scheme which has been agreed, yes, I know by QMV, at the October Joint Council.  This is what we have to do in the next six to eight weeks, at the same time working on the more fundamental questions of border control, and the more fundamental questions of resettlement, of voluntary settlement, in the future. But we have to make a clear distinction. I believe that everybody wants to keep Schengen on board. Here I would say in reaction to Jean-Claude Juncker and others mentioning this issue that, in my view, what is now happening in Denmark, Sweden and other countries is not about closing Schengen or making sure that Schengen is no longer valid. I think what these countries are doing is trying to deal with the crisis at the moment. It is all temporary. It is not a full closure of these borders, and we have to make sure that we do deliver in the next six to eight weeks so that it does not come to a situation where we have to do more.  I want to thank Mr Weber for his very kind words, for ‘Unterstützung’ (support). Indeed ‘Glaubwürdigkeit’ (credibility) is a key word for the next six months and even beyond. Implementierung und Migration – das sind ja die wichtigen Wörter für die nächsten sechs Monate – und auch Sicherheit und Wirtschaft. And yes, we will work on the free trade agreement with Canada. We will try to push forward the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, and I do believe, along with Mr Weber, that we need this, and also the Ukraine agreement. We need the Ukraine agreement because it is, on the one hand, a free trade agreement, but it also has to do with stability on the borders of the European Union. It is not about pre-accession. That is why I, in the Dutch referendum, will make a clear plea, together with my colleagues, in support of this agreement with Ukraine.  I want to thank Mr Pittella for his very kind words of support. I do agree that in the whole area of the labour mobility package and the Posting of Workers Directive there is a lot we need to do in the next couple of months, and we will try to push this together with the Commission. I think the deeper and fairer market in the European Union will go hand in hand. This is also to Ms Steinruck and so many others who made a point on this. Mr Pittella also asked me about the situation concerning the humanitarian corridor for Syrian refugees, and I can assure him that the Dutch Presidency is continuing the work of previous Presidencies to pursue and further implement the common solutions Europe needs to solve this crisis, and the facilities for the Syrian refugees we need to work on in the region. I believe that is the best humanitarian corridor we can think of. I also want to thank Mr Kamall of the ECR Group for his kind words of support. I agree with him: it is about quality of legislation, not quantity of legislation, and with him and others we will work on the digital single market, the capital markets and the Energy Union. I would like to thank Mr Verhofstadt of the ALDE Group for his kind words of support for the next six months. There is a lot to be done. Of course, on refugees, I am not sure whether a special summit will be the solution but it will certainly be discussed, no doubt at a level of the European Council. I would also like to thank Ms Zimmer for her kind words of support. I think she challenged me about this question of whether the European Union is a union of nation states or something else. Here, I would say that as a Union it is clear that we pool sovereignty. That is a clear given, to address the common challenges that Europe faces – the economy, climate, energy, migration and, at the same time, security. But we are more than just an intergovernmental organisation. Europe consists of nation states. They are the foundation of the EU and they are, therefore, I believe, the master of the Treaties, but thank you so much for that challenge and this is indeed an important question. Your question on the referendum of Ukraine and the Netherlands I have already answered. I very much agreed with Mr Borrelli on the question of the circular economy.  Mr Lamberts and many others asked questions on the issue of tax avoidance and how we will deal with that during the Dutch Presidency. There were also questions from Mr Lamassoure, Mr Niedermayer, Mr Kofod and of course Mr Pittella. I can assure you that, during our presidency, the Netherlands wants to play an active role in the fight against tax avoidance by multinationals. It is a focal point for the Netherlands to reach an international agreement on increasing transparency and improving convergence between national tax systems. As we all know, the Commission is expected to present its anti-tax avoidance package, including a directive with measures against tax avoidance, later this month. Mr Pittella referred to the Ferreira—Theurer report. It contains far-reaching and interesting suggestions and recommendations. I think at this stage I would prefer to wait for the tax avoidance package which the Commission intends to present, and then the Council will take a position. And, to respond to the point of Mr Lamassoure, we will try to do this as soon as possible – I am not sure it is possible by June – but indeed as soon as possible to take a view on this very important matter. Mevrouw De Lange, u vroeg mij om vooral te voorkomen dat ik met voetbalmetaforen kom de komende tijd. Ik zal dat doen. Het is al pijnlijk genoeg dat Nederland dadelijk gaat juichen voor de Rode Duivels. Althans, dat zal ik doen.  Ik ben het eens met de heer Tang wanneer hij het heeft over het belang van perspectief voor Syrische vluchtelingen, bijvoorbeeld in Turkije op het gebied van onderwijs en gezondheidszorg.  Ik ben het eens met de heer van Dalen dat we heel scherp moeten letten op de concurrentie uit andere delen van de wereld op het gebied van onze vliegtuigindustrie en dat we zeker moeten weten dat er gelijke concurrentievoorwaarden zijn.  Ik was blij met de zeer pragmatische insteek van mevrouw in 't Veld, die opnieuw, zoals ik ook in het Nederlandse parlement een paar keer merkte, nogal verschilt van de benadering van haar partijleider, de heer Pechtold. Zij stelt een zeer pragmatische aanpak van de problemen in de Europese Unie voor. Dat spreekt mij aan en ik hoop dat zij ook in haar partij nog meer mensen kan overtuigen van deze benadering.  Many asked me about my vision on the European Union, particularly some of your Members. Wir alle wissen, was Helmut Schmidt gesagt hat: „Wer Visionen hat, soll zum Arzt gehen.“ That deals with that point, and I believe it also answers the questions by Ms Hazekamp and Mr de Jong.  Er was een interessante discussie tussen meneer Eickhout en Annie Schriejer-Pierik.  We agree that agriculture and fisheries are of great importance to the EU economy and food security. The challenge will be to feed 9 billion people globally in 2050. Climate policy, smart agriculture, combating food and water waste are all important and prominent issues for the Netherlands Presidency programme. The central element, of course, is the review of the common agriculture policy in 2020. We must take the interests of farmers and food producers to heart. Here I fully agree with Mrs Schreijer-Pierik’s approach on this issue.  I thank Mr Farage, Mr Vilimsky and Mr Voigt for their very critical remarks. I am not sure I will be able to convince them in the next six months about our approach, but I can assure them that I will do my utmost to listen.  Mr Olbrycht asked a question on the Pact of Amsterdam and the position of cities within the European Union. I consider them the engines of innovation, so the Pact of Amsterdam has my full support. We will work on this.  Meneer van Baalen, u vroeg over de vluchtelingencrisis. Een gebalanceerde benadering, ik ben het daar zeer mee eens. We moeten ook precies weten wie er wel en niet mag binnenkomen. Belangrijk is ook een betere bescherming van de buitengrenzen, ook om daarmee te voorkomen dat terreur een kans krijgt en een verdere voet aan de grond zou krijgen binnen de Europese Unie. Ik ben het daar zeer mee eens. Mr Buonanno, I would like to thank you for the film tip. I will certainly try to look at ‘Quo Vado?’ as soon as possible and then see whether it can help us in the Presidency. Mevrouw Van Bossuyt, zeer veel dank voor de ondersteunende woorden. I think I am almost at the end of my time. Again, there are so many others who spoke. I can only tell you I wrote everything down, we will make sure that we make maximum use of all your insights, I look forward to working with all of you over the next six months, and this debate has really fired me up for that relationship between the Dutch holding the Presidency of the Council and this esteemed European Parliament. (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – Thank you for the dutch Presidency priorities presented for the next half-year, but I miss initiatives to combat poverty, especially child poverty in Europe. The fight against child poverty should be one of the main priorities on our social agenda. The paradox is that, at present, in the European Union, the most developed continent, more than one in four children live in poverty, and in many countries poverty is more at risk for children than adults. We urgently need new concrete measures, such as the Children's Guarantee proposed by Parliament, which enables every child to receive free health and childcare, education, decent accommodation and adequate nutrition. This could be a similar measure to the youth employment initiative that is already in place. We in the European Parliament very much hope that we have taken over the helm of the Presidency with the support of the Dutch Presidency, so that the Children's Guarantee with its budget is created as soon as possible. We must all fight poverty together from as young age as possible, so that all children have equal opportunities and are not condemned to poverty.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. Welcome and good luck, Prime Minister. In these six months there are definitive challenges facing the European Union: immigration, terrorism and Brexit in the first place. Only greater cooperation between Member States will offer the necessary breakthrough in the management of migratory flows and refugees. The maintenance of the Schengen area is at risk and the creation of European intelligence is a priority. The reference you made to young people is strategic: a Europe that wants a future must cultivate it in its youth. The Presidency therefore encourages the development of a comprehensive approach to reducing unemployment and social exclusion among young people. We must therefore challenge and achieve the objective of innovation and sustainability in the agricultural sector, in simplifying the CAP, which is one of the priorities of any Presidency that wants to combat food waste and wants to guarantee food security. The European economic fabric of SMEs must also be rebuilt, taking advantage of their resilience to times of recession such as the current ones. The chain of European values must therefore be strengthened, against all radicalisation and terrorism, with more Europe, but also with a Europe that is closer to its citizens. Time is short. Good luck with your work!

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing. I fully agree with what Mr Juncker said. It is true that Europe has recently been facing one crisis after another, or rather one crisis next to another. The economy, migrants, Greece's near-exit, Brexit, advancing terrorism. It is a test time for the European house, but it is also time to prove that our foundations are solid. We must remain united, work together, in a concrete way and close to the citizens of the Union. We have managed to reach an agreement with Greece, we must also find one with Great Britain. It's not by losing pieces on the street that we're going to go far. Just as it is not by cancelling Schengen that we will solve the problem of migrants. Closing borders has a very high economic cost, but not only that, it is not in the spirit of European integration. In order to resolve a crisis that threatens us, we must not take any steps backwards, we must make progress. We must focus on a common immigration policy, we must show solidarity between all of us in the Union and with the non-European countries that need us at the moment.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – Today we have heard fine words from the Dutch Prime Minister about history and the future of Europe, but no concrete plan for the six-month Dutch presidency that has begun. We have heard that refugee flows must be reduced immediately, but no idea how this can be done, nor how the Erdoğan regime will be forced to end its tolerance towards Turkish slave traders who are exploiting the refugee drama in an obscene way. We have also heard good wishes for the European economy and that the agreed rules must be respected. I would remind you that among the agreed provisions are not only the provisions of the Treaties on budgetary discipline, but also the provisions of the Charter of Fundamental Rights on decent living, health protection, social security and others which are systematically violated through austerity policies. Europe needs a change of course before it is too late. We need more solidarity both between European states and within their societies, by strengthening the weakest so that a common path can be achieved. Otherwise the Union will be in danger of collapse and the consequences for its people will then be dramatic.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. In the six months of work that the Dutch Presidency has before it, I hope that it will demonstrate its ability to face the difficult challenges that lie ahead, at such a critical time for the European project itself. It is to be welcomed that one of the priorities of the new Dutch Presidency is the issue of migrants and international security: we need common and effective solutions to resolve the epochal crisis that is affecting our continent. At the same time, however, it is very worrying that equal attention has not been paid to the need to relaunch Europe through the enhancement of European industry and the real economy, within the framework of the completion of the European internal market. It seems that the new Dutch Presidency has not learned any useful lessons after years in which the short-sighted vision of a model of economic development exclusively linked to finance and services prevailed. This does not upset, however, since it is clearly stated in the Presidency's work programme that the issue of china's recognition of market economy status and the consequent de-strengthening of European trade defence instruments, such as anti-dumping instruments, is already decided. That would be a huge blow to European industry.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Europe's current political and economic situation poses a number of challenges to the Dutch Presidency that will require the European Union to take balanced, solidarity-based and wise action, which is why I have become all the more interested in the Presidency's programme. I am pleased that it contains particularly important issues, such as the announcement of simplification measures and the development of the Energy Union. With regard to the former, we have recently adopted a resolution on simplifications in cohesion policy, the introduction of which is a necessary factor for increasing the effectiveness of the impact of cohesion policy. I hope that the Presidency will take into account its recommendations. I was also pleased that the Presidency took as one of its priorities the further development of the Energy Union and the reduction of the UNION's energy dependency. In this respect, I look hope to raise the issue of the construction of Nord Stream 2, the creation of which is contrary to those objectives.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – The Dutch Presidency must take concrete steps to create the Digital Single Market and to implement projects relating to the Energy Union. These two markets will have a positive effect on economic growth and job creation in innovative areas. The Dutch Presidency must actively engage in achieving the objectives of the Energy Union by promoting common rules on the energy market. The EU must take decisive steps to strengthen its energy policy based on competitiveness, sustainability and securing supply. The European Strategic Strategic Investment Fund is a tool in the hands of the Dutch Presidency which must encourage the promotion of investment projects in the modernisation of energy infrastructure, cross-border network connectivity and promote technology technologies that promote energy efficiency. Simplification and uniformity of European digital rules and rules must be the top priority for building the digital market. The Dutch Presidency must focus on the rights of consumers and cross-border digital workers. Further integration of the single market in the internet and strengthening consumer confidence in digital technologies, ensuring security, transparency and confidentiality are issues that need to be taken into account. Consumers should be informed of the use of their data, in particular in the case of services provided in exchange for data.

name: József NAGY
text: writing – The biggest challenge is the creation of an EU border guard that is the only one that can stop illegal migration and restore Schengen free movement. They must create the first permanent armed branch of Brussels to operate on the territories of the Member States at a time when populists are haunted by the loss of sovereignty. Before the REFERENDUM in Great Britain, it may also be about the demise of the EU or, conversely, its future federalisation.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. – The Dutch EU Presidency has the opportunity to address a number of energy and telecommunications impact proposals during its term of office. In the field of telecommunications, a modern regulatory framework for telecommunications companies is needed to strengthen competition, competitiveness and investment in this sector. There is also a need to review the wholesale market for roaming services and to propose a harmonised framework for spectrum allocation, and for eGovernment we need an ambitious and comprehensive action plan. The Dutch Presidency has also set out to contribute to the objectives of the Energy Union to reduce energy dependency and provide affordable energy. Thus, in the coming period, the revision of the Energy Labelling Directive will take place and the proposal to redesign the electricity market aims to increase the flexibility of the energy system and coordinate security of supply policies. Another legislative proposal with an impact on European industry is the revision of the ETS. I stress that we must ensure that the proposed objectives and targets are not met to the detriment of European industry and jobs.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. - A comprehensive approach to migration and international security, Europe's leadership in innovation and job creation, Europe's forward-looking finances and long-term climate and energy policy are well-balanced priorities announced by the Kingdom of the Netherlands for the next 6 months of the EU presidency. Bearing in mind that agriculture and fisheries are vital branches of the European economy and provide certainty for The People of Europe in the supply of quality food, I believe that the Dutch Presidency will put emphasis on a "climate-smart" approach to agriculture and reducing the amount of food wasted.  The challenges of European agricultural policy are reflected in the excessive administrative burden on farmers, so I expect the Dutch Presidency to actively pursue a policy of simplifying the Common Agricultural Policy. I consider it necessary to step up care for small farmers and family farms, as family farms form the basis of the Common Agricultural Policy. I call on the Dutch Presidency to stand up for tackling the problems faced by farmers in the food supply market and to help legisize at European level to combat UTPs.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – Without being make or break for the European Union, the first six months of 2016 could be make and break for current major European policies. Overall, the main challenge is to maintain political coherence. This should be a priority for the Dutch Presidency. The rift between the north and south of the Union can be seen by all. It has been honed by the Eurozone’s governance rules, confirmed by the results of the recent national elections in the south and highlighted by the ongoing spat between the Italian government and the Commission. A rift between the west and the east has now also become palpable. It has been spurred by the immigration crisis but is driven too by a growing disparity in economic structures and different approaches to political methods. These have hitherto been masked by the perceived need to counter Russian ‘expansionism’. Meanwhile, the possibility of a major EU player leaving the Union is further compounding uncertainties. By putting a priority on promoting political cohesion, starting with immigration, the Dutch Presidency could help to lay the basis for an effective consolidation of EU decision making. At present, institutionally, it is probably in the best position to do so.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing – the Dutch Presidency comes at a difficult time. The decisions taken in the coming months will be crucial for a long-term and functional solution to the migration crisis. It is positive that the Netherlands wants to focus on completing the single internal market. On the other hand, I expected a greater emphasis on supporting small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. – Continuation on the path of austerity, rigour, structural reforms, faithful implementation of the Commission's recommendations, further strengthening of coordination mechanisms and economic governance, completion of the banking union, capital markets union, relaunch of securitisation. These are just some of the priorities on the Dutch political agenda, following the disappointing six months of the Luxembourg Presidency. Let us remember that the Netherlands is one of the main culprits of the problems which it is now proclaiming that it wants to solve by calling for compliance with the rules. Those same rules that, with the approval of the European Commission, have systematically violated, such as those on excessive trade surpluses and state aid in the field of taxation. From one of the world's largest tax havens, which has thrived for years on the shoulders of its European partners, I expect nothing more than a 'business as usual' semester, in complete continuity with the excellent work of diplomatic sabotage at any level in the fiscal field carried out by the Juncker Presidency, as well as with the very hard line embodied by its Finance Minister, Mr Dijsselbloem, who has already demonstrated how important they are. , for a Europe of hawks, cooperation, common sense and fairness in crisis management.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – The Dutch Eu Presidency has a crucial role to play in harmonising Member States' positions on refugees, the primary aim being to safeguard the Schengen area. Today, the Schengen area is in danger, and its collapse means the collapse of the Union.  The Dutch Presidency takes office at a time of unprecedented challenges for the EU. Its most important priority, the integrated approach to the issue of migration and international security, is correctly established, but does not sufficiently reflect the urgency of the necessary measures.  We need more ambition. We must recognise the EU's failure to deal with the refugee crisis. We have failed to formulate a common European response to the refugee crisis. We must say bluntly: not all migrants coming to Europe can stay in Europe. We need a clear rule to distinguish between refugees and economic migrants. We have a moral duty to provide protection to refugees in Syria, but we need to identify the economic migrants who need to be directed back to their countries of origin.  The Dublin mechanism must be urgently reviewed on the basis of the EC proposal expected for March. A radical reform of Frontex is needed, leading to the effective protection of the EU's external borders. Thus, by saving the space of free movement, we are preventing the disintegration of our Union.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. – In a brief reading of the Dutch Presidency's programme, we immediately draw attention to the first and main theme entitled "a comprehensive approach to migration and international security", an approach that has all the ingredients it should not have. In a mix of issues and problems that must be properly dealt with in their separate places by their completely different nature, the Dutch Presidency follows the EU's line of putting terrorism and migrants in the same bag, in the same "comprehensive" approach, as the text itself says, intertwined.  The text goes on to say that the EU's external and internal security issue is a matter to be addressed together, sticking the idea of lack of security to the flow of migrants, referring to an "integrated approach to issues as complex as the migration crisis, terrorism and cybersecurity", clearly advocating "common solutions in the areas of justice, security, asylum and migration". The deliberate confusion between migrants and the safety of EU citizens is well-exampleed by the xenophobic and racist nature of EU policies. We are not talking about isolated measures by any EU government. This is the Programme of the Presidency of the Council of the EU, one of the main decision-making bodies of the European Union. Unacceptable.   ***

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Mr President, I would like to speak under the rules concerning conduct in the Chamber. I have been trying to listen to the Dutch Prime Minister’s concluding remarks. It is one thing to cheer or jeer or barrack or heckle during a debate, because that is a democratic interchange of ideas. But what we have had here now is an absolute shambles. I have tried to listen to the Prime Minister above the hubbub of people having conversations with their backs turned. What other Parliament in the world would behave in such a manner and treat a Head of Government with such disrespect?

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you, Mr Batten. I am very grateful to you for your comment.  I share your view, by the way, but perhaps you will start asking your colleagues around you not to speak throughout the debate.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, I am raising a very concerning matter which I know you personally will take deeply to your heart. On Monday, my colleague James Carver raised a point of order here on the EU funding an organisation in Israel called B’Tselem. B’Tselem’s raison d’être is the protection of people from torture and terrorism. Unfortunately, activists in that organisation have now been caught selling the details of Palestinian individuals selling land to Israelis, who have then been tortured and killed. I would urge you to investigate this matter and the use of EU money – otherwise people will regard the EU has having blood on its hands.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I have taken note of that, and we will investigate it.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: I have an announcement to make on the consultation. Following the consultation with the political groups, I wish to put the following proposal to the House for a change to tomorrow’s agenda. The debate on the oral question on the opening of the FTA negotiations with Australia and New Zealand is to be wound up by a resolution to be put to the vote in the February I part—session. Are there any objections?

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, we are against having the vote in February I and, in accordance and in agreement with the co-rapporteurs, Mr Bernd Lange and Mr Daniel Caspary, we would like to propose having the vote in February II. We do not see the necessity of urging things on because only in the Committee we are voting on the resolutions of next week.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: OK, this is your argument. Then I will put to the vote the proposal for February II.  (the proposal was approved)

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the vote.  (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Keith TAYLOR
text: – Madam President, this vote comes down to whether we want to continue fuelling a growing obesity epidemic or whether we want to protect the health of our children and future generations. The Commission has proposed continuing to allow 30% of energy in baby foods to come from sugar. This, I believe, is unacceptable and way above what the World Health Organisation (WHO) recommends. They recommend limiting intake of free sugars to less than 10% of total energy intake and to less than 5% for additional health benefits. So my resolution calls upon the Commission to go back to the drawing board with this proposal and to bring it in line with the WHO recommendations.  So to give all European children a better, healthier future, I urge you all to vote in favour.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Commission. – Madam President, the adoption of the delegated regulation without further delay would put an end to the uncertainty created by the deferral of the date of adoption which the legislator had already set for 20 July 2015. The delegated regulation would set clear rules for operators and enforcement authorities and would enable the manufacturers to anticipate its enforcement, in particular for the labelling requirements. The Commission confirms the commitment already given by its services to consult the European Food Safety Authority in early 2016 on the totality of the compositional requirements for processed cereal-based food and baby food, including with respect to the sugar levels and taking into account the latest scientific evidence. On the basis of EFSA’s advice, the Commission will be able to revise as appropriate the compositional requirements for these foods.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2005 Prum Treaty established new modalities and rules for improving the exchange of information between Member States on strengthening cross-border cooperation. The exchange and sharing of police information between EU countries makes it possible to create a communication and cooperation network that is particularly useful in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime. The Council therefore decided to extend this network of cooperation to Latvia as well, enabling latvia to receive and transmit vehicle registration data. I voted in favour because I believe that the fight against cross-border crime and terrorism are today absolute priorities that require the cooperation and commitment of all.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. ‒ This is very much a procedural matter in which Latvia is included into the Prüm Directive. We abstained on this issue because it is completely up to Latvia if they want to be a part of this Directive.
politicalGroup: The Earl of) Dartmouth Mike Hookem Diane James Margot Parker and Julia Reid (EFDD
partyIdeology: The Earl of) Dartmouth Mike Hookem Diane James Margot Parker and Julia Reid (EFDD

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This is a report on Latvia's access to the Treaty of Prum, which aims to exchange data between countries for the fight against crime. Our position is contrary to the Treaty, because we consider that it does not guarantee data protection and allows law ensuring that law ensuring that different States exchange information without any transparency or possibility of auditing. However, Council Decision 2008/616/JHA lays down a number of criteria relating to data protection, for which States need to complete a questionnaire. Having recently completed Latvia, what is voted on is its access to the new data protection criteria which, although insufficient, improve the initial provisions of the Treaty. For this reason, we abstained in this vote.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia.  The purpose of this text is to approve the Council's proposed enforcement decision authorising Latvia to receive and transmit personal data as part of the automated consultation of vehicle registration data. Firmly opposed to the transmission of personal data of French citizens, I cannot support this report.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the launch of automated exchange of vehicle registration data (ACO) in Latvia as it forms part of the overall framework of cross-border and judicial cooperation between The Member States of the European Union in criminal matters. This improves the exchange of information between the authorities responsible for the prevention and investigation of criminal offences.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This text allows Latvia to receive and transmit personal data. Together with my colleagues at the Front National, we are strongly opposed to this kind of automatic and widespread transmission of data relating to French citizens. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I felt it was appropriate to abstain on this, as the United Kingdom has an opt-out from the relevant legislation. It would be morally questionable for me to cast an affirmative vote on something which does not relate to the United Kingdom in any way.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to launch an automatic exchange of vehicle registration data (EDPD) with Latvia.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have endorsed this positive opinion of Parliament regarding the Council's willingness to authorise, with regard to vehicle registration data, Latvia's participation in the scheme put in place by the Pmo Treaty, which promotes the exchange of data on the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime between the signatory states.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the report on the Council's draft implementation on the launch in Latvia of the automated exchange of vehicle registration data. This is a technical measure confirming Latvia's compliance with the general data protection provisions laid down in Council Decision 2008/615/JHA. This is an important step which I wanted to support and which allows the Baltic country to be included in the system for receiving and transmitting registration data.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. This report is part of the Prum Convention (signed in 2005 by some Member States) on police and judicial cooperation, which emphasizes access to national human identification databases (fingerprints, DNA...) and vehicle registration. In particular, it is voted to authorise the Council to implement its Decision on the establishment of the automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia. The planned assessments and pilot experiences have been validated by the Council. The GUE/NGL Group has traditionally opposed all the agreements contained in the Prum Convention, but since the decision concerns measures to safeguard privacy and data protection, we abstained.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work in this report, which I have supported, for the establishment of automated data exchange on vehicle registration data in Latvia.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on automated vehicle registration data exchanges in Latvia should authorise Latvia, in order to combat terrorism and cross-border crime, to receive and transmit personal data for the purpose of automated consultation of vehicle registration data. I am strongly opposed to the automatic and widespread transmission of personal data of French citizens. Rather, I believe it is essential on a case-by-case basis to engage in cooperation between states, if necessary. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Moraes report dealing with the automated exchange of vehicle registration data between Latvia and the EU is acceptable and without any critical issues, so I wanted to support it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Legislative Resolution on the establishment of automated data exchange with regard to vehicle registration data (DMV) in Latvia. This is a matter of formality, implementing the 'Pr'm Decision' to deepen cross-border cooperation in the field of counter-terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the proposed resolution confirming the Council's position on the proposal for the exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia.  I believe that the mutual exchange of information on vehicles is necessary both for the purpose of preventing or finding the culprits of the latter and for ensuring a higher level of safety on European roads. With proper punishment of the offenders, of course.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I am deeply opposed to any transfer of personal data, especially automatically and generally.  Therefore, I voted against this report.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia is an important step in the fight against international terrorism, allowing for a faster exchange of information between the authorities of the Member States.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The evolution of cross-border cooperation aims to support the fight against terrorism and international crime. We must bear in mind that Europe is also attractive to investors because of the legislative framework that preserves and promotes the exchange of data in order to guarantee greater security for citizens. In order to achieve this objective of cooperation and to continue development in all sectors within a secure framework, the Union must support a system for the most efficient exchange of information, which, in the case of Latvia, has also developed on the basis of Decision 2008/615/JHA. Given that this country has already fully implemented the fundamental principles of data protection in its legislative system, completed the vehicle registration questionnaires and, moreover, on a pilot test, obtained a successful assessment, I believe that it can now provide personal data in accordance with Decision 2008/615/JHA on automatic data exchange. I support the European objective of cooperation and security, and that is why I voted in favour of this report on the launch of the automatic exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour. Simple text of agreement (like others already voted on in recent sessions) on the exchange of information for vehicle registration with Latvia. As in the previous cases, there are no problems.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of the report on the Council's draft implementation on the launch in Latvia of the automated exchange of vehicle registration data. Latvia has successfully completed questionnaires on the exchange of vehicle registration data, including pilot experience with the Netherlands and fully implementing the general data protection provisions set out in Council Decision 2008/615/JHA. In addition, a comprehensive evaluation report summarizing the results of the questionnaire, evaluation visit and pilot experience on data exchange was submitted to the Council, which concluded that Latvia had fully implemented the general provisions on data protection. Therefore, in order to include Latvia in the system for receiving and transmitting this information and data, I voted in favour of the acceptance of this draft implementation.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report which was basically the process by which Latvia would start receiving and sharing data with nations operating within the Prüm Decision. Although opposed to the Prüm Decision which allows exchange of data such as DNA, fingerprints and vehicle registration data, I abstained rather than voted against as this particular procedure was concerned with mere consent to Latvia joining, and therefore concerned their sovereign choice to join.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report so that Latvia can exchange vehicle registration data with other countries after a series of questionnaires and tests. The aim of this, among others, is to allow for a more effective combat against cross-border crime.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the text, which concerns the proposal for a Council implementing decision authorising Latvia to receive and transmit, by automated exchange, vehicle registration data under Council Decision 2008/615/JHA on strengthening cross-border cooperation. These are important measures, especially in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and consider it important to upgrade cross-border cooperation, particularly in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Although the resolution on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of the automated exchange of data on vehicle registrations in Latvia contains positive elements, I am not convinced that possible access to the set of sensitive personal data of citizens is ensured and, in this sense, I have doubts about the positive impact of the resolution. That is why I chose abstention.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council proposal to launch the automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia as I believe it is functional to improve cross-border cooperation in the fight against crime and terrorism.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 The start of this exchange is, in a single market worthy of the name, a simply due act that I cannot but agree with. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Decision 2008/615/JAI on deepening cross-border cooperation substantially incorporates the Treaty of Prüm into the Community legal system, maintaining the objective of stimulating greater cooperation between member states' security forces, in particular through greater exchange of information.  As I have said several times, this exchange of information is essential in the field of security and results and promotes greater mutual trust between Member States. Certain requirements must therefore be respected, in particular the principles of necessity and proportionality.  Therefore, in order to establish the automated exchange of vehicle registration data, each Member State must ensure that data protection standards are implemented. This Council decision correctly authorises the initiation of the automated exchange, since Latvia has implemented it correctly.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The automated exchange of vehicle registration data is in line with the political will for greater cross-border cooperation. Automated data exchange will improve our security and give us the skills we need to better fight terrorism. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – Automated data exchange on vehicle registration data (VRD) is an effective tool in cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime. As Latvia has fulfilled its obligation on the digitalisation and transmission of dactyloscopic data, for the purposes of automated searching of VRD, Latvia should be entitled to receive and supply vehicle registration data.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Council implementing decision aims to authorise Latvia to receive and transmit the automated exchange of vehicle registration data under Council Decision 2008/615/JHA on strengthening cross-border cooperation, especially in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This is a report on Latvia's access to the Treaty of Prum, which aims to exchange data between countries for the fight against crime. Our position is contrary to the Treaty, because we consider that it does not guarantee data protection and allows law ensuring that law ensuring that different States exchange information without any transparency or possibility of auditing. However, Council Decision 2008/616/JHA lays down a number of criteria relating to data protection, for which States need to complete a questionnaire. Having recently completed Latvia, what is voted on is its access to the new data protection criteria which, although insufficient, improve the initial provisions of the Treaty. For this reason, we abstained in this vote.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which is a straightforward procedural vote on a text which has already been adopted by the Council with regards to the exchange of data between Member States on vehicle registration. Because of the provisions within the Treaty of Amsterdam, the Parliament was called to approve the decision, which facilitates better exchange of data between Latvia and the other Member States with regards to vehicles. This type of exchange of data can help authorities better facilitate their fight against terrorism and cross—border crime, and is already used throughout various other Member States.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to strengthen cross-border cooperation in order to combat terrorism and crime. That is why I have approved this text providing for the automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The Commission's proposed decision that this report approves seeks to increase the flow of personal data transfer for automated consultation in the area of vehicle registration. Automatic data transmission is part of a current trend towards deprivation of freedoms in a defined space, under the pretext of a fight against terrorism. However, the latter prospers thanks to the collapse of our borders, the laxity of the judiciary and the lack of resources of the national services in the fight against the networks concerned. The data exchanged will be those of a very large majority of innocent citizens while crime, particularly cross-border, continues to escape widespread surveillance. I am opposed to this counterproductive and liberticidal approach to combating crime and terrorism. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to vehicle registration data in Latvia. Latvia has completed the questionnaire on the protection of personal data as well as the vehicle registration questionnaire. Latvia has also successfully carried out a pilot test with the Netherlands. On the basis of the overall assessment, on 8 October 2015 the Council concluded that Latvia had fully implemented the general data protection provisions.  I believe that these measures can support the fight against terrorism and contribute to better security cooperation between Member States. That's why I support the report.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I believe that there are still legislative gaps and procedural ambiguities with regard to cross-border cooperation in the fight against organised crime and terrorism, as well as with regard to the implementation of the Prum decision and the European standard for the exchange of information.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I am opposed to the automatic and widespread transmission of personal data of French citizens.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims at launching in Latvia the automated exchange on vehicle registration data (DRV) in the context of deepening cross-border cooperation – Prüm Decision (2008/615/JAI) – in the fight against terrorism and crime. The provision of personal data provided for in the context of that decision may not take place until the general data protection provisions are transposed into national law in the territory of the Member States participating in that transmission. The Prüm Convention, signed in May 2005 in Prüm (Germany), between seven Member States – Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, Luxembourg, Spain and the Netherlands – aims to intensify and speed up exchanges of information between authorities. We know that, on the pretext of combating terrorism and crime, the EU has been putting together a surveillance system that reduces citizens' freedoms and guarantees, and which call into question the sovereignty of states with regard to the control and safeguarding of data and information. The aim is to create a supranational structure, which will progressively impose on Member States strategies and actions outside national and democratic control. From the foregoing, we voted against it.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the project concerning the automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia, as it will contribute to cross-border cooperation between law enforcement agencies in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of the automated exchange of vehicle registration data (ACO) in Latvia as legislative gaps and procedural ambiguities remain with regard to cross-border cooperation in the fight against organised crime and terrorism, as well as with regard to the implementation of the Prum decision and the European information exchange standard.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on automated data exchange with regard to vehicle registration data (VRD) in Latvia, as it will strengthen cross-border law-enforcement cooperation in the EU.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. ‒ With today’s vote we authorised Latvia to receive and supply personal data in accordance with the Council Decision regarding Vehicle Registration Data. We favour this decision as it falls in the broader effort to strengthen cooperation among Member States on improving cross-border data exchange, which is crucial for law enforcement authorities in fighting criminal organisations and terrorism.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the automated exchange of data on vehicle registration data (DMV) in Latvia in order to facilitate further integration of Latvia into this area through the EU as a whole.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the technically sound and useful report on the draft Council implementing decision on the automated exchange of vehicle registration data with Latvia. In principle, I am in favour of simplifying and harmonising car registration and transfer within Europe – to the benefit of the citizens.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. This report is part of the Prum Convention (signed in 2005 by some Member States) on police and judicial cooperation, which emphasizes access to national human identification databases (fingerprints, DNA...) and vehicle registration. In particular, it is voted to authorise the Council to implement its Decision on the establishment of the automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia. The planned assessments and pilot experiences have been validated by the Council. The GUE/NGL Group has traditionally opposed all the agreements contained in the Prom Convention but since the decision concerns measures to safeguard privacy and data protection, we have abstained.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I voted in favour of the launch of automated data exchange in Latvia for vehicle registration data. Latvia fully complied with the guidelines of the above-mentioned project and successfully carried out a pilot programme with the Netherlands. Automated data exchange for vehicle registration data is extremely important in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Implementing Decision to authorise Latvia to exchange automated vehicle registration data.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We chose abstention. Although the report relates to the 'Prüm decision' to which we have consistently opposed, this implementing decision has to do with the data protection safeguard measures that should be observed before any exchange of personal data. We have consistently supported substantial data protection measures so that the framework governing each exchange of personal data is that of justice.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on automated data exchange with regard to vehicle registration data (VRD) in Latvia, which approves the Council draft and calls on the Council to notify Parliament if it intends to depart from the text approved by Parliament.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is actually a mere formality since the European Parliament is only consulted. The Council's enforcement decision is to authorize the automated exchange and consultation of personal vehicle registration data in Latvia. I believe that, in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, we must gather all the tools at our disposal to be able to identify threats and track down criminals and terrorists. The exchange of information on vehicle registrations is certainly only a small link, but I believe it is necessary in this fight against those who expect our freedom and security.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that will step up cross-border cooperation in combating terrorism and cross-border crime through the launch of automated data exchange with regard to vehicle registration data.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft implementing decision to initiate automated data exchange from the vehicle register in Latvia, as this strengthens the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, and strengthens cross-border cooperation between The Union Member States. I believe that the exchange of information and data should be swift and effective, and that the quality of information needs to be improved in order to guarantee the principles of security, freedom and justice.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This report authorizes Latvia to receive and transmit personal data. Together with my colleagues at the Front National, we are opposed to this kind of automatic and widespread transmission of data relating to French citizens. I voted against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Claude Moraes' report on the automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia. The Council has taken an enforcement decision and is consulting With Parliament to authorise the automated exchange and consultation of personal vehicle registration data in Latvia. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which allows the automated exchange and consultation of personal data relating to vehicle registration between Latvia and the European Union.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am abstaining on this proposal due to privacy considerations and reservations.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the launch of automated exchange of vehicle registration data (TRD) in Latvia.  I believe that this is a welcome decision that will help Latvian law enforcement authorities and other security authorities to operate more effectively, ensure even better functioning of the data protection system and greater security for the citizens of the European Union.  Data protection and automated exchange of information between the competent authorities of the EU Member States are a very topical topic in the light of last year's events and this is a positive step towards a safer Europe. In order to improve the fight against terrorism and organised crime, it is necessary to ensure the effective exchange of data and information at least within the Union, while respecting the protection of citizens' data and citizens' right to data privacy.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it aims to increase cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime, and following the pilot project in Latvia, evaluations have shown no hindrance to EU data protection standards.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This report is a consent procedure to an EU Council implementing decision, regarding cross-border data exchange with Latvia regarding vehicle registration data. The Council decided through the Decision to authorise Latvia to receive and supply personal data regarding vehicles. The GUE/NGL has been opposed to this Parliament report, since this report is not only on how to safeguard data protection but also on prior to any exchange of personal data. Given that data protection and data exchange are two important considerations I preferred to abstain.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia. This vote is not directed against Latvia. The report endorses the Council's proposed implementation decision to allow Latvia, in order to combat terrorism and cross-border crime, to receive and transmit personal data for the purpose of automated consultation of vehicle registration data. However, I am opposed to the automatic and widespread transmission of personal data of French citizens.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it allows Latvia to receive and transmit personal data. However, I am opposed to this type of automatic and widespread transmission of data relating to French citizens.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I have spoken out against this report which authorises Latvia to receive and transmit personal data as part of the automated consultation of vehicle registration data. The fight against terrorism and cross-border crime must not be at the expense of honest citizens and their individual freedoms, and does not justify the automatic use of their personal data.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This report gives the green light to the implementation of the 'Pr'm Decision' on the fight against crime in the field of automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia, with which we agree, and I voted in favour.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. This is a report on Latvia's access to the Treaty of Prum, which aims to exchange data between countries for the fight against crime. Our position is contrary to the Treaty, because we consider that it does not guarantee data protection and allows law ensuring that law ensuring that different States exchange information without any transparency or possibility of auditing. However, Council Decision 2008/616/JHA lays down a number of criteria relating to data protection, for which States need to complete a questionnaire. Having recently completed Latvia, what is voted on is its access to the new data protection criteria which, although insufficient, improve the initial provisions of the Treaty. For this reason, we abstained in this vote.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I have withered because I do not want to prevent Latvia from exchanging data regarding vehicle registration.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The report on the Council's draft implementing decision on the initiation of automated data exchange from the vehicle register in Latvia shall take particular account of the deepening of cross-border cooperation with a view to countering terrorism and cross-border crime. Automated data exchange aims to strengthen cross-border law enforcement cooperation in the European Union and to apply the Prüm Decision and the European information exchange model. I supported Representative Moraes' report because it covers the exchange of data when criminal events have a cross-border dimension. In such cases, the proposed model may apply only where necessary and proportionate, based on specific circumstances indicating that a criminal offence may be committed.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Strengthening cross-border cooperation is one of the cornerstones of the European Union's integration policy and covers a number of areas, including transport and, in particular, vehicle-related policies. As a Member representing the Republic of Latvia, it was a great honour to be shadow rapporteur for this draft Council implementing decision, especially in view of the potential benefits that this practice will have for both my homeland and partner countries. Automated vehicle registration data exchange will both increase the efficiency of this area in Latvia itself and will contribute to the development of relations with the rest of the EU Member States, as well as – which has recently become more urgent and important than in the past – will stimulate the existence of security within our Union. Each country must make its own progress in this area.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of the automated exchange of vehicle registration data (ACO) in Latvia because I consider it complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report. The Council, in order to combat terrorism and cross-border crime, authorizes Latvia to receive and transmit personal data. This will allow it to automatically access vehicle registration data. The European Parliament had to approve this proposal for a decision to implement the Council. We strongly oppose this because we are against this automatic and widespread transmission of personal data.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch in Latvia of the automated exchange of vehicle registration data. The transmission of personal data can only take place after the implementation of a series of data protection provisions, the verification of which is carried out by means of a questionnaire-based evaluation report, which must be completed by a Member State as soon as it considers that it fulfils the preconditions for the exchange of data in the relevant data category. Latvia completed the data protection questionnaire and the questionnaire on the exchange of vehicle registration data.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important to ensure Latvia's participation in the automated exchange of vehicle registration numbers. This is a step towards greater road safety in Europe.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. In principle, there is no objection to the exchange of vehicle register data with Latvia. However, the relevant data protection regulations must be respected. It is not clear in the report whether this can be guaranteed. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The aim is to allow Latvia to receive and transmit the license plates, personal data, of its police files with those of other Member States. While the legislation contains an issue on data protection and the limits of its use, the flaws in these laws are known. In France, the CNIL was also concerned about this legislation. Most importantly, this file is part of a general trend of criminal and citizen registration. These files are then cross-referenced with passport or other data to determine "profiles" of each citizen. A so-called Big Brother to fight terrorism, an argument that Snowden has largely demonstrated as ineffective. Above all, it is a way of increasing the amount of citizen data to be made available to the United States, a country with which Latvia has a particularly close defence relationship. Given the bellicose nature of the government of this country and its hostility to Russia, our neighbour and partner, it does not seem prudent to me to incite this country to monitor peaceful people. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report authorizes Latvia to receive and transmit personal data. Together with my colleagues at the Front National, we are opposed to automatic and widespread transmission of data relating to French citizens. I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch in Latvia of the automated exchange on vehicle registration data. As the general data protection provisions laid down in Decision 2008/615/JAI have been incorporated into latvian national legislation, latvia may participate in the exchange of such data.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution because I believe Member States’ individual law enforcement authorities require all the tools possible in order to increase the exchange of information and combat crime.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the positive opinion given by the European Parliament to the Council's draft decision on the launch of the automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia. I welcome the conclusive assessment made on Latvia's implementation of the data protection provisions, which are the prerequisite for launching the automated exchanges discussed here. Latvia will now be able to receive and transmit such personal data. This is yet another step in the crucial area of cross-border cooperation in justice and home affairs. With terrorism and crime knowing no borders, we should welcome any deepening of cooperation between Member States to combat these scourges more effectively.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ The proposed Council Implementing Decision aims to authorise Latvia to receive and supply personal data pursuant to Decision 2008/615/JHA from the date of entry into force of the Decision with respect to automated data exchange regarding Vehicle Registration Data. Latvia has completed the questionnaire on data protection and the questionnaire on Vehicle Registration Data (VRD) exchange. It carried out a successful pilot run with the Netherlands. That is why I voted in favour of the report on automated data exchange with regard to vehicle registration data (VRD) in Latvia.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council has submitted a draft implementing decision according to which Latvia complies with the conditions laid down in Council Decision 2008/615/IB on strengthening cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime and intends to authore Latvia to participate in the automated exchange of data on vehicle registration data by receiving and transmitting personal data. Under the Treaty on European Union, the Council is obliged to consult the European Parliament before adopting the decision. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommends that Parliament approve the draft. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This report endorses the Council's proposal to allow Latvia, in order to combat terrorism and cross-border crime, to receive and transmit personal data for the purpose of automated consultation of vehicle registration data. The objective is laudable, but we are opposed to the automatic and widespread transmission of personal data of French citizens.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 In the light of Article 25, 2 of Council Decision 2008/615/JAI of 23 June 2008 on deepening cross-border cooperation, in particular in the field of combating terrorism and cross-border crime, the transmission of personal data under that decision may be carried out only where the general data protection provisions laid down in Chapter 6 of that decision have been incorporated into the national legislation of the territory of the Member States participating in that transmission.  Latvia has complied with article 20 of the Decision and should therefore be empowered to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with Article 12 of Decision 2008/615/JAI.
