For the foregoing, this report has my vote in favour.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report endorses the Council's proposal for an enforcement decision to allow Latvia, in order to combat terrorism and cross-border crime, to receive and transmit personal data for the purpose of automated consultation of vehicle registration data. I am opposed to the automatic and widespread transmission of personal data of French citizens.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which concerns a pilot project carried out by Latvia with the Netherlands regarding the exchange of information regarding vehicles between the two Member States. This project is part of an old Council decision to increase cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime. Following the pilot project in Latvia, evaluations have shown no hindrance to EU data protection standards.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which was intended to approve the Council's enforcement decision authorising the exchange and consultation of personal data relating to vehicle registration in Latvia. The aim is to deepen cross-border cooperation within the framework of the European information exchange model, in particular with a view to combating terrorism and crime.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. The report on the automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia, which has received my support, is part of a standard consultation procedure for the European Parliament.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council proposal on the launch in Latvia of the automated exchange of vehicle registration data in order to improve cross-border cooperation in the fight against crime.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this legislative proposal that will implement methods of combating cross-border crimes, support the data supply in regard to vehicle registration data and advance in initiating a common database of vehicle registration data at a European level.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I abstained because there are gaps in the report and the procedure is still unclear in relation to cross-border cooperation in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. Thus, it is not sufficiently clear how the decision will be implemented.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Latvia has complied with the necessary requirements to join the vehicle registration data exchange data exchange programme, which aims to improve transnational cooperation to combat and prevent terrorism and crime.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 It is now common ground that cross-border crime and terrorism require an effective response from European bodies and Member States. I therefore believe that the launch in Latvia of the automated exchange of vehicle registration data, which it has already experienced with the Netherlands, is a further step, as it can be seen in the list of measures aimed at making European territory safer. I therefore say that I am voting in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒Taking into account the Council's decision to increase border cooperation, in particular in the fight against terrorism and border crime, the personal data collected will not be able to be used until the Member States involved in the collection have introduced provisions to protect them. In order to determine whether data protection complies with a Council decision, an evaluation report should be written based on a survey, field assessment and test. In the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, it is of utmost importance to share information, but it should also be protected. The more countries with positive intentions involved in the prevention of terrorism and other criminal activities, the greater the chance that prevention will occur. Latvia completed a data protection survey, a survey on the exchange of data from the vehicle register and successfully conducted a test test with the Netherlands. On the basis of the overall evaluation, on 8.10.2015, the Council adopted a decision saying that Latvia had successfully applied the provisions of Chapter 6 on data protection. Some countries such as Denmark and Ireland participate in the adoption and application of the proposed act, while the United Kingdom is not obliged to apply the same act.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report endorses the Council's proposal for an enforcement decision to allow Latvia, in order to combat terrorism and cross-border crime, to receive and transmit personal data for the purpose of automated consultation of vehicle registration data. I am opposed to the automatic and widespread transmission of personal data of citizens and I therefore vote against this text which threatens freedoms.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support the Council's draft implementing decision to initiate automated data exchange from the vehicle register in Latvia. This is another decision in a number of forms of cooperation in the field of cross-border information sharing, and is particularly important in terms of joint efforts by Member States to prevent terrorism and cross-border crime. I welcome this green light for Latvia to be able to participate in the provision and receipt of personal data with the stated objectives, as it has met all the requirements regarding the protection of personal data.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I fully support Claude Moraes' report on the Council's draft implementing decision to launch an automated vehicle register data exchange (VRD) in Latvia. According to Article 4 of Annex to Decision 2008/616/JHA, the questionnaire drawn up by the relevant Working Group of the Council of Europe covers any automated data exchange and must be met by a Member State as soon as it believes it meets the requirements for data sharing in the relevant data category.  Latvia completed a data protection questionnaire and on the exchange of data from the vehicle register.  Latvia conducted a successful "pilot run" with the Netherlands. In October 2015, The Council concluded that Latvia fully implemented the general data protection commissions set out in Article 6 of the Regulation. Decisions 2008/615/JHA. Consequently, and for the purpose of automated requesting of vehicle register data, Latvia should be entitled to receive and supply personal data under Article 12 of the Regulation. Decisions 2008/615/JHA.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Latvia, after completing its data protection questionnaire, the vehicle registration data exchange questionnaire (DIV) and conducting a pilot study with the Netherlands, fully complied with the general data protection provisions in accordance with Council Decision 2008/615/JHA. For this reason, in its resolution of 9 July 2015 on the European Safety Agenda, the European Parliament approves the draft Council decision on the launch in Latvia of the automated exchange of vehicle registration data. That is why I voted in favour of this decision.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia. It is indeed an administrative formality, because Parliament is only consulted, but it is an important act in the message we deliver.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 From the adoption of this Council proposal, Latvia is authorised to receive and provide vehicle registration data in the deepening of cross-border cooperation, which is particularly important in the field of combating terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Legislative Resolution on the establishment of automated data exchange with regard to vehicle registration data (DMV) in Latvia. This is a matter of formality, implementing the 'Pr'm Decision' to deepen cross-border cooperation in the field of counter-terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which, in view of the Council's 23 June 2008 decision on deepening cross-border cooperation, in particular to combat terrorism and cross-border crime, and the European Parliament's resolution of 10 October 2013 on strengthening cross-border cooperation in repressive matters in the Union: implementation of the 'Prem decision' and the European model of information exchange, endorses the Council's draft and instructs the President of the European Parliament to pass on Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch in Latvia of the automated exchange on vehicle registration data. In view of the current fight against terrorism and organised crime, the European Union has been forced to strengthen its cross-border cooperation and latvia's contribution to the transmission and reception of personal data with regard to the automated exchange of vehicle registration data is essential, which is why I supported this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to authorise Latvia to receive and transmit vehicle registration data. This text is part of the desire to promote the exchange of information between the Member States of the European Union and to strengthen cross-border cooperation.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This is a report on Latvia's access to the Treaty of Prum, which aims to exchange data between countries for the fight against crime. Our position is contrary to the Treaty, because we consider that it does not guarantee data protection and allows law ensuring that law ensuring that different States exchange information without any transparency or possibility of auditing. However, Council Decision 2008/616/JHA lays down a number of criteria relating to data protection, for which States need to complete a questionnaire. Having recently completed Latvia, what is voted on is its access to the new data protection criteria which, although insufficient, improve the initial provisions of the Treaty. For this reason, we abstained in this vote.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia because it will enable us to take an important step forward in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime. Current circumstances require more efficient cooperation between European and national law enforcement agencies on the exchange of personal data. It is necessary, however, for the Member States concerned to implement certain general provisions so that this transmission can be started. Latvia, following the verification of this condition carried out on the basis of a questionnaire and a pilot project, has shown that it has fully implemented the general provisions and can therefore exchange vehicle registration data, thus making a significant contribution to the prevention of the most serious forms of crime and terrorist activity.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as this does not affect the UK.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I am happy to see that this report passed with such large support in the plenary as it did in the Committee. This report concerns the proposed Council Implementing Decision which aims to authorise the exchange of information of vehicle registration data in Latvia, pursuant to the Prüm Treaty, and I support the intentions of the decision.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ with the implementing decision we approved in Parliament today, Latvia will proceed to an automated exchange system for vehicle registration data. It will thus participate in European cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime. Latvia is only now joining this cooperation, as it was necessary to ensure sufficient protection of personal data and to test the data exchange system itself. I am therefore happy that this country will also be involved in the protection of internal security. In accordance with this Data Exchange Regulation, Latvia will be involved in the cross-border transfer of information on DNA profiles, dactyloscopic data and specific vehicle registration data. It will provide this data, in particular in the context of serious events with a cross-border dimension, in order to prevent terrorist attacks, but also in order to increase cross-border police cooperation. In order to make this cooperation effective, the Latvian Government shall establish a national contact point. Through it, Latvia's police forces will be able to enter into cooperation with neighbouring countries if this is necessary to ensure order in major events of a cross-border nature. In order to ensure security within the Schengen area, all countries need to be involved in the fight against crime. This, too, is one way to strengthen cooperation with each other.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 This is a report on the uncontested consultation procedure in which the Council wishes to inquisi anything from the European Parliament to know whether the exchange of vehicle registration data between Latvia and the other Member States is appropriate.  The legal basis of this decision is the data protection provisions of Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615/JHA (Prüm). The Council prepared a report on the evaluation of data protection measures in Latvia. In doing so, it was derived from data obtained from the questionnaire, the evaluation visit and the test. Thus, the Council concluded that Latvia respects all the provisions of the aforementioned legislation. As the consistency and appropriateness of the exchange of vehicle registration data between Latvia and the Member States was established during the process, I voted in plenary in favour of adopting the report.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Due to the fight against terrorism under Council Decision 2008/615/PUP, the start of automatic data exchange has accelerated and personal data from the vehicle register can be used within the legally defined territory, i.e. member states of the European Union, but the same (personal data) is also required by the protection provision. The decision to automatically exchange data was taken on the basis of eligibility (Assessment Report).  On 8 October 2015, the Council found that Latvia had fully implemented the general data protection provisions in accordance with Decision 2008/615/PUP. With this Decision, the Council authorised Latvia to be able to receive and provide personal data in accordance with the rules (within the Member States). The more countries involved in prevention against terrorism and crime, the greater the chance that they will be suppressed, and therefore I support this proposal.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which concerned a pilot project carried out by Latvia and the Netherlands regarding the exchange of information on vehicles between the two Member States. This project, according to subsequent evaluations, had no adverse impact on EU data protection standards.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. According to the Council decision, border cooperation with neighbouring countries should be improved in order to prevent possible terrorist attacks and other threats. Mutual exchange of data is necessary to indicate potential threats, but data protection must be at a high level. In order to create the conditions for secure international data exchange, it is necessary to create circumstances in which all personal data is secure. Latvia has successfully completed a data security and exchange survey with neighbouring countries to prevent terrorism and border crime, and the same process is under way in other Member States. The United Kingdom is exempt from this Council decision. Latvia has successfully conducted an exchange of vehicle register data with the Netherlands. The Council reported that Latvia successfully conducted the survey and that it had successfully changed the provision in the data protection chapter. I support this proposal because data protection is uncompromisingly important and data sharing is necessary in the circumstances we are currently in.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the start of automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia.  Latvia has successfully passed a data protection test in the past and completed a questionnaire on the exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia. Since it also successfully carried out an evaluation visit, it fulfilled the conditions for fully implementing the general data protection provisions for the purposes of exchanging vehicle registration data.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report concerns the process of adopting a Council resolution, which has been implemented and establishes cross-border cooperation between Latvia and other countries on intensifying actions for the exchange of data relating to vehicle registrations.  We abstained on this report because the measures being promoted do not adequately protect personal data. We also believe that there is a serious risk of violating a range of individual and collective human rights as methods of monitoring and suppressing not so much criminal circles as organised social groups are promoted.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I believe that there are legislative gaps and procedural ambiguities with regard to cross-border cooperation in the fight against organised crime and terrorism, as well as with regard to the implementation of the Prum decision and the European standard for the exchange of information.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which is an important step towards the completeness of the Single European Market and strengthens cross-border cooperation, in particular the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime. It should be noted that the part of the decision relating to the transfer of personal data cannot enter into force until the preconditions, such as the provision of data protection, are transposed into the relevant national legislation. The preconditions have been fulfilled by Latvia, so that the road to cooperation can be opened up. The automatic exchange of vehicle registration data is in line with other relevant European Council regulations and has been preceded by a Dutch-Latvian pilot cooperation programme. Furthermore, I think it is important to mention that, in addition to Latvia, Denmark and Ireland are also taking steps to adopt and apply the decision.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I supported Mr Moraes' plan for the Council's draft implementation decision on the launch of the automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia. This programme is a symbol of better interaction between European services.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Council implementing decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to Vehicle Registration Data (VRD) in Latvia. This aims to authorise Latvia to receive and supply personal data in accordance with Council Decision 2008/615/JHA from the date of entry into force of the Decision with respect to automated data exchange regarding Vehicle Registration Data.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. In order to contribute as much as possible to the strong fight against terrorism and organised international crime, I support moraes' report on automated data exchange from the vehicle register in Latvia. Cross-border cooperation between institutions will be raised to a greater level in this way, and at this time, when organised international crime and terrorism have reached their peak, such data sharing is more than welcome. As Latvia is one of the Schengen members, and whose functionality, efficiency and security have often been questioned recently, such data sharing can greatly contribute to the security of citizens. I would also like to invite the institutions to effectively implement such provisions aimed at enhanced measures to combat all forms of threats, both to the national security of member states and to global security.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia, as this will deepen cooperation at international level, particularly in the area of combating terrorism and cross-border crime, which is absolutely necessary in the present day in the future.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. This report is part of the Prum Convention (signed in 2005 by some Member States) on police and judicial cooperation, which emphasizes access to national human identification databases (fingerprints, DNA...) and vehicle registration. In particular, it is voted to authorise the Council to implement its Decision on the establishment of the automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia. The planned assessments and pilot experiences have been validated by the Council. The GUE/NGL Group has traditionally opposed all the agreements contained in the Prom Convention, but since the decision concerns measures to safeguard privacy and data protection, we have abstained.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This report endorses the Council's proposal for an enforcement decision to allow Latvia, in order to combat terrorism and cross-border crime, to receive and transmit personal data for the purpose of automated consultation of vehicle registration data. We are opposed to the automatic and widespread transmission of personal data of French citizens. I'm voting against it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council consulted Parliament in accordance with the provisions of the Treaty on European Union. Effective action against terrorism and cross-border crime requires strengthening cross-border cooperation. I therefore voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: Writing. – I am pleased that Latvia has successfully implemented pilot actions with the Netherlands and has implemented all the necessary data protection rules, and thus, together with other Member States of the European Union, such as Belgium, Sweden, Germany, the Netherlands, Lithuania, Estonia, Poland, will be able to participate in the EU automatic system for the exchange of car registration data. Latvia's accession to the single automated vehicle registration exchange system is of utmost importance from several points. It will ensure cross-border cooperation and help prevent serious criminal offences or terrorist threats if they arise. It is extremely important that Latvia will now be able to attract assistance from other national police officers, if necessary, 24 hours a day and seven days a week, in order to ensure public order and security, or to prevent criminal offences, such as during mass events.  I have always stressed that the safety of the country and its citizens must be one of the priorities, so I hope that latvia's accession to the car registration system will increase the security of latvian citizens, as well as be able to help prevent and investigate criminal crimes and terrorism in other European countries.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a matter which was approved by a large majority in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and which has been submitted to the legislative procedure for consultation with the European Parliament by which this house proceeds to approve the Council's draft and asks it to either be told whether it intends to depart from the text adopted by the European Parliament or to consult it again if it intends to substantially amend the text approved by the European Parliament. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. This is a report on Latvia's access to the Treaty of Prum, which aims to exchange data between countries for the fight against crime. Our position is contrary to the Treaty, because we consider that it does not guarantee data protection and allows law ensuring that law ensuring that different States exchange information without any transparency or possibility of auditing. However, Council Decision 2008/616/JHA lays down a number of criteria relating to data protection, for which States need to complete a questionnaire. Having recently completed Latvia, what is voted on is its access to the new data protection criteria which, although insufficient, improve the initial provisions of the Treaty. For this reason, we abstained in this vote.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'Terrorism and organised crime have no national borders. That is why I can only welcome further cooperation between Member States which want to effectively identify and combat this problem.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 We would like to warn you that the provision of personal data provided for in the context of that decision cannot take place until the general data protection provisions laid down in that decision have been transposed into national law in the territory of the Member States participating in that transmission. The objective of the Prüm Decision thus is to intensify and accelerate exchanges of information between authorities. We know that, on the pretext of combating terrorism and crime, the EU has been putting together a surveillance system that reduces the freedoms and guarantees of individuals, and which calls into question the sovereignty of states with regard to the control and safeguarding of data and information. The aim is to create a supranational structure, which will progressively impose on Member States strategies and actions outside national and democratic control.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. In principle, there is no objection to the exchange of vehicle register data with Latvia. However, the relevant data protection regulations must be respected. It is not clear in the report whether this can be guaranteed. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the vote on this technical report concerning Latvia. The report was adopted by the committee responsible by a large majority.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the report on automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia. Latvia has fulfilled all the conditions necessary to initiate automated replacement and has demonstrated the implementation of the relevant Council Decision. I believe that such cooperation between countries will help in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, which is currently taking on significant proportions. As I believe that cooperation and trust between Member States need to be promoted, the report received my support in the final vote.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This is intended as a procedure for approving the Council decision on Decision 2008/615/JAI on deepening cross-border cooperation - prüm decision - in the fight against terrorism and crime. In particular, this report aims at launching automated exchange in Latvia on vehicle registration data (DRV). This report is part of the Prüm Convention, which was signed on 27 May 2005 in Prüm (Germany), between seven Member States - Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, Luxembourg, Spain, and the Netherlands. The objective of the Prüm Decision thus is to intensify and accelerate exchanges of information between authorities. We know that, on the pretext of combating terrorism and crime, the EU has been putting together a surveillance system that reduces the freedoms and guarantees of individuals, and which jeopardise stake in the sovereignty of states with regard to the control and safeguarding of data and information. The aim is to create a supranational structure that will progressively impose on Member States strategies and actions outside national and democratic control. For the above, I vote against.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated exchange of vehicle registration data in Latvia, as it will strengthen cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Nirj DEVA
text: – Madam President, one of the most important things that have come down from our legal traditions in the United Kingdom is the tradition of the Magna Carta that no—one should be held in trial and arrested without due cause and no-one can be kept in prison for a long period of time without due cause. This tradition that everyone, including the monarch himself, is under the law has been one of the most important attributes of our legal system: the presumption of innocence until proven guilty.  If we have a different structure, then the state becomes the dominant partner and the citizen becomes the junior partner in that relationship whereas, when we have the state to prove that you are guilty, then you are required to state the rights of the citizen first.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Of course, I voted in favour of the report on the presumption of innocence. All the more so because the principle of the presumption of innocence is sorely necessary in order to protect the current citizen, the individual, from the excesses and abuses of the power at all times. We see this especially when, for political reasons, the power wishes to take advantage of the possibility of prosecuting and detaining us, as the Romanian State does to our Hungarian brothers and sisters in the so-called István Beke case. Here we see the significance of the presumption of innocence. It happens that the burden of proof is on the authorities. Evidence of the guilt of the accused must be or should be present – this does not happen. Similarly, detention and pre-trial detention should not be considered as early sentences, so for example, allow... (The President has withdrawn the floor from the Member.)

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I supported this report. Yesterday, during the debate, I explained why I consider it important that we have a single basis for procedural criminal law in Europe, because we have a European arrest warrant and we are issuing citizens around Europe. But I did not have time to say, and that is why I entered the debate today, that it is good that the version of the proposal that was prepared by the European Parliament has passed and that some of the shortcomings that were in the original proposal that came from the Commission have been removed. I consider it particularly important that the Commission's proposal has been deleted, allowing for an exception and a breakthrough in the principle that the burden of proof in criminal proceedings must always be up to the prosecution, so it must be up to the state, not the citizen. I do not know why the Commission wanted to break this fundamental principle. Similarly, some concepts have been refined, such as how criminal proceedings are understood, because in each country it is regulated in a slightly different scope. So it is good that the European Parliament version has passed, it is certainly better.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – The presumption of innocence is one of the most important cornerstones of jurisprudence. It is legal in the Bible, and in fact this principle functions throughout the world. The idea is central and this idea must be implemented, and I support and voted in favour of today's decision. It must be said that the inadmissibility of the use of force during the conduct of criminal procedures, the inadmissibility of characterising a person as a criminal in public or in the mass media, and the fact that it is the party to the prosecution that must prove it guilty in court. It is an absolute right for the accused to be in the courtroom during the proceedings. Further universal promotion of these principles is necessary for our community. I repeat that I voted in favour. This will help to realeal, reinforce our values, because the rule of law is a characteristic of any healthy country and society.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo agus tá áthas orm gur vótáil an chuid is mó de na Feisirí i bhfabhar comh maith mar téann sé le réasún na moltaí atá ann. For instance, the recommendations there include prohibiting public authorities from providing information to the media, if it would demerit the principle of the presumption of innocence. That is a very important point. Not allowing the reversal of the burden of proof principle, not allowing authorities to use force to obtain information from an accused person, and placing very strict limitations on cases where a judgment may go ahead in the absence of the accused. All these elements are crucial to ensure that we have a just and fair criminal system and that the criminal proceedings are done in as a transparent and clear a manner as possible, and this of course underpins what the European Union is all about: a Union of values, respecting the rights of everybody, and this is a very important aspect of it.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, 800 years ago we established the principle of habeas corpus, that you should not be arrested or detained without purpose, and now in the name of the creation of a European criminal justice system and particularly through the mechanism of the European Arrest Warrant, that principle has been abandoned.  I was involved in a constituency case where a young man in what was very obviously a case of mistaken identity spent two years in detention in Greece, 11 months of it in one of the nastiest prisons in Europe, for the sake of a criminal action that was dismissed almost the moment it came to court because it was so very obviously a false case. Now that is no presumption of innocence; being detained without any charge being brought for that length of time one can only conclude that the process is the punishment. So now, in this anniversary of Magna Carta, to be told that we are going to be given the presumption of innocence by the European Union, I find insulting.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would also like to mention that last year marks 800 years since the adoption of such a fundamental charter as magna carta libertatum. It was really crucial for us, as Parliament, to remain not only on the content guarantees of a fair trial, a fair trial, but also on that form, as well as on the formal rules. A procedure that really forms the skeleton of a fair trial. And it turns out that in some countries, centuries-old principles simply work and form a complex complex. It is then not possible to remove certain rights from them and weaken them. The whole of the guarantees provided by both the Charter of Fundamental Rights and Freedoms, but also those guarantees that have been verified by centuries, simply form the framework for a fair trial in criminal matters as well. That's why I supported the report.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The presumption of innocence is an indispensable fundamental principle and corollary of due process, provided for in the rule of law to prevent any form of arbitrariness or abuse in judicial proceedings. This principle is enshrined in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights in Article 48, where the presumption of innocence is considered a general principle of the European Union. Within the policy of judicial cooperation, the harmonisation of national legislation on procedural rights will ensure respect for the principle of due process throughout Europe, as well as the concrete realisation of European citizenship. I voted in favour because I believe it is essential to establish a relationship of mutual trust between the national judicial systems.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. ‒ The United Kingdom has an opt-out on this legislative proposal, therefore the vote will not affect us. We abstained for two reasons; the first is that we of course believe in the presumption of innocence for anyone that has been accused of a crime and the UK has a longstanding history in protecting that value, we however do not believe that it should be the EU that decides this for Member States. The second reason is that we feel that we should not interfere on those situations that affect other Member States and not ours.
politicalGroup: The Earl of) Dartmouth Mike Hookem Diane James Margot Parker and Julia Reid (EFDD
partyIdeology: The Earl of) Dartmouth Mike Hookem Diane James Margot Parker and Julia Reid (EFDD

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive as it seems very important to us to introduce minimum criteria at European level which will enable Member States to respect the presumption of innocence and other rights of detainees, such as being present during their trial. One of the main ideas introduced in this proposal for a Directive is the shielding of the right to access of all detainees to some form of legal aid, even if provisionally. We find it positive that, in the face of the regressive changes in the judicial systems of different European countries, the presumption of innocence will be shielded and trials prevented in the absence of the accused. Some of the key issues for us have not been included, such as the inclusion of the right to remain silent or some measures relating to the custody of evidence, often violated in the Spanish State in cases related to the persecution of social activists. However, we believe that the end result introduces improvements by shielding rights and introducing measures to protect the rights of detainees.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. This report aims to adopt a proposal for a directive on the presumption of innocence and the right to attend his trial in criminal proceedings.  If I recognise the right to the presumption of innocence, as well as its central principles, as a fundamental right, I strongly oppose the EU's interference in criminal law cases, which is an exclusive competence of the Member States.  Opposed to the harmonisation of criminal law at European level, I voted against this report.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it reinforces specific aspects of the presumption of innocence and provides the necessary guarantees in criminal proceedings carried out at European Union level. It thus creates the appropriate balance required between repressive measures and the right of each individual to a fair trial. I believe that the establishment of rules governing the presumption of innocence is an important step towards ensuring this balance.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Criminal proceedings should only be the responsibility of the Member States. The European Union is undertaking to harmonize this principle from the bottom. For example, with respect to the burden of proof, the text shifts it to the detriment of the accused. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I felt it was appropriate to abstain on this, as the United Kingdom has an opt-out from the relevant legislation. It would be morally questionable for me to cast an affirmative vote on something which does not relate to the United Kingdom in any way.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this legislative resolution, the result of a long work by my colleague Nathalie Griesbeck, because it is a concrete piece of legislation that works for the rights of the defence of every citizen. The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right and above all an essential principle to prevent arbitrary judgments and abuses in criminal proceedings.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has presented a final set of procedural rights, which includes three proposals for directives to strengthen the procedural rights of suspects and accused persons in criminal matters. These three directives will enable the completion of the existing EU legal framework on the rights of defence of suspects and accused persons in criminal proceedings throughout the European Union. These are the main means of ensuring a fair trial throughout the European Union and full respect for the rights of the defence. The presumption of innocence is one fundamental right and an essential principle to avoid arbitrariness and any abuse in criminal proceedings. This proposal underlines the need to refer to the European Convention on Human Rights, the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. I also support the proposals aimed at clarifying the scope of the directive: the persons to whom it applies, the time at which it applies and its material scope.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. This legislative report concerns the Commission's proposal to ensure a minimum level of protection for the principle of the presumption of innocence in all Member States and to strengthen the right of those prosecuted to attend their trials. The main elements concern the presumption of innocence, the burden of proof, the right not to incriminate oneself, not to cooperate and to attend trial. The rapporteur amended this proposal in order to strengthen its protective character for citizens, in particular with regard to the impossibility of reversing the burden of proof to the detriment of suspects, the ineligibility of evidence gathered in violation of the principle of the presumption of innocence and the extent of the latter. At a time when some European governments are jeopardising fundamental rights, I have obviously supported this report.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The presumption of innocence is one of the fundamental principles underlying the legislation of European legal systems in the field of criminal law and procedure, enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union and, previously, in the European Convention on Human Rights. The Griesbeck report, on the proposal for a directive on strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial in criminal proceedings, is an important step, at EU level, towards the establishment of minimum standards applicable throughout the Union. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is necessary to strengthen the mechanisms for protecting defendants and suspects in order to avoid cases of arbitrariness of judgment and abuse in criminal proceedings. The text presented reaffirms the right to silence, the right not to incriminate one another and not to cooperate, outlining the central elements of the principle of innocence and reaffirming the importance of the right to attend the trial. Limiting cases where trials can be carried out in absentia is a central issue that must be carefully considered in the new directive in order to protect the right to due process.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. The rapporteur, while welcoming the proposal for a Directive reinforcing certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present in her own trial in criminal proceedings, believes that the Commission has taken too limited an approach and questions the lack of ambition of the initial proposal, which carries the risk of harmonisation of national provisions on the down. It therefore proposes amendments aimed at greater protection of suspects and accused persons in Europe. The amendments tabled by different groups broaden and specify aspects relating to the presumption of innocence, the burden of proof, the right not to self-inculpate and not to cooperate, the right to remain silent, the right to be present at trial itself and the right to a repeat trial, by significantly amending the Commission's proposal , which contained unacceptable aspects such as the reversal of the burden of proof, the admission, in certain circumstances, of the use of coerction for the collection of information or the admission of the 'tácita' waiver to be present at the trial itself. We voted in favour of the Resolution.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. My congratulations to Nathalie Griesbeck on the excellent work and agreement reached in the LIBE Commission on the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial itself in criminal proceedings. The Directive shall apply at all stages of criminal proceedings until the final decision on whether or not the person has committed the criminal offence in question becomes final. In addition, Member States shall ensure that the innocence of suspects and accused is presumed until proven guilty under the law.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report proposes to adopt a proposal for a directive to strengthen certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to attend trial in criminal proceedings. The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right.  Nevertheless, the report also believes that the Commission has taken too minimal an approach and questions the lack of ambition of this initial proposal, which could harmonize national provisions "down".   Criminal law is the jurisdiction of the Member States. I oppose EU interference and any attempt to create a 'European' criminal law. I have therefore decided to vote against this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the presumption of innocence is a fundamental right and an essential principle to avoid any arbitrariness and abuse in criminal proceedings. The report we are voting on is acceptable and balanced, and I therefore voted for it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this agreement at first reading reached with the Council on the proposal for a Directive which the Commission presented in November 2013 on the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial itself in criminal proceedings. This proposal, which is part of the procedural guarantee package, contributes to strengthening the right to a fair trial in criminal proceedings by establishing minimum standards relating to certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial, as well as to ensure that suspects and accused in criminal proceedings in the Member States enjoy , throughout the Union, a common and high level of protection and full respect for procedural safeguards, without prejudice to the application in a given Member State of rules offering greater protection. By establishing these minimum rules on the protection of the procedural rights of suspects or accused parties, Member States' confidence in the criminal justice systems of the other Member States will be strengthened and therefore contributed to facilitating mutual recognition of judgments in criminal matters.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament examines how to ensure certain elements of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present in criminal proceedings. This proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council aims to ensure certain elements of the rights of suspects or accused persons in criminal matters in the European Union until their guilt has been confirmed by a final judgment and to strengthen the right to appear before a court. The Commission carried out an impact assessment and examined this issue in detail: it was concluded that measures on certain aspects of the presumption of innocence were necessary in order to further ensure this fundamental right. In order to achieve the general objectives of the measures already adopted , including the most important of which, the Directive on the right of access to a lawyer) relating to procedural rights in criminal proceedings, a certain minimum level of protection of the principle of the presumption of innocence still needs to be ensured in all EU Member States. The current proposal will also help to strengthen legal safeguards for individuals involved in investigations by the European Public Prosecutor's Office. The recent proposal for a Council Regulation stipulates that the suspect has all the rights established by EU law, as well as other rights directly enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, applied in accordance with existing national legislation, and explicitly refers to the right to the presumption of innocence.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at its own hearing in criminal proceedings contributes in particular to guaranteeing a fair trial in the European Union and guaranteeing the rights of the defence. For me, it was important to ensure that one of the most fundamental rights of the accused or suspect, the presumption of innocence, was guaranteed. This will provide greater protection for the accused or suspect in Europe without undersaking the proper course of justice. A balanced compromise has been negotiated in setting minimum standards in this aspect of criminal proceedings. Once this is put into practice by all Member States, our common European legal system will become more effective.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposed report, which I supported, is final iting up the European legal framework in the area of the rights of defence of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings throughout the European Union. The three new directives thus establish an important instrument to ensure a fair trial across the EU. The amendments mainly relate to the presence of defendants in trials, the scope of the directive and the protection of suspects and accused persons from hasty statements of guilt. In the latter, I share the rapporteur's view that the presumption of innocence is being violated primarily by the media and the press.  In the face of spectacular arrests, which we witness often in Slovenia, or during the trial, all the cameras are pointed at the accused, their lives are upside down, they are guilty before they are proven guilty. The latter can thus take many years. Even if the verdict is acquitted in the end, the individual is found guilty for life - thanks to the media.  I therefore strongly support the proposed solutions on strengthening the presumption of innocence laid down in those directives.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒i2012 I support this Report on the first reading of agreements in criminal proceedings. In my view, effective conduct in criminal proceedings remains essential in order to establish an appropriate balance between repressive measures and an individual's right to a fair trial. Adopting rules governing the presumption of innocence is certainly an important step in rebalancing.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. If the principles mentioned in this report, such as the presumption of innocence, the right to remain silent, the right not to cooperate, the fact that the burden of proof rests on the prosecution, that doubt must benefit the accused, are principles that I support, I am on the other hand firmly opposed to any interference of European law in national law. I also see no need to create a European criminal law. For all these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the presumption of innocence and the right to stand trial in criminal proceedings are the pillar on which the rule of law and our society are based and that, therefore, they must be protected in every way by all authorities and institutions at all levels, without exception.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 A viable European Union cannot exist without effective justice. The European Union's ongoing legislative steps support the functioning of the procedural framework, and the legal pillars must be strengthened and applied uniformly in order to recognise the freedoms of citizens on which the Union was built. The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right and an essential principle for avoiding arbitrariness and abuse in criminal proceedings, as well as a principle underlying the protection of the right to a fair trial. This proposal for a directive is all the more important since, at present, in many Member States, there is a reduction in the rights of suspects and accused persons, as well as an erosion of the principle of the presumption of innocence, the infringement also subsidising at the media level. Both the presumption and the right to be present at trial in criminal proceedings seek to guarantee a certain minimum level of protection in all Member States and to strengthen the right of the accused. Thus, I conclude that it is necessary to guarantee adequate legislation by the Member States in order to prevent these infringements, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission's proposal has rightly and profoundly been amended by the LIBE Commission. The aim of the reworking is to strengthen the right to a fair trial in criminal proceedings by establishing common minimum standards (with a higher standard than that proposed by the Commission) relating to certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to attend the trial. I am voting in favour.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive on strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial in criminal proceedings. The directive is part of the final package on procedural rights presented by the Commission, which aims to complete the existing European body of legal law on the rights of defence of suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings within the European Union. These are key instruments for ensuring a fair trial throughout the Union and absolute respect for the rights of the defence as enshrined in the European Treaties, the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and the European Convention on Human Rights. Some important aspects concerning the presumption of innocence, which is an essential fundamental right to avoid arbitrariness and abuse in criminal proceedings, have been strengthened, thanks to the affirmation of the right to attend the trial and the wide limitation of cases where it is possible to carry out trials in absentia.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which seeks to reinforce the ECHR, EU Charter, International Covenant on Civil and Political Right and the Universal Declaration on Human Rights in terms of guaranteeing the presumption of innocence and right to be present at trial. There are also provisions enshrining the right to remain silent and safeguards in place for when an accused cannot be present in trial.  These guarantees have been provided for under Irish law for decades, the presumption of innocence being an indispensable part of due process and the right to a fair trial.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it makes some very important amendments to the Commission proposal. For example, it is important that the person is presumed to be innocent from the beginning of the proceedings until the very end of the trial and not only in criminal proceedings. Additionally the report stresses that coercion cannot be used against the suspect when trying to obtain information and that violence, whether physical or psychological is unacceptable. The report also limits the number of cases in which the judgement can be announced in the absence of the accused.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Directive on strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial in criminal proceedings is part of the European Procedural Rights Package and concerns a key principle of criminal law. Although the final text is not as ambitious as it could have been, it does not present any particular critical issues, and it needs to be approved from a general perspective of improving judicial cooperation in criminal matters between The Member States. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because it seeks to strengthen the right to a fair trial in criminal proceedings by establishing minimum rules for certain parameters relating to the presumption of innocence and the right to appear in his trial. By establishing minimum rules for the protection of the procedural rights of suspects or accused persons, this Directive will strengthen Member States' confidence in the criminal justice systems of the other Member States, and may therefore contribute to facilitating the mutual recognition of judgments in criminal matters.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The resolution on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council to strengthen certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right of the accused to appear in criminal proceedings is a particularly positive move aimed not only at maintaining but also strengthening existing rules and rights for the benefit of citizens. Issues such as that of the presumption of innocence are now more at the forefront than ever. Because of the ongoing economic and political crisis that is amening Europe, we need to provide for the protection of fundamental citizens' rights. In this light, I believe that the text we voted on has a positive impact and that is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure as I consider the presumption of innocence to be a fundamental right and an essential principle to avoid any arbitrariness and abuse in criminal proceedings as well as the principle underlying the protection of the right to a fair trial. Nathalie Griesbeck's report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to stand trial in criminal proceedings aims to improve the quality of protection reserved for these procedural rights and those linked to them. In particular, it removes the clause allowing the burden of proof to be reversed in court, which must always be the responsibility of the public prosecutor; strengthens the wording of the right not to incriminate one another, not to cooperate and to remain silent, stating that any evidence obtained in violation of those rights should be declared inadmissible. It also expressly prohibits forcing or forcing people to make statements or answer questions.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 With my vote I wanted to confirm my agreement with this proposal for a directive. In my opinion, this is also a step forward in establishing common rules on matters of competence that are not strictly transnational, but on which it is not acceptable for different rules to be applied on the one hand of a state border to the other. We are still in the area of procedure, but that does not alter the fact that there is room for further coordination and, over and above the political choice of whether or not to prosecute behaviour as a crime, at least the basic protections for defendants are the same.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The presumption of innocence is a fundamental principle of the legal process and one of the most important rights of the defence and according to the directive, Member States have to ensure that accused persons are presumed innocent until proven guilty under the law. The proposals in the text are very reasonable. They include banning public authorities from providing information to the media if it would demerit the principle of the presumption of innocence, prohibiting authorities from using force to obtain information from an accused person and placing very strict limitations in cases when a judgement may go ahead in the absence of the accused. All of the these are crucial to ensure that we have a just and fair criminal system and that criminal proceedings are done in the most transparent way.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. One of the most tangible and appreciated successes enjoyed by European citizens is the Schengen area. For the worst reasons, it has been evident almost daily how this area of free movement requires delicate balances, cooperation and solidarity that always require mutual trust between its members. The field of justice is part of this set of instruments aimed at promoting mutual trust while protecting citizens.  We must ensure a minimum level of procedural procedural guarantees across the continent that cover everyone, without distinguishing nationalities. Given their complexity and proximity to the core sovereignty of states, several rights were identified, such as the presumption of innocence, which required this harmonization.  The agreement reached in the negotiations with the Council is good, and I therefore very pleased ly welcome its adoption.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right to avoid any arbitrariness or abuse in criminal proceedings, as well as a principle that undersoes the protection of the right to a fair trial. I therefore welcome the Commission's presentation of the final package on procedural rights, containing three proposals for directives and therefore further provisions aimed at protecting suspects or defendants from premature guilty pleas, in fact the presumption of innocence is often violated in the media or the press, or the right to silence, not to incriminate one's own and not to cooperate and the right to attend the trial.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Everyone charged with a penal offence has the right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty according to law in a public trial. This means that the accused has been afforded all the necessary judicial guarantees for his defence. We need to strengthen cooperation between Member States so as to enhance the protection of individual rights. Procedural rules should guarantee the same rights, ensuring that people will not be treated unfairly according to the jurisdiction dealing with their case. The Union’s objective is to provide citizens with a high level of safety within an area of freedom, security and justice by developing common action among the Member States.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal is part of the second package presented by the Commission on procedural rights aimed at bringing the relevant Member States' legislation closer together with a view to improving judicial cooperation in criminal matters. These are key instruments for ensuring a fair trial throughout the Union and absolute respect for the rights of the defence as enshrined in the European Treaties, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR). The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right and an essential principle to avoid any arbitrariness and abuse in criminal proceedings and a principle that undersoes the protection of the right to a fair trial, in accordance with Article 6 of the ECHR, Article 48 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The Commission's initial proposal was not ambitious enough and the final text is not an example of upward harmonisation. However, I believe that instruments such as this and the other directives in the procedural rights package are essential instruments for facilitating and improving judicial cooperation in criminal matters between Member States in the future. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – We voted in favour as we think it is very important to introduce minimum criteria at European level which will enable Member States to respect the presumption of innocence and other rights of detainees, such as being present during their trial. One of the main ideas introduced in this proposal for a Directive is the shielding of the right to access of all detainees to some form of legal aid, even if provisionally. We find it positive that, in the face of the regressive changes in the judicial systems of different European countries, the presumption of innocence will be shielded and trials prevented in the absence of the accused. Some of the key issues for us have not been included, such as the inclusion of the right to remain silent or some measures relating to the custody of evidence, often violated in the Spanish State in cases related to the persecution of social activists. However, we believe that the end result introduces improvements by shielding rights and introducing measures to protect the rights of detainees.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 In 2013, the Commission presented a package of procedural rights containing three proposals for a directive. One of these is the proposal for a directive on strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence in criminal proceedings and the right to be present at their own hearing. The Directive, which points out that the presumption of innocence is a fundamental right and an essential principle to avoid arbitrariness and abuse in criminal proceedings, has been finalised under the Luxembourg Presidency. The presumption of innocence is the principle of protection of the right to a fair trial, which states that all accused or suspected persons should be treated as innocent until proven otherwise. And the burden of proof is the responsibility of the prosecution. The proposal focuses primarily on the principle of the presumption of innocence, the burden of proof, the prohibition of self-in retrial, the right to refuse cooperation, the right to remain silent, the right to be present at their own hearings and the right to a retrial. Today's vote formally confirmed the joint text of the Council and Parliament at the interinstitutional hearing, thereby ensuring that suspects or accused people receive a sufficiently high level of protection throughout the Union.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative resolution as it approves the latest text proposed during the recent trialogue stage. This text, is more advanced than the one negotiated within the Committee and emphasises the right for persons to be fully presumed innocent until proven guilty by a competent court. The text introduces and reinforces specific legal safeguards, such as the right to remain silent and the right to be present at a trial. These instances further reinforce the rights and privileges already defined in European and International Human rights instruments and work towards ensuring that everyone is considered equal in the eyes of the law and a fair trial is assured.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the final vote on this report as the UK has decided not to opt in to this directive. This is partly because the broad principles and safeguards contained within it are already reflected in UK law, but mostly because I share the British Government’s view that EU action in this area is not necessary, and it should be left to Member States.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report concerns the presumption of innocence and the right to attend his trial in criminal proceedings. The presumption of innocence is indeed a fundamental principle requiring states to consider any innocent person until the person has been convicted before the law. This new text will apply at all stages from the moment a person is suspected. In particular, it provides for a ban on public authorities making public statements about alleged culprits. Moreover, the burden of proof is the responsibility of the prosecutor. Considering that this report is an important step towards the creation of a European judicial area, I voted in favour.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at its own hearing in criminal proceedings contributes in particular to guaranteeing a fair trial in the European Union and guaranteeing the rights of the defence. It was important for the People's Party to ensure one of the most fundamental rights of the accused or suspect, the presumption of innocence. This will provide greater protection for the accused or suspect in Europe without undersaking the proper course of justice. A balanced compromise has been negotiated in setting minimum standards in this aspect of criminal proceedings. Once this is put into practice by all Member States, our common European legal system will become more effective.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission's proposal for a directive on strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial in criminal proceedings aims to ensure a fair trial throughout the Union while respecting the rights of defence as enshrined in the European Treaties, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR). I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important to avoid any arbitrariness and abuse in criminal proceedings, ensuring adequate protection of the right to a fair trial.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report aims to propose a European framework for strengthening the protection of the presumption of innocence and the right to attend its trial, in the context of criminal proceedings.  However, criminal law is a fundamental subject of justice already battered by recent reforms. The interference of the European Union is not acceptable in this area and affects both the regal prerogatives and the corpus of fundamental rights that France has developed. Attached to the sovereignty of States, particularly in criminal matters, I voted against this report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the presumption of innocence relating to the directive with the same subject aims to set minimum standards to be applied such as the right not to present the accused as 'guilty' before a final verdict, the principle that the prosecution must prove 'culpability', the right to attend the hearing, the right to refuse to give evidence and so on. Although I appreciate the report positively, I abstained as I disagree with certain aspects of it that have been achieved since the trialogies held with the Luxembourg Presidency.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 They constitute fundamental provisions concerning the right to a fair trial in criminal proceedings, the establishment of rules on certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to appear before the accused, the equal and high level of protection with full guarantee of procedural provisions. At Union level this should translate into adoption and/or equation with the highest level of protection that may apply in a Member State. The arbitrariness and abuses of the pre-inquest and criminal proceedings in the case of golden dawn political prosecutions in Greece demonstrate that European institutions selectively legislate and apply criminal procedure à la carte when they are silent or when they avoid reacting to the violation of the fundamental principles of "in dubio pro reo" and the presumption of innocence.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is aimed at bringing member states' legislation closer together with a view to improving judicial cooperation in criminal matters. These are key instruments for ensuring a fair trial throughout the Union and absolute respect for the rights of the defence as enshrined in the European Treaties, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) by complementing the existing European legal corpus on the rights of defence of suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings within the EU. The proposal for a directive presented by the Commission on strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial in criminal proceedings concerns a key principle of criminal law. The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right and an essential principle to avoid arbitrariness and abuse in criminal proceedings and a principle underlying the protection of the right to a fair trial, in accordance with Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights, Article 48 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission presented the 'Final Package – Procedural Rights' which contains three proposals for directives, following the adoption of the first three instruments of the European Union roadmap for strengthening procedural rights. These three directives will make it possible to conclude the European legal framework on the right of defence of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings throughout the European Union. The proposal reinforces certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to appear in court in criminal proceedings.  I voted in favour.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I believe that criminal procedure and criminal law must remain the responsibility of the Member States.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is based on the presentation of the 'Final Package – Procedural Rights', which contains three proposals for directives which fall within the EU roadmap for strengthening procedural rights. These directives aim to complete the European legal framework on the right of defence of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings across the EU. It is worth noting that a process of reducing the rights and guarantees of suspects and accused persons is underway in certain Member States.  The presumption of innocence is an essential principle for avoiding arbitrariness and any abuse in criminal proceedings, and is a principle underlying the protection of the right to a fair trial, in accordance with Article 11(1) of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which states that "every person accused of a criminal act shall be presumed innocent until his guilt is legally proven in the course of a public proceedings in which all necessary safeguards are defence are assured to it." Being at the fundamental according to the content of the proposal, it is worth noting that the Portuguese, in essence, already offers these guarantees. Regardless of the assessment of this particular proposal, the legal harmonisation objectives deserve reservations and disagreement.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ Effective procedural safeguards in criminal proceedings at European Union level continue to play a unique role and strike a balance in the European Union between punitive measures and an individual's right to a fair trial. The adoption of rules governing the presumption of innocence is an important step towards striking this balance. I therefore welcome the proposal for a directive tabled by the European Commission on strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at a criminal trial. The presumption of innocence is one of the fundamental rights and guiding principles in order to prevent arbitral and any abuses in criminal proceedings, which translates into the protection of the right to a fair trial.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is fundamental that the right to a fair trial in criminal proceedings such as fundamental needs is the establishment of rules on certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right of the accused to appear on trial and equal and high-level protection with full guarantee of procedural provisions. At Union level, this translates into an adoption and/or equation with the highest level of protection that may apply in a Member State. However, the arbitrariness and abuses of the pre-inquest and criminal proceedings in the case of the political prosecutions of Golden Dawn in Greece demonstrate, however, that the European institutions apply the case law selectively and apply criminal democracy à la carte, silent and not reacting to the violation of fundamental principles such as the principle of "in dubio pro reo" (in doubt in favour of the accused) and the presumption of innocence. That is why I am voting against this report.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the removal of a specific reference to presumption of facts or law concerning criminal liability (reversal of the burden of proof) from the operative part of the text: this was a key achievement. Similarly, the agreement on the text of the right to remain silent represents a significant improvement on the Commission proposal and the Council’s general approach. With regard to public references to guilt undermining the presumption of innocence and the role of the media, the result is satisfactory. The same goes for the text agreed upon in relation to in absentia trials. Effective procedural safeguards in criminal proceedings at EU level remain crucial to establish the appropriate balance in the EU between repressive measures and the individual’s right to a fair trial. The adoption of rules governing the presumption of innocence is an important step in establishing that balance.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it represents an important step towards completing the current European legal framework on the rights of defence of suspects, accused persons or those prosecuted in criminal proceedings within the European Union. This proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council is key because currently in many EU Member States the protection of the rights of suspects and accused persons is understated and the principle of presumption of innocence is violated. The presumption of innocence is a fundamental legal principle to avoid abuse in criminal proceedings. The adoption of this report aims at strengthening the right of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings throughout the European Union to enjoy the presumption of innocence until proven guilty by a final judgment, and to ensure the right of persons to attend the trial against them.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
