text: Writing. \u2012 Like the rapporteur, I welcome the commission's proposal for a final package on procedural rights, which contains three proposals for directives following the first three instruments adopted under the EU Roadmap for the Strengthening of Procedural Rights. These three directives make it possible to finalise the existing European legal toolkit for the protection of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings in the European Union. The three directives are an essential instrument to guarantee a fair trial throughout the European Union and to ensure full respect for the right to protection guaranteed by the EU Treaties, the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the European Convention on Human Rights (ECE). I therefore support the Commission's proposal for a directive on strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at its own hearing in criminal proceedings. The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right and an essential principle to avoid arbitrariness and abuse in criminal proceedings, as well as in accordance with the principle of protecting the right to a fair trial, Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights, Article 48 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. This proposal for a directive is all the more important because today, in many Member States of the European Union, the rights of suspects and accused persons are being eroded and the principle of the presumption of innocence is being worn out.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of strengthening procedural rights in the EU. These are key instruments to ensure a fair trial throughout the European Union and the absolute respect for the rights of defence guaranteed by the European Treaties, the European Charter of Fundamental Rights and the European Convention on Human Rights. We must always be ambitious in our defence of basic rights and freedoms, so the Commission's proposal represents a positive step.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. With this directive, Europe is referring not so much to the principles that already exist, at national and international level, but to the application of these fundamental rights, which are often disregarded, as confirmed by the European Court of Human Rights. The principle of the presumption of innocence is a fundamental element in guaranteeing the right to a fair trial and in avoiding arbitrariness and abuse. We will ensure that this principle is applied in national law, that past violations are put to an end and that every citizen is finally found innocent until the final judgment.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. As a human rights politician, I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council to strengthen certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present in criminal proceedings, as it strengthens European criminal law in international proceedings and guarantees more justice.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The addition of existing legislation in the field of the rights of the defence of suspects and suspects is important in order to ensure a fair and uniform procedure throughout Europe.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ This draft directive is part of a package of proposals to further strengthen procedural rights for citizens in criminal proceedings, which includes one on safeguards for children, and another on legal aid. Labour MEPs support the idea of establishing minimum standards across the EU in areas as fundamental as the presumption of innocence. The report outlines effective procedural safeguards in criminal proceedings at EU level which will strengthen an individual’s right to a fair trial. Along with Ireland and Denmark, the UK will not opt in to this directive so there is no conflict between national constitutional rules and secondary EU law.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. The rapporteur, while welcoming the proposal for a Directive reinforcing certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present in her own trial in criminal proceedings, believes that the Commission has taken too limited an approach and questions the lack of ambition of the initial proposal, which carries the risk of harmonisation of national provisions on the down. It therefore proposes amendments aimed at greater protection of suspects and accused persons in Europe. The amendments tabled by different groups broaden and specify aspects relating to the presumption of innocence, the burden of proof, the right not to self-inculpate and not to cooperate, the right to remain silent, the right to be present at trial itself and the right to a repeat trial, by significantly amending the Commission's proposal , which contained unacceptable aspects such as the reversal of the burden of proof, the admission, in certain circumstances, of the use of coerction for the collection of information or the admission of the 'tácita' waiver to be present at the trial itself. We voted in favour of the Resolution.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial in criminal proceedings is an extremely important issue and is a matter of the life and dignity of individuals. I voted for the report because I believe that there is a need for better application in all Member States of Article 11(1) of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights adopted by the UN in 1948. I believe in the need for suspects or defendants to enjoy adequate protection against incriminating public statements prior to the final conviction. Member States should provide the necessary conditions for suspects or defendants to appear or appear in the courtroom before and during the trial properly, because handcuffing or holding in a glass box creates the impression of guilt before trial. I also believe in the provision of the report on the accused's right to silence. This right must not prejudice the right to a fair trial. The right to remain silent cannot be used in any way against the person.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Labour Party colleagues, I voted in favour of this draft directive which is part of a package of proposals to further strengthen procedural rights for citizens in criminal proceedings, including one on safeguards for children, and another on legal aid. I support the idea of establishing minimum standards across the EU in areas as fundamental as the presumption of innocence. The report outlines effective procedural safeguards in criminal proceedings at EU level which will strengthen an individual’s right to a fair trial. Along with Ireland and Denmark, the UK will not opt in to this Directive so there is no conflict between national constitutional rules and secondary EU law.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. The presumption of innocence directive is an essential stone in the legislative package on the procedural rights of citizens in criminal proceedings, the result of negotiations between the Council and Parliament; The package also includes a proposal containing guarantees for children and another covering legal aid. The presumption of innocence, for its part, enshrines a fundamental principle of law that must apply at all stages of criminal proceedings. In the context of the negotiations, Parliament's particularly strong position with the Council is to be underlined in order to uphold a fundamental principle of law under which the burden of proof must be placed on the prosecution. The compromise reached also makes it possible to enshrine the right to silence as an absolute right. It also strengthens the provisions relating to the right not to incriminate oneself. The resulting text is balanced and very satisfactory. Member States will have two years to transpose this text; it is therefore to be hoped that it will enable the essential modalities surrounding the presumption of innocence to be harmonised as soon as possible. In Parliament, we will pay attention to it.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 After a very good report by the rapporteur of ALDE Mrs Griesbeck, our group voted in favour of the report in the LIBE debate. The first reading of the report by the Council was much more conservative than the European Parliament's report. The two institutions had a long debate and in the end the compromise was reached somewhere in the middle. However, the final report contains important victories for the European Parliament, such as not overturning the presumption of innocence. That was one of the main elements for us. In general, our assessment is that the directive respects the case law of the European Court of Human Rights and in some cases even goes even further. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I along with ALDE voted in favour of the Presumption of Innocence Directive which is one of a package of three directives, the other two being legal aid and specific safeguards for children, that are all aimed at strengthening the rights of individuals in criminal proceedings. I welcome this step forward to ensuring individuals’ rights are respected in criminal proceedings and that there are fairer trials for all EU citizens. Of particular importance in this directive is that the principle of ‘innocent until proven guilty’ remains across Member States and that the final text agrees is a positive result for EU citizens who will have access to fair trials across the EU.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the Commission proposal seeks to guarantee a minimum level of protection for the principle of presumption of innocence in all Member States and to enhance accused persons’ right to be present at their trials. The proposal therefore focuses mainly on the principle of presumption of innocence, the burden of proof, the right not to incriminate oneself and not to cooperate, the right to remain silent, the right to be present at one’s trial and the right to a retrial. In general, I welcome the approach adopted at the time and endorse almost all of those amendments; in particular, those seeking to prevent the reversal of the burden of proof to the detriment of suspects or accused persons and to ensure that evidence gathered in breach of the principle of presumption of innocence are inadmissible. The report also tables a number of additional amendments seeking to clarify the scope of the presumption of innocence, in particular as regards public references to guilt before conviction and thereby to ensure that suspects or accused persons enjoy a sufficiently high level of protection throughout the EU.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at its own hearing in criminal proceedings contributes in particular to guaranteeing a fair trial in the European Union and guaranteeing the rights of the defence. It was important for the People's Party to ensure one of the most fundamental rights of the accused or suspect, the presumption of innocence. The amendment provides greater protection for the accused or suspect in Europe without undersusing the proper course of justice. A balanced compromise has been negotiated in setting minimum standards for this stage of criminal proceedings. If the new rule is put into practice by all Member States, the effectiveness of our common European legal system will greatly increase.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. The institutions, in the context of inter-institutional negotiations, have succeeded in proposing a balanced approach to the presumption of innocence and the right to attend one's own trial in criminal proceedings. Therefore, I have decided to support this approach. For the French, in general, the right to a fair trial is an acquired principle. Unfortunately, this is not so evident in all Member States.  In fact, our reading varies from country to country and that is why legislators have wanted to define, in accordance with national sovereignty, common minimum rules governing certain aspects of the right to the presumption of innocence and the right to attend trial in criminal proceedings.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ The UK has decided not to opt in to this legislation and that is a position I can support.  The Commission failed to show that this proposal brings any added value and accordingly it fails to meet the subsidiarity requirements set out in the EU Treaty.  I therefore abstained in this vote.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report that guarantees a minimum level of protection for the principle of presumption of innocence in all Member States. This is a fundamental right that represents the key to preventing arbitrary judgments and any abuse of process in criminal proceedings.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a directive from Parliament and the Council on strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of non-prosecution and the right to be held at trial in criminal proceedings, as this is the way in which minimum European standards of law are set, which constitute the principle of presumption of non-prosecution. In my view, this empowers the rights of individuals in criminal proceedings and guarantees fair trials for all European citizens. However, it is clear that there are still violations of these principles across the European Union, and that some adjustments and amendments are needed. In this context, I support the rapporteur's amendments, including the report in question.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Together with my colleagues on the National Front, we believe that criminal proceedings should not be a matter for the sovereignty of the Member States. The European Union is undertaking a work of harmonisation from the bottom of this beautiful principle. For example, with respect to the burden of proof, the text shifts it to the detriment of the accused. I voted against it.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ Although presumption of innocence is a fundamental principle of law enshrined in the EU charter of fundamental rights, there are still reports of violations of this principle by some Member States. This new directive seeks to better ensure that the right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty in criminal proceedings is respected in the EU. It significantly improves citizens’ rights to a fair trial as well as the provisions on public statement about accused persons. Moreover, Member States should ensure appropriate presentation of the person so as not to create an impression of guilt. These changes will help to avoid any arbitrariness and abuse during criminal proceedings.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Nathalie Griesbeck's report on the presumption of innocence and the right to attend her trial. The purpose of this text is to establish common minimum rules governing certain aspects of the right to the presumption of innocence and the right to attend trial in criminal proceedings. The presumption of innocence is a fundamental principle of the judicial system and the basis of the right to defence. It will now be better protected at all stages until the verdict is delivered. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to ensure respect for the right to a fair trial in the Union by setting minimum rules common to all countries, in particular regarding the right to the presumption of innocence and the right to attend its trial in criminal proceedings.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. In principle, these are criminal justice mechanisms that should be applied in all Member States. Nevertheless, criminal law should remain a national matter, without an attempt at European harmonisation. It is also an attempt to pave the way for a European Public Prosecutor's Office, which I am critical of. I am abstaining from these considerations.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Labour MEPs support the idea of establishing minimum standards across the EU in areas as fundamental as the presumption of innocence.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: in writing. ‒ This draft directive is part of a package of proposals to further strengthen procedural rights for citizens in criminal proceedings, which includes one on safeguards for children and another on legal aid. Labour MEPs support the idea of establishing minimum standards across the EU in areas as fundamental as the presumption of innocence. The report outlines effective procedural safeguards in criminal proceedings at EU level which will strengthen an individual’s right to a fair trial. Along with Ireland and Denmark, the UK will not opt in to this directive so there is no conflict between national constitutional rules and secondary EU law.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The  Commission had to establish minimum procedural rights for suspects or accused persons, and to address the issue of presumption of innocence, in order to promote better cooperation. Until now, we have three directives on this topic: the right to interpretation, the right to information and the right of access to a lawyer in criminal proceedings.  I voted in favour since it improves four important elements: statements must not reflect an opinion that the person is guilty; the directive applies also to criminal proceedings; authorities must not use coercion in order to obtain information from a suspect or an accused person; last but not least it defines what the right to remain silent is.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. \u2012 If anyone, well, I know what it means to trample on the presumption of innocence. There are incredible intertwinings between politics, between certain actors in the supposedly independent judiciary and the press, which have recently been revealed by the much-seen German journalist Udo Ulfkotte. This report serves to strengthen fundamental freedoms, also provides important procedural guarantees and helps to restore citizens' strong confidence in the rule of law. It is rare for me to come up with such a collected, concrete, truly supportive report.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. The Directive on the presumption of innocence will allow this key concept, in order to defend fundamental rights, to be incorporated within two years into all the national laws of the Member States of the European Union. In practical terms, the text requires that the burden of proof be borne by prosecutors; it recognizes the right of the accused to silence, without being held against them, and also asks that an indictee not be automatically handcuffed, or his movements hindered.  These practices may seem common, but legal traditions differ from state to state and it is especially important that the European Union prevents any decline in fundamental rights, while some governments may be tempted to challenge them. It is also important to show that the European Union can be a source of progress, of defending certain rights, while its economic policy remains rightly associated with serious social recessions. I have therefore supported this directive.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the presumption of innocence and the right to attend its trial in criminal proceedings. These are, of course, fundamental rights to which I am attached. These rights are guaranteed in France and other Member States. However, this report criticises the Commission for too minimal an approach and questions the "lack of ambition" of this initial proposal which would risk harmonising the national provisions "down".  Criminal law is an exclusive jurisdiction of the Member States. I oppose EU interference and any attempt to create a 'European' criminal law.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I believe that criminal proceedings should be the sole sovereignty of the Member States. The European Union is exploiting the presumption of innocence - the fine principle that France proclaimed in Article 9 of the 1789 Declaration - to increase its scope of intervention. And for what result? In order to risk harmonizing the presumption of innocence downwards, the report is so reluctant to take sides on fundamental problems such as the possible reversal of the burden of proof to the detriment of the accused.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Another interference of the European Union in the powers of the states. In this case, if this report defends basic principles of criminal law to which I obviously agree (presumption of innocence and its corollaries, such as the right to remain silent, the right to attend trial...), it is out of the question that the European Union should interfere in this crucial area of justice. Yes to state specificities in such important areas of competence, and not to the introduction of a European criminal law. My vote against this text is therefore not motivated by a questioning of the criminal principles in question, but by a firm desire not to abandon this specific part of our national sovereignty to Europe.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The report contains an agreement at first reading on the basis of a proposal for a Directive submitted by the Commission in November 2013 on the presumption of innocence. Parliament approved a negotiating mandate in April 2015 after addressing the in-depth processing of the proposal. In the LIBE Commission, the outcome of the report was satisfactory and consistent with the progressive political lines and, although there were changes in the House, the final outcome of the negotiation is acceptable and respects the red lines of our political group, so I voted in favour.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this proposal as we think it is very important to introduce minimum criteria at European level that will enable Member States to respect the presumption of innocence and other rights of detainees, such as being present during their trial. One of the main ideas introduced in this proposal for a Directive is the shielding of the right to access of all detainees to some form of legal aid, even if provisionally. We find it positive that, in the face of the regressive changes in the judicial systems of different European countries, the presumption of innocence will be shielded and trials prevented in the absence of the accused. Some of the key issues for us have not been included, such as the inclusion of the right to remain silent or some measures relating to the custody of evidence, often violated in the Spanish State in cases related to the persecution of social activists. However, we believe that the end result introduces improvements by shielding rights and introducing measures to protect the rights of detainees.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The report we are dealing with comes from the european Commission's proposal for a Directive reinforcing certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial itself in criminal proceedings. According to the rapporteur, this effort is not enough. To this day, the rights of accused persons are becoming less and less and the principle of the presumption of innocence is degrading. As we already know, the presumption of innocence is a fundamental right, as well as a basic principle to avoid arbitrariness in the judicial sphere. That is why it must have great legal support. The report aims to make the Directive apply to both natural persons and legal persons, from the moment the person is suspected, during the process and until the conclusion of the process. Similarly, the report also aims to prevent or suppress premature guilty pleas. In my view, the adoption of this report is essential to ensure a fair trial throughout the European Union and to increase respect for the rights of defence guaranteed in the European Treaties.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained because I take it for granted to respect the principle of the presumption of innocence and the fundamental legal protection of defendants in the EU.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The aim of the proposal for a Directive from the European Parliament and the Council is to strengthen certain aspects of the rights of suspects or accused persons. The right to a fair trial is one of the fundamental principles of a democratic society guaranteed by Article 47 of the European Union. Charters and Article 6. Convention on Human Rights (EEA). The right of the accused person to attend his or her own trial should be guaranteed in the Union. The principle of effectiveness of EU legislation requires Member States to establish appropriate and effective remedies in the event of an infringement of the rights that individuals have under Union law. The proposals put forward relate mainly to the following rights: the right not to be found guilty by a public authority before a final judgment is delivered, the fact that the burden of proof is on the prosecution, the right not to incriminate oneself, the right to remain silent, the right to be present at his own trial and the right to a retrial. The Committee on Legal Affairs looked at the proposals in detail and adopted a number of amendments that were adopted unanimously. I supported Mep Nathalie Griesbeck's report, as each person has the right to enjoy a sufficiently high level of protection at trial in criminal proceedings, and it is up to the Member States to apply appropriate safeguards and ensure presumptions of non-prosecution.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing \ u2012 The presumption of innocence is an obvious part of any democratic legal order and the rule of law. Strengthening the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at criminal court proceedings increase the state's responsibility in thoroughly examining each act. They have a fundamental impact on the fulfilment of the right to a fair trial. Proceedings in absentia must be restricted to the extent necessary and must be clearly lawfully justified. The restriction of personal liberty must always be lawfully justified. At the same time, however, it is important that material, personnel and legislative conditions are created for swift and timely action so that the acts are investigated as quickly as possible and that evidence and investigations are not obstructed as quickly as possible.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council to strengthen certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right of the accused to appear in his trial in criminal proceedings because it is a complete and substantiated report.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against it. However, the European Commission does not like criminal law, which is the competence of the Member States which Europe does not have to meddle with. We recognize that the presumption of innocence is a fundamental right, as are all the principles surrounding it (burden of proof on the charge, right to remain silent, right not to self-incriminate and not to cooperate, right to attend trial...). This attempt by the Union to create a 'European' criminal law is misplaced, which is why we oppose it.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the Commission’s proposal for a directive on the strengthening of certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and of the right to be present at trial in criminal proceedings. The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right and a principle which is key to preventing arbitrary judgments and any abuse of process in criminal proceedings, and which underpins protection of the right to a fair trial as set out in Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights, Article 48 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union , the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The proposal for a directive is made all the more important by the limitation of the rights of suspects and accused persons and the erosion of the principle of the presumption of innocence that is currently being seen in several EU Member States.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial in criminal proceedings. This proposal, which focuses on the presumption of innocence, the procedural protection of minors during criminal proceedings and the right to provisional admission to legal aid in criminal proceedings, aims to guarantee citizens of the European Union the right to a fair trial, to increase mutual trust in the systems of the Member States, to facilitate the mutual recognition of their judicial decisions and to ensure absolute respect for the rights of defence , as enshrined in the European Treaties.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on the report, which is part of a package of three draft directives aimed at strengthening procedural rights in the EU. These three directives will make it possible to finalise the European legal system that exists in the area of rights of defence for suspects, defendants or accused in criminal proceedings throughout the European Union. These are key instruments that should guarantee a fair trial throughout the European Union and full respect for defence rights, as guaranteed by the European Treaties, the European Charter of Fundamental Rights and the European Convention on Human Rights. I therefore welcome the European Commission's proposal for a directive reinforcing certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present in criminal proceedings before a court. The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right and a fundamental principle used to exclude arbitrary action and any abuse in criminal proceedings, and is the principle behind the protection of the right to a fair trial in accordance with Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights, Article 48 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. I therefore voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 We must ensure that procedural rights have uniform minimum protection in all Member States. I welcome the proposal for a directive voted on today, calling not only for proper transposition into the legislation of all Member States, but also for a broad communication so that citizens are informed about their rights.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I supported the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council reinforcing certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial itself in criminal proceedings. It is important to work to ensure that these rights are guaranteed throughout the Union, which is why we have also stressed from the European Parliament that it is necessary to ensure that suspects and accused persons in criminal proceedings in the Member States enjoy, throughout the Union, a common and high level of protection as well as full respect for procedural safeguards , without prejudice to the application in a given Member State of rules offering greater protection.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The Commission has tabled three notable proposals for a directive concerning the presumption of innocence and the right of the accused to appear in criminal proceedings. Protected by the EU Treaties as well as by the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the ECHR, the two rights mentioned above are key ways of protecting the suspect or accused person in criminal proceedings and guaranteeing a fair trial for the proper administration of justice. In this context, and in order to actually achieve an impartial trial, some amendments will have to be made to the Commission's proposals. These amendments which I consider important and which I am voting in favour of are, for example, the prohibition of early assessments of guilt by the exercise of the right to silence which should not have a negative effect on the outcome of the trial, but also the prohibition of media accusations prior to the conviction of the accused. At the same time, it should be clear that the burden of proving the accused's guilt is beyond reasonable doubt, as is the case in Cypriot law and therefore whether at the end of the trial the court retains any doubt about the guilt of the accused should acquit him. Finally, cases of trial in absentia of the accused should be reduced to the absolute extent.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Criminal law is a national issue and does not require European harmonisation. There is also a risk that this proposal will make criminal prosecution even more difficult. I therefore reject this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Stockholm programme has focused on strengthening the rights of individuals in criminal proceedings. The European Council has therefore called on the Commission to consider proposing minimum procedural rights for suspects or defendants, with the aim of promoting better cooperation in this area in the European Union. The Commission's proposal amended by Parliament effectively guarantees the presumption of innocence. "Suspects must be presumed innocent until proven guilty by a final decision made in accordance with the law, in a trial in which they have had all the necessary guarantees to defend themselves." But also the right to remain silent, to be present at his trial and the right to a fair trial. The text also ensures that the burden of proof rests with the charge.  I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Together with my colleagues on the National Front, we believe that criminal proceedings should not be a matter for the sovereignty of the Member States. The European Union is undertaking a work of harmonisation from the bottom of this beautiful principle. For example, with respect to the burden of proof, the text shifts it to the detriment of the accused. I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on strengthening certain aspects of the rights of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings, in particular that they are presumed innocent until their guilt is proved by a final decision and that of appearing at the trial itself. The presumption of innocence and the right to appear in court in criminal proceedings are fundamental values so that we can qualify a State as the rule of law, a value enshrined in Article 6 of the ECHR, Article 48 of the CDFUE, the ICCPR and the UDHR.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it is essential that the Union strives to prevent abuses in criminal proceedings. This resolution seeks to ensure that the right to be present at trial in criminal proceedings is observed in all Member States because it is a key component of the presumption of innocence.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I am pleased that the European Parliament has adopted this legislation which aims to strengthen a right as fundamental as the presumption of innocence in criminal proceedings. Justice can only be virtuous if it effectively guarantees the basic principle of considering an innocent person as long as he or she has not been found guilty. It was a priority for the European Parliament to ensure that the burden of proof was not reversed. This implies, therefore, that any doubt as to the question of guilt benefits the person being prosecuted. In addition, the text recalls a series of rights related to the right of the presumption of innocence, such as the right to remain silent, not to incriminate yourself or the right to attend a trial.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – The presumption of innocence and the rights of the accused in criminal proceedings have been among the most fundamental rights of the European legal system since the earliest times. Without unconditional respect for them, we cannot talk about the rule of law and fair conduct. The necessity of complying with the procedural provisions and constantly improving them is that every single one of us can be brought to justice. Life brings different situations that we often can't control. One small error of inattention or failure of the human factor is enough, and a person is exposed to the actions of law enforcement. The lawful action of law enforcement authorities, and in particular the possibility of personally participating in proceedings, enable the accused to sufficiently protect his procedural rights. Let us not forget that the dignity of man must also come first in criminal proceedings. I welcome any new legislation that protects the dignity of the accused person more.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ Effective procedural safeguards in criminal proceedings at EU level remain crucial to establish the appropriate balance in the EU between repressive measures and the individual’s right to a fair trial. The adoption of rules governing the presumption of innocence is an important step in establishing that balance. That is why I voted in favour of the report on presumption of innocence and right to be present at trial in criminal proceedings.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has submitted a proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council to strengthen certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at its own hearing in criminal proceedings. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs states that the proposal is an essential instrument to guarantee a fair trial throughout the European Union and to ensure full respect for the right to protection guaranteed by the EU Treaties, the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the European Convention on Human Rights (ECJ), and parliament therefore adopts the draft with a number of amendments. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. It is a matter of adopting a proposal for a directive to strengthen certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to attend trial in criminal proceedings. The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right. The principle that the burden of proof is on the prosecution and that any possible doubt about guilt should benefit the accused, the right to remain silent, the right not to self-incriminate and not to cooperate, the right to attend his trial are also central elements of the presumption of innocence. These are principles that we recognize. However, this report is of the opinion that the Commission has taken too minimal an approach and questions the lack of ambition of this initial proposal which could harmonize the national provisions "down". Criminal law is the jurisdiction of the Member States. We oppose EU interference and any attempt to create a European criminal law; for this reason, we cannot vote in favour of this text.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 This report has my vote in favour of substantially strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to appear in criminal proceedings.  The principle of the presumption of innocence, or non-culpability, is a fundamental principle of criminal proceedings and establishes the state of innocence as a rule in relation to the defendant in the commission of a criminal offence. This proposal aims to ensure that the principle of the presumption of innocence is applied at all stages of criminal proceedings. In this regard, I believe it is essential to extend the scope of a fundamental principle of the rule of law, the "presumption of innocence of the accused", also shaped by the Declaration of Human and Citizen Rights, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the European Convention on Human Rights.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Criminal law is the responsibility of the Member States. I oppose EU interference and any attempt to create a 'European' criminal law.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ This draft directive is part of a package of proposals to further strengthen procedural rights for citizens in criminal proceedings, which includes one on safeguards for children, and another on legal aid. Labour MEPs support the idea of establishing minimum standards across the EU in areas as fundamental as the presumption of innocence. The report outlines effective procedural safeguards in criminal proceedings at EU level which will strengthen an individual’s right to a fair trial. Along with Ireland and Denmark, the UK will not opt in to this Directive so there is no conflict between national constitutional rules and secondary EU law.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to define common minimum rules governing certain aspects of the right to the presumption of innocence and the right to attend trial in criminal proceedings. This text, which is part of the procedural rights package, aims to ensure that the right to a fair trial is respected. It is also about strengthening Member States' confidence in the criminal justice system of other Member States and, therefore, facilitating mutual recognition of criminal decisions.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial in criminal proceedings. It aims to ensure a minimum level of protection of the principle of the presumption of innocence in all Member States, as well as to strengthen the right of defendants to be present at their trial. The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right and an essential principle that every State of the Union must guarantee to the accused, in order to avoid possible arbitrariness of judgment and possible abuse in proceedings, as already enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, as well as in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. It is crucial that this issue is confronted at European level, so as to ensure uniform protection within the Member States and avoid the expiry of the rights of suspects and defendants, especially as regards the presumption of innocence and procedural guarantees. In this context, it is essential that the Union guarantees rights such as the right not to respond, the right to a new trial, the burden of proof and the right to attend its trial.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. The report on the presumption of innocence and the right to attend a trial in criminal proceedings is intended to ensure that the right to a fair trial is respected. I voted in favour of the report, considering that the enactment of common rules of procedure is fundamental.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 It is not uncommon for judicial truth, the only one that really matters, to be influenced, and distorted, by arbitrary conjectures and interpretations by third parties. Although the principle of the presumption of innocence is a cornerstone of the rule of law, it is often sacrificed on the altar of interests outside purely judicial interests. The document in question describes, in a balanced and transversely acceptable way, the need to guarantee the suspect or the accused the right to be considered innocent until the expression of the last degree of judgment. By sharing the content and expectations of this document, I have decided to support it with my vote in favour.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the report on the presumption of innocence and the strengthening of the right to be present at trial, since the fundamental rights of defendants are still frequently violated in many Member States of the European Union. With the help of this report, we will be able to introduce a minimum level in order to protect the principle of innocence, which can contribute, inter alia, to mutual acceptance of decisions taken in each Member State and to strengthening their trust in each other.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that aims to set a common set of regulations across Member States in order to enforce the presumption of innocence and further rights in criminal procedure trials.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. This report risks further complicating the prosecution of potential offenders. Consequently, I voted against it.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This report, part of the Stockholm process, focuses on the protection of those charged and the need to implement a procedure allowing a minimum legal basis for rights for suspects, in order to harmonize in Europe the principle of the "presumption of innocence". I voted in favour of this report, which ensures legal certainty and avoids abuse in criminal proceedings. The report also recalls the European and international conventions that the Union is obliged to respect in this regard. Finally, through this report, the Union therefore strengthens the principle of the burden of proof on the prosecution, the principle that the possible doubt about guilt should benefit the defence, as well as the right to remain silent and the right to attend the trial.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In particular, the aim is to ensure a minimum level of protection of the presumption of innocence in all Member States and to strengthen the right of accused persons to be present in person at the trial.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that European legislation on the rights of defence of suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings plays a key role in ensuring a fair trial, I very much welcome the proposal to strengthen certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to attend the trial in criminal proceedings presented by the rapporteur on the Commission proposal considered weak and unclear in some respects. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – I believe it is every suspect’s or accused person’s right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty by a final judgment. Europe needs a fair justice system guaranteeing fair trials everywhere in the European Union and ensuring complete respect for the rights of the defence. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. I believe that every defendant has the right to a fair trial. Guilt must prove and I am a supporter of the presumption of innocence. It is important to provide the suspects with all the conditions for preparing the defence and to ensure that confidential information from criminal proceedings is not made public during its duration so as not to encourage the public to believe that they are guilty. Therefore, caution should be exercised in statements made to the media during trials. In its work, the Court should be impartial and I am pleased that the members of the Committee stressed this in the report.  The use of force is not the way to gather information because, in addition to being inhumane and in breach of human dignity, it cannot obtain credible testimony from parties to criminal proceedings. It is natural to allow a suspect the right not to incriminate himself and I support the position expressed in the report that non-cooperation must not be considered a guilty verdict. The right to remain silent must be maintained as a possibility, as well as the right to a retrial in the event of new evidence appearing in order to preserve the e are fairness of the trial.  Finally, I stress that defendants for serious crimes for which imprisonment is scheduled should be present at trial. This report strengthens the right to a fair trial, provides good and concrete proposals and I have therefore supported it.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report deals with a proposed directive that aims to strengthen certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to attend trial in criminal proceedings. The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right. The principle that the burden of proof hangs over the prosecution and that any possible doubt about guilt should benefit the prosecution, the right to remain silent, the right not to self-incriminate and not to cooperate, the right to attend a trial are also central elements of the presumption of innocence. These are principles that I recognize, of course, and defend forcefully. But the report believes that the Commission has taken too minimal an approach and questions a "lack of ambition" that could harmonize national provisions "down". Criminal law is a sovereign jurisdiction of the Member States. I strongly oppose EU interference and any attempt to create a 'European penal law'. I therefore vote against this report.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Griesbeck report because it improved the Commission's proposal for a directive on strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial in criminal proceedings. The final package on procedural rights, of which the directive is a part, will establish a common European legal framework capable of guaranteeing a fair trial and absolute respect for the rights of the defence, as enshrined in the European Treaties, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and the European Convention on Human Rights. In particular, I particularly welcome the decision to change the Commission's proposal, supported by the centre-right, where it proposed a reversal of the burden of proof on defence. Equally important, I believe, are those passages that reaffirm the right of the accused to remain silent, so as not to contribute to his own indictment; establishing the extension of these rights also to natural persons and administrative procedures that could have criminal consequences; which affirm the need to respect the presumption of innocence in public statements, in particular of the media and the press.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I believe that in times of crisis, which unfortunately often favor an atmosphere of fear, lynching and social incarceration, it is especially important to insist on the presumption of innocence as one of the fundamental principles of fair judicial proceedings. Equally, the application of this principle should be accompanied by a strong rule of law and an independent judiciary. Only through effective and consistent procedural guarantees of protection can we ensure that the rights of accused and suspects are upholding. In this regard, I consider Article 4 of this proposal, which insists on a prohibition of prejudgment and reference to guilt before proven guilt by public authorities, to be particularly important.  Furthermore, important achievements are the elimination of the original part of the text, which was to allow in certain cases the twisting of the burden of proof and the principle in dubio pro reo, but also the expressed commitment to the protection of the right to silence. In addition, and also with regard to the rights of individuals and in particular with the right of presence, it is commendable that the amendments significantly strengthen the conditions for conducting proceedings and decision-making in cases where the person concerned is not present. The Union's commitment to strong regulation guaranteeing the right to a fair trial should in this form put more pressure on all those States and for all cases where this right has been called into question.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒I support MEP Nathalie Griesbeck's report on the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council to strengthen certain aspects of the presumption of non-prosecution and the right to be present at trial in criminal proceedings. The right to be tried in criminal proceedings is an essential right of defence. Likewise, this right is crucial to the fulfilment of the right to a fair trial granted by Article 6 of the 1953 European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights I therefore believe that strengthening the right to be present at trial in criminal proceedings will greatly contribute to the application of the right to a fair trial. The presumption of ineligency is also important, and the European Commission recognised this during a thorough review of the issue of non-compliance and concluded that a measure on certain aspects of the presumption of non-compliance is necessary to strengthen this fundamental right.  In February 2013, Croatia had a meeting with representatives of the ministries of justice of the European Union members specifically on the presumption of non-compliance and thus proved that it cares about human rights and their implementation. In my view, this directive would greatly strengthen the rights of individuals in criminal proceedings on which the Stockholm Programme has placed emphasis. It is very important to remove the perception that the rights of suspects or accused persons are not respected at every stage, as the same has a really detrimental effect on mutual trust and judicial cooperation.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission has presented the final package on procedural rights containing three proposals for directives which will make it possible to complete the existing European legal corpus on rights relating to the defence of suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings within the European Union. The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right and an essential principle to avoid any arbitrariness and abuse in criminal proceedings. Furthermore, Article 4 of the proposal for a directive is a fundamental provision to protect suspects or defendants from premature guilty pleas. It is therefore necessary to ensure that The Member States have adequate legislation to prevent certain infringements. The right to silence, the right not to incriminate one and not to cooperate, as referred to in Articles 6 and 7 of the proposal for a directive, are also central elements of the presumption of innocence. Finally, the right to attend trial is a fundamental element of the presumption of innocence, which is currently protected only by European legislation within the framework of the European arrest warrant. The proposal for a directive provides an opportunity to improve the protection provided for in this instrument. I support the adoption of this motion for a resolution in order to guarantee all citizens the means to protect them from any abuse of a judicial nature.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. In particular, he emphasizes the presumption of innocence and the right to attend his trial, two principles that are now fundamental to our national law.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Directive is part of a broader package aimed at strengthening the rights of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings in order to ensure full respect for their rights of defence and a fair trial throughout the European Union. To that end, it lays down minimum standards for certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to appear at the trial itself.  On 4 November 2015 the Council and Parliament agreed on this proposal, and Parliament succeeded in achieving some objectives, in particular as regards: clarification of the temporal scope of the Directive (the Directive applies at all stages of the procedure from the moment a person is considered suspicious or constituted to the final conclusion of the procedure); the prohibition of any statement by public authorities presuming the guilt of the accused or suspect; and the consecration of the principle that the burden of proof rests with the accusation and the right to silence.  This is a particularly important initiative, as the presumption of innocence is an essential dimension of the right to a fair trial.  I voted, therefore, in favor.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right and an essential principle to prevent arbitrariness and any abuse in criminal proceedings. The proposal for a directive which I voted in favour of is especially important, as a reduction in the rights of suspects and accused persons is underway in many member states of the European Union, as well as an erosion of the principle of the presumption of innocence.  The Commission initially adopted a minimalist approach which could level national provisions 'below'. The proposal is therefore to clarify the scope of the Directive, both personally, temporally and materially. The right to remain silent, the right not to incriminate oneself, not to cooperate in attending the trial itself are also fundamental elements. In view of the foregoing, I voted in favour of this report. It is essential to protect suspected or guilty persons from premature culpability statements and it is important that Member States ensure appropriate legislation to prevent the usual violations of the presumption of innocence of the media.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right of citizens to avoid arbitrary decisions during criminal proceedings. This is what MEPs recalled this afternoon when they adopted by a very large majority (577 votes in support) the new directive on the presumption of innocence negotiated by my friend Nathalie Griesbeck for the European Parliament. Of course, this new European legislation is not intended to interfere in the organisation of judicial systems and criminal procedures operated by public authorities which remain a regal power of the Member States, but rather to set minimum standards for fair trials throughout the European Union.  For, despite the existence of national laws on the presumption of innocence, many violations of this principle still exist in Europe. This is why this European directive is important in that it harmonizes essential aspects of the presumption of innocence, such as the right not to be charged by public authorities before a judgment or the conditions for the admissibility of evidence.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The adoption of rules ensuring the presumption of innocence is an important step towards the balance between repressive measures and the right of individuals to a fair trial. The Court of Human Rights considers that there are some minimum requirements for the presumption of innocence that must be commonly respected: the right not to be publicly presented as guilty by the authorities before the trial; the burden of proof which must be on the prosecution; the right of the accused to be informed of the charges against him; the right to be present before a court; the right not to cooperate and to remain silent (and to be informed of this right). These are requirements that all EU Member States must comply with. Only then can we have the legitimacy necessary to demand them from third countries.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this agreement at first reading reached with the Council on the proposal for a Directive which the Commission presented in November 2013 on the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial itself in criminal proceedings. This proposal, which is part of the procedural guarantee package, contributes to strengthening the right to a fair trial in criminal proceedings by establishing minimum standards relating to certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial, as well as to ensure that suspects and accused in criminal proceedings in the Member States enjoy , throughout the Union, a common and high level of protection and full respect for procedural safeguards, without prejudice to the application in a given Member State of rules offering greater protection. By establishing these minimum rules on the protection of the procedural rights of suspects or accused parties, Member States' confidence in the criminal justice systems of the other Member States will be strengthened and therefore contributed to facilitating mutual recognition of judgments in criminal matters.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. We adopted the draft agreement reached last November between the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union on the directive on the presumption of innocence. This directive must ensure that the principle of the presumption of innocence is applied throughout the Union and Member States will have to act on it until the suspect's guilt has been proven, for example by avoiding handcuffing him, unless these measures are strictly necessary. The adopted text recognizes that the burden of proof must rest on the prosecutors and that any doubt raised should benefit the accused. Moreover, the right to silence should not be used against individuals either. Once formally adopted by the Council, Member States will have two years to transpose this text.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report which reinforces certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to appear in court in criminal proceedings.  Minimum procedural rights for suspects and accused persons must be established, respect for the principle of the presumption of innocence must be ensured in order to promote a fairer and more balanced system. I would like to see the reversal of the burden of proof on the defendant, the right to remain silent and the non-regression clause as instruments at the service of citizens, who see a new framework for guaranteeing and safeguarding their rights in criminal proceedings. For the reasons put forward above, I supported this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the European Commission's proposal for a directive strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to attend its trial in criminal proceedings.  The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right and an essential principle to avoid arbitrariness and abuse in criminal proceedings. It is a principle that underlies the protection of the right to a fair trial. This directive will apply at all stages of the criminal proceedings, from the time a person is suspected of having committed a criminal offence or an alleged criminal offence, or is prosecuted as such, until the final decision on whether that person has committed the criminal offence in question has become final. The right to attend his trial, the right to remain silent or the burden of proof are also specified in this text.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive as it seems very important to us to introduce minimum criteria at European level which will enable Member States to respect the presumption of innocence and other rights of detainees, such as being present during their trial. One of the main ideas introduced in this proposal for a Directive is the shielding of the right to access of all detainees to some form of legal aid, even if provisionally. We find it positive that, in the face of the regressive changes in the judicial systems of different European countries, the presumption of innocence will be shielded and trials prevented in the absence of the accused. Some of the key issues for us have not been included, such as the inclusion of the right to remain silent or some measures relating to the custody of evidence, often violated in the Spanish State in cases related to the persecution of social activists. However, we believe that the end result introduces improvements by shielding rights and introducing measures to protect the rights of detainees.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider the presumption of innocence a fundamental principle of the law and an essential element for there to be a fair trial. As cases of repeated violations of this principle have been recorded, the Commission has taken the initiative to legislate by proposing a new Directive. The Commission's initiative includes provisions to strengthen the protection of suspected or accused children and the right to legal support, among others. The report voted in plenary reinforces some aspects, such as those relating to the additional protection of vulnerable people. In agreement with the Commission's initiative and the perspective reflected in the report, I voted positively for this initiative.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as this does not affect the UK.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this draft directive which is part of a package of proposals to further strengthen procedural rights for citizens in criminal proceedings, which includes one on safeguards for children, and another on legal aid. I support the idea of establishing minimum standards across the EU in areas as fundamental as the presumption of innocence. The report outlines effective procedural safeguards in criminal proceedings at EU level which will strengthen an individual’s right to a fair trial. Along with Ireland and Denmark, the UK will not opt in to this Directive so there is no conflict between national constitutional rules and secondary EU law.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the resolution because I consider the presumption of innocence and the right of accused persons to be present at court proceedings to be one of the fundamental principles of any democratic society and should be guaranteed throughout the Union. I am glad that such a proposal is coming, because recently we have seen that the rights of suspects and accused persons are being curtailed in several EU Member States, as well as the principle of the presumption of innocence being undermined. I believe that the proposed directive will strengthen the right to a fair trial in criminal proceedings and strengthen member states' confidence in the criminal justice systems of other Member States. Although some Member States are already following the concept of criminal liability of legal persons according to their national rules, I believe that these rules on certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at court in their own case can help it is precisely the Member States that do not have any concept processed. I believe that, by adopting this directive, we will guarantee a minimum level of protection for the presumption of innocence in all Member States, thereby also strengthening the right of the accused person to be present at the trial in his own case.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. In November 2013, the Commission presented the 'Final Package - Procedural Rights' package containing proposals for three directives. These directives will make it possible to complete the European legal framework in the area of the rights of defence of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings across the EU.  These are key instruments to ensure a fair trial across the EU and to fully respect the rights of the defence. I believe that it is extremely important that this package of measures reinforces the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at a trial in criminal proceedings.  The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right and an essential principle that avoids arbitrariness and abuse in criminal proceedings. The principle of the presumption of innocence contains the right to remain silent, transfers the burden of proof to the prosecution and includes the principle of 'in dubio pro reo' (in doubt in favour of the accused). However, the right to be present at your own trial is a fundamental element of the presumption of innocence, which is currently protected in European law only in the context of the European arrest warrant and the Framework Decision on the recognition of the enforcement of criminal judgments handed down in absentia.  I agree that it is essential to strengthen the protection provided for by these instruments and to ensure the benefit that all suspects and accused persons in criminal proceedings would thus have.  For the sake of the above, I supported the report.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal that builds on the related Directives adopted so far (2010/64/EU on the right of interpretation and translation; 2012/13/EU on the right to information; 2013/48/EU on the right of access to a lawyer in criminal proceedings). The aim of this Directive is to strengthen the right to a fair trial in criminal proceedings by setting minimum rules on certain aspects of the presumption of non-prosecution and the right to be present at trial. By setting minimum rules on the protection of procedural rights of suspects or accused persons, this Directive should strengthen Member States' trust in the criminal justice systems of other Member States, thereby facilitating the mutual recognition of decisions in criminal matters. Taking into account the report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I support this report.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ This draft directive is part of a package of proposals to further strengthen procedural rights for citizens in criminal proceedings, which includes one on safeguards for children, and another on legal aid. Labour MEPs support the idea of establishing minimum standards across the EU in areas as fundamental as the presumption of innocence. The report outlines effective procedural safeguards in criminal proceedings at EU level which will strengthen an individual’s right to a fair trial. Along with Ireland and Denmark, the UK will not opt in to this directive so there is no conflict between national constitutional rules and secondary EU law.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The presumption of ineligency and the right to attend a trial are fundamental rights of the individual. There is no doubt that everyone has the right to defend themses. There are already three rights that anyone can consume, namely the right to translation and interpretation, the right to information and the right to a lawyer in judicial proceedings. This proposal proposes that an individual be presumed innocent before public authorities until proven guilty. The right to remain silent and refusal to cooperate are essential items of this proposal. I support this proposal, because the rights of the individual must not be subject to any influence and each individual has the right to defend his innocence before the judicial authorities.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council to strengthen certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at a trial in criminal proceedings.  I support the establishment of a minimum level of protection for the principle of the presumption of innocence in all Member States and strengthening the right to be present at trial. It is also necessary to ensure a common high level of protection for accused persons in criminal matters in a Member State, without prejudice to the higher standards of protection that may apply in each Member State.  I welcome that the report considers the reversal of the burden of proof in criminal proceedings to be unacceptable and that it insists on the principle that the burden of proving guilt lies with the prosecution.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We supported the report on strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right of the accused to appear in his trial, in criminal proceedings, as procedural procedures must first of all respect fundamental rights and not discriminate. The law must be equal to all. Otherwise, there is increasing questioning and lack of confidence in the justice of society, which leads to violent events and an increase in crime.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is fundamental that the right to a fair trial in criminal proceedings such as fundamental needs is the establishment of rules on certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right of the accused to appear on trial and equal and high-level protection with full guarantee of procedural provisions. At Union level, this translates into an adoption and/or equation with the highest level of protection that may apply in a Member State. However, the arbitrariness and abuses of the pre-inquest and criminal proceedings in the case of the political prosecutions of Golden Dawn in Greece demonstrate, however, that the European institutions apply the case law selectively and apply criminal democracy à la carte, silent and not reacting to the violation of fundamental principles such as the principle of "in dubio pro reo" (in doubt in favour of the accused) and the presumption of innocence.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The presumption of innocence is one of the fundamental human rights reflected both in the legal systems of individual states and in international law. This principle is key to avoiding abuse during criminal proceedings.  Unfortunately, despite the presumption of innocence in the national criminal systems of the Member States for centuries, there have still been violations of this principle. Harmonisation of the law on the presumption of innocence will ensure minimum standards for fair trial throughout the European Union. This will strengthen the rights of European citizens. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The presumption of innocence is one of the concepts underlying the legal systems of the EU Member States. However, its application in practice has a number of difficulties related to possible, sometimes involuntary, infringements of this right. One of the main problems that arise is the violation of the right to remain silent in the context that this may lead to the indictment of a suspect. Another issue concerns ensuring the proportionality of punitive measures with the amount of damage created. Problems also arise when the overexposure of a suspect, sometimes produced with an important contribution by public authorities, unduly harms his rights of defence.  However, the task of providing evidence in a trial must remain the responsibility of the prosecution, in accordance with the principles of law existing at European level. The use of coercive measures to obtain evidence directly from the accused is not compatible with European practices and should lead to the invalidation of that evidence. At the same time, the right to be present at your own trial, under the conditions of criminal proceedings, must be guaranteed, unless the accused person waives this right. The adoption of the current report is an additional guarantee of respect for the rights of European citizens.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The main elements of the proposal therefore relate to the principle of the presumption of innocence, the burden of proof, the right not to incriminate oneself and not to cooperate, the right to remain silent, the right to attend a trial and the right to a new trial procedure. It's a good report and I've spoken out for it.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement reached on the directive on the presumption of innocence. This directive aims to ensure that the principle of the presumption of innocence is applied throughout the EU and the Member States must act accordingly until the guilt of the suspect has been proved. The text adopted recognises that the burden of proof must lie with the prosecution and that the accused must have the benefit of any doubt. Additionally, the right to remain silent must not be used against individuals, a European Parliament press release explains. Once formally adopted by the Council, the Member States will have two years to transpose the text.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. Too often, the European Union is seen as a technocratic monster far removed from the concerns of our fellow citizens. Yet it is a great tool to promote and guarantee the rights of every European.  At a time when Europe is going through a wave of regression of human rights and freedom of expression, I fully support this report which aims to defend the right to the presumption of innocence and to guarantee the principle of a fair trial for all.  Faced with the Council, the European Commission and the right, the European Parliament has fought against any possibility of reversing the burden of proof: everyone is presumed innocent until proven guilty. This proposed directive, once approved by the Council, will have to be transposed into the law of all Member States. Thus, every European will henceforth be presumed innocent, will be entitled to a defence and will be able to remain silent during a trial.  It is by building bulwarks against arbitrariness, by guaranteeing the rights of all, that the European Union is great and closer to its citizens. I therefore welcome the adoption of this text.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. \u2012 Mr President, as a member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, I voted in favour of the report. The directive that we have been debating in Parliament today will lead to the completion of the EU legal framework on the right of defence of suspects and accused persons in criminal proceedings throughout the European Union. The Directive includes the measures necessary to ensure a fair trial in the European Union and absolute respect for the rights of the defence guaranteed by the Treaties of the European Union, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and the European Convention on Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. The Directive, which is about strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial in criminal proceedings, contains a number of useful recommendations, in particular of which I would point out the right of the defendant to be presumed innocent until proven guilty.
