I would also point out one of the most important rights, namely the right of presence in a trial that must be available to all defendants and suspects, as this should reduce the number of cases in which they are convicted in absentia. While I consider this report to contain many useful provisions to protect suspects' right to a fair trial, I believe that the proposal to extend the scope of the Directive to legal authorities is unfounded and unacceptable.  That's why I voted abstention.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. -u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council to strengthen certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at a trial in criminal proceedings, as I believe that the three directives entitled 'Final package - procedural rights' will help to complete the European legal framework in the area of the rights of defence of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings. Respect for the rights of the defence and the trial itself will thus be fairer throughout the European Union.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I agree to any proposal that serves to improve the legal certainty of people and ensure that everyone has the right to be presumed innocent until proven otherwise.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. It is a matter of adopting a proposal for a directive to strengthen certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to attend trial in criminal proceedings. The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right. The principle that the burden of proof hangs over the prosecution and that any possible doubt about guilt should benefit the prosecution, the right to remain silent, the right not to self-incriminate and not to cooperate, the right to attend a trial are also central elements of the presumption of innocence. These are principles that we recognize. However, this report is of the opinion that the Commission has taken too minimal an approach and questions the "lack of ambition" of this initial proposal which would risk harmonising the national provisions "down". Criminal law is the jurisdiction of the Member States. We oppose EU interference and any attempt to create a 'European' criminal law. I am voting against this text.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has presented a final package on procedural rights, which contains three proposals for directives following the first three instruments adopted under the EU Roadmap for the Strengthening of Procedural Rights. These three Directives make it possible to finalise the existing European legal toolbox on rights to protect suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings in the European Union: the three Directives are an essential instrument for guaranteeing a fair trial throughout the European Union and ensuring full respect for the rights of defence guaranteed by the EU Treaties, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and the European Convention on Human Rights (ECE). I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ Voted in favour so legal guarantees for the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial will be harmonised and strengthened in Member States’ laws on criminal proceedings.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The presumption of innocence is a fundamental principle of the legal process and one of the most important rights of defense. Under this Directive, Member States will have to ensure that suspects and defendants are presumed innocent and only cease to be innocent when the law proves their guilt. We are talking about a text which has been the subject of broad compromise in the legislative process, so I think it is appropriate to vote in its favour.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive as it seems very important to us to introduce minimum criteria at European level which will enable Member States to respect the presumption of innocence and other rights of detainees, such as being present during their trial. One of the main ideas introduced in this proposal for a Directive is the shielding of the right to access of all detainees to some form of legal aid, even if provisionally. We find it positive that, in the face of the regressive changes in the judicial systems of different European countries, the presumption of innocence will be shielded and trials prevented in the absence of the accused. Some of the key issues for us have not been included, such as the inclusion of the right to remain silent or some measures relating to the custody of evidence, often violated in the Spanish State in cases related to the persecution of social activists. However, we believe that the end result introduces improvements by shielding rights and introducing measures to protect the rights of detainees.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. The presumption of innocence is one of the most fundamental principles of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Judging within criminal proceedings is a tricky and dangerous undertaking: mistakes can and should never be an option. The damage of a judicial error in criminal proceedings is immense, its impact can ruin a person's life. The purpose of this new directive is therefore to ensure that the presumption of innocence in criminal cases throughout the EU is better respected.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The protection of the presumption of innocence in the current context is fundamental.  It cannot be variable geometry depending on individuals or context. The proposal for a directive submitted to the European Parliament aims to implement a minimum base of rights for those charged.  While the European Commission's initial proposal for harmonisation towards the bottom of the directive, the European Parliament proposed a more ambitious text and reiterated that the presumption of innocence is there to avoid forms of abuse and arbitrariness and to protect the right to a fair trial.  In particular, the European Parliament has introduced provisions reaffirming the right to remain silent, the right to attend trial and the principle that any doubt benefits the accused. These proposals were accepted by the Council.  At a time when the security and the risk of arbitrariness are spreading throughout the Member States of the Union, it seems important to implement a European base of rights to protect the rights of defence. So I voted for this directive.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report contains three proposals for directives, following the adoption of the first three instruments of the European Union roadmap for strengthening procedural rights. These three directives aim to complete the European legal framework on the right of defence of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings throughout the European Union. At a time when the reduction of the rights of suspects and accused persons is underway in certain Member States of the European Union, it should be stressed that the presumption of innocence is a fundamental right and an essential principle for avoiding arbitrariness and any abuse in criminal proceedings, as well as a principle underlying the protection of the right to a fair trial. Being fundamental, in accordance with the content of the proposal, it is, however, part of the creation of a European legal framework which, in order to harmonise between Member States, aims to impose national legislation.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Criminal law is a national issue and does not require European harmonisation. There is also a risk that this proposal will make criminal prosecution even more difficult. I therefore reject this report.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I abstained from the EUROPEAN Parliament resolution on the presumption of innocence and right to be present in criminal proceedings. It is a question of introducing minimum requirements for the rule of law in the EU Member States in order to strengthen mutual trust in their respective national procedures. In particular, it concerns self-evident things such as the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at the proceedings. The aim is to clarify the requirements for a fair trial under Article 6(1) of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (ECHR). The project builds on past work. I voted against this resolution because I believe that it is up to all Member States to ensure a fair trial if they want to be EU members. This must be a prerequisite for admission. It is not clear to me why an absolute matter of course still has to be enforced by EU law.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This draft directive is part of a package of proposals to further strengthen procedural rights for citizens in criminal proceedings, which include one on safeguards for children and another on legal aid. Labour MEPs support the idea of establishing minimum standards across the EU in areas as fundamental as the presumption of innocence. The report outlines effective procedural safeguards in criminal proceedings at EU level which will strengthen an individual’s right to a fair trial.  Along with the Ireland and Denmark, the UK will not opt in to this directive, so there is no conflict between national constitutional rules and secondary EU law.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour following the rapporteur's proposal. Griesbeck in this report for which the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs was responsible.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. I consider that, in the field of judicial and criminal matters, it is important to defend the rights of the accused and ensure that his moral integrity is always protected and guaranteed. To this end, his treatment as presumed innocent is fundamental until proven otherwise. Also, giving him the right to be present at the trial itself is another way of allowing him to enjoy his full rights, which is linked to the presumption of innocence. I believe that what this report stands for and asks for are fundamental principles of the legal process and a right that should be offered to every citizen. I firmly believe in the benefits these laws would bring to society and that is why I show my support for the report. To support my position on this, I have the backing of my experience as a Spanish citizen, since in my country all these laws are in force and the functioning of the judicial area is satisfactory.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 The presumption of innocence is a fundamental principle of judicial proceedings, which is why I have decided to support this directive, which reinforces aspects of the presumption of innocence and the right to be present in criminal proceedings. I consider it important that the same standards of application of the presumption of innocence be set in all Member States of the European Union. I also agree with other proposed points of the directive, such as the fact that the right to remain silent does not automatically imply a confession to acts on the part of the defendant.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the Directive on the presumption of innocence. This Directive aims to lay down minimum rules on the presumption of innocence in order to ensure that everyone within the European Union enjoys at least a minimum level of protection. The rules themselves concern, in particular, the right to be present at the trial, the right not to be found guilty until the final decision on the case, the extent of the evidence needed, the burden of proof, as well as other procedural rights. It is, of course, very important that the principle of the presumption of innocence is strictly respected in criminal proceedings until all doubt is established and decided upon. On the other hand, however, I do not agree with some of the elements contained in the proposal for a directive. For example, the directive proposed too broad remedies in case the right to be present at a trial is violated, which, due to their excessive benevolence, may eventually end in their abuse. That is why, although I believe that the presumption of innocence is one of the fundamental principles that must be respected, I abstained in this vote.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is based on the presentation by the Commission of the 'Final Package – Procedural Rights', which contains three proposals for directives, following the adoption of the first three instruments of the European Union Roadmap for strengthening procedural rights. These three directives aim to complete the European legal framework on the right of defence of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings throughout the European Union. The presumption of innocence is a fundamental right and an essential principle for avoiding arbitrariness and any abuse in criminal proceedings and a principle underlying the protection of the right to a fair trial. Being fundamental, in accordance with the content of the proposal, it is part of the creation of a European legal framework aimed at harmonisation between Member States, and it is intended to be imposed on national legislation.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal for a directive lays down minimum rules on certain aspects of the presumption of innocence, the principle of legality and compliance with the principle of adversariality and the balance between the rights of the parties to criminal proceedings.  It points out, inter alia, that the presumption of innocence is infringed if judicial or other public authorities mark by means of a judicial decision or a public statement of suspects or accused persons as if their guilt had already been proven without prior proven guilt in accordance with the law.  I support the proposal for a directive, as it aims to provide fundamental procedural guarantees in criminal proceedings and to allow the right to a fair trial, without prejudice to the higher standards of protection that may apply in each Member State.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – At Community level, the legal system for finding personal protective equipment (PPE) in the single market has been in place for more than a quarter of a century. However, it is clear that, given how far since 1989, both Union legislation in this area and the technical development of PPE have come, it is clear that the time has come to modernise the Council Directive, which also regulates the placing of PPE in the Single Market of the European Union. I support this orientation because personal protection systems, which are actively applied not only by professionals such as firefighters or soldiers, but also by other people who have become necessary for some reason, must comply with a number of different rules, first of all in terms of quality and application. Consequently, I welcome this proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council aimed at promoting these aspects of the use of PPE, and I repeat that I voted in favour.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo comh maith. Dar ndóigh tá an-chuid oibre déanta ag an rapóirtéir, Vicky Ford, agus tá moladh tuillte aici maidir leis seo. This is an important legislative change and I am pleased that products will now be subject to a conformity assessment, informing buyers of this, and contact details should be on the product in order to help market surveillance authorities. I support this report and the rapporteur’s calls for linguistic obligations for importers, such as the use of the official language of the importer country in marking their contact details on the equipment and a use of language that is easily understandable for consumers for precautionary instructions. I particularly agree with the rapporteur’s call for an obligation on the manufacturers to ensure that instructions are clear and understandable and to ensure that recorded performances, i.e. to check standards of the protection provided, are all in order. Transparency and efficiency is of the utmost importance to ensure maximum protection of EU citizens in the context of personal protective equipment.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, it is a fact that the protection of people really goes hand in hand with technological developments and alludes to both opportunities and the principles of the single internal market. It must be acknowledged that the introduction or improvement of rules for the protection of persons will simply have an impact on both the budgets of legal entities and, of course, specific workers, as well as public budgets. However, in supporting this proposal, to which I subscribe – and I really thank the rapporteur, because she has done an excellent job – I have decided to compare this support and put it on the scales with the risks that I have outlined here. I think that in the protection of people, in the protection of workers, we should not lose the opportunities that the new legislation will bring. That is, although there are some problems, we cannot suffer relief.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has opposed this proposal on the principle that we are against further harmonisation of the internal market. This relates specifically to the change of the legislation from a directive to a regulation. Furthermore, we are also particularly concerned with the inclusion of products that are intended for private use against heat (i.e. oven gloves) in the scope of this legislation. UKIP believes this breaches the principle of proportionality and we therefore support the UK Government’s recommendation in voting against this proposal.
politicalGroup: The Earl of) Dartmouth Mike Hookem Diane James Margot Parker and Julia Reid (EFDD
partyIdeology: The Earl of) Dartmouth Mike Hookem Diane James Margot Parker and Julia Reid (EFDD

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite introducing positive aspects seeking to improve the safety of such individual equipment, the Regulation maintains aspects tailored to the interests of industry. This proposal leads to certain gaps which may pose problems in the implementation of the precautionary principle in the production and marketing of such individual equipment. Parliament's proposal allows the outsourcing of evaluation bodies, which poses a threat to the safety of those products by leaving decisions on compliance with established security measures in the hands of the market. However, the Regulation in turn contains measures that will improve the safety of these equipment. That is why I have decided to abstain in the vote on this report.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. This text proposes a regulation to replace the 1989 Directive on Personal Protective Equipment (EPI). Changes include an expansion of the PPE categories (e.g. custom PPE), the need to attach a compliance statement to each EPI, the designation of new certifying bodies, and a shortened compliance period. I voted against this text because the amendments it proposes will have a financial impact on manufacturers, and therefore on households and businesses. In addition, they will lead to a consequent complexity of their production chain, which are already subject to very rigid standards.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This European Parliament regulation, which I voted in favour of, brings current legislation into line with the provision on the package of legislative measures on goods adopted in 2008 by European Commission Decision 768/2008, which referred to a common framework for the marketing of products. This concerns the requirements for the design and manufacture of personal protective equipment placed on the market in order to ensure the protection of users and the rules on their free movement in the Union. It also includes rules on market surveillance and obligations for economic operators as well as employers. Finally, the original report was adopted in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection in April 2015, followed by four tripartite dialogues aimed at finding an agreement at first reading.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report will result in an additional cost of production of personal protective equipment (PPE), which will increase prices and put a stick in the wheels of manufacturers who are being added increasingly stringent standards. In the end, it will be households that will be penalized since they will no longer be able to buy this type of equipment that has become too expensive despite negligible safety gains. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This was a bizarre report, written by a British Conservative MEP, yet opposed by Her Majesty’s Conservative Government. It rather implies that the left hand does not know what the right hand is doing. On the subject of hands, the inclusion of items such as oven gloves and umbrellas in ‘personal protective equipment’ is rather stretching a point. I find little to add to the comments of Her Majesty’s Government, which notes that the inclusion of such items ‘breaches the principle of proportionality’.  Indeed, I see no reason why the UK government should not have the competence to deal with such matters as oven gloves and umbrellas instead. It was therefore entirely consistent with my principles to vote against.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Since 1989, the placing of personal protective equipment on the EU market has been fully harmonised in accordance with Council Directive 89/686/EEC. For the last 25 years, this Directive has ensured the functioning of the single market. Nevertheless, the existing legislation on personal protective equipment must be updated under the New Legislative Framework (RSAS), which is a toolkit for the rationalisation and simplification of single market goods rules. Given the complexity and overlap of current legislative requirements, this Regulation clarifies the role of economic operators, strengthens cooperation between actors and introduces common definitions. The powers of market surveillance authorities to track and return unsafe goods placed on the single market have also been clarified.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have approved this report, which aims to broaden the scope of the current Personal Protective Equipment Directive (any device or means intended to be worn or maintained by a person to protect them from one or more risks that could threaten their life or health) in order to better protect the health and safety of PPE users. In particular, it eliminates exclusions from products for private use that provide protection against heat, humidity and water.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on personal protective equipment. The technical aim of the text is to replace Council Directive 89/686/EEC, which presents problems of clarity and repetitiveness. In general terms, it is committed to protecting the safety of workers by tackling a twofold problem involving, on the one hand, the non-use of personal protective systems and, on the other, their incorrect use. The new regulation aims to update and simplify the regulatory framework, in particular by clarifying the points relating to the linking system and the obligation of importers and distributors to inform supervisory authorities in the event of a risk arising from non-compliant PPE. In view of the importance of these proposals, I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the Ford report.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We abstain in the vote on this report because, broadly speaking, the proposal for a Regulation is positive as it replaces a Directive dating back to 1989 and clarifies terms which gave rise to ambiguous interpretations. However, we see two important problems that have not been corrected: firstly, that the number of stakeholders who responded to the Commission's survey to assess the impact was very low. Secondly, the new legislation is too heavy for small businesses, as the new legislation will result in comparatively high translation and bureaucracy costs. This was corrected by amendments in the committee, but they were rejected. That's why we abstained.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank rapporteur Vicky Ford for her work on this excellent report on personal protective equipment, which I have supported. This Regulation lays down the requirements on the design and manufacture of personal protective equipment to be placed on the market, in order to ensure the protection of the health and safety of users and to lay down rules on the free movement of equipment in the Union.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report must implement a regulation that will have financial consequences for epips manufacturers (compliance and administrative burden) and will therefore ultimately weigh on the price and therefore on consumers and businesses. Manufacturers are already subject to strict standards and the legislature will force manufacturers to constantly challenge. Health and safety improvements are minimal and do not justify these new standards. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 While I agree with the need to simplify and update legislation on safety and personal protection, I would have preferred these changes to have been made by means of a directive rather than a regulation. That is why I abstained.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have abstained on these three reports on the establishment of new regulations (instead of directives). The consequence of these reports is that no EU Member State may legislate for higher protection and environmental rules with regard to cableway installations, appliances for the combustion of gaseous fuels and personal protective equipment. I think that is fundamentally wrong. Having a minimum limit on environmental and protection measures that all Member States must achieve is one thing, but it is wrong to decide that no Member State should be able to improve its legislation independently in terms of protecting people and the environment. That's why I put my voice down.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. With the proposal for a Regulation on Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), it is desired to harmonise the common framework for the marketing of these products. In particular, the Regulation clarifies the role of economic operators, strengthens cooperation between different participants and introduces common definitions. The priority objective of this report has been that worker safety can only be protected by truly effective equipment, since workplace accidents are very often caused not only by the non-use of adequate protective equipment but also by their misuse. The proposal also includes rules on market surveillance and obligations of economic operators as well as workers. That is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it is necessary to update the Personal Protective Equipment Directive, which has been in force for the last 25 years. The current legislative requirements are confusing and duplicative, this Regulation clarifies the role of economic operators, strengthens cooperation between actors and introduces common definitions. The European Parliament's ex-ante impact assessment of this proposal noted that the Commission's decision to extend the scope of the original directive was a concern. Parliament does not consider it necessary to significantly adapt the scope, since this draft proposal primarily seeks to ensure the proper functioning and implementation of the regulatory framework and not the achievement of its objectives. Therefore, in order to ensure legal certainty for the actors in this sector, the rapporteur sought to have the scope similar to that of the original directive. In order to ensure the swift conclusion of negotiations on this document, Parliament considers that many of the Council's proposals for alignment with the New Legislative Framework need to be approved.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. -u2012 Personal protective equipment is used to meet a large number of people in Europe, either professionally or in their spare time.  The very title, that is to say, 'protective equipment', points out that the production of such equipment, which protects an individual from certain dangerous effects, must be properly regulated and regulated. Such equipment must therefore be properly tested and the type of production and the materials from which these products are produced are important. I therefore support the efforts of the Commission and the Council to improve the conditions for the use of PPE contained in the proposed report.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. As a Doctor of Occupational and Sports, I support the report because it includes all important elements for workers' health. Congratulations to my colleague Stihler for the work done.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. The Report on Personal Protective Equipment is to implement a new regulation making small changes that will have significant financial consequences for EPI manufacturers. The additional cost of production induced by this revision of the regulation will be borne by households and businesses while improvements in safety and health are minimal and do not justify the establishment of new standards. For all these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the legislation governing trade in PPE (Personal Protective Equipment) needs some small changes that increase its efficiency and, at the same time, improve the safety conditions of the individuals who use them.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 PPE (Personal Protective Equipment) have been present in the EU market since 1989. For twenty-five years, existing legislation in this area has enabled the single market to function, but today it needs to be updated in line with the new regulatory framework (NQN) which outlines the package of measures aimed at streamlining and simplifying the regulations on goods in the single market. In particular, in response to the concerns expressed with regard to the existing regulatory requirements considered unclear and repetitive, this regulation clarifies the role of economic operators, strengthens cooperation between actors and introduces common definitions. The common NQN approach is to be supported because it improves and clarifies more effectively the competences of market surveillance authorities and allows the location and return of unsafe goods that may have been introduced into the single market, thus improving worker safety and the quality of goods on the market.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The functioning of the European Union's single market is intrinsically linked to strengthening cooperation between the various parties involved and could be optimised by introducing common definitions for harmonising and simplifying commodity regulations throughout the market, which this Regulation also proposes. Recent developments in communications and the need to adapt individual protective equipment (PPE) to its end-users make it necessary to implement specific tools to enable end-users to understand correctly how to use PPE, in particular to protect them from workplace risks. If workers are aware of these issues and properly and properly informed, they will not only be protected, but also involved in matters that directly concern them.  Ensuring the safety of workers can only be achieved by means of instruments of undeniable effectiveness, since accidents at work are often caused not only by the failure to use adequate protection systems, but also by their misuse. I voted in favour of the proposed measures, which ensure that the existing directive cannot give rise to interpretations that undermine its effectiveness and legal certainty.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 For this measure too, the issue is similar to other legislative texts recently approved in the Committee on the Internal Market. In this case, the rapporteur is the same president as IMCO. Simplification and updating requirements on issues such as safety have justified the European Commission's updating of Directive 686 of 1989. Our delegation would have preferred, here too, to have a directive, rather than a regulation. Note that Italy is the leader in the European production of personal protective equipment. The abstention vote is dictated by the need to be cautious about rules that could potentially create costs of adaptation to our production system. In fact, The Italian companies have not sent us any elements of concern and the text resulting from the agreement with the Council seems peaceful and does not bring elements of tension.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on personal protective equipment. As indicated in the text voted on, it is necessary to replace Council Directive 89/686/EEC in order to update the entire regulatory framework for this type of goods on the single market and to streamline and simplify the sources of law still in force. This regulation clarifies the role of economic operators, strengthens cooperation between all stakeholders, introduces common definitions and specifies the competences of market surveillance authorities. Importers and distributors are also required to inform the manufacturer and market surveillance authorities in the case of non-compliant devices. The text before us fully achieves the objectives that had been identified and I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report which had as its aim the replacement of an existing piece of legislation with a regulation. My reasons for abstaining were that there was little to no consultation with stakeholders on the initial proposals, meaning that the environmental impact, costs and red tape associated with new provisions were not taken into account.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as the current Council Directive on Personal Protective Equipment needs updates and alterations in line with the modern trends and requirements. The report outlines measures that will, among others, allow the consumer to be more informed.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Ford's report because the text aims, among other things, to harmonise the health and safety requirements of personal protective equipment (PPE) in all Member States.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and the position of the rapporteur, who argues that strict requirements should be laid down with regard to personal protective equipment. Given that this proposal is primarily aimed at modernising and simplifying a system that is already functioning effectively, the rapporteur believes that it is not necessary to make significant changes to the objectives. On the contrary, on the basis of the reservations expressed by the Member States and associations of undertakings in the field of safety equipment, the amendments tabled are intended to restore clarity in certain areas.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The vote on the renewal of the regulatory framework for personal protective equipment can only always be timely, as it directly concerns a large number of economic operators, while at the same time its implications reach all citizens. In this light, I believe that any attempt to modernise and harmonise the current rules has a positive impact on Europe and that is why I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on personal protective equipment. Since 1989, the presence on the EU market of personal protective equipment (PPE) has been fully harmonized by Council Directive 89/686/EEC. Nevertheless, the current IPR legislation needs to be updated in line with the new regulatory framework, which is a package of measures designed to streamline and simplify the regulations on goods in the single market. The IPR Regulation replacing existing Directive 89/686/EEC responds to the need to increase the protection of the health and safety of users and to ensure the free movement of PPE in the EU market.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 Italian companies are European leaders in the production of personal protective equipment. This further harmonisation of technical standards to reduce the possible non-tariff barriers faced by our products when they enter other markets is therefore very good news. The great strength of the EU, and the greatest reason why it is worth staying in Europe, is precisely this huge potential market for Italian products, and helping companies to seize this potential is our task as Members of Parliament. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal for the Regulation on Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) aims at updating the current Council Directive 89/686/EEC and aligning it with the New Legislative Framework (NLF) on the marketing of products. It is important that guidelines for using Personal Protective Equipment are transparent to avoid misuse, ensuring protection of EU citizens. I support the proposed amendments for technical and linguistic clarifications and the use of the official language of the importer country to be clearly marked on all PPE.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Regulation on personal protective equipment updates, in the alignment of the New Legislative Framework, Directive 89/686/EEC, harmonising and giving clarity to regulatory requirements in this area. Although the Directive has successfully achieved its objectives in creating a single market and ensuring a high level of protection for users of personal protective equipment, some problems have been encountered in its implementation.  PPE are any means or devices intended to be used by a person against possible threatening risks to their health or safety during the exercise of a given activity. I support the Ford Report because I believe that this new proposal amends and clarifies a number of provisions of the existing Directive, aligning it with the provisions of Decision No 768/2008/EC establishing a common framework for the marketing of products.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because it will enable us to work in a safer working environment, while at the same time providing workers with reliable protection.  The current legal situation is inadequate and I therefore welcome the fact that the report harmonises definitions and clarifies the tasks of the economic operators concerned. This will enable us to raise the quality of the labour market to a dignified level and ensure that we work in itself.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I agree with the update of the existing directive to bring it into line with the new legislative framework, as well as the provision for the instrument of the regulation that improves harmonisation between the different national systems. The improvement of personal protective equipment undoubtedly strengthens the safety of the wearer and reduces health risks.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal for a regulation on personal protective equipment aims at updating the current directive and aligning it with the New Legislative Framework on the marketing of products. The proposal has a harmonised approach regarding the obligations on economic operators, improved cooperation between actors and common definitions. I voted in favour.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: in writing. ‒ Personal protective equipment (PPE) is worn or used to protect a person’s health and safety, such as goggles or helmets worn by builders on a construction site.  Today’s vote will help improve the existing rules, and ensure better compliance of PPE manufacturers. Having common standards across the whole European market helps improve effectiveness, while lessening costs.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite introducing positive aspects seeking to improve the safety of such individual equipment, the Regulation maintains aspects tailored to the interests of industry. This proposal leads to certain gaps which may pose problems in the implementation of the precautionary principle in the production and marketing of such individual equipment. Parliament's proposal allows the outsourcing of evaluation bodies, which poses a threat to the safety of those products by leaving decisions on compliance with established security measures in the hands of the market. However, the Regulation in turn contains measures that will improve the safety of these equipment. That is why I have decided to abstain in the vote on this report.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 Council Directive 89/686/EEC fully harmonises the placing of personal protective equipment on the EU market. The Directive has enabled a functioning single market. The regulation approved today and drafted in the codecision procedure updates this Council Directive. As the proposal focuses primarily on modernising and simplifying an already well-functioning system, Parliament's rapporteur considered that there was no need to significantly change its objectives. The amendments focused on creating clarity in a number of areas. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report is the completion of one of three technical adaptation procedures updating the legislation applicable to personal protective equipment products, cableways and gas appliances in relation to the 'new legal framework'. Under the new legal framework, the obligations imposed on manufacturers, importers and market regulators are largely harmonised, reducing administrative burdens and increasing legal certainty for all actors involved in the manufacture and supervision of products placed on the EU market. Reducing the administrative burden – I am in favour. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which will update the existing Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) legislation in line with the New Legislative Framework (NLF), which is a package of measures designed to streamline and simplify regulations on goods across the Single Market. This deals with requirements for the design and manufacture of PPE which is being made available on the market in order to ensure the protection of users and rules on its free movement in the Union. The report deals with the modernisation and simplification of an already well-functioning system regarding PPE.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I support the final agreement on personal protective equipment, which avoids any unnecessary expansion of the scope of the Regulation. I particularly welcome the exclusion of oven gloves from the proposal, which the Commission had originally suggested to cover even though these products were not regulated as PPE previously. Their inclusion in the scope would have entailed a significant increase in costs for manufacturers of such gloves, without any clear corresponding consumer benefit.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Regulation of Parliament and of the Council on Personal Protective Equipment (IPR) simplifies and improves the legislation in force, consisting of a now obsolete directive. A legislative measure that finally defines a harmonised and clear European regulatory framework, interprets and applies the provisions on everyday products for European citizens and workers, such as protective clothing and headgear, life jackets and sunglasses. The regulation I voted on also establishes common technical standards, compliance and safety requirements and specific rules for market surveillance of personal protective equipment. A series of technical measures that serve to further increase the health protection of users of these products, protect their safety and ensure fair and simplified conditions of competition for European companies producing such products. The updating of European standards is necessary for the completion of the single market and for the proper functioning of a sector relevant to European and Italian industry, such as personal protective equipment, which has over 4000 companies and an average annual turnover estimated at several billion. A sector of which Italy is a leader and main producer.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report aims to update EU legislation on personal protective equipment, dating back to 1989. The text provides for harmonization measures to ensure better protection for users of equipment such as bicycle helmets or kitchen gloves through common standards. Supporting these objectives, I voted for this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported this proposal because it contributes to greater clarity and improved legislation for personal protective equipment. This measure is beneficial to users as it aims to strengthen the protection of their safety and health.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the current legislation on personal protective equipment (PPE) requires an update in line with the new legislative framework. In response to the concerns expressed with regard to the current regulatory requirements considered unclear and repetitive, this regulation clarifies the role of economic operators, specifies the competences of market surveillance authorities, strengthens cooperation between the different actors involved and introduces common definitions.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The replacement of the 1989 Personal Protective Equipment Directive with the new text supported by this report constitutes a significant extension of the scope of the standards that affect many producers of protective equipment. This is a financially burdensome transformation for businesses, risking rising prices. The safety gain brought by these new standards is not up to the regulatory and economic impact. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a Council regulation on personal protective equipment. This report relates to updating the legislation applicable to products in the field of personal protective equipment, cableway installations and gas appliances to the 'new legislative framework'. Under the new regulatory framework, obligations imposed on manufacturers, importers and market surveillance authorities are largely standardised, which will reduce the administrative burden and improve legal certainty for all actors involved in the production and control of products placed on the EU market. The report was prepared by my colleague Vicki Ford and I congratulate her on the job well done. I believe that the report is consistent with the position of the group and my personal one, namely more rights of the Member States.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The well-being of professionals in different sectors who must use personal protective equipment is something that concerns all citizens of the Member States. We believe that upgrading and updating existing legislation and related directives will fill many gaps in user safety. There is a need to fill the security gap created by the products that are mostly imported from Asia and we hope that this will be reduced.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The placement of personal protective equipment (PPE) on the EU market has been fully harmonised by Council Directive 89/686/EEC. In the 25 years that have followed, this Directive has enabled the single market to function smoothly. However, the current legislation on PPE needs to be updated. This Regulation clarifies the role of economic operators, strengthens cooperation between actors and introduces common definitions. The proposal deals essentially with the modernisation and simplification of a system whose operation is already good and no substantial changes to its objectives are necessary. Thus, on the basis of the reservations issued by the Member States and the federations of the security industries, the amendments are intended to clarify certain aspects. The report also proposes the elimination of the maximum five-year period of validity applicable to the EU-type examination certificate, taking into account the reservations issued by economic operators.  I voted in favour.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it involves too much red tape and poses a risk of increased production costs for businesses.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 It is proposed that Directive 89/686/EEC be replaced by a regulation, given the little flexibility in transposition of directive. The purpose of this Directive was to harmonise health and safety requirements for Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) in all Member States and to remove barriers to trade in such equipment. This Regulation lays down requirements for the design and manufacture of PPE intended to be made available on the market in order to ensure the protection of users' health and safety and to lay down rules on the free movement of PPE within the EU. It is essential that PPE does not endanger the health or safety of persons, domestic animals or property. It is therefore imperative that health and safety rules are well defined and, therefore, that they be respected. On the other hand, it is also essential that SMEs in Member States operating in this sector, in particular manufacturers, be able to receive the necessary support (technical and financial) to respond correctly and in a timely manner to the changes introduced by the Regulation, as such legal changes should not be a covert way of favouring the largest companies in the sector and, consequently, increasing the concentration of market power.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the measures it contains favour a reduction in administrative burdens and greater legal certainty for all those involved in the production and supervision of products placed on the EU market.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: In writing ‒ The placing on the Market of Personal Protective Equipment on the European Union has been regulated by Council Directive 89/686/EEC since 1989. However, after such a long period of time, the time has come to update the existing legislation in this area in line with the new rules on goods within the single market. I fully support the strict requirements concerning personal protective equipment, because this proposal in question focuses only on modernising and simplifying an already well-functioning and existing system that has been in operation in the European Union for years.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The well-being of professionals in different sectors who have to use personal protective equipment is something that concerns all citizens of the Member States. I believe that upgrading and updating existing legislation and related directives will fill many gaps in user safety. I also believe that the dimensions of the security problem posed by imported products from Asia in particular will be limited, which is why I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on personal protective equipment.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The regulation aligns the current legislation to the provisions of the goods package adopted in 2008 and in particular to the Decision 768/2008/EC on a common framework for the marketing of products. This concerns requirements for the design and manufacture of personal protective equipment (PPE) which is being made available on the market in order to ensure the protection of users and rules on its free movement in the Union. It includes rules on market surveillance and obligations for economic operators as well as employers. The committee vote was uncontroversial. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the strict requirements for personal protective equipment. As the proposal focuses primarily on modernising and simplifying an already well-functioning system, the rapporteur considers that there is no need to significantly change its objectives. Instead, on the basis of the stated interests of Member States and security industry associations, the amendments focused on creating clarity in a number of areas.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the need to update legislation regulating personal protective equipment, which dates back to 1989. In its twenty-five years, this Directive has enabled an operational single market, but it is now necessary to update under the new legislative framework, clarify the role of economic operators, strengthen cooperation and introduce common definitions.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on personal protective equipment because I shared the need highlighted by the European Commission to modernise the existing legislation, which dates back to the 1990s, with regard to the evolution of the regulatory framework for the labelling of available products and technologies. I am in favour of legislation that guarantees legal certainty for market operators, protects the health and safety of workers and users by combining market requirements and safety at work. I believe, in fact, that the latter can only be guaranteed with really effective devices that are calibrated with respect to the characteristics of the user. I am in favour of legislation that allows a sector in which Italian industry has always been a leader to grow further, with a harmonisation of European rules that eliminates those unfair competitors from the market and that recognizes the quality of products also with regard to the safety of those who use them. I therefore welcome the definition of the different categories of users, the requirements for technical documentation, including through the use of new technologies, and the role assigned to national supervisory authorities.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. As a social policy expert, I support every measure to promote and improve the applicability of osh." Personal protective equipment plays a crucial role – it saves lives. I therefore voted in favour of the excellent report by group colleague Vicky Ford.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ The use of requisite personal protective equipment can be essential for a person’s health and safety, be it at home or at work. I voted in favour of this proposal, which will harmonise and improve the existing rules in this area and thus ensure better compliance of PPE manufacturers.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 It is necessary to strike the right balance between the greatest possible consumer protection and the additional costs this entails for producers so that small and medium-sized enterprises do not go bankrupt. The shadow rapporteur for our group has tabled five amendments which were moving in this direction in the Commission. Since the final text of the report does not reflect our proposals, we have chosen to abstain in the final vote in plenary.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution to update the existing personal protective equipment (PPE) legislation. This revision is in line with the New Legislative Framework (NLF) which is a package of measures designed to streamline and simplify the regulation of goods across the Single Market. Given that this proposal deals primarily with the modernisation and simplification of an already well-functioning system, this update correctly focuses on some concerns expressed by Member States. In particular, it now requires importers and distributors to inform the manufacturer, as well as Market Surveillance Authorities MSA, where they believe there is a risk of non-conforming PPE. Furthermore, it will require Member States to notify manufacturers if a notified body has ceased activity and requires any appeal procedure to be transparent and accessible.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to support this report as since 1989, the placing of personal protective equipment on the EU market has been fully harmonised through Council Directive 89/686/EEC). In the intervening 25 years, this directive has enabled a functioning single market. Despite this, the existing PPE legislation is in need of updating in line with the New Legislative Framework (NLF) which is a package of measures designed to streamline and simplify regulations of goods across the Single Market. In particular, in response to concerns that current regulatory requirements are confusing and duplicative, the Regulation clarifies the role of economic operators, reinforces cooperation between actors and introduces common definitions. The common approach under the NLF also clarifies the powers of market surveillance authorities enabling the tracking and returning of unsafe goods placed on the single market. The existing PPE Directive provides that Member States must allow the marketing of all products compliant with the Directive and must not allow the marketing of non-compliant products. Given that neither lower nor higher standards are allowed by the existing Directive, it is unlikely that there will be significant practical operational implications by replacing it with a Regulation.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report that provides technical clarifications for the regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on personal protective equipment.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on personal protective equipment, while ensuring the free movement of personal protective equipment and its users with a high level of security, while strengthening the single market.  I support the fact that basic conditions need to be clearly defined so that personal protective equipment can be placed on the market in accordance with health and safety requirements. I also consider it necessary to provide the authorities in charge of market surveillance with the possibility of monitoring and withdrawing unsafe products from the market. In this context, I believe that it is necessary to continue with the started modernization and simplification of the system in question, and therefore I support this report.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This report infers an additional cost of production of personal protective equipment (EPI), as a result of which prices will rise. This text puts a stick in the wheels of manufacturers by adding increasingly stringent standards. In the end, it is households that will be penalized because they will no longer be able to buy this type of equipment that has become too expensive. All for negligible security gains. I voted against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Vicky Ford's report on personal protective equipment. The purpose of this text is to update the current directive by encouraging better cooperation to benefit in particular from common definitions at European level.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. This report, for which I voted, deals with strengthening and harmonizing legislation on protective equipment, such as work gloves, helmets, wetsuits, masks and other work protections.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am abstaining from my voice. The intentions of the proposal are well-intentioned, but the practical benefits, such as pot holders, are only partially comprehensible. The marginal gains in consumer protection are linked to an increase in bureaucracy.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Personal protective equipment (PPE) means equipment designed and manufactured to be worn or held by a person for protection against one or more risks for his or her health or safety. I voted in favour of this report as it will help to harmonise and improve the existing rules, thus ensuring better compliance of PPE manufacturers. It is about ‎making sure products used in homes and factories are safe. Health and safety is not about red tape – it is about saving lives and protecting people’s health.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. \u2012 Significant progress has been made in the field of OSH in the EU, and this report is well served by this report. An important goal is to develop and implement products that are tailored to the needs of end users. Indeed, account should be taken of who wears the equipment and a distinction should be made between the categories of users. Accidents at work and damage to health must be avoided in all possible ways and action at EU level can help. There are a number of warning signs warning of past shortcomings, such as the shocking number of damage to health caused by the processing, incorporation and application of asbestos, deaths and insulations that have been removed as ticking bombs ever since.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on personal protective equipment. Household and business concerns are light years away from an already demanding new PPE regulation. This regulation will have significant financial consequences for episen manufacturers (compliance and increased administrative procedures), thus on the final price of the product put on the market. The additional cost of production that this revision of the regulation will ultimately be borne by households and businesses. Legislators will force manufacturers to permanently question their production lines, which will be very problematic for manufacturers already subject to strict standards. Improvements in safety and health (or even the environment) are minimal and do not justify the establishment of new standards.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it incurs an extra cost of production of personal protective equipment (EPI), which will increase their price. This text is discouraging for manufacturers, who are subject to increasingly stringent standards, and may encourage households to stop buying their products that have become too expensive. And all this for negligible security gains.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted against this proposed regulation, intended to replace the 1989 directive - which was deemed obsolete - on personal protective equipment (EPI). Changes induced by this text include an expansion of the PPE categories, the need to attach a declaration of compliance by each EPI, as well as the appointment of new certification bodies and the reduction of compliance time. These changes will have a financial impact on the companies producing such equipment and on their customers, whether they are individual or professional. Finally, and as is often the case with European regulations, it will overburden legislation that is already very restrictive for EPI producers.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This Regulation aligns the current legislation with the provisions of the product package approved in 2008 and, in particular, Decision (EC) No 768/2008 on a common framework for the marketing of products. This concerns the requirements for the design and manufacture of personal protective equipment (PPE) which are made available on the market to ensure the protection of users and provisions on their free movement in the Union. It includes rules on market surveillance and obligations of economic operators as well as workers. My group considers the final agreement reasonable, so I voted in favour.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite introducing positive aspects seeking to improve the safety of such individual equipment, the Regulation maintains aspects tailored to the interests of industry. This proposal leads to certain gaps which may pose problems in the implementation of the precautionary principle in the production and marketing of such individual equipment. Parliament's proposal allows the outsourcing of evaluation bodies, which poses a threat to the safety of those products by leaving decisions on compliance with established security measures in the hands of the market. However, the Regulation in turn contains measures that will improve the safety of these equipment. That is why I have decided to abstain in the vote on this report.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against because I do not agree that harmonisation in the field of protective equipment, such as rain gloves and gloves against heat, should be further addressed by detailed regulation.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 Member States should take all necessary measures to ensure that products covered by this Regulation can only be placed on the market if they do not endanger the health and safety of users as well as other persons. When we take into account the fact that the cost borne by social security and entrepreneurs amounts to 5.9% of domestic gross product and that adequate protection of workers promotes well-being, productivity, risk prevention using quality protective equipment is essential to reduce accidents at work and occupational diseases. All economic operators participating in the supply and distribution chain should take appropriate measures to ensure that only personal protective equipment that is in compliance with this Regulation is available on the market. I supported MP Vicky Ford's report on the fact that the right to health and safety is a fundamental right and all workers must enjoy a legal guarantee on working conditions that respect their health, safety and dignity.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing \ u2012 The submitted proposal for a directive specifies the current regulation in the field of protective equipment. The aim is to unify common definitions and at the same time rationalise and simplify the existing rules – e.g. modifying the declaration of conformity, which will allow economic operators to provide a paper copy or a link to the website, more precisely formulated requirements for employers who are obliged to provide PPE employees. This arrangement should be more practical, comprehensible and clearer both for employers who are obliged to procure PPE and for their manufacturers and for the control and safety authorities themselves.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on personal protective equipment, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 19/1/2016, and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. PPE (personal protective equipment) is equipment designed to protect a person from a risk that could threaten his or her safety or health, mainly at work, but also in the context of sports or leisure activities (safety shoes, protective clothing, sunglasses, harnesses, etc.). Among other things, this regulation will introduce new "category" of EPI, which will expand the scope of the text, an obligation to attach a declaration of compliance to each EPI made available on the market, and the designation of new certifying bodies and a shortened compliance deadline. This text is intended to be positive but will in fact have very little impact in terms of safety and health. On the other hand, it will have significant financial consequences for EPI manufacturers and this additional production will be borne by households and businesses. Employment itself may suffer from this regulation.  There was no justification for setting new standards.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this Report and support strong requirements regarding personal protective equipment.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on personal protective equipment. It is a proposal for a regulation on personal protective equipment which is intended to update existing Directive 89/686/EEC and bring it into line with the new legislative framework on the marketing of products. This regulation clarifies the role of economic operators, strengthens cooperation between actors and introduces common definitions.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a proposal for a regulation to replace the outdated Directive on personal protective equipment. With the help of the regulation, full harmonisation and the emergence of directly applicable, uniform legislation across all EU Member States would be created. Although I generally welcome the proposal and consider it very important, particularly because of its relationship to safety and health in the workplace, there are some passages in the proposal that I consider problematic. This includes, for example, the expansion of certain categories of personal protective equipment, some unjustified increased administrative requirements for manufacturers, etc. although I am fully aware of the importance of this sector, which is also developing rapidly, mainly due to new technologies such as nanomaterials, quality substances, etc., I abstained in the final vote.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. We need to approve strict requirements for personal protective equipment from the EU. I support the European Parliament's position on this proposal for a Regulation, which seeks to modernise and simplify the current system, which has been so good at it.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The practical benefits of the proposed measures are only partially comprehensible. The marginal gain in consumer protection is offset by further bureaucracy. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report that updates existing legislation on personal protective equipment and turns the existing directive into a regulation.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This text aims to define through a regulation the essential requirements that individual protective equipment must meet in order to be made available on the European Union market. These diverse equipments include private protective elements, such as motorcycle helmets and professional protective equipment. Parliament's amendments add to the initial list of equipment provided for oxygen-deficit protection equipment (e.g. diving equipment), chemicals, biological agents, radiation and radioactive contamination. I am voting for this text that promotes security.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report infers an additional cost of production of personal protective equipment (EPI), as a result of which prices will rise. This text puts a stick in the wheels of manufacturers by adding increasingly stringent standards. In the end, it will be households that will be penalized since they will no longer be able to buy this type of equipment that has become too expensive. All for negligible security gains. I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on personal protective equipment. Although the placement of personal protective equipment (PPE) has been harmonised since 1989 and works well in the single market, there is now a need to update existing legislation with the New Legislative Framework. Such an update consists of a package of measures designed to improve and simplify the regulation applicable to goods in the single market. It is important that there is more supervision in our market capable of locating and returning non-compliant goods. The safety of our workers is paramount.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution because the safety of our workers is paramount. The proposed measures regarding personal protective equipment (PPE) are aimed at ensuring legal certainty and the effectiveness of the directive.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. By supporting this regulation, we want to ensure the safety of certain protective clothing such as lifejackets, bicycle helmets, sunglasses. The changes are essential for legislation tailored to 21st century products. Consumer protection is not only about ensuring that the right price is paid, but also about ensuring that the product purchased is safe and of good quality. I support this regulation, which is in line with the inter-institutional agreement of 22 September, which ensures product safety in a globalised world, and which does not hinder the market, by allowing manufacturers to benefit from a simplified procedure for renewing their certificates of compliance with health and safety rules.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – The legislation on safety and health at work and the related legislation on personal protective equipment has been at a very high level in the European Union for many years. Although there are no major shortcomings in this area, I welcome any proposal aimed at improving the safety of workers. We know that there is always a risk present at work and absolute safety cannot be guaranteed. Any new legislation is needed that improves the immediate protection of workers, in this case the use of personal protective equipment. I particularly highlight and appreciate in the present text the new adaptation of testing and testing of protective equipment, for which a high level of protection for working people must also be ensured.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ Since 1989, the placing of personal protective equipment (PPE) on the EU market has been fully harmonised through Council Directive 89/686/EEC. In the intervening 25 years, this directive has enabled a functioning single market. Despite this, the existing PPE legislation is in need of updating in line with the New Legislative Framework (NLF) which is a package of measures designed to streamline and simplify regulations of goods across the Single Market. In particular, in response to concerns that current regulatory requirements are confusing and duplicative, the Regulation clarifies the role of economic operators, reinforces cooperation between actors and introduces common definitions. The common approach under the NLF also clarifies the powers of market surveillance authorities enabling the tracking and returning of unsafe goods placed on the single market. That is why I have voted in favour of the report on personal protective equipment.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning the placing of EDPs on the EU market. The placing on the Union market of personal protective equipment is harmonised by Council Directive 89/686/EEC. Over the past 25 years, the Directive has enabled a functioning single market to be established, but it should nevertheless be updated in line with the new legislative framework, in line with the package of measures intended to streamlin and simplify the regulation of goods in the single market. In its report, the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection said that Parliament supported the proposal with more than 1 1/2 hundred amendments. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal aims to adapt Council Directive 89/686/EEC on personal protective equipment by updating and adapting it in accordance with the New Legislative Framework.  Directive 89/686/EEC has ensured the smooth functioning of the single market over the last 25 years and no major changes will be necessary. I support this proposal for improving and simplifying the rules applicable to goods in the single market, clarifying the role of economic operators, the powers of market surveillance authorities and strengthening cooperation between actors. For the foregoing, this report has my vote in favour.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This regulation will have considerable financial consequences for epise manufacturers (compliance and increased administrative procedures) and therefore on the final price of the product put on the market.  The additional cost of production that this revision of the regulation will ultimately be borne by households and businesses. Legislators will force manufacturers to permanently challenge their production lines, which will be very poorly perceived by manufacturers already subject to strict standards. Employment is likely to suffer as a result of this new regulation.  Improvements in safety and health (or even the environment) are minimal and do not justify the establishment of new standards. I am voting against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on personal protective equipment. The aim was to approve the european Parliament and Council's proposal for a regulation, which aims to improve the internal market and consumer protection for such products.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the need to adapt the directive currently in force, launched in 1989, to the new regulatory framework (NQN), we welcome the Ford report. In particular, the reform is intended as a means of simplifying and clarifying current legislation, which is criticised for its supposed repetitiveness and lack of precision. The proposed text also goes in the direction of strengthening cooperation between the various actors, institutional and non-institutional, providing definitions and rules, common throughout the European Union, on the treatment reserved for goods introduced into the European market whose security is debated. We also agree with the rapporteur's intention not to upset the current regulatory framework by changing its objectives. The aim of the reform is, in fact, to update and improve the instruments provided by the previous directive, but to share its aims. The aim of the legislative act is, in fact, to ensure the maximum safety of users of personal protective equipment, workers and consumers, within a common Community framework. We also agree with the innovations in market surveillance and in the obligations arising from corporate responsibility.
