Finally, the text appears to be consistent with the strategy for harmonizing the common market adopted by the European Commission.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. The proposed regulation on personal protective equipment has reached a broad consensus. I voted in favour of the report to show my support for a proposal that I consider fair and clear.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a regulation on personal protective equipment (PPE) aims to update Council Directive 89/686/EEC in line with the new legislative framework on the marketing of products. It contains a package of measures designed to streamline and simplify the regulations on goods in the single market by responding to the need to increase the protection of the health and safety of users and to ensure the free movement of PPE in the EU market. I have therefore decided to support the document with my vote in favour.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 By supporting the adoption of this report, I hope that it will be possible to ensure that workers using personal protective equipment can use these devices with even greater safety in the future and that the number of possible health damage is minimised. In order to do so as soon as possible, I support the simplification of the European regulatory environment and the levelling of competition between ICEs companies as soon as possible, thereby helping to improve the working conditions of EU workers.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report on PPE (personal protective equipment) according to which all Member States should improve their current regulations, taking into consideration that health and safety protection is extremely important for all EU citizens.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on personal protective equipment in my vote today, because I believe it is extremely important that the legislation in this area is clear and complete. The legislation in this area is based on an EEC directive of 1989 to which additions have been made over the years, which has made this legislation have a provision and provisions which make the bureaucratic process more difficult. In this context, supplementing, clarifying and simplifying legislation will bring major benefits to both manufacturers and beneficiaries of such protective equipment.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, which ensures greater safety of protective equipment and therefore means increasing consumer protection without creating an excessive administrative burden. In this case, the EP corrected the Commission's proposal to include common household protective equipment, such as kitchen gloves and mittens, in the scope of the Directive, which would lead to additional costs for their manufacturers and ultimately to make them more expensive for final consumers.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. European entrepreneurs are obliged to provide employees with the necessary personal protective equipment (PPE). In winter, these are e.B. shoes with correspondingly non-slip sole. The PPE Directive also allows the free movement of personal protective equipment. Unfortunately, in recent years, some fake or safety-threatening safety helmets and life jackets have entered the European market. In the report, I do not want the directive to be tightened up in relation to the above-mentioned cases. That is why I abstained.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This report on personal protective equipment aims to replace an older text, dating back to 1989. Although there are not many changes, its scope is widening. However, neither the provisions relating to employees, nor the opinions of SMEs, nor measures to simplify procedures were finally included in the report, which led me to abstain in the plenary vote.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Regulation on PPE resolves a situation where the current requirements are confusing and duplicate, which is an update of existing legislation.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The rules on personal protective equipment (PPE) date back to Council Directive 89/686/EEC; which, although it has had excellent results, needs an update. Therefore, in the light of the new regulatory framework aimed at streamlining and speeding up procedures, I believe that the amendments proposed by the rapporteur on the draft regulation on PPE aimed at avoiding repetition and clarifying points that are difficult to understand are desirable, especially since the protection of the end-user passes through effective devices and the ability to use them correctly. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – PPE is equipment that protects users against health or safety risks at work and is used in a wide range of jobs and industries. The PPE rules, for example, are now in need of updating to reflect the new technologies development, without lowering the existing standards. I believe the safety of any European citizen should be maximised and that is why I support the personal protective equipment proposal for a regulation.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. \u2012 The aim of this proposal is to introduce amendments to Directive 89/686/EEC on personal protective equipment (PPE), which would ensure an even higher level of protection of human health and safety, while guaranteeing fair competition on the European PPE market. The proposal also requires PPE producers to draw up technical documentation to ensure its issuance in accordance with EU rules and standards. In addition to simplifying the definition itself, i.e. categorization of PPE, all personal protective equipment is required, the purpose of which is to protect against drowning, violation of the hand chainsaw, high pressure cutters, gunshot wounds, stabbings, harmful sounds, subjected to the strictest procedural checks. The proposed changes would give a clear instruction to manufacturers and users, resulting in further trust between them. It is also necessary to encourage the competent authorities to make inspections as frequent and as rigorous as possible, which would minimize accidents.    The proposal will be applicable two years after entry into force, in order to give manufacturers, competent authorities and Member States sufficient time to adapt.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This proposed regulation replaces the 1989 Personal Protective Equipment Directive (PPE). This new regulation will have significant financial consequences for episen manufacturers (compliance and increased administrative procedures) and therefore on the final price of the product put on the market. The additional cost of production that this revision of the regulation will ultimately be borne by households and businesses. Legislators will force manufacturers to permanently overhaul their production lines when they are already subject to strict standards. Employment is likely to suffer. Improvements in safety and health (or even the environment) are minimal and do not justify the establishment of new standards. I therefore vote against this report.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. \u2012 Existing regulations in the field of personal protective equipment need to be harmonised with the new legislative framework (NLF), which seeks to simplifie redundant, confusing and duplicational acts. In this regard, it is important to clarify the role of different parties, in particular economic operators, and to specify the powers of the authorities overseeing the market and monitoring the course of uncertain goods.  Also commendable are the achievements of this well-balanced text regarding the rules regarding the design and manufacture of the protective equipment itself, its advertising, but also the right of individuals to use it privately. As a whole, I support the efforts of this proposal for a regulation to reinforce the importance of workers' right to safety at work, taking into account that this safety is often caused precisely by the lack of knowledge of the necessary protective equipment, but also by its incorrect use.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I fully support MEP Vicky Ford's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on personal protective equipment. The proposal for personal protective equipment regulation aims to update the existing Council Directive 89/686/EEC and align it with the new legislative framework on product marketing.  What is important to point out is that regulation has a great ability to create a harmonised approach to the obligations of economic operators, improve cooperation between actors and common definitions, as well as transform the directive into regulation. Because the current directive does not allow lower or higher standards, significant practical implications will not arise from the change in instruments. It is important to mention that only fully efficient instruments can guarantee the safety of workers. Workplace accidents often occur due to the failure to use suitable protective equipment or to use it in the wrong way.  The last, but by no means less important, is to note that protection should be adapted to those who use it, for example by categorizing it by gender, age or special needs.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Current legislation on personal protective equipment (PPE), while well functioning, requires an update in line with the new regulatory framework (NQN), which is a package of measures designed to streamline and simplify the regulations on goods in the single market. In particular, this regulation clarifies the role of economic operators and introduces common definitions. In addition, it is proposed to eliminate the five years of maximum validity of the EU certification certificate because, according to economic operators, this period is excessively short given the normal life of PPE. In the hope that negotiations on this dossier could soon be concluded, I voted in favour.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I would like to highlight at this point the proposal of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, which removed, for example, kitchen mitts from regulation and showed that a reasonable compromise can be found between consumer protection, single market requirements and the position of producers. The report therefore deserves the support of those of you who are not directly members of our committee.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. It is essential to ensure the best possible protection for users of personal protective equipment. That is why I approved this text, which is now becoming a regulation. A way to enforce the regulations more evenly.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 It is assumed that only through truly effective instruments is it possible to irremissiblely protect the safety of workers, given that accidents at the workplace are often caused by the absence of adequate protection systems and their incorrect use. It is necessary to increase the dignity of the world of work and to reduce as much as possible any doubts and misinterpretations. The report which I voted in favour of is intended to clarify aspects of personal protective equipment such as requiring importers and distributors to alert both the manufacturer and the market surveillance authorities of the potential existence of non-compliant personal protective equipment and also to require any redress procedures to be transparent and accessible.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I supported the text on personal protective equipment, which repeats the terms of the agreement reached between the institutions on the normative requirements for these products, in order to ensure their free movement in the Union and a high degree of protection for their users, whether for private or professional purposes.  What is the actual personal protective equipment? These include safety shoes and gloves, lifejackets, construction helmets, hearing protection, goggles, safety harnesses.  As rapporteur of my political group on this text, I welcome the result that has finally been achieved. In particular, we have managed to define a simplified procedure for the renewal of certificates for equipment that has not been modified since their previous certification, while maintaining a "safety net" for all. With these new balanced rules, we achieve our goal, avoiding unnecessary burdens and enhancing security.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of this proposal which aims to replace Council Directive 89/686/EEC on personal protective equipment. This is a proposal which seeks to adopt a regulation ensuring an even higher level of protection of human health and safety from what we previously had, while safeguarding the existence of a fair competition framework for economic operators on the Union market and simplifying the regulatory framework in this area. Since I agree overall with the measures in this report, I have given it my vote in favour.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. The European Union's introduction of personal protective equipment (PPE) has been fully harmonised since 1989 through Directive 89/686/EEC. Today, there is a need to bring the current PPE legislation into line with the new legislative framework (NCL), a package of measures to improve and simplify product regulations within the single market. I supported this report, which stresses that the common approach in the context of the NCL clarifies the powers of market supervisors by allowing the tracking and return of dangerous products put on the single market. The text also recalls the obligations to which economic operators are bound.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this regulation because it introduces an updated set of measures aimed at streamlining and simplifying the rules on personal protective equipment within the single market, while at the same time strengthening the protection of end-users of a wide range of personal protective equipment.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite introducing positive aspects seeking to improve the safety of such individual equipment, the Regulation maintains aspects tailored to the interests of industry. This proposal leads to certain gaps which may pose problems in the implementation of the precautionary principle in the production and marketing of such individual equipment. Parliament's proposal allows the outsourcing of evaluation bodies, which poses a threat to the safety of those products by leaving decisions on compliance with established security measures in the hands of the market. However, the Regulation in turn contains measures that will improve the safety of these equipment. That is why I have decided to abstain in the vote on this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation voted on today aims to simplify and update the existing rules on personal protective equipment (PPE) in order to lighten the administrative burden and improve legal certainty for all those involved in the production and supervision of products placed on the European market. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that simplifying the legislation is an advantage both for the producer, who will thus be able to reduce unnecessary costs, and for the consumer, who will still be guaranteed a high level of protection and safety. Finally, I am pleased that products intended for private use for protection against non-extreme weather conditions or against moisture and water have not been included in the scope of the regulation, because this provision would have led to a significant increase in costs for manufacturers, without any obvious benefit to consumers.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 Personal protective equipment is essential for numerous activities. Community legislation on this subject has been in the area since 1989. It was this legislation which, through a Directive, has made it possible to harmonise the different existing laws and to open up the single market also for this type of products which is now estimated at EUR 10 billion per year. However, as a result of new technical challenges, increased security requirements and some proliferation of loose legislation, there was always a need to produce new legislation that would respond to these designs. In the present situation, legislation has to be updated and aligned with the New Legislative Framework, which consists of a package of measures designed to improve and simplify the regulation applicable to goods in the single market. For these reasons, I voted positively for this report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it is ridiculous that the EU are trying to regulate things like oven gloves.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ This legislative proposal on personal protective equipment from Vicky Ford was well written and I voted in favour of it. Personal protective equipment is essential to protect a person’s health and safety whether they are at work or at home. The vote today will help to harmonise and improve the rules that already exist providing for personal protective equipment for manufacturers of the product.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. ‒ It is very important that people protect themselves in a good way. Therefore I supported this resolution as it contains improvements both in protecting the user and in the manufacturing of this equipment and regulates European standardisation on it.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the resolution because I believe that the existing legislation on personal protective equipment (PPE) needs to be updated in line with the new legal framework, which is a package of measures aimed at rationalising and simplifying the rules on goods within the single market. I also agree that PPE should comply with Union law and only enter the market if it does not endanger the health and safety of users or other persons. I welcome the measures under which the regulation establishes a framework for market surveillance and control of products that comply with these harmonised requirements. I consider the possibility of PPE traceability throughout the supply chain to be a positive element of the regulation, which can contribute to simplifying and streamlining market surveillance. I expect that, also on the basis of this regulation, greater attention will be paid to work that cannot verify compliance with the provisions on the allocation of PPE (undeclared work, domestic work), and awareness of the adopted regulation will be raised within the EU and individual Member States.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of Parliament's amendments to the proposal for an EU regulation on personal protective equipment, which primarily aims to modernise and update the existing directive with a new legal framework. The proposal for a regulation is specific where the current directive is confusing and unclear, which has so far caused different interpretations of the rules to ensure the safety of personal protective equipment in individual EU countries. The proposal for a new regulation aims to simplify the regulatory environment in this area, while ensuring that only products that meet all safety standards and rules on free movement within the single market enter the EU market. I consider it positive that Parliament has excluded from the regulation personal protective equipment for private use to protect against heat, such as kitchen mitts.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The report refers to the proposal for a regulation on PERSONAL equipment.  The basic assumption of the proposal for a regulation was that protection for workers can only be provided in a completely smooth manner through very effective instruments. It must, of course, be borne in mind that accidents at work occur not only because of the failure to use adequate protective equipment, but also because of its misuse. I believe that protective equipment will only be effective if it is designed and put on the market in an appropriate form, taking into account different users.  The report on the proposal for a regulation highlights, among other things, certain purely technical aspects of the regulation, with the desire to include all risk categories and all possible cases. Thus, legal uncertainty or misinterpretation should be avoided as far as possible.  I agree that, in order to improve the working environment, we need not only investment policies, but also irrefutable safeguards. These can be considered everything from minimum requirements for the safety of workers to measures to protect workers and to improve the quality of the working environment accordingly.  For the sake of this, I voted in plenary to adopt a report on the proposal for a regulation on personal protective equipment.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing \ u2012 In view of the development and simplification of the rules on the entry of products into the single market, it was also necessary to update the rules on personal protective equipment. This Regulation lays down requirements for the design and production of personal protective equipment (PPE) made available on the market in order to ensure the protection of users and the rules for their free movement within the Union. It is necessary to lay down rules for manufacturers and importers, in particular their identifiability and the obligation to indicate contact details directly on the packaging. It is also important to attach instructions for the use of individual protective equipment to each separately sold prepackage. The checks on compliance with those obligations shall be ensured by distributors who are obliged to ensure compliance with their obligations under this Regulation.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒I support the conditions for ensuring the protection of the health and safety of users, as the proposal requires personal protective equipment manufacturers to produce technical documentation to ensure that it is published in accordance with eu governing rules and standards. Personal protective equipment should be subjected to procedural checks, and it is a personal protective equipment intended to protect against drowning, violation of hand chainsaw, high pressure cutter, gunshot wounds, stabbings, harmful sounds. Accidents should be kept to a minimum, which is why more frequent inspections are needed and the proposed amendments would give a clear instruction to manufacturers and users, resulting in additional trust between them.  I support this proposal because we aim at a high level of health protection and a high level of safety.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on personal protective equipment.  I support the creation of a single market with regard to personal protective equipment, which must be in front of its eyes first and foremost the consumer, to which we must ensure a high level of protection. For any PPE that re-emerges in the European Union's internal market, we must lay down the essential requirements and conditions under which it can compete on the European market. I welcome the proposed amendment to ensure that appropriate measures should be taken to ensure people's safety during the presentations of equipment and field tests. The amendment also stipules that field tests should not be designed to test the effectiveness of PPE, but to assess other aspects not related to protection, such as ease, ergonomics and shape.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The well-being of professionals in various sectors who have to use personal protective equipment is something of interest to all citizens of the Member States. I believe that upgrading and updating existing legislation and related directives will fill many gaps in user safety. I also believe that the security problem posed by imported products from Asia in particular will be reduced.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The way consumer products are marketed at Member State level must be a matter of interest to the European institutions at all times. In this regard, there is a need to align European legislation with the provisions of the legislative package adopted in 2008, in particular to Decision (EC) No 768/2008 on the common framework for the marketing of products. In particular, the requirements for the design and production of personal protective equipment which are first placed on the European market, as well as the rules of free movement within the Union, are concerned. These include provisions relating to marketing supervision and compliance with the obligations of the economic operators and companies involved. Self-defense products, a number of household products for personal use, some decorative or artisanal products are not included. The main problem is the implementation of these rules in practice, for which the Commission must actively ensure. However, the adoption of the current report constitutes an important step forward in this area and supports citizens by enriching the range of safe and certified products they can choose from. The same applies to the report on appliances consuming gaseous fuels.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the regulation on the safety of personal protective equipment such as life jackets or bicycle helmets. Since 1989, the placing of personal protective equipment (PPE) on the EU market has been fully harmonised through Council Directive 89/686/EEC. In the intervening 25 years, this directive has enabled a functioning single market. Despite this, the existing PPE legislation is in need of updating in line with the New Legislative Framework (NLF) which is a package of measures designed to streamline and simplify regulations of goods across the Single Market.  In particular, in response to concerns that current regulatory requirements are confusing and duplicative, the regulation clarifies the role of economic operators, reinforces cooperation between actors and introduces common definitions. The common approach under the NLF also clarifies the powers of market surveillance authorities enabling the tracking and returning of unsafe goods placed on the single market.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the extent and essential requirements relating to health and safety and conformity assessment procedures must be the same in all Member States, this should be introduced using the method proposed in the report. It is therefore appropriate to replace the Directive with 89/686/EEC by means of a Regulation which would provide an appropriate legal instrument for the development of clear and detailed provisions which do not give Member States different interpretations. Our priority as Parliament was to propose amendments that would ensure that the existing directive does not lead to interpretations that could in any way affect the effectiveness and certainty of the law. The basic premise is that only very effective measures can ensure the safety of workers, given that very often workplace accidents occur not only because of the lack of safety measures, but because of their misuse. Any proposal that can increase the security of citizens, and especially workers, is worthy of support during the vote.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the improvements and upgrades of the PERSONAL Protective Equipment Regulation, as I believe these changes will achieve simplification and modernisation of the sector.  I also support efforts to reduce administrative burdens in order to improve the legislative security of all participants in the production and supervision of products on the European Union market. Nevertheless, in order to ensure the achievement of the purpose of this Regulation, it is important that each Member State reports if it considers that certain equipment does not comply with the conditions and does not meet the safety requirements. Moreover, I believe it is of utmost consequence that these amendments did not expand the scope of the Regulation, as the addition of new paragraphs would result in a significant increase in costs for equipment manufacturers and would not benefit consumers clearly from such changes. I also believe that Member States must focus their efforts on the fact that these products do not endanger human health.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on personal protective equipment, as this regulation complements and updates the existing 1989.  The new proposal, which clarifies the role of economic operators, further strengthens cooperation between actors and further defines the powers of market surveillance authorities. It allows for even more accurate tracking and return of dangerous products made into the single market. Tighter controls mean greater safety and additional confidence in the quality of end-consumer PPE.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This regulation will have significant financial consequences for epise manufacturers (compliance and increased administrative procedures) and therefore on the final price of the product put on the market.  The additional cost of production that this revision of the regulation will ultimately be borne by households and businesses. Legislators will force manufacturers to permanently question their production lines, which will be very poorly perceived by manufacturers, who are already subject to strict standards. Improvements in safety and health (see environment) are minimal and do not justify the establishment of new standards. It is interesting to know that the Commssion has tried to regulate the manimans (kitchen gloves), an attempt fortunately rejected by MEPs but significant as to the total absence of any sense of priorities.  I'm voting against the text.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Since 1989, the placing on the EU market of personal protective equipment (PPE) has been fully harmonised by Council Directive 89/686/EEC. During the 25 years of intervention, the Directive has enabled a functioning single market. Nevertheless, the existing PPE legislation should be updated with the new legislative framework, in line with the package of measures intended to streamlin and simplify the regulation of goods in the single market. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour to maintain or improve the high level of consumer protection and ensure consistency of the regulations with the goods package.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: Writing. – I am pleased that this regulation has succeeded in establishing harmonised rules aimed at better user protection, while reducing the amount of bureaucratic conditions that producers must fulfil. The use of personal protective equipment – anti-impact helmets, safety fasteners, life jackets – depends on people's health and even life. These tools, which are used daily in many workplaces and sports, must be absolutely safe and perform their functions. The use and manufacture of these products has changed a great deal over the last 25 years – since the development of existing EU standards for the safety of personal protective equipment. Both the working environment in which these products are used has become different, as well as new, often more extreme, sports activities that do not be enough to do without these products. I am therefore pleased that we have adopted provisions that will significantly modernise existing legislation by setting higher safety standards. At the same time, it is essential that bureaucratic workload will not burden manufacturers whose products, such as decorative cooker and dishwashing gloves, umbrellas or clothing with decorative reflective elements, are not intended for extreme conditions.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The proposal aims to update the current Council Directive 89/686/EEC to align it with the new legislative framework for the marketing of products. We are talking about a dossier which has been the subject of technical and linguistic amendments and which has had great support in its parliamentary committee, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite introducing positive aspects seeking to improve the safety of such individual equipment, the Regulation maintains aspects tailored to the interests of industry. This proposal leads to certain gaps which may pose problems in the implementation of the precautionary principle in the production and marketing of such individual equipment. Parliament's proposal allows the outsourcing of evaluation bodies, which poses a threat to the safety of those products by leaving decisions on compliance with established security measures in the hands of the market. However, the Regulation in turn contains measures that will improve the safety of these equipment. That is why I have decided to abstain in the vote on this report.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this proposed regulation aimed at modernising the current, often confusing, regulations.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of that Directive was to harmonise the health and safety requirements for PPE in all Member States and to remove barriers to trade in such equipment. This Regulation lays down requirements for the design and manufacture of PPE (new on the EU market when placed there), intended to be made available on the market in order to ensure the protection of users' health and safety and to lay down rules on the free movement of PPE within the EU. It is essential that PPE does not endanger the health or safety of persons, domestic animals or property. It is therefore imperative that health and safety rules are well defined and, therefore, that they are respected. On the other hand, it is also essential that SMEs in Member States operating in this sector, in particular manufacturers, be able to receive the necessary support (technical and financial) to respond correctly and in a timely manner to the changes introduced by the Regulation, as such legal changes should not be a covert way of favouring the largest companies in the sector and, consequently, increasing the concentration of market power.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The practical benefits of the proposed measures are only partially comprehensible. The marginal gain in consumer protection is offset by further bureaucracy. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on personal protective equipment. This Regulation applies to personal protective equipment which is listed as new on the Union market, either imported from a third country by a manufacturer established in the Union. The aim of the project is to adapt the existing legal situation to the new regulatory approach without extending regulatory access. This has not been fully achieved.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this report, which updates existing legislation in this area. I believe that simplifying and streamlining these regulations is a step in the right direction. I agree with clarifying certain concepts and introducing clear definitions that allow for the same interpretation of this Regulation in all Member States of the Union. I consider it important that only those products that actually protect the health of workers in the performance of their professions reach the EU market.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 On the grounds that there is virtually no flexibility in the transposition of directives based on the principles of the new approach to national law, it is proposed that Directive 89/686/EEC be replaced by a regulation. The purpose of that Directive was to harmonise health and safety requirements for Personal Protective Equipment in all Member States and to remove barriers to trade. This Regulation lays down requirements for the design and manufacture of PPE (new on the EU market when placed there), intended to be made available on the market in order to ensure the protection of users' health and safety and to lay down rules on the free movement of PPE within the EU. It is essential that PPE does not endanger the health or safety of persons, domestic animals or property. On the other hand, it is also essential that SMEs in Member States operating in this sector, in particular manufacturers, be able to receive the necessary support (technical and financial) to respond correctly and in a timely manner to the changes introduced by the Regulation. Since such legal changes should not be a covert way of favouring the largest companies in the sector and, therefore, increasing the concentration of market power. We voted for it.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I support the proposal for a regulation as it aims to ensure a high level of protection of public interests, such as health and safety and the protection of users and, where appropriate, other persons, and fair competition on the Union market.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on personal protective equipment (PPE) which represents the opinion of the European Parliament on Directive 89/686/EEC whereby, since 1989, the placing of personal protective equipment on the EU market has been fully harmonised. The report adopted by Parliament helps to update the legislation on PPE and clarifies the role of economic operators, as well as the powers of market surveillance authorities, with which it is possible to track and return unsafe goods placed in the single market.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The members of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection approved Vicky Ford's report. Similarly, I voted in favour as a member of the same Commission.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – While a number of European Union citizens use wood, coal, kerosene or specially recycled, organic and other remnants for the purpose of firing, gaseous fuels continue to be the most popular fuels. Home heating, water heating, transport fuel – given the often constant daily proximity of consumers to gaseous fuel installations, I naturally welcome this desire to improve the safety situation. Gas poisoning, first of all, carbon gas, or any leak of substances, can clearly cause quite serious damage to the health of humans and domestic animals. Consequently, greater unification of supranational legislation aimed at standardising quality in all 28 Member States is necessary and, of course, welcome.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, cosúil leis an tuarascáil deiridh tá moladh tuillte ag an rapóirtéir, Catherine Stihler, maidir leis an tuarascáil seo, agus arís tá a lán céille ag baint leis. Dá bhrí sin, bhí mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála agus vótáil mé i bhfabhar comh maith. So this regulation is very important because it changes the directive that was there already, and it helps us to complete the single market, which of course we have heard about this morning from the Dutch Presidency and which is now very much in vogue, particularly in relation to gas, because gas is going to be a very important part even as we move to renewables. Renewables can be intermittent, so gas is going to be a very important part of our energy mix into the future. For that reason the gas appliances should be to the very highest standards, because some of these boilers, etc. can emit carbon monoxide, which is a deadly killer. But these proposals will help to ensure the highest possible standards and protection for consumers.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst UKIP are not against standardised safety proposals which help to ensure that citizens are better protected against harmful appliances reaching the market, we are opposed to this proposal on the grounds that we are against further harmonisation of the internal market. This relates specifically to the change of the legislation from a directive to a regulation.
politicalGroup: The Earl of) Dartmouth Mike Hookem Diane James Margot Parker and Julia Reid (EFDD
partyIdeology: The Earl of) Dartmouth Mike Hookem Diane James Margot Parker and Julia Reid (EFDD

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it extends the health protection of users of all types of gaseous fuel appliances. Such equipment, both domestic and non-domestic, poses certain health risks, such as the risk of gas poisoning such as carbon monoxide. This type of risk causes numerous fatal accidents each year and it is absolutely necessary for our legal framework to take binding actions to drive the manufacture, control and review of such equipment to ensure that risks to the user are minimized. The report significantly improves the European Commission's initial proposal to reduce these risks and that is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. This text aims to replace the 2009 gas appliance directive with the aim of simplifying legislation and defining the obligations of the economic operators concerned (manufacturers, agents, importers and distributors). The main measures of this text are based on the obligation that gas furnaces be installed and maintained by professionals for safety reasons, the obligation to inform consumers of health and safety risks, and the implementation of CE markings (in accordance with the requirements) of the appliances.  However, this text has very few amendments to the current directive. Moreover, under the pretext of a desire to strengthen security, it presents a political objective aimed at harmonising the internal market. So I voted against this report.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the vote on the European Parliament's report on household and non-domestic appliances intended for certain specific gas applications and on their components intended to be incorporated into such appliances. This is a very important report because it concerns the placing on the market of these products and the protection of consumers when using these products. In conclusion, the Group of the European Democrats and Socialists is in favour of the application of basic rules in order to avoid any poisoning from the leakage of gases that are harmful to the health and safety of consumers.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. There is little change in this text from the current directive, whose primary purpose is the harmonisation of the internal market, not security, as it is claimed. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not oppose international standards in such matters in any way.  Indeed, in many ways I would describe myself as a globalist.  Whilst I do not support the European Union, I support British membership of organisations such as the United Nations, the International Organisation for Standardisation, the G7, the G20, the Commonwealth, and many, many more. The UK already has such regulations concerning the burning of gaseous fuels, so there is no need for us to further add to the regulatory burden. This report seeks to harmonise where harmonisation is unnecessary (and explains why I support the organisations listed above but not the European Union). I voted against.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to replace Directive 2009/142/EC, which ensures the free movement of gaseous appliances and contributes significantly to the completion and functioning of the single market and harmonises the conditions under which appliances burning gaseous fuels are placed and put into service on the market. The gas sector plays an important role in the EU economy: the gas appliances sector alone employs 476 000 people. Gas appliances include a wide range of products, from portable stoves to boilers for large buildings, and there are currently 470 million gas appliances in the EU and are growing. I agree that the amendment of the legal instrument from the directive to the regulation is in line with the overall political commitment to better regulation and the simplification of the regulatory environment. It lays down clear and detailed rules to be applied uniformly at the same time throughout the Union. In particular, the mandatory essential requirements and the conformity assessment procedures to be followed by manufacturers must be the same in all Member States.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved this report, which supports the proposed regulation to simplify and harmonize EU legislation on the internal market for gas appliances by strengthening consumer safety and the rational use of energy.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Stihler report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on gas appliances. It is a technical proposal that complements the previous regulations of the sector, maintaining a focus on controlling the market of these devices and consumer protection. The main objective is to ensure uniformity of legislation throughout Europe, with particular attention being paid to essential requirements and evaluation procedures.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because we find it clear that there are aspects of the previous Directive that had become obsolete in the light of technological developments. The new legislation advances intra-European legislative harmonisation. In addition, the report contains elements that are positive for consumer protection, such as improvements in labelling.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I preferred to vote against this report on the proposal of Parliament and the Council on gas appliances. Of course, the stated objective is that of the safety and health of users, since the report sets out obligations for the economic operators concerned, in particular with regard to the risk of carbon monoxide production by certain devices; for example, a gas furnace can only be installed and maintained by a professional in charge of verifying the safety of combustion. While I am committed to the safety and health of my fellow citizens, I have had to oppose this text, which, on the one hand, brings nothing new or different from the previous directive on the subject and, on the other hand, under the guise of more protection, has in fact as a framework the harmonisation of the internal market by regulation, that is, this European single market which aims to , ultimately, a globalized economy at the expense of the national common good.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 While I agree with the need for harmonisation in the internal market pursued by this measure, I would have preferred it to have been implemented by means of a directive that would have granted greater autonomy to the Member States and instead opted for a regulation, which was much more binding, which is why I abstained.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have abstained on these three reports on the establishment of new regulations (instead of directives). The consequence of these reports is that no EU Member State may legislate for higher protection and environmental rules with regard to cableway installations, appliances for the combustion of gaseous fuels and personal protective equipment. I think that is fundamentally wrong. Having a minimum limit on environmental and protection measures that all Member States must achieve is one thing, but it is wrong to decide that no Member State should be able to improve its legislation independently in terms of protecting people and the environment. That's why I put my voice down.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this agreement reached at first reading with the Council on the Regulation on gaseous fuel appliances and equipment which are new to the Union market at the time of their marketing. This Regulation, which adapts current legislation to the provisions of the product package adopted in 2008 and, in particular, decision No 768/2008/EC on a common framework for the marketing of products, applies to domestic and non-domestic gaseous fuel appliances intended for a number of specific applications and to equipment designed to be incorporated into such appliances. This new legislation lays down harmonised standards for the marketing of these products and for the protection of consumers when using such products, in particular the prevention of gas poisoning and the leakage of any substance harmful to health and safety.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, in which the European Parliament supports the proposal for a regulation on appliances burning gaseous fuels, which aims to replace Directive 2009/142/EC. This Directive, which ensures the free movement of gaseous appliances, is an example of Union harmonisation legislation. This Directive makes a significant contribution to the completion and functioning of the single market and harmonises the conditions under which gaseous combustion appliances falling within its scope are placed and/or put into service on the market because of the risks of gas safety and the rational use of energy. Directive 2009/142/EC lays down the essential requirements that gaseous combustion appliances must meet in order to be placed on the EU market. The gas sector plays an important role in the European Union's economy: the gas appliances sector alone employs 476 000 people. Gas appliances include a wide range of products, from portable cookers to boilers for large buildings, and there are currently 470 million gas appliances in the EU and are growing in number, with more than 30 million units sold each year.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I also support the new proposal for a regulation governing the new rules on the free movement of gaseous appliances within the EU internal market. This is an extremely important area, with as many as 470 million gaseous appliances in the EU, from simple portable cookers to boilers for large buildings, and their numbers are increasing. The proposed regulation replaces the directive currently in force, which has proved quite problematic in the harmonisation procedures with the national laws of the Member States. By choosing a regulation that applies directly in the Member States, the latter will be able to save the costs associated with transposing the Directive. Moreover, the form of the Regulation avoids the risk of divergences in transposition, which could lead to different levels of security and distortion of the internal market. It should also be noted that the proposal is in line with EU legislation governing energy supply and energy efficiency. The equipment will also have to bear the CE marking, which will facilitate the certification of products marketed.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ Carbon monoxide poisoning is very common in Croatia. That is why I am pleased that my amendment on the importance of regular servicing and quality production of such products has been adopted for the safety of consumers.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the changes made to the legislation on gas appliances contribute significantly to the clarification and simplification of the relevant regulation by imposing clear and organic rules that will become applicable uniformly throughout the Union at the same time.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This regulation aims to replace the 2009 European Gas Device Directive. The text does not change the scope of the previous directive but amends certain provisions, notably with regard to the obligations of economic actors. In practical terms, only professionals will be able to install and maintain gas appliances. This type of device poses a danger to consumers because it can release carbon monoxide if it is not properly installed. The report also calls on national authorities to ensure that consumers are better aware of the threats posed by gas appliances.  This regulation makes very few changes to the previous directive in terms of safety for users. On the other hand, for the European Commission, this new regulation is another step in its desire to fully harmonise the internal market. The European Union therefore uses a false pretext for purely political purposes.  That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The gas sector plays an important role in the EU economy and creates 476,000 jobs in the gas-consuming appliances sector alone. It imposes clear and detailed rules, which will become uniformly applicable at the same time throughout the Union. The mandatory essential requirements and conformity assessment procedures to be followed by producers must be identical in all Member States. The text, which is in line with the Single Market Act, will be strengthened from the point of view of consumer safety, adding changes to the precautions to be considered to avoid poisoning of people with carbon monoxide, which is the leading cause of deaths associated with the use of gas-consuming appliances in Europe. All the measures proposed in the report are appropriate means to achieve transparency in European Union legislation and to ensure the free movement of gas-consuming appliances, which is why I voted in favour with a view to replacing the directive.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The nature of this regulation is absolutely technical. No political aspects emerged during the debate in the Committee on the Internal Market, so much so that the negotiations between the Council, Parliament and the Commission took place quickly. This measure is part of a process of harmonisation within the internal market. The aim is to simplify and update the technical updating of the rules relating to products which, on our market, are linked to the safe use of gas and the rational use of energy. Our delegation would have preferred the text to be maintained in the form of a directive, while the European Commission preferred to adopt a regulation (less scope for action for the Member States). The abstention vote is a caution in order to prevent any problems related to this legislation from being negative in the future. Of course, our production sector has not expressed any concerns at the moment, but we prefer a more cautious attitude.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The European harmonisation of rules on gas appliances was necessary to improve the efficiency of this sector. One of the EU's priorities is to complete the single market. This would allow businesses to benefit from a more favourable environment for the smooth running of their business and for consumers to obtain the same protections regardless of the country in which they reside. I voted in favour of this report, which fully highlights the need to complement the single market and the need to use energy rationally.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on gas appliances. The previous legislation already guaranteed the free movement of gas appliances, harmonising the conditions for the placing on the market and commissioning of such equipment and setting the parameters necessary to avoid safety risks and the essential requirements that must be met in order to be marketed in the EU. The proposal for a regulation imposes clear and organic rules that will become uniformly applicable throughout the Union: in particular, mandatory essential requirements and manufacturer conformity assessment procedures will have to be identical in all Member States. The proposal also contains provisions relating to products, setting out the obligations of the economic operators concerned. The text before us appears to be complete and exhaustive, which is why I voted for its acceptance.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislation which would regulate how appliances burning gaseous fuels would enter the market.  Most of the content is technical and contains provisions on labelling, assessments, risks to health and safety of persons and animals and how to deal with references to poisonous substances such as carbon monoxide.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because it provides good amendments to the existing text which improve consumer safety and allow the consumer to be better informed about the product.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Together with the M5S Europe delegation, I voted in favour of my colleague Catherine Stihler's report because the text aims, among other things, to harmonise the health and safety requirements of gas appliances in all Member States. The protection of consumer safety is essential and essential.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 As part of the vote, I supported the proposal for a regulation that regulates the rules for the use of domestic gas installations. It applies, for example, to popular gas flow heaters or karem in the Czech Republic. In the EU, these devices are the most common cause of gas-related deaths, unfortunately we also learn about victims of carbon monoxide poisoning from time to time. The regulation adopted by the EP clearly defines the standards that all gas appliances must meet and also requires their certification in accordance with European standards. This will clearly contribute to the fact that only proven devices will be available on our market and prevention of possible accidents will be strengthened.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation on gas appliances to replace Directive 2009/142/EC. This Directive is an example of harmonisation of Union legislation to ensure the free movement of gas appliances and has made a significant contribution to the completion and functioning of the single market by harmonising the conditions for the placing on the market and/or putting into service of gas appliances falling within its scope in relation to risks to gas safety and the rational use of energy. It is recalled that the gas sector plays an important role in the EU economy.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on gas appliances has economic and ecological implications for the daily lives of all European citizens. Its proposals are therefore of particular interest. If we take into account the fact that it provides for upgrading, strengthening and harmonising the rules relating to citizens' safety and good trade practices, it is easy to conclude that we must vote in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on gas appliances. The proposal for a regulation on gas appliances is intended to replace Directive 2009/142/EC, which covers a wide range of consumer products – appliances used for cooking, refrigerating, air conditioning, heating environments, producing hot water, lighting or washing. The amendment of the legal instrument from directive to regulation is in line with the general political commitment to simplify and harmonise legislative production. The report proposes that the regulation should apply more specifically to gas appliances for domestic and non-domestic use intended for certain applications as well as to accessories, stressing that the latter should also be marked with the CE mark.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 When it comes to technical legislation, the transition from directive to regulation is always good news. In fact, the room for manoeuvre left by the directive always hides non-tariff barriers and technical barriers to entry into a national market, which the regulation can finally avoid. These are pockets of inefficiency that are reduced, to the benefit of excellent companies (and Italy has many) which, especially when they are medium-small, do not have the opportunity to adapt to all markets but benefit from an opening by regulation. That is why I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Regulation on gas appliances is intended to replace Directive 2009/142/EC by harmonising the conditions for placing gas appliances on the market and/or putting into service with regard to safety risks and the rational use of energy, allowing clear rules to be applied to the gas apparatus sector uniformly throughout the Union. The gas sector plays a key role in the EU economy and employs 476 000 people in the gas appliance sector alone. Gas appliances cover a wide range of products, from simple portable stoves to boilers for large buildings and currently gas stocks reach 470 million in the EU, with steady growth, with annual sales of more than 30 million units. I support the Stihler Report because I believe that the provisions inserted as a result of the alignment with the Decision on the New Legislative Framework are satisfactory and that the changes introduced in order to enhance consumer safety, such as preventing poisoning of people by carbon monoxide (which is the leading cause of death in Europe related to gas appliances), enrich the new legislative text.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I welcome the introduction of mandatory requirements for gas consumption facilities. From the point of view of internal market policy, and also in view of our efforts to improve regulation and simplify the legal environment, it is essential to observe and identical conformity assessment procedures in all Member States.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. I agree with the choice of the regulation to increase the level of harmonisation between the various national regulations, which will undoubtedly have a positive impact on the single market. The gas equipment sector is of great importance to the European economy. I agree with the changes that have been introduced which aim to improve consumer safety, especially with regard to the risk of carbon monoxide poisoning, which is the main cause of mortality in this sector.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The Gas Installations Regulation approved today aims to replace Directive 2009/142/EC. This Directive is an example of EU harmonisation legislation ensuring the free movement of gas-powered equipment. The Directive has made a significant contribution to the establishment and functioning of the single market and has harmonised the conditions for the marketing and/or putting into service of the gas-powered installations covered by it, having regard to the safety risks associated with gas and the rational use of energy. Directive 2009/142/EC lays down the essential requirements that gas-powered installations must meet in order to be marketed on the Union market. Despite the successful functioning of the Directive, there is broad agreement on the need to improve the Directive. The Directive has been amended to take account of the fact that, in accordance with the principle of full harmonisation, the national law of the Member States cannot make the placing on the market of gas-powered equipment subject to stricter or additional requirements. Thus, the essential requirements to be met and the conformity assessment procedures to be followed by manufacturers should be the same in all Member States. The instrument of the Regulation saves Member States the costs of transposing the Directive. In addition, the Regulation avoids the risk of divergent transposition, which may lead to a different level of protection and distortion of the internal market. The common text of the regulation adopted in the interinstitutional negotiations, approved today by Parliament, was eligible.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report is the final element of the three technical adjustment procedures adapting to the 'new legal framework' the rules applicable to personal protective equipment products, cableways and gas appliances. The new legal framework largely harmonises the obligations imposed on producers, importers and market surveillance authorities, reducing administrative burdens and increasing legal certainty for all actors involved in the manufacture and supervision of products placed on the EU market.  As regards gas appliances, I share the view, in particular, with regard to the maintenance requirements of professional service technicians and the wording used for carbon monoxide poisoning. The agreed text avoids the obligation to professionally maintain all gas appliances, including gas-fired tourist cookers, which are designed to be maintained in part by users, relying rather on national legislation to provide a more common-sense solution. With regard to cases of carbon monoxide poisoning, I fully support the work carried out by the rapporteur in this area to raise awareness of this problem. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Despite the successful Directive 2009/142/EC, that sets out essential requirements that appliances burning gaseous fuels must comply with in order to be made available on the EU market, there are issues mainly related to simplifying the European regulation environment in the field of gas appliances and fittings, clarifying and aligning existing provisions. Hence I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of appliances burning gaseous fuels, which intends to replace Directive 2009/142/EC. The regulation will align the provisions to the goods package adopted in 2008 and to the Decision EC 768/2008 on a common framework for the marketing of products.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ As a shadow draftsman on this report for my group I am pleased with the agreement reached, after extensive negotiations. It will reduce red tape for manufacturers and national authorities. We have avoided some of the more problematic original proposals in Parliament, such as professional servicing for typically self-maintained appliances such as camp stoves, by allowing national rules to be applied where those exist.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 The new proposal for a regulation adopted today updates and improves the previous legislation in force in the gas equipment sector – e.g. boilers, kitchens, ovens, barbecues and heating mushrooms – Directive 2009/142/EC. A legislative measure that finally defines a harmonised and precise European regulatory framework, interprets and applies uniformly the provisions on gas appliances for domestic and non-domestic use, which are used daily by European citizens. The regulation I supported also sets out shared technical standards, compliance and safety requirements, such as the marking of products under the CE mark, and specific rules for market surveillance of gas appliances. A series of technical measures that serve to further increase people's safety, promote a more rational and efficient use of energy and at the same time ensure fair conditions of competition for European companies. I am convinced that the completion of the internal market and the increasingly effective protection of consumers are intrinsically linked and should go hand in hand. The new rules voted on today are therefore an excellent example of the application of the principles of better regulation, which is necessary for the full functioning of the single market.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report aims to update EU legislation on the free movement of gas appliances, dating back to 2009, by harmonising the conditions for marketing or commissioning gas appliances. Gas is indeed an important sector in the European economy, covering a wide range of products (heaters, boilers). Each year, more than 30 million devices are sold. The primary objective of this text is to improve consumer safety and avoid carbon monoxide poisoning, which is the leading cause of death in Europe for gas appliances. Considering that the gas sector in Europe employs nearly 480,000 people and provides many practical solutions to consumers, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to improve and simplify the legislation for gas appliances. This measure aims to strengthen the guarantee of quality of the products offered on the EU market.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation imposes conditions for the placing on the market and commissioning of gas appliances that will become uniformly applicable throughout the Union, avoiding the risk of differences in transposition that could lead to different levels of safety protection and distort the internal market. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the amendment of the legal instrument from directive to regulation is in line with the general political commitment to work towards better regulation and simplification of the regulatory environment.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The proposed regulation amending a 2009 directive reinforces the regulatory constraints on the installation and use of gas appliances. While the obligation to inform and labelling the products concerned is also increased, the fact remains that the safety gain for consumers is minor. On the other hand, this text is part of the strengthening of the internal market and regulatory harmonisation, which is why I voted against it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 Unfortunately in my country very often there is a case of burst gas cylinders, both for domestic use and those that are attached to cars otherwise powered by gasoline. Unfortunately, all these cases either lead to a fatal end or have lasting consequences on the people using these appliances. This is one of the reasons I support this report. The other is that it aims at standardising these appliances, which will greatly reduce the administrative burden as well as improve all kinds of security for EU citizens.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The safety of users or those in places with gas appliances is quite an important issue, considering also that gas as fuel is becoming more widespread. The updating and the attempt to homogenise the rules concerning these devices is entirely in agreement with us.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The gas sector plays a key role in the EU economy and employs 476 000 people in the gas appliances sector alone. Gas appliances cover a wide range of products, from simple portable stoves to boilers for large buildings. There are currently 470 million gas appliances in the EU. More than 30 million units are sold every year. The new Regulation imposes clear and detailed rules which will apply uniformly and simultaneously throughout the Union. In accordance with the principles of full harmonisation, Member States are not allowed to impose stricter or additional requirements in their national legislation on the placing on the market of gas appliances. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it is more about harmonization than about a security imperative.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 It is proposed that Directive 2009/142/EC be replaced by a regulation, given the little flexibility in transposition of it. This Directive established rules for the placing on the market and commissioning of gas appliances, i.e. apparatus eats gaseous fuels used for cooking, cooling, air conditioning, heating the environment, producing hot water, lighting or washing, as well as fan burners and heat generators to be fitted with such burners. This Regulation should apply to household and non-household appliances intended for a number of specified applications and equipment intended to be incorporated into such appliances, and also covers appliances and equipment imported from third countries. It is essential that such appliances do not compromise the necessary guarantee of a high level of protection of the health and safety of persons and ensure the protection of consumers and goods and the rational use of energy. It is also essential that SMEs operating in this sector, in particular manufacturers, can receive the necessary support (technical and financial) to respond correctly and in a timely manner to the changes introduced by the Regulation, as such legislative changes should not be a covert way of favouring the largest companies in the sector and, therefore, increasing the concentration of market power.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution on gas appliances. I welcome the updating of the new regulatory framework in terms of harmonisation and simplification, which will lighten the administrative burden and improve legal certainty for all actors involved in the production and control of products placed on the EU market.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The safety of users or those in places with gas appliances is quite an important issue, considering also that gas as fuel is becoming more widespread. I fully agree with the update and effort to homogenise the rules on these appliances and I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on gas appliances.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The regulation aligns current legislation to the provisions of the goods package adopted in 2008 and in particular to Decision 768/2008/EC on a common framework for the marketing of products. It applies to domestic and non-domestic appliances intended for a number of specified applications burning gaseous fuels and to fittings designed to be incorporated into such appliances. It concerns the placing on the market of these products and protection of consumers while using the products concerned. Our main achievements concern rules to prevent gas poisoning and the leakage of any substances harmful to health and safety. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 Our number one priority in our work on the proposal for a regulation on personal protective equipment was to table amendments to ensure that the current directive does not allow for interpretations that undermine its effectiveness and legal certainty. The basic preamble is that only truly effective means can be used to ensure the safety of workers, taking into account that accidents at work are caused not only by the use of inadequate personal protective equipment, but also by the inappropriate use of them. We also found that the effective effectiveness of protective equipment can be ensured by the development and implementation of products adapted to the needs of their end-users. We therefore stress the need to take into account who wears the equipment and to distinguish between the following categories of users: men, women, young workers and people with disabilities. We also believe that, in order to minimise ambiguity and misinterpretation, certain aspects of the technical specifications of the Regulation should be reviewed to cover all risk categories and eventuality.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I supported the proposal for a Regulation on gaseous fuel appliances, intended to replace Directive 2009/142/EC. The change of legal instrument, from directive to regulation, is in compliance with the general political commitment to work for improving regulation and simplifying the regulatory environment and aims to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market for gas appliances. It imposes clear and detailed rules that will apply uniformly and simultaneously across the EU. We must also not forget that the gas sector plays an important role in the EU economy and, in the gas equipment sector alone, employs 476 000 people.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the EP and Council regulation on gas appliances because I believe that the harmonisation of the rules and requirements for the marketing of these products in the internal market is a primary interest for many citizens who regularly use these products. I am thinking of a sector that employs some 476 000 people in the Union, with almost 470 million units sold. I am therefore in favour of harmonising the conditions of sale on the market of these products so that the legislation reflects the new EU regulatory framework on the marketing of products, giving a further boost towards the completion of the single market.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on gas consumption facilities, as it contains some technically very important innovations that take account of the progress and safety of citizens. This report is a contribution to reducing red tape by modernising existing targets.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The gas sector is an important industry within the EU. The gas consumption sector in particular creates many jobs. I therefore support the free movement of gas consumption facilities. This industry can particularly benefit from further deregulation.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation is absolutely necessary, given that gas appliances cover a wide range of products and the fact that the number of gas appliances in the EU is estimated at 470 million and growing. A further 30 million units are sold every year. The sheer quantity of appliances therefore necessitates a high level of protection of the health and safety of persons, domestic animals and property. The report aims to achieve this by setting harmonised requirements and more transparent rules for gas appliance manufacturers.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This is a technical report containing all the formal provisions of EU legislation on goods and defining the obligations of the economic operators concerned (producers, dealers, importers and distributors). That is why we voted in favour of it.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report so as to ensure that appliances burning gaseous fuels on the market fulfil the requirements providing for a high level of protection of health and safety for users and for rational use of energy.
