With the previous directive, there was a lack of clarity with regard to the scope and definitions, which this new regulation aims to improve. This new regulation will also help to improve the functioning of the internal market for gas appliances and help to prevent distortions by some Member States not applying essential health and safety requirements or conformity assessment procedures. Unfortunately it is not within the scope of this regulation to include mandatory standards for carbon monoxide alarms or to require the fitting of a carbon monoxide alarm wherever a gaseous appliance is installed. This is something I had inquired about with the rapporteur and the legal services. Nevertheless, I am happy that there is a recognition of the dangers posed by carbon monoxide in the regulation and that it allows Member States to legislate on periodic inspections or installer training when deemed necessary.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report due to the important role the gas sector plays in the EU economy. The gas sector employs 476 000 people and gas appliances cover a wide range of products, from simple portable cookers to boilers for big buildings, The current EU stock of gas appliances is at 470 million and growing with no more than 30 million units being sold annually. I concur with the rapporteur that the change of legal instrument from a Directive to a Regulation is in line with the general political commitment to strive for better regulation and to simplify the regulatory environment.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: in writing. ‒ Six people died and more than 300 were left injured in Essex last year as a result of gas-related incidents. Carbon monoxide poisoning kills. In the last five years, the Gas Safe Register found dangerous appliances in one in six homes in this, just one of the six counties in my East of England constituency.  I am not just talking about gas fires and cookers; from the smallest portable camping stoves to industrial boilers for big buildings, the current EU stock of gas appliances is at 470 million and growing, with more than 30 million units being sold annually. Given this magnitude, a high level of safety is absolutely essential.  I welcome this report, proposed by my British Labour MEP colleague, which aims to achieve this higher level of safety by setting common requirements and more transparent rules for gas appliance manufacturers in Europe. This is the perfect example of the EU not simply looking to improve the lives of people, but actually to save them.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report with regard to appliances that use gaseous fuels taking into consideration that the gas sector is an important sector in the EU economy. The current EU stock of gas appliances is at 470 million and growing, with more than 30 million units being sold annually.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft european parliament legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on gaseous fuel appliances, on the basis that I think it is necessary for the rules in the sector concerned to be applied evenly across the Union in order to increase consumer confidence in the quality of products and to strengthen market surveillance. It is essential to protect the health and safety of users and to encourage rational use of energy in terms of sustainability and competitiveness of the sector and consistency of the European Union's energy policy. Precautions must definitely come first to avoid all forms of possible carbon monoxide poisoning, which is the main cause of death when it comes to gaseous fuel appliances.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This text has little change from the current directive. The underlying reason for this report is the harmonisation of the internal market, not security as it is claimed. I voted against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Catherine Stihler's report on the gas appliance regulation. This proposed regulation aims to replace the 2009/142/EC Directive, which harmonizes the conditions for the marketing and commissioning of gas appliances by guaranteeing essential requirements to be sold in the single market. The text thus strengthens consumer safety and precautionary measures have been modified to better combat carbon monoxide poisoning. This text was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which pushed for harmonising the conditions for the marketing of gas appliances, including the imposing of safety standards and the rational use of this energy.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am abstaining from my voice. While the proposals could contribute to better export opportunities, there is also a risk of additional financial burdens on citizens in the event of profits in the area of CO2 reduction and security.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Gas appliances cover a wide range of products, from simple portable cookers to boilers for big buildings, and the current EU stock of gas appliances is at 470 million and growing, with more than 30 million units being sold annually. Given this magnitude, a high level of protection of the health and safety of persons, domestic animals and property are absolutely essential and the report aims to achieve this by setting harmonised requirements and more transparent rules for gas appliance manufacturers.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on gas appliances, given that the text has little change from the current directive and that the objective is not a security objective but a regulational harmonisation of the internal market. It is part of the "Harmonisation of the Internal Market" package, and the concern for public safety is in fact just a pretext.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it shows little change from the current directive. Its objective is less a security improvement than an increase in harmonisation of the internal market.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Until now, gas appliances have been governed by a 2009 European directive. The aim of this report is to replace it, in order to simplify the legislation by defining the obligations of the economic operators of the sector (manufacturers, agents, importers, distributors). This text requires buyers or holders of a gas furnace to have it installed and maintained by a professional for security reasons, to inform consumers about the health and safety risks of the products, and to put in place a CE marking in accordance with the requirements. Under the guise of simplification, this report changes the existing regulations little or no. Moreover, under the pretext of security, it is part of a desire to harmonize the internal market. I have spoken out against this report.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Regulation adapts the current legislation to the provisions of the product package adopted in 2008 and, in particular, to Decision No 768/2008/EC on a common framework for the marketing of products. It applies to domestic and non-domestic gaseous fuel appliances intended for a number of specific applications and equipment designed to be incorporated into such appliances. It refers to the putting on the market of these products and the protection of consumers when they use such products. My group considers the final agreement reasonable, so I voted in favour.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree that the EU should further address the harmonisation of these appliances, these powers are to come from an international agreement between states and manufacturers.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 The report by Stihler highlighted the need to regularly maintain gaseous fuel appliances so that devices that are on the market do not endanger the health and safety of consumers or its surroundings.  This initiative is in agreement with the elements of the single market, which further encourages the trust of users and guarantees high quality services both in the European Union and in Croatia. It is essential to strengthen public awareness of the needs of regular maintenance of gas appliances in order to less harm the environment, but also to reduce the possibility of carbon monoxide poisoning, which is why I supported this Report.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ 30 million gas appliances are sold annually in the EU. I support the adoption of a unified regulation in the treatment and regulation of gas installations in the EU's internal single market. Mandatory basic procedures and conformity assessments, which must be respected by all manufacturers of gas appliances and appliances, will contribute to improving product safety while removing barriers to their placing on the internal market.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from voting on the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on gas appliances because I think it is not complete.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This unnecessary report brings nothing new and merely replaces an existing text by changing small provisions. This text itself is not aimed at security but at harmonizing the internal market through regulation.  Voting against will not undermine the security of our citizens and we strongly oppose any step aimed at strengthening the internal market.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I support the proposal for a Regulation on appliances burning gaseous fuels which intends to replace Directive 2009/142/EC. This Directive is an example of Union harmonisation legislation, ensuring the free movement of gas appliances. It has contributed considerably to the completion and operation of the Single Market and it harmonises the conditions for the placing on the market and/or putting into service of appliance burning gaseous fuels covered within its scope with regard to gas safety risks and rational use of energy. Directive 2009/142/EC sets out essential requirements that appliances burning gaseous fuels must comply with in order to be made available on the EU market. The gas sector plays an important role in the EU economy and employs 476 000 people in the gas appliances sector alone. Gas appliances cover a wide range of products, from simple portable cookers to boilers for big buildings and the current EU stock of gas appliances is at 470 million and growing, with more than 30 million units being sold annually.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Favourable to the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on gas appliances. The directive is designed to ensure the free movement and proper functioning of the internal market in gas appliances and accessories which are new on the Union market when they are placed on the market. It also lays down the essential requirements that gas appliances must meet in order to be made available on the EU market, in particular, the mandatory essential requirements and conformity assessment procedures that manufacturers must follow must be identical in all Member States.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 Gas appliances are a sensitive problem in which a fair balance must be found between safety requirements and the guarantee of competition. By voting in favour of this report, I also support the desire for greater protection of the environment and the health of citizens.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The regulation of gaseous fuel appliances is essential to ensure safety in an area affecting millions of citizens in Europe, and we must also make progress in harmonising the legislation of all Member States in this area. I support the report on the proposal to amend the legislation, moving from a directive to a regulation, and the amendments we have adopted to improve the content of the proposal from the point of view of consumer safety and with precautionary measures to be taken into account to avoid cases of carbon monoxide poisoning, which is the main cause of death in Europe related to gas appliances.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. On the one hand, a regulation brings more clarity and certainty to the production and use of gas consumption plants, but it also further curtails national competences. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This text has little change from the current directive. The underlying reason for this report is the harmonisation of the internal market, not security, as it claims. I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on gas appliances. It is extremely important that the mandatory essential requirements and conformity assessment procedures that manufacturers must comply with must be the same in all Member States, especially the requirements concerning the safety of gas appliances. Only in this way will the conditions that allow the free movement of gas appliances be met.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution in order to create a uniform set of rules for all Member States to ensure that the market for gas burning appliances can function properly.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The adoption of this regulation is primarily aimed at providing consumers and professionals with the same and necessary protection, regardless of where the product (the gas stove, the boiler) is manufactured. It was therefore essential to introduce obligations both to economic operators and to national entities responsible for verifying compliance with safety standards. The free movement of goods is one of the cornerstones of European integration. It requires us to optimize our cooperation and strengthen our competitiveness. It cannot be done at the expense of consumer protection, but must instead remain at the service of consumers.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – The fact that 470 million gas appliances are currently in use on the territory of the European Union and their number is constantly increasing is reason enough to reconsider legislation, which is currently at a high level, but its change from directive to regulation will contribute to better regulation of the sector. I consider a great benefit to the provision that deals with the rules that appliances must comply with in order to prevent carbon monoxide poisoning. Poisoning with this gas is currently the most common cause of death related to gas appliances in Europe. I find the report on this state of play alarming. As the sale of gas appliances increases every year, it is our duty that these provisions are not lacking in legislation and that this avoids unnecessary loss of life.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on appliances burning gaseous fuels, which aligns current legislation to the provisions of the goods package adopted in 2008 and in particular to Decision EC 768/2008 on a common framework for the marketing of products. It applies to domestic and non-domestic appliances intended for a number of specified applications burning gaseous fuels and to fittings designed to be incorporated into such appliances. It concerns the placing on the market of these products and protection of consumers while using the products concerned.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council regulating the internal market in gas-powered equipment. Currently, Directive 2009/142/EC lays down the essential requirements that gas-powered installations must meet in order to be marketed on the Union market. The legislation should be updated in line with the new legislative framework, the package of measures intended to streamlin and simplify the regulation of goods in the single market. In its report, the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection said that Parliament supported the proposal with more than 200 amendments. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This regulation replaces a 2009 directive on gas appliances in line with the objective of simplifying legislation. This text defines the obligations of the economic operators concerned (manufacturers, agents, importers and distributors), already largely existing at the national level. Given that the text has little change from the current directive and that the objective is not a security objective, but a harmonisation of the internal market by regulation, we will not vote in favour of this text.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on gas appliances is intended to replace Directive 2009/142/EC. This Directive guarantees the free movement of gas appliances and has contributed to a large scale to the completion and functioning of the single market and the harmonisation of conditions for placing gas appliances on the market and/or putting into service. I endorse the rapporteur's position on the change of legal instrument from a directive to a regulation, in line with the general political commitment to make efforts to better regulate and simplify the regulatory framework. The Regulation will reduce the costs of transposition of a Directive, as well as avoid the risks of divergence in transposition, which can result in different levels of security protection and distort the internal market.  For the foregoing, this report has my vote in favour.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This is a regulation on the safety and health of users, which requires us to be cautious in the positioning of our vote. Given that the text has little change from the current directive and that the objective is not related to security, but to the harmonisation of the internal market by regulation, I am opposed to this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on gas appliances. The aim was to approve the european Parliament and Council's proposal for a regulation, which aims to improve the internal market and consumer protection for such products. The gas appliance sector is very important in the EU: it employs 476,000 people and covers a wide range of products. More than 30 million devices are sold each year.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Stihler report. The proposed regulation intends to replace the 2009/142/EC Directive, which is an example of EU harmonisation legislation guaranteeing the free movement of gas appliances. It has made a significant contribution to the completion and operation of the single market and harmonizes the conditions for the marketing and/or commissioning of gas appliances within its scope with regard to gas safety risks and the rational use of energy. The 2009/142/EC Directive sets out the essential requirements that gas appliances must meet in order to be made available on the EU market. Provisions were introduced as a result of alignment with the decision on the new legislative framework (NCL).  The gas sector plays an important role in the EU economy, and even if only in the gas appliance sector, 476,000 people are employed. Gas appliances cover a wide range of products, from simple gas stoves to boilers in large buildings, and the current stock of gas appliances in Europe is 470 million and growing, with more than 30 million appliances sold each year.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 With a view to action to improve and simplify the European regulatory framework, the text, which requires the amendment of the legal instrument from directive to regulation, can only be welcomed. In view of the great importance of the gas appliances sector, both in the field of employment and in terms of consumption, the legislative proposal is positive because it is attached to improving the functioning of the relevant internal market. Indeed, the regulation, by imposing legislation common to all Member States, which will therefore not be able to supplement its provisions by means of national legislative acts, will ensure greater harmonisation and integration of the single market. The procedural rules will, in fact, require common compliance with standards and standards for all Community producers, regardless of their country of origin, which will therefore be able to prevent any kind of distorting effect on the markets. The proposal also appears to be very consistent with European environmental and consumer protection policies. The new regulation, in fact, seems open to compliance with and implementation of energy efficiency regulations. By postulating a strengthening of supervisory activity, it is organically part of the broader policy of protecting consumer rights.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. The proposed regulation on gas appliances has its place in the search for greater consumer safety. I therefore voted in favour of the report, allowing, in particular, the updating of the indication of compliance with European standards for greater transparency.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on gas appliances. This proposal is intended to replace Directive 2009/142/EC, which lays down the essential requirements that gas appliances must meet in order to be made available on the EU market, with new provisions to allow alignment with the new legislative framework. It has also contributed to the completion and functioning of the single market, as it harmonises the conditions for the placing on the market and/or commissioning of gas appliances falling within its scope with regard to the safety risks of gas and the rational use of energy.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on gas-powered equipment serves complex purposes. It improves consumer protection, facilitates eu law harmonisation and the completement of the single market. The report harmonises the conditions for placing gas-powered equipment on the market at Union level, thereby reducing the safety risk associated with these equipment and facilitating the rational use of energy. When voting on this report, I took these important factors into account. It is important to know that carbon monoxide poisoning is one of the leading causes of death at EU level, and efforts in this regard must be supported in all areas. In addition, the role of the gas sector in the labour market is important at EU level! Slightly less than half a million workers are employed in this sector. The legislation must be so adapted that it does not have a negative impact on the future of these workers.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will regulate the gas appliances sector by creating a single market which will have a positive impact on the European Union in terms of businesses and consumers.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report supports the conversion of the existing Gas Consumption Facilities Directive into a regulation and justifies this by the need for a better legal framework. However, this also leads to a further curtailment of national competences, which is why I abstained.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This rather technical report concerns the market and the use of gas appliances in Europe. It allows us to move from a directive to a regulation and, therefore, to push harmonisation within the Union further. With further definitions and clarifications, as well as with the introduction of measures on the eco-design of its devices, this report seems positive to me, which is why I voted for it.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Directive will significantly facilitate the functioning and completion of the single market, it sets out the essential requirements that gas appliances must meet in order to be made available on the EU market.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Noting that the gas sector plays a key role in the Union's economy and that gas appliances contain a wide range of goods involving a significant turnover (around 470 million units for more than 30 million units per year), I consider the transition of the legislation from directive to regulation to useful; By making the legislation directly applicable in the Member States, it is not possible for them to impose additional or stricter requirements. In view of my participation in the ENVI and ITRE Committees, I very much welcome the new provisions and amendments proposed by the rapporteur, which are part of the Union's energy policy. It is therefore consequential that I voted in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The gas sector has an important role in the EU economy, as well as in my home country, Bulgaria. The current EU stock of gas appliances is at around 470 million and growing, with more than 30 million units being sold annually. The proposal sets out essential requirements that appliances burning gaseous fuels must comply with in order to be made available on the EU market and I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒the proposed regulation does not change the purpose of Directive 2009/142/EC on gaseous fuel apparatus, but modifies some provisions to clearly determine and update its contents. Some of the most important changes proposed by this Regulation are the abolition of the outdated temperature limit of 105°C from defined introducing specific definitions for this area not covered by Directive 2009/142/EC, introducing harmonised content and forms of communication between Member States on the type of gas and supply pressure used in each of them, explaining the relationship between Directive 2009/142/EC and other EU rules, and explaining certain parts of Directive 2009/142/EC. The proposed regulation will be applicable two years after entry into force, in order to give manufacturers, competent authorities and Member States sufficient time to adapt. Due to the provision of a transitional period without difficulty, transitional provisions are provided for products manufactured under Directive 2009/142/EC. Very important for manufacturers and for users is the fact that this regulation proposes stricter rules when testing gaseous fuel apparatus, thereby bringing the risk of injury to a minimum.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Since the text has little change from the current directive and the aim is not security but the harmonisation of the internal market by regulation, I am voting against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. \u2012 When it comes to harmonisation of regulations with a view to improving the internal market in goods, special attention should be paid to those products, ingredients and parts that may pose a threat to health and safety. In this regard, I welcome this proposal for a regulation on gaseous fuel appliances relating to various household and household appliances and associated equipment.  Given that sales of these products within the Union reach as much as 30 million pieces per year, commendable achievements in harmonising regulations that would prevent the leakage of harmful gases (in particular carbon monoxide) or other substances harmful to the health and safety of all are also important. The change from directive to regulation will ensure clear and specified rules that can apply equally in all Member States and prevent transposition differences that potentially lead to distortions in the market or different levels of product safety.  Finally, it is important to point out that the regulation is consistent and in line with energy policy in terms of energy efficiency and renewable energy.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ This proposal would greatly contribute to the harmonisation of legislation within the European Union as well as to ensuring the free movement of gas appliances. It complements the free market and harmonises the conditions for use and the placing of gaseous fuel appliances on the market in view of the risks associated with the security of gas supply and rational use of energy. As the gas sector plays a vital role in the Economy of the European Union, employing 476 000 people in the gas appliances sector itself, this proposal is of significant importance. The stock of gas appliances in the European Union is around 470 million, of which more than 30 million are sold annually, and these figures are constantly growing. It is a significant fact that this initiative is in line with the Single European Act, which underlines the importance of ensuring consumers' confidence in the quality of products on the market and enhancing market watch.  For all these reasons, I support MEP Catherine Stihler's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on gas appliances.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2009/142/EC sets out the essential requirements that gas appliances must meet in order to be marketed in the EU. This proposal for a regulation is intended to replace Directive 2009/142/EC with clear and organic rules that will become applicable uniformly throughout the Union, without, however, changing its scope. In this way, the essential mandatory requirements, and the conformity assessment procedures to be followed by manufacturers, will be the same in all Member States. According to the content of Directive 2009/142/EC, gas appliance accessories do not bear the CE mark. Given that accessories must meet the essential requirements, so that they can properly achieve the purpose for which they are intended when they are integrated into equipment, it is proposed that the CE mark be included for the equipment as well. Another important aspect that is highlighted in this report is consumer protection in order to strengthen their confidence in the quality of products on the market. I believe that all these amendments to the existing directive are useful, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 This report also strengthens the internal market and is not just regulation for regulation. For this reason, even as a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I have decided to support it.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this regulation because it sets out the essential requirements that gas appliances must meet on the European Union market. The gas sector plays an important role in the EU economy. This text pays particular attention to consumer safety. It focuses on precautionary measures against carbon monoxide poisoning, which remain the leading cause of death in Europe linked to gas appliances.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report which I voted in favour of is aimed at ensuring the proper functioning of the internal market for gas appliances and imposes clear standards that will be applied uniformly and simultaneously throughout the European Union, so that no Member State can impose additional requirements on its national legislation. I voted in favour of this report because it provides for the strengthening of precautionary measures to prevent poisoning by inhalation of carbon monoxide, one of the main causes of death in Europe related to gas appliances.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 Essential requirements are laid down that gas appliances must comply with in order to be made available on the EU market. It imposes clear and detailed rules which will apply uniformly and simultaneously throughout the Union.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this agreement reached at first reading with the Council on the Regulation on gaseous fuel appliances and equipment which are new to the Union market at the time of their marketing. This Regulation, which adapts current legislation to the provisions of the product package adopted in 2008 and, in particular, decision No 768/2008/EC on a common framework for the marketing of products, applies to domestic and non-domestic gaseous fuel appliances intended for a number of specific applications and to equipment designed to be incorporated into such appliances. This new legislation lays down harmonised standards for the marketing of these products and for the protection of consumers when using such products, in particular the prevention of gas poisoning and the leakage of any substance harmful to health and safety.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal replaces Directive 2009/142/EEC on the free movement of gas appliances and represents an extremely important step towards the completion and full functioning of the single market, as well as for harmonising the conditions of operation and placing on the market for gas/gas appliances. Gas appliances cover a wide and wide range of products for both domestic and commercial/industrial use, and this sector plays an important role in the Union economy, securing almost half a million jobs. It should also be seen that the current number of appliances in Europe has seen strong growth in recent years. With the replacement of the previous Directive, another step is taken towards deepening the Single Market towards further legislative harmonisation in the context of the conditions for placing and operating such appliances on the market, in particular with regard to the implementation of greater safety requirements and the rational use of energy. For the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this report on a regulation to replace the 2009 directive on the free movement of gas appliances. In particular, the directive set out the essential requirements that gas appliances must meet in order to be made available on the EU market. The aim of this text is to improve consumer safety, as carbon monoxide poisoning is the leading cause of death in Europe for gas appliances, while maintaining the competitiveness targets of the gas sector in Europe.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The report proposes replacing the existing directive on the free movement, placing on the market and/or commissioning of gas appliances with a view to greater harmonisation of EU rules. We must support any initiative aimed at the completion and functioning of the single market, which is why I voted in favour of this initiative.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this regulation because it introduces an updated set of measures aimed at streamlining and simplifying the common essential requirements and conformity assessment procedures to be followed by manufacturers when placing gas appliances on the market. In particular, I consider it a success for the rapporteur to enforce the requirements on preventive measures in order to prevent poisoning of persons caused by carbon monoxide. These are the main cause of death in Europe in relation to gaseous fuel appliances.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report because I believe that it introduces a number of measures which result in the minimisation of safety checks on gaseous fuel appliances, reducing the current control by the Member States. I have also warned of the inclusion of aspects aimed at the elimination of the safeguard clause, leaving the door open to self-regulation by companies.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report adopted today because it aims to simplify and update the existing rules on gas appliances in order to lighten the administrative burden and improve legal certainty for all those involved in the production and supervision of products placed on the European market. The scope of the proposal concerns appliances used for cooking, refrigerating, air conditioning, heating environments, producing hot water, lighting or washing, and includes, in comparison with the previous directive, safety, control and regulatory devices and their sub-groups incorporated in gas appliances. I believe that in an area particularly at risk of accidents such as gas appliances, consumer safety must be particularly protected; Thanks to the new regulation, the new appliances placed on the European market will ensure a further increase in the safety and protection of citizens, as well as a rational use of energy. I am also pleased that the report refers to carbon monoxide poisoning as one of the many problems associated with the use of gas appliances, and not as the only problem that can be encountered, as was originally foreseen.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Regulation aims to strengthen the harmonisation of the European market with regard to gas appliances. As was already the case in the legislation that changes here, the proposal excludes the devices specifically designed to fulfill tasks in the industrial process. The text that is now being voted on has already been harmonised by the co-legislators. Because It seems to me that this proposal for a regulation leads to an improvement in terms of domestic security and introduces advantages for informed consumption, I voted positively for this proposal.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal as I do not wish to see EU Regulation in this area.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the gas sector plays an important role in the EU economy and employs 476 000 people in the gas appliances sector only. There are currently 470 million gas appliances in use in the EU and their number is constantly growing (30 million are sold each year). I supported the resolution because the current regulation, like the two other regulations that Parliament is negotiating - cableway equipment, personal protective equipment - comes up with measures and proposals to prevent the risk of possible different transpositions, and only products that comply with the relevant regulations and do not pose a risk to anyone have always been placed on the market. I also voted in favour of the resolution because Europe needs a legal framework in the area of appliances burning gaseous fuels that improves regulation and simplifies the regulatory environment. I expect the new regulation to ensure, in practice, that appliances burning gaseous fuels and their accessories comply with harmonised requirements ensuring a high level of protection of the health and safety of persons, domestic animals and property and the use of energy is as rational as possible.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Today's adoption of amendments to the draft EU regulation on gaseous fuel appliances has contributed to improving the safety of European Union citizens. The new proposal, which passed its first reading today, aims to change the legal framework from directive to regulation. This legislative form will better avoid different implementations in different Member States and thus guarantee the same security protection. More than 470 million cookers, boilers and other gas appliances are used daily in and outside the EU. By clarifying and harmonising the existing rules for producers and importers, as well as from third countries, market surveillance and product control will be strengthened, thereby avoiding, inter alia, gas poisoning and leakages of harmful and hazardous substances, which are the main cause of death in Europe in relation to gas appliances. I very much welcome the introduction of stricter health and safety requirements under the new regulation, which should also contribute to increasing consumer confidence in the quality of products.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The report refers to the proposal for a regulation on gaseous fuel installations to replace Directive 2009/142/EC. A revision of the legal instrument from the Directive to a regulation would bring better regulation and simplification of the regulatory environment, in line with general political efforts. The proposed regulation should thus ensure the proper functioning of the internal market for gas appliances.  The gas sector plays an important role in the EU economy and employs 476,000 people. Gas appliances cover a wide range of products, which currently have 470 million in the EU and their number continues to grow.  The proposal for a Regulation contains specific provisions for Union harmonisation legislation on products and lays down the obligations of the relevant economic operators (producers, authorised representatives, importers and distributors) in accordance with the decision on a new legislative framework. The text of the regulation also includes a number of amendments which give greater weight to consumer protection and includes amendments on precautionary measures that should be taken to prevent carbon monoxide poisoning.  I believe that it is crucial that such an important sector is properly regulatoryly regulated and that it provides for appropriate regulatory measures for the relevant industry. For this very part, I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on gaseous fuel installations.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported amendments to Directive 2009/142/EC, which advocates that all gaseous fuel appliances available on the market meet the conditions that would have to ensure a high level of health protection and a high level of safety for users, but also its assets and rational use of energy. The Regulation proposes stricter testing rules for all types of gaseous fuel apparatus, which is essential for producers and users, as this would keep the risk of possible injury to a minimum.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The gas sector plays an important role in the EU economy and employs 476 000 people. Gas appliances cover a wide range of products. Here we are talking about simple portable cookers all the way to boilers for large buildings. This initiative is in line with the Single Market Act, which stressed the need to ensure consumer confidence in the quality of products on the market and the importance of strengthening market surveillance. This is in line with the Union's energy policy and does not affect the application and implementation of Union energy efficiency and renewable energy legislation. Furthermore, this initiative supports the Commission's policy of simplifying regulation. I am aware of all the benefits of this proposal and that is why I support it.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on gaseous fuel installations. The report brings some important amendments that I support. One of these is an amendment to exclude from the Regulation devices which have historical and artistic value and are not put into service as antiques, as well as other devices used for exhibition or collectible purposes.  I also welcome the amendment to delete the Commission's proposal that equipment manufacturers should issue a certificate of conformity of equipment, in which they should provide information on the conformity of equipment with the requirements of this Regulation. The issue of certificates of conformity of equipment would only constitute additional work for undertakings and further confusion in the fulfilment of their obligations.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The safety of users or those in places with gas appliances is a very important issue, especially considering that the use of gas as fuel is becoming more widespread. It is essential to update and make the rules for these devices homogeneous.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The gas sector is important for the economy and citizens of the European Union, employing up to half a million Europeans not only in the energy sector, but also in the production of appliances burning gaseous fuels. It is worth noting that gas is used in both very simple kitchen portable appliances and the most technologically advanced industrial boilers. The proposed Regulation aims at harmonising the conditions for the placing on the market and putting into service of appliances burning gaseous fuels. That Regulation not only lays down the obligations incumbent on the manufacturers of those products, but also the obligations of importers and distributors. It is to be hoped that the introduction of this regulation can contribute to reducing the losses resulting from the use of defective or incorrectly efficient appliances burning gaseous fuels.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I am in this text tending to harmonize. The gas sector plays an important role in the EU economy and, if only in the gas appliance sector, 476,000 people are employed there. Gas appliances cover a wide range of products, from simple gas stoves to boilers in large buildings, and the current stock of gas appliances is 470 million and growing, with more than 30 million appliances sold each year.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal to set up an EU regulation instead of Directive 2009/142/EC. This Directive enabled harmonisation of the conditions for placing on the market appliances burning gaseous fuels. Turning the directive into a regulation is in line with my agenda for better regulation as it will simplify the regulatory environment. This was confirmed by the Commission’s impact assessment. In addition, Member States will not be allowed to impose any additional requirements in their national legislation.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported a proposal to regulate gaseous fuel apparatus that would replace the current one and ensure the free movement of gas-powered appliances. I believe that this proposal will harmonise the conditions for placing such appliances, which will contribute to a simpler regulation of environmental protection and ensure a more convenient functioning of the market for gaseous fuel appliances. I also support clear objectives set that will benefit both producers and consumers, taking into account security measures and rational energy distribution. In my view, the proper and efficient functioning of the internal market requires common rules for gas-powered appliances in terms of health and safety risks due to the use of gas, as well as their energy efficiency. Since the proposal is in line with a single market act that emphasises customers' confidence in the quality of products as well as many improvements in solving potential and possible problems, I voted to adopt it.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on gas-fuelled installations, because given that the gas sector plays an important role in the EU economy (it employs 476 000 people in the gas plant sector alone) and that more than 30 million gas installations are sold every year, I believe that the existing Directive 2009/142/EC needs to be updated. The new directive, which simplifies the European regulatory environment, in particular by clarifying and unifying the existing provisions, has a greater weight from the point of view of consumer protection. I also support the amendments on precautionary measures to prevent human poisoning by carbon monoxide, which is the leading cause of death in relation to gas appliances in Europe.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The regulation makes very little change from the directive already in force (transposition in national laws). The objective is not related to security but to the harmonisation of the internal market by regulation.  I am opposed to that. So I'm voting against it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The reporter supports the proposal for a regulation on gas-powered installations to replace Directive 2009/142/EC. This Directive is an example of EU harmonisation legislation ensuring the free movement of gas-powered equipment. The Directive has made a significant contribution to the establishment and functioning of the single market and harmonises the conditions for the marketing and/or putting into service of gas-powered installations covered by it, having regard to the safety risks associated with gas and the rational use of energy. There are currently 470 million gas-powered installations in the EU, and this number is increasing as 30 million units are sold each year. I voted in favour of the document.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour to maintain or improve the high level of consumer protection and ensure consistency of the regulations with the goods package.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: Writing. – In Latvia, at the beginning of the heating season, an average of 60 to 70 patients are admitted to hospital every year, poisoned by steam gas. The most common cause of these life-threatening poisonings is the leakage of gas boilers.  I am pleased that we have developed stricter rules for gas installations in the European Parliament. As we have asked in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, producers will be obliged to design gas equipment in such a way that no accumulation of carbon monoxide or carbon dioxide or other substances harmful to health is formed. With this Regulation, boilers and gas cookers, ovens, barbecues for baking, outdoor heaters and boilers will become considerably safer. The Law also stipulates that only professionals will be allowed to install and operate any type of gas equipment. It should be noted that there are currently around 470 million gas combustion plants in the EU, and this number continues to grow, with more than 30 million sales sold annually. There is also growing interest in autonomous gas heating in dwellings in Latvia.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This proposal is intended to replace Directive 2009/142/EC, which is an example of the harmonisation of legislation, as it ensures the free movement of gas appliances. This amendment aims to lay down certain essential requirements relating to the safety and rational use of energy to harmonise the conditions for the distribution and marketing of gaseous fuel appliances. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to vote in favour of this report. Gas appliances are a big part of our lives and the economy, from simple portable cookers to the industrial boilers needed for big buildings. The current European stock stands at 470 million and growing, that is almost one for every single citizen in the EU. This stock is also growing, with more than 30 million units being sold annually. The sheer size of the area means that safety measures are vital for the health and happiness to our citizens. This report helps to maintain a high level of protection for persons, domestic appliances and properties. This can be achieved by harmonising safety requirements across the EU and creating more transparent rules for gas appliance manufacturers. It is vital that we continue to do so in the coming years.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted to convert the directive into a regulation. This will simplify the applicable regulations and national authorities will no longer be able to impose additional requirements in their national legislation.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 It is proposed that Directive 2009/142/EC, which established rules for the placing on the market and commissioning of gas appliances, should be replaced by a regulation. This Regulation should apply to household and non-household appliances intended for a number of specified applications and equipment intended to be incorporated into such appliances, and covers new appliances and equipment manufactured by a manufacturer established in the EU or new or used appliances and equipment imported from a third country. It is essential that such appliances do not compromise the necessary guarantee of a high level of protection of the public interest, in particular the health and safety of persons and domestic animals, the guarantee of the protection of consumers and goods and the guarantee of the rational use of energy. On the other hand, it is also essential that SMEs in Member States operating in this sector, in particular manufacturers, be able to receive the necessary support (technical and financial) to respond correctly and in a timely manner to the changes introduced by the Regulation, as such legislative changes should not be a covert way of favouring the largest companies in the sector and, consequently, increasing the concentration of market power.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. On the one hand, a regulation brings more clarity and certainty to the production and use of gas consumption plants, but it also further curtails national competences. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on gas consumption facilities. This Regulation applies to gas consumption equipment and equipment which is listed as new on the Union market, either produced by a manufacturer established in the Union or imported from a third country. The aim of the project is to adapt the existing legal situation to the new regulatory approach without extending regulatory access. This has not been fully achieved.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of new safety rules for gas appliances to help keep UK consumers safe. Strict safety requirements are really important in this industry, as gas appliances include a huge range of products, from simple portable cookers to boilers. This report aims to achieve this by setting harmonised requirements and more transparent rules for gas appliance manufacturers.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on appliances consuming gaseous fuels which will replace Directive 2009/142/EC. This directive is an example of Union harmonisation legislation, ensuring the free movement of gas-consuming appliances. The gas sector plays an important role in the EU economy and creates 476,000 jobs in the gas-consuming appliances sector alone.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report, which was adopted by a large majority in the committee responsible.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on gas appliances, which replaces Directive 2009/142/EC, which lays down essential requirements that gas appliances must comply with in order to be made available on the European Union market. I therefore believe that this Directive is an example of harmonisation of EU legislation, which will not only ensure the free movement of gas appliances, but also allow for full harmonisation of the conditions for placing gas appliances on the market and/or putting gas appliances within its scope to be put into service with regard to gas-related safety risks and the rational use of energy. I also think it is important that this initiative is in line with the Single Market Act, ensuring consumer confidence in the quality of available gas appliances by imposing clear standards that will apply uniformly and simultaneously throughout the Union, especially with regard to strengthening market surveillance of gas appliances.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 It is proposed that Directive 2009/142/EC be replaced by a regulation. That Directive established rules for the placing on the market and putting gas appliances into service, i.e. apparatus eats gaseous fuels used for cooking, cooling, air conditioning, heating the environment, producing hot water, lighting or washing, as well as fan burners and heat generators to be fitted with such burners. It is essential that such appliances do not compromise the necessary guarantee of a high level of protection of the public interest, in particular the health and safety of persons and domestic animals, the guarantee of the protection of consumers and goods and the guarantee of the rational use of energy. On the other hand, it is also essential that SMEs in Member States operating in this sector, in particular manufacturers, be able to receive the necessary support (technical and financial) to respond correctly and in a timely manner to the changes introduced by the Regulation. Since such legislative changes should not be a covert way of favouring the largest companies in the sector and therefore increasing the concentration of market power, we voted in favour.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 The market for gaseous fuel installations plays an important role in the European economic area; the sector employs around 476 000 people and 30 million units are sold each year.  The proposal for a regulation thus lays down the essential requirements to be met by gas appliances. As the proposed measures will further strengthen consumer protection, reduce the risk of accidents when using appliances and contribute to more rational energy consumption, I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, there are many thousands of cable cars operating in Europe today. It is vital that they are safe and that the public has full confidence in their safety. This new regulation will help ensure up-to-date and strengthened design and construction standards for the future of cable car transport, including in sporting and urban settings. As the lead member for this measure for the Socialists and Democrats, I warmly welcome the new rules and the fact that they were overwhelmingly adopted by this Parliament. I also welcome the extensive work that has been undertaken to achieve this improvement in cable car regulation, and especially to put in place clearer drafting and a tougher penalties regime to prevent and to deal with breaches of the law.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – The European Union is the world's leading region for the use of cableway installations. Around 17 500 local installations account for 60% of the world's total. The European Union also holds leading positions in the production of such equipment. It is therefore absolutely logical and correct that the aim of the new regulation will therefore be to replace the old directive on cableway installations for the transport of persons. The renewal of the relevant legislation, in parallel with efforts to take into account the latest standards to ensure the safety of passengers and the technical regulations, lays the foundations of the new regulation. This is important, and it is important that the new regulation does not affect historical structures, agricultural and forestry-based equipment, as well as other equipment which is only used for pleasure purposes and not for transporting persons. I'm positively welcome!

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, cosúil leis an dá thuarascáil roimhe seo tá an tuarascáil seo ag tabhairt seans dúinn an margadh aonair a chur i bhfeidhm arís. Dar ndóigh, vótálas i bhfabhar. Bhí mé ag an díospóireacht aréir agus bhí a lán Feisirí ag caint agus ag tabhairt tacaíochta dó — ní nach ionadh. Because this again is a very important little piece of legislation, maybe not the most high profile, there may be no publicity out of it for the rapporteur, but nevertheless it helps to make European Union citizens safer because the application of harmonised standards and rules in relation to the safe installation of cableways, the marketing of components, subsistence and infrastructure is an important piece of work for the benefit of workers and the general public. I also feel it is a sensible approach to leave out historical cableways from this area. Agus arís, tá an jab déanta go maith ag an rapóirtéir.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has opposed this proposal on the principle that we are against further harmonisation of the internal market. This relates specifically to the change of the legislation from a directive to a regulation.
politicalGroup: The Earl of) Dartmouth Mike Hookem Diane James Margot Parker and Julia Reid (EFDD
partyIdeology: The Earl of) Dartmouth Mike Hookem Diane James Margot Parker and Julia Reid (EFDD

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it represents an increase and improvement in the scope of the proposed Regulation, improving fundamental aspects such as passenger safety in all types of cable transport facilities. Parliament's report increases the scope of the Regulation by including a reference not only to mountain tourism facilities, but also to sports facilities of a historical nature, etc. Also, a very positive aspect is the repeated mention of the precautionary principle, which is clearly established as a fundamental principle in the development and authorization of installations of this genre, increasing the requirements that this type of equipment must meet. It is because of this objective improvement for the safety and control of all facilities based on cable transport that I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against this report to replace the 2000 Cable Facilities Directive. Indeed, despite some interesting technical proposals, this regulation does not meet any need of the professionals concerned and only reinforces the normative constraints to which they are subjected. Finally, the current directive presents a satisfactory level of requirement in a sector that is doing well. It is therefore not useful to change it.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which deals with safety aspects related to cableway installations. Although being primarily concerned with harmonising standards throughout the EU, many safety aspects are still left to the control of national Member States such as the appointment of competence national authorities to control cableways, analysis procedures by those bodies, market surveillance and penalties for breach of safety standards.  The regulation further puts in place a notification system for when a defect is detected in one country, and is assumed not to be confined to the territory of that country. Given that the aims are to provide protection for users, operators and workers, I was happy to support the proposals.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 With this report, Parliament and the Council propose the implementation of a regulation on wire ropes installations in order to bring this legislation into line with the provisions of the package of legislative measures on goods adopted in 2008 and more specifically with the European Commission Decision 768/2008 establishing a common framework for the marketing of products. The new regulation proposed in the report I voted for is intended to improve the area of market surveillance and the safety of consumers and other users of wire ropes installations. Members of the Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament have also been able to make explicit reference to the precautionary principle as well as to the strengthening of the safety of consumers and other users.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report requires the "CE" stamping of cable installations. Once again, the Union is allowing itself an unnecessary and costly requirement when there are already many quality controls. That is why I objected.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ As with the previous report, the Health and Safety Executive in the United Kingdom already has appropriate legislation in place.  Further harmonisation will not enhance public safety but will generate further bureaucracy.  I therefore voted against this proposal.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to harmonise the conditions for placing subsystems and safety components of cableway installations on the market and to ensure the free movement of these products within the EU. All safety components and subsystems will have to be designed and manufactured in accordance with the essential requirements laid down in this Regulation. With regard to cableway installations, this Regulation also provides for full harmonisation of the essential requirements which they must meet. This Regulation repeals and replaces 20 March 2000. Directive 2000/9/EC on cableway installations for passenger ships.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved this resolution, which supports the proposed regulation to harmonize the marketing conditions for subsystems and safety components for cable installations and to ensure the free movement of products within the Union. Under this proposal, all safety components and subsystems will have to be designed and manufactured in accordance with the essential requirements set out in the proposed regulation.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on cable way installations. The aim of the measure, which has a high degree of technicality, is to harmonize the legislation of the Member States on the design, manufacture and placing on the market of subsystems and safety components for cable-rope installations. The text presented by my colleague Antonio López-Istúriz White clarifies in particular the differences in the application of the legislation between facilities used for the transport of persons and cable-rope installations used for recreational activities. Given the quality of the report and my sharing of content, I have chosen to vote in favour of it.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this as this is a report which makes a directive a regulation for the harmonisation of safety measures in cable transport facilities. It is a question of moving one step further in harmonisation at European level without undermining the ability of Member States to regulate sensitive matters in terms, for example, of historical installations or cultural heritage.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work and the effort made to reach agreement on the proposal for a Regulation on cable transport installations which lays down rules on the marketing and free movement of subsystems and safety components of such installations. It also contains rules on the design, construction and commissioning of new cable transport facilities. I welcome this agreement.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I did not think it was appropriate to vote in favour of this proposed regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on cable installations. First mistake: the only real purpose of the regulation is to replace a 2000 European directive in order to avoid any national transposition law, i.e. to override the prerogatives of national parliaments. The current directive already regulates the construction and operation of cable installations such as funiculars, cable cars, ski lifts, etc. The future regulation seeks only to harmonize European standards for subsystems and constituents - including the obligation to provide a declaration of compliance with them stamped "EC" - in the name of the sacrosan ndp single market. However, European companies already dominate this sector, notably a Franco-Italian group which generates 80% of its turnover in the EU. We therefore once again have an attempt at normative hyperproduction - the current standards being sufficient - to the European way at the very expense of our economic and industrial interests.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The López-Istúriz White report analysing the simplification and improvement of safety criteria for cable-based installations is acceptable and balanced. I consider the text to be voted on without any particular critical issues, I agree with the rapporteur's decision to specify precisely the fields of application of this regulation and the exclusion of historic plants such as the ancient funiculars present in many of our cities, all of which go in the direction of containing the increase in costs for companies active in the sector. For all these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have abstained on these three reports on the establishment of new regulations (instead of directives). The consequence of these reports is that no EU Member State may legislate for higher protection and environmental rules with regard to cableway installations, appliances for the combustion of gaseous fuels and personal protective equipment. I think that is fundamentally wrong. Having a minimum limit on environmental and protection measures that all Member States must achieve is one thing, but it is wrong to decide that no Member State should be able to improve its legislation independently in terms of protecting people and the environment. That's why I put my voice down.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This proposal for a Regulation on cable transport installations is another example of harmonisation of Union legislation. This proposal wants to harmonize the conditions for the introduction into the market of new cable transport facilities, including subsystems and safety constituents. Cable installations are mainly cable-drive elevators such as railways, funiculars, cable cars, gondola lifts, chairlifts and ski lifts and other facilities for tourist or sporting purposes. The new Regulation improves market surveillance and the safety of consumers and other users. In addition, an explicit mention is made of the precautionary principle (product and consumer safety). That is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament supports the proposal for a regulation on cableway installations, which is an example of harmonisation of European Union legislation. The proposal aims to harmonise the conditions for placing subsystems and safety components on the market of cableway installations and to ensure the free movement of these products within the EU. All safety components and subsystems will have to be designed and manufactured in accordance with the essential requirements laid down in this Regulation. With regard to cableway installations, this Regulation also provides for full harmonisation of the essential requirements which they must meet. The amendment of the legal instrument from the Directive to the Regulation is in line with the overall political commitment to better regulation and simplifying the regulatory environment. The decision to make this amendment was taken in the light of the need to ensure uniform implementation throughout the European Union. Since this Regulation provides for full harmonisation, Member States may not impose more stringent or additional requirements in their legislation. However, Member States will continue to have the right to regulate other aspects relating to cableway installations, such as land use, regional planning and environmental protection. In this respect, it is to be welcomed that a regulation has been chosen, as this will avoid unnecessary transposition costs and introduce clear and detailed rules that will apply uniformly throughout the European Union.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. The proposed report on the new regulation on cableway installations also seemed to me to be worth supporting. Its essential purpose is to harmonise the conditions for placing subsystems and safety components of cableway installations on the market and ensuring their free movement within the EU. This means that all safety elements will have to be designed and produced in accordance with the requirements of that Regulation.  As with the PERSONALing report, this case is about changing the legal instrument from a directive to a regulation, ensuring uniform implementation of legislation across the EU. However, Member States remain competent to regulate other aspects related to cableway installations, such as land use, regional planning and environmental protection.  The proposed regulation will also contain provisions on market surveillance for cableway installations and is expected to provide greater legal clarity for users.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the changes made to the legislation on cable-rope installations contribute significantly to the clarification and simplification of the framework in this area by imposing clear and organic rules that will become applicable uniformly throughout the Union at the same time.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The current proposal for a regulation on cable-rope installations is an example of EU harmonisation legislation. The harmonisation of the conditions for placing subsystems and safety components on the market for cable-shaped installations is useful in ensuring the free movement of these products in the EU. The obligation provided for in the proposal to design and manufacture, In accordance with the basic requirements laid down in the new regulation, all safety components and subsystems increase the level of safety of citizens using cable-based installations, both for passenger transport and for the handling of goods, ensuring uniform implementation throughout the Union with clear and detailed rules that will avoid the costs of transposition or secondary adaptation, looking at the criterion of the highest standard as a factor for the protection of the internal market and the safety of the consumer/user of the cable way system.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This regulation is intended to replace the current EUROPEAN directive governing the construction and operation of cable facilities, such as cable cars, gondolas or chairlifts. The report calls for harmonising European standards for subsystems and security components. In addition, the new regulation, which this text promotes, would require the intervention of notified agencies in the production and design phase as well as a safety analysis of all ongoing installation projects. We believe that the current legislation sufficiently guarantees the safety of users of this type of facility. As a result, this new regulation seems to us to be unnecessary or even harmful to those in a healthy industry, as manufacturers will be subject to additional constraints.  So I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The conditions for the placing on the market of subsystems and safety components for cableway installations and ensuring the free movement of these products in the EU are an example of the need to harmonise European legislation. The Union shall endeavour to better legislate in order to ensure the free movement of these products. All safety components and subsystems will have to be designed and manufactured in accordance with the essential requirements laid down in this Regulation, which will increase product quality and human safety. We note, however, that Member States retain their powers to regulate other issues relating to cableway installations, such as land use, regional planning and environmental protection, although they are opting for implementation by regulation. The choice is welcome, as it will eliminate unnecessary transposition costs and impose clear and detailed rules that will be uniformly applicable throughout the Union.  I voted in favour of this report, because I believe that both for these proposed measures and for the change of the legal instrument of the directive in the regulation, it is appropriate to substantially simplify the regulatory framework and avoid the risk of divergent transposition.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. In practice, the text does not contain any politically problematic aspects. One of the Aims of the European Commission is to simplify and improve safety criteria. The interests of companies in our territory seem to be sufficiently protected by the measure.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on cable-rope installations. The proposal aims to harmonise the conditions for placing subsystems and safety components on the market for cable-shaped installations and to ensure the free movement of these products in the EU. All safety components and subsystems must be designed and manufactured in accordance with the basic requirements of the Regulation. The latter also provides for the overall harmonisation of the basic requirements to be met by such passenger transport facilities by repealing and replacing Directive 2000/9/EC of 20 March 2000. Finally, exclusions from the scope of the regulation are clearly indicated, such as cable-rope installations used for leisure activities in amusement parks and amusement parks. The text before us fully achieves the objectives that had been identified, and that is why I voted for its acceptance.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which deals with safety aspects related to cableway installations. Although being primarily concerned with harmonising standards throughout the EU, many safety aspects are still left to the control of national Member States such as the appointment of competence national authorities to control cableways, analysis procedures by those bodies, market surveillance and penalties for breach of safety standards.  The Regulation further puts in place a notification system for when a defect is detected in one country, and is assumed not to be confined to the territory of that country. Given that the aims are to provide protection for users, operators and workers, I was happy to support the proposals.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report so that the existing legislation can be updated in line with the New Legislative Framework (NLF) on the marketing of products. This will increase transparency and improve safety of the products.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Today we are voting on the third text for the protection of consumer safety.
