As this is an essential condition, together with the M5S Europa delegation, I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Antonio López-Istúriz White because the text aims, among other things, to harmonise the safety requirements of cable-based installations in all Member States.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I am glad that the historic cable cars have been removed from the scope of the regulation. In the Czech Republic, we have de facto saved, for example, today's form of the funicular to Petřín or a similar attraction in Karlovy Vary. These devices will not strictly require their components to comply with the Regulation. After all, this would not be conceivable at the historic engine room of the Petrin cable car. Of course, this does not mean that these plants will be less safe, they must meet the basic safety standards, which are regulated by the Czech Republic's own legislation. I fully support the regulation, as clearer rules will apply to lift and cable car operators, and it means greater certainty for consumers that the facilities are safe not only in our country, but throughout Europe.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the proposal for a regulation on wire ropes installations because it aims to harmonise the conditions for placing on the market subsystems and safety components for wire ropes installations, and to ensure the free movement of these products in the EU. All safety components and subsystems should be designed and constructed in compliance with the essential requirements laid down in the Regulation.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Strengthening the framework of rules protecting consumers at pan-European level must remain at the heart of our attention at all times. Therefore, today's debate on the harmonisation of safety rules on wire ropes installations and equipment would not be able to receive a negative reception. Since I consider this resolution to be positive, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to support the report on the proposal for a regulation of Parliament and of the Council on cable way installations because I support the need to simplify and harmonise legislative production. The proposed regulation on installations, the scope of which concerns cable-rope installations, their subsystems and safety components, replaces the existing Directive 2000/9/EC, thus adapting the legislation to the new regulatory framework.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted wholely in favour of this proposal for a regulation, having tabled a question on this subject several months ago. However, although this regulation is a step forward, I still have some misgivings: this text lays down the technical requirements for installations, while regulatory disparities remain with regard to the management aspects of ski lifts. I am referring to professionals who could be merged but which the laws of the individual States provide for (distorting competition in favour of other States that have looser legislation and therefore entail less costs for companies) and which are not justified by greater security. The next step is therefore to take these other aspects.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission proposal for this regulation aims at updating existing EU legislation on cableway installations and thereby bringing it also into line with the New Legislative Framework (NLF) on the marketing of products. There are several thousand cableways in Europe today and it is important that citizens feel safe when using one. The new regulation will help ensure up-to-date and stronger design and construction standards for the future of cableway installations.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Regulation aims to harmonise the conditions for the placing on the market of subsystems and safety components for cable installations and ensures the free movement of these products within the EU by repealing Directive 2000/9/EC. Cable facilities are mainly lifting systems such as funiculars, cable cars, telesquis and other facilities for tourism or for sports purposes. I support the White report because I believe that, on the one hand, the change of legal instrument allows for better regulation and simplification of the regulatory framework, aligned with the Decision on the New Legislative Framework, and because the new proposal introduces more clarity and is based on the precautionary principle.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported, with my vote in favour, this report which aims to update existing legislation on cable-rope installations. I agree, in particular, with the introduction of provisions that improve market surveillance.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it represents an increase and improvement in the scope of the proposed Regulation, improving fundamental aspects such as passenger safety in all types of cable transport facilities. Parliament's report increases the scope of the Regulation by including a reference not only to mountain tourism facilities, but also to sports facilities of a historical nature, etc. Also, a very positive aspect is the repeated mention of the precautionary principle, which is clearly established as a fundamental principle in the development and authorization of installations of this genre, increasing the requirements that this type of equipment must meet. It is because of this objective improvement for the safety and control of all facilities based on cable transport that I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation on cableway installations is an example of EU harmonisation legislation. The proposal aims at harmonising the conditions for placing on the market of components and safety components to be incorporated in cableway installations and ensuring the free movement of those products within the Union. All safety components and components must be designed and manufactured in accordance with the essential requirements of this Regulation. The Regulation also provides for full harmonisation of the essential requirements for cableway installations which they must comply with. The Regulation also repeals and replaces Directive 2000/20/EC on cable-towing railways for passenger transport. The Directive has been changed to a regulation because the Regulation provides for full harmonisation and Member States cannot impose more stringent or additional requirements in their national law. The regulation avoids the risk of divergent transposition, which may lead to a divergent level of protection and distortion of the internal market. The common text of the regulation adopted in the interinstitutional negotiations, approved today by Parliament, was eligible.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report is a summary of Parliament's work on three technical adjustment procedures adapting to the 'new legal framework' the rules applicable to personal protective equipment products, cableways and gas appliances. The new legal framework largely harmonises the obligations imposed on producers, importers and market surveillance authorities, reducing administrative burdens and increasing legal certainty for all actors involved in the manufacture and supervision of products placed on the EU market.  I believe that the report rightly points out the importance of protecting historic cableways from being covered by the full scope of the regulation, since the spare parts of the equipment of such historic railways are made to measure and, as such, these devices could not be included in the tests referred to in the Regulation, without consequence in the form of costs which would probably prevent the further operation of such railways. With this in mind, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The report is on the proposal for a regulation which will repeal and replace Directive 2000/9/EC of 20 March 2000 relating to cableway installations designed to carry persons. This regulation applies to new cableway installations and covers subsystems and safety components which are new to the Union market when they are placed on the market. The new regulation improves market surveillance and safety for consumers and other users, hence I voted in favour of the report

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report as a sensible agreement which should reduce administrative burden and enhance consumer safety. I particularly welcome the common-sense approach taken to historic cableways, which have been excluded from the scope of the regulation. Such visitor attractions as Bridgnorth’s Cliff Railway already comply with national health and safety requirements and would have found it very difficult to meet the standardised replacement parts requirements of the regulation given their custom-built nature. Thanks to this agreement these historic tourist attractions can continue to be enjoyed by generations to come.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 Italy, together with Germany, France, Austria and Switzerland, has more than half of the 17,500 cableway plants in Europe. Ascent systems such as funiculars, cable cars, cable cars, cable cars, chairlifts, ski lifts and other lifts for tourist or sports purposes are essential for the operation of the entire ski and urban transport sector, its main markets. The aim of the new proposal is to update and improve the previous legislation in force, Directive 2000/9/EC. A measure that finally clarifies the European regulatory framework, defining precisely its scope, strictly interprets and applies the provisions in a market that plays an important role for our country's economy. The approved regulation defines shared technical standards, compliance and safety requirements, marking and market surveillance of cable cars and leads to improved surveillance and safety for citizens, sportsmen and women and any other type of user. Today's vote is another step towards a priority objective for the Union and for the Group of the Party of European Socialists and Democrats: the completion of the European internal market and its full and proper functioning.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report aims to update EU legislation on cable installations and equipment marketing. These include funiculars, gondolas or cable cars, which are very present in mountainous regions.  The main objective of this text is to strengthen the security associated with these facilities, through common rules for compliance assessment and market monitoring by public authorities. It should be noted that historical installations are excluded from the scope of this text.  Considering that these rules aim to introduce common and protective safety standards at EU level, without additional bureaucracy for businesses, I have supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to improve and simplify the legislation for cable installations. This measure is beneficial to users as it aims to provide a high level of protection for user safety.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation aims to harmonise the conditions for placing subsystems and safety components on the market for cable-rope installations used for the transport of persons, ensuring the free movement of such products in the EU. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the amendment of the legal instrument from directive to regulation is in line with the general political commitment to work towards better regulation and simplification of the regulatory environment. The choice of regulation avoids the risk of differences in transposition by imposing clear and detailed rules applicable uniformly throughout the Union.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. Although the text contains several interesting technical points, this regulation is not justifiable by a request or any need from professionals in the sector (manufacturers, companies). It appears that the standards already in place in this area are satisfactory. Considering that normative inflation should be avoided whenever possible, according to the adage "too much regulation kills regulation", I voted against this report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 Any decision of ours that leads to a reduction in administrative burden, as well as an improvement in the security of the people of the EU, will always meet my support, of course, if there are no hinds thoughts. Lifts are usually used when people indulge in rest and want to enjoy their holiday in the mountains. That is why we must ensure their security and allow them to enjoy the views around them, not worry about their security. That is why I support this report, and I hope that this is, if not a comprehensive solution to this security, at least one step towards it.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I believe that this is a positive piece of legislation because the use of barbed wire in installations involving human lives, both for leisure and professional reasons, requires very serious safety checks and certifications. The same applies, of course, to the transport of products. The important thing is that all these measures are observed and that there are no interests that will exploit human life.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal aims to harmonise the conditions for placing on the market subsystems and safety components for cable installations and to ensure the free movement of these products within the EU. All safety components and subsystems must be designed and manufactured in accordance with the essential requirements laid down in the Regulation. As regards cable installations, the Regulation also provides for full harmonisation of the essential requirements to which they must comply. The Regulation repeals and replaces Directive 2000/9/EC of 20 March 2000 on cable installations for the transport of persons. As the Regulation provides for full harmonisation, Member States are not allowed to impose stricter or additional requirements in their national legislation. However, Member States remain competent to regulate other aspects relating to cable installations, such as land use, spatial planning and environmental protection. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it does not require real additional safety standards.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 It is proposed that Directive 2000/9/EC be replaced by a regulation, given the little flexibility in transposition of directive. This Directive established rules for cable installations designed, constructed and operated for the transport of persons, but merely lay down the essential requirements applicable to such installations. The Regulation lays down rules on the availability on the market and the free movement of subsystems and safety components of cable installations and lays down rules for the design, construction and entry into service of new cable installations. It applies in its entirety to new cable installations and to changes in cable installations requiring further authorisation. It is essential that cable installations do not endanger the health and safety of persons and property, and it is imperative that safety rules are well defined and respected. On the other hand, it is also essential that SMEs operating in this sector, in particular manufacturers, can receive the necessary support (technical and financial) to respond correctly and in a timely manner to the changes introduced by the Regulation, so as not to favour the largest companies in the sector and, consequently, to increase the concentration of market power.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the measures it identifies reduce administrative burdens and improve legal certainty for producers and those involved in product surveillance; I also welcome the measure concerning historic cable-rope installations, which will be able to continue to operate without the use of very probably prohibitive costs.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on wire ropes installations because the use of barbed wire in installations, whether for recreational or professional reasons, with a possible impact on human lives, requires very serious safety checks and certifications. The same applies, of course, to the transport of products. The important thing is that all statutory measures are observed and that there are no interests that will exploit human life.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The Regulation aligns current legislation to the provisions to the goods package adopted in 2008 and in particular to Decision 768/2008/EC on a common framework for the marketing of products. It applies to new cableway installations and covers subsystems and safety components which are new to the Union market when they are placed on the market. The regulation does not apply to cableway installations of historical construction, installations intended for agricultural or forestry purposes, cableway installations for the service of mountain shelters and huts intended only for the transport of goods and specifically authorised persons and on-site or mobile equipment exclusively designed for leisure and amusement purposes and not as a means for transporting persons. The new regulation improves market surveillance and safety for consumers and other users of cableway installations. A main achievement is the inclusion of the explicit mentioning of the precautionary principle, as well as enhanced safety for consumers and other users. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for a regulation on cableway installations, which is an example of EU harmonisation legislation. The proposal aims at harmonising the conditions for placing on the market of components and safety components to be incorporated in cableway installations and ensuring the free movement of those products within the Union. All safety components and components must be designed and manufactured in accordance with the essential requirements of this Regulation. The Regulation also provides for full harmonisation of the essential requirements for cableway installations which they must comply with. The Regulation repeals and replaces Directive 2000/20/EC of 9 March 2000 on cable-towing railways for passenger transport.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal, which aims to harmonise the conditions for the introduction on the market of subsystems and safety constituents for cable transport facilities and to ensure the free movement of these products in the EU. It is also very positive that unnecessary costs of transposition will be avoided and clear and detailed rules will be imposed which will be uniformly applicable throughout the Union.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. It's winter - ski season. Across Europe, millions of citizens use cable cars to reach the destination of their skiing pleasure. Millions of people, many families, must be able to rely on a technology based on a European internal market. I therefore welcome the EU's efforts to improve safety here by updating and harmonising the technical specifications. I have therefore voted in favour of this report and wish all winter sports enthusiasts an accident-free pleasure. Whether in the cable car or on the slopes!

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Free movement of goods and uniform safety standards have always been the hallmarks of a free European internal market. I therefore welcome the fact that this will now also apply to products from the cable car industry in the future.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ Cableways are a common feature in ski and sports resorts across the EU and also play a key role in many urban transport systems. This regulation will help to harmonise the rules to make sure that newly constructed cableways meet stringent health and safety requirements, protecting the passengers and workers who travel on them.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Cableways are a common feature in ski and sports resorts across the EU and also play a key role in many urban transport systems. Today's vote will help to harmonise the rules to make sure that newly constructed cableways meet stringent health and safety requirements, protecting the passengers and workers who travel on them.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We were concerned that the regulation would be fully harmonised and that it would prevent Member States from imposing more stringent additional measures on their national legislation. However, the regulation contains some exceptions and the Member States retain the ability to legislate in other areas relating to wire ropes, which we consider to improve safety. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Regulation on Cableway Installations. The regulation will repeal and replace Directive 2000/9/EC of 20 March 2000 relating to cableway installations designed to carry persons. As the diverging transposition in the implementation report of Directive 2000/9/EC was identified as a problem, I welcome this change to a regulation from a directive. The change takes into account the need to ensure a uniform implementation throughout the EU. As the regulation foresees total harmonisation, Member States are not allowed to impose more stringent or additional requirements in their national legislation, but Member States will remain competent to regulate other aspects relating to cable installations such as land-use, regional planning and environmental protection. Furthermore, it will avoid unnecessary transposition costs and impose clear and detailed rules which will become applicable in a uniform manner throughout the EU.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it endorses the proposal for a Regulation on cableway installations which is an example of Union harmonisation legislation. The proposal sets out to harmonise the conditions of placing on the market of subsystems and safety components for cable installations and to ensure the free movement of these products in the EU. All safety components and subsystems will have to be designed and manufactured in compliance with the essential requirements provided for by the Regulation. With regard to the cableway installations, the Regulation also foresees total harmonisation of the essential requirements to which they must comply.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report as it sets out to harmonise the conditions of placing on the market of subsystems and safety components for cable installations and to ensure the free movement of these products in the EU.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on cable cars, as this aligns the conditions for the marketing of cable car subsystems and safety components, and guarantees the free movement of these products within the European Union, which has a direct impact on the single market. In order to achieve such a thing, it is necessary to ensure a uniform implementation of the rules across the Union, taking into account that certain aspects of cableway installations such as regional and environmental planning remain under the competence of the Member States. Moreover, it is necessary to provide legal clarity in order to implement legislation in the area concerned in a coherent and effective manner.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This report requires that cable installations be stamped "CE." Again, this is an unnecessary and costly requirement, given the many quality controls already in place. I voted against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Antonio Lopez-Isturiz White's report on the cable regulations. With this text, the aim is to update existing European legislation under the new legislative framework. The aim is therefore to clarify European standards and to achieve harmonisation between Member States. The harmonized approach will include compliance assessment procedures and the EC label.  This text was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aimed to harmonize the marketing conditions for cable installations (teleskis, funiculars, gondolas, etc.), to strengthen the safety of these facilities and to ensure the free movement of these products within the Union.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The measures in this report create major safety gains in the cable car sector. I am therefore voting in favour of this proposal.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, as it will help to harmonise the rules to make sure that newly constructed cableways meet stringent health and safety requirements, protecting the passengers and workers who travel on them.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on cable installations. This text, although it contains some interesting technical points, does not reveal any additional safety requirements demanded by manufacturers or companies in the sector. A regulation is therefore not useful, since the current standards are already satisfactory and the European sector of activity is in good health.  As CE marking is not an original marking but an additional quality control constraint required of manufacturers, it is appropriate to refuse a normative bid which penalises the players in the sector anyway.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it requires cable installations to be stamped "CE". However, this is an unnecessary requirement given the existing quality controls.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. If there is nothing shocking about this report, I still voted against it. It aims to replace the 2000 directive governing cable installations (tele-cars, funiculars, gondolas, etc.). However, this directive already had a satisfactory level of requirement, particularly in terms of safety standards. Finally, this regulation does not meet a specific need of the professionals concerned and only reinforces the normative constraints (including CE marking), which they must face. There is no need to add more for a sector that is doing well overall.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Regulation aligns the current legislation with the provisions of the product package approved in 2008 and, in particular, Decision No 768/2008/EC on a common framework for the marketing of products. It applies to new cable transport installations and includes new subsystems and safety constituents on the Union market when placed on the market. The new Regulation improves market surveillance and the safety of consumers and other users of cable transport facilities. The main achievements of the S&D Group include the specific mention of the precautionary principle, as well as greater consumer and user safety. For these reasons I voted for it.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree that the EU should further address the harmonisation of these facilities, these powers are to come from an international agreement between states and manufacturers.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒I supported Representative Antonio Lopez-Isturiz White's report because I think it is necessary to harmonise all the conditions for placing on the market subsystems and safety components for cable cars. Member States must take all necessary measures if it is established that an approved cable car could endanger the health, safety of persons and property to limit working conditions or to prohibit its operation.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing \ u2012 The proposal for a regulation harmonises the requirements for cableway installations and their placing on the internal market of the European Union, thereby unifying the regulatory environment. Not only the equipment itself, but also all components and subsystems will have to meet the specified requirements. Market surveillance of these facilities is regulated and unified.  All this will contribute to unifying the level of protection and safety of these devices, while removing barriers to their placing on the market.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on wire ropes for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 19/1/2016 and because it is a complete and documented report.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text.  This report must replace an existing 2000 directive to avoid any national transposition law. It supervises the construction and operation of cable installations (funiculars, cable cars, gondolas, chairlifts, etc.) with a harmonization of safety requirements. The future regulation is aimed at harmonising European standards for sub-systems and security components, now included in the broader definition of 'cable installations'. This text does not reveal any additional safety requirements requested by manufacturers or companies in the sector. In the end, it is limited to adding an additional constraint and playing the normative over-bid. We oppose it.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I support the proposal for a Regulation on cableway installations which is an example of Union harmonisation legislation. The proposal sets out to harmonise the conditions of placing on the market of subsystems and safety components for cable installations and to ensure the free movement of these products in the EU. All safety components and subsystems will have to be designed and manufactured in compliance with the essential requirements provided for by the Regulation. With regard to the cableway installations, the Regulation also foresees total harmonisation of the essential requirements to which they must comply. The Regulation shall repeal and replace Directive 2000/9/EC of 20 March 2000 relating to cableway installations designed to carry persons.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Favourable to the proposal for a Regulation of Parliament and of the Council on cable-rope installations. This Regulation shall apply to new cable-rope installations and shall regulate subsystems and safety components which are new to the Union market at the time of placing on the market. The proposal aims to harmonise the conditions for placing subsystems and safety components on the market for cable-shaped installations and to ensure the free movement of these products in the EU. It is therefore a proposal for a Commission regulation which aims to update existing Eu ropean legislation on cable-rope installations, bringing it into line with the new legislative framework) on the marketing of products.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report will ensure greater security for European citizens, especially in tourist areas with cable-based facilities. The transformation of the previous directive into a regulation is an important signal in this direction.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I would like to congratulate my colleague Antonio López-Istúriz on the report we have adopted to strengthen the safety of cable transport facilities used for the transport of persons, which will also harmonise the rules applicable to this sector throughout Europe. The rules in this area, dating back to 2000, needed to be updated to ensure high protection of citizens and to establish detailed technical standards that will be uniformly applicable throughout the EU.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Europe-wide safety standards for cable cars should be supported in order to prevent possible accidents. In addition, the VO has been defused in some respects in order not to place an undue burden on operators and manufacturers of small lifts. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report which updates existing EU legislation on cableways.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The report aims to harmonize the gas appliance regulations. The report introduces the requirement for "EC" marking on gas appliances to ensure compliance. It extends this obligation to related equipment. These rules and measures are essential to prevent gas poisoning, including carbon monoxide (CO), and leakage of any substance harmful to health and posing a danger to safety. The precise report pushes attention to detail to define "cooking", since the offending appliances are most often cooking appliances. It is "the art or practice of preparing or heating food for consumption using heat and a wide range of methods."  From chemistry to gastronomy Europe still has a long way to go. I am voting for this text which, although it is mainly aimed at enabling better market efficiency, will also increase information and user safety.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report requires cable installations to be stamped "CE." Again, this is an unnecessary and costly requirement, given the many quality controls that exist. I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a regulation of Parliament and the Council on cable installations. This proposal aims at harmonising the conditions for placing on the market subsystems and safety components for cable installations and ensuring the free movement of these products within the EU. It is extremely important that all safety components and subsystems will have to be designed and manufactured in accordance with the essential requirements laid down in the Regulation. In addition to those requirements, union market surveillance measures should also be strengthened.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution in order to harmonise the safety regulations and free movement of cableway installations, creating a uniform set of guidelines across the Union.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. This proposed regulation is the result of an inter-institutional product safety agreement taken in September 2015 for cable installations (funiculars and gondolas). Its aim is to simplify and update the provisions of Directive 2000/9/EC with a view to greater legal certainty.  Replacing the directive with a regulation uses an appropriate legal instrument which, by imposing clear and detailed rules, introduces identical obligations to economic operators and national entities responsible for verifying compliance with safety standards. This is the only way to have uniform implementation across the Union.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – Harmonisation of the conditions for placing subsystems and safety components for cableway installations on the market is a question of ensuring safety for the general public. Cableway facilities are used most often in tourism, recreational facilities or public transport. All these places are visited by a large number of ordinary people, often used by families with young children. It is therefore in the interests of all of us to do everything that can help to ensure the best level of safety throughout the European Union in this area, and I see the uniform conditions for the placing on the market of these devices, as well as their components, as a decisive step towards achieving it. The single market in rope installations is the best way to avoid fluctuating levels of safety protection and to set a standard that is generally applicable throughout the European Union.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on cableway installation, which aligns current legislation to the provisions of the goods package adopted in 2008 and in particular to Decision EC 768/2008 on a common framework for the marketing of products. It applies to new cableway installations and covers subsystems and safety components which are new to the Union market when they are placed on the market. Cableway installations are mainly lift systems, such as funicular railways, aerial ropeways, cable cars, gondolas, chairlifts, drag lifts and other installations for tourism or sports purposes. The Regulation does not apply to cableway installations of historical construction, installations intended for agricultural or forestry purposes, cableway installations for the service of mountain shelters and huts intended only for the transport of goods and specifically authorised persons, and on-site or mobile equipment exclusively designed for leisure and amusement purposes and not as a means for transporting persons. The new regulation improves market surveillance and safety for consumers and other users of cableway installations.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the harmonisation of the conditions for placing on the market of components and safety components to be incorporated in cableway installations and ensuring the free movement of those products within the Union. The Regulation replaces Directive 2000/20/EC on cable-towing railways for passenger transport. The Regulation harmonises the provisions relating to cableway installations with the package of goods adopted in 2008 and, in particular, with Decision 768/2008/EC on a common framework for the placing on the market of products. In its report, the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection said that Parliament supported the proposal with almost 150 amendments. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The Commission proposes to replace with a regulation an existing directive that regulates the construction and operation of cable installations (funiculars, cable cars, gondolas, chairlifts, ski lifts, etc.). While the directive sets out harmonised safety requirements, the future regulation aims to harmonize European standards for safety subsystems and components, now included in the expanded definition of cable installations. The text does not reveal any additional safety requirements requested by manufacturers or companies in the sector. It is therefore not useful in view of the already satisfactory standards in force and the good health of the European sector of activity. As CE marking is not an original marking, but an additional constraint on quality control imposed on manufacturers, it is appropriate to refuse a normative overbid which penalises the players in the sector in every way.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Regulation on cable installations aims to replace Directive 2000/9/EC and aims to harmonise the conditions for placing on the market subsystems and safety components for cable installations and to ensure the free movement of these products within the EU.  The amendment takes into account the need to ensure uniform application throughout the Union. I endorse the rapporteur's position on the change of legal instrument from a directive to a regulation, with the aim of making efforts to better regulate and simplify the regulatory framework. The Regulation will reduce the costs of transposition of a Directive, as well as avoid the risks of divergence in transposition, which can result in different levels of security protection and distort the internal market.  For the foregoing, this report has my vote in favour.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This text does not reveal any additional safety requirements requested by manufacturers or companies in the sector.  On the face of it; a regulation is therefore not useful since the current standards are already satisfactory and the European sector of activity is in good health.  As CE marking is not an original marking but an additional quality control constraint required of manufacturers, it is appropriate to refuse a normative bid which penalises the players in the sector anyway.

name: Clare MOODY
text: in writing. ‒ Cableways are a common feature in ski and sports resorts across the EU and also play a key role in many urban transport systems. Today’s vote will help to harmonise the rules to make sure that newly constructed cableways meet stringent health and safety requirements, protecting the passengers and workers who travel on them.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ Cableways are a common feature in ski and sports resorts across the EU and also play a key role in many urban transport systems. Today’s vote will help to harmonise the rules to make sure that newly constructed cableways meet stringent health and safety requirements, protecting the passengers and workers who travel on them.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on cable installations. The aim was to approve the european Parliament and Council's proposal for a regulation, which aims to improve the internal market and consumer protection for such products.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the adoption of this proposal for a regulation on cable-rope installations, because it is a concrete example of EU harmonisation legislation. The proposal is, in fact, aimed at harmonising the conditions for placing subsystems and safety components on the market for cable-shaped installations and ensuring the free movement of these products in the EU. All safety components and subsystems shall be designed and manufactured in accordance with the basic requirements of this Regulation, which is based on the general principle of precaution and consumer protection. Since the regulation establishes total harmonisation, Member States will no longer be allowed to impose additional or stricter requirements in their national legislation. Finally, we welcome the decision to propose the measure through a regulation, thereby avoiding all unnecessary transposition costs and imposing clear and detailed rules applicable, immediately and uniformly, throughout the Union. This choice was also dictated by the desire to avoid the risk of divergences in transposition, which could consequently lead to different levels of protection of the safety and health of European consumers and to hinder the internal market.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the cable installations report, deeming it necessary to grant the current legislation with the new legislative framework.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal aims to harmonise the conditions for placing subsystems and safety components on the market for cable-shaped installations and to ensure their free movement in the EU. All safety components and subsystems shall be designed and manufactured in accordance with the basic requirements of the Regulation. The Regulation repeals and replaces Directive 2000/9/EC of 20 March 2000 on cable-rope installations for the transport of persons. I voted in favour of this measure because I support the need to simplify and harmonise legislative production.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I place a very important emphasis on consumer protection, which is why I support the report, which provides for minimum requirements for components and safety components to be incorporated into cableway installations, ensures uniform conditions for placing on the market and guarantees the free movement of these products within the Union. Under existing legislation, it was difficult to determine which products would be covered by the legislation. On the basis of experience, producers have in several cases used this to their advantage. I hope that this loophole will be removed in the future and, as a result, the number of accidents associated with cableway installations will also decrease.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will facilitate free movement of cable installations and will increase efficiency in the market of subsystems.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to modernise legislation on under-sea cables and allows for better enforcement within the Union, through the transition from a directive to a regulation. For example, the report calls for full harmonization of the rules and conditions for marketing safety subsystems and components for cable installations; it also sets out the necessary safety requirements for users, operators, workers and third parties. The area of environmental protection, marketing authorisation, the management of compliance with pre-1986 facilities remain the responsibility of Member States as well as the "on land" management of under-sea cables.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report, as Europe-wide safety standards for cable cars are to be advocated in order to prevent possible accidents. In addition, operators and manufacturers of smaller lifts should not be unduly burdened by conditions, without disregarding the safety of the passengers transported.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The proposal aims to harmonise the conditions for the placing on the market of alarm systems and safety components for cableway installations and to ensure the free movement of these products within the EU, as well as to update legislation.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am pleased to note that the new regulation repeals and replaces Directive 2000/9/EC, harmonising discipline and inhibiting states from creating different regimes that would create market distortions and differences in treatment. I also believe that it is a priority, as the rapporteur has made clear, to clarify the cable ways covered by the legislation and the excluded installations, thereby dispelling the persistent doubts in this area. On the basis of what has been said, I can vote in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Cable installations have a strong market in Europe. I am in favour of the report as it is necessary to have a high level of consumer protection with clear standard rules to apply in a unified manner across the EU.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. I support this proposal because I believe that Member States should take all necessary steps to ensure that cable cars can only be put into service if they comply with this Regulation and cannot jeopardise the health or safety of persons or property safety, if properly installed and maintained and used in accordance with their intended purpose.  I also support this proposal by making it clear that when placing subsystems and security components on the market, each importer on the subsystem or security component should indicate their name, registered trade name or registered trademark and the postal address where it is available, as well as websites if any. Exceptions should be provided for cases where the size or type of subsystem or safety component does not allow it. Member States should lay down rules on penalties applicable to breaches of this Regulation and ensure their application. The penalties envisaged should be effective, in line with the gravity of the infringement.  Given that cable cars represent an alternative form of public transport and can contribute to the achievement of greenhouse gas emission reduction targets, I support this proposal, which modernises existing Union legislation.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The text does not reveal any additional safety requirements requested by manufacturers or companies in the sector. A new regulation is therefore not helpful as the current standards are satisfactory and the industry is in good health. CE marking is not an original marking but an additional quality control constraint imposed on manufacturers. I reject this normative over-bid which penalises the players in the sector and I therefore vote against this text at best useless.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ This proposal for a cable car regulation seeks to harmonise the conditions of market placement of subsystems and the safety parts of cableway installations in order to ensure their freedom of movement in the internal market. It is commendable that it strives for maximum harmonisation to ensure simpler, better and safer rules. In this regard, it is better that it is a regulation rather than a directive.  Cable cars are defined as lift systems, such as funievers, suspension cable cars, suspension cable cars with cabins, chairlifts, lifts and other cable cars used for tourist or sporting purposes. It is positive that historical and museum traction installations and those in forestry or agriculture function are not included in the regulation, as the aim is to cover the safety aspects of public use, i.e. use on public transport. I consider that the issue of security, with the importance of market surveillance and harmonisation, is essential for this Regulation and addressed in a quality manner by the text of the proposal.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒I agree with the report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on cable cars prepared by my colleague Antonio López-Istúriz White. The proposed regulation, which targets existing cableway laws in the European Union, clears up the inclusion of subsystems and safety components of cable cars in the volume of regulation. One of the purposes of this proposal is to refer to the difficulties that arose in the implementation of Directive 2000/9/EC. For example, the authorities, notified bodies, and manufacturers have completely different answers to the question of whether the specific type of installation is covered by Directive 2000/9/EC and must therefore be manufactured and certified in accordance with the requirements and procedures of the directive.  Such an approach can lead to distortion of marketing and different treatment of economic operators, which is completely contradictory to the single and harmonised internal market of the European Union. I therefore believe that this proposal will be of great importance and I fully support it.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a regulation aims to replace Directive 2000/9/EC of 20 March 2000 on cable-rope installations for the transport of persons. I voted in favour because the aim of this initiative is to harmonise the conditions for placing subsystems and safety components on the market for cable-shaped installations and to ensure the free movement of these products in the EU. This avoids the risk of divergences in transposition, which can lead to different levels of security protection and hinder the internal market. It is also considered important to improve the coherence of the text with the new regulatory framework (NQN) and to introduce specific rules on market surveillance. The proposal also has the privilege of making clearer the scope that applies to cable-rope installations designed for the transport of persons, subsystems and safety components intended for such installations.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 Compared to protective equipment or appliances for gaseous fuels, it may seem that cable cars are not our frequent companions and some might have doubts about whether the regulation submitted is necessary. However, here, too, the same rules are at play within the single market, and I believe that the proposal comes from our Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection in a rational form that deserves your support.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. I welcome the presentation of this report which, on the one hand, aims to harmonise the conditions for the placing on the market of subsystems and safety components for cable installations and, on the other hand, seeks to ensure the free movement of these products within the EU. I voted in favour of this report because, although it ensures uniform application throughout the Union, it also allows Member States to continue to be able to regulate aspects of cable installations (land use, spatial planning and environmental protection). In this way, it will be possible to ensure compatibility with the decision on the new legislative framework (NQL) as well as market surveillance. Also for subsystems, conformity assessment procedures are maintained with regard to the safety components provided for in Directive 2000/9/EC on cable installations.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal aims to harmonise the conditions for placing on the market subsystems and safety components for cable installations and to ensure the free movement of these products within the EU. All safety components and subsystems must be designed and manufactured in accordance with the essential requirements laid down in the Regulation.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament yesterday set the floor in stone with proposals for a regulation strengthening the safety of certain products. One of these is cable infrastructure (funiculars, gondolas). The changes that the European Parliament makes to the regulations will simplify and modernise the legislation that has been in place for 25 years, which aims to prevent the marketing of counterfeit or fraudulent security products. These amendments include certain obligations of economic operators and national entities responsible for verifying compliance with safety standards. Manufacturers will also benefit from a simplified procedure for renewing their certificates of compliance with health and safety rules.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the European Commission's proposal for the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council which aims to update existing Union legislation on cable installations for the transport of persons, such as funiculars, telecabins, chairlifts, cable cars or functions. This Regulation replaces Directive 2000/9/EC on cable installations with a regulation laying down rules on the design and construction of such installations and their availability on the market and the free movement of the underlying safety subsystems and components. It is therefore intended not only to ensure a high level of security of cable installations for users, workers and third parties, but also to establish the essential safety requirements to be respected. This proposal is therefore another step in deepening the single market (as a result of the replacement of a Directive by a Regulation), as well as another example of union legislative harmonisation which guarantees not only free movement within the EU single market, but also guarantees the same conditions for placing this type of facilities on the market. For the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this proposed regulation on cable installations, which aims to harmonize EU legislation. The proposal aims to harmonize the marketing conditions for subsystems and safety components for cable installations and to ensure the free movement of these products within the Union.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this regulation because it brings an updated set of conditions for the delivery of sub-systems and safety features for cableway installations to the market and ensuring the free movement of these products in the EU. I very much welcome the explicit reference to the fact that the provisions of this regulation are based on the precautionary principle. I consider it to be a fundamental principle of ensuring product safety for the benefit of their users.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 There are currently around 17,500 cable cars in Western Europe and the Alps and the ski sector is still the main market for related technologies. In addition, Italy, Germany, Austria, France and Switzerland have 50% of European plants. I therefore voted in favour of the report which aims to harmonise the conditions for placing safety components on the market for cable-shaped installations and to ensure the free movement of these products in the EU. The proposal provides that the new harmonisation legislation should apply to new cableway installations (cable cars, chairlifts, ski lifts and funiculars), and that all safety components should be designed and manufactured in accordance with the basic requirements laid down in the Regulation. Furthermore, thanks to the ECR Group, rope installations of a historical nature have been excluded from the full application of the regulation, since spare parts are tailor-made and, as such, could not have been within the scope of the checks provided for in the regulation without incurring prohibitive costs for their operation.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. Currently, there are 17,500 cable installations in the European Union or, as they are more commonly known, cable cars. Also in Portugal are installed some of these equipment in Mainland Portugal and Madeira. This proposal for legislation clarifies the applicable terminology and essentially harmonises at Member State level some so far open and security-related issues. It seems to me that the proposal makes important improvements to the current situation and that is why it voted in a positive sense.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal as I do not wish to see EU regulation in this area.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted on this legislative report which will help to harmonise the rules to make sure that new constructed cableways will meet the much needed requirements for health and safety, which will protect the passengers who travel on them as well as the workers on board. As many of my constituents go on holiday to ski and sports resorts across Europe, where cableways are a common feature, this legislation should be able to make their holidays that bit less risky.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ the Motion for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on cableway installations responded in an appropriate manner to the need to modify outdated legislation in this area. At the same time, the submitted proposal also took into account the requirements of the Slovak Republic, which requested the exempting from the scope of rope equipment used for forest purposes. For this reason, I voted in favour of adopting this resolution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 The new Regulation on cableway installations will provide legal clarity and thus better implementation of the relevant legal provisions. I therefore supported the resolution. I believe that the proposal will ensure harmonisation of the conditions for the placing on the market of subsystems and safety components for cableway installations and the free movement of these products within the EU. I agree with the rapporteur that all safety components and subsystems will have to be designed and manufactured in accordance with the essential requirements of this Regulation. I expect manufacturers to carry out conformity assessment procedures more rigorously before placing on the EU market and to ensure that the labelling of subsystems and safety components and the processed documentation are always available to the competent national authorities for the purpose of carrying out the inspection. In this context, I also consider it important that Member States lay down clear rules on penalties applicable to infringements of this Regulation and also ensure their consistent application.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Today in the European Parliament, I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation on cableways, which significantly changed the original proposal of the European Commission. The main objective of this Regulation is to harmonise the safety features of cableways and the conditions for the marketing of their sub-systems in all Member States of the European Union. The Regulation establishes specific rules on market surveillance in order to ensure the maximum level of protection of the health and safety of persons and property. Parliament supported the proposal of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's report despite being alerted to a partial deficiency concerning the definition of historical cableways. Their inclusion in this category shall be left to the decision of each Member State and shall remain excluded from the scope of this Regulation. This deficiency can be addressed in the next legislative process. On the contrary, the proposal for a regulation clearly sets out the still unclear difference between cableways intended for the transport of persons and leisure activities.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The report refers to a proposal for a regulation on cableway installations, which aims to harmonise the conditions for placing subsystems and safety components of cableway installations on the market and ensuring their free movement within the EU.  All safety components and subsystems will have to be designed and manufactured in accordance with the essential requirements laid down in the Regulation pursuant to that Regulation. The Regulation also fully harmonises the essential requirements to be met by cableway installations. This means that Member States may not impose stricter or additional requirements in their national legislation.  I believe that the regulation is an appropriate solution, as it will prevent unnecessary transposition costs and will lay down clear and precise rules that will be applied uniformly throughout the EU. In particular, the Regulation defines more clearly cableway installations intended for transport and leisure, and excludes those installations used for leisure time in fairs or amusement parks.  The Regulation shall also harmonise the conformity assessment procedures available for subsystems with those already applied to safety components.  I agree with the proposal for a regulation, but I am also aware of the importance of maximising harmonisation within the EU in this area, which is why I voted in plenary.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal for a Cable Car Regulation, which is an example of harmonised legislation within the EU. The purpose of the proposal is to harmonise the conditions under which sub-systems and safety components for cable cars are placed on the market and to ensure the free movement of these products within the Union. All safety components and sub-systems will have to meet the standards prescribed by the Regulation. In doing so, the Regulation will replace Directive 2000/9/EC from 20 March 2000 concerning cable cars for transporting people.  The change in the legal instrument applicable, i.e. replacing the directive with a regulation, seeks to ensure better regulation and simplify the regulatory framework. The Regulation will avoid unnecessary transport costs and set clear and detailed rules that will be applicable throughout the Union. Also, the Regulation will reduce the risk of different transpositions, i.e. ensure the same level of security protection throughout the Union, as well as prevent deviations in the internal market.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ Cableways are a common feature in ski and sports resorts across the EU and also play a key role in many urban transport systems. Today’s vote will help to harmonise the rules to make sure that newly constructed cableways meet stringent health and safety requirements, protecting the passengers and workers who travel on them.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on cableway installations.  At European Union level, we need uniform measures that will lay down basic requirements for human safety and health, the protection of the environment and consumers, which apply to cableway installations, subsystems and their safety components. The report proposes, inter alia, an amendment that cableway installations identified under national law as historical installations and their subsystems and safety components should be excluded from the scope of this Regulation. In any case, all the proposed changes go towards greater consumer protection and safety.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The use of barbed wire in installations, whether for recreational or professional reasons, with a potential impact on human lives, requires very serious safety checks and certifications. The same applies, of course, to the transport of products. The important thing is that all statutory measures are observed and that there are no interests that will exploit human life.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Cableway installations intended for the transport of persons are no longer an image belonging exclusively to tourist resorts or mountain areas with limited access. Elevator systems, such as funiculars, cable cars, cable cars, gondolas and chairlifts, contribute to citizens' mobility, combating challenges normally related to traditional urban transport, such as congestion and low air quality. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to harmonise the ways in which subsystems and safety components for cableway installations are placed in the internal market and the conditions under which their free movement is ensured within the European Union. Personally, I can only welcome such a measure, which will facilitate the adoption of this mode of transport in the urban environment, where we face on a small scale the most serious pollution problems, which have serious implications for the health of European citizens.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which addresses the scope of Directive 2000/9/EC on cable installations. As the impact assessment, which was positively assessed by the Ex Ante Impact Assessment Unit of Parliament, has established, a majority of stakeholders cite improved legal clarity as key objectives.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation on cableway installations. The current framework under which the conditions of placing onto the market safety components for cable installations was established by Directive 2000/9/EC from 2000. Turning the directive into a regulation will simplify the current regulatory environment and ensure a uniform implementation throughout the EU. This regulatory change is in line with the better regulation agenda that I support. In addition, the proposal clarifies the scope of the regulation by specifying it is applicable only to cableway installations designed to transport persons and the related subsystems and safety components.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported amendments to cableway legislation, as the new legislative framework brings standardised commitments to manufacturers, importers and market surveillance authorities, which will lead to a significant reduction in administrative barriers, as well as a clearer regulatory environment for all economic operators. In addition, I consider the conformity assessment process, i.e. the selection of a random sample and the review of all its subsystems or safety components, to be an appropriate and objective way of determining whether the sample will be accepted or rejected. In particular, I support efforts to facilitate the use of alternative technical solutions, as well as to place the cable cars of the historic structure outside the scope of this Regulation, and to place them under the jurisdiction of national legislation. I also support the decision that Member States continue to have the regulation of other aspects in the case of cable cars such as land use, spatial planning and environmental protection.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on cableway installations, as I believe it is necessary to harmonise the conditions for placing subsystems and safety components of cableway installations on the market and ensuring their free movement within the EU. I support the fact that safety elements and subsystems, where this relates in particular to leisure, transport and tourist historical installations, will have to be designed and manufactured in accordance with the essential requirements of this Regulation. The main objective of the European Union is to provide end-users with greater security when using devices.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The regulation (replacing an existing directive) would require: - the intervention of notified bodies in the production and design phase; - provide a declaration of compliance with subsystems and security components stamped "CE";  - a safety analysis of all ongoing facility projects is required to condition their eventual operation. Note: elevators and other specific equipment are excluded from the scope of the regulation. It is interesting to note that no additional security requirements are required by industry professionals.  A regulation is therefore not useful, since the current standards are satisfactory and the European sector of activity is in good health. As CE marking is not an original marking but an additional quality control constraint required of manufacturers, it is appropriate to refuse a normative bid which penalises the players in the sector in every way.  I'm voting against it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The reporter supports the proposal for a regulation on cableway installations, which is an example of EU harmonisation legislation. The proposal aims at harmonising the conditions for placing on the market of components and safety components to be incorporated in cableway installations and ensuring the free movement of those products within the Union. All safety components and components must be designed and manufactured in accordance with the essential requirements of this Regulation. The Regulation also provides for full harmonisation of the essential requirements for cableway installations which they must comply with. I supported the document.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour to maintain or improve the high level of consumer protection and ensure consistency of the regulations with the goods package.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a proposal that also aims to update existing legislation in cable transport facilities in accordance with the new legislative framework for the marketing of products. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of the report.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted to convert the directive into a regulation. This will simplify the applicable regulations and ensure uniform application throughout the European Union.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2000/9/EC established rules for cable installations designed, constructed and operated for the transport of persons, but merely lay down the essential requirements applicable to such installations. Cable installations are defined as a complete system, implanted on site, consisting of an infrastructure and subsystems, designed, built, assembled and put into service with the aim of transporting people and in which traction is ensured by cables arranged along the route.  The Regulation lays down rules on the availability on the market and the free movement of safety subsystems and components for cable installations and lays down rules for the design, construction and entry into service of new cable installations. It is essential that cable installations do not endanger the health and safety of persons or property, and it is imperative that safety rules are well defined and therefore respected. On the other hand, it is also essential that SMEs in Member States operating in this sector, in particular manufacturers, are able to receive the necessary support (technical and financial) to respond correctly and in a timely manner to the changes introduced by the Regulation.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Europe-wide safety standards for cable cars should be supported in order to prevent possible accidents. In addition, the VO has been defused in some respects in order not to place an undue burden on operators and manufacturers of small lifts. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on cable cars. This Regulation applies to cable cars, subsystems and safety components which are listed as new on the Union market, either produced by a manufacturer established in the Union or imported from a third country. The aim of the project is to adapt the existing legal situation to the new regulatory approach without extending regulatory access. This has not been fully achieved.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on cableway installations, which is an example of harmonising Union legislation. The regulation adopted by the EP aims to harmonise the conditions for the placing on the market of subsystems and safety components for cableway installations and to ensure the free movement of these products in the EU

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I am a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, responsible for the substance of this report. I voted in favour of voting on its final text, as my colleagues from various political groups have done for the vast majority.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on cable installations, which replaces Directive 2000/9/EC on cable installations for the transport of persons. I believe that this Directive is an example of full harmonisation of EU legislation on the conditions for placing on the market for subsystems and safety components for cable installations, ensuring not only the free movement of these products within the European Union but also the safety of European citizens. I also think it is important that this initiative is in line with the Single Market Act, meaning that all safety components and subsystems will have to be designed and manufactured in accordance with the essential requirements laid down in the Regulation, avoiding the risks of divergence in the transposition of the Regulation by Member States, which could result in different levels of security protection and distort the internal market.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 It is proposed that Directive 2000/9/EC be replaced by a regulation. That Directive established rules for cable installations designed, constructed and operated for the transport of persons, but merely lay down the essential requirements applicable to such installations. The Regulation lays down rules on the availability on the market and the free movement of security subsystems and components through cable installations and lays down rules applicable to the design, construction and entry into service of new cable installations. It is essential that cable installations do not endanger the health and safety of persons or property. It is therefore imperative that safety rules are well defined and, therefore, that they are respected. On the other hand, it is also essential that SMEs in Member States operating in this sector, in particular manufacturers, be able to receive the necessary support (technical and financial) to respond correctly and in a timely manner to the changes introduced by the Regulation. Since such legislative changes should not be a covert way of favouring the largest companies in the sector and, consequently, increasing the concentration of market power, we voted in favour.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Regulation provides for a set of measures that will harmonise the conditions for placing subsystems and safety components of cableway installations on the market and ensuring their free movement within the EU. I support the regulation that cableway installations meet requirements guaranteeing a high level of protection of the health and safety of persons, which is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. ‒ The Generalised Scheme of Preferences Plus (GSP+) is a trade scheme whereby the EU meddles in the internal politics of third countries by making tariff-free access to EU markets subject to implementation of international conventions – in areas including labour rights and related civil-society issues. According to the resolution’s authors, Kyrgyzstan has failed to meet the (politicised) requirements necessary for GSP+ treatment. The Commission disagrees, having granted Kyrgyzstan eligibility for GSP+ in November 2015 following that country’s own-initiative application. The resolution’s authors call for repealing the Commission delegated act that would activate GSP+ treatment for Kyrgyzstan.   Though UKIP believe the EU should not force countries to change their sovereign laws in order to trade favourably with it, Kyrgyzstan made a choice on its own initiative to gain GSP+ treatment.  On these grounds, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain.
politicalGroup: The Earl of) Dartmouth Mike Hookem Diane James Margot Parker and Julia Reid (EFDD
partyIdeology: The Earl of) Dartmouth Mike Hookem Diane James Margot Parker and Julia Reid (EFDD

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection to the Commission Delegated Regulation implementing a system of generalised tariff preferences to the Republic of Kyrgyzstan, a system known as GSP+, by opposing the delegated act by which the European Commission intends to amend the Regulation by an accelerated process. Taking into account reports from the Committee on the Application of Standards of the International Labour Organization, the Committee against Torture, the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination and the Committee on the Rights of the Child, the worrying situation of human rights in these areas, as well as the discriminatory provisions also by sexual orientation in the country , confirm to me the need for the provisions of the agreement to be carefully analysed, in the face of the notable deficiencies identified in relation to several relevant conventions of the GSP+ Regulation.
