Convinced that respect for human rights must prevail over the EU's commercial interests, I supported the proposal for an objection to the Delegated Regulation.

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: Written. \u2012 We are in favour of adding Kyrgyzstan to the list of GSP+ beneficiary countries in the future with the tariff preferences this entails, but the EU should have waited for the decision. The Kyrgyz Parliament is expected to adopt a bill against homosexual propaganda that violates international human rights law. In addition, the UN and several international organisations are sharply critical of the country for not applying adopted conventions and shortcomings, including on children's rights, the use of torture and the treatment of human rights defenders. We believe that this is a missed opportunity for the EUROPEAN Union and the European Parliament to influence the country in the direction of greater transparency and respect for human rights, and that is why we support the resolution.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. It is out of the question to allow a delegated act to extend the scope of generalised trade preferences, which could only worsen the situation of European companies. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I object to the principle of delegated acts, but in this particular instance I felt that it would be unwise to oppose this act in case it were to damage Kyrgyzstan’s trade with the European Union.  I therefore reluctantly abstained on this vote.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of opposing the delegated act on a scheme of generalised tariff preferences. The Commission has been empowered to provide that the requesting country is granted a specific incentive arrangement for sustainable development and good governance by including that country in the list of GSP+ beneficiary countries. The applicant State must fulfil certain conditions in order to become a GSP+country and this status is not granted automatically. In its report, the Committee on the Application of Standards of the International Labour Organisation identified the Kyrgyz Republic among countries which still had failed to fulfil the necessary conditions for the competent authorities. The Government of the Kyrgyz Republic did not participate in the discussions on the fulfilment of its country's related obligations. The most important shortcomings are: persistent and widespread torture and ill-treatment of captive persons, continued non-execution of rapid, impartial and thorough investigations, inability to provide all captive persons, especially those subject to pre-trial detention, with all basic legal guarantees, etc. As the monitoring bodies of the relevant conventions identified significant shortcomings in relation to certain GSP+ relevant conventions, I therefore support the objection of 25 November 2015. commission delegated regulation applying a scheme of generalised tariff preferences.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. This resolution objects to the Council's delegated regulation by which it granted a scheme of generalised tariff preferences in Kyrgyzstan. Parliament considers that human rights violations in Kyrgyzstan stand in the way of granting such preferential status. I approved this resolution.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today against the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the Commission delegated regulation of 25 November 2015 amending Annex III to Regulation (EU) No 978/2012 on the application of a generalised system of tariff preferences. The proposal put forward by the CONFEDERAL GROUP of the European United Left/Nordic Green Left, while highlighting real problems concerning violations of human rights, the principles of equality and non-discrimination on the part of the Republic of Kyrgyzstan, is not, in my view, an effective response. Objecting to a Commission delegated act aimed at establishing a special development incentive scheme in Kyrgyzstan would not help to tackle and overcome the country's difficulties. The Union's response must not be through objection, but must be expressed in a constant political commitment to the affirmation of the rule of law, which is why I did not support the motion for a resolution.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of this objection because we find it contradictory that GSP+ status be granted to Kyrgyzstan when reports from international organizations of remarkable credibility have caught the attention of human rights violations in this country. GSP+ status is granted to developing countries on the clear condition that they meet a number of good practice requirements. In 2013, the Committee against Torture warned about the systematic use of torture in Kyrgyzstan, failures of the rule of law and abuse. In 2015, the ILO ranked Kyrgyzstan among the countries with the least protection for workers.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted against the proposal for a resolution submitted by the GUE/NGL Group on the system of generalised tariff preferences. The Commission is closely monitoring them and I do not agree with the objection raised.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I wanted to support this GUE resolution on an objection to a delegated act on a scheme of generalised tariff preferences. While the reasons given by this political group for opposing such a delegated act may seem wobbly, including interference and cultural imperialism concerning the Kyrgyz Republic, it is certain that it is not at present appropriate to offer the country a regime of tariff preferences, including a reduction or even a gradual abolition of tariffs on its exports to the EU. In addition to the fact that Kyrgyzstan is not currently complying with the so-called "relevant" conventions provided for by Regulation (EU) 978/2012 to become a beneficiary of the GSP, I am generally opposed in principle to extending the area of trade preferences which is part of the logic of a globalised single market. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have always opposed the generalised system of tariff preferences in force in the EU, not because I believe that this instrument is not useful, but because I believe that it should be calmed down and limited to a smaller and better selected number of beneficiary countries. I am convinced that the gue group's objection to this delegated act in relation to Kyrgyzstan alone is purely political in nature, which is why I abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The System of Generalized Preferences (GSP) is a key trade instrument of the Community development aid policy, where by which the European Union provides preferential access to the Community market for products originating in developing countries and territories by exempting all or part of tariff duties. With this instrument, the EU aims to help reduce poverty in developing countries, while ensuring fundamental human rights and promoting sustainable development. The inclusion of a country in the Generalized System of Preferences requires an individual assessment of compliance with the requirements of the Regulations, including the ratification of a number of international conventions, as well as monitoring compliance with such requirements. Kyrgyzstan currently benefits from the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) but, on 25 November 2015, the Commission decided to propose granting its access to the GSP+, which is why I voted against the proposal to object to its grant.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 During the vote, this resolution was rejected, in which the European Parliament examines the Commission's mandate to provide the requesting country, in this case Kyrgyzstan, with a special incentive for sustainable development and good governance, to include this country in the list of beneficiary countries. The European Parliament notes that the monitoring bodies of the relevant conventions have identified significant shortcomings in relation to certain relevant conventions and considers that these shortcomings constitute a serious infringement which impedes the effective implementation of the relevant conventions. Both the Committee against Torture, the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination and the Committee on the Rights of the Child, all of whom have reported violations of human rights and freedoms and various shortcomings.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I did not support the proposed decision opposing the delegated act on the scheme of generalised tariff preferences, as I do not see the reasons for this or that I have been convinced by the Commission's arguments that the adoption of the delegated act is justified.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote against this objection to the delegated act relating to a generalised system of tariff preferences because I believe that it is essentially unfounded.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 To grant a requesting country the benefit of the special scheme to encourage sustainable development and good governance, adding that country to the list of GSP+ countries, is an important step in the development of that country, for which the Union wants to ensure that it supports the strengthening of a democratic system and that all measures arising from it are aimed at the safety of citizens and respect for their fundamental rights. However, in the Kyrgyz Republic, following evaluations by several bodies, including the Committee against Torture (CAT), the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination (CERD), the International Labour Organisation Committee for the Application of Standards (CAS), the Committee on the Rights of the Child, it has become clear that the country still has consistent processes to go through to demonstrate that it wants to improve the lives of its citizens and strengthen a system of law. The presence of torture, exploitation of children, violation of the rights of the defence and discrimination of minority ethnicities cannot be acceptable. I therefore voted in favour of this report on the formulation of objections to the application of a generalised system of tariff preferences to Kyrgyzstan.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote. Our delegation has always opposed the generalised system of tariff preferences in force in the EU (and its recent reform), not because we do not believe that this type of instrument is not useful and necessary (they should facilitate trade in poor or less developed countries), but because we believe that they should be limited to a considerably smaller number of beneficiaries. In fact, it is not only countries with poor economic conditions that benefit from the GSP+ system, but also production realities that can create distortions of the market by their exports to Europe (think of pakistan's textiles or the Philippines' catch, for example). For these reasons, therefore, we feel that an objection to Kyrgyzstan, a former Soviet state in Central Asia which certainly does not represent a problem in terms of potential competition with our production system and which, coincidentally, seems to be politically close to Putin's Russia, seems to be instrumental.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the Commission delegated regulation of 25 November 2015 amending Annex III to Regulation (EU) No 978/2012 on the application of a generalised system of tariff preferences. The Commission has the power to adopt delegated acts to allow an applicant State to benefit from the special incentive scheme for sustainable development and good governance, under which no import duties are applied for more than 6,000 tariff lines from beneficiary nations.  In order to achieve this regime, each country must fulfil precise conditions, as this status is not automatically conferred, but requires a case-by-case assessment. The Republic of Kyrgyzstan, which has requested the granting of these benefits, has detected numerous violations, such as the widespread practice of torture and ill-treatment of those arrested, the failure to carry out timely and impartial investigations, and other violations of the principles of equality and non-discrimination. These elements seriously affect the effective implementation of the relevant conventions in Annex VIII to the aforementioned regulation and therefore, in order to inform the Commission that the delegated regulation cannot enter into force, I voted in favour of the text.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this GUE/NGL resolution which objected to the inclusion of the Kyrgyz Republic in the EU’s Generalised Scheme of Tariff Preferences.  GSP beneficiary countries benefit from tariff preferences under arrangements with the EU and the status is given to developing countries vulnerable due to a lack of diversification and insufficient integration with the international trading market. Countries can only benefit from GSP if they have signed up to and ratified core international conventions on human rights and labour rights.  Although the Kyrgyz Republic has done this on its face, the Committee Against Torture and International Labour Organisation have listed it as one of the countries most failing its obligations. There are numerous instances of human rights violations including legislation against the LGBT community, torture and ill treatment by the criminal justice system, deaths in custody and threats against human rights defenders.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted against the call for a system of generalised tariff preferences against Kyrgyzstan.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against the motion for a resolution, which points out that the monitoring bodies of various conventions linked to the GSP (EU Generalised System of Preferences) have detected obvious abuses by the Kyrgyz Republic and considers that the above violations constitute a serious lack of effective compliance with the relevant conventions set out in Annex VII to the GSP Regulation.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I disagreed because I do not believe that the formal and substantive conditions of the measure exist.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this objection because I believe that the Commission has done a good job in preparing this act and because I find it consistent with the legislative mandate received. I believe that the political message sent out by the group that raised this objection is now out of date, and that we have to deal with reality.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ The Generalised Scheme of Preferences Plus (GSP+) is a trade scheme whereby the EU meddles in the internal politics of third countries by making tariff-free access to EU markets subject to implementation of international conventions – in areas including labour rights and related civil-society issues. According to the resolution’s authors, Kyrgyzstan has failed to meet the (politicised) requirements necessary for GSP+ treatment. The Commission disagrees, having granted Kyrgyzstan eligibility for GSP+ in November 2015 following that country’s own-initiative application. The resolution’s authors call for repealing the Commission delegated act that would activate GSP+ treatment for Kyrgyzstan.   Though UKIP believe the EU should not force countries to change their sovereign laws in order to trade favourably with it, Kyrgyzstan made a choice on its own initiative to gain GSP+ treatment.  On these grounds, UKIP MEPs voted to abstain.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The EU may proceed to define and pursue common policies and actions in order to foster the sustainable economic, social and environmental development of developing countries, with the primary aim of eradicating poverty, thus I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The EU’s ‘Generalised Scheme of Preferences’ (GSP) allows developing country exporters to pay less or no duties on their exports to the EU. This gives them vital access to EU markets and contributes to their economic growth. Standard/general GSP arrangement offers generous tariff reductions to developing countries, while the GSP+ enhanced preferences mean full removal of tariffs on essentially the same product categories as those covered by the general arrangement. In fact, these are granted to countries which ratify and implement core international conventions relating to human and labour rights, environment and good governance. The objection of the GUE group claims that monitoring bodies of the relevant conventions have detected some shortcomings in connection to a number of the GSP+-relevant conventions, and that these shortcomings constitute a failure to implement effectively the relevant conventions. In this specific case I am more in line with the original proposal of the Commission and thus voted for the delegated regulation to enter into force.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this objection, which takes no account of the positive steps taken by Kyrgyzstan to improve their human rights record including efforts to guarantee the independence of judges and the direct applicability of international treaties (including the Convention on Torture) before the courts. GSP+ is a very important tool in further motivating Kyrgyzstan to continue reforms. Indeed, it is the very objective of GSP+ to help poor and vulnerable countries like Kyrgyzstan to improve their record in implementation of international conventions, despite strenuous economic conditions. So I feel it is counter-productive to exclude Kyrgyzstan from GSP+.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The Kyrgyz Republic continues to violate many international conventions, practices torture, does not allow detainees to receive a lawyer, and allows ethnic conflicts to take hold within it. There is therefore no reason to grant this country a duty exemption with the European Union, through the GSP scheme, for reasons of "good governance".  Being committed to respect for international law, and in particular conventions, I voted for this objection.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the objection to the delegated act on the scheme of generalised tariff preferences for Kyrgyzstan, as I believe that progress and development in the Caucasus Republic have not been taken into account. On the contrary, I believe that it should remain part of the agreement on sustainable development and good governance, as it will have a beneficial effect on its future development and in particular on the implementation of international conventions, despite difficult economic conditions.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 According to the motion for a resolution, the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic has not complied with its obligations with regard to standards for its accession as a beneficiary country of the SG%amp%A+ but has instead committed human rights violations and discriminatory actions, creating inequalities and gagging freedom of expression. It should also be noted to the Commission that the delegated Regulation amending Annex III to Regulation (EU) No 1782/2003 should be amended accordingly. It is therefore appropriate to amend Regulation (EC) No 978/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the application of a system of generalised tariff preferences. We are in favour of the abolition of the EU-Kyrgyz agreement but we believe that this motion for a resolution serves other interests and is a manifestation of the already existing lack of democracy in the EU. We also believe that the Commission, under the pretext of defending human rights, seeks to pursue a foreign policy contrary to the interests of European citizens.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The GSP consists of a general scheme and two special schemes, including the special incentive scheme for sustainable development and good governance (GSP+), according to which no duties on imports of more than 6 000 tariff positions from the beneficiary countries will be charged. The Parliament of the Kyrgyz Republic ignored the European Parliament Resolution of 15 January 2015 and proposed a draft legislation which violates the principle that sexual orientation and gender identity are issues within the sphere of the individual right to privacy, as guaranteed by international human rights law, under which equality and non-discrimination must be protected and freedom of expression must be guaranteed. I therefore agree that the Delegated Regulation cannot enter into force.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 It is known the situation of political instability that has been experienced in Kyrgyzstan in the last decade, the difficulties and contradictions that result. Regardless of the lack of specific knowledge of news that confirms the timeliness and accuracy of the report expressed in this objection, the pressures and interference that have been developed by the West in this former Soviet republic, resulting from the geopolitical game of control of that region and the imperial ambitions that underlie it, are known. Pressure stemming recently from the process of that country's joining the Eurasian Economic Union – a sovereign decision that must be respected. In this context, we do not follow the position of call for sanctions.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are in favour of repealing the EU-Kyrgyzstan agreement because this motion for a resolution serves other interests and is another indication of the already existing lack of democracy in the EU. Furthermore, the Commission seeks, on the pretext of defending human rights, to pursue a foreign policy contrary to the interests of European citizens.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 On the basis of Commission Delegated Regulation C(2015)08213 and Article 290 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, I note that the control bodies of the relevant conventions have identified outstanding deficiencies with regard to the relevant conventions of the GSP+ system, and I consider that the abovementioned deficiencies constitute a serious deficiency in the effective implementation of the relevant conventions listed in Annex VIII to the GSP Regulation. I also object to the Commission Delegated Regulation of 25 November 2015 amending Annex III to Regulation (EU) No 978/2012 on the application of the system of general tariff preferences (C(2013)9133).

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the GUE Group's objection to the Commission's delegated regulation of 25 November 2015 amending Annex III to Regulation (EU) No 978/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the application of a generalised system of tariff preferences (GSP) because I consider it important to open a negotiating and trade relationship with the Republic of Kyrgyzstan. I share the S-D Group's position in rejecting the objection to the application of tariff preferences, because I believe that good trade relations, and trade policy in general, are also an important instrument for raising rights and pushing local authorities towards a path of openness and recognition of the rights of the citizens of that country. With this vote, we do not want to lower our guard on the issues in the country, but we intend to send out a relaxing message that could lead the Commission to address these issues in the context of trade relations between the EU and Kyrgyzstan.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted against the GUE/NGL motion for a resolution on 'Objections to the delegated act on a scheme of generalised tariff preferences', as this text contains many misleading or erroneous claims and conclusions. This does not change the fact that, as an MEP and citizen representative, I continue to consider the instrument of 'delegated acts' to be a major mistake by my predecessors in the European Parliament. Here, MEPs once blindly paved a path that unnecessarily weakens the power of today's MEPs towards the European Commission.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. We do not question the resolution's description of the human rights situation in Kyrgyzstan. However, we do not wish to contest the delegated act concerned because the tariff preferences granted to Kyrgyzstan through the GSP can hopefully act as an incentive for the country to make positive changes. We believe that the Commission now has a very great responsibility to closely monitor developments in Kyrgyzstan, including through its monitoring body, in order to ensure that the country fully ratifies and applies all relevant conventions on human rights, workers' rights, environmental protection and good governance.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The EU has granted trade preferences to developing countries through the Generalised System of Tariff Preferences (GSP) since 1971. The SG%A supports these countries in their efforts to take on specific burdens and responsibilities a resulting from the ratification of 27 international conventions on human and labour rights, environmental protection and good governance and the effective implementation of these conventions. Kyrgyzstan has applied for the SG%A. The Commission has examined the application and decided that Kyrgyzstan meets the necessary criteria. Our opinion is that there are serious contradictions and failures in the implementation of the conventions by Kyrgyzstan, and the Commission's report recognises this.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the resolution objecting to the decision to grant GSP+ status to Kyrgyzstan. Kyrgyzstan’s application gives an encouraging sign of the progress the country is making and by engaging in GSP+, we can push for further progress by the Kyrgyzstani Government. As one of the poorest countries in the region the government faces significant challenges while at the same time trying to introduce reforms and GSP+ status can go towards helping combating this widespread poverty through investment and reform. Regarding the draft law on sexual orientation, this of course is a matter of concern but the key point is that it remains a draft at the moment and it would be disproportionate to base a criterion for a serious failure on a law which does not exist. I believe that it will be through the granting of GSP+ that we can better monitor and address the issue and hopefully prevent its adoption as part of GSP+ dialogue.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to vote against this report as the parliament of the Kyrgyz Republic has ignored the European Parliament’s resolution of 15 January 2015 on the country’s homosexual propaganda bill, and moved the bill forward to pass its second reading. This draft legislation violates the important principle that sexual orientation and gender identity are matters falling within the sphere of the individual right to privacy, as guaranteed by international human rights law, according to which equality and non-discrimination are to be protected and freedom of expression is to be guaranteed.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this motion for a resolution on generalised tariff preferences taking into consideration that the Kyrgyz Republic has ignored the European Parliament’s resolution of 15 January 2015 on the country’s homosexual propaganda bill.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the Commission's Delegated Regulation resolution of 25 November 2015 amending Annex III. Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013. 978/2012 of parliament and the Council on the application of the general customs preferences system, as this is a proposal for a political grouping resolution which clearly had no chance of obtaining parliament's support, and therefore I decided to follow the position of the ALDE Group and voted against the resolution.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I voted against this objection because it is unthinkable to allow a delegated act to extend the scope of generalised trade preferences, which could only worsen the situation of European companies.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution of the European Unitarian Left on the objection to a delegated act on a scheme of generalised tariff preferences for Kyrgyzstan. This objection was aimed at rejecting the tariff preferences granted to Kyrgyzstan. The reasons given by the GUE did not, in my view, justify the total questioning of this delegated act of the European Union. That objection was rejected, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting against the proposal. It disproportionately interferes with Kyrgyzstan's national fabric and legal system.

name: Ska KELLER
text: Mr President, Mr President, I would like to say, in writing, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance. Once again, the Commission has faced a request for tacit consent without first discussing criteria and consequences. Without today's vote against the award of GSP+, Kyrgyzstan would be able to enjoy it without singing or sounding after an automatic deadline. This regime provides for substantial tariff facilitation for exports to the EU in return for ratification and implementation of 27 conventions on labour law and environmental issues. International human rights organisations have serious doubts about the implementation of these conventions. Civil society organisations in the country complain that they have never been consulted. Within the Central Asian group of countries, Kyrgyzstan stands out positively as a country with a multi-party system and elections. On foreign policy, the country concluded an important water management agreement with Kazakhstan, thus avoiding conflicts in the region through diplomatic. Undoubtedly, the road from the Soviet sub-state to a functioning democracy is long. Much remains to be done. Since an EP emergency resolution on Kyrgyzstan in January 2015, the recommendations made have been written in the wind. If the Commission takes the EP seriously, it should consult MEPs in sensitive cases before taking far-reaching decisions. DG TRADE has often proved that it has no idea or strategy on human rights issues. However, these should be discussed before any trade agreement with the EP. That is why today the Greens/EFA Group's 'yes' to rejecting the Commission's proposal.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the objection to a delegated act on a scheme of generalised tariff preferences. This text lists a number of human rights violations in Kyrgyzstan. I do not see why this country would be given the benefit of the special incentive regime for sustainable development and good governance, which is to exempt certain imports from that country from tariffs.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the opposition to maintain free trade with Kyrgyzstan, which should not be affected by a different perception of politics towards minorities. All restrictions on trade always have the opposite effect and lead to a tightening of local government policy.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 Customs preferences are provided for in a specific agreement on incentives for sustainable development and good governance provided that it has ratified all necessary conventions and that the most recent available conclusions of the supervisory authorities do not mention serious gaps in the effective implementation of any of these conventions. Given that the supervisory authorities of the relevant conventions have detected significant gaps in the entire set of conventions relevant to OPS+ and that these problems constitute a serious failure to effectively implement the relevant Conventions easually cited in Annex VIII. OPS Regulation.  I supported the complaint because customs preferences require an individual assessment to meet all the necessary conditions due to the fact that customs preferences are not automatically granted.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is often in a so-called 'generalised tariff preferences' system in its relations with developing countries, under which exporters in such partner countries are able to pay lower tariffs on or not to pay domestic goods within the EU. Regulation (EU) No 978/2012 is currently in place in this area, which was amended by The Commission on 25 November last year by Delegated Regulation (EU.C) No 2015)8213. It has historically been the case that EU foreign policy, including trade policy, often depends on value being taken into account. And the problem here is that the already quite long-term behaviour of the Kyrgyz authorities does not largely reconsure these values, although there has certainly been some progress in the past. Consequently, as long as the situation does not change, it is not really permissible either to include Kyrgyzstan in the GSP+ list or to approve the abovementioned Commission delegated regulation. There is a clear need to support our partner countries, but only when there is also a certain amount of active movement in return.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Commission's delegated regulation of 25 November 2015 amending Annex III to Regulation (EU) No 1782/2003. 978/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the implementation of a system of generalised tariff preferences. because I believe that this is a complete and well-documented proposal.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text. The European Union may grant an applicant country the benefit of a special tariff regime if that applicant respects sustainable development and good governance (special regime of generalised preferences). This regime allows, among other things, to be exempt from customs duties on 6,000 tariff lines. The conditions for being GSP are to promote sustainable development, to protect human rights and democracy.  However, the Kyrgyz Republic is guilty of serious breaches: it still practices torture, ethnic conflicts are commonplace, the accused are still unable to have a lawyer, etc. In these circumstances, it cannot be said that the Kyrgyz Republic has "good governance", and it is normal to exclude it from this scheme.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Commission proposes to grant Kyrgyzstan a new status allowing it exemptions from customs duties, through a delegated act in which neither Parliament nor the Council have a say. This resolution at the initiative of my group challenges the validity of the act. Delegated acts are supposed to deal with "non-essential elements of legislative acts" but are regularly the way for the Commission to force through.  This new status granted to Kyrgyzstan is not insignificant. It is theoretically granted to countries on the basis of their good compliance with key international human rights conventions. Kyrgyzstan regularly flouts them: the use of torture by the forces of repression, the corrupt legal system, and the abused freedom of expression, as the various international monitoring bodies have recently demonstrated.  On the political background as well as on the form used, this commission act is yet another symbol of human rights with variable geometry defended by the Commission and immediately put in the closet when they do not allow the extension of the Union's free trade area. The anti-Russian intent of this new attempt at annexation cannot escape me. I support this initiative that denounces it

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This is a delegated act aimed at extending the scope of trade preferences, which could only worsen the situation of European companies.  So I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution objecting to the delegated act on a system of generalised tariff preferences.  I believe that there are conditions for the adoption of the delegated act under Article 290 TFEU.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – the European Union has been supporting developing countries for many years by granting trade preferences through a system of generalised tariff preferences. This aid is not automatic but conditional on the fulfilment of certain conditions and therefore a country applying for the status of beneficiary country under the scheme of generalised tariff preferences is required to fulfil the conditions laid down by its action. If a country does not fulfil these conditions, it cannot be included in the list of beneficiary countries. The ILO Committee on the Implementation of ILO Standards, the Committee Against Torture, the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination, as well as the Committee on the Rights of the Child have confirmed serious violations by the Kyrgyz Republic of the standards and conditions established by the European Union. For this reason, I agree that the resolution should be forwarded to the Commission and communicated to it that the delegated regulation cannot enter into force.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against the resolution on the objection to the delegated act on a scheme of generalised tariff preferences because I do not oppose the delegated act, as no major serious and systematic failures have been found in the Kyrgyz application. In this case the GSP+ instrument can be used as an incentive to bring about further positive changes in the Kyrgyz Republic.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The GUE/NGL Group tabled a motion for a resolution on the Commission delegated regulation of 25 November 2015 amending Annex III to Regulation (EU) No 978/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the application of the system of general tariff preferences. The motion proposes to establish that serious deficiencies can be identified in the Kyrgyz Republic on a number of human rights issues and that the country does not meet the conditions laid down in Article 9(1) of Regulation (EU) No 978/2012 that the requesting countries must meet in order to become beneficiaries of the GSP+ scheme. The motion therefore proposes that the European Parliament object to Commission Delegated Regulation C(2013)9133, amending Annex III to Regulation (EU) No 978/2012 on the application of the system of general tariff preferences, so that it cannot enter into force. I supported the adoption of the draft.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Under Article 10(4) of Regulation (EU) No 978/2012, the Commission may adopt delegated acts to establish or amend Annex III in order to grant the requesting country the special incentive scheme for sustainable development and good governance (GSP+), by addition of that country to the list of GSP+ beneficiary countries. The GSP is composed of a general scheme and two special schemes, including the GSP+ in which, according to the latter, no duties on imports of more than 6 000 tariff positions from the beneficiary countries will be charged. In view of the number of major shortcomings in the relevant conventions relating to the GSP+ scheme, I believe that the beneficiary country should make a binding commitment to maintain the ratification of the conventions listed in Annex VIII and to ensure their effective implementation.  Considering the shortcomings pointed out as serious shortcomings in the effective implementation of the relevant conventions, I would argue that the Delegated Regulation should be amended.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The Kyrgyz Republic violates many international conventions, continues the practice of torture, and allows ethnic conflicts to take hold. It would make no sense to give it zero tariffs with the EU because of "good governance" thanks to the GSP scheme. I therefore vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I voted against the GUE's objection to the scheme of generalized tariff preferences for Kyrgyzstan, which encourages destabilization by preferring the use of sanctions. Political stabilization should be further encouraged by the EU's support for the Kyrgyz economy.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the resolution on the regulation on the application of a generalised system of tariff preferences because I do not believe that the formal and substantive conditions of the measure are met.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this motion taking into consideration that the Parliament of the Kyrgyz Republic has ignored the resolution on 15 January 2015 with regard to the individual right to privacy, as guaranteed by international human rights law.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as I am aware of the provisions and benefits of the GSP+ programme, as well as the kyrgyz Republic's human rights issues. I believe that the European Union must respond with one voice to this issue, which is one of the most important foundations of the EU. As the document adopted today states, the supervisory bodies of the relevant conventions have found, within the Kyrgyz Republic, significant shortcomings in compliance with the obligations set out in the GSP+ Convention, and I believe that these shortcomings must be taken into account with a view to the effective implementation of the programme.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the objection to the delegated act concerning the granting of the scheme of generalised tariff preferences in Kyrgyzstan, in view of the country's failure to comply with several world labour organisation conventions, the Committee against Torture or the Convention on the Rights of the Child. The Commission should take these elements into account and not include Kyrgyzstan in its list of countries with preferential tariffs.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 Did not support the objection. Kyrgyzstan needs to be persuaded to move forward with reforms to improve both the economic environment there and the human rights situation, and leaving the tariff preferences scheme in place could motivate them to move forward.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Generalised System of Preferences (GSP) is intended to help developing countries through facilities for their exports in order to make them full partners in international trade. From what I have learned from reading the objection, I do not believe that support for it is the best way forward and I do not intend to support it. I am therefore voting against.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I call on Kyrgyzstan to respect human rights and values, and I advocate greater economic exchange between Kyrgyzstan and the European Union. Such cooperation would lead to the creation of better connections, i.e. would contribute to further strengthening democracy and human rights in the country. I believe that the abolition of general customs preferences would lead to harmful consequences for Kyrgyzstan and its inhabitants, so I think it is of utmost importance to deepen trade relations with the country in order to improve the daily lives of its citizens. Further sanctions could undermine any possibility of progress in Kyrgyzstan-European Union relations, leading to negative consequences for all participants. Kyrgyzstan's progress, i.e. the effort to strengthen freedoms should be welcomed and assisted in their further efforts, in order to bring about even greater changes in democracy and the protection of human rights as soon as possible. Due to all the negative consequences that would lead to the abolition of general customs preferences, I do not support this resolution, i.e. objection to the delegated act on the system of general customs preferences.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. On the merits, I support this objection to the delegated act on a scheme of generalised tariff preferences, despite some reluctance over the chosen formulations. So I'm voting for it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. Taking into account the situation in Kyrgyzstan, I support the resolution on these regulations concerning the application of the general customs preferences system. According to reports of various committees, the situation of human rights in the Kyrgyz Republic is worrying, and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic has failed to fulfil its obligations to the UN and other international organisations and committees with regard to reports on compliance with certain standards, a precondition necessary for the state to become a beneficiary of the general customs preferences system. In particular, we are talking about reports that warn about the prevalence of torture practices, lack of basic legal protection, political and police repression, ethnic discrimination, and the widespread occurrence of the most serious violations of children's rights such as sexual exploitation, abduction of minors, physical abuse, etc. Also alarming is Kyrgyz's proposal for a law on homosexual propaganda that violates an individual's right to privacy, as well as freedom of expression. The European Union must promote good rule, human rights and democratic principles and insist on respecting these values in relations with third countries and partners.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I rejected the GUE's objection to the granting of the GSP to Kyrgyzstan. This country, which is suffering from economic and political difficulties, must see its economy survive some external pressures. I therefore support the idea of temporarily and modestly helping a country that should not sink into potential instability.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The System of Generalized Preferences (GSP) is a key trade instrument of the Community development aid policy, where by which the European Union provides preferential access to the Community market for products originating in developing countries and territories by exempting all or part of tariff duties. With this instrument, the EU aims to help reduce poverty in developing countries, while ensuring fundamental human rights and promoting sustainable development. The inclusion of a country in the Generalized System of Preferences requires an individual assessment of compliance with the requirements of the Regulations, including the ratification of a number of international conventions, as well as monitoring compliance with such requirements. Kyrgyzstan currently benefits from the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) but, on 25 November 2015, the Commission decided to propose granting its access to the GSP+, which is why I voted against the proposal to object to its grant.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Yesterday, we voted on a motion to object to a delegated regulation adopted by the European Commission at the end of 2015 on the preferential status GSP granted to Kyrgyzstan under the EU's System of Generalised Trade Preferences (GSP). This motion of objection was tabled to warn of the deteriorating human rights situation in Kyrgyzstan as reported by many NGOs. It should be noted that the GSP is a system of tariff preferences granted by EU Member States to developing countries that are making good governance efforts (implementation of international conventions on human rights, labour rights and sustainable development). However, a recent Commission report on Kyrgyzstan lists serious cases of systematic torture in police custody in the country and denounces neglect of women's and children's rights and discrimination against Uzbeks.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The GSP consists of a general scheme and two special schemes, including the special incentive scheme for sustainable development and good governance (GSP+), according to which no duties on imports of more than 6 000 tariff positions from the beneficiary countries will be charged. Kyrgyzstan, according to the report, to become a GSP+ beneficiary country, has to fulfil a number of requirements, namely the ratification of all 28 Conventions listed in Annex VIII to Regulation (EU) No 978/2012. The reservations and shortcomings listed in this objection report lack some phallic support, so, on the basis of the principle of 'change by approximation', I believe that this country's entry into the GSP+ will represent for the Union an additional form of pressure, control and monitoring of the implementation of the 28 Conventions on Human Rights, Labour Rights and Environmental Preservation. This objective pressure would not exist if this country were outside this system, so effective compliance with the 28 Conventions will be the real test of their permanence in the preferential system.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as I do not wish to see the EU in charge of British Trade relations, but at the same time I do want Britain to have trade relations with other nations.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this motion because, while I do sympathise with the need to highlight the abuses in Kyrgyzstan, I do not believe that the problems flagged up in the file are going to be addressed by withdrawing this delegated act.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ by the European Parliament resolution on the Commission Delegated Regulation of 25 November 2015 amending Annex III to the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council applying the scheme of generalised tariff preferences, we authorised the Commission to adopt delegated acts with a view to establishing or amending Annex III, thereby granting the requesting country specific incentive measures for sustainable development and good governance by including that country in the list of beneficiary countries under the GSI scheme. Given that the authorities monitoring the relevant conventions found significant deficiencies in Kirkizsk in relation to a number of conventions relating to generalised tariff preferences and those deficiencies constitute serious failures, the EP requested to object to the Commission Delegated Act of 25 November 2015 amending Annex III to Regulation No 978/2012 applying the GSI scheme.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing \ u2012 The scheme of generalised tariff preferences favours certain States in accessing the European Union market. The status of a country is granted not automatically, but after the conditions laid down have been met. Having been found that the Kyrgyz Republic has failed to fulfil the conditions and serious deficiencies in the area of human rights restrictions have been identified, the rule of law, discrimination against minorities, child abuse and other serious issues, it was necessary to object to Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No .C(2015)08213 of 25 November 2015 amending Annex III to Regulation (EU) No 978/2012 applying the scheme of generalised tariff preferences.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ The main objective of the general system of preferences is to facilitate preferential access to the EU market for developing countries and areas by reducing tariffs on their products. Customs preferences on the EU market should allow developing countries to participate more in international trade, thereby generating additional export revenues that they can then use to implement their sustainable development and poverty reduction policies as well as diversify their economies. Under the general system of preferences, these countries are neither expected nor required to provide the EU with reciprocal preferential access to its markets. For these reasons, I voted against this objection to the delegated act on the system of general customs preferences.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I support the objection to the delegated act on the system of general customs preferences, because Kyrgyzstan did not meet the agreed requirements. The European Union grants a preferential customs regime to individual countries. In that case, the European Union granted Kyrgyzstan the placement of certain goods on the Union market with preferential customs conditions, but Kyrgyzstan did not comply with the Union's requirements. Therefore, we need to suspend this process temporarily, until Kyrgyzstan meets EU requirements.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ i voted against the resolution on the Commission delegated regulation amending Annex III to the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the application of the scheme of generalised tariff preferences.  The resolution notes that the monitoring bodies in the relevant conventions have identified significant shortcomings with regard to a number of important GSP+ conventions. However, I do not consider that those shortcomings identified by the authorities are a serious error in the effective implementation of the relevant conventions set out in Annex VIII to the GSP Regulation.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 According to the resolution, the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic has not complied with the obligations regarding standards for its accession as a beneficiary country of the SG+A but has instead continued human rights abuses, discrimination, inequalities and the exclusion of freedom of expression. This means that the delegated Regulation amending Annex III to Regulation (EU) No 1782/2003 should be amended accordingly. It is therefore appropriate to amend Regulation (EC) No 978/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council on the application of a system of generalised tariff preferences. This motion for a resolution serves other interests and is another indication of the existing lack of democracy in the EU. Furthermore, the Commission seeks, on the pretext of defending human rights, to pursue a foreign policy contrary to the interests of European citizens.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The application of a generalised system of tariff preferences (GSP) by the European Union is a useful tool for the development of trade relations with third countries. The conclusion of such arrangements between the EU and other countries is likely to remove obstacles to free trade, but also to increase the Union's influence worldwide.  The achievement of such agreements implies that third countries, including in the field of democratic governance, respect certain European values and norms. The Commission is currently proposing to promote such an agreement, from GSP to GSP+ in relation to Kyrgyzstan. Despite the undoubted benefits of such a measure, a number of internal problems persist, which call into question the desirability of this important step.  In particular, it is about maintaining reprehensible practices such as torture and abusive deprivation of liberty, corruption in the judicial sector, high rates of deaths in detention, ethnic conflicts, discrimination of minorities (including sexual minorities), ill-treatment of minors.  In these circumstances, the current resolution rightly notes that there is a need to reconsider the measure envisaged by the Commission and to support the remediation of the deficient areas in that country. For this reason, the resolution is timely and must be supported.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which notes that the supervisory bodies of the relevant conventions have found clear deficiencies in relation to a series of relevant GSP conventions and considers that the deficiencies outlined above constitute a serious breach in the effective implementation of the relevant conventions.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed the objection raised by the GUE/NGL Group to granting generalised tariff preferences to Kyrgyzstan. Up to now Kyrgyzstan’s application has been encouraging: the Committee against Torture in its last report mentions some of the positive elements that were achieved, for instance towards compensation of victims or guaranteeing the independence of judges. Many reforms are yet to be introduced, but I believe this is only within the GSP+ monitoring that we can closely accompany it.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against objecting to the delegated act on the system of general customs preferences, initiated by the European United Left Group - the Nordic Green Left because they feel kyrgyzstan is not making progress in implementing the provisions of the Convention against Torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading punishment procedures. I believe that the objection did not take into account the positive steps of the Kyrgyz government as one of the poorest countries in the region. Namely, the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic has taken positive steps to improve human rights through various initiatives to combat violence against women, improve the Refugee Act, introduce human rights educational programmes for public officials and judges, seek to guarantee the independence of judges and apply international treaties directly before the courts. In addition, I believe that general customs preferences are an additional motivation for Kyrgyzstan to continue reforms, as well as to strengthen their economy, increase exports and promote industrialisation, and therefore we should not abolish them.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I rejected the motion for a resolution opposing the delegated act on the scheme of generalised tariff preferences, because I do not agree with the objection tabled. I believe that the delegated act complies with all the rules and is thus credible.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this objection because we find it contradictory that GSP+ status be granted to Kyrgyzstan when reports from international organizations of remarkable credibility have caught the eye on human rights violations in this country. GSP+ status is granted to developing countries on the clear condition that they meet a number of good practice requirements. In 2013, the Committee against Torture warned about the systematic use of torture in Kyrgyzstan, failures of the rule of law and abuse. In 2015, the ILO ranked Kyrgyzstan among the countries with the least protection for workers.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted against because no major or systematic errors were found in the Kyrgyz application. In addition, the GSP+ instrument can serve as an incentive to bring about further positive changes in the Kyrgyz Republic.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 We recognize the existence of difficulties in the Kyrgyz Republic, many of them arising from aggressive and imperialist policies, the consequences of which always fall on populations and workers. We do not follow the assessment underlying the annulment of the delegated act. Moreover, we believe that the problems that exist in that country should be solved by the local population, in the strictest respect for their sovereignty.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the EU Parliament resolution on 'Objections to the delegated act on a scheme of generalised tariff preferences'. The aim of the motion is to cut off Kyrgyzstan from certain privileges granted by the Special Scheme for Sustainable Development and Good Governance (GSP+). These include, among other things, advantages in customs clearance. However, the motion does not take into account the positive steps that Kyrgyzstan has already taken to date. As one of the poorest countries in the region, Kyrgyzstan has taken some considerable steps to improve its human rights record, for example in ensuring victim compensation and the introduction of human rights education programmes for civil servants and judges. The ECR believes that this should be rewarded by the GSP+, which can be a very important tool for further reforms in Kyrgyzstan. The motion ignores Kyrgyzstan's efforts so far, so I and my group voted against it.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. We know the situation of political instability that has been experienced in Kyrgyzstan in the last decade, the difficulties and contradictions that result. We do not know of news that confirms today the report expressed in this objection. We are well in mind the pressures and interference that has been imposed by the West in this former Soviet republic, resulting from the geopolitical game of control of that region, pressures that have recently been amplified by that country's process of joining the Eurasian Economic Union. We reject the position of call for sanctions on a sovereign country seeking to boost its own development project. We voted against it.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted against the adoption of the Delegated Regulation because I do not believe it will help to resolve the identified violations of fundamental human rights in the Contracting States. The findings are alarming and under existing schemes it is necessary to establish stricter controls on compliance with international conventions on human and labour rights in underdeveloped countries, parties to trade agreements, and to effectively sanction violations.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – Today UKIP voted in favour of the objection to delegated act on the specific compositional and information requirements for processed cereal-based food and baby food. We in UKIP believe that all infant products should be safe and used appropriately and that all parents and carers should receive accurate information about infant and young child feeding. We oppose misleading promotions and we believe in the importance of preventing child obesity and supporting zero tolerance for pesticides in infant food.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection because the EP must stop a delegated act with which the European Commission intends to undermine the nutritional and transparency and information requirements of processed foods based on cereals and children's foods, for example by allowing a rate of up to 30% sugars in infant food, thus contradicting WHO's opinions. In addition, I am firmly against the Commission trying to adopt such measures through delegated acts, thus trying to avoid the European Parliament.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution which rejected a Commission proposal to allow 30% of the energy in a baby food to be derived from sugar. This dangerous proposal flew in the face of health expert advice and was rightly rejected by the majority of Parliament, and I was happy to support the rejection of the proposal. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that less than 10% of a food’s total energy intake should be from free sugars and a further 5% is recommended for additional health benefits. With worrying levels of childhood obesity in Ireland, both North and South, and a warning from the WHO that Ireland is due to become the most obese country in Europe if current trends continue, it is right that this proposal, which should never have been put forward in the first place, was rejected.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. With this resolution, Parliament rejects a Commission proposal which would have meant that baby food could contain much more sugar than recommended by the World Health Organisation. Because increased sugar consumption already leads to a large part of the known diseases of civilisation, it is particularly important and right to protect the youngest from them. The same applies, incidentally, to the use of genetically modified substances. Although I voted in favour of the resolution, I find it regrettable that the points to be voted on did not receive a majority on zero tolerance for pesticides. For my part, I will continue to advocate a halt to carcinogenic substances such as .B. glyphosate.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The objection proposal put forward has the effect of delaying new positive regulations on the information and limitation of pesticides in infant food. A negative vote was therefore required.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, primarily because I do not believe in the principle of delegated acts which place power in the hands of the unelected Commission and take it away from the elected Parliament. However, I do note that there are significant health concerns with sugary additives to baby food. I also oppose misleading advertising and labelling, although it is important to point out that such matters are already regulated at a national level, including through the Advertising Standards Authority.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of rejecting the EC decision on the level of sugar in infant food because it did not take into account global recommendations. Although the World Health Organisation recommends that sugar should produce up to 10% of the energy value of food for infants, the EU is currently allowed to use and distribute baby foods, which up to 30% of the energy value comes from sugar. I agree that the sugar levels allowed in infant foods need to be significantly reduced, in line with the WHO recommendation. I agree that the labelling and distribution of processed foods for infants 'should make it clear that these products are unfit for consumption by infants under 6 months of age', as it is recommended that such infants be fed exclusively with breast milk. I also support calls for the use of genetically modified organisms and nanotechnologies in baby food.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This is an objection to a delegated act that is intended to regulate the composition and information of baby food from 4 months of age. The rapporteur stresses the importance of breastfeeding, which is certainly desirable but not always possible. It also calls for a review of the maximum allowed sugar level and a total ban on glyphosate. However, the return of the text will not necessarily produce the desired effects and may, above all, delay some real progress, particularly with regard to packaging information.  In addition, EFSA is due to produce two 2016 notices on the composition and pesticides allowed. These notices will result in revisions to this delegated act. You should know that so-called "baby-food" products are the most standardized and controlled products. It is almost certain that a well-meaning mother who does not want to buy specialty products exposes her child to more pesticides (multiplied by 10 in breast milk for example or uncontrolled on fresh products) than with so-called industrial products that are highly standardized. The industrialists are already ready to apply it and this text will not harm babies more than at present, on the contrary. That is why I voted against this objection.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. This resolution aims to oppose a Council regulation that sets the conditions for the composition of cereal-based preparations and baby food. Parliament considers that the regulation does not provide sufficient measures to protect infants and young children from obesity, and that the maximum sugar content had to be significantly reduced to a level in line with WHO recommendations.

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: Written. I objected to the Commission's act. I've done this because we have to look after our children and babies. I understand that the proposal will allow the Commission to maintain european limit values for sugar in baby food, for example, even though the WHO recommendations are at a considerably lower level. I have also noted that the necessary analysis by the EU food safety agency EFSA is not available.  I call on the Commission to ensure that the necessary analytical basis is put in place immediately, so that eu limit values are properly grounded and so that we have certainty about how public health is affected by sugar content and processed foods in diets for babies and young children. Then we can adopt EU rules that give meaning and added value to Europe's citizens. I expect the Commission to start doing so immediately.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Weaning foods play a key role in the transition from an all-breasted diet to a diet involving the introduction of solid foods. Each of these products must comply with high quality standards and have a formulation that allows the infant to receive the nutrients necessary for its specific stage of development. The WHO recently published a recommendation for a total absence of added salt and sugar in complementary infant foods. This is a much more restrictive position than that laid down in Part 3 of Annex I to the Delegated Regulation presented by the Commission, which provides that 30% of the energy supplied by baby food may come from sugar. It is precisely with this in mind that I have chosen to vote in favour of the objection, believing that the Commission has not been sufficiently attentive to the dimension of protecting children's health.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of the delegated act, which seeks to take into account issues such as the composition requirements of baby food and scientific evidence of the effects of added sugar, the precautionary principle for emerging technologies (nanotechnology) not sufficiently tested, that glyphosate and other pesticides are considered substances to which a zero tolerance should be applied Etc. All Member States have ratified the International Code for the Marketing of Breast Milk Substitutes, aimed at ensuring that breast milk substitutes are used safely.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to a delegated act on the specific composition and information requirements for cereal preparations and baby food. The delegated act in question aims to regulate the composition and information of baby food from 4 months, a laudable and necessary objective.  The reference of this text proposed by the English ecologist Keith Taylor seems inappropriate since it would only delay advances in packaging information. Baby food is now the most controlled product and we can only welcome this because of the health and food security of our children.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution in the vote would slow down an already established review process. That is why I voted against.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Commission has not submitted to Parliament and the Council the report on the composition of preparations for young children provided for in Article 12 of Regulation (EU) No 609/2013, a necessary condition for national strategies to reduce childhood obesity. The Commission also aims to allow the energy provided by infant food to come from 30% of sugar, a proposal that contradicts all WHO health opinions, which has recommended significant reductions in total sugar intake. That is why I voted in favour of this Resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament examines the composition and information requirements for processed cereal-based foods and baby foods. The Commission has not submitted a report to Parliament and the Council on feeding mixtures for young children, as provided for in Article 12 of Regulation (EU) No 609/2013, as a prerequisite for the development of national strategies to reduce childhood obesity. The European Parliament considers that this Regulation does not provide for sufficient measures to protect infants and young children against obesity and that the maximum level of sugar should be significantly reduced in line with the recommendations of the World Health Organisation (WHO). In addition, given the high vulnerability of the endocrine system in infants and young children, the general principle of strict pesticide intolerance should apply. Any derogations from the principle of zero tolerance of pesticides should be explicitly listed in the Annex to the Regulation, which should be regularly updated in order to continuously reduce maximum levels, taking into account new scientific evidence on the health effects of active substances and their metabolites. The European Parliament also proposes that labelling and distribution provisions should be reviewed in line with the recommendations of the World Health Assembly (PSA) on foods for infants and young children.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that further measures are needed to protect infants and young children from obesity, and therefore, in accordance with who's recommendations, the maximum permitted sugar levels should be significantly reduced. In accordance with the Hungarian Basic Law, the production of GMO-free products must be ensured. I am convinced that, as a general principle, zero tolerance should be applied to plant protection products in order to protect infants and young children. In the light of new scientific evidence on the health impact of active substances and their degradation substances, regulation should be regularly updated towards continuously stricter maximum residue levels.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I also did not support the proposed decision rejecting the delegated act on specific requirements for composition and information in the case of processed cereal-based foods and baby foods, as the refusal could have consequences for the food industry, which has been waiting for a long time to see that delegated act.  I believe that the proposal for a delegated act adequately protects the health of young children and infants, who are the largest users of processed cereal-based porridge, if I may express myself. I fear that the rejection of the delegated act will cause damage to the European food industry. But it is now up to the Commission to respond to the complaints and to come up with a more acceptable act.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote provides an important signal about the european Parliament's position on child nutrition and demonstrates its alignment with the general recommendations of the World Health Organisation. Since the WHO recommends limiting sugar intake to less than 10% of total energy consumption in early childhood, we could only reject the Commission's proposal that sugars could continue to account for up to 30% of the caloric intake of baby foods. This provision would not only have been contrary to the who's aforementioned position, but also to the health advice from the scientific committees of the Member States.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ The Commission simply signed over a 1996 provision that baby food can contain up to 30 per cent sugar and that is why I support this objection. In 2015, the World Health Organisation published a recommendation that no sugar and salt should be added to baby food for up to two years. The introduction of high-sugar foods, especially at such an early stage, can contribute to more obese children and affect the development of a tendency towards flavours that are still developing in children.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this objection to a delegated act on specific composition and information requirements for cereal-based foods and baby food because I believe that the provisions contained in this act do not take sufficient account of the main recommendations of the World Health Organisation and therefore have important scientific shortcomings.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important to make public the list of 'bilateral meetings' that the Commission has held with stakeholders in drafting the regulation, which includes the specific composition and information requirements for cereal-based foods and baby food (C(2015)06507 – 2015/2863 (DEA) for both transparency and to strengthen citizens' confidence in eu institutions and decision-making. That is also why we hope that the Commission will comply with the WHO's guidelines on infant nutrition, with particular reference to limiting the sugar content of infant feed and the elimination of glyphosate in the food industry because of the damage to children's health caused by this substance. The road to the well-being of the Union depends first and first and for all on the proper protection of the health of our children and their proper nutrition.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Inadequate nutrition is currently the leading cause of disease and mortality worldwide, while overall food security is an important objective assumed by the Union and steps in this regard, given the impact on this segment of the population, should be done in consultation with global research bodies, taking into account in particular the questioning of breastfeeding and the worsening of childhood obesity. In addition to the fact that the labelling and marketing of products should be reviewed in accordance with the recommendations of the World Health Assembly on foods for infants and young children, we cannot fail to recall that transparency is needed in eu decision-making, giving public access to the commission meeting documents during the drafting of the delegated regulation. I voted in favour of this resolution because I consider it necessary for the European Union to clarify and adapt these aspects of the optimal health and nutrition of its citizens, in particular categories such as infants and young children, which represent a particularly vulnerable population with regard to endocrine disruptors and other contaminants.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The text of the objection, tabled by the Greens, aims to call for a lowering of maximum sugar levels in line with the WHO recommendations. In this regard, it should be specified that the European Commission has already indicated its intention to require EFSA to review and update the composite criteria for baby food that are now dated and dating back to a scientific opinion several years ago. The Italian industry therefore considers that the reasons for the objection are already taken into account by the Commission, which has set in motion the correct procedure for this purpose. Approval of the objection would in fact have the opposite effect to the intended effect, delaying an already planned review process. Finally, the profound reason for this objection is the forced promotion of breastfeeding, which is irreplaceable in terms of immune defences, but which is not always possible and potentially more dangerous than industrial products, since it concentrates the chemicals consumed by the mother.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the objection to a delegated act on specific composition and information requirements for cereal-based foods and baby food. Parliament has decided to oppose this delegated act because the Commission has not submitted to Parliament and the Council the report on baby formulae as provided for in Article 12 of Regulation (EU) No 609/2013, which is a necessary precondition for national strategies to reduce childhood obesity.
