In addition, Part 3 of Annex I to the Delegated Regulation provides that 30% of the energy supplied by baby food may come from sugar. This is contrary to the advice of the World Health Organisation (MDG), which recommends a sharp reduction in total sugar intake, particularly for infants and early childhood children. In view of these factors, I have chosen to vote in favour of this objection, thus opposing this delegated act.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This vote was to reject proposals that would have allowed 30% of the energy in baby foods to be derived from sugar. Given the high amounts spent by the government every year on conditions such as obesity and diabetes, and the proven difficulties in weaning young infants from sugary foods, it was essential that the existing cap was not allowed to be raised. The WHO recommends limiting intake of sugars to less than 10% of total energy intake, therefore this was a no-brainer.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I believe that the emerging technologies in the area of food processing, such as GMOs and nanotechnologies, should be prohibited in cereal-based food and most importantly in baby food. Their long-term effects are not yet known to us and not enough studies have been carried out in this area so it would be very unsafe and unreasonable to use them in these foods.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text, which raises objections to a delegated act on specific compositional and information requirements for cereal-based foods and baby food. The text recommends reducing the maximum sugar content in such a way that it corresponds to the indications of the World Health Organization (WHO). The WHO recommends limiting the sugar content to less than 10% of total energy consumption, but according to the European Commission's proposal sugars could continue to provide up to 30% calorie intake in baby foods. An excessive amount of sugar in baby food would not protect infants and children from obesity, which is why I supported the veto of this draft legislation.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We object to the Commission's delegated regulation because we consider it wrong not to provide for adequate measures to protect infants and young children from obesity. Given the particular vulnerability of the endocrine system of infants and young children, we believe that a zero tolerance policy on pesticides should be applied as a general principle.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Discussions on the need to revise and improve the rules governing the production and marketing of food are by definition of importance. In particular, cases involving the feeding of children and newborns need careful consideration. I therefore consider the nature of this resolution to be very important, which emphasises the need to adopt a stricter framework of regulations. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of it, considering it to be protective of the whole of European society.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because I do not believe that the Commission's delegated regulation is deficient in provisions to protect the food safety of children.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this objection for two important reasons: the first is that, given the recent cases of communication, I no longer believe in the World Health Organisation and therefore no longer believe that its recommendations are reliable and I do not think that the legislation should be adapted to what a body that has shown itself to be extremely partisan says. The second, more legal reason is the regulatory vacuum that this objection would create and that absolutely must be avoided so that companies can act within a clear and predictable legislative framework.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because the Commission has already asked EFSA for a review and update of the composite criteria for baby food, which are now dated. Therefore, the adoption of this objection would only delay an already planned review process.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ In Annex I of the Commission’s proposal the compositional requirements concerning sugars are taken over from previous legislation, and have not been revised since 1996. The Commission was given a time frame of 2 years to adopt the delegated acts, however it said that EFSA has not yet had time to carry out a study and provide scientific advice. This lack of action means only that such foods can contain added sugar up to a maximum of 30%. In 2015, the World Health Organisation published a recommendation that salt and sugar should not be added to complementary foods for infants and young children in the first two years of their life. Considering the time lapse and new evidence I cannot accept the Commission’s position and therefore  voted in favour of this objection.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution supported by the Green Group suggests opposing the Commission's draft decision in a delegated act on the requirements for cereal-based baby formula, on the grounds that sugar levels are too high. I would like to point out that the Commission has complied with its mandate by applying the highest international standards. It also announced that a new study would be conducted by the European Food Safety Agency and that measures would be taken based on its results. For these reasons, I objected to this objection.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted in favour of the objection to the delegated act on the specific compositional and information requirements for processed cereal-based food and baby food. We in UKIP believe that all infant products should be safe and used appropriately and that all parents and carers should receive accurate information about infant and young child feeding. We oppose misleading promotions and we believe in the importance of preventing child obesity and supporting zero tolerance for pesticides in infant food.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to the permitted sugar content in cereal and baby food preparations because it seemed to me to be unfounded.  Not only is the sugar level fully aligned with the Codex foodarius standard (global food regulations), as revised in 2006, but the delegated act also provides for extremely high standards for the composition of these specific foods, in particular to reduce their sugar, salt and fat content. In addition, the Commission has committed to promptly requesting a rapid reassessment of the composition standards of these products, in order to further restrict them if necessary.  Finally, talking about the sugar level of a given food does not make much sense, it is the level of sugar consumed as part of the general diet that counts.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. 'The N-VA delegation did not support the proposal of delegated action on processed foods based on cereals and baby food. The existing legislation (i.e. Regulation (EU) No 609/2013) rightly ensures that the EU applies the strictest standards on baby food.  The delegated act should help ensure a consistent interpretation and application of this legislation throughout the EU-28 while providing adequate protection for this vulnerable group. This must be done as quickly as possible. However, supporting the objection would be an endorsement of the status quo.  The call for zero tolerance for pesticide residues seems neither realistic nor practically workable: the legislation already contains – quite rightly so – extremely strict maximum levels of pesticide residues. However, a legitimate point of discussion and cause for concern is the permitted sugar content. The N-VA supported the amendments calling for a reduction in the content of added sugars and the taking into account the scientific evidence on the effects of added sugar and the findings in the EFSA study on this subject. In the context of the fight against obesity, the N-VA welcomes the European Commission's explicit commitment to this.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. I have fully joined this report on the feeding of babies and early-age children, which states that a number of WHO rules, in particular and precautions, are not in place regarding the composition and labelling of cereal-based formulas and baby food.  Young children are a vulnerable audience, in Europe and around the world, that must be protected above all else. Eating habits and taste determination are fundamental to human health. The introduction of salt and sugar artificially and early increases the prevalence of obesity and cardiovascular disease. We have therefore asked the Commission to review its copy.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This objection is intended to promote the feeding of babies exclusively through breastfeeding. While the latter allows irreplaceable immune intakes, it is sometimes impossible or even dangerous if the mother has ingested chemicals. On the other hand, industrial food is tightly controlled. To the extent that this objection is likely to have a counterproductive effect, particularly by delaying information on feeding babies, I voted against it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the objection to the delegated act on the specific composition and information requirements for processed cereal-based foods and baby foods, as I believe that the existing legislation on the subject of food composition is too heterogeneous and work needs to be worked towards improving it. I do not deny the fact that sugar consumption levels are rising head-on and in the 21st century we are facing a new problem, namely obesity. I voted against not because I want to block the adoption of this delegated act, but because I believe that the Commission must stick to its commitments.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The delegated regulation does not include sufficient measures to protect infants and young children from processed food. This motion for a resolution contains the objections raised and calls on the Commission to delay the adoption of this delegated act until its own report on preparations for young children has been published. EFSA's views are also expected to be made public with a view to reviewing the evidence on sugar and early consumption of processed foods in relation to recommendations on optimal nutrition for infants and young children, in particular in relation to undermining breastfeeding and sharpening the phenomenon of childhood obesity. It is clear that the delegated regulation should not enter into force.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution referring to Regulation (EU) No 609/2013 on food intended for particular nutritional use, because it addresses 4 important issues: obesity in early childhood and the need to substantially reduce the maximum level of sugar permitted in line with who's recommendations; contaminants and zero tolerance for pesticides as a general principle; labelling and clear indication that baby foods are not suitable for infants under 6 months and should not undermine the recommendation on exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months; the transparency and publication of the bilateral meetings which the Commission held with interested parties during the process of drawing up the delegated regulation. My decision was dictated by the fact that both the WHO and the scientific committees of the Member States recommend a significant reduction in the total sugar intake; warn that the introduction of such foods is likely to contribute to rising levels of childhood obesity and may affect the development of taste preferences in children; finally, that for infants and young children, in particular, the levels of added sugars should be kept to a minimum.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. 'Infants and young children are a particularly vulnerable group when it comes to endocrine disruptors and other contaminants. What they eat and drink is therefore of particular importance for their health, and the regulations on, for example, infant formulae and nutritional supplements for children must therefore be strict and scientifically based. For this reason, we have supported the call for a new delegated act which takes into account the results of the EFSA review of processed cereal-based foods and baby foods and which is based on scientific proof of the effects of added sugar. However, we have chosen not to object to this delegated act, because we do not want to slow down the application of EU Regulation No 609/2013 on food for specific groups, thereby helping to create legal uncertainty.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Currently, poor diet is by far the world's leading cause of disease and death – surpassing the sum of tobacco, alcohol and physical inactivity values. Who herself recommends that children be fed exclusively by breastfeeding during the first six months of life, that, from this age on, breast milk should be supplemented with a series of adequate, safe and nutrient-rich foods that do not add salt and sugar to complementary foods. All Member States have adopted the International Code for the Marketing of Breast Milk Substitutes and its 16 subsequent resolutions, which are intended to ensure that all parents and carers receive objective and truly independent information, remove barriers to breastfeeding and ensure that breast milk substitutes, if necessary, are used safely. However, the measures of the Delegated Regulation are not sufficient to protect infants and young children against obesity and the maximum permitted sugar level should be significantly reduced in accordance with WHO recommendations. It is therefore to agree that this regulation should not enter into force.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report because the delegated act has no more drawbacks than the current legislation in this area.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The main objection to this delegated act concerns how the industry advertises and places products on the market with processed cereal-based foods and baby foods. The measures of the Delegated Regulation are considered not sufficient to protect infants and babies against childhood obesity. The rules proposed by this delegated act turn these products into potential Trojan horses to introduce sugar quantities above those recommended by the World Health Organisation for babies over 6 months. In the case of foods targeted at consumers with the most vulnerable endocrine system (infants and young children), the principle of zero tolerance for pesticides is justifiably asked to apply. There are a number of criticisms of the European Commission, which we endorse.  Better and more accurate labelling and the prohibition of advertising of specialised products for specific medical conditions are advocated, as they should be restricted to providing scientific data to doctors who prescribe them, not misleading parents. No health benefits should be mentioned for the consumption of these products and labelling and marketing rules should be revised in accordance with WHO recommendations on infant and baby foods. We voted in favour.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution as the delegated regulation does not contain sufficient measures to protect infants and young children from processed food.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that the delegated regulation does not contain sufficient measures to protect infants and young children from obesity and that the maximum permitted sugar levels should be significantly reduced, in accordance with who's recommendations. In view of the specific vulnerability of the endocrine system in infants and young children, as a general principle, zero tolerance should be applied to plant protection products. Any deviation from the principle of zero tolerance for plant protection products should be explicitly listed in Annex III, which should be regularly updated to continuously stricter maximum residue levels following new scientific evidence on the health effects of active substances and their degradation substances. In order to build transparency and public confidence in the Union institutions and union decision-making, a list of bilateral meetings (including their dates and participants) with stakeholders should be made public during the process of drafting the Delegated Regulation.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted against the objection to ensure that the Delegated Regulation includes sufficient measures to protect infants and young children from obesity, in line with WHO recommendations. It is essential to ensure the health and well-being of European citizens, even more so in view of the group targeted by the Delegated Regulation, young children.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I strongly supported the proposal to reject the adoption of the Delegated Act on Baby Food. In particular, I agree with what is stated in the text on the protection of early childhood from obesity: the delegated regulation does not contain sufficient measures to protect children, especially for the maximum level of sugar permitted in line with the WHO recommendations.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the objection to the Commission's delegated regulation of 25 September 2015 supplementing Regulation No. I believe that regulation (EEC) No 609/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council on specific requirements for composition and information for cereal-based foods and baby food should be a shared challenge for policy and institutions to affirm new lifestyles and new eating habits, ensuring well-being and health for future generations. I believe that sugars taken in quantities equal to or even greater than 10% are negative health determinants, since excessive energy and caloric intake is a certain cause of numerous metabolic diseases, before which obesity. I therefore believe it is essential to pursue the objective of promoting breastfeeding by organising campaigns to raise awareness and promote scientific relevance in relation to the nutritional benefits and positive effects linked to the mother-child relationship. Investing in prevention also means reducing the costs of public health. We therefore welcome the Commission's commitment in this House to the definition of the new delegated act, which should be completed within 12 months at the latest.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the objections to the delegated act with regard to the specific composition and information requirements for cereal foods and other foods, making it clear that I want a healthy baby food. I do not want experiments with nanotechnology, genetic engineering or increased hidden sugar content. European legislation must strengthen parents, children and responsible producers here – not the cheap tricksters. At the same time, I say that the healthiest food for our little ones is breast milk. Promoting this must also be Europe's stated concern. My aim is a europe that is completely quiet!

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. There is still a lack of essential elements in the regulation to really improve food safety for infants and children. The level of childhood obesity has increased significantly in recent years. It is precisely here that we must take further measures.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. Mr. Taylor objected to a delegated act of the Commission. This delegated act relates to the regulation of baby food, when baby food starts to eat solid foods. The text merely clarified that food must now be labelled as "not suitable for children under 4 months of age".  Of course, breastfeeding is to be preferred, as long as the mother can, and I support any measure that allows for longer breastfeeding, but not all mothers can follow the recommendations of the World Health Organization: exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months. So we need drastic regulations on alternative foods, and immediately, to protect the health of our children. The regulations in place are already very restrictive and can be further improved.  EFSA is due to make two recommendations this year, including the maximum sugar levels that these foods can contain. I will advise at this time whether to object, recalling that the nutritional balance of children rests primarily on the parents. So I voted against that objection.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Labour Party colleagues, I voted in favour of this report. Given the obesity epidemic and especially concerns about childhood obesity – one in three 11-year-olds in Europe are overweight or obese – it is ridiculous to allow so much added sugar in baby food. Giving very young children highly sweetened foods can also influence their developing taste preferences and make them more likely to consume unhealthy, sugary food in the future. Labour MEPs want lower maximum sugar levels in baby food – we must ensure babies get the best start in life, and that means reducing the amount of sugar allowed in baby food.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted against this objection because its justifications seemed completely unfounded to me. Aiming to challenge a draft text on food for infants and young children (including small pots), it conveyed a lot of false information.  Aimed at vulnerable populations, it is normal for these foods to meet strict compositional standards, in order to limit the content of salt, saturated fats, and sugars. This was precisely the purpose of the Commission's text, which confirmed the current compositional requirements and current nutritional standards, among the highest in the world.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The objection is based on the fact that this measure does not adopt the necessary measures to prevent obesity, especially in infants and young children, since it allows very high levels of sugar in foods contrary to all the recommendations of the World Health Organization. Since poor nutrition is the leading cause of disease and death worldwide, we agree and vote in favour of the objection.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this objection to a delegated act on the compositional and information requirements for processed cereal-based food and baby food as I believe MEPs should have an opportunity to re-open negotiations on the sugar content of such products. The current proposal allows baby foods to provide 30% of their energy from sugar, which flies in the face of WHO recommendations which set the maximum levels at 10%. Levels of 30% are outdated and do not take the latest findings into consideration. According to estimates from the WHO’s Childhood Obesity Surveillance Initiative, around one in three children in the EU aged 6-9 years were overweight, or obese, in 2010. Information from various different studies suggests that this number has increased steadily over the past 20 to 30 years. Childhood obesity is closely linked to an increased intake of carbohydrates and fats. Therefore a limit of 10% sugar in baby foods would be a significant step in fighting childhood obesity and, hopefully, today’s positive vote will now allow this to happen.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because the European Union has an obligation to promote high-quality public health principles, standards and legislation in its relations with non-EU countries and international organisations in the field of public health and a duty to establish an effective health protective framework. The delegated regulation does not contain sufficient measures to protect infants and young children against obesity and the allowed maximum sugar level should be substantially lowered in line with WHO recommendations.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission’s proposal to allow baby foods to contain sugar far in excess of WHO guidelines was simply ludicrous. The EU is facing an obesity crisis which brings with it massive problems for individuals and public health services. I fully support this House’s objection to the delegated act and congratulate my colleague Mr Taylor in steering this through parliament.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution on the specific compositional and information requirements for processed cereal-based food and baby food. The World Health Organization clarifies that healthy food is a primary step in the good and healthy development of a baby. A primordially negative factor of obesity for children is sugar added in the early stages of developing, thus the amount of sugar added to baby foods should be reduced.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for Parliament's resolution on the Commission's Delegated Regulation amending Regulation (EU) No 2012/2013. 609/2013 concerning specific requirements for ingredients and information for processed cereal-based foods and baby food, as this raises objections to the Delegated Regulation of the Commission. The protection of infants and young children should be the primary objective of the Delegated Regulation, however, in the same maximum level of sugar is too high, and zero tolerance for pesticides is not fully applied.  Poor nutrition is one of the main causes of disease and death globally, and therefore I believe that when it comes to baby food, one should be especially careful and use the highest possible standards. On the other hand, public confidence in the EU institutions and transparency of the decision-making process should also be increased.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Baby food is already very effectively controlled, and this objection unnecessarily panics about the consequences of the disputed text. I voted against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted against objecting to a delegated act on the specific composition and information requirements for cereal preparations and baby food. I consider the objection to be unfounded insofar as the delegated act already provides for very high standards of sugar, salt and fat content.  That objection has been adopted, which I regret.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report. It notes that the Commission's delegated acts concerned do not provide for sufficient measures to prevent childhood and infant obesity and that the maximum sugar content should be reduced in line with existing WHO recommendations. In view of the vulnerability of the endocrine system in infants and young children, zero tolerance for pesticides should also be made the general standard. For these reasons, I agree with the call for the appropriate delegated acts to be withdrawn.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the objection as the delegated regulation would allow baby foods to continue to contain up to three times more sugar than is recommended by the World Health Organization and it fails to protect infants and young children against obesity.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: Writing. Parents should be given the freedom to choose to eat their children. In the case of the mother's professional activity or the impossibility of illness, a substitute for breastfeeding with cereal foods is essential. There is also no need for additional warnings. For these reasons, I voted against the objection to the delegated act on cereal sedan foods.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. \u2012 A very important resolution has been adopted which rightly raises objections to the Commission Delegated Regulation. Our health and illnesses are largely based on infant nutrition. Lifelong allergic diseases and their complications are "due" to the recklessness and profit interests of formula manufacturers. The Commission's leniency with regard to pesticides and artificial sugars is unacceptable. It is important to expect transparency and to avoid suspicion of corruption in order to make public the list of bilateral meetings with dates and participants that the Commission has conducted with stakeholders during the process of drafting the Delegated Regulation. It is essential that every possible effort should be made to ensure that infants receive breast milk exclusively for the first six months of their life.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I did not support the objection to a delegated act on the specific composition and information requirements for cereal preparations and baby food. The rapporteur stresses the importance of breastfeeding, which is certainly desirable but not always possible. It also calls for a review of the maximum allowed sugar level and a total ban on glyphosate. The removal of this text will not necessarily have the desired effect. It will only delay progress, including some packaging information.  In addition, EFSA is due to produce two 2016 notices on the composition and pesticides allowed. These notices will result in revisions to this delegated act. You should know that so-called "baby-food" products are the most standardized and controlled products. It is almost certain that a well-meaning mother who does not want to buy specialty products exposes her child to more pesticides than with so-called highly standardized industrial products. The industrialists are already ready to apply it and this text will not harm babies more than at present, on the contrary.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this objection because I think it unnecessarily panics about the consequences of the impudnt text. Baby food is very well controlled.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the appeal in order to maintain a higher will when it comes to regulating the amount of sugar in the diet.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution because poor diet is by far the biggest cause of disease and death globally, greater even than tobacco, alcohol and physical inactivity considered together. The Commission has not submitted to Parliament and the Council the report on young children's food required by Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013. 609/2013 (Article 12) and which is a necessary condition for national strategies to reduce childhood obesity. The maximum sugar level should be significantly reduced in line with WHO recommendations.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 While any person needs food consumption to sustain life, perhaps the most dependent group in this respect are children, especially infants, in which the quality and maximum safety of food are of fundamental importance. I therefore welcome the motion for a resolution adopted by the European Parliament, which was drafted in response to the Commission's delegated regulation of 25 September 2015. Protection of infants and young children from obesity, the absolute minimisation of allowable sugar levels in line with World Health Organisation standards, the total inadmissibility of pesticides, the clearest possible labelling system and, of course, the maximum transparency of the whole system: if we want our future generations to be healthy, we must unequivocally guarantee safety in an area that everyone regularly encounters throughout his or her life and in which there can be no 'discounts' in principle.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Commission's delegated regulation supplementing Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 609/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council, as regards the specific composition and information requirements for processed cereal-based foods and baby foods, because I believe that this is a complete and well-documented proposal.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this objection. MP Keith Taylor objected to a delegated act on the composition and information of baby food from 4 months. Among other things, the rapporteur praises breastfeeding, which is certainly desirable but not always possible, and calls for a review of the maximum amount of sugar allowed and a total ban on glyphosate.  The reference of this text seems to us to be a little unnecessary since it will only delay progress. In addition, baby products are already the most standardized and controlled products. The Commission's text will not harm babies any more than it does now, on the contrary. This opposition is therefore unnecessary.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution. Given the obesity epidemic and especially concerns about childhood obesity – one in three 11-year-olds in Europe are overweight or obese – it is ridiculous to allow so much added sugar in baby food. Giving very young children highly sweetened foods can also influence their developing taste preferences and make them more likely to consume unhealthy, sugary food in the future. Labour MEPs want lower maximum sugar levels in baby food – we must ensure babies get the best start in life, and that means reducing the amount of sugar allowed in baby food

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we discussed a topic of considerable importance, which is the composition of the diet for the youngest children, who for various reasons could not be breastfed or for whom breastfeeding was discontinued. Of course, I agree that breast milk is irreplaceable for infants and, of course, it is the best that a child can get. However, if breastfeeding is not possible, we must also look at ensuring the quality and best composition of artificial nutrition for children. WHO studies show that poor diet is by far the world's leading cause of disease and death – greater than tobacco, alcohol, and physical inactivity combined. It is therefore extremely important to teach children the right eating habits. I agree with the objection tabled, which draws attention to the excessively high carbohydrate content of artificial infant milk, as well as to misleading advertisements for products that de facto reduce the importance of breastfeeding. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Infant and child protection in the food sector is a very important issue. Parents need to be able to transparently identify the ingredients of the food and trust in the products. The ban on GMOs and nanotechnology in cereal sedan foods is very welcome. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The resolution proposes to reject the Commission's delegated act on food for infants and young children. The Commission allowed baby food to provide 30% of its energy in sugar, which is higher than the recommendations of WHO and the scientific committees of member states, as sugar is an important factor in obesity. In addition, the resolution calls for zero tolerance for pesticides, given the particular vulnerability of the endocrine system of infants and young children. I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The adoption of this objection will not advance the ongoing studies at EFSA (European Food Safety Authority) on the composition of products and the presence of pesticides. Food balance is designed across the diet and not food by food. Industrialists and standards should not be a substitute for nutritional education and the common sense of parents. Also, the deep motivation for this objection is the forced promotion of breastfeeding, irreplaceable in terms of immune defenses but not always possible and potentially more dangerous than industrial products because it concentrates in milk the chemicals consumed by the mother. So I voted against that proposal.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the delegated regulation on the specific composition and information requirements for processed cereal-based foods and baby foods.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – As a doctor and father, I was concerned that the delegated regulation in question allows 30% of the energy in children's food to come from sugar. Today, we are facing increased obesity not only among adults, but an alarming rate of obesity among children. Obesity is one of the reasons why various difficult, often incurable diseases arise. If children increasingly receive sugar at an early age, we will not be able to eradicate obesity or the many other civilisational diseases directly linked to it. It is our duty to take all measures to ensure that the diet intended for children is balanced and made from quality raw materials. I agree that such a regulation should not enter into force.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the objection to delegated act on the specific compositional and information requirements for processed cereal-based food and baby food because the introduction of such high levels of sugar to foods – especially so early – would have contributed to the rising levels of childhood obesity and may affect the developing taste preferences of children. For infants and young children in particular, added sugar levels should be kept to a minimum.  It is an important step in helping to ensure that EU rules on baby food are designed with their health as the utmost priority. The proposal by the Commission would have allowed baby foods to contain far higher levels of sugar than those recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO).

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety tabled a motion for a resolution on 25 September 2015 (EU) .../... commission regulation. The motion proposes that the Delegated Regulation does not contain sufficient measures to protect infants and young children from obesity and does not meet the legitimate need to apply zero tolerance to plant protection products as a general principle, in view of the specific vulnerability of the endocrine system for infants and young children, listing all derogations allowed thereon in Annex III. It therefore proposes that the European Parliament object to the delegated regulation so that it cannot enter into force. I supported the adoption of the draft.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The objection to this delegated act, which is intended to regulate the composition and information of baby food from 4 months of age, is brought by an English ecologist, Keith Taylor. It stresses the importance of breastfeeding, the revision of sugar levels and the total ban on glyphosate. However, these are already measures that manufacturers are ready to implement and this delegated act risks delaying the progress of regulations in this area, particularly in terms of packaging information.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EU) No 609/2013, in Part 3 of Annex I, allows 30 % of the energy of baby food to be obtained from sugar (7.5 g sugar/100 kcal is equivalent to 30 kcal supplied per sugar per 100 kcal of energy) contrary to the World Health Organisation's health recommendations, which advises significant reductions in total sugar consumption. I would support that the introduction of these foods, especially at such an early stage, may contribute to the increase in childhood obesity rates and may affect the development of children's dietary preferences and that, in the case of infants and young children, sugar added levels should be reduced to a minimum. It is important to point out that who recommends that children be fed exclusively by breastfeeding in the first six months of life, and that, from this age on, breast milk should be supplemented with a series of adequate, safe and nutrient-rich foods that do not add salt and sugar to complementary foods.  I would argue that the recommendations of who and the scientific committees of the Member States should be taken into account in a later way in adopting the Delegated Regulation.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The removal of this text via this objection will not necessarily produce the desired effects: it will only delay progress, including certain information on packaging.  In addition, EFSA is due to produce two 2016 notices on the composition and pesticides allowed. These notices will result in revisions to this delegated act.  You should know that so-called "baby-food" products are the most standardized and controlled products. It is almost certain that a well-meaning mother who does not want to buy specialty products exposes her child to more pesticides (multiplied by 10 in breast milk for example or uncontrolled on fresh products) than with so-called industrial products that are highly standardized. The industrialists are already ready to apply it and this text will not harm babies more than at present, on the contrary.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I objected to this report, which was intended to reject a delegated act on the composition of baby food. I regret that this text has been adopted because the delegated act already provided for extremely high standards in the composition of sugar, salt and fat, rendering this objection unfounded.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. The objection to a delegated act on the specific composition and information requirements for cereal preparations and baby food was unfounded to me. I voted against the objection, which did not take into account the particularly high standards already provided for by the act.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because I do not believe that the Commission's delegated regulation is deficient in provisions to protect the safety of baby food

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ According to a report created by the Commission, one in three children aged between 6-9 years old in EU is overweighed or obese. Consequently, I voted for this motion as it is necessary to implement a set of rules in order to diminish these risks.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against objecting because I believe that the Commission's proposal for a regulation is well prepared and sufficiently protects children's health. In this case, the left in the EP misinterprets, if not deliberately, the data and recommendations of the World Health Organisation and places unrealistic demands. On the other hand, the Commission's approach has a foothold in the position of industry, consumer organisations and Member States, including the Czech Republic, which have agreed to it.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I support this report because the quality of babies' food is particularly important and children should not get used to food that is too sweet too early. The EU Commission wanted to allow up to three times as much sugar as recommended by the WHO. In addition, there are false promises on the part of manufacturers, who suggest healthy and age-appropriate nutrition by attaching images of fruit and whole grains to the product packaging, thus obscuring the actual contents. In addition to tooth damage, high-sugar foods can also lead to unhealthy eating habits and obesity.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of rejecting the Commission's delegated act on the specific composition and information requirements for cereal preparations and baby food. This objection is justified because the act does not take the necessary measures to prevent obesity in infants and young children, particularly through the reduction in sugar content recommended by WHO. In addition, it would be necessary to ban the presence of pesticides in this type of diet, due to the particular vulnerability of young people

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 Did not support the objection. Given that certain requirements are currently agreed, they should enter into force and, on that basis, should move forward in order to improve the situation.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider the problem to be of fundamental importance given that levels of overweight and obesity in European children have increased significantly in recent years and it is our duty to implement a strategy aimed at combating the situation. Despite this, I do not believe that the approach presented in the objection is the strategy to be adopted, which I believe needs to be reviewed. I therefore feel that I am voting against it.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's Resolution on the Delegated Regulation amending the Regulation (EU) of the European Parliament and the Council on specific requirements for ingredients and information for processed cereal-based foods and baby food objecting to the Delegated Commission Regulation. In my view, there should be no untested and emerging technologies, such as GMOs and nanotechnology, whose long-term dangers are not yet known, in accordance with the precautionary principle in infant formula. Due to the sensitivity of infants and the potential impact of pesticides on their endocrine system, I believe it is necessary to introduce zero tolerance to pesticides in baby food. I also believe, as well as experts from the World Health Organization, that in the first six months of a child's life, the best food is breast milk. The impossibility of breastfeeding is unfortunately a disorder from which, due to stress, unfavourable working conditions, partly as a consequence of the insufficient care of society in certain countries with a poor legislative framework on maternity leave, young mothers are increasingly suffering, but it is not a rule and a reason to avoid highlighting this important recommendation of the World Health Organization. For these reasons, I supported this Resolution and expect parliament's new proposal to take into play.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The objection is raised by Keith Taylor, an English ecologist. It objects to a delegated act that is intended to regulate the composition and information of baby food from 4 months. The rapporteur stresses the importance of breastfeeding, which is certainly desirable but not always possible. It also calls for a review of the maximum allowed sugar level and a total ban on glyphosate. The reference of the text on which the objection relates will not necessarily produce the desired effects and will only delay progress, including certain information on packaging. In addition, EFSA is due to produce two 2016 notices on the composition and pesticides allowed. These notices will result in revisions to the delegated act.  You should know that so-called "baby-food" products are the most standardized and controlled products. It is almost certain that a well-meaning mother who does not want to buy specialty products exposes her child to more pesticides (multiplied by 10 in breast milk for example or uncontrolled on fresh products) than with so-called industrial products that are highly standardized. The industrialists are already ready to apply it and this text will not harm babies more than at present, on the contrary. I vote against the objection.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support an objection to the Delegated Commission Regulation which would allow a higher level of sugar presence in baby food (30% of the energy value, i.e. 7.5g sugar/100 kcal) than recommended by the World Health Organisation. Such a solution would endanger the healthy development of children, i.e. children. eating foods with these sugar levels at an early age can contribute to growing childhood obesity and develop unhealthy habits, which is particularly worrying given that poor diet is the leading root cause of the disease globally. Scientific research and findings on the safe use of breast milk options should also be taken into account and should ensure that appropriate age of consumption is emphasized when labelling the product. This is, inter alia, the Union's duty as an international organisation leading in promoting quality principles of public health. Unfortunately, in Croatia, according to the Ordinance on processed foods based on cereals and baby food for infants and young children, a level of up to 7.5 g of sugar/100 kcal is allowed, and I hope to change this provision soon.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Part three of Annex I to Regulation (EU) No 609/2013 on baby food and baby food provides that 30% of the energy supplied by baby food may come from sugar. I believe that the Commission's Delegated Regulation (C(2015)06507) contains sufficient measures to adequately protect infants and young children from obesity and sets clear rules for practitioners and competent authorities. In fact, the European Commission has committed itself to this by consulting the European Food Safety Authority and taking into account the latest scientific data. I voted against this motion for a resolution because I believe that the Commission will be able, if necessary, to review the essential requirements for the composition of these baby foods.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I would like to stress that, although I did not support the resolution as a whole, I am also opposed to the use of GMOs because I am sceptical in this area. Especially in the area we are discussing, I would be careful about dealing with GMOs.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I objected to this objection, as did my EPP colleagues, because we find that the delegated act already has very high requirements for the composition of these foods. One of the things I want to talk about is their salt, fat and sugar content. There is therefore no use in doubling up with a new procedure that would delay the final objective.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 The reason for having voted for this objection to the delegated act concerns doubts about obesity, contaminants, labelling and transparency with regard to the Commission Regulation. I therefore believe that the measures are not sufficient to protect infants and young children from obesity and that the maximum permitted sugar level should be significantly reduced in line with the recommendations of the World Health Organisation. It also considers that zero tolerance should be given to pesticides in order to establish increasingly stringent residue ceilings on the basis of new scientific evidence on the health effects of active substances and their metabolites.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. The measures of the Delegated Regulation are not sufficient to protect infants and young children from obesity. Hence this objection. The maximum permitted sugar level should be significantly reduced in accordance with WHO recommendations. Labelling and marketing of processed baby foods should make it clear that products are not suitable for children under six months of age and should not compromise the recommendation on exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months. All labelling and marketing should be reviewed in accordance with the World Health Assembly recommendations on food for infants and young children.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The Commission has not submitted to Parliament and the Council the report on the composition of preparations for young children provided for in Article 12 of Regulation (EU) No 609/2013, a necessary condition for national strategies to reduce childhood obesity.  The Commission also aims to allow the energy provided by infant food to come from 30% of sugar, a proposal that contradicts all WHO health opinions, which has recommended significant reductions in total sugar intake. That is why I voted in favour of this Resolution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. In this resolution, in addition to voting positively in the final vote, I supported the amendments recommending reducing the intake of free sugars to less than 10% of the total energy intake in cereal-based formulas and baby foodstuffs and which estimate that reducing sugar intake to less than 5% would have additional health benefits for infants.  I also supported the provision stating that, in accordance with the precautionary principle, emerging technologies such as GMOs should be banned in food for babies and children.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 In this regard, the EPP parliamentary group, of which I am a member, has decided not to object to this Delegated Act and to accept commissioner Arias Cañete's commitment to consult the European Food Safety Authority with a view to reviewing the standards and requirements for the composition and information of processed cereal-based foods with respect to their sugar levels. However, WHO data show that the amounts of sugar in foods made possible by the Delegated Act are above the recommended doses for infants, and I therefore consider it urgent that all measures of this delegated act be re-examined, in particular with regard to labelling and advertising of specialised products for specific medical conditions. In view of the foregoing, but accepting the Commissioner's commitment, I considered it more prudent to abstain.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: Written. \u2012 I decided to vote against my group on this issue and support Parliament's objection to the Commission's proposal. It wasn't a difficult decision. We should reduce the use of sugar, not increase it. If implemented, the Commission's proposal would have meant that the quantity of sugar allowed in baby food would have exceeded three times the world health organisation's WHO recommendation. It is clear today that such a proposal does not contribute to the health of children and young people. Numerous studies have shown that an overly sugary diet increases children's overweight and adversely affects children's taste habits. Infants in particular should be protected from excessive sugar yields. For these reasons, it is better for the Commission to go back to the drawing board and present a stricter proposal to Parliament in line with who's recommendations.  I would also like to remind you that the Commission should not take food regulation lightly. Personally, I am opposed to genetically engineered foods and excessive use of vegetable toxins. More residues often end up in food than the manufacturers report. I hope that these points of view will also be reflected in the Commission's future work.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ There is a childhood obesity crisis affecting a large number of children in Europe and storing up health problems for tomorrow’s adults. Infant and childhood diet profoundly affects child health and future eating habits. Too much sugar in baby foods can lead to over-consumption of sugar and inappropriate calorie intake in the long term, causing obesity and increasing the risk factor for conditions such as type 2 diabetes, heart disease, and some cancers. The sugar limits set for baby foods can have major consequences, so we need to get them right. We cannot ignore the big discrepancy between the recent WHO recommendations and the Commission’s proposal. I am delighted a majority of colleagues joined me in backing this resolution and look forward to the Commission’s revised proposal.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: Written. 'Infants and young children are a particularly vulnerable group when it comes to endocrine disruptors and other contaminants. What they eat and drink is therefore of particular importance for their health, and the regulations on, for example, infant formulae and nutritional supplements for children must therefore be strict and scientifically based. For this reason, I have supported the call for a new delegated act which takes into account the results of the EFSA review of processed cereal-based foods and baby foods and which is based on scientific proof of the effects of added sugar. However, I have chosen not to object to this delegated act, because I do not want to slow down the application of EU Regulation No 609/2013 on food for specific groups, thereby helping to create legal uncertainty.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this as I wish to see the delegated act stopped. This should be a matter for sovereign parliaments, not the EU Commission.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this Motion for a Resolution because I find that there are several issues with this delegated act. As this motion points out, there are not sufficient measures to protect infants and young children from obesity as the maximum level of sugar is far too high and should be in line with the recommendations of the World Health Organisation. Furthermore, I feel that there were several issues with transparency in this delegated act and that the Commission should delay the adoption of this delegated act until its own report on young-child formula is published and until the EFSA has published its review regarding the evidence on sugar and the early introduction of processed foods in relation to optimal infant and young-child feeding recommendations.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the EP resolution on the implementation of the Commission Regulation of 25 September 2015 supplementing the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards specific requirements for the composition and information of processed cereal-based foods and baby foods. Since the Commission has not submitted to Parliament and the Council the report on the nutrition of young children required of it, which is a necessary condition for developing national strategies to reduce the incidence of childhood obesity, the EP is, by hijacking it, objecting to the Commission delegated regulation. The measures provided for in the Delegated Regulation are not sufficient to protect infants and young children from obesity and the maximum permitted amount of sugar should be substantially reduced in line with the WHO recommendations. Also, in view of the particular sensitivity of the endocrine system of infants and young children, pesticides should be subject to the zero tolerance principle. With the resolution adopted, we called on the Commission to postpone the adoption of the delegated act until it has published its report on nutrition for young children.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the objection to the Commission Regulation on compositional requirements and information for cereal-based foods and food for young children. Unfortunately, the objection eventually passed, although by an unconvincing majority, the veto of the Commission regulation. The regulation, which provided for an optimal sugar intake for infants, complied with the nutritional requirements laid down in the Framework framework by the World Health Organisation (WHO). The position of the Government of the Czech Republic, which I had at my disposal, also spoke in favour of the Commission regulation. On the positive aspect, the resolution dropped the requirement for zero tolerance of pesticides, which was illusory in view of reality. The authorised pesticide content is closely monitored by the Commission and its decisions are based on the recommendations of the European Food Safety Authority, which I consider to be a sufficient guarantee. I had no factual or professional reason for rejecting the implementing regulation, which is why I did not vote for it. Now the Commission will have to submit a new regulation.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Under the provisions of the delegated regulation, children's food may have 30% of the energy composition from sugar. The WHO and the scientific committees in each Member State recommend a sharp reduction in the total amount of sugar consumed. The introduction of such foods at such an early age may contribute to an increase in childhood obesity and may affect the development of their taste. I think it is a good idea to note at this point that poor nutrition is by far the biggest cause of disease and death in the world these days. The motion for a resolution is opposed by the delegated regulation, as it does not contain adequate measures to protect infants and young children from obesity. The Regulation should significantly reduce the maximum amount of sugar ingested, in line with who recommendations. I agree that the amount of added sugar, especially for infants and young children, should be minimal. For this purpose, I supported the motion for a resolution on specific compositional requirements and information for processed cereal-based foods and baby food.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the objection to the draft delegated act that would have allowed baby food to continue to contain much higher levels of sugar (up to three times higher) than those recommended by the World Health Organisation (WHO). With this vote, Parliament is calling for a reduction in the sugar content limit in the EU in order to meet who's recommendations and avoid an increase in childhood obesity, which is already a serious problem today due to bad eating habits. Furthermore, the text adopted today recalls that, in accordance with the precautionary principle, emerging technologies such as GMOs and nanotechnologies, the long-term risks of which are not known, should be banned in baby food.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I did not support this Objection to the Delegated Act on Specific Requirements for Ingredients and Information for Processed Cereal-Based Foods and Baby Food to Regulation (EU) No 100/2013. 609/2013 of the European Parliament and the Council of 12 October 2013 On June 30, 2013 on infant and young children's food, food for special medical purposes and replacement for all-day diets on a reduction diet, and on the repeal of Council Directive 92/52/EEC, Commission Directive 96/8/EC, as some people need such ingredients as they are unable to breastfeed for health or professional reasons. I also believe that a choice has been left to consumers, but that it is extremely important to inform them validly about the ingredients thereof.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The ENVI Committee urges the Commission to postpone its application in order to further agree on the content of processed baby food and information on packaging. According to a proposal from the European Commission, baby food can still contain up to three times more sugar than world health organisation recommendations. I do not think this is acceptable because this does not prevent the risk of obesity. I support delaying the entry into force of this resolution on ingredients and information on children's food, and poor nutrition is also the biggest cause of mortality in the world, so it is necessary to encourage better nutrition from an early age.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ i voted against the resolution on a Commission delegated regulation supplementing the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards specific compositional requirements and information for processed cereals and baby food.  I believe that the Commission's delegated regulation is satisfactory and contains sufficient measures to protect infants and young children from obesity. I also do not agree with the statements made in the resolution on pollutants, labelling and transparency. That is why I did not support the proposed resolution.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of this objection concerning the criteria for the composition and information of specially processed cereal-based baby and baby foods, adopted in accordance with the delegated act resulting from Article 11 of EU Regulation 609/2013.  According to the objection, the recent regulation on specific requirements for these processed foods does not provide for the necessary measures to prevent obesity, in particular in infants and young children. It also maintains the sugar level in these foods at a high rate relative to the levels recommended by the World Health Organisation.  The introduction of such foods is likely to contribute to increasing levels of childhood obesity. According to World Health Organization experts, sugar levels specifically in baby foods should be kept to a minimum so as not to cause endocrine disorders and future diseases in infants.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The delegated regulation does not include sufficient measures to protect infants and young children from processed food. This motion for a resolution objects, calls on the Commission to delay the adoption of this delegated act until its own report on preparations for young children is published and until EFSA publishes its review of the evidence on sugar and early consumption of processed foods in the light of recommendations on optimal nutrition for infants and young children , and in particular with regard to the undermining of breastfeeding and the exacerbation of the phenomenon of childhood obesity, and finally wishes to inform the Commission that the delegated regulation cannot enter into force.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution rejecting the Commission's draft regulation. In this connection, I consider it important to recommend the Recommendation of the World Health Organisation to limit the intake of free sugars to less than 10% of total energy intake, while at the same time proposing a further 5% reduction in order to further benefit. I agree that foods with high sugar content are increasingly contributing to childhood obesity and that they also influence the development of children's tastes. I share the view that inadequate nutrition is the root cause of most diseases, especially in infants and young children. I support the commission's proposal to present as soon as possible a new delegated act that takes into account the related findings of the European Food Safety Authority. In addition, scientific evidence should be taken into account with regard to optimal infant and toddler nutrition recommendations. I believe that all of this contributes to the development of good nutrition, which ultimately has clear public health benefits.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Food safety of products marketed within EU Member States is one of the main objectives of the European institutions. Food sector regulation must take into account the highest standards in the field.  All the more so, food regulations for children must take into account the highest degree of special safety standards, because any escape can cause tragedies that are hard to imagine. In this respect, it is necessary to label as detailed as possible baby foods marketed at European level in order to avoid the use of certain substances by infants and young children. It also requires a more rigorous control of the level of sugars consumed by infants and young children, which can lead to obesity. A zero tolerance is required for the presence of pesticides in foodstuffs.  All food safety decisions must be taken in a transparent manner to enable all interested parties to participate in the decision-making process. In order to support these wishes and to improve the Commission's delegated regulation in this area, it is necessary to adopt the current resolution.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for this text. I am against all derogations from the zero-tolerance principle for pesticides, which should be explicitly cited in Schedule III, which should be regularly updated with ever stricter maximum residue limits, in light of new scientific evidence demonstrating the health effects of active substances and their metabolites.  I also voted in favour of Amendment 2, which enshrines the precautionary principle on GMOs.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed the objection raised by the Greens/EFA group on the draft delegated act by the Commission on the specific compositional and information requirements for processed cereal-based food and baby food. According to Regulation No 609/2013 on Foods for Specific Groups, the Commission is responsible for drafting specific compositional and information requirements for processed cereal-based food and baby food. Current compositional requirements are about 20 years old and were agreed based on studies dating back to 1989-1990. The Commission draft, which is opposed by this objection, complies with the most recent relevant Codex Alimentarius standards from 2006. Although some of the findings may be outdated it is already a considerable improvement on the current situation and I find it regrettable that its entry into force will be delayed until a new study is published.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against objecting to the delegated act on specific requirements for ingredients and information for processed foods based on cereals and baby food, as I consider the rejection of the Commission's proposal to be too harsh a reaction. While I agree with the rapporteur in some parts, for example in the part stating that the intake of sugar into the general population should be reduced, the Commission has committed to considering the final level of sugar ingredients in 2016, i.e. after the European Food Safety Agency publishes its opinion on the topic. I understand that current levels appear high, but I do not think it is necessary to reject this act altogether and I support the Commission's commitment to amend the levels of added sugars once it has completed the full data.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution opposing the delegated act on specific compositional requirements and information for processed cereal-based foods and baby foods because infants and young children are a group of residents who are particularly susceptible to dietary supplements.  Childhood obesity is a serious problem facing too many children. It is intolerable that by over-advertising and setting too low standards, we encourage the consumption of foods that are harmful to health in the long term. This is particularly unacceptable when it comes to infant nutrition. Especially in children, we need to be careful, because we must be aware that poor nutrition is by far the most common cause of disease and death worldwide in this day and age.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The objection relates to a delegated act that is intended to regulate the composition and information of baby food from 4 months of age. The rapporteur stresses the importance of breastfeeding, which is certainly desirable but not always possible. It also calls for a review of the maximum allowed sugar level and a total ban on glyphosate. The return of this text will not necessarily produce the desired effects, it will only delay progress, including certain information on packaging. In addition, EFSA is due to produce two 2016 notices on the composition and pesticides allowed. These notices will result in revisions to this delegated act. You should know that so-called "baby-food" products are the most standardized and controlled products. It is almost certain that a well-meaning mother who does not want to buy specialty products exposes her child to more pesticides (multiplied by 10 in breast milk for example or uncontrolled on fresh products) than with so-called industrial products that are highly standardized. The industrialists are already ready to apply it and this text will not harm babies more than at present, on the contrary.  I therefore vote against this objection.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has not submitted a report to Parliament and the Council on the feeding of young children, as required by Regulation (EU) No 609/2013, which is a necessary condition for national strategies to reduce childhood obesity. Currently, inadequate nutrition is by far the most important cause of disease and death worldwide. The WHO recommends that infants be fed exclusively breast milk for the first six months of their life and that breast milk be supplemented from the age of six months with a variety of appropriate, safe and nutrient-rich supplements, but not salt and sugars in complementary foods. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to reject draft EU rules on baby food, which would have allowed baby foods to contain far higher levels of sugar than those recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO). I voted to put the health of babies and children first. The health risks associated with excessive sugar consumption are now widely accepted. The role of the Regulation should be to try and address this risk, particularly for infants and children, who are the most vulnerable consumers.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection because the EP must stop a delegated act with which the European Commission intends to undermine the nutritional and transparency and information requirements of processed foods based on cereals and children's foods, for example by allowing a rate of up to 30% sugars in infant food, thus contradicting WHO's opinions. In addition, I am firmly against the Commission trying to adopt such measures through delegated acts, thus trying to avoid the European Parliament.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ On this I voted to call on the Commission to rethink its strategy for lax limits on sugar. Childhood obesity levels are far too high across Europe and we need to tackle this problem at source. Too high levels of sugar in children’s food. Anything less is simply treating the symptom rather than the underlying cause. We cannot allow our children to be pumped full of sugar, and the best way to do this is to ensure that companies lower the level of sugar in children’s food. The Commission must put the future of our children first and foremost, full stop.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This resolution opposes a draft Commission act extending the authorisation of sugar levels three times higher than the World Health Organization's recommendations for infant and young children's foods. Although I do not share all the analyses of this resolution, the most important thing seems to me to be to continue with the idea of the precautionary principle and to do everything possible to protect young children and infants.  The introduction of over-sweet foods particularly affects the development of young children and contributes to the rise of childhood obesity, including by influencing their taste in the short and long term. This is an increasingly alarming public health problem.  In addition, in line with international health agency recommendations, zero tolerance for pesticides in these food products must prevail.  For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution opposing the Commission's draft act and I welcome the adoption of it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 It is considered, in the resolution, that the measures of the Delegated Regulation are not sufficient to protect infants and babies against childhood obesity. The rules proposed by this delegated act turn these products into potential Trojan horses to introduce sugar quantities above those recommended by the World Health Organisation for babies over 6 months.  In the delegated act concerned, the Commission proposes that 30% of the energy contained in the food comes from sugars, when the WHO recommends a maximum of 10%, with 5% being ideal. In addition, and in the case of a consumer-targeted food with the most vulnerable endocrine system (infants and young children), the zero tolerance principle for pesticides is asked to be applied. The European Commission has not yet submitted the long-awaited report on baby milk and Regulation (EU) No 609/2013 was adopted before the European Food Safety Authority published its scientific opinion on the basic composition of infant formulae and follow-on formulae of 5 August 2014.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Infant and child protection in the food sector is a very important issue. Parents need to be able to transparently identify the ingredients of the food and trust in the products. The ban on GMOs and nanotechnology in cereal sedan foods is very welcome. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the EUROPEAN Parliament resolution on 'Objections to the delegated act with regard to the specific composition and information requirements for cereal sedentary and other foods'. While my group shares the concerns of many stakeholders about sugar consumption, I nevertheless welcome the legislation, I believe that the concerns raised are convincing. The limit values proposed by the Commission do not go far enough. I think it is a mistake to adopt the legislation first and to hope that the Commission will revise it in a timely manner. It is better to reject bad proposals from the Commission immediately and to demand immediate rectification. This is particularly true in the light of the fact that Parliament's powers of control are not particularly strong in the case of secondary legislation. That is why Parliament should proactively exercise its rights here and not let the Commission go through with trivialities.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: writing – As a doctor, I have always stressed the great importance of breastfeeding, a balanced diet and a healthy lifestyle. EU food safety legislation is already very detailed and sets very high standards and clear requirements for food labelling, which is all for the benefit of the consumer. In order to enable consumers to make informed choices, European legislation lays down rules on information on product labels, forcing food manufacturers to indicate in particular the use-by date, safety warnings, nutritional properties and recycling details. Scientists and doctors agree that breast milk is the best diet for all healthy infants, as it provides a sufficient supply of all nutrients to support their growth and development. The composition of breast milk continuously changes, while the composition of infant formula remains stable over time, and therefore infant formula can not actually replace breast milk. Each food product for children must be nutritionally balanced and take into account a gradually diversifying dietary regime.  The general scientific opinion is that nutrients and dietary supplements should be added to baby food only if they are necessary from a nutritional point of view or development.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ the objection we voted on concerned the composition of processed cereal-based foods and baby foods and opposed the Delegated Act of the European Commission, in particular the permitted sugar content of children's foods. This exceeded several times the amount of sugar recommended by the World Health Organisation. I believe that, in the current upward trend in childhood obesity, there is no need for children's energy intake to increase even in such an unnecessary way, and therefore to consciously go against the health of the next generation. I also agreed to add an article on precautionary observance of new technologies, which include, for example, GMOs and nanotechnologies. In all these cases, as there is not yet sufficient evidence of their impact on human health, I believe that, at least in foods intended for young children, they should be banned.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
