text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the objection to the delegated act on the specific composition and information requirements for processed cereal-based foods and baby foods as the European Commission has not submitted to the European Parliament and the Council the report on formulas for young children, regulation (EU) No 609/2013 (Article 12), which is a requirement for the adoption of national strategies aimed at reducing childhood obesity. In addition, the delegated regulation allows 30 % of the energy of baby food to be obtained from sugar, which is contrary to all the health recommendations of the World Health Organisation and the scientific committees of the Member States, which advise significant reductions in total sugar consumption, which could contribute to increased levels of childhood obesity and which may affect the development of children's food preferences in the long term.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The main objection to this delegated act concerns how the industry advertises and places products on the market with processed cereal-based foods and baby foods. The measures of the Delegated Regulation are considered not sufficient to protect infants and babies from childhood obesity. The rules proposed by this delegated act turn these products into potential Trojan horses to introduce sugar quantities above those recommended by the World Health Organisation for babies over 6 months. In the case of foods targeted at consumers with the most vulnerable endocrine system (infants and young children), the principle of zero tolerance for pesticides is justifiably asked to apply.  There are a number of criticisms of the European Commission, which we endorse. We voted for it.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. The WHO recommends limiting sugar intake to less than 10% of total energy consumption, making it clear that sticking to the 5% limit would offer greater guarantees of preventing the onset of certain diseases. According to the European Commission's proposal, however, sugars could continue to account for up to 30% of the caloric intake of baby foods, which is three times more than recommended. The introduction of these high levels of sugar into food, especially at such an early age, would have contributed to the increase in childhood obesity and could affect children's food preferences. In particular, according to who's recommendations, for infants and young children, the levels of added sugar should be kept to a minimum. Given that, to date, poor nutrition is by far the leading cause of disease and death worldwide, even more so than smoking, alcohol and physical inactivity taken together, I find the Commission's proposal disconcerting. I therefore voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I am convinced that the maximum permitted sugar level in food must be brought into line with the who requirements.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ i did not support the proposed resolution because I believe that the existing provisions of Regulation (EU) No 609/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council on specific compositional requirements and information in food based on processed cereals and baby food properly pursue health principles and standards and establish an effective health protection framework.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I supported this resolution. I took the liberty of coming out because we usually debate here how human rights are trampled on in the world, where and in what form armed conflicts or civil wars take place. Here is, in principle, a positive exception, when we adopted a resolution welcoming the peace process in Colombia itself. That is why I was happy to adopt this resolution, because it is indeed true that, after 50 years of hard civil war in this Latin American country, Colombia, there is finally a clear concrete hope that the conflict will end and that there will be a ceasefire between the government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces. The whole agreement, which has been in the works for more than four years, I think, has a rational subtext, and if ratification is completed later this year, I think that peace can finally prevail in Colombia.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent It must be said that colombia's civil war is one of the longest-standing conflicts in the modern world, in modern history, with hundreds of thousands of victims, millions of internally displaced persons and several kidnappers. I had the opportunity last year to meet the President of Colombia as part of the meeting of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, and it is clear that the fact that the peace process is gradually evolving and that a very good result has recently been achieved - Article 5 of the General Agreement, precisely for the victims, who are also at the centre of the settlement- is a very important and positive step in this direction. The difficulties faced by the parties involved, both the parties to the conflict and the intermediaries, cannot be unmarked. The intermediaries, as we know, are Cuba, Norway, Chile, Venezuela, and also the Vatican. The intermediaries have done a great deal of work, but clearly this work still needs to be continued and much remains to be done, and it is very good that we have taken another step in this direction today as the European Parliament.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because I believe that the ongoing peace process in Colombia between the Government of Colombia and the FARC guerrillas is historical in nature and could indeed end fifty years of internal armed conflict, during which the Colombian people have suffered enormous suffering , with negative effects also sensitive in neighbouring countries. The end of this conflict and the advent of peace will have a positive impact not only on Colombia but on the region as a whole. The agreements reached to date are also innovative in the transitional justice institutions they create and the role given to victims and to the principles of reparation, truth, justice and non-repetition of conflict. This is a complex bet for a country like Colombia, which needs international support to successfully complete the process.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on the Colombia Peace Process because, all though we are fully supportive of the peace talks and hope that a peaceful settlement can be reached, we do not believe that the EU should be taking positions, or interfering, in such matters.
politicalGroup: The Earl of) Dartmouth Mike Hookem Diane James Margot Parker and Julia Reid (EFDD
partyIdeology: The Earl of) Dartmouth Mike Hookem Diane James Margot Parker and Julia Reid (EFDD

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour even though the resolution on the peace process in Colombia adopted by this Parliament does not concern the root causes of the armed conflict that has plagued the Andean country for decades. From the European United Left we wanted to live up to what is required and to send an unequivocal and explicit signal of full support for the peace process at a time when an agreement is near, after three years of negotiations between the Government of Colombia and the FARC guerrillas in Havana. To come to fruition, this process must be based on truth, justice, reparation and guarantee of non-repetition, restitution of land, access to political participation or agreement on victims. For me, however, the sine qua non condition is the dismantling of paramilitary groups in the service of Colombian elites and extractive multinationals, some of them European. The Government must assume its responsibility to protect its people and, in particular, activists from social, political and trade unionist movements, who remain threatened or even killed.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that we are faced with a historic event, that of the conclusion of an agreement between the Government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia on transitional justice, an agreement that will be a decisive step towards achieving a definitive peace and will put an end to this long-running armed conflict in Latin America. The European Union must not let this historic moment go to waste and is therefore called upon to support in every way the talks that will put an end to 50 years of armed conflict.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The peace process in Colombia is a useful step in supporting, but the Union can only interfere with the States directly concerned and the United Nations, whose role in the restoration and maintenance of peace has its place here.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Most such reports coming before the European Parliament adopt language which make it difficult for me to support as someone who opposes British membership of the European Union.  However, the text of this report was different.  It recognised the problems in Colombia and supported the peace process.  It promoted action by individual Member States, not by the European Commission.  It did not propose further European Union funding.  Consequently, I was delighted to be able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the ongoing peace process in Colombia between the Government of colombia and the FARC guerrillas is historical in nature and could indeed end fifty years of internal armed conflict, during which the Colombian people have experienced enormous suffering , with negative effects also sensitive in neighbouring countries. The end of this conflict and the advent of peace will have a positive impact not only on Colombia, but on the region as a whole.  The agreements reached to date are also innovative in the transitional justice institutions they create and the role given to victims and to the principles of reparation, truth, justice and non-repetition of conflict. This is a complex bet for a country like Colombia, which needs international support to successfully complete.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on the implementation of the Colombian peace process and the final peace agreement. I agree with the need for the Member States of the European Union to set up a trust fund, which is supported after the conflict and which can involve community and civil society organisations, and that the priorities identified by the victims – truth, justice, redress and guarantees that the conflict will not recur – are taken into account. Both the Colombian government and the FARC have made political efforts to unify their opposing views by gradually creating a compromise-friendly environment that allows for a strong and lasting peace. It is also essential that, in order to achieve peace, the fight against inequality and poverty is taken decisively, while addressing fairly the problems of displaced persons and communities displaced from their homes, access to decent work, recognition of labour and social rights throughout Colombia. A positive aspect is that colombia's military doctrine will be reviewed in order to respond effectively and quickly to the new post-conflict challenges.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved the joint resolution, which welcomes the agreements reached between the Colombian government and the FARC for peace. Parliament underlines the sustained efforts of the various actors involved and the importance of agreements on comprehensive rural reform, political participation and democratic openness to build peace and the solution to the problem of illicit drugs.  Parliament wants the negotiations to be concluded as soon as possible to end the violence and achieve lasting peace in a country that has been affected by violence for too long.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Colombia has been torn apart by a terrible civil war for more than fifty years, pitting the national government and several guerrilla groups against each other; Among them are the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC). Since 2012, exploratory dialogues have been launched in Havana that have led the Government of Colombia and the FARC to conclude, in September 2015, an agreement to create a special jurisdiction for peace. In recent years, the Union has promoted a path of economic and political cooperation with the American country, making concrete efforts to promote a cessation of hostilities. I supported the resolution on the peace process in Colombia because I believe that we must continue to support this path, including by negotiating with the National Liberation Army, another guerrilla group involved in the conflict. The end of the years of violence, murder and disappearances of civilians can only be achieved with the commitment of the whole of Colombian society supported by the international community. The paths of respect for human rights, the fight against inequality and poverty will open Colombia to a peaceful future.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Final Joint Resolution on the Peace Process in Colombia because, although it does not delve into the root causes of the conflict, it does rescue many positive elements, such as the inclusion of paramilitaries in its definition of terrorist actions, and the reference to the importance of the participation of victims, NGOs and civil society in the peace process. It also includes an appeal to the Government (remembering its responsibility) to provide protection to trade unionists and human rights defenders. In short, it is a resolution that supports the whole Colombian people in their objectives for achieving peace.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this resolution on the peace process in Colombia. Of course, I am in favour of any multilateral dialogue and/or action that could lead to a peaceful settlement to the internal armed conflict in Colombia, which has lasted for more than fifty years and has caused great suffering to the population, whether through terrorist acts or the actions of paramilitary groups. However, the European Union is not intended to replace sovereign states, or even the United Nations, when it comes to processes relating to the regal rights of sovereign nations for the former or the peacekeeping mission for the latter. However, as the resolution reminds us, "the Colombian government, its legislature and the Colombian people are sovereign in setting the parameters of this special court for peace", and there is therefore no reason for the EU to interfere in such a process, whatever the good intentions behind it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I think it is crucial that the EU supports the stabilisation process in Colombia in order to bring the socio-political situation back to normal, so I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution on support for the peace process in Colombia. The end of this internal conflict, which has lasted more than 50 years and demanded millions of victims and the safeguarding of strong and lasting peace in Colombia, is not only a priority for this country, but also for the European Union and the international community, as evidenced by the statements made by many different countries, regional and international organisations, including the European Union itself, in support of the peace process. The European Parliament welcomes and supports the agreements reached so far between the Colombian Government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia aimed at peace in Colombia, and notes the agreements on comprehensive rural reform, political activism and openness to democracy with a view to achieving peace, as well as agreements on the resolution of the problem of illicit drugs and the establishment of a Special Peace Court, which includes the establishment of the Truth, Co-existence and the Conflict Prevention Commission and the Special Unit responsible for the search for missing persons during or for the conflict and the establishment of an investigation and disassembly unit of criminal groups. Parliament expresses its wish for the negotiations to end as soon as possible and to bring the conflict to an end as soon as possible and to finalise the conflict and to be recorded as a real achievement in modern Colombian history, and to this end calls on all parties, all political forces in Colombia and colombian society as a whole to make a positive contribution to ending the violence.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. Colombia appears to be a long way off, but the internal armed conflict that has been going on there for more than 50 years and its closure could also provide lessons for closer regions. The actions carried out by the opposing parties have caused enormous suffering to the population. Ending the conflict and achieving a solid and lasting peace in Colombia is essential not only for Colombia, but also for the European Union and the international community, as indicated by the numerous declarations by various countries and regional and international organisations, including the European Union, in support of the peace process. I therefore welcome the start of the process and monitor its implementation.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 In September and December 2015, the Colombian government and the FARC announced the conclusion of two agreements concerning an ad hoc jurisdiction for the construction of a stable and lasting peace in the country. The recognition of victims' rights, the inclusion of civil society and NGOs in the conclusion of agreements are particularly important elements in this context, which bode well for future developments towards a genuine and participatory democratic transition. The European Union warmly welcomes the political and cultural openness of the FARC on the one hand and the perseverance and efforts shown by the Colombian Government on the other, reaffirming its willingness to assist the country in the implementation of the agreements or in the delicate post-conflict phase, a commitment also called for in parliament's resolution that I support.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I support this Statement on the Peace Process in Colombia, which calls for the creation of a bilateral agreement and a final ceasefire as a precondition for creating a complete and lasting peace. I believe that the European Parliament must take a coherent and well-coordinated response in this situation, which will help further increase support for further negotiations and the creation of agreements.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the success of the peace process in Colombia represents an important objective in many respects and that it is the task of the entire international community, and therefore also of the European Union, to support this process to resolve this guerrilla situation that has lasted for almost 30 years.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The peace process that the FARC and the Government of Colombia have undertaken after fifty years of violent clashes that have caused great suffering to the population, both as a result of terrorist attacks and the actions of paramilitary groups, which has led, among other things, to murders, enforced disappearances, kidnappings, sexual violence, child abuse, internal and external displacement of the population, the outbreak of anti-personnel mines and over 200 thousand victims of violent death of various kinds in Colombia alone. , is to be supported with all the political and diplomatic resources that the Union and its Member States can put in place, as it is fundamental not only for the pacification of the Republic of Colombia but also for the stabilisation of the area and the weakening of international drug trafficking that has flourished in the situation of constant civil war that has characterised Colombia's history since the post-war period. We hope that the peace process will proceed quickly, with the cooperation of the international community, so that we can quickly implement the reforms that the Colombian people need and open a new – and better – page in the history of modern Colombia.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The political and cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Andean Community has also resulted in this welcome resolution on encouraging the stabilisation of peace in Colombia. Maintaining stability is a complex process, to be worked on on several levels, from solving the problems of illegal armed groups and drug trafficking to transitional justice, then alternative and rural development and, of course, demobilisation and reintegration of former combatants, including through psychosocial programmes for child soldiers and female combatants who have suffered sexual abuse. All forms of suffering caused by such conflicts must be condemned and it is important to take into account in particular the right of the victims of the conflict to full, genuine and fair reparations for the physical, moral and material damage suffered. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the European Union must fully and fully support the implementation of the peace agreement and the efforts made by the Colombian Government and the FARC to reach the agreements signed so far on political participation and democratic openness, thereby providing a positive example of a conflict resolution process.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. Confused context but with prospects for stabilising the conflict situation and trying to restore balance and peace between the opposing factions in the Colombian national context.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The peace process between the Colombian government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) is finally moving forward. The two opposing forces were able to reach realistic agreements on issues that divided them, such as rural reform, the management of illicit drug trafficking and the creation of a peace court.  However, much more needs to be done. The European Union is Colombia's political, economic and trade partner. She hopes that this conflict, which has lasted for more than fifty years and which has claimed many victims in the Colombian population, will stop. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Peace Process in Colombia. After more than three years of ongoing negotiations in Havana, the country is heading, in steps now dispatched, towards the signing of the agreement between the government and the main guerrilla group, the FARC. In order to achieve this very important result, the commitment of the Colombian Church and the Holy See have been crucial. But we should also remember the intervention of the European Union, which, with its constant support for the negotiations, helped to find a global agreement quickly that would open the way to an armistice and put an end to half a century of suffering in Colombia. The path, even if it is still uphill, does not seem impossible. Now, even with Europe's contribution, every effort must be made to reach a peace agreement, which represents a concrete hope in the international scenario torn apart by the 'Third World War in pieces'.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. Colombia has been experiencing an endemic crisis since the mid-1960s, Colombian civil society, as well as human rights defenders, are threatened by the guerrilla state that is continuing in the country. On 20 December, the FARC unilaterally declared a cease-fire after 3 of the 6 items on the agenda saw an agreement with the Government. Alarming issues, as Amnesty denounces in its 2014/15 report, are the impunity guaranteed to paramilitaries who have laid down their arms, as well as the extrajudicial executions of the armed forces. The guerrilla state clearly violates the rights of large sections of the population. I voted in favour of the resolution because it supports the peace process that began in Havana, calling on the EU and, above all, the Member States and donors to guarantee the promised financial support. It stimulates involvement in the peace process and its operational developments of civil society and its organisations. It calls for specific support for ethnic communities and for the fight against and sanctioning drug trafficking, but, above all, welcomes the fact that the parties have agreed that there will be no amnesty for the most serious crimes.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the motion for a resolution and hope that the negotiations will be concluded as soon as possible so that the final peace agreement can begin to take effect. The motion for a resolution welcomes the historic agreements reached so far by the Colombian Government.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to support the measure. On 23 September 2015, the Government of Colombia and the FARC announced the conclusion of an agreement on the creation of a special peace jurisdiction under international law that satisfies the rights of victims and contributes to the construction of a stable and lasting peace. Parliament welcomed the agreement and acknowledged the political effort, realism and perseverance shown by both the Government of Colombia and the FARC in bringing their divergent positions closer together, progressively creating an area of commitment which enabled progress to be made towards a stable and lasting peace. It also stresses the importance of ensuring that peace-building also involves a firm commitment to the fight against inequalities and poverty.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the spirit of conciliation and overcoming the conflict in it must animate any efforts of the international community in the face of this kind of issue. I also believe that the text of the resolution tabled and strongly desired by the PPE is balanced as is appropriate when it comes to the affairs of another State, while respecting the principles of which my political group is the bearer.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the European Union, which is based on essential principles such as peace and democracy, should support the peace process in Colombia. Fifty years have already passed since the outbreak of the conflict with the loss of thousands of lives.  I therefore welcome the willingness shown by the Colombian Head of State and the FARC to put an end to this war and to have reached agreement on the judicial consequences of the war, and I also welcome the signing of the peace agreement.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The parliamentary resolution focuses on the recent political developments in Colombia vis-a-vis the Peace negotiations between the Government and Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia following the internal armed conflict in the country. The resolution condemns the various murders, disappearances enforced, kidnappings, sexual violence and child abuse that has occurred within the country and calls for more efforts to reach peace and stability in the region. While reinstating the EU and Colombia’s solid political framework of economic and trade cooperation, the resolution speaks about the responsibility of the Colombian state to promote human rights within its territory and the necessity for the state to ensure equitable economic and social development as a prelude for peace. For this reason I voted in favour of this resolution

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Through my vote, I wished to support peace-building efforts between the Colombian government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC). The establishment of a trust fund will finance the establishment of a post-conflict justice system and reparations to end impunity.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. It is true that it is not appropriate to oppose a peace process, which, on the face of it, is in the direction of the common good. On the other hand, the question is whether the European Union is in danger of parasitizing States in their regal functions, as well as the United Nations in its primary role of peacekeeping and post-conflict process management. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 This peace process in Colombia has already taken quite a long time and I think it should now be addressed. I hope that once the Un starts monitoring him, it will be over. I really hope that the victims will be indemnity, although this is unlikely to dull their pain. Finding those who have disappeared during the conflict is also one step in the right direction. I really doubt that the guerrillas and their leaders, who are responsible for many murders, will get what they deserve, but I can hardly say who deserves punishment in a country that is openly supported by the spread of cocaine. However, I hope that the peace process in Colombia will come to a resolution and a cessation of hostilities. This will put out another point on the map where military action is taking place, and again this will be with the help of the EU.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against this motion for a resolution, as it is another intervention in the internal affairs of a third State. No one has appointed the Union as a global monitor to require independent states to comply with the laws it lays down. The European Union must not interfere in the internal affairs of countries, especially in matters relating to peace and security.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The end of this internal conflict, which for more than 50 years has claimed millions of victims, and the achievement of a stable and lasting peace in Colombia are a priority, first ly for the country, but also for the European Union and the international community. The EU and Colombia have established a framework of close political, economic and trade cooperation not only to strengthen economic and trade relations between the parties, but also to strengthen peace, democracy, respect for human rights, sustainable development and the well-being of citizens. It is important that the negotiations are concluded as soon as possible in order to determine the definitive end of the conflict which will constitute a real milestone in Colombia's modern history, and that both sides, all the political forces of Colombia and the whole of Colombian society make a positive contribution to ending the violence.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 We support a resolution that contained very positive elements regarding the Peace Process in Colombia. We highlight: - The explanation of the true nature of the conflict, dismantling some current mystifications; - The defence of peace through a bilateral ceasefire, the renunciation of the use of violence and reconciliation; - The call for the extension of the process to the ELN (not a tripartite negotiation, but that the government can proceed with a parallel process); - The continuation of policies that promote equality and development, especially agrarian reform; - The end of policies to pursue left-wing groups and forces and trade unions; - the establishment of truth commissions and support for victims of war, forgiveness and amnesty for political crimes, but not in the case of genocide and crimes against humanity, with the participation of victims and NGOs; - The rejection of the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Treaty. This joint resolution, signed by various political groups, loses some important references and sees others added in a legalistic, conservative and Euro-centered logic. However, the resolution does not change what seems essential to us in this process – supporting the peace process and negotiating between equals, without officially stigmatizing the FARC, allowing for political and economic rights that were claimed decades ago.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ The peace process in Colombia cannot go unnoticed by the European Union, as this is a historic moment that deserves full recognition from the European Union and its representatives. We must, by all means available, support peace talks that will dot 50 years of armed conflict. After more than a year and a half of negotiations, the Colombian Government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia have reached a landmark agreement on the transitional judiciary, representing a huge step forward and an effort to bring peace and end the long-running armed conflict in Latin America. Both sides in the conflict have agreed to conclude a final peace agreement by March 23, 2016 at the latest. This resolution therefore clearly declares the European Parliament's political support for the peace process, especially at its initial implementation stage.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this motion for a resolution because it is another interference in the internal affairs of a third State. No one has appointed the Union as a global monitor to require independent states to comply with the laws it lays down. The European Union must not interfere in the internal affairs of countries, especially in matters relating to peace and security.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ After more than one year and a half of negotiations, the Colombian Government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia have finally reached a ground-breaking agreement on transitional justice, which is a definitive step forward to a conclusive peace in the long-lasting armed conflict in Latin America. The transitional justice agreement has resolved some of the most serious sticking points and makes any derailment of the peace process highly unlikely. I strongly support the call for a bilateral and definitive ceasefire agreement and for starting a similar process with the ELN (National Liberation Army) guerrillas in order to have a complete and lasting peace in Colombia. The EU cannot let this historic moment get away. We must give full support to the talks that will put an end to 50 years of armed conflict.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, because it is a new sign of the European Parliament's support for the peace process in Colombia. The resolution stresses that this is a unique agreement that, for the first time in history, focuses on victims, ensuring justice without impunity and reparation for the damage suffered.  Furthermore, the resolution recalls that this is the first time that a subcommittee on gender has been established to ensure that the gender dimension is integrated into the negotiations.  Finally, it is important to support this peace process, especially in the context of strengthening our partnership, with the conclusion of a visa-free agreement at the moment.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of supporting the peace process in Colombia convinced that it can bring peace, reconciliation and progress. We must support the conclusion of the negotiations as soon as possible and offer EU assistance in reaching the implementation of the final peace agreement. The parties involved in the peace process have promoted a historic agreement whose main achievements include the recognition of victims, the promotion of justice without impunity and the true reparation of harm.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 After 51 years of civil war, the peace agreement reached by the Colombian government represents an historic milestone. I particularly welcome the inclusion in the agreement of a clause on the creation of a committee for the clarification of the truth, for coexistence and non-repetition, as well as the measures provided for the reparation of victims.  At this crucial moment, it is essential for Europe to prove to be a peacekeeping force that will ensure that an agreement that brings peace and justice to the Colombian people is concluded and implemented effectively.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution, tabled pursuant to Article 123 of the Regulation, on support for the peace process in Colombia.  The internal civil conflict which has been going on in the South American country for about fifty years has caused enormous suffering to the population; I therefore believe that the time has come to guarantee the country the opportunity to achieve a stable and lasting peace and to turn a page on a dramatic history of brutal murders, kidnappings, rapes, disappearances and all kinds of abuse of civilians.  In this direction, therefore, the agreement of last December 2015 between the Colombian Government and the FARC is positive, the result of a rare realism and political perseverance that will perhaps succeed in bringing together two positions that have hitherto been irreconcilable, to put an end to the violence and to give justice to the countless victims. Finally, I would like to stress the importance of combining the peace process with a strong commitment to the fight against poverty and social inequalities and strong support for employment and the protection of human rights, as well as decisive action to find a solution to the problem of drug trafficking.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the resolution on the peace process in Colombia. This country has been suffering from the bloody civil war for decades – and it should not only be europe's stated goal to help bring about and maintain a stable peace here. In the current world political situation, we can be happy to be at every place in the world where we can help to ensure stability and peace. In Colombia, the chances are good – thank God!

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Colombian peace process, and call on  EU Member States to set up a trust fund to support the post-conflict phase, inter alia by funding the prosecution of war criminals and help for their victims to seek truth, justice, reparations and guarantees of non-repetition. It is vital that the peace process is accompanied by a determined effort to combat inequality and poverty, including fair solutions for people and communities forced off their lands.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because Europe must reaffirm and strengthen its support for the path of national peace launched in 2012 with the FARC. It is a fundamental step towards improving the human rights situation and the economic and civil development of the country.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Colombian Government's peace talks with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia are extremely important to achieve stability in the country. I support the efforts of both parties to reach an agreement and hope that the planned date of signature of the final document on, inter alia, transitional justice will not change. The colombian government's and the FARC's compromise on compensation for victims of armed conflict is also commendable.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 It is our firm position that conflicts must be resolved in a peaceful manner and that everyone's efforts must move in this direction. We supported the joint resolution because we believe that today there is an important effort being made between the Colombian Government and the FARC to bring peace to the region. The Agreement of 19 January in Havana is another important step in the whole process of reaching a final peace agreement in Colombia.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I was very pleased to support the resolution supporting the Colombian Peace Process following the conclusion of negotiations between the Colombian Government and the FARC in 2015. The internal armed conflict has for over 50 years caused untold suffering to its people and given rise to atrocities such as assassinations, enforced disappearances, kidnappings, sexual violence, population displacements and the scourge of anti-personnel mines.  The General Agreement for the termination of the conflict establishes a five-point agenda covering integral agricultural development policy, political participation, a solution to the problem of illicit drugs and victims reparation and justice, finally clearing the way for the end of the conflict by 23 March 2016.  I particularly welcome the resolution’s call for the peace process to be accompanied by a determined effort to combat inequality and poverty, including finding fair solutions for people and communities forced off their lands, and providing Colombia’s people with access to decent work and ensuring recognition of their social and labour rights as well as welcoming the establishment of a Subcommittee on Gender to ensure gender mainstreaming in negotiations and the participation of victims of sexual violence and women’s rights organisations in the peace talks.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as putting an end to this internal conflict, which has raged for 50 years, leaving millions of victims, and securing a stable and lasting peace in Colombia are a first priority both for that country and the European Union and the international community, as demonstrated by the many statements made in support of the peace process by various countries and regional and international bodies , including the European Union. It reiterates the readiness to provide all possible assistance to support the implementation of the final peace agreement, and renews its call on European Union Member States to create a trust fund to accompany the post-conflict phase, in which communities and civil society organisations are invited to participate, and to take due account of the priorities expressed by the victims in terms of truth , justice, reparations and guarantees of non-repetition. The report also stresses how important it is for the peace process to be accompanied by a determined effort to combat inequality and poverty, including by finding fair solutions for people and communities forced off their lands, and providing all of Colombia’s people with access to decent work and ensuring recognition of their social and labour rights.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ During the peace talks that began in November 2012, the Colombian government and the FARC have agreed on four topics (land reform, political participation of rebels, drug trafficking and transitional justice). The motion for a resolution addresses the transitional justice deal, which states that prisoners who own up to their crimes will not go to prison but face ‘alternative forms’ of punishment, making the incarceration of guerrilla leaders unlikely. Given the crucial importance of these peace talks and the need for a balanced deal, I have voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a European Parliament resolution to support the peace process in Colombia, as the EU as an active "player" in creating a more stable world environment based on democratic values, must play an active role in creating peace, stability and prosperity in a country that has been plagued by internal armed conflict for more than 50 years. In this regard, all activities of both government institutions and the FARC and external countries involved in ending conflicts and creating conditions for lasting peace, the democratic environment, the fight against poverty and the application of generally accepted international rules sanctioning the most serious crimes are supported. I support the call on the Member States of the European Union to establish a trust fund for the period following the end of the conflict.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. We can only welcome the peace process in Colombia. However, in this case the Union can only parasitize the States directly concerned as well as the United Nations, whose role in the restoration and maintenance of peace has its place here. I voted against it.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution reaffirms that peace in Colombia is a priority for the EU. Full implementation of the peace agreement will be the real challenge. The creation of an EU Trust Fund to  support the post-conflict phase is a concrete way for the EU to be with Colombia all the way towards sustainable peace. This fund will help victims of the recently-ended 50-year internal conflict to seek truth, justice, reparations and prosecute war criminals. I believe this is an important step for Latin America and I hope it will encourage other countries to follow the same positive path.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the peace process in Colombia. The various parliamentary groups of the European Parliament believe that the European Union should promote the peace process that is taking place in Colombia between the government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC). Both sides must continue their efforts to reach a resolution of the conflict between them. At the same time, it is necessary to prosecute war criminals and provide reparations for victims. This resolution has been adopted, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of the joint resolution. I am particularly concerned about supporting the peace process in Colombia in the face of many civilian casualties, and the EU should do everything in its power to move this process forward!

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as it welcomes the agreement between the government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC), and calls on the National Liberation Army (ELN) to commit to peace and to enter into similar negotiations. This agreement deserves the support of the European Parliament, because we are probably witnessing the end of more than 50 years of violence in Colombia.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution because the ongoing Colombian peace process represents to us a historic opportunity to end one of the longest and bloodiest internal conflicts on the Earth. Colombia’s decades of civil conflict resulted in the death of more than 6 million people, the displacement of 220 000 people and the disappearance of 45 000 people. These numbers are not only shocking, but also are a warning. In fact, they remind us that we should not miss this opportunity to end violence, drug trafficking, arms trafficking, slavery, terrorism, massive violation of human rights and atrocities committed by both sides. Therefore, the EU should have an active role in the negotiation process in order to guarantee that a final peace deal will be signed. Because Colombia’s problems are not only its responsibility, particularly since they have become regional and global ones.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I abstained on the resolution on the peace process in Colombia, as did the other National Front MPs. Of course, I am never opposed to a peace process, but it must be remembered that the European Union has no place in this matter, except to interfere with the states in their regal functions and the United Nations in its primary role of peacekeeping and the management of post-conflict processes.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I am opposed to the various violence in Colombia, the recruiting of underage soldiers, etc. However, I do not think it is Parliament's role to adopt resolutions on problems everywhere.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The EU supports the agreement reached between the parties to establish a commission on establishing truth, coexistence and non-adoption, as an independent and impartial out-of-court mechanism to jointly draw up a true historical account of what has happened, because a peaceful future and satisfying the rights of all victims can only be based on a true description of the past and taking full responsibility. Since 2013, the EU and Colombia have had close economic and trade relations governed by a trade agreement between Colombia and Peru and the EU and its Member States, whose ultimate goal is not only to strengthen economic ties between the parties concerned, but also to forge partnerships that go beyond trade itself, the same as to contribute to strengthening peace, democracy and the well-being of their citizens. I supported the proposal for a resolution because building lasting and lasting peace in Colombia by ending the internal conflict, which lasts for more than 50 years and has caused millions of casualties, is primarily important for Colombia, but also for the European Union and the international community, as expressed in numerous declarations by various countries and regional and international organisations, including the European Union, supporting the peace process.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ Colombia is currently the country with the second highest number of refugees, a consequence of a long-standing internal conflict between the government and units of left-wing movements. This also affects the surrounding states, especially Venezuela, where most of the refugees have left. In order to eliminate and resolve this conflict, it is necessary for the Union, through all its diplomatic branches, to assist in the peace process and to oversee the investigation of acts, trials and the enforcement of decisions so that they comply with international treaties and conventions on fundamental human rights.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the joint motion for a resolution in favour of the peace process in Colombia for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 19 January 2016 and also because I consider this report to be complete and substantiated.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this Resolution which welcomes the agreements made to date between the Government of Colombia and the FARC to achieve peace in Colombia and highlights the agreements on a comprehensive rural reform, political participation and democratic opening to build peace, solving the problem of illicit drugs and the establishing a Special Jurisdiction for Peace, including a Commission for the Clarification of the Truth , Coexistence and Non-Repetition and the Special Unit for the Search for People considered to have Disappeared in the context of and on account of the conflict, in addition to the Unit for the Investigation and Dismantling of Criminal Organisations.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a motion for a joint resolution that evaluates and welcomes the peace process taking place in Colombia. The internal conflict, which has been going on in Colombia for more than 50 years, has resulted in millions of casualties. In the resolution, we stress that the priority for the EU and the international community as such is, of course, to achieve a stable and lasting peace in Colombia. I welcome, of course, the agreements reached so far between the Colombian Government and the FARC in order to achieve peace in Colombia. In the resolution, we also stress the importance of agreements on comprehensive agrarian reform, political participation and democratisation aimed at peace-building. Another priority must then be to address the problem of illegal drugs and to create special peace courts, which include the creation of a commission on truth, coexistence and non-re-establishment of the past, as well as the creation of a special unit to find people who have been reported missing in connection with or as a result of the conflict. I supported the resolution in the final vote.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I support the Resolution adopted by the European Parliament so that from here we can support the peace process that takes place in Colombia. The progress made by the Colombian Government and all parties involved in the peace process, which have promoted a unique agreement in history that has as its axes the recognition of victims, justice without impunity and the real reparation of the damage suffered are evident. That is why we want the negotiations to culminate as soon as possible and we offer the help of this House for the implementation of the final peace agreement.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Violence is not a political tool and so all efforts to promote the peace process in Colombia sustainably and efficiently must be supported. The report is consistent and takes up specific points that can help to resolve the conflict satisfactorily.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The internal armed conflict in Colombia, which has lasted for more than fifty years, has led to murders, enforced disappearances, abductions, sexual violence, abuse of minors, displacement of populations, etc. Nevertheless, a negotiating table between the Colombian government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) was established in Havana, Cuba, on 19 November 2012, which led to the conclusion on 23 September 2015 of an agreement to establish a special peace court that satisfies the rights of victims and contributes to a stable and lasting peace.  The resolution "welcomes the agreements reached to date between the Colombian government and the FARC for peace in Colombia." The resolution also notes the important role played by Cuba, Chile, Venezuela and Norway. Finally, it stresses the importance of a "genuine effort to combat inequality and poverty" in order to bring about peace. I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The peace process in Colombia is a useful step in supporting, but the Union can only interfere with the States directly concerned and the United Nations, whose role in the restoration and maintenance of peace has its place here. As a result, I abstain.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Colombian peace process.  Peace-building will help to combat inequalities and poverty and the recognition of social and political rights.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of the peace process in Colombia in order to end armed conflict between the Colombian Government and FARC. The resolution also calls on other combatants to commit to the peace process in order to improve the lives of the Colombian people as well as to tackle the flow of illegal drugs which contribute to armed violence across the region.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. It is essential that 2016 marks the end of Colombia's crisis, a crisis that has lasted far too long. After 50 years of uninterrupted armed conflict, a conflict that has claimed more than 220,000 lives, 81.5 per cent of them civilians, and 15,000 missing, it is essential to support the country in the peace process that began in 2012 and to encourage the final signing of an agreement announced in March 2016.  That is why we welcome the adoption of this resolution marking our desire to support Colombia in this peace process with a view to establishing a stable rule of law, based on a judicial system that respects the rights of its citizens. Not only does this text underline the efforts undertaken by the Colombian government and the FARCS, on the one hand, and the international community, on the other, to reach a peace agreement, but it also underlines the need to continue to encourage the negotiation process. Colombia is a partner of the Union to which we owe it to ourselves to provide encouragement, assistance and support.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – The conflict in Colombia has been going on since 1964, which means that generations of Colombians have been affected by it. The whole world has read with relief that the antagonous camps have been able to enter into negotiations to end the unrest and conclude an agreement that includes a promise by both sides that they will try not to repeat the violence. Today, it is no longer the most important to deal with who has caused more damage. It is important to look ahead with a focus on achieving peace and justice. I fully support the efforts of both sides to achieve peace, and I highly commend this initiative. I was also pleased to receive information on the agreement between the Government and the FARC on compensation for victims, the number of which has increased enormously in 50 years of conflict. I call on the parties to continue their efforts to achieve the peace that Colombia so badly needs.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ After more than a year and a half of negotiations, the Colombian Government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) have reached a ground-breaking agreement on transitional justice, which is a definitive step forward to a conclusive peace in the long-running armed conflict in Latin America. The transitional justice agreement has resolved some of the most serious sticking-points and it makes any derailment of the peace process highly unlikely. This resolution will convey the political support of the EP for the peace process, especially in the implementation phase. The EP must present a coherent and well-coordinated response to this historic occasion. Moreover, it will help to create momentum for rising public support in Colombia for the talks. That is why I have voted in favour of this resolution

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Seven political groups, PPE, ECR, ALDE, Verts/ALE, GUE/NGL, S&D and EFDD, submitted draft resolutions on the Colombian peace process. The political groups reached an agreement on the draft, and I voted in favour of the compromise proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. The 50 years of internal conflict in Colombia have caused millions of victims and constant suffering in the Colombian population. I welcome the efforts of the Government and the FARC to achieve peace and the numerous agreements already signed between the parties for the implementation of the definitive peace agreement. I support the assistance of the Union and various civil society entities and I consider it extremely important that the international community, if necessary, monitor and support the post-conflict phase.  I am voting in favour of this Motion for a Resolution, because I believe that the agreements reached will allow a country divided and beset by this armed conflict to now rise up and focus on the creation of a rule of law for people and attentive to improving the living conditions of Colombians.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on support for the peace process in Colombia. This text reminds us that the establishment of peace must be accompanied by a genuine effort to combat inequality and poverty. In particular, it calls for support for the few groups that have suffered disproportionately from conflict, such as Afro-Colombians and indigenous peoples. The framework for cooperation created by the November 2009 Memorandum of Understanding between the European Union and Colombia provides not only for strengthening economic and trade relations between the parties, but also for consolidating peace, democracy, respect for human rights, sustainable development and the well-being of citizens.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on the peace process in Colombia, highlighting the gains made by the various agreements between the Colombian government and the FARC, and reaffirming the Union's support for peace negotiations.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on support for the peace process in Colombia, also taking into account the close political, economic and trade cooperation between the EU and Colombia.  On 23 September 2015, the Government of Colombia and the FARC announced the conclusion of an agreement on the creation of a special peace jurisdiction under international law that satisfies the rights of victims and contributes to the construction of a stable and lasting peace.  Parliament welcomed the agreement and acknowledged the political effort, realism and perseverance shown by both the Government of Colombia and the FARC in bringing their divergent positions closer together, progressively creating an area of commitment which enabled progress to be made towards a stable and lasting peace.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report by vote because I believe that supporting the peace process in favour of the EU's political, economic and trade partners is and will be one of the most important external policies of the European Union. In this respect, today's report presents the current unstable situation in which Colombia finds itself, the measures taken by the Colombian Government to improve it and the importance that Colombia has in relation to the EU. I also welcome the fact that the European states intend to create a trust fund to serve in the post-conflict stage, to which communities and civil society organisations can participate and to take into account the priorities expressed by victims in the area of truth, justice, compensation and guarantees of non-repeat.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Ending the 50-year-long internal armed conflict in Colombia is important for Colombia itself, its neighbours and the EU, and the international community must support Colombia in implementing the recent agreements.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 After decades of conflict, Colombian President Juan Manuel Santos has opened negotiations with the rebel group Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) to discuss a bilateral and final ceasefire as part of the ongoing peace talks. Taking into account the resolutions of the various parliamentary groups on this subject, I would like to welcome the efforts of the parties to achieve a stable and therefore lasting peace. I would also like to express my support for the decision taken by the Colombian Government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) to set up a truth commission to shed light on the bloody conflict.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the results of the peace process in Colombia, which alone can ensure lasting peace after decades of violence and victims. Reconciliation and peace have no alternative. I am convinced that peace will enable a new quality of co-existence in Colombia and help release its rich development potential. I congratulate the political leaders and supporters of the peace process for their achievements. I am thankful to Pope Francis and to spiritual leader Sri Sri Ravi Shankar for contributing in the peace process. They have contributed vitally to the decision of the conflicting parties for a non-violent exercise of political will. Definitely, the signature and full implementation of the agreement will also open a new era of enhanced cooperation, between the EU and Colombia.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Considering that Colombia, after a 50-year war that resulted in millions of casualties, deserved a final end to the conflict and a lasting peace, I welcome the efforts made by the Colombian authorities and the FARC and all conflict actors to start negotiations on breaking up the conflict and building lasting peace. The European Union also contributes to achieving this objective and therefore I have supported this Resolution of the European Parliament on support for the peace process in Colombia. I believe that the European Union must actively support the effort to ensure lasting peace in Colombia, as well as to pay attention to the preservation of the rights of victims and their families. It is precisely the protection of individuals most affected by this devastating conflict that should be one of the foundations on which to build a long-lasting peace in Colombia. I believe that breaking up the conflict and meeting the agreed points will have positive effects on Colombian society. The end of violence and peacebuilding must be accompanied by the fight against poverty, so I am glad that a historic agreement has been reached on a comprehensive agram reform by which the state has committed to giving the country to use and process the poor population. I deeply believe that agriculture is one of the keys to the recovery of the Colombian population, which will eventually contribute to both the prosperity and development of the economy of the whole country.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Of course, I support balanced peace processes in principle, but I deny the European Union the right to interfere in such international issues. It is up to the States concerned and the United Nations to act, certainly not to the Union. So I prefer to abstain.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The negotiations to secure a lasting peace agreement in Colombia are entering a decisive phase and the European Union must support this process with all its might, which aims to put an end to a conflict that has inflicted enormous suffering on the Colombian people for more than fifty years. The agreements reached in Havana between the Colombian Government and the Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces (FARC) are heading in the right direction.  Both sides have shown perseverance and realism in their efforts to affirm the rights of the victims and contribute to the creation of a stable and lasting peace, based on the establishment of the truth, the application of justice and the provision of reparations. Decisive elements, so that the peace process can actually work, are also the agreements signed for a generalized land reform, political participation and democratic openness, to allow all colombian political forces to contribute to the process of pacification, economic and social development of the country.  I consider it very important to set up, for the first time in history, the Gender Subcommittee, which will have the task of ensuring the participation of women in the process of social reconstruction and ensuring that victims of sexual violence receive justice.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the agreement establishing a Specialised Jurisdiction for Peace, which strikes stable foundations for sustainable peace within the Colombian people, namely between the Colombian government and the FARC, in Colombia for the first time in decades of conflict. This resolution is only a crowning image of the European Union's support and efforts to support the development of peace, stability and democracy in Colombia. I also consider it essential to be part of the text of the resolution calling on the Member States of the Union to establish a trust fund to support the implementation of this peace agreement. Also important is the fact that the agreement implies a balanced understanding of the need for clemency on the one hand, and for punishing those responsible on the other. Bearing in mind the conflicts in the former Yugoslavia, but also my own political experience in view of the sensitive situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina, I would especially emphasize the importance of two aspects of peace for Colombia: the establishment of a Commission for Truth-Finding, Coexistence and Non-Development, and balanced social and economic development throughout the territory of the state. Dealing with the past and establishing the truth are essential elements that can ensure transitional justice. At the same time, sustainable peace is only possible when all groups in society are equal and protected from scaries.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ After several attempts to launch a peace process in Colombia, the current peace talks with the Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces (FARC), initiated by Colombian President Santos, promise very much. The Agreement on the Most Important Issue, the one on reparations for victims and justice, was reached at the end of 2015 and the final agreement is scheduled for March 2016. However, it is important to note that the most difficult part of the entire peace process is yet to come, and it involves the implementation of the concluded agreements, which will certainly be slowed down by many obstacles. The EU is an important part of this peace process, especially as it has shown a strong desire to offer assistance through the creation of a foundation to support the period following the conflict. The EU has committed to assisting Colombia with EUR 26 million, most of which, 21 million, will be earmarked for a programme whose primary objective is to help Colombia overcome social and economic shortcomings in marginalised and conflict-affected regions. I fully agree with the High Representative's decision to appoint Eamon Gilmore, a former Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister who was directly involved in the Northern Ireland peace process, as the EU envoy for the peace process in Colombia.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I am very happy and support the agreements reached so far between the Colombian Government and the FARC in order to achieve peace in Colombia. I am aware of the political effort, realism and perseverance shown by both the Colombian Government and the FARC in order to bring their opposing positions closer together and gradually create room for compromise. I firmly believe that the negotiations will be concluded as soon as possible so that the conflict is finally concluded and the conclusion of the negotiations reaches a milestone in Colombia's modern history. As a Social Democrat, I firmly believe that violence is not a legitimate method of political struggle and that democracy must be accepted with all its consequences and demands. It will also be important for Colombia to be accompanied by decisive efforts to combat inequality and poverty, and I am glad that the EU will provide significant support to Colombia in this area.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 After 50 years of internal conflict in Colombia, the government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) are trying to achieve the creation of a special jurisdiction, which satisfactorily resolves the main and most problematic issue of the negotiations, setting a six-month deadline to sign a final peace agreement before 23 March 2016.  The European Parliament calls on the Member States to set up a trust fund to accompany the post-conflict phase and to finance the prosecution of war criminals and to help compensate the victims. The peace process should also be accompanied by a determined effort to combat inequality and poverty.  I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution and I welcome the fact that the Colombian armed forces recently announced their intention to review Colombia's military doctrine in order to prepare the armed forces to respond quickly and effectively to the new challenges posed by the post-conflict phase, while at the same time fulfilling the function of guarantor of peace agreements.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I support the peace process currently underway in Colombia. After years of civil war, it is time for this country to return to peace and stability. Many efforts are still to be made, but Europe must also send such messages in order to recall its values.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 After the demonstrations of the antagonistic positions, this report welcomes and supports the agreements reached between the Government of Colombia and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia to achieve a lasting and stable peace in the country, and draws attention to the agreements on comprehensive rural reform, the resolution of the problem of illicit drugs and the creation of a Special Jurisdiction for Peace. This includes the creation of a Commission for the Clarification of Truth, Coexistence and Non-Repetition, as well as the Unit for the Search for Persons Reported as Missing in the context and as a result of the conflict and the Unit for the Investigation and Dismantling of Criminal Organizations. This search for peace promotes a unique agreement in history that puts victims at the center of the approach and defines as a priority the truth, justice without impunity, the effective reparation of the damage suffered and the non-repetition. In view of the foregoing, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted for the resolution on the peace process in Colombia. The establishment of a stable and lasting peace in Colombia is a priority for the European Union as part of its close political, economic and trade cooperation with the country. The internal armed conflict has lasted for more than 50 years and has caused great suffering to the population, whether through terrorist acts or the actions of paramilitary groups.  In order to best support Colombia in the post-conflict phase, we call on Member States to create a trust fund to end impunity, to reach the truth and to try and punish the perpetrators of crimes committed during the conflict so that they do not happen again and that victims receive redress.  Finally, it is important to tackle inequality and poverty upstream by, for example, helping displaced people and communities, by guaranteeing access to decent work and the recognition of social and labour rights in Colombia.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution aims to convey the Political Support of the European Parliament to the peace process between the Colombian Government and the FARC. This is a historic moment. It has been 50 years of armed conflict and the EP cannot fail to support it. It is also important to recognise the role of victims' associations, NGOs and civil society in the success of these agreements. We call on the National Liberation Army (ELN) to also work on the peace process in Colombia, calling on the Colombian Government to begin a parallel negotiation process that could develop in similar terms. I would like to support the suggestion of a gender subcommittee to ensure gender integration into the negotiations and the participation of victims of sexual violence and women's rights organisations in peace talks. This should be a source of inspiration for other peace processes around the world.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which considers that the end of this internal conflict, which in more than fifty years has claimed millions of victims, and the establishment of a stable and lasting peace in Colombia, are a priority for that country, but also for the European Union and the international community.  The text of the resolution also calls on the National Liberation Army (ELN) to make a firm commitment to peace in Colombia as soon as possible, and urges it to engage with the Colombian government in parallel negotiations that could take place under similar conditions.  Finally, we welcomed the decision of 1 October 2015 by Federica Mogherini, High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, to appoint Eamon Gilmore, former Minister of Foreign Affairs and Trade of the Republic of Ireland, Special Envoy of the European Union for the Peace Process in Colombia, and also welcomed the mission to monitor the human rights situation , in the context of the peace agreements, which the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights is expected to fulfil in Colombia.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The special ties between the EU and Colombia have enabled the establishment of a framework of close political, economic and trade cooperation established by the November 2009 Memorandum of Understanding and the Trade Agreement between the EU and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru on the other (signed in June 2012, to which Ecuador has decided to accede in the meantime , having been concluded with the latter country in July 2014) in which the objective was not only to strengthen economic and trade relations between the parties, but also to strengthen peace, democracy, respect for human rights, sustainable development and the well-being of citizens. Considering the remarkable political efforts to consolidate peace and an effort to combat inequalities and to progress in the full and permanent guarantee of human rights, these were fundamental reasons for voting in favour of this report which is of extreme importance to EU-Colombia relations.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which marks the Union's support for Colombia in its peace process that began in 2012. After 50 years of uninterrupted armed conflict between the Colombian authorities and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC), March 2016 is to be the occasion for the signing of a final peace agreement, as foreseen by the agreement on between the forces involved. This conflict, which has claimed nearly 230,000 lives, must give way to a real rule of law. That is why this resolution calls for the establishment of a special trust fund for Colombia, in order to accompany the victims to help them obtain truth, justice and reparations.  The Union must stand with Colombia and welcome the political efforts of both the Colombian authorities and the FARC.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal was supported by the vast majority of political groups in Parliament. What is happening in Colombia today is extraordinary and the European Parliament must support the very difficult result achieved and promote the conclusion of the negotiations as soon as possible.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this as I do not wish for the EU to get involved with foreign affairs.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ In the last vote of today, I voted to support the talks that could put an end to 50 years of armed conflict, and the EU cannot let this historic moment get away.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. ‒ After many years of fighting between the Colombian government and the FARC there is finally a chance for peace. This resolution supports the parties to negotiate further and stop the violence. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ The internal armed conflict in Colombia has been going on for over fifty years, has caused great suffering to the population, whether as a result of terrorist interventions or the activities of paramilitary groups, and has led, inter alia, to murders, forced disappearances, kidnappings, sexual violence, abuse of minors, internal and external population resettlement and the scourge of anti-gun mines. Therefore, for the EU, international organisations and the current Government of Colombia, the priority is to end the internal conflict and achieve a stable and lasting peace. Cuba and Norway, as guarantor countries, and Chile and Venezuela as countries assisting in the peace process play an important role in this peace process, and much thanks go to Pope Francis for his cooperation on this role. The EU also welcomes the announcement by the Colombian military forces that they are going to revise Colombia's military doctrine in order to prepare the army to respond more effectively and swiftly to new post-conflict tasks and to serve as a guarantee of peace agreements.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
