text: Writing. The EU and Colombia have political relations based on dialogue and mutual respect within the framework of the Memorandum of Understanding of 28.11. Since 2009, there has also been a political dialogue focusing on human rights between them. 19. 11. 2012, the signing of a general agreement to resolve the conflict and build a stable and lasting peace between the Government of Colombia and the FARC fulfilled the wish of the Colombian people to live in peace. On 15 May 2015, the same parties also reached an agreement on the victims of the conflict, which includes a special competence for peace and a commitment on human rights. This agreement is seen as an essential step towards building a stable and lasting peace and recognises all victims of conflict as citizens with rights.  I agree that such talks are essential for reaching an agreement for a stable and lasting peace that marks the end of half a century of armed internal conflict. I support all ongoing talks to reach a final ceasefire and a complete cessation of hostilities as quickly as possible.  The resolution highlights the problematic points of the peace process in Colombia and proposes appropriate solutions to improve the situation there. As such, I can mention the establishment of an effective system that will be able to verify the link between crimes and armed conflict, and call on Colombia to disband paramilitary groups. For the sake of the above, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ Ending the internal conflict in Colombia, which has killed millions of people in more than fifty years, and achieving a stable and lasting peace in Colombia are a top priority for that country, but also for the European Union and the international community. It is necessary to adopt instruments and measures for peace-building.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. Since 2013, the EU and Colombia have had close economic and trade relations governed by a trade agreement between Colombia and Peru and the EU and its Member States, the ultimate goal of which is not only to strengthen economic ties between the parties concerned, but also to forge partnerships that go beyond trade itself, the same as to contribute to strengthening peace, democracy and the well-being of their citizens. As part of this agreement, the EU abolished visas for Colombian citizens, which occurred at the second EU-CELAC summit in June 2015. Building lasting and sustained peace in Colombia by ending the internal conflict, which has lasted more than 50 years and has caused millions of casualties, is primarily important for Colombia, but also for the European Union and the international community, as expressed in numerous declarations by various countries and regional and international organisations, including the European Union, which support the peace process. I welcome the Agreement reached on 23 September 2015 between the Government of Colombia and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia - FARC) on the creation of a Specialised Jurisdiction for Peace, which satisfactorily addresses the main and most difficult issue in the negotiations, and welcomes the joint decision to set a six-month deadline for the final peace agreement to be signed before 23 March 2016.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. I support the proposal for a resolution on the peace process in Colombia. Progress is evident in a number of areas of government and the functioning of society. The European Union is the cradle of democracy, tolerance and solidarity and as such supports systematically and financially numerous peace processes in the world. Colombia has unfortunately been part of these peace processes due to problems in the state, but it is encouraging that many positive progresses are visible. Positive progress is also evident in other Latin American countries, and Colombia has become an example in the region. Much more effort is needed to solve the accumulated problems. The EU will continue to support the peace process in Colombia.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the peace process in Colombia.  In the European Parliament, we often discuss human rights violations around the world, armed conflicts and civil wars. This resolution is different. It welcomes the peace process achieved in Colombia after 50 years of civil war, which has claimed enormous casualties. This is an important step forward to the signing of a ceasefire between the government and the resistance.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The members of the Group of the European United Left have succeeded in adopting several important references in the text. I list some of them, such as the reference to the action of paramilitary groups, the call for the government to provide protection to trade unionists and human rights defenders, the reference to the need for citizens to participate in the peace process. For these reasons and despite our disagreement with individual petitions (e.g. on terrorist organisations) we voted in favour of the text.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Union must approach the cases of foreign states, especially non-member countries, carefully and in the light of international law. Any attempt at involvement is a brutal interference in the countries' internal affairs, especially in matters relating to peace and security.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a resolution, which reflects the chances of compromise between the political parties opposed to Colombia and the efforts of the international community, in particular the European Union, to this end. The agreement, which is scheduled to be signed on 29 March, still needs clarification and additional guarantees on a number of points in order for the referendum on its adoption to be successful. At the same time, it already contains, in my view, important and forward-looking elements, including in terms of limiting the role of the military, reducing drug trafficking and measures to ensure the safety of the population. I also consider the commitment made in the report and in the High Representative's oral supplement to monitor and provide political and financial support to the internal political reconciliation process in Colombia after the agreement enters into force, from the point of view of strengthening the EU's external relations and global positions.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 A quarter of a million dead, 27,000 kidnappings, thousands of children forced to bear arms and more than 7 million injured are the balance of the civil war that has been going on for more than half a century in Colombia. Finally, after 30 years of ineffective peace talks, there is a significant chance of reaching a historic agreement between the government side and the FARC militia.  In its resolution, the European Parliament called for the talks to be completed as soon as possible. It also draws attention to the need for financial, logistical and political support from the European Union in the implementation of the Peace Agreement in Colombia. It also called on EU Member States to set up a trust fund to support the post-conflict phase of the peace process, taking into account the priorities identified by victims of crime, such as truth-seeking, justice and redress, and a guarantee that the conflict will never happen again. This resolution is a very important element of the Union's commitment to promoting peaceful solutions in armed conflicts, which is why I fully supported its provisions.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The latest events in Colombia represent a new hope for the peaceful internal development of this country. The agreement signed by the Colombian government with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) on transitional justice assurance provides the prerequisites for a lasting resolution of this internal armed conflict after more than 50 years. This agreement involves a number of amnesty for FARC members aimed at increasing trust between the two parties, which is considered essential for a peace agreement in the near future. The European Union has consistently supported the peace process in Colombia, one of its important partners in Latin America. We are witnessing a historic moment that could lead to the conclusion of one of the longest and bloodiest civil conflicts in the world. That is why we must welcome this positive development of the situation and encourage the conclusion of a definitive ceasefire agreement. At the same time, however, we must not forget the similar conflict between the Colombian government and the National Liberation Army, where a similar agreement is needed. Only under these conditions will Colombia and its citizens be able to move towards a normal situation, in which they will be able to reach their real development potential.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for this text. However, I insist that Colombia continue its reforms to respect labour and human rights in general.  We also call on the National Liberation Army (ELN) to make a firm commitment to peace in Colombia as soon as possible, and urge it to engage with the Colombian government in parallel negotiations that could take place under similar conditions.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the peace negotiations in Colombia. By voting on this text I expressed my support for a definitive end to the conflict as soon as possible. Over the past months the EU High Representative as well as the EU Special Envoy, Eamon Gilmore, supported Colombians in the implementation of a possible peace agreement. The EU will also contribute to the introduction of a ceasefire follow-up mechanism and weapons handover.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Establishing peace among the warring parties is a lengthy and difficult process, and it has been going on for too long in Colombia. The key points of the agreement between the rebels and the Colombian government seem encouraging towards peace and the continuation of normal life for citizens. Compensating victims, establishing true facts about the conflict, finding the missing and guaranteeing security for the victims of the conflict, as well as for all other citizens, are key steps that should lead to the establishment of peaceful and normal coexistence.  In the hope that the final peace agreement will actually be signed in March this year, I supported this report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the peace process in Colombia, as I believe that, after decades of violence, numerous casualties (there have been more than 220,000 so far) and the forced migration of more than 6 million people, it will be a crucial step closer to the end of the conflict and lasting peace in the country.  The agreement, which puts at the forefront of helping victims, tackling the problem of illicit drugs and establishing a fair justice system, will, in the long term, enable citizens to live better in the country, ensure fairness and contribute to the progress of the Colombian economy. It is right that the European Union actively supports Colombia in laying the foundations of democracy and sustainable peace.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the agreements made to date between the Government of Colombia and the FARC to achieve peace in Colombia and highlights the agreements on a comprehensive rural reform, political participation and democratic opening to build peace, solving the problem of illicit drugs and the establishing a Special Jurisdiction for Peace, including a Commission for the Clarification of the Truth, Coexistence and Non-Repetition and the Special Unit for the Search for People considered to have Disappeared in the context of and on account of the conflict, in addition to the Unit for the Investigation and Dismantling of Criminal Organisations. With this vote, we recognise the political effort, realism and perseverance demonstrated by both the Government of Colombia and the FARC in reconciling their conflicting views and gradually creating an area of commitment that has allowed progress to be made in achieving a stable and lasting peace and thus securing an agreement that is unique in history, places the victims above any other consideration and whose priorities are truth , justice, reparation and non-repetition; acknowledges, moreover, the important role played by victims' associations, NGOs and civil society in securing these agreements. We call on the National Liberation Army (ELN) to commit firmly and decisively, without further delay, to peace in Colombia.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. I choose abstention for this text.  This is not to oppose the peace process, but simply to remind us that the Union has nothing to do in this matter, other than to parasitize states in their regal functions and the United Nations in its primary role of peacekeeping and management of post-conflict processes.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Ending the internal conflict, which has lasted more than 50 years and has killed millions of people, and achieving a solid and lasting peace in Colombia, is essential not only for Colombia, but also for the European Union and the international community, as indicated by numerous declarations by various countries and regional and international organisations, including the European Union, in support of the peace process. I supported my group's joint proposal.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour because, after more than half a century of war and more than 220,000 killed according to official data (80% are civilians), for the first time peace negotiations seem to move forward. This long-awaited EP Resolution supports the peace process and highlights, among others, agreements on rural reform, the establishment of a commission for the clarification of truth, coexistence and non-repetition and the establishment of a gender subcommittee. However, we must remember that Truth, Justice, Reparation and Non-Repetition cannot be left in beautiful words, but that institutions that are guaranteeing these principles must be created that are free from judicial contradictions.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This motion for a Resolution aims to support the peace process in Colombia following the agreement reached between the Government of Colombia and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) on Wednesday, September 23, 2015. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this resolution on the peace process in Colombia because it welcomes the agreement between the government and the FARC. In addition, this resolution calls on the National Liberation Army (ELN) to also enter into peace negotiations. From the European Parliament, we must support this peace process because, after more than 50 years of violence in Colombia, there is finally hope for peace.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. I am pleased that the European Parliament has passed a balanced resolution in favour of the peace process in Colombia, a country that has been mired in deadly conflict for more than 60 years.   Having visited Colombia, as part of an EMP mission last June, I know how much Colombians hope for a final peace agreement.  It is therefore a historic agreement that the Colombian government and the FARC are reaching; the lock on the establishment of a special justice for peace to defend the rights of victims and a court capable of trying those responsible for the conflict, including paramilitaries.  The desire to establish restorative justice mechanisms capable of compensating all victims, to carry out a broad amnesty, to involve the entire Colombian people and to reach a bilateral ceasefire as soon as possible are major points of the agreement, including the involvement of all the actors in the conflict and in particular the other guerrillas of the National Liberation Army.  The peace process must now come to an end despite the obstacles posed by former President Alvaro Uribe. It was important for Parliament to support the process, so I voted for it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution contains positive elements. It is clearer the framework of the conflict with the explicit reference to paramilitaries. However, it says nothing about the true nature of these paramilitary forces, which are in practice the armed arm of the government, through which it acts with impunity. It is of great importance to mention the role of victims' associations and other civil organizations throughout the mediation process. It contains specific calls to the government to defend the interests of specific sections of the population, with particular emphasis on trade unionists and activists, who have been preferred victims of the action of paramilitary groups and that any rule of law should protect. We regret that it has gone further in the accountability of the Colombian regime, which has always boycotted the many peace processes, systematically betting on the path of violent repression, always with the support of the United States, which holds in that country one of its largest military bases in Latin America.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Violence is not a political tool and so all efforts to promote the peace process in Colombia sustainably and efficiently must be supported. The report is consistent and takes up specific points that can help to resolve the conflict satisfactorily.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported this motion for a resolution because stability and the defence of peace are our primary concern. The purpose of this text is to promote and defend peace and human rights in Colombia.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 An armed conflict has been taking place in Colombia for more than 50 years, which has resulted in a large number of casualties, so I have decided to support the motion for this resolution aimed at establishing lasting peace in the state. The peaceful organisation of the world is one of the European Union's priorities, which is why I support its involvement and efforts to bring about peace. The steps that have already been taken, such as special peace courts, are certainly milestones in the country's history. However, I believe that all agreements concluded so far need to be consistently implemented, which also requires an continued active role for the EU, because only in this way can real peace be achieved.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the motion for a joint resolution on the peace process in Colombia. I think it is important to send out a signal that the European Parliament supports a peace process that will hopefully end a 50-year period of internal armed conflict in which the population has suffered greatly as a result of terrorist activities or attacks by paramilitary groups. During this period, there have been many murders, abductions, disappearances, sexual violence or abuse of minors. It is therefore positive that the peace talks that began as early as 2012 in Havana will finally bring peace, but especially the rules for compensation for victims, the establishment of a special commission to search for missing people and the exclusion of any amnesty or pardon for crimes against humanity, genocide and serious war crimes. I therefore hope that the signing of the peace agreement will be implemented as foreseen by March this year, and I have expressed my support for the people of Colombia with my vote.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favor of the joint motion for a resolution in favor of the Colombian peace process, because I believe that a peace process like that that has been consolidated in Colombia is always a fragile and difficult process, but that it is our obligation to converge all efforts for a positive outcome, ever closer, although not yet fully guaranteed. I also note that the peace process in Colombia has been focused on the victims and not on the conflicting parties, a remarkable option for pioneering. Moreover, the agreement on the victims of the conflict signed in December 2015 is a key pillar of this peace process, a process that will be all the more resilient the stronger the role of civil society and a process aimed at ending violence in all its forms. In this sense, I believe that the reparation of the damage caused by a conflict of more than 50 years of time must be a priority and that the agreements established enshrine exactly that perspective. The European Union has indeed made an important contribution to what has been acquired in this process.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 We cannot but say that this resolution has positive aspects, notably by making a commitment to the defence of peace, through a bilateral ceasefire, renouncing the use of violence and calling for reconciliation and therefore supporting peace negotiations and their continuity. Positively, it is also necessary to call for the extension of the process to the ELN, the express defense of policies that promote equality and development, highlighting agrarian reform, the defense of the end of policies of persecution of left-wing groups and trade unions, among others. While it does not clearly hold the colombian conflict responsible – state terrorism carried out by colombian governments – nor clearly demonstrates the social injustice to which the Colombian people have been subjected for decades, the resolution essentially advocates the continuation and success of the peace process.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I supported the resolution on the peace process in Colombia, which will enable the Colombian people to build a stable and lasting peace after 50 years of continuing armed conflict.  Peace negotiations lay the foundations for just economic and social development and the rule of law.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by Laurent Fabius, Chairman of the Paris Climate Conference on COP 21 (2016/2524(RSP)). Minister Laurent Fabius, I would like to thank the Minister for his excellent work and for his excellent work. We are very pleased that you have accepted the invitation to talk to us about the Paris climate agreement. I would like to extend a warm welcome to the European Parliament. Ladies and gentlemen! On 12 December last year, a historic step was taken in Paris. For the first time, all the countries of the world have committed themselves to making the fight against climate change binding. 195 countries have agreed on clear and ambitious targets for climate protection. It is clear that success always has many fathers and mothers, so I would like to take this opportunity and on behalf of the European Parliament to thank all those who have worked for many years for the success of this Paris conference. I would like to thank Commissioner Caete, the Luxembourg Presidency and the entire EU negotiating team. But there is no doubt, Foreign Minister Fabius, as President of the climate conference, that you have played a huge part in the success of this summit. They succeeded with great diplomatic skill in reconciling the different interests of the participants. You have shown that the European Union can and wants to take a leading role in climate protection – we also believe that it must take action! For now, countries are also obliged to fulfil their commitments and to implement what has been agreed. I believe that it is indisputable, above all, here in this House, that we must keep our promise to the developing countries. The success of Paris shows that if we stand together, we can achieve a great deal. It is therefore a great honour for us, Minister, that you are with us today. Dear Laurent Fabius, welcome once again!

name: Laurent FABIUS
text: President of the Paris climate conference COP 21. Mr President, Commissioner Caete, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to thank President Schulz very much for inviting me, as President of COP 21, to present to you the outlines of the agreement that was adopted on 12 December in Paris, and to speak to you as well, since I think that is what will interest you , next steps. 2015 was a difficult year all over the world, and especially for Europe. In this context, the Paris climate conference was a hope. It has allowed, which is rare, a gathering of all nations. It showed that diplomacy and multilateralism, under certain conditions, could achieve important results. I had the opportunity last October to set out, before your Committees on the Environment and Foreign Affairs, the criteria of what a good agreement would be in Paris. But at the time, we didn't know what the results would be. However, through the 29 articles contained in the Paris Agreement and the 140 points of the decision that accompanies it, these criteria of a good agreement have been met.  We have reached a universal agreement, which is based on national contributions from 187 countries, which is considerable. The agreement is recognized as ambitious; it includes, in the long term, limiting global warming to 2 degrees, as well as a commitment to continue efforts to reach 1.5 degrees and carbon neutrality in the second half of the century. It is a dynamic agreement; A five-year commitment review mechanism is planned, which is very important. A first meeting is set for 2023, but a review of efforts will take place as early as 2018, which will allow for a discussion for an increase in commitments. With regard to the monitoring of commitments, a common framework of transparency is defined, with so-called flexibilities based on the capabilities of each state.  The agreement is legally binding, as much as it could be given the political constraints of several states, and finally, the agreement is generally recognized as just; the concept of differentiation is spread across all subjects and solidarity among rich countries will take place towards the most vulnerable countries, including a commitment to meet and then exceed the target of $100 billion annually for vulnerable countries and to set a new target by 2025. In saying that, I summarize the economics of the main provisions. These results, which few people actually believed before the COP, owe much to the Europeans, as you said, President Schulz. This is particularly true with regard to the level of ambition of the agreement, and I would like to welcome, in particular, the commitment that was expressed in Mr Pargneaux's report here, entitled 'Towards a new international climate agreement in Paris', which you adopted in October 2015, before the conference. I would also like to salute, very amicably, the strong commitment of Commissioner Caete, with whom I must say, without compromising it, we have spent sleepless nights, and of the Luxembourg Presidency, in this case Minister Carole Dieschbourg, who has helped us enormously. I want to thank, of course, through you, each of your countries who has enabled this success. Beyond the agreement itself, COP 21 has allowed a significant number of non-governmental actors to be associated with the climate cause, for the first time on this scale. More than 5,000 cities, regions, businesses, investors and NGOs from 180 countries made commitments on this occasion. So there is the state sphere and there is the non-state aspect. Several ambitious projects, the impact of which is expected to be measured even before 2020, were launched at the conference. In the end, I think a shift dynamic has been set in motion towards low-carbon development; in my opinion, this dynamic is irreversible. The word "historical" is often used, a little wrongly and through, but, in this case, I believe that, for once, the word "historical" is not overused and that, in the indispensable fight against climate change, there will be a before Paris and after Paris. However, ladies and gentlemen, much remains of course to be done to clarify and implement this historic agreement.  2015, if I sum up, was the year of negotiations and decisions, and 2016 must be what I would gladly call the year of the four "Ps". What do I mean by that? The first "P" is the signing and ratification process. The opening of the agreement to the signing will take place on 22 April at the United Nations. You are certainly aware that at least 55 countries representing 55% greenhouse gas emissions must ratify the agreement for it to enter into force, and of course the maximum number of European and global leaders must be present on 22 April. The European Union was one of the first to publish its national contribution in March 2015, and I believe it must continue to lead by example by signing the Paris Agreement on 22 April and then ratifying it as soon as possible. The second "P" is the clarifications concerning both the Paris agreement and the decision attached to it. In December, principles were laid down, objectives defined; it is now a matter of agreeing on how to translate them into action. This will be the subject of the first meeting of the group in Bonn in Bonn in May to prepare the implementation decisions. In particular, as you will understand, we will have to come up with a common and precise definition of climate finance; we will have to determine the exact terms of what is called the five-year review of national commitments, and we will have to set rules for transparency in the follow-up of commitments. Of course, I will be present at these meetings. The third "P" refers to the pre-2020 period. Beyond the implementation of the agreement, which, I remind you, is scheduled to enter into force in 2020, follow-up on the action will be needed before 2020. This is called the Lima-Paris Action Plan, which brings together the initiatives of both states and non-governmental actors. What am I thinking? I am thinking, for example, of the International Solar Alliance, launched by the Indian Prime Minister, Mr Modi, which brings together almost all the countries between the tropics of Cancer and Capricorn. I am thinking of the "mission innovation", a public-private law initiative, launched with President Obama, Bill Gates and other investors for the development of clean technologies. I am thinking - and France has made its mark - on the generalisation of disaster early warning systems, the so-called CREWS system, and on the climate insurance system in vulnerable countries, on which Germany, in particular, has worked hard. I am also thinking about the protection of tropical forests and I would like to stress our financial commitments to renewable energy in Africa, which will have to be honoured quickly and completely. On all these concrete projects and on many others, significant progress will have to take place as early as 2016. The last "P" is the preparation of COP 22, which will take place in Marrakech at the end of 2016 and we will work there with our Moroccan friends in the same spirit that the Peruvians had worked with us to prepare the COP 21, in order to achieve this time a success in Marrakech in November. We will therefore hold with our Moroccan friends, and a whole series of international leaders, many informal and formal meetings, according to the method that has been successful in Paris. Beyond these four sets of actions, these four "P's", we will also have to move forward in the important sectors that were not covered by the Paris Agreement and for which action is essential: air transport, in particular, maritime transport and an agreement in principle that was reached by the parties to the Montreal Protocol to prepare, in 2016, an amendment to eliminate HFC refrigerants. , high emitters of greenhouse gases, and there, quick decisions will have to be taken. None of the negotiations I have just mentioned, which will take place in different frameworks, will be easy, but the success of Paris and the urgency of the necessary actions should enable us to achieve results also in these important areas. Ladies and gentlemen, in the promising context of the Paris Agreement, I am convinced, and I hope, that the European Union will continue its commitment to the preservation of our planet. In this regard, I think there are a number of initiatives that I believe is necessary. The first relates to the EU's ratification of the Doha amendment on commitments for the second period of the Kyoto Protocol. Only a few countries are missing; they would have to respond to that call. A second initiative will have to focus on the implementation by our Union of the commitments made in Paris for 2030 in terms of mitigation. Several negotiations await us, including the reform of the ETS carbon market and the sharing of effort in sectors outside the ETS , including buildings, transport and agriculture. It would be excellent if Parliament could make progress in its decision-making process, particularly for the first reading of the revision of the ETS Directive.  The European Energy Union project will also need to be seized to achieve the energy transition in Europe, with an emphasis on new jobs which can be created in this way, because , I stress, ecological transition is not only a constraint, it is also a major opportunity. Many texts will be put on the table by the Commission in 2016 in order to move forward on this ambitious project - I am thinking in particular of strengthening our commitments on renewable energy development or energy efficiency. Again, I am counting on the European Parliament to help us move forward quickly. Finally, we must strengthen our European action for sustainable development among our partners in the South. The European Union, which is already, I recall, the leading donor in the field of climate, will have to continue and, if possible, increase its support for these countries in terms of finances, technology and expertise. In total, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Paris conference is therefore unquestionably a success in the fight against climate change, even if it is obviously not the end point. Action will therefore have to continue and the European Union will assume a major responsibility. In the work to come, your Parliament will play a singular role in carrying out all the European ambition.  Finally, Mr President, my last words will be to underline a point which is not often recalled and which I consider essential. The Paris Agreement is not just about climate in the narrow sense; it will serve the environment in general, biodiversity, public health, food security and, more broadly, development. But it is also, and I insist, an agreement for security and peace. Let's be very careful at this point. Food and water scarcity, the risk of mass migration of populations caused by the consequences of global warming, the threat of conflicts linked to the control of fossil resources: uncontrolled climate change would ultimately lead to widespread conflicts. By refusing, as you did in Paris, this drift, by directing the world towards renewable and decarbonised energies, the agreement of 12 December, to which you have contributed mightily, is therefore working for the present and future generations. In our certainly chaotic, dangerous and uncertain world, this contribution to international security is a major component of the Paris Agreement, where Europe has taken and will take its full share.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would also like to warmly congratulate the French Foreign Minister, Mr Laurent Fabius! Their conduct of negotiations was one of the important points, one of the key points that led to a successful agreement in Paris. You have done that really well and you have thrown all your energy and your political weight into this matter. But I would also like to thank you personally and you, Mr President, for thanking Commissioner Miguel Arias Caete. And I am pleased that even my green colleague, Bas Eickhout, in this Chamber in December could not help but praise Miguel Arias Caete. I think back to the time when we had to deal with it. The Commissioner is doing a good job and has done a good job, especially before Paris and Paris. I agree with you, Foreign Minister: this agreement is not only important for climate protection, but it is a very important sign in these troubled times, in this difficult year 2015. The world is uneasy, and we have managed to reach an agreement in which some countries that are at war against each other have made a joint commitment. That is a value in itself. More than 190 countries have made a concrete commitment to how to reduce greenhouse gases, and we have the long-term goal of carbon neutrality. All this is a major breakthrough. However, I am a little sceptical about this 1.5 degree target. If we are honest, we do not even have enough commitments to reach the 2 degrees in the commitments made by the individual states in Paris. I would have liked us to really bring this to the point where we reach 2 degrees and for us to be sure of that before we talk about tightening up. We were right to point out that there is a lot to be done on the subject of air transport and maritime transport. Europe, in particular Parliament, would have liked us to settle this clearly in Paris and to give a mandate to the ICAO and the IMO. It is a pity that this has not been achieved. But I think it is right that you mentioned that something needs to be done in these sectors. I would like to ask you personally to point out in your government, as we do in other governments, including the country I know best, that there is legislation in Europe. And if the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) is unable to achieve a reduction in greenhouse gases – reduction, not just stabilization – then our legislation, including for international air traffic, will come back into force. And this time we have to be credible. It is not acceptable for all sectors to have to implement some very drastic targets – I have spoken to the steel industry again today, for which it is really very, very ambitious – and for other sectors not to be covered. I believe that we must achieve fair – ambitious but fairer – implementation here, so that we do not place too much strain on individual sectors. With this in mind, we want to work together on implementation. I look forward to it. But that's still a very hard piece of work.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: au nom du groupe S&D. – Monsieur Fabius, bienvenue ici au Parlement. Mr President, let me congratulate Mr Fabius in the name of the whole group for the excellent work he has done as the French Presidency. Mr Fabius, the way you prepared the COP21, the way you managed it, was brilliant and outstanding and there was a result. So, thank you so much.  But let me thank you too, Mr Commissioner. The Commission also took a very important role. You managed to keep ambitions high, you were building bridges towards the different coalitions who negotiated and you supported the French Presidency, and maybe the combination of the two of you made the agreement happen. It cannot be overestimated how important that is. For the very first time, in Paris nearly all states all over the world – developing countries and emerging economies – have committed themselves to taking the necessary measures to tackle climate change. In that sense, Paris is the very first universal agreement, and that is crucial and of crucial importance for the future.  As you mentioned yourself, Mr Fabius, 2015 was on its way to becoming an annus horribilis with the problems in the war in the Middle East, Ukraine, the refugee crisis and, of course, the attacks in Paris. These events made the world look divided, and made Europe look divided. The climate agreement in that sense is a game changer and a reason to become at least a little bit optimistic about the future, and Paris – the city of lights – has also become the city of hope. That is very encouraging. However, not everything was a success, we have to admit that. One of the most striking examples is the international aviation and shipping industry. We all know that they stand for a lot of emissions: the emissions of these two sectors, for instance, can be compared with the emissions of South Korea and Germany put together, and these are rising. In the years to come, by 2050, they will rise by 270% and we have to admit that we failed in that we could not include that in the agreement. So, my additional question to both of you is this: how will we deal with that in the next year to come? How will we make sure that these two very important sectors will be part of future implementation? On the level of agreement – and here I do not agree with my colleague from the PPE – I think that agreement on 2°C decreasing to 1.5°C is very important and that, if we want, we can achieve that. But then, that will mean that we cannot lean back. We cannot lean back in Europe either. We have a good agreement, but it is this just on paper. If we want to succeed, we need to implement it and that means – I am looking to the Commissioner in particular – more ambitious targets than we have had up until now.  We had targets for 2030 and 2050. We have to admit that we took the lower end of these targets when the IPCC made the calculations. We said 80% for 2050. We should go now to the higher end, and make sure that our emissions go down 95% by 2050. So we need to look to the world, but we can only look to the world if we take our own responsibilities. I am looking to the Commission again: when can we see further developments in that sense? That needs to be done prior to the finalisation of the revision of the current legislation, for example, as mentioned, before the ETS.  Let me conclude by addressing you again, Mr Fabius, as a final remark. We are very grateful for the work you have done. As I said before, there is a lot of work in front of us and you are not only the President of the COP21 but also the Foreign Minister of a very important Member State, so you now have the moral duty – together with all of us, of course – to take up that responsibility, and we are counting on you.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, it was a hell of a result. An extraordinary result emerged from Paris. I get the feeling that afterwards, rather like over-indulging in a night of celebration, many people woke up scratching their heads and trying to work out exactly what it was they had agreed to the night before, because in reality, some of those agreements are quite extraordinary, and rather like checking your phone to find those slightly embarrassing text messages or the slightly unusual tweets you sent when you should not have sent them , we have in fact discovered that inside this bold and extraordinary agreement is genuine boldness, and that represents the 1.5°C ambition which is being mentioned.  Now I listened to my colleagues, one for and one against these things, but whatever it means, we are moving forward at a pace and we must not lose sight of the destination we are going towards. I am conscious, however, that the European Union’s ambitions themselves represent only a 70% chance of hitting our 2050 targets and I think again that ambition must be reconsidered. Listening to Commissioner Arias Cañete, who has much to be thankful for again in what he brought back from Paris, this represents full decarbonisation. All of these things will be serious challenges for this Chamber and we must embrace those challenges and we must live up to the ambitions Minister Fabius set in Paris. Congratulations, Minister. It was an extraordinary achievement.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, let me also start by thanking Minister Fabius for his superb role in Paris in negotiating this agreement. It is truly a historic agreement that gave a clear signal that the world is, in an irreversible way, going towards a low carbon economy. Although I do agree with all those who say that Paris was just an agreement on paper, we should not underestimate the value of paper. We needed this paper agreement in order to come to the real action on the ground. Talking about action, just like Peter Liese, I would like to emphasise that we do need to do more than we agreed upon in Paris, not only to stay below the 2°C but – even more importantly – to come near the 1.5°C.  And talking about actions, I would like to concentrate on the EU actions. We do have the EU policies in place, but are they sufficient, given the Paris agreement? What about carbon leakage? The idea of carbon leakage is based on the assumption that the rest of the world is not doing what we are doing. That is going to change now. So what are we going to do about carbon leakage now? What about the 2020, 2030 and 2050 targets, given the 1.5°C benchmark? I am really looking forward to the comments from Minister Fabius on whether he believes that the EU should step up its efforts. Finally, I would like to talk about competitiveness because, if the Paris agreement made one thing clear to our economy, it is that low carbon will be more competitive than high carbon and that is a very crucial notion. To give you one example, we had a historic moment this week at the Amsterdam Stock Exchange, where one company that is leading in sustainability, Unilever, for the first time in history became more valuable than a company that it is not seen as one of those leaders, Royal Dutch Shell. It was a really historic moment which I believe was much more than a coincidence. Talking about competitiveness, Minister Fabius, I am slightly concerned here because Europe is falling behind in its investment in clean technology. So my clear question to you is: do you believe that, in order to safeguard European competitiveness, we should step up our efforts towards a low carbon economy in Europe?

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Minister Fabius, thank you very much for coming to Strasbourg. I have not had the opportunity to congratulate you on the outcome of the Paris climate conference last month. That's what I'd like to do with this one.  You probably know the lyrics to a Billie Holiday song "The difficult will do right now, the impossible may take a little while". That ruling applies here too. The hard is done, now it's the impossible's turn. And there's a lot to do. Europe must show more ambition. We must definitely move away from fossil fuels and switch to alternative, sustainable energy sources. We need to be more sensible and economical with our energy. Isolating homes would be a good start on the part of the Member States and it would also do a lot of work. The low oil price is a good reason for countries to abolish fossil energy subsidies, you said in Le Monde last week. I wholeheartedly support that proposal.  But let us be honest, it will not come from the Dutch Presidency. I asked State Secretary Sharon Dijksma last week what they are going to do to implement the climate agreement, but she refused to go into it. This morning we have heard our Prime Minister Mark Rutte and he only wants to develop the internal market. Now there is nothing against the development of technological development, as you yourself suggest, but we cannot count on it. Europe must show leadership and radically focus on renewable energy and increase its ambitions.  Your presidency of the Conference of Parties will last until the next conference in Marrakech in 2016 and I would like to call on you to help achieve the impossible. 2015 was the year of negotiations and decisions, you said, also in Le Monde. 2016 should be the year of implementation and action. Our diplomacy remains highly mobilized. I hope that in this task you will include Europe and the Dutch Presidency in a more ambitious programme than what is before us.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, thank you for being there. Basically, you should have been there as a guest - I think - in the middle of the votes, when the plenary is present as a whole, as this subject is important and deserves to be debated before all parliamentarians. Everyone has legitimately congratulated you and your team for the great work that has been done in Paris. I hope that you will be able to pass on to the following presidencies the quality of the work and the way in which you have worked, because I believe that you have also reinvented a form of presidency of the COP. It is often said that you were hesitant at first when it came to France proposing its candidacy. I am absolutely convinced today that you have had one of the highlights of your career. So, of course, COP 21, with its goal of getting closer to 1.5oC, requires us to get out of fossil fuels. This agreement is of a weak constraint, let us acknowledge. We will see, yes, how we will build the implementation modalities, but that is a weak constraint. Basically, this is necessarily based on virtuous circles that will take us from today's 3oC - which reflects the reality of the commitments of states, namely climate chaos - to 1.5 degrees Celsius.  But to have these virtuous circles, everyone has to get on with it. So today, the conditions are favourable as they have never been. We see how renewable energy - for example, photovoltaic or onshore wind - is more competitive than oil, gas, nuclear and soon coal. But at the same time, when we look at the latest figures on investments in renewable energy, we see that all regions of the world are making progress in terms of investment in renewable energy, except Europe, and in particular because of France, where investment was cut in half in 2015, when they were growing everywhere. Then, when we listened to this morning's debate, in the presentation of the Presidency's programme, there was only one sentence on climate, Minister, a single sentence on climate! If that is the mood in the Council on the climate issue, I fear that, at the end of the day, this virtuous circle between States, businesses, local authorities and NGOs is not taking place. So you have a huge responsibility, as does the Commissioner, to change the mood in the Council. We have an important meeting: the summit meeting with the Council. To apply to go towards 1.5 degrees Celsius , and the Commissioner is well aware of that - is to change our targets in 2020, because, in any case, we are beyond the targets set. But in 2030, it means purging the carbon market, it's changing the goal of renewable energy as energy savings. And now you have a responsibility, or the Council will not move. Finally, one last request, Mr Fabius, please. We see this incredible movement in divestment. So can France take the initiative of an international conference involving the major players in finance, banks and institutions on divestment, in the run-up to Marrakech? Take this initiative on behalf of France, and we will continue the movement.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you Minister for being here and also for the work you have done in Paris, which we have all appreciated. The agreement is necessarily a compromise, because 195 countries were sitting around the table, so it could not be otherwise. Like any compromise, it has positive points, which have already been mentioned by you and my fellow Members, and others negative, on which I would like to focus on some of them. It is disappointing, for example, that the word decarbonisation disappears: our goal was to stop emitting, but instead we find ourselves with a definition that is a little ambiguous because it says it achieves a balance between anthropogenic emissions and removal through greenhouse gas sources. We are talking about negative emission technology, which, if anything, would balance the positive ones that therefore clearly remain. We have created an alibi and it is an alibi for advanced technologies and huge land use.  In the scenario of the agreement these technologies are absolutely crucial, but they are currently in a very experimental, very expensive state and we do not know if they work, at the moment they do not work everywhere. I would now like to ask you specifically, what is the real capacity to implement these negative-emission technologies on a very large scale and what measures will governments take to facilitate this process? Another point is the market, the ETS. It is a system that we believe is not working, it has failed to stimulate investment in new technologies to reduce emissions, and this has led to fraud and financial speculation. The establishment of a global market, as called for in the Paris Agreement, worries us even more about the delay it would cause in the implementation of other policies that have had a greater impact on ETS in the European Union, such as incentive tariffs for renewable sources and energy saving and efficiency measures.  Finally, we must close a gap between the perception of reality and reality itself, otherwise we will be implementing the changes too slowly. Article 12 of the agreement is good and we welcome it, but it must be implemented decisively and precise messages are needed that are proportionate to the problems. They are needed now and, above all, they must be directed at citizens and local authorities, so that we work hard at this level too. You have to make it clear what we're playing with and there's no more time to play.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Last week, in Germany, what everyone already knew was demonstrated, namely that the media is on a leash with the ruling political elite. When it comes to refugees, it has to be written positively, it is about the climate then a doomsday scenario has to be outlined. Nor did the Commission's spin doctor have much trouble linking these two elements and introducing the concept of climate refugees. "Climate refugee": manipulative framing that Frank Underwood can still suck at, a kind of double turbopropaganda engine that should be a solution to all the EU's problems at once. But things didn't work out. The effect of this so-called climate refugee was really only that he caused warming in Cologne and other European cities and further cooled enthusiasm for the EU. And especially with the latter, I'm very happy.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – At its meeting on 15 December, the European Parliament addressed in detail the results of the Paris climate conference. Why did we have to put this back on the agenda now? Apparently, parliament should thank Minister Fabius, who was president of the climate meeting. Mutual expressions of thanks are also expressed. There's nothing wrong with that, but some questions remain unanswered. What is the weight of the commitments? What happens when there is a Republican political majority in the United States in 2016 who we know don't share the Obama administration's commitment to climate change. What happens then? The second largest emitter. The Kyoto Protocol has been signed, not ratified. And another issue: if the EU supports developing countries financially in climate investment, this also means that, for example, Hungary, as a member of the EU, do you support China, which is the second largest economy in the world, with huge financial reserves? So there are a few more unanswered questions.

name: Laurent FABIUS
text: President of the Paris climate conference COP 21. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank you very much for your comments, your questions. I thank those who intervened, those who did not intervene. I was going to tell you, Mr President, that having heard what I heard, I am ready to come every day, because it was a real bed of roses. More seriously, I will return to the compliments you have given to Commissioner Caete: they are justified. With regard to French diplomacy, I will be a little more nuanced, but I will keep that for the end. On the other hand, first of all, many of you have come back to the question of 1.5 and 2 degrees and the ambition which is, I think, remarkable and which is recognized by everyone in this agreement. I must admit that we might not have agreed, because after all, the previous conferences did not give an example of perfect success, as they say at the Quai d'Orsay. But the main risk, at least the risk I identified, was that we would agree, but on a minimum ambition - and we've often talked about it, you remember. But we have to be honest: not everything is settled. That said, the success of Paris, basically, is to have reached an agreement between 195 countries without any opposition - and people were free - on content that is very ambitious. And that's where the notion of 2 and 1.5 degrees comes in. You have seen, and this has given rise to lengthy discussions, that the drafting is not exactly the same for the 2 and 1.5 degrees. For the 2 degrees, it was already not easy to get; I remember, having replaced President Hollande at the G20, that I had already had a hard time getting the 2 degrees. And then what happened? There has been a kind of dynamic of international conferences that advocates multilateralism. There have been extremely strong interventions from, in particular, the small islands, their representatives, who have said that, of course, the 2 degrees is fine, but if you do not write 1.5 degrees and if you do not make the arrangements to go to 1.5 degrees, you are implicitly saying that we, we no longer exist. It is not simply the question of whether we can live well or not: we will be covered, we will no longer be able to exist. This argument was so strong that it convinced countries that were not spontaneously in favour of the 1.5 degree. I will express myself with my hands. Today, when we sum up all the NPCs, we are on the 3-degree trajectory, we have to be honest. What we are talking about, through the Paris Agreement and now the subsequent decisions, since all this is on a fairly long horizon, is to go from a trajectory of 3 degrees to a trajectory of 2 degrees and 1.5 degrees. And that requires a whole series of concrete actions and a point that many of you have highlighted, namely technological innovations and major investments. Initially, I was not the world's leading expert on these issues, I have to make a confession, but hey, I'm a hard-working mind, so I immersed myself in the subject. I am absolutely convinced that there will be major technological changes that will make the financial hierarchy of energies quite different from what it is today. As many of you have already pointed out, in some cases renewable energy is already much cheaper, when you sum up the direct and indirect costs, than highly polluting energies such as coal. We will go more and more in that direction. The ambition of the agreement and its universal character, therefore, were not contradictory, but they were complementary, and this is one of the great successes of Paris. Second, many of you have rightly come back to the air and sea sectors in international transportation. Then, there, too, I'll be square. There were several parties, including the European Union, who wanted us to mention international transport in the agreement. But you know the mechanism, which is the mechanism of consensus. It soon became apparent that this point was met with strong opposition - let's call it by name - from several emerging and Gulf countries, and therefore consensus was not possible. This is absolutely no impedoful of ICAO and IMO, the two international organizations responsible for this matter, taking steps in this direction. Europe, the presidency of COP 21 and all those who are of good will will mobilise in this direction this year. ICAO has set a target of reaching an agreement by September 2016 to stabilize emissions from the aviation sector after 2020, and why not to lower them. The European Union, if I can give a feeling, must be at the forefront of this issue and promote compromises well in advance.  As far as the maritime sector is concerned, the discussions, let us acknowledge, are less advanced, but compliance with the objectives set out in the Paris Agreement means that negotiations are opened without delay in the case of IMO. Firstly, it seems to me that the EU will have to encourage recognition of emissions levels in the maritime sector and the establishment of a system for measuring global emissions in this sector. But you are absolutely right, because it represents significant greenhouse gas emissions, this year significant progress must be made in these two areas. Thirdly, many of you have intervened, and you are absolutely right, on low carbon issues, a lot of carbon, competitiveness, etc. It's absolutely central. There is no opposition between greenhouse gas emissions on the one hand and competitiveness or employment requirements on the other. Of course, we need transformations, we need accompanying measures, but, again, I am absolutely convinced that competitiveness, not only for countries like ours, but also at the global level, must be combined with downward-carbon progress, and that is where we join the question - I think it was Mr Jadot who asked it - divestment or investment. Yes, you have already seen that, apart from public investment, which is very important and essential, in the private sector, there is a shift that is taking place, and so much the better; we need to be able to speed it up. First, it seems to me, that countries should gradually reduce fossil fuel subsidies. This principle, I remind you, was set by the European Council in May 2013 and France had argued for an ambitious position, for example, in the framework of export credits for coal-fired power plants. This movement has to be general and, I was going to say, let us take advantage of the fact that oil prices are low. You know the numbers: we are talking about the $100 billion that we, as rich countries, have to allocate to poor countries for climate, but the money that is spent on fossil fuel subsidies exceeds 500 billion a year; so we have the orders of magnitude in mind. Then, to answer Mr. Jadot, we must encourage private sector players not to invest, or even to disinvest, in highly carbon-intensive sectors and, as of COP 21, this is a movement that we are seeing: the first sovereign wealth fund, which is a Norwegian fund, has given instructions that there will be divestitures in this sector, to the point that the Governor of the Central Bank of England believes that the next financial bubble could well occur in the carbon sector, because we will realize that this sector, of course, is going to have difficulties, whereas massive investments have been made there. I think that, as far as the private sector is concerned, central bankers and credit rating agencies can now systematically take climate risk into account and make the publication of the carbon footprint mandatory: these are measures that are not beyond our reach and would be extremely useful. However, in parallel with this trend towards divestment, there is a need to maintain a constant effort to invest in renewable energy; the needs are immense. The European Union has instruments: the Juncker Plan, the Structural Funds, EIB projects etc., which I believe can and should be mobilised. You have a European Council in March and, on this occasion, I believe that the Commission will take stock of the assessment for the implementation of the Paris agreement. These are really directions we can go. Finally, the last point - and I do not want to be too long - will be about the compliments, I cannot find any other words, which you have said about the French Presidency. I have already told you that, with regard to the European Union, the role of Commissioner Caete and that of the Luxembourg Presidency, I have no reservations. On the other hand, with regard to French diplomacy, even if it, through me, has blushed when listening to you, especially since our modesty is known to all, in fact, I was thinking about it, our role and mine, was simply to promote, and translate diplomatically, a quite remarkable alignment of the planets.  The first planet was the planet itself. 2015 was the warmest year on record, with considerable disasters and an awareness of the part of the public, and this disastrous situation has, if I may say so, a good side: it has made it even more obvious that there must be an agreement, and this has fostered an awareness. The first planet, then, which is ours, is an element of alignment.  The second planet - I really want to pay tribute to him - is the scientific planet. I want to pay tribute here to the remarkable work of scientists, and in particular to the work of the IPCC, which established the indisputable nature of warming and quantified threats. When we were having public meetings 5, 10 years ago, etc., half of the meeting was about whether or not there was climate change and the second part of the meeting was about whether it was due to human action. Now I am not saying that these debates have completely disappeared, but they have largely disappeared, at least in many of our countries, and that is thanks to the work of scientists. This scientific planet has helped us a lot. The third planet is the planet I will call political-societal. There have been major countries emitting greenhouse gases that have taken very strong positions: China, the largest emitter which, for obvious reasons, which are practical, economic, societal and social reasons, played a very important role, President Obama, who has committed strongly and, of course, the European Union, and other countries still , but it allowed there to be, in accompaniment, a very strong evolution of the economic circles, the commitment of the municipalities, the commitment of the regions, the commitment of NGOs, the commitment of great spiritual and religious voices, and this is all this, this planet that I call political-social, which is a completely new element, which has made the Paris conference obviously presented itself in circumstances quite different from those of the famous Copenhagen conference. And finally, the fourth planet is the diplomatic planet. Our task has been, with all countries, and particularly with the European Union, to promote convergence and to translate all this into an international agreement, with its 29 articles and 140 decision points.  I am often asked: but the work of diplomat, etc. I say, with a little humor, that I do not fully understand the reasons for this success, but that I prefer not to understand the reasons for a success, rather than having brilliant explanations to explain a failure, but once I have said that, basically, when I look back a little bit at the work we have done, it is a bit of a sculptor's job. You know, the sculptor takes blocks of clay, he first takes the main blocks, which were China, the United States, Europe, India, and you had to aggregate all these blocks and then give them some shape. Then there are the smaller blocks, which are also needed because, without consensus, there is no agreement. We had to give shape to all of this, but without losing any of these blocks and, ultimately, that is the work we did in a spirit of transparency, of trust, that was underlined. At the end of this show - later, I will give a small hammer to Mr Schulz, who has become the most famous hammer - and it is quite rare in international conferences, everyone kissed. But it was not something agreed upon; we had the feeling that in a world really very hard, very dangerous, very complicated and very uncertain, for one of the first times, thanks to the work of all, there was really something that would allow not only the current generation, but future generations, to live better. As has been pointed out, of course, these are circumstances that one does not always encounter politically in one's life, so thank you all for making this possible.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – The signing of the Paris Agreement is a real success that we attribute to all humanity, without neglecting the role played in this process by the European Parliament. In order to truly understand the success of this conference, it is enough to look at the results of all the previous climate change conferences, which have proved totally ineffective. Limiting global temperature warming to 2 degrees Celsius and committing efforts to reach 1.5 degrees over time is a goal that will result in technological innovation and extensive investment. Therefore, all States must react as soon as possible with a view to signing and ratifying the agreement. The European Union must remain an example to the other world actors and be the first signatory to the agreement, as the process will be completed after ratification by all Member States.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. – The agreement reached at COP 21 is important; it is expected to be signed enthusiastically by the States and essentially put into action. In Paris, I checked in detail the commitment and responsibility shown by the different interlocutors. Now, it is everyone's duty to make what has been established consequential. The identification of the impact of industrial society on climate change is not recent. In 1957, oceanographer Roger Revelle pointed out that we are subjecting the planet to a large-scale geophysical experience never tested and impossible to repeat. Basically, industrial society began to release into the atmosphere, in a very short period of time, the carbon sequestered by forests for millions of years and which was the guarantor of life on the planet. Something very wrong was happening. But in a business-based society, the political discourse of denial has blocked the need for change. I've heard CEO of oil companies refer to oil, fossil fuels, as "stored solar energy," shuffling and distracting attention. Quoting pope Francis' recent encyclical: "... the social and environmental responsibility of companies is in most cases reduced to a number of advertising and image actions."

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: I would also ask that interviews be conducted not here in the Chamber, but outside. I would like to ask to have interviews taken outside of the hall and not inside. Thank you very much. The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the humanitarian situation in Yemen (2016/2515 (RSP)).

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would first of all like to thank this Parliament for holding this important and very timely debate to discuss the humanitarian situation in Yemen. Let us face it, Yemen is too much of a neglected, even forgotten, crisis. It is absolutely necessary that we devote attention to what has been described as a humanitarian crisis of catastrophic proportions, surpassing all others when measured by the number of people in need of immediate assistance. In spite of repeated international condemnation, we are witnessing continuous disregard for the very basic principles of international humanitarian law and human rights law. Civilians and civilian infrastructures are being targeted by all parties to the conflict on an almost daily basis. We are particularly concerned by the recent attacks on Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF). Their facilities in Yemen have been attacked, leading to casualties which are yet another example of the violations of international law that occur during this war. The intensity of the humanitarian crisis is constantly on the rise. Humanitarian organisations estimate that 21.2 million Yemeni people – that is 82% of the total population – are in need of humanitarian assistance; 14.4 million are suffering from food insecurity; 14.1 million are in need of health care and 19.3 million lack access to water and sanitation.  The European Union has been actively contributing to efforts aimed at resolving the current conflict and restoring basic rights for ordinary Yemenis. We are doing so on several tracks. On the humanitarian front, the Commission increased its emergency assistance for Yemen by EUR 17 million in December, bringing the total amount of Commission support in the crisis to EUR 52 million for 2015. Some Member States already contribute to emergency and humanitarian assistance and more will follow. The funding benefits the most vulnerable people, including internally displaced persons, refugees, migrants trapped in Yemen and those affected by the pre-existing nutrition and food crisis, all of whose situations have deteriorated due to the conflict. The European Union will continue to call on all parties to allow access for delivery of humanitarian aid. However, the level of humanitarian funding is only one aspect of the problem. We know this. With a population dependent on imports for 90% of its basic needs, the lifting of all restrictions on commercial imports is equally important. In this respect the European Union is working very closely with the United Nations and other partners to expedite the implementation of the United Nations verification and inspection mechanism to allow the flow of humanitarian and commercial goods into Yemen, to which it is contributing EUR 2 million. The second track is political. The escalation of hostilities in the second half of 2014, and more prominently since March 2015, has gravely obstructed the achievements and the implementation of the Yemeni transition and have left the country on the brink of a humanitarian disaster. The European Union, as stated in the conclusions of 20 April and 16 November 2015, strongly believes that the solution to this crisis must be a political one. Achieving an inclusive political settlement, fully in line with the framework provided by the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) initiative, the outcomes of the National Dialogue Conference and relevant United Nations Security Council resolutions is the only sustainable way to alleviate the plight of the Yemeni people. After United Nations facilitated talks in Geneva in June, a second round was held in Bern, Switzerland in December 2015. The European Union is closely coordinating with the United Nations to continue playing a helpful role with the parties to ensure that the third meeting can take place in the coming days.  The conflict has now involved a number of regional players. We encourage all relevant actors to play a positive role towards a lasting political solution of the crisis. One of the main concerns of the European Union remains the implementation of immediate steps leading to a durable ceasefire. Previous ceasefires have failed to take hold due to multiple violations by the parties and it is crucial that the parties implement confidence-building measures, including the full respect of international human rights and humanitarian law and the release of political prisoners. Permanent access for humanitarian and emergency assistance to reach the suffering population, in particular in the city of Taiz, but also in Saada and other affected regions, must be guaranteed.  In Yemen’s dramatic situation, ensuring accountability for violations is an important part of the process to achieve a lasting settlement in the current conflict. The United Nations Human Rights Council adopted a compromise resolution on 2 October 2015 on technical assistance and capacity building for Yemen in the field of human rights, which sets the conditions for a national commission of inquiry, which the EU expects to work independently. I reiterate our call for the independent investigation of all alleged violations of international human rights law and international humanitarian law. The European Union looks forward to the High Commissioner’s oral update at the Council’s 31st session and to a comprehensive written report during its 33rd session.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Yemen is a threefold emergency: humanitarian, security and political. On the humanitarian front, first of all, the situation in Yemen, after less than a year of conflict, is almost worse than that of Syria after five years. It is one of the most serious humanitarian crises at present, according to the United Nations. The current political commitment, however, does not reflect this. We must call on Member States and the rest of the international community to contribute more to the revised humanitarian response plan. I would add that we must be careful that humanitarian aid is impartial towards civilians who are victims of this civil war. From a security point of view, we know that the threat is twofold. The vacuum left by a failed state and this civil war is already exploited by al-Qaeda and Daesh. Moreover, the real risk, as I have already said, is the extension and junction of several areas of instability and insecurity. Yemen is like a link between the Arabian Peninsula and Africa. Let us anticipate this danger even further beyond the emergency humanitarian aid that the Union has provided to Somalia and Djibouti. Finally, politically, the European Union has a full role to play. I have two points: on the one hand, we must support the efforts of the United Nations to get the negotiations started, and do more to keep Yemen on the agenda. On the other hand, from a medium- and long-term perspective, let us invest even more in strengthening our political relations with the Gulf and Arab League countries to build a partnership. Without this, we would prove that we have not learned the lessons of the conflicts that have erupted in some of the "Arab Spring" countries, whose historical and geopolitical roots are multiple.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, when a humanitarian crisis comes from a war, especially if it is an internal conflict of a country, the fundamental objective must be to achieve the cessation of hostilities and to seek a just and sustainable peace. For while the conflict lasts what occurs is, first of all, the loss of human life; secondly, the destruction of essential infrastructures that most have to do with the needs of those who have less access to water, education or health care; and, thirdly, population displacement and the loss of opportunities for an entire generation as well. And, from a humanitarian point of view, there is a constant violation of human rights and ignorance of the principles of humanitarian action. All these kinds of issues focus on the situation we are experiencing in Yemen. As the representative of the Council and also in this case of the Commission pointed out, in Yemen almost 80% of the population – more than twenty million people – has needs, and continued human rights violations are taking place.
