My group, and particularly I, as head of humanitarian action — the permanent rapporteur of this Parliament — support the European Council's effort in April and November to support the United Nations in the search for safe and sustainable peace, with cessation of hostilities, with respect for human rights and with a commitment to humanitarian access to meet the needs of the millions of people who currently lack the most essential.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, as one of the poorest countries in the world, reliant upon imports for over 90% of its food even before the outbreak of the war, Yemen is now facing an extreme humanitarian crisis and the UN and other aid agencies have made it quite clear in their assessment that the situation is extremely dire.  The EU and its Member States have given much money in aid, with my own country, the UK, having invested some GBP 250 million in aid over the last five years. But now, however, we must consider the futility of sending such money to Yemen only for these investments to be bombed and destroyed by the military attacks of Saudi Arabia. Repeated sources show that public buildings, vital infrastructure and civilian areas have been tragically hit by the Saudis’ very poorly targeted bombing campaigns, the results of which have been over 6 000 civilians killed to date. Saudi Arabia and Iran’s ongoing race for regional, sectarian supremacy is growing ever bolder, and it is those in the periphery that are most suffering now as they become caught up in this terrible proxy war.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the people in Yemen are slowly dying of hunger and disease and they are wiped out by bombings by the coalition that is ‘Saudi-led’, but it is followed by the US and the UK. Prime Minister Cameron this week said: ‘We are trying to do everything we can to make sure that the work done by Saudi Arabia is properly targeted’. Well, obviously this is not working. It is a disgrace that your proposals – and by this I mean those of the Dutch Government, to have an inquiry into the war crimes perpetrated in Yemen through the UN – were actively boycotted by Saudi Arabia, and also that France and the UK did not support the Netherlands. The EU, if it wants to be strong, needs a common position. In the Committee on Foreign Affairs you spoke of exporting stability which I believe is a noble goal, but it should start by the EU seeking to end the export of weapons to Saudi Arabia. I would like to ask you whether you are willing to work towards an embargo in the Council, at least of bombs, fighter jets and combat helicopters, and whether you are willing to pressure anyone who may be using cluster bombs, which are disproportionate and are allegedly used in Yemen. I want to ask whether you agree that the violence in Yemen underlines the need for the EU to review its relationship with Saudi Arabia and actually make it more even-handed with the relationship we have with the Islamic Republic of Iran. After the nuclear deal, there is room to engage that country also with regard to ending the violence in Yemen. Iran, like Saudi Arabia, must be pushed to be a part of the solution and end the violence in the Middle East. Lastly, the blockades of sea, land and air have hampered humanitarian aid delivery which is so desperately needed and this hampering kills people, according to Doctors Without Borders, who also claim that people have stopped coming to hospitals because they believe these have been targeted in a worrying pattern. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: blue-card question. – You specifically mentioned the United Kingdom, as I gather, trying to veto or prevent an investigation proposed by Holland into war crimes in the Yemen. Do you have any direct evidence to suggest that Saudi Arabia has deliberately targeted hospitals or schools? There are reports, but if your government has got such evidence, why does it not go public about it? Because clearly that is a very serious accusation, and I would be ashamed to think that the United Kingdom would try and protect such a thing.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you, Mr Tannock, for your question. I think there are two issues in my remarks which may have been confused. One is the proposal by the Dutch Government – I am sure Minister Koenders can elaborate if that is necessary – that was supposed to be executed by the UN and which was successfully blocked – I would say unfortunately, because I think an independent inquiry into the crimes perpetrated is key. What I was citing in terms of a pattern of targeted attacks on hospitals is a claim that is made by the respected international NGO ‘Doctors Without Borders’. I was not attributing that observation to the Dutch Government but citing what ‘Doctors Without Borders’ has said it observes.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, the scene of a formidable popular movement in 2011, Yemen has been at the centre of a deadly conflict between a Saudi-led coalition and the Houthis, allied with former President Saleh's forces, for the past ten months. In the name of a binary reading grid, we are led to believe that there is only an internal conflict between "good" Sunnis and "bad" Shiites - some supported by Saudi Arabia, aspiring to stability at its borders, and others by an Iran in need of regional influence. It is to ignore the history of the country, the alliance games of each other and the complexity of the political and social situation. One thing is certain: the Yemeni population, already among the poorest in the world, is paying the price for a mixture of underdevelopment, competition between AQAP and Daesh, and the warmongering of Saudi Arabia, a kingdom with medieval practices, on which Westerners turn a blind eye. Indeed, how long will Yemen remain a forgotten conflict? Will the mistakes of the Syrian conflict be repeated? We must not be satisfied with denunciation or humanitarian aid. We must act on the actors and not just hide behind the United Nations and the United States.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Since March 2015, the conflict in Yemen has escalated, plunging the country into a humanitarian catastrophe. The victims are civilians, including two million children, who are at risk of malnutrition. It is essential that the EU and the Member States ensure that sufficient humanitarian aid is available to Yemen. The conflict in Yemen is confronted by two fragile alliances: in the north, the Houthi rebels, allied with former President Salih. President Hadi's camp cooperates with political forces, including separatists from the south.  The conflict is complicated by the interference of the regional powers Saudi Arabia and Iran. The Houthi rebels receive weapons from Iran. Saudi Arabia intervenes directly with its air force. Both camps violate international law. More than 2,800 civilians have already been killed by both Saudi airstrikes and rocket fire from Houthi rebels. Civilian targets bombed by the coalition include hospitals, schools and food warehouses. The United Nations reports on cluster bomb operations. The escalation of the conflict mainly benefits jihadist groups such as Al-Qaeda or Da'esh. We therefore call for a ban on any arms deliveries to the parties to the conflict, including Saudi Arabia. Instead of instaging further escalation through arms deliveries, a political solution must be found under the leadership of the UN.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what is the best way to silence internal dissent? It is often precisely to focus on the external enemy, raising the total threat before which any other divergence must be set aside, on pain of being considered traitors or terrorists. It is precisely this that the Saudis must have thought of embarking on yet another proxy war against the Iranians in Yemen, sponsors of the large Houthi minority.  The coalition he commands does not advance, however, according to plan. It was supposed to be the tool to show off the country's renewed military ambitions and instead the conquests of Aden and the most recent Dubab, crucial for the control of the Bab el Mandeb Strait, have caused thousands of deaths, 60% as a result of indiscriminate air strikes, many of them women and children, 3 million displaced persons, 16 million Yemenis without drinking water and without health care and in the meantime the ceasefire fails and the start of the peace talks is moving away. What is even more serious is the very high number of human rights violations verified by the United Nations Organisation itself: more than eight thousand since April 2015, when the coalition was already under the aegis of UN Resolution 2216. Secretary-General Ban Ki Moon is beginning to raise doubts about saudi management. Frankly, I wonder what else needs to happen before an official inquiry is opened, the least that needs to be done. I do not want to have to think that all this distraction from so many European states and the United States, which sometimes logistically support intelligence, as happened in Operation Decisive Storm, Saudi Arabia, is seen as the price to be paid to avoid a total public attack by Saudi Arabia itself on the Iran nuclear deal. I would ask the High Representative, who is not here today, but I would ask the Minister not to spare any effort to relaunch the peace process, but to take a firm line in condemning the violence and demanding such an investigation, because otherwise, by turning a blind eye to protecting profit, we will end up blind to the indispensable.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, in her statement of 10 January, the High Representative condemned the new bombing of a hospital in northern Yemen, which left six people dead and several seriously injured, including doctors Without Borders (MSF) staff. She referred to , and I quote - "attacks that deliberately target humanitarian operations and civilians". But the Commission is careful not to demand an investigation, as MSF is calling for. I recall that this is the third hospital run by MSF that is directly targeted by the anti-Shiite coalition led by Saudi Arabia. Similarly, we do not intend to condemn the use of cluster munitions by the Saudis, weapons that are prohibited by a UN convention signed in 2008. Ah! I am sorry, I forgot that our Saudi friends got with their petrodollars to preside over the HUMAN rights council of that same UN. But let me remind you that in the days when there were only poor Bedouins in Saudi Arabia, Yemen was already a great civilization — that of the Queen of Sheba, of which the Old Testament speaks. So let's stop letting Yemenis die under Saudi bombs and prevent irreparable destruction of their multi-millennial heritage!

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the seriousness of the situation in Yemen should require closer cooperation between humanitarian organisations and the parties involved. We are therefore expressing our deepest concern because, at the very heart of the humanitarian crisis that is ravaging the population, we have also seen conflicts between those who, on the other hand, should be on the same side in order to find solutions. We are particularly concerned about what the population is experiencing: hospitals, it has been mentioned, are short of basic medicines, the world food programme has found that around 13 million people are at risk of starvation, including 6 million in desperate need of food assistance. And the news we have gathered says that the Saudi-led coalition has caused more than 2,500 civilian casualties and bombings at medicine depots and relief centers. I therefore take advantage of this debate to strongly renew the call for immediate diplomatic action to be taken in support of the Yemeni people and for a humanitarian corridor to be created with the imposition of a ceasefire, giving new impetus to the peace negotiations.

name: Javier NART
text: – Mr President, the conflict in Yemen is a historic conflict. I was there in 1975 as a war correspondent and nothing has changed.  The Bakils against the Sunnis, that is, Zaidí, in this case under the name of Ansar Allah — some call them Houthis – and, moreover, Saudi Arabia intervening, as it has intervened since 1920, in continuous wars, to have decisive influence in Yemen. Right now, conflict is a historic conflict. It is one of many that the region has been suffering. The big problem right now is the brutal, criminal intervention of Saudi Arabia, which, in an internal conflict, also turns it into a massacre, because of its hegemonic intention in the area. It is a hegemonic intervention that also takes place through mercenaries, including almost three thousand Colombians. It's about time we told our so-called friends enough. We cannot establish peace in Yemen if the first thing we do not establish is the expulsion of external agents from aggression into an internal conflict. I therefore fully agree with the peace conference, but to reach it we must expel the aggressors, in this case the Saudis.

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, I am in close contact with the leaders of the South Arabian Assembly who work within the Southern Movement seeking an independent South Yemen. I am disturbed that despite the best efforts of the Southern Movement and the militia attached to their cause, they remain under siege in Aden from forces allied to Sunni fundamentalists rather than Iranian-backed Houthis. In recent weeks Southern Movement supporters managed to free Aden and the surrounding areas, but the lack of support from Saudi Arabia has seen the situation deteriorate again, allowing extremist forces back.  I have been told that Southern Movement forces are ready and able to bring the south under control and that they have no intention of crossing into what was north Yemen. They indicate that the potentially stabilising elements in Yemen are the clans which can bring peace to their areas, yet the Saudis will not allow this. Throughout Yemen the population is suffering and dying because Saudi Arabia and Iran continue to play politics, ensuring no lasting solution to the Yemeni crisis.  If we are serious about securing for Yemen a stable and hopeful future, international actors must actively engage with those on the ground rather than relying on the usual suspects who seem to go around in circles at such a tragic cost.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her So much suffering and so little effort to alleviate that suffering. Substitutes who want to extend their sphere of influence to this strategically important area. 6 000 people have already lost their lives, and every day there are more. Six and a half million people are suffering from hunger. There is hardly any clean water, rarely electricity. This is Yemen today. It is therefore essential that peace negotiations begin as soon as possible. At the same time, it is not possible to stress often enough how important it is that humanitarian organisations in this conflict region can carry out their important work unhindered. We, the European Union, must support the United Nations in ensuring that a lasting ceasefire and then peace negotiations are reached, but we must not, at the same time, as arms exporters, provide additional ammunition for an already explosive situation. Only a broad political alliance, which leads to all parties sitting down at the same table, can resolve this conflict. Hard-won progress, which should put this country back on a safe footing economically, will again turn into piles of rubble after the bombings– from whatever side. The chaos and bloody conflicts in this country are once again benefiting the fighters of al-Qaeda or Da'esh – with direct repercussions for Europe. After all, one of the terrorists is said to have visited a terrorist camp in Yemen during the paris attack.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 6 000 victims, some 3 000 civilians involved, I believe that they are sufficient as data to understand the seriousness of the situation in Yemen, which is certainly nothing new, because Yemen has always been in these difficult conditions, but it has become a real scenario of proxy war, but above all of the war fun of some great powers.  Great powers which – it is good to always remember – are our friends. Because it seems to me that so many things have been proposed, good proclamations have been made, we are favouring the peace process, we are intervening, we are doing this, we are doing the other, but I do not think there is any clarity and firmness in saying that Saudi Arabia, which is the main actress in this conflict, we are selling arms to it. Because it sells them to it, for example, the Italian Government, from which ships with bomb supplies continue to depart, sells them to the United Kingdom, and sells them to the United States of America. And we are always a little too weak to follow what our foreign policy leader has indicated. Perhaps in a case like this, if we want to be credible, we should be a little more rigid and stronger towards Saudi Arabia.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Yemen is literally dramatic. More than 80% of Yemenis need humanitarian assistance. We're talking about 21 million people who are in disi ree. The situation is getting worse by the day, clinics, hospitals and reception centres are being attacked. Of course, the situation is no worse than in other parts of the Middle East. Yemen has been a pawn in the conflict between Saudi Arabia and Iran for years. The political and ideological confrontation between Riyadh and Tehran is also taking place in Sana'a, which is mainly a land of Al Qaeda. It is worrying that the UN human rights representative in Yemen has recently been declared an unseaking person. We must support the UN for an immediate ceasefire. The country is ready to break out, and we must not ignore a convinced fight against terrorism and fundamentalism.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I very much appreciate the efforts shown by the European institutions in dealing with the humanitarian situation in Yemen. However, I find it very unfortunate that we are merely spectators competing between Iran and Saudi Arabia in the region. I think that this would not only be unfortunate, given the role and the finances that we have already sent to these areas as the European Union, but it would also be very shameful in relation to the civilian population. Therefore, at a time when Saudi Arabia has been positioning, say, an actor of military coalitions for a long time, but also a partner of the United States of America and the European Union, I think that we should negotiate with both it and, of course, Iran now and with Iran not to make this region their own firing range. This would be appropriate in view of the position of the European Union and, of course, the protection of the civilian population.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the humanitarian situation in Yemen is serious. Almost two thirds of the population needs help and assistance. The country is the battleground of a war that many analysts call "by proxy" between Saudi Arabia and Iran that challenge each other on sectarian lines for the region's hegemony. The situation is getting worse by the hour. The United Nations ranked the ongoing humanitarian crisis at Level 3, the highest category. 80% of the population, 20 million people, need urgent humanitarian assistance. Bombs spare no one, and once again it is helped civilians and aid workers who are affected. In recent days, for the third time in a few months, a hospital, supported by Médecins sans Frontières, has been affected. The parties to the conflict should immediately refrain from targeting civilian infrastructure. Contempt for humanitarian law, as well as causing innocent victims, hampers efforts to bring about a political solution to the crisis. The European Union must make its voice heard without stuttering and ensure, working together with the international community, a political solution to the crisis.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, last October the head of the Red Cross declared that Yemen, after five months of war, looks like Syria after five years of war. Ten thousand people have been killed since March 2015, many of them civilians, including 630 children. At the same time, a large-scale humanitarian crisis is unfolding as, according to the UN, out of a total population of 21 million, 19 million do not have access to drinking water, 14 million have no access to food and some 320 000 children are malnourished due to the air and naval blockade imposed by Saudi Arabia on a importing country to meet 90% of its needs. After the bombing of a camp of refugees, schools and health units, it came to be added to the list of collateral damage hit a medical center of Doctors Without Borders while at the same time the Arab Alliance is accused by international observers of using cluster bombs. The European Union has a moral duty to recognise war crimes committed in Yemen. The Commission should propose measures against those responsible.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me start with one issue that was mentioned: we cannot be just observers. I think this is a very important statement because we cannot be only observers, and we are not only observers. The present situation in Yemen – I think all of you have mentioned that this afternoon – is of very deep concern to all members of the Council, and I am very glad to speak on behalf of Federica Mogherini, the High Representative, on this issue. Let me just say on a personal note, I have been to Yemen a lot. Yemen was a country where we had a ‘pre-announced’ crisis: a high population growth rate, ecological disasters, a very difficult environment and bad governance, and that combination has led, especially in the region that Yemen finds itself in, to the crisis we are seeing now. It is a catastrophic situation. All the humanitarian actors have described the humanitarian situation as catastrophic – you did, and all of us are extremely concerned. So the question is then, are we observers or not? Let me say that the proactive role, also of the High Representative, is that we are one of the few actors who can speak to all parties and can engage. I think this is important specifically since the humanitarian crisis can only be resolved if it is also in line with progress on a political solution. I think many of you have said that this afternoon, and I can quote many of the people who have spoken this afternoon that this is actually the key issue that we are faced with. Of course, this also concerns issues of human rights. Now the United Nations Human Rights Council – and obviously I am not speaking here in a national position, I have my views as a member of the Dutch Government on this – adopted a compromise resolution – yes, a compromise resolution – on 2 October 2015 which sets out the conditions for a national commission of inquiry which the EU expects to work independently. I want to underline that again here today. I reiterate our call for the independent investigation of all alleged violations of international human rights law and international humanitarian law, and the European Union will therefore also actively follow and expect the High Commissioner’s update at the upcoming Council session, and obviously also a comprehensive written report on this in the future. That is very important. Many of you have raised not only the issue of the humanitarian situation, but also the respect for international humanitarian law. We are aware and concerned by what seems to be credible reports on the use of cluster munitions in populated areas. And we also note – and I think this is important, you asked about investigations – we note with satisfaction that the High Commissioner for Human Rights has seized this matter immediately and will closely follow OHCHR’s investigation into this matter. On the issue of arms, as you know at the moment an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia is not a response to the region’s current challenges, but it is important that the issue concerning common position 2008/944 of the CFSP will be discussed in the Council working group on conventional arms exports, chaired by the EEAS. Many of you asked, obviously, about the regional aspect of all these issues, including on the role of the tension with Saudi Arabia, and to what extent this spat has an impact on Yemen’s UN-facilitated talks. Well, first of all, it should not. It should not. All the international community and all the main regional actors are already actively working, including the High Representative, to support the talks regarding the situation in Yemen, and they must be maintained. Every effort should be made to avoid jeopardising these talks, and I hope also there will be some progress in the coming days. We expect that the process and the meetings can happen, although recent indications tell us that the timing may slip, and early February seems likely now. We fully support the efforts of the UN Special Envoy, Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed, who has been relentlessly travelling to the region and to Yemen to ensure that this is possible. We are comforted by the declarations of the Government of Yemen and the Saudi authorities regarding their commitment – and this is important – to these negotiations, and expect that they will proceed with the aim of implementing a sustainable ceasefire and confidence-building steps leading to the implementation of United Nations Security Council Resolution 2216. On the issue of Médecins Sans Frontières, this is also an issue that for very good reasons is being raised by the members of the European Parliament. We have seen more attacks on MSF in recent weeks and months in various places around the world, and of course that needs investigation. I also expect the High Commissioner for Human Rights to report on this in the coming discussions that I have mentioned. The question was whether we are reaching out to Tehran: yes, we are. Iran has been politically supportive of the Houthi movement, and it is our hope that it will now positively use its privileged contacts with that group to promote a peaceful settlement. Iran is an important regional player – I could go into all the details, but we discussed this last night – but the EU encourages and is also in a position to talk to the parties, to encourage the Iranian authorities to play a constructive role towards lasting political settlement in the region, including in Yemen because this is absolutely crucial. Some of you mentioned, correctly, that if that does not happen then obviously it is only ISIS and other groups of an extremist nature that will profit from that. I would like to thank you very much, Madam President, for giving me the possibility to talk about Yemen. I feel that this is not only very urgent, if you look at the number of people who are in extreme distress, but it requires all the political attention that you have given it this afternoon. We have learned the hard way that instability in the wider Gulf and Middle East region can have a direct impact also on our own stability and security. This crisis will not only come to an end through an inclusive political settlement, but we will have a physical and social reconstruction of the country. If you go to Sana'a even today you will see the destruction of the old parts of the city. It is an enormous task which no government can bear alone, so I am sure that massive international support will be necessary. In any case, the European Union intends to continue engaging its Member States and partners in the region towards a concerted, coordinated and strategic approach by the international community and the Government of Yemen to the country’s reconstruction, and stands ready to play its part in efforts for the benefit of all Yemenis.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Thank you, Minister, also for your detailed explanations. The debate is closed. The vote will take place during the next part-session, not tomorrow. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. – I express my deep concern about the dramatic and violent conflict, as well as the serious humanitarian crisis in Yemen, in which 21 million people, representing 80% of the population, are in urgent need of aid and 6 million people need immediate vital assistance. While fighting continues in several areas, humanitarian access to the provision of essential food and fuel supplies remains extremely limited. I strongly condemn the series of attacks on medical personnel and facilities and i strongly believe that it is necessary for the parties to the conflict to respect international humanitarian law and international human rights law. It is particularly important that all parties to the conflict take firm action against terrorist groups, which pose a direct threat internally and externally. Only a broad political consensus in the UN-led negotiations can provide a lasting solution, restore peace and preserve Yemen's unity, sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity. The European Union must provide support to all regional actors, who should act responsibly and constructively to provide the possibility of a de-radicalisation of the crisis and to avoid the spread of regional instability.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in south-eastern Turkey (2016/2530(RSP)).

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I welcome the opportunity to join you today. The continued deterioration of the overall security situation in the south-east of Turkey is extremely disquieting. The EU has repeatedly expressed its concerns about the situation, including in its latest statements of 22 December and then recently on 16 January, and is following developments closely. Some of the political problems on both sides have also been exacerbated by the current crisis, including the threat from Daesh, as demonstrated by the latest attack in Istanbul on 12 January and the attacks last year in Suruç and Ankara. However, a stable south-east is important, not just for Turkey from a political, economic and security perspective, but for the European Union and the wider region as well. We absolutely need to preserve the political space which we have worked hard to create so that a transition can start in Syria. The only possible and effective response is to deal with the conflicts that we have in our region in a united way. This will be the best way to effectively counter and defeat Daesh on the ground. We must be very careful not to allow the breakdown of the Kurdish peace process and fuel further tensions in the southeast. In all our interactions with Turkey, we continue to urge all parties to guarantee the rule of law in the country and to call for an immediate ceasefire and an urgent return to the Kurdish peace process. The high-level political dialogue on 25 January 2016 will be another opportunity to raise these issues.  Important progress has been made over the past two years, and this should not be thrown away. The peace process remains the best opportunity in a generation to solve a conflict that has claimed far too many lives. We have also been clear that the PKK must cease its attacks against Turkey. It must stop declaring autonomous districts within the south-east and re-engage in political dialogue. Resuming talks and negotiations within the peace process is the only way forward.  We will continue to reassure Turkey that the European Union takes the PKK threat very seriously, and that the EU Member States have also acted robustly against the PKK. The PKK has been a listed organisation for the purposes of fuel sanctions since 2002. The Council unanimously endorsed this decision in March 2015, and it will remain so for the foreseeable future. However, while I recognise Turkey’s legitimate right to defend itself against the PKK, we have also emphasised –and will continue to emphasise – in our dialogue with the Turkish authorities, that measures taken against the PKK must be proportionate, targeted and should not endanger the democratic political dialogue. The measures currently being taken by security services in the south-east, which includes the use of long-lasting curfews, have resulted in extreme disruptions to essential services such as healthcare and means of communication. The proportionality and legality of such operations must be ensured, and should comply with international human rights standards. Some of the sensitivities have existed for decades, and it will require real courage from all parties to address these long-standing and deeply-felt issues.  The Commission will work with the new government on all reforms in the areas of the rule of law and fundamental rights, freedom of religion and expression. I look forward very much to hearing the views of the honourable Members of Parliament.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has What is the reality in the Turkish south-east?  A state of emergency for weeks. For fifty days curfew in Diyarbakir. Turkish security forces use heavy weapons against the civilian population. Many people, including children, women, the elderly, are dead! Dead people lie in the streets, cannot be rescued for days, because everything that moves is shot at.  Similar situations exist in other cities: another 17 Kurdish cities and neighborhoods – it is like a siege. There are supply shortages, not only not for electricity, telephone and internet, but there is no access to food, water and electricity for days. The situation is inhumane! People are leaving the cities, they are not allowed to return. More than a million people are affected. 250 000 people are already on the run.  It is alleged, Commissioner, that it is a fight against the PKK. But in fact it is a fight against the Kurds, on the backs of the civilian population. The southeast has become a war zone. It cannot and must not be the case that we behave in such a moderate way that we remain silent on this. It must not be the case that the Member States want to look the other way because of the refugee crisis and even reward the Turkish Government with the opening of new negotiating chapters. Turkey is heading for a civil war. The EU must actively intervene and mediate in order to continue the peace process and resume it. It is a requirement of humanity and of our European values that we interfere. We have a responsibility. One final sentence, Madam President. It is in our own interest to prevent an exodus, otherwise there will be a new wave of refugees from the Kurds into the EU.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the situation in the southeast of Turkey is very worrying. Since the fighting between the PKK and the state security forces restarted this summer, the situation on the ground is deteriorating still further. Imagine living in the Silopi, Cizre or Sur districts. Most people left their houses in a hurry when an open-ended, round-the-clock curfew was declared in early December. At that time, more than 200 000 people had to flee. Heavy fighting is going on day and night between the security forces and the PKK youth militias who have built barricades and dug trenches in the middle of these neighbourhoods. The anti-terrorism operations heavily affect the civilian population: not being able to leave your house for more than 40 days; so-called Esedullah forces who intimidate the local population; and an increasing number of civilian deaths, including of children and elderly people. How is it possible that a 16-year-old boy can bleed to death on the streets without receiving any medical aid? The attacks by the PKK last week killing police officers and their family members can in no way be justified, but why are there crackdowns on peaceful protesters? In this regard, I am also gravely concerned about the intimidation and prosecution of more than 1 000 academics who signed a petition calling for peace. How can reasonable people calling for the violence to stop be labelled traitors and promoters of terrorism? The right of Turkey to fight against terrorism is not questioned here today. The general feeling, however, is that the operations are a collective punishment rather than aiming at restoring public order. It is time that the EU made a strong and determined call for a ceasefire and for the peace talks to be restarted. The curfews must be lifted and those people who can be part of a peace campaign must be empowered and supported.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr Hahn, I have listened carefully to what you have said, but I must join the previous speakers. The reality is that the Turkish army has recreated Kurdistan in a war zone and in a massacre. The violence is raging arbitrarily through the Kurdish villages, entire neighbourhoods are being thriated, residents are waiting in their shelters until the violence stops and the bodies are lying on the streets. In essence, this violence is the result of the growing authoritarianism of Erdogan and his party. His priority is not the fight against IS, his priority is absolute power and the fight against the Kurds.  Western allies are keeping quiet: no criticism, no condemnation. We need Erdogan to contain the refugee crisis, and that is why, Mr Hahn, I am ashamed, deeply ashamed that the European Union does not dare to protect its backbone to defend kurdish citizens, to protect them. This old, proud people in the region, the only reliable ally in the fight against IS, are getting a knife in the back. I want to know what the European Commission will do. Accession talks are resumed. Make it a priority of the protection of minorities, make it a condition. I thought history had taught us that silence is never the right choice.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for The situation in south-eastern Turkey is terrible, as you have rightly described here, it really resembles a war zone. There is much that can be blamed on the Turkish Government in this context. What cannot be blamed on her is that she has started this conflict. On 22 July 2015, the PKK ended the ceasefire and the peace process by killing two Turkish policemen in their car. That was the beginning of the argument. What the PKK has completely misjudged is that the Turkish Government in Ankara and the Turkish armed forces were almost grateful for this opportunity to re-inflame a conflict which , and Here I fully agree with Mr Demesmaeker – is of course appropriate for an increasingly authoritarian style of government by Mr Erdogan. This attack on the two policemen took place between the two rounds of elections in Turkey last year, and the AKP wanted to regain its absolute majority, which it had lost in June, in the autumn. That is exactly what she has succeeded in doing. Since then, this conflict has entered the way it is now. Of course, the peace process must be revived and, of course, the PKK must realise that it can never defeat Turkey militarily. Their gains in Syria, along with the PYD, the Democratic Union Party, may underscore the illusion that it can achieve something in southeastern Turkey by military means. That is nonsense! It will only work politically. And it is high time for the PKK to understand exactly that. But also for Turkey, the government in Ankara. It must understand that autonomy, independence and cultural self-determination of the Kurdish areas in south-eastern Turkey must be more than just development aid, more than just economic measures. There must be a form of self-government that really deserves the name. And on what is concerned with academics and increasing authoritarianism, Mrs Piri has said everything right.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I come from a meeting of the European Union-Turkey Joint Committee attended by the Country's Ambassador. I have to tell you that the Representative of the Commission has put almost all the burden of responsibility for what is happening in south-eastern Turkey on the PKK. Is it possible that an area of half a million people has been under house arrest for two months and that all these people belong to the PKK? I don't think there are many people who can believe that. But if it is, then it is a revolution and not a terrorist activity of so many people. I have just received a message from an HTP MP who is trapped in a house in the Sur area. Maybe – he told me – that phone call he made was the last phone call he made in his life. I think we are faced with a problem that Turkey has to deal with because its obligations are great. I believe that the European Union's task is to get this message across clearly to Turkey.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the situation in the south-east of Turkey is indeed deplorable, as everybody has said. It is disastrous, and civilians are being killed almost every day. But let us not forget that the situation is not only very bad in the Kurdish areas; it is very bad all over Turkey. For example, we had the peace call from the academics. It is really great that they are doing it – they are really heroes. But what happens is not that they get applauded by all sides, but rather they are being threatened by President Erdoğan and even threatened by a mafia boss. Their lives and their freedom are under threat, and we should do everything we can to support them. But while most of us probably agree about the problems in the south-east and all over Turkey, we might not all have the same ideas about what we ourselves, as the EU, contributed to these problems, and what we are going to do about that now. To my mind, it was a big mistake to have the accession negotiations with Turkey blocked by a couple of Member States, because that gave Erdoğan the possibility to instrumentalise the problems in the accession process at home in his internal policies. He did that well, and that is also our fault. So let us not repeat this mistake. As for what to do now, the European Union needs always to be strong on human rights, also with regard to Turkey. We need to, and should, cooperate with Turkey on refugees in order to help Turkey cope with the situation, but also to help refugees. But under no circumstances should we trade away human rights at the cost of the human rights of refugees.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, Turkey’s treatment of the Kurdish people, not just within their own borders but also against those bravely fighting IS in Iraq and Syria, is a scandal. All will have been pleased when the armed conflict between Turkey and the PKK was brought to a mostly peaceful conclusion, yet now we are witnessing the Turkish authorities rekindle that fight. What is worse is that, not content with President Erdoğan’s attack on a free press and journalists, his wrath is now being directed towards the Kurdish people. Damningly, evidence mounts highlighting collusion between Turkish authorities and Islamic State in the region, including support for oppressive actions towards Kurds. This is a timely reminder of the fundamental differences between Turkish and European values and is further proof that Turkey must never be allowed to join the European Union.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Western values of freedom, democracy and human rights do not go hand in hand with Islam, with Islamic Turkey. Every day, Turkey proves this with the jailing of political opponents and then the silence of critical journalists. And now it's shelling and terrorizing its own civilian population in the southeast.  Because the Commission believes that the Beast of Ankara will stop refugees, it is closing its eyes to these crimes against humanity and to its blackmail policy. I ask Mr Hahn: do you really think that those millions of refugees who were safely in their Turkish camps have been driven towards the EU by a gust of wind or have they been given a boost by the Turkish government? You must stop supporting the Ottoman Empire and extend it to the North Sea. What happened to the Armenians, what is happening now with the Kurdish people is our foreland.  Let me be crystal clear: Turkey is not part of Europe. Condemn Turkey and stop negotiating accession to the European Union.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Mr de Graaff, let me first reply to you. I find it intolerable and indecent to take millions and millions of Muslims into arrest ingessoled when one in Turkey, such as Mr Erdogan, is increasingly pushing law and law into the background and oppressing others. That is quite a naughty thing, and we must not accept it in this way. Secondly, it is true that terrorist attacks find our firm opposition, and this applies to all types of terrorism, including in Turkey. It is also true that Vice-President Timmermans has negotiated an agreement with the Turkish Government that includes joint efforts to mitigate the refugee crisis. It is also true that this deal involves more negotiations on accession. Unfortunately, they have chosen the wrong chapters. If they had taken Chapters 23 and 24, namely law and freedom, we would have had a discussion with Turkey on the issues we are discussing today. That would have been very important to me. It is up to the Commission to make it clear that we are promoting the peace process. You do. Clear words are needed against the Turkish President and his policies, because these hundreds of thousands of Kurds are not all members of the PKK. It is about our credibility that we can solve problems together with the Turks, but therefore do not become blind and deaf.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Madam President, the policies of the Turkish Government are becoming increasingly erratic and authoritarian. The recent arrest of 27 academics is an extension of the already routine harassment and detention of journalists. Meanwhile, as a result of Turkey’s military campaign against the PKK, which is banned by the EU as a terrorist organisation, hundreds of Kurdish civilians have been killed and disproportionate curfews and the restriction of civil liberties are being imposed in Kurdish areas. Such a view is emblematic of the Turkish authorities’ continued view that it is the Kurds that should be viewed as the biggest threat in the region, rather than Islamist terrorists such as ISIS. As evidenced by its policy in Syria, Turkey remains focused on preventing the emergence of a Kurdish enclave, rather than fully committing itself to fighting ISIS. Furthermore, there is evidence that Turkey is failing to cooperate in stemming the flow of migrants to Europe, and it is even, as reported in the British press, allegedly deporting some refugees back to Syria. It is time that EU leaders called on Turkey to live up to its NATO and EU candidate commitments rather than continually apologising for its slide towards autocracy under President Erdoğan. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". – So I have listened carefully: there is a relapse into authoritarianism, there is collusion between the Turkish Government and Sunni militias in Iraq, there is a violation of the ban on deportation, that is, non-refoulement to Syria, there is an erratic autocratic behaviour of the Turkish Government. My question, Charles, is that the Conservatives in Britain have always been the strongest supporters of Turkey's accession to the EU. Has this attitude changed?

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: blue-card answer. – I think I asked you, Count Lambsdorff, in the last debate over Turkey whether you would be in favour of withholding any of the pre-accession funds, to which you gave me a very opaque answer. I will give you the simple answer that it remains the official party view of the Conservative Party and the British Government that Turkey should, at some stage, become a member of the European Union. Nevertheless, there are grave concerns about the change of course that Turkey has adopted in the last few years and it is a very long way away from being fit to be a member of the European Union at present. In the meantime, we have to ensure that Britain remains a member of the European Union.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Madam President, the deal on migration that Mr Timmermans rushed through at the most unfortunate moment seems to be the reason why the very dangerous situation in the south-east of Turkey is being met with deafening silence from the EU and its Member States, and that must end. Many topics other than migration need to be addressed – human rights and the rule of law and, crucially, the EU must call on the AKP Government to return to the peace negotiating table with the PKK, and they should end the disproportionate collateral damage on civilians.  Terrorism can never be justified and the democratic path for the Kurdish people in Turkey is the key alternative that must be given room, and when academics call for an end to violence that is their freedom. It is essential for the EU to find in Turkey a reliable partner as a candidate Member State, as a NATO partner, and as an active member of the coalition against ISIS. That should be the priority of targets. Let us make sure and be cautious that counter-terrorism is not used as an excuse to restrict the freedoms and rights of people in Turkey altogether.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Madam President, for more than a month, the Turkish army has been carrying out an operation of rare violence in south-eastern Turkey, making this predominantly Kurdish region a war zone with more than 50 cities under curfew. The crackdown is on the elected representatives of the HDP, who are not all Kurds, let alone all members of the PKK, but also on journalists, trade unionists and academics who dared to sign a petition denouncing these operations. The fight against terrorism has a good back. No, it is not the PKK that is at the origin of the conflict: this is Ankara's version. Civilians are the main victims of the conflict, including many women and children, including very young. 5-year-old terrorists: but who are we kidding? Commissioner, the European Union must stop having a unilateral view on this issue. It must weigh its weight to stop the violence, bring the parties back to the negotiating table and force the Turkish government to resume the peace process. The rights of minorities, whether cultural or religious, must be recognized. Discrimination and repression against them must stop. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I think there is an urgent need to organise an official delegation of our Parliament to Turkey.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for "You will be destroyed in the houses, apartments and trenches that you have dug. All Turkish forces will fight until the entire southeast is cleared of terrorists and until peace prevails. We will not give up." That is what President Erdoğan said in a speech on 15 December. It is to be assumed that he wants us to believe that this is his fight against the PKK, but the reality shows that his war in south-eastern Turkey, i.e. northern Kurdistan, is a war against mainly civilians. Over the past four months, more than 160 Civilian Kurds have been killed, most of them women and children. Last night I went through the many videos, news reports and articles I have sent to me in recent months by both Kurds and Turks in Sweden – an information from within that shows something completely different from the image Erdoğan wants to spread to us. And it's scary. One might, for example, ask whether a lot of soldiers really need to overpower a lonely lady. We are on the brink of a civil war and if we do not put pressure on Erdoğan, who will? We cannot look between our fingers forever in exchange for promises to stop the flow of refugees.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I will give you a secret: a few minutes ago, I was still with the Turkey delegation. I represented you in this delegation, which is very important and which, ladies and gentlemen, had not met for ten months. Throughout this period, Turkey's delegation did not meet in the European Parliament. And why? Because at every delegation meeting is present the Turkish ambassador to the European Union and the latter speaks more than any Member present in that delegation. I think it is a denial of democracy. Today, Turkey is present in the European Union, not physically, but through deeds. In relation to the subject we are interested in today, I would like to tell you that there is not a day in Turkey without an attack or murder. Unfortunately, Turkey is at the very centre of our news. The Kurdish people should not be confused with Turkey. I also think that we must pay attention to the fact that, under the guise of fighting Daesh, Turkey has decided to fight its opposition and as such Turkey is once again showing a lack of real democracy in its actions and within the European Union.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Madam President, I will reiterate that I am among the friends and supporters of Turkey and of the strengthening of cooperation between the EU and Turkey. But what is happening today in Turkey is, first of all, detrimental to Turkey’s best interests. The violence and escalation on the south-eastern side of Turkey represent a real danger which should be stopped.  We need first and foremost for political dialogue between the government and the Kurdish representatives to go back to the point where the government of Turkey had already achieved important results in the peace process. Now these achievements have been lost and we are coming to a point which could be a point of no return if the escalation continues further.  I will reiterate that it is first and foremost in the best interests of Turkey to prevent further destabilisation and the escalation of violence which can turn into a civil war. And yes, the EU does have the responsibility – the EU, the Commission, Parliament – to condemn without exception all wrongdoings by our partners, including Turkey. They are our long-term partners that we have to cooperate with on our common challenges, common values, but also to commonly share our values in the future, and have the courage to engage with Turkey on the need to call for an immediate ceasefire, the peace process and official visits in this area which is somehow forbidden to Western access.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the European Union must finally stop blinding itself to the flagrant violations of the rights of the Kurdish people committed by the Turkish army in the country's southeastern provinces. The violence of the Turkish army has forced two hundred thousand people, the majority Kurds, to flee their homes. Entire towns have been blocked and residents have been stranded because of the curfew. Elected mayors and politicians of the pro-Kurdish HDP party are being prosecuted while others are already in jail, in an of authoritarianism on the part of the Turkish government. According to Turkish media, turkey's government wants to have completed this so-called counter-terrorism operation by spring. We warn that the European Union is facing an unprecedented outbreak of military violence and the time it has to intervene under international law is limited. We therefore call on the European Union to take immediate action against Turkey and to close its door on It to Europe, instead of attacking Ankara and tolerating its oriental tertiaries. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Mr Marias, I truly understand that you are a Greek and that is very important, but do you not think that the European Union should intervene in some way and send a letter to President Erdoǧan and our representatives in order to try to broker talks between the Government of Turkey and the Kurdish representatives? Because, you know, destabilisation of Turkey would mean the destabilisation of Greece, and of Europe as well.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), a "blue card" answer. – Mr President, it is a given that the European Union must find ways to force Turkey to finally apply human rights rules. This must be done by taking measures because, so far, the European Union has done nothing but silence Turkey, tolerate human rights violations not only against the Kurds, but also against other Turkish citizens, tolerate violations of international law, tolerate the occupation of 37% of Cyprus at this time, tolerate the presence of troops within a country that is a member of the European Union. Measures must be taken for Turkey to understand what it needs to do. (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: – Madam President, the truth is that it annoys me especially when the situation of refugees fleeing millions of wars and persecution in this region is used or instrumentalized. It is some Member States of the Union and Turkey itself that are doing so. The Turkish state massacres hundreds of Kurdish civilians and the European Union prefers to close its eyes and cover its ears. And that's simply unacceptable.  Commissioner, beyond your good words and intentions, what the facts convey, which reflects the attitude of the Member States, their dealings with Turkey, abandoning the Kurds to their fate, is insane. The European Union cannot remain silent in the face of the systematic violation of the individual and collective rights of the Kurdish people by the Turkish state.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: – Madam President, I first visited this region of Turkey some 15 years ago. A time of martial law, we saw ghost villages, the oppression of the people there, and now we are back to that point. As others have said, that golden possibility of a peace process has been thrown away, not least by a government that could not accept a pro-peace Kurdish-led party beating the prohibitive 10% threshold in the election before last. But we have also seen NATO allies permit Turkish attacks on the PKK in exchange for access to bases in Turkey for attacks on ISIS. The PKK is not ISIS. Yes, it also has carried out attacks against civilians, that must be condemned, but this parity is a really important question that governments need to deal with in order for us to get back to a peace process, and an end to violence across the country, to be able to concentrate on the real threat.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Turkey is a candidate country and we have revived the negotiations.  This status also allows us to ask critical questions. Critical questions on the situation of democracy, the rule of law and human rights. Developments in Turkey in recent weeks are extremely worrying and are linked to the Kurdish question. The current government believes that it can solve this by using force and that it has a carte blanche to do so. After years of talks and rapprochement, we are now back in civil war- That cannot be in our interest.  Commissioner, I call on you to point out to the Turkish side that this is not in our mutual interest. It is important for Europe to appeal to both sides to immediately cease hostilities and to act as mediators. The model could be the peace agreement in Northern Ireland, where all the parties to the conflict – including those who were considered terrorists at the time – have also come to the table.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, the Erdoğan regime condemns citizens in South-Eastern Turkey to starvation through the curfews it has imposed for weeks. It attacks Kurdish towns and villages with heavy weapons and systematically tramples on their inhabitants' rights to life, personal freedom and security, as well as the prohibition of torture. This premeditated massacre and the displacement of hundreds of thousands of Kurds from their homes violates both international law and the Turkish Constitution. The Erdoğan regime denies independent observers access to Kurdish areas and persecutes numerous intellectuals who have denounced its inhumane practices. With its tolerance for these crimes, the European Union is betraying its founding values, those of respect for human dignity and fundamental rights. The attempt to appease the Erdoğan regime is wrong. The only language he can understand is the language of political and economic sanctions.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: S&D). Madam President, very worthy colleagues have faithfully described the situation in South-Eastern Turkey following the escalation of the conflict. I will not repeat their words, but I will repeat the words of Selahattin Demirtaş, president of the HDP. The NDP is a party that is massively supported by the Kurdish minority and not just by it. The DP did not cause the war, the HTP does not guide the conflict, it does not control it. On one side is the hand of President Erdoğan and on the other is the hand of the PKK. That is what President Demirtaş said. I would suggest to this House and Commissioner Hahn that we call on the Turkish National Assembly to take a brave initiative leading to the ceasefire and the peace process. And I would like to add that if it takes courage to take the weapons to protect yourself against asymmetric government violence, it takes even more courage to overcome challenges and lead the peace process.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have co-signed the appeal of the 1 820 Turkish academics and I confirm that worldwide solidarity has been created with the Kurdish people, who have been hit by a deliberate and planned massacre. In dozens of cities the curfew has been permanent for months, food, medicine are lacking. Cities without barricades are also assaulted. Hundreds of people killed are denied burial.  The signatories of the appeal are considered accomplices of terrorism. The Turkish Constitution and international laws are being violated. The fight against terrorism is a pure pretext. The aim is to break up a people that only aspires to be recognised as part of their own country. Thousands of Turks are hoping for European and UN mediation to reopen the negotiations interrupted by Erdogan between the Government and kurdish rebels, so that the massacre can end immediately. In response to a question of mine, Mrs Mogherini says that Erdogan is our ally on migrants and against ISIS. The argument doesn't take a minute. (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support You are indeed making serious personal commitments on this whole issue, and I very much appreciate that. At the same time, do you not think it would be more worthwhile, or would it also be worth using institutional relations? By name, to convene parliamentary assemblies, such as the NATO Parliamentary Assembly, which would otherwise be able to settle this issue institutionally?

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Answer to a blue card question. I can confirm to you that contacts are being made not only with the High Representative, but with the UN and, above all, with the Council of Europe.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, the spiral of violence in Turkey continues. A violence that escalates in the southeast of the country, a spiral of violence that has tinges of collective punishment on the Kurdish community, with tens of thousands displaced, hundreds dead and hundreds of people indiscriminately detained. We must today, here, solemnly, call for a ceasefire, to call for the reassessing of the negotiations that were truncated this summer, as the only formula for resolving the conflict in Turkey today. And at the same time, it should be remembered at a time like this, when we are intensifying our cooperation — which we believe is necessary, probably more necessary than ever — with Turkey, that this cooperation cannot in any case be a currency of change of anything, nor of the management of the refugee crisis, nor can it exempt us from denouncing what we see intolerable , like what's happening in Turkey today. That is why today it is our turn to do so solemnly. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Blue card question. Thank you, Mr President, I wanted to ask my colleague this: if he too believes that Turkey is not doing well, but has certainly not behaved well for a very long time – we are also talking about centuries – about Turkey's history. But why do you think it is right for Turkey to have already given it EUR 10 billion and is preparing to give it another EUR 3 billion? I mean, if you misbehaving, is it fair to give them money?

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Buonanno, I do not think it is right how Turkey behaves on many occasions, but when we talk about money for Turkey there is no talk of money for the Turkish State, nor for the Turkish Government, there is talk of money for refugees who are suffering today and living in Turkey: Syrian refugees. As for the behavior, I often don't think it's right how you behave, but I respect what you say and what you do.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to add my voice forcefully to that of my Socialist colleagues and others, who preceded me in denouncing the serious situation that has been going on for weeks in south-east Turkey, which takes us back to dark years. What is happening cannot go unnoticed by Europe, and so far the demands for a ceasefire have not been heeded. We are now at the point where the violence is in danger of leading to a real civil war without any official investigation into the action of the security forces, nor attention from the international community, despite the fact that the number of displaced persons is now around 300 thousand people. What we are asking the Commission to do is to raise this issue as early as the next visit by High Representative Mogherini to Ankara and, more generally, in all areas of EU-Turkey relations, so that a ceasefire and a relaunch of the peace process can soon be achieved. The European Parliament has always supported the Kurdish peace process and we cannot now hide behind possible political conveniences dictated by Turkey's role in the migration crisis.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I think we can all agree that Turkey is a strategic partner for the European Union. But we also expect that this is a mutual relationship and that the European Union is respected by Turkey and that Turkey will not use this situation to promote its unilateral political interests. So far, it is attacking the population and exploiting this situation. I am very disturbed by the response of Ambassador Yenel, who answered the members of the delegation in the EU-Turkey Joint Parliamentary Committee half an hour ago. He stated that military intervention in turkey's southeast was simply legitimate and necessary. I don't think that's acceptable. I expect the European Commission not to remain silent and to oppose this attack on civilians in the south-east of Turkey.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, since December 2015, several areas of south-east Turkey have been subject to a 24-hour curfew. More than 200,000 people live in the affected areas, much of whom are unable to obtain food or receive medical treatment. The series of arrests involved academics who had signed a call for peace and criticised the ongoing military operations in the south-east of the country is a cause for concern. The petitioners received death threats on social media.  Again, since the curfew was first applied, hundreds of civilians have been killed. This is helping to make the situation of a country, Turkey, which aspires to join the European Union difficult. I will end with the words of Can Dündar, editor of a Turkish opposition newspaper currently in prison, who, addressing Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi, asks not to ignore human rights violations in Turkey in exchange for an agreement on migrants. I turn this thought to the House.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, there is a civil war in southeastern Turkey. That's the right word. This war has been fought for decades, and has now been intensified by the neo-Sunni government of Erdogan and Davutoglu. At the same time, this government has been fighting illegally and illegally occupying territories in Syria and Iraq, and has continued to occupy Greek Cyprus for decades.  At the same time, this same government continues and carries out ethnic cleansing and genocide in Kurdish territories, where the Kurds are in both Syria and Iraq. These are the right words, and I am astonished that there are colleagues in this room who are made that they do not understand and do not know. At the same time, the European Union has committed pure political suicide by lodged with Erdogan's racketeering, promising him billions to continue to fight these fighting. I argue that this is suicide and argue that the government's behavior in Ankara towards the Kurds is genocide, ethnic cleansing, and it must be terminated, as well as negotiations with this country, which has no place in the European Union, because it is not European and because it continues to do such things.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, Turkey is flirting with authoritarianism. Erdoğan builds, with Europe's tolerance, his modern Turkish Empire on the corpses of Kurdish civilians and the plight of millions of refugees, on the wreckage of the Republic, the rule of law and fundamental rights, on the absence of freedom of expression, independence of justice and freedom of the press, with mass purges in the public administration and with arrests and accusations of national treason of dissident academics and Kurdish citizens and politicians. Curfews, military and police violence are creating ghost towns with hundreds of thousands displaced. Turkey is indifferent to both the action plan you have agreed on the refugee issue and the traffickers. There are 31,000 refugees who crossed the Aegean Sea this month with 8 and 9 bofors. So who in this Chamber can argue that this situation refers to a safe country?  From this step, ladies and gentlemen, I call on the High Representative to take immediate initiatives to get the two sides back to the negotiating table and to end the perpetual cycle of escalating violence.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Madam President, we all know that what is happening in the Kurdish provinces cannot be explained – as the Government intends – simply in terms of combating terrorism. Silenced academics, detained mayors, destroyed buildings, occupied neighborhoods, more than one hundred and fifty civilians killed. The only explanation lies in the actions of the security forces against the civilian population of towns and cities, as the mayors of Mardin, Diyarbakir and Van have just explained to us. There is too much distance between the Government's explanation and the information coming to us from Human Rights Watch or Amnesty International, which dramatically illustrate what is really happening. The European Union cannot look the other way in the name of an alleged greater demand for the agreement with Turkey on the refugee ground. Nor can we simply ask for the ceasefire from here or condemn the obvious. I ask you, Commissioner, to demand — I should say — that the European institutions intervene immediately. Parliament's technical delegations, such as those that will be moving to Ankara in a few weeks and of which I myself will be a part, are not enough. A special envoy for the area must now be appointed, with full powers to meet with all parties, to open the way to a genuine ceasefire.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, how much does it cost and with what currency is the price paid for preventing the collapse of European reception? Collapse of inadequate reception in the face of the migration crisis. They are paid in euros, in blood and in dignity: the three billion euros are paid by European taxpayers, in the hope that they will not be used for other purposes than to help refugees. The Turkish Kurds, who are discriminated against and harassed in every way, who, as citizens of a major NATO state, are uncomfortable Kurds, unlike their Syrian and Iraqi cousins, pour blood into it. The European institutions lose their dignity when they relaunch negotiations and relations with a government – and I am not talking about the people but about the government – which tramples on freedom of expression and association, which uses censorship and intimidation and which perpetrates a real racial attack on the Kurdish minority. Words from the United Nations, not mine. Journalists and university professors are also arrested. They do not seem to me to be proportionate, adequate or justifiable measures. How long will we tolerate them? As for... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Madam President, the situation in South-Eastern Turkey is covered by a veil of secrecy and silence. Unfortunately, this is also due to the tolerance of the European Union. The Western media reproduces only news reports concerning the casualties of the Turkish security forces, diligently concealing in their reports the crimes against humanity committed by the regime of the bloodthirsty Erdoğan. The geographical position of the militants – for the right to life and prosperity – of Kurds is a way and a bridge for illegal acts and dealings between Turkey and the Jihadists of the Islamic State. The European Union must plan very carefully its geostrategic and geopolitical movements on a chessboard with characteristics of a huge conflict of interest and a massive concentration of warring factions. The chaos between the Kurds of Turkey, Syria and Iraq, Daesh, the Ouachabit groups, Shiites, Sunnis and Christians, with the apparent or secret involvement of foreign forces, will inevitably lead to a conflict of global proportions.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – If we look at the situation in south-eastern Turkey today, we see that the Turkish state is trying to extend the accusation of terrorism to the entire Kurdish movement, and the media is using all available means to deter the Kurds in the eyes of the public. Acts of violence are commonplace, and every day for the Kurds, the peace agreement that has been within reach for a few months is moving further away. Some Turkish society would also support peace talks, and there are even supporters among members of the Turkish parliament, ruling party and opposition, as the international crisis group is pushing for. I believe that the Union must take stronger action to renovate the Kurdish-Turkish negotiations. Even if, according to some, the price of Turkey's assistance in the migration crisis is that the Kurdish issue can be settled in their own way. Let us not forget that we are talking about a country that is negotiating accession with the European Union. We cannot therefore be indifferent to the serious infringements that are occurring in this area.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D). Madam President, do you not think we should stop closing our eyes to reality and be more honest with each other in relation to Turkey? Is it because elections are taking place in Turkey that it has also become a democratic country? This is the country that continues to own 38% of Cyprus, prosecute dissidents, imprison journalists, cooperate with ISIS and send refugees to Greece and by extension to Europe. As we speak, he is carrying out genocide against the Kurdish people and not against the PKK. Is this the Turkey you want as a partner? Can you, because of the refugee crisis, turn a blind eye to crimes against humanity? One is the way: real democratisation of Turkey. In order to do this, Europe must follow the appropriate 'road map', without discounts to serve any other interests.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you for this discussion, which is also very important for consolidating our opinion. It has been pointed out on several occasions that the Vice-President, Commissioner Stylianidis and my little one will hold talks in Ankara on Monday, high-level political dialogue. Rest assured that we will raise this issue very intensively there. Although there has been a lot of talk today about the continuation of the accession negotiations, we are still at a very early stage here, for example in terms of Chapters 23 and 24, but we are in the preparatory phase. Anyone who deals with this matter to some extent knows quite clearly that the greatest lever in the preparation, but especially in the actual conduct of these accession negotiations, is to influence things. Then there is the litmus test for the Turkish Government to show how serious it is about the convictions of the rule of law in accordance with international European standards. This must then be examined and tested. Membership of the European Union is only possible if we follow our beliefs, principles and legal structures. Negotiations in this area are not negotiations, to converge, but rather to take over the European values and legal system, so to speak. That is the subject of the negotiations, and that is what the negotiations can do. In this respect, we certainly have the strongest lever at this stage. We should try that. I believe that there are no alternatives in this direction if we want to help the Kurdish population in Turkey, for example. With this in mind, I am also pleased that some Turkish mayors are here, who have had discussions with many of us today, have also taken advantage of the opportunity to provide us with first-hand information accordingly. This, too, is very important in order to have an appropriate opinion-forming system. In any case, thank you very much for the discussion.
