And thank you for keeping this issue on the international agenda.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed.  Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Alyn SMITH
text: in writing. – Turkey is a potential EU member, a member of the Euro-Mediterranean partnership and an important trade partner of the EU. More recently, Turkey has undertaken to play a key role in supporting the EU’s efforts to manage the refugee crisis and received EUR 3 billion aid package. The EU has very close ties with Turkey, but our cooperation and friendship shouldn’t stop us from openly criticising our partners when such criticism is due. Turkey has launched a high-risk offensive against the PKK. The scale of the military operations being carried out in towns and cities by police and military units is truly shocking. In southeast Turkey, civilians have been killed and several towns have been put under curfew for weeks on end. I’ve met with Ms Figen Yuksekdag, co-chair of the HDP, and I was deeply concerned with her account of the events in Turkey, including violent crackdowns on protests and rapidly shrinking space for political opposition. As Turkey’s partner, the EU must support the peace process and call on both parties of the conflict to agree on an immediate ceasefire, end and denounce all violent acts and start negotiating in good faith for the end of hostilities.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the Association Agreements/Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I am grateful, on behalf of the High Representative, for this opportunity to take stock of where we are concerning the Association Agreement and the implementation, as approved a year ago in this House, with Ukraine, Georgia, and Moldova. For Ukraine, the DCFTA can bring significant economic benefits. Ukrainian businesses will now receive stable and predictable preferential access to the largest market in the world, with 500 million customers, and EU enterprises will be able to benefit from easier access to the Ukrainian market, so we must help Ukraine develop the right conditions to encourage new business and investment relationships. Over 20 meetings were held in trilateral format to address alleged Russian concerns about the DCFTA implementation. Now Ukraine faces a number of measures imposed by Russia impeding trade and transit and will need our support here too. In 2016 we will be stepping up our efforts to support Ukraine with more coordination with EU Member States and greater visibility for our work. Particularly on the implementation of the DCFTA, we will build on current support programmes to improve the business climate, provide support to small and medium-sized enterprises, and help Ukraine find new markets. Ukraine needs to show it is open for business by aligning with EU standards in key sectors and taking decisive action on the rule of law. The Support Group for Ukraine is playing a key role with the Commission in all these areas. Despite very challenging circumstances, the Ukrainian Government has made progress in implementing the Association Agreement. The National Anti-Corruption Bureau and the new national police force have started to work. The selection process for an anti-corruption prosecutor has been completed. The government has also adopted a law on the natural gas market, which aims at bringing the gas sector of Ukraine into line with the EU Third Energy Package. These developments were welcomed at the second Association Council in Brussels which was held on 7 December, but we should not underestimate the challenges ahead. The fight against corruption, reform of the judiciary and the public administration, as well as amendments to the constitution, particularly the second reading on decentralisation, will require courage and political will. Shortly before Christmas, we published our final report on Ukraine’s implementation of the visa liberalisation action plan which concluded that, since the necessary process has been made and the number of additional commitments undertaken by the Ukrainian leadership, a positive recommendation for visa-free travel could be made. We aim to present a legislative proposal to pave the way for visa liberalisation with Ukraine soon. Turning to Moldova, the country has made great strides in concluding and implementing the Association Agreement and DCFTA with the European Union. Since 1 January the region of Transnistria also has the possibility to trade preferentially under the DCFTA, making an important contribution to our conflict resolutions, but recent Moldovan governments have not implemented important reforms. We are currently witnessing a highly unstable political situation, which is also an obstacle to the effective implementation of the Association Agreement and making full use of opportunities. The country is in great need of stable leadership, with the determination and energy required to address a number of problematic issues, including high-level corruption. This is necessary before Moldova can proceed with other key reforms, in particular in the justice, financial and media sectors and the reform of the public administration. I have just received information that there was a positive vote on the new government and I hope this is now a stable one. I think we should support any government that is ready to undertake the necessary reforms, and it is also important to provide the necessary substantial support in terms of staff, human resources, but also, if needed, and this is definitely the case, in terms of money, provided that there is a positive assessment by the IMF. Finally, as regards Georgia, impressive efforts have been made to implement the Association Agreement and the results are already visible, with strong growth in foreign direct investment. Other indicators also show promising signs. The visa liberalisation action plan has proven to be an effective tool for promoting a range of reforms, but Georgia has gone beyond the action plan benchmarks and taken further steps to reform the judiciary as well as the Prosecutor’s Office. In this regard, we also closely monitor the authorities to ensure that there is no unlawful conduct targeting the constitutional court and its personnel. The result was our positive report last December and with Georgia, too, we will press ahead now with legislation to achieve full visa liberation as soon as possible. In summary, we can be happy that we have already come so far with our three Association Agreement partners, but we still have a long way to go and no room at all for complacency. I look forward to hearing the honourable Members’ views during this debate today.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Madam Vice-President, in my minute and 30 I will reflect a little more on the situation in Ukraine, and my colleagues Gahler and Harmna will talk more about Moldova and Georgia. Especially today about Moldova where there was a vote of confidence, but I also hear certain protests that are currently happening in the Moldovan parliament.  Today's "Association Agreement" theme is extremely pertinent and comes at a good time. The entry into force of the Ukraine-EU Free Trade Agreement has seen lengthy negotiations, but also insufficient assurances from Russia that this treaty will have some negative consequences for it. Unfortunately, we have seen countermeasures that Russia has taken and are damaging to trade. I think the EU should help Ukraine in this situation.  Also, I expect from the Commission a very soon concrete legislative proposal that will relate to further liberalization of the visa regime, when it comes to Ukrainian citizens, because that is exactly what our Ukrainian friends expect 2 years after Majdan. The third is that we should continue to support security in the implementation of the Minsk agreements, decentralisation and strong implementation of all obligations and association agreements where we as Parliament's parliamentary association committee give strong support to both the Council and the Commission in this process.  Lastly, we want the upcoming referendum in the Netherlands in April to take place in such a way as to allow for a positive result and the entry into force of the Association Agreement.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We welcome the fact that, since 1 January this year, all three countries have been de facto on board. With the Association Agreement, the EU offers its eastern neighbours a comprehensive offer of political cooperation and economic integration – even without EU membership. However, in order for our EU neighbours to fully benefit from this offer of cooperation, they need to implement more far-reaching reforms in the economy and trade, as well as in the approximation of legislation. The more reforms that are implemented, the greater the benefits these countries will have. I am pleased that today we have succeeded in electing a new government in Moldova. I wish the new Prime Minister and his team every success. We also expect a lot from them, because words are spoken enough – we must see concrete action. I am pleased that great progress has been made in Georgia, although we will ensure that decisions in media policy, for example, are made and justified much more transparently than before. I am pleased with the progress made in Ukraine, which Commissioner Hahn referred to. But here too, the high level of corruption must continue to be combated.  It is important for us, also with regard to Minsk, that the constitutional amendment continues in the next few days, because we all know that if this does not happen, everything must start all over again, and that would really be to the detriment of the country. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Blue card question. I would like to ask my colleague whether he is aware, given that he spoke about the new government in Moldova, of the fact that the new government belongs to a party, the Democratic Party, linked to one of the most powerful and corrupt oligarchs in the country, which presents itself with the European label, but remains that oligarch linked to the mafias that it is.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mrs Spinelli, I would like to thank Mrs Spinelli for her part in the I am sorry. I have also heard of these rumours, and I also know that there are problems to be resolved there. But the 57 Members of Parliament who have elected a new Prime Minister are all freely elected Members, and I hope that they will have already made the right decision.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. This year will be twenty-five years since the soviet union was solved. Despite such a long time, Moscow's influence is still a destabilising factor in the region. Compared to the like Georgia, Ukraine and Moldova, moldova have intensified in recent years, hampering the reform processes. In relation to my country's close neighbour Ukraine, this is already an open aggression with the annexation of part of the territory. We support reform efforts in all three countries. We want visa facilitation to be implemented as soon as possible. Poland has good experience with migration from the East, especially from these countries. We have hundreds of thousands of Ukrainians in Poland, this is primarily economic migration and – let us not be afraid of it – is a positive factor. We very much support a joint resolution on this issue. We hope that it will be adopted by the European Parliament in tomorrow's vote.

name: Johannes Cornelis van BAALEN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the European Union needs stable neighbours, but also a democratic Russia would need stable neighbours. The Russians do of course the opposite: they destabilise. It is in the interests of all that we talk with the three countries we mentioned to help them, to assist them, and the agreements we speak about are vital in this respect. A stable economy, economic growth, the re-establishment of the rule of law, the fight against corruption – and we should, of course, financially support them, and we do, but every euro spent should be accounted for. This would mean that in a few years’ time these countries will be able to export stability and not only consume stability. I have visited the three countries also on a party-to-party basis and I am positive about the results we are seeing there. Much must be done, can be done and should be done. I think that my colleagues in this Parliament who have worked together with the parties in Moldova to form a new government, have done a great deal. We should thank them for that, and all the Association Agreements should be ratified, including the Association Agreement with Ukraine. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. You mentioned that Russia is having a destabilising effect on the processes in Ukraine and, by this, in Europe. I ask you, what do you think of the intentions, which I also think are destabilising, e.g. in referendums that will unraive these association agreements?

name: Johannes Cornelis van BAALEN
text: blue-card answer. –  The people who know my position in Dutch politics know that I do not think that referenda are the right way to make decisions, because normally in a referendum it is not about the issue, it is about whether you like the government or not. The Dutch Government should look at the results of the referendum, and it has its own responsibility. I hope that the government will take its own responsibility. Of course, in the meantime we will fight for the fact that we want to convince our citizens to vote ‘yes’. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tim AKER
text: blue-card question. – You talk about wanting a democratic Russia, which is very honourable, but surely this Union should get its own house in order. How can we lecture the Russians when this Union ignored the constitution votes in France and the Netherlands and ignored the Lisbon Treaty votes in Ireland? Surely this place should get its own house in order before lecturing anyone else.

name: Johannes Cornelis van BAALEN
text: blue-card answer. – There are no Dutch soldiers on foreign soil in the European Union, not in your country or other countries. So it is Russia which has to explain and has to account for what it did and does, and a democratic Russia – we hope that the country becomes democratic – that is good for Russia and for the Russians. That is an ideal, but they have to do it themselves, there I agree with you, but we may help them.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I think we need to think again. The European Commission, with the support of the Council, has enforced free trade and association agreements with Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia, which have caused economic decline throughout the region. The agreements have destroyed the increased production and trade networks in the region in a very short space of time. The EU is not in a position to make up for the losses. Social hardship is getting worse every day, and corruption is eating up societies. Why are you letting things escalate like this? In Ukraine, more than 9,000 people have already died in an avoidable war. Moldova's government, which is still operating today, is now blocking the opposition's votes in dungeons, and the overall situation is deteriorating in Georgia as well. The GUE/NGL Group remains in the same vein: there is an urgent need to reassess and align the neighbourhood policy to the east and relations with the Russian Federation, including with the neighbours of the neighbours. This must include an end to the EU's confrontation with Russia and the Eurasian Union, as well as a willingness to work together – with all 28 EU Member States and the neighbourhood countries – to build a common area of peace and social and economic progress. This is what is needed in the current acute international situation, in view of the need to eliminate the causes of flight in full, what people long for in the face of the real situation in their countries. The people of the Netherlands will vote on it on 6 April. And my question to her is whether she thinks the agreement with Ukraine is right. Will you respect the result? (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure – Dear colleague, I have noted in your exposition the following sentence: 'The Commission has imposed the free trade agreement with the countries we are considering today'. Firstly, explain the words 'The Commission has imposed', because we are in a democratic parliament and nothing is required here - it is discussed, it is voted on - and how would you see, if it were not for the free trade agreement, our neighbourhood with the countries we are talking about?

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The negotiation process and the conclusion of this agreement have taken place over a long period of time, including, of course, with all the political elites and leaders in these countries, including Ukraine. I myself was present when the free trade agreement was parafitised in the European Parliament. Nevertheless, what I wanted to say is that we should have thought much more deeply about the historically developed economic relations and had to take into account from the outset that these agreements influence the reality of today. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the association agreements are very powerful tools to ensure that these three countries go through the necessary reforms that will result in the rule of law, democracy and respect of fundamental freedoms and human rights, and we have already seen that all three are struggling to go through those processes. It is not very easy, and we have to give them all the support we can. That is why I believe we have to show them that parliamentary oversight of these processes is important. We can also show them how the best practices of our EU Member States have given Parliament a real say on EU integration processes and the transposition of EU legislation. That is what we are trying to do in the European Parliament right now. We can, perhaps, conclude that this parliamentary support has so far been the strongest in Ukraine, and perhaps we can learn from that and adopt the same kind of means and procedures for Moldova and Georgia. I believe that to go through the necessary reforms of the justice sector, media freedoms, etc., is the best guarantor of independence and sovereignty for these countries, and we all know that Russia casts a very long shadow over all three. We also need to make sure that there is a full monitoring of the reforms, that they are not just for show, and there I believe that the EU could do even better. Concerning the forthcoming referendum in the Netherlands, we should take note of it. We should hope that the Dutch people are fully aware that this is about Ukraine’s place in the geopolitical landscape – whether it will have the right to join Europe as it wishes, or whether it will be left at the mercy of Russia. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – I notice in your speech you speak about respecting independence and sovereignty of the countries we are discussing, but then you talk about association with the European Union, which even its fondest supporters say is about pooling independence and sovereignty, and those of us who dislike it say it is about giving it up altogether. So there is a complete contradiction there in what you are suggesting. Are you saying that I should jump out of the frying pan of the Russian control into the fire of the EU?

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much for this interesting question. I really believe that the independence today means that we can also pool our forces across national borders, but we are doing it in a voluntary way in the European Union. I think it is absolutely incorrect that you make this comparison between what used to be the Soviet Union and what is the European Union today.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova: how much effort is Europe making to fuel a confrontation with Russia that is not going anywhere? The billions of euros that the Eu ropean Union has already paid as assistance to Ukraine were not enough, the free trade agreement also entered into force on 1 January, while the association agreement has already been in force for more than a year. But what has changed in Ukraine since the start of negotiations? Has there been a reform of the state? Has there been a real fight against corruption? I too was in Ukraine with my colleagues on the INTA Committee a few months ago and no one has been able to explain to me why, in the country par excellence of the oligarchs, there is no credible law on conflict of interest. Perhaps Ukraine is following the Italian example? But above all there is a great absentee in all this: Russia. In any strategy aimed at the former Soviet countries, we cannot ignore the close cooperation that we should have in order to allow real and continuous economic development of the area. Why, then, do the Commission and, above all, the Council, continue to isolate and isolate us? Why do we continue to go to direct confrontation, using Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, when we realised that this approach leads to nothing? What really amazes me is that for years we have not had the slightest consideration for these countries and now we find that they are our dearest neighbours and that they need us. Let us stop playing good Samaritans and admit that what we are trying to do is create a buffer zone to isolate Russia. And the only way to do this, since the Union does not have a foreign policy, is through association, partnership and free trade agreements. Does that sound familiar to you? It's called the Cold War!

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: on behalf of the ENF group. – Madam President, yes, we all know, we need to strengthen the Eastern Partnership, given the current geopolitical context, the bilateral dimension is no longer sufficient. You must therefore make a more sustained effort to support Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine.  We all know that these states face great problems in terms of the rule of law. The European Union must not be involved in their internal process, but it must give them an additional impetus in the process of implementing the European idea. I've done it wrong so far.  Moldova is one of three states that is currently facing a difficult political situation and financial instability that has already become perpetual. It is very important to overcome this moment and return to a stable queen, allowing the maintenance and advancement of Moldova's path. It is essential to reconfirm the Union's interest and support for Moldova, which also remains one of the key partners in maintaining balance in this area.  What do you do for them? The European Union must remain committed to Moldova and ensure that it remains in a area of stability, otherwise we cannot wait or demand reforms. What have you done so far? Moldovans have already made significant progress in terms of anti-discrimination, justice and free movement, and it should be stressed that in the implementations of free trade agreements, Moldova is at the forefront of increasing trade with the European Union, according to Eurostat data. Georgia, which received an economic supplement due to better implementation of reforms, accounted for almost half of the percentages of Moldovans; we continue to criticize moldovans.  Therefore, at the forefront of the concerns of the Chisinau government must be to re-establish the implementation of free trade agreements and, further, to maintain a stable situation, enabling the construction of a system of sound and sustainable reforms, both institutionally, economically and politically. Therefore, on the part of Chisinau, we expect a renewed political commitment to the reforms agreed with the European Union on the basis of the Association Agenda, but also from Europe for genuine support.  Reforms and strengthening Moldova's stability are interdependent processes that complement and strengthen each other. The efforts made in the transition processes of Moldova and the other two countries must be guided, the role of Europe being that of educator.  (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The formation of a new government in Moldova is to be welcomed. She must get to work immediately. It must prove to be an active government, because democracy in Moldova is bad. The modernisation programme and reforms urgently need to be resumed, and rapprochement with the EU must continue. The country needs, for example, an independent attorney general, and the country needs an effective fight against corruption. The citizens of Moldova want an investigation into crimes in the banking sector, they want to stabilise the state and the economy. The EU is ready to help. But there will be no improvement without sufficient efforts of moldova's elites. We expect respect for human and civil rights, we expect the rule of law, we expect pluralism in democracy, that is, also in the media, and we expect decisive and successful reform work. The citizens of Moldova also have all these expectations. The country therefore has no time to lose. The European Union must establish detailed reform steps and a timetable with the Moldovan administration. EU experts must enforce this route in the ministries in order for our aid to be successful. The citizens of Moldova want better living conditions. The country must not lose even more citizens who seek their happiness abroad. Nor do we want to lose Moldova as an EU partner.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Madam President, at this point when we are debating, the Parliament of the Republic of Moldova, as you have learned, has invested the new government, Pavel Filip. This vote comes after a long period of severe political instability and non-implementation of commitments made to both the Union and the citizens of the Republic of Moldova. These lost months have led to the loss of some of the citizens' confidence in democratic institutions and political parties in Moldova. That is why it is so important that the role and performance of this government, once installed, is seen by restoring the economic and social situation, as well as by implementing without hesitation the reforms undertaken. The installation of the new government is at the same time a positive sign for the much-needed stability of the Republic of Moldova, but above all, it is imperative to increase and gain the trust of the citizens of this country.  Commissioner, before I conclude, I tell you that, in Chisinau, today came two representatives of forces hostile to democracy and stability, with the flight of a plane from Moscow, and that forces hostile to democracy have tried to break into the Parliament of the Republic of Moldova in order to block and block its work, and I expect the European Commission to react to this attempt at destabilisation.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: – Madam President, may I firstly welcome the commitment shown by Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine to their association agreements and the DCFTAs with the European Union. As a co-Chair of the EU-Georgia Parliamentary Association Committee, I would like to particularly highlight the added value of the Association Agreement and the DCFTA to Georgia’s reform processes. Already we are seeing the early results of these agreements, with Georgia having a good pace of approximation of Georgian legislation to EU standards. The latest trade statistics show that EU imports from Georgia have risen by 15% despite negative economic trends in the region. I would also like to congratulate Georgia on the progress made in all areas covered by the visa liberalisation action plan, as confirmed by the Commission in December; with Georgia on its own merits now meeting all the requirements for visa-free travel, we therefore swiftly expect as co-legislators that the European Commission will submit to us the legislative proposal needed so that we can demonstrate our commitment to Georgia.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, how could it be that the association agreements, which aim to promote peace, stability and prosperity, can be against someone’s interests? Those who sit in the Kremlin say exactly this: it is against Russia. Why is this so? For one basic reason: the rule of law and democracy next door is so much in contrast to what is happening in Russia today. The choice for Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine is this: either Europeanisation or being embraced by ‘Russkiy Mir’. In this context, I wish to stress the following. I call on the Georgian Government to cherish freedom of the media and fully respect the independence of the constitutional and other courts. I urge the new Moldovan Government, appointed just two hours ago, not to waste time in tackling reforms that are so long—awaited, and I remind the Ukrainian Government of the ideals of the Maidan and I call on them finally to start cutting the heads of the beast named corruption.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: – Madam President, our group has drafted a motion for a resolution on this subject, which I supported. In this proposal, we have highlighted significant shortcomings in the European Union's policy in relation to the three countries that we are debating today. Perhaps the most serious mistake is, and the debate shows that, despite experience, the Commission does not take into account the historical ties that have arisen in this territory, including those with Russia. In both Ukraine and Moldova and Georgia, we are convinced that the reforms that are necessary for the very survival and economic and social development of these countries, a stable legal environment, are not being implemented even with large investments from the European Union. The question arises as to who stole the investments from those elites that were there and that we supported. We must be aware that our decision takes responsibility for the fate of more than forty million people. Without Russia, this project will be doomed to failure.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – When the so-called pro-European structure was won a year and a half ago in Ukraine, when the elections were held, and then, of course, there was a great hope that, even with the help of the Association Agreement, Moldova could quickly foot the path of important reforms, which, of course, will raise confidence in politics and, on the other hand, will ensure greater well-being of moldova's citizens.  Then, of course, quite a few sad things have happened in Moldova, including, of course, banking matters, financial matters, with justice, including media freedom.  Now the new government is giving new hope, and it is for us, of course, that we are helping Moldova, as far as possible, to take reforms seriously as soon as possible, thus also enabling the realisation of the so-called association agreements and moving forward.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: – Madam President, during a recent trip to Ukraine I discovered that, despite two revolutions, the democracy people crave is still elusive and the old establishment still clings to power. This situation creates three major problems. Firstly, the greatest obstacle to democracy is corruption. This is endemic and seems to blight from what I saw and the people I spoke to, all levels of the political and judicial system. Secondly, there is the problem of political prisoners held as scapegoats for systemic failure. Finally, there are the Ukrainian people who continue to feel let down, disenfranchised and ignored by the political elite. But with rampant inflation, falling pensions, an average wage of only USD 200 a month and soaring energy prices eating into their salary, who can blame them? It therefore beggars belief that, due to its obsessive, expansionist policies and empire—building, the EU continues to betray the ideas of the Maidan Revolution by propping up a corrupt and uncaring government with nearly EUR 2 billion in loans. The fact is, despite protestations to the contrary from officials desperate to expand the EU’s influence ever further east – particularly in one of the most oil- and gas-rich territories in the world – what the people of the Ukraine crave is independent democracy. Instead, they have been offered the new form of dictatorship which the EU represents.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what are we looking for in our enlargement policy? What do we want? Do we want peace, do we seek peace or do we want war? I would like to speak as an Alsatian, because we are in Strasbourg today. Alsace, when it was the originator of the First and Second World War, was in a camp against another camp, instead of being a bridge. When she wanted to, did she become the bridge? It has become the capital of Europe. In our policy of enlargement, are we looking for a confrontation - that is, to put in one camp against another side - or are we trying to build bridges for those countries that belong to two cultures, on the one hand, the West and, on the other hand, the East, being taken in both the Western influence and that , it must be said, also of Russia, and even of Asia? I suggest, and I implore you, to make your policy bridges for peace.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today's resolution concerns developments in the three countries with which the European Union has concluded association agreements, Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia. May I remind you, ladies and gentlemen, that these three countries have one more common denominator. Parts of the territories of all these countries are occupied by the Russian Federation. As shadow rapporteur for the Association Agreement with Georgia, I very much appreciate this country's efforts to implement it, although our resolution does not lack criticism about the dangers of threats to freedom of speech and selective justice. We stress that the existence of a political opposition is crucial for a balanced and mature political system, and we stress that any act of violence against members of any political party should be investigated immediately and thoroughly. For me personally, it is unacceptable that some members of the opposition remain in prison. There is a need to improve the political climate, eliminate confrontation and polarisation and ensure cross-party dialogue in order to strengthen democracy and the rule of law. I would also like to point out that georgia's new Prime Minister, Giorgi Kvirikashvili, has called for an end to polarisation and stressed that his cabinet is open to cooperation with all political groups in parliament. There is no doubt that democratic Georgia belongs to the European Union.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Madam President, after the setbacks of the Riga Summit, tonight there are glimmers of hope that the prospects for the Eastern Partnership are being rekindled with the completion of the ratification of Georgia’s Association Agreement by all 28 Member States last month and the free trade deal with Ukraine officially coming into effect at the start of the year. The Minsk agreement may have been questioned, but it has not been destroyed and, alongside the efforts the Commissioner referred to on Transnistria, we should welcome political developments in Moldova this very day, which look to have brought a political crisis to an end. However, it is clear in Moldova, and in Ukraine in particular, that it is necessary for the EU to undertake deep engagement in order to strengthen Europe-facing movements in these countries. I do hope that the country which suffered most from the MH17 disaster will support political progress in Ukraine, which could help prevent such terrible events from happening again. On Georgia, selective justice and corruption are problems in all the countries of the neighbourhood, not one country. The EPP should not engage in selective politics, but support Georgia’s aspirations too. Finally, regarding our neighbours’ neighbours, once again I place on record that my group supports the Commission’s tentative work on studying possibilities for relations between the European Union and the Eurasian Union. And we support political dialogue with Moscow, but not to bargain over sovereign countries or to weaken our approach on sanctions. Socialists and Democrats do not deny or underestimate different perspectives, but we do want to make genuine attempts to bridge them.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, in recent days a life-and-death battle for the fate of the Republic of Moldova has been waged. Does Moldova stay with the oligarchs, the mafia and the Russians or does Moldova go on the European road and the road to democracy? There was political instability until today, when a new government was voted on, but let us be honest and tell the truth: there was political instability because the government fell in October 2015, and when this government fell, they also put their shoulder to the Democratic Party of the Republic of Moldova, who are part of the European socialist family, of the European Socialist Party. The president of this party, Mr Lupu, even came here to Strasbourg and asked for light and advice from his fellow socialists. Can our fellow socialists tell us what they advised him to do: to bring down the government, to negotiate to take more power?  We have a new government now, of which the Communists are part. What we are asking of this government is to comply with the conditions of the association agreement, precisely to prove that they have good intentions for the Republic of Moldova.

name: Javier NART
text: – Madam President, I believe that we take our wishes for realities. When we are talking about democracy in Ukraine, in Moldova, in Georgia, we have to take into account that what is there are oligarchs, as a result of the corruption of the Soviet system and the collection of resources by a number of people. These oligarchs create political parties and these political parties are finally the ones who manage these countries. Corruption, therefore, is not an atypical fact, it is the logical consequence when business becomes politics.  Moldova has suffered from the plundering of 1 billion euros by three banks backed by the National Bank , one of which also had the name "Social Bank".  In the case of Georgia, it is a country owned by an oligarch whose political party is simultaneously the axis of power. All major members of the Government—the President, the Foreign Minister—belong to Cartu Bank or have belonged to Cartu Bank. How do we think it is possible... (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: – On 6 April, the Dutch will go to the polls to speak out in a referendum on the association agreement with Ukraine. Eurocrats in Brussels are pretending that a vote against that association agreement is a vote for war and a vote against democracy and against progress. But this association agreement is not about democracy for Ukrainians at all. This association agreement is about trade and growth, more trade, more Europe and more space for multinationals. And in the growing European Union, we are seeing a decline in ambitions and standards.  A level playing field seems to be a magic word, but we are already seeing, for example, that Europe is subsidising mega-stables in Ukraine. More animals, more products, and products that have long been banned here in Europe, such as foie gras and battery eggs. We allow these products cheaply on our market. So if the Netherlands says no to the association agreement in the referendum, Then Europe cannot ignore it. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: – Madam President, if we compare the resolutions submitted by different political groups as well as today’s interventions on the issue, it seems that we are speaking of completely different Georgias, Moldovas and Ukraines. How is it possible? My answer is blind eyes, lies and double standards. Blind eyes on the irresponsibility of the governments of these countries supplied with oligarchs. Lies on prospects of future EU membership for these countries. The Dutch Prime Minister told us openly this morning that the Association Agreement is not a pre-accession. For the European Union this is like being a man using a woman sexually without promising to marry her. Double standards – why are Nadia Savchenko and Oleg Sentsov the only persons in detention to be cared about? Why is there a silence of prisoners of conscience in Ukraine and Moldova, such as Grigory Petrenko and Ruslan Kotsaba?

name: Petr MACH
text: – Colleagues, we are debating an agreement between the European Union and Ukraine. However, we forget that this agreement has not yet been ratified. A referendum on the agreement will soon be held in the Netherlands, and polls show that the Dutch will reject it. Why? Because they have had enough of the European Union's condescending policies, which lead to one disaster after another. Let us remember that this agreement was the detonator of the coup d'état in Ukraine and the ensuing conflict. So when the Dutch reject this agreement, we have a chance to negotiate this agreement again and better. And I propose that this agreement really be all about free trade, so that it does not drive a wedge into Ukrainian society, into Moldovan society, so that it does not complicate these countries' trade relations with Russia, so that it does not place all our meaningless regulations and regulations on these countries. Then there will be harmonious trade between us and Ukraine and we will not bring further conflicts to these countries.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: Mr Hazekamp has already indicated that on 6 April the Dutch people will go to the polls to vote in the referendum on Ukraine. That's an exciting moment. Our Foreign Minister, Mr Koenders, has already set out how the Dutch Government is going to tackle this campaign. But of course you're curious how the no camp is going to handle the campaign. That is not yet fully known, but there seem to be voices to be doing only one thing, and that is to show mr Juncker's picture as often as possible. That should be enough. Because the Dutch people know enough when they see Mr Juncker's face: lying, turning, drinking and lying even more. We're done. The Commission will probably think it is smart enough to bring this to a successful conclusion. But I assure you that the Dutch people are many times smarter and that will soon become apparent.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Congressman, I'm sorry. Believe me, your comment would have been appropriate if you had not made these epithets about President Juncker.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: – Madam President, I would like to speak about the EU-Ukraine Agreement. Its entry into force was postponed until 1 January 2016 due to Russian objections. It is an irony of history that now its future is challenged not by Mr Putin but by Dutch citizens. However, I want to believe that one of the world’s most advanced nations, among the first in Europe to embrace modern freedoms, a trade and technology powerhouse and leader on human rights, will support the freedom aspirations of another European nation and will let the freedom of trade and human exchange advance in the relations between the European Union and Ukraine. We should never forget that the EU shares over 1 300 kilometres of border with Ukraine. That is why a secure and prosperous Ukraine is in our own strategic interests. Stability and trade across this border means more secure borders for the Union. Ukraine is an important trade partner for the European Union. It is the largest European country, with fairly well developed industrial, agricultural and technology sectors. The agreement allows European businesses free access to this huge market. We have to be aware that a Ukraine closely associated with the EU is the best safeguard against the revisionist powers who want to redraw European borders.

name: Tim AKER
text: – Madam President, on a point of order, can you explain under what rule under the Rules of Procedure you as the Chair are allowed to give editorial comment on the previous speaker’s speech? As the President, and what one would assume is a neutral Chair, what rules give you the right to give editorial comment on what any Member of this House says? Can you explain the rules that give you that power, please? (Applause from EFDD Group)

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Well, if you're curious, of course I can tell you. I think that our fellow Member is just... Congressman, I'm sorry. Will you listen to me? He was insulting the President of the European Commission. I think it is inappropriate in the European Parliament and, on the other hand, it was absolutely not a topic. You don't have any more options to comment. Thank you, Congressman, you have no opportunity, take a seat, please. Regardless of whether you are shouting in this Parliament and not behaving properly, I will not give way to this behaviour. You can discuss it between you, it's none of your business. Next Member, Congressman Martin. By the way, if you want to keep yelling, I suggest you do this outside the room. That's the way it's going to be

name: David MARTIN
text: – Madam President, I want to start by saying that I fully welcome the agreement between Ukraine and the European Union and despite what we have heard from the other side of the House, we need to keep stressing that this is an agreement between two sovereign trading partners. No one has forced this agreement on Ukraine. No one has forced this agreement on the European Union. We have come to it voluntarily and the aim is to improve trade and investment between our two groups, and also to ensure that the living standards of the people of Ukraine are improved as a result of this agreement.  Can it succeed? Well it is early days but I think that if we look at the agreements with Georgia and Moldova, we can see that we have a good starting point. Trade between those two countries and the European Union has increased significantly since the comprehensive trade agreements came into being. Of course, that is of itself not enough and we have to do more to make sure that ordinary citizens of Georgia and Moldova benefit from the trade agreements, that living standards are improved in their country.  Likewise with Ukraine. Our partnership there gives us the opportunity to start working with our Ukrainian friends, to tackle corruption, which is a serious problem in that country, to improve the price of energy available to ordinary citizens, which has gone up as a result of changes there. We need to make sure that energy poverty does not exist in that country. Finally, let me say that although it is for the Dutch people to decide what they do in their referendum, I hope they will not give a free gift to the Russians who have tried to divide this continent and have also done that partly by financing some of the right-wing Putin friends we have on the other side of this Chamber.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Dear! I hope there are things that unite us. This must be some common European values and that they must also be an opportunity for our neighbours, and Ukraine is our neighbour. I think that it is a country no less connected with European history, culture, civilisation, tradition than some of the current members of the European Union, quite far away, or at least, from Europe. It is good that they are in it, but I would like Europe to be wider. We must also support Georgia, although I have copies of emails in front of me that come to me and whose authors express concern about the fate of political prisoners in this country. I hope that the authorities in Tbilisi will continue along the European path together with the opposition, not separately. I firmly believe this. I hope that the European Parliament will support them along this path.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Association agreements help the EU to make all kinds of agreements with countries, conditions for trade, rules on human rights and the rule of law. Although Ukraine is an important partner for the EU, it is certainly not the only country with which we agree these rules, from Israel to Chile, from Egypt to South Africa. In the Netherlands, particular attention is paid to the agreement with Ukraine because there will be a referendum on 6 April on whether the Signature of the Netherlands, after the support of the government and the House of Representatives, should remain under these agreements. Some people fear that the agreement will quietly lead to Ukraine's accession. But the opposite is true. It is precisely when a country is not eligible to join that an association agreement is a very useful and good way of establishing agreements. It is good that the EU is helping Ukraine tackle corruption and reform its economy and society. A stable and prosperous Ukraine is good for people in the country itself, but also good for Europeans. That is why D66 is calling on all Dutch people to vote in the referendum on 6 April and to vote in favour.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: Madam President, the implementation of association agreements with Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova does not meet any economic imperative for the Member States of the European Union. On the contrary, and given the relatively low economic levels of these three countries, there is currently no justification for expanding a free trade area to countries with such low levels of development. The free trade area already generates, as you know, real economic and social tragedies in Europe. I would also like to point out to you, I may be telling you, that in Moldova, for example, the monthly minimum wage is EUR 43. Moldova is 30% of the population living below the poverty line, but it is also an underground economy that accounts for 40% of GDP. Therefore, in the context of the Russian embargo, Georgia and Ukraine are real weapons of massive unfair competition for our farmers, who are struggling and facing difficulties in exporting their agricultural products.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for the work he has I believe that the discussion we are having today on Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine is about the importance of us being able to implement this from our side, but even more so that these countries can implement this.  I am pleased that a Prime Minister has been elected in Moldova today, in circumstances that are not pleasing. But I hope that, despite this difficult concept, we will still be able to make the best of it in order to make the next three years sensible, and that it is a government that really lasts the three years. After Georgia, of course, we are looking with concern. Yesterday, when we received the letter from the President of the Constitutional Court, we must say, in all other positive remarks, that the rule of law, the independence of the courts, etc. must be guaranteed in such a country. But Perhaps I would like to put a major point on the subject of Ukraine. Ukraine is experiencing many positive developments. We now see that developments towards the reform of the judicial system are also taking a sensible approach. At the same time, however, we also see that we are discussing within the European Union whether we can maintain the sanctions in order to exert the necessary pressure on Ukraine, so that we can bring the issue of eastern Ukraine into what we believe to be positive development and the Minsk agreement can be created. That is why it is extremely important that the Russian side is not given an alibi by not respecting it on the Ukrainian side either. That is why I think it is important that the constitutional commitments of decentralisation are adopted, at least in the constitutional process.  This does not yet need to be implemented here. However, Russia should not be given a template on this issue, so that the pressure is removed in our internal discussions. We should also give this advice to Ukraine at this hour.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Madam President, already in the first year of application of this agreement, Georgia's exports to the EU have increased by 15% and Moldova by as much as 62%. We expect an increase in exports from Ukraine. However, as with other trade agreements, I believe that free trade must also be accompanied by the free movement of people. The conditions have been met and I believe there is no reason to maintain the visa regime for Ukraine and Georgia. The EU needs to help eastern partnership countries, except declaratively and politically, certainly economically with strict supervised implementation of the agreement.  But, of course, the key moment is the European Union's relationship to Russia. Russia is at conflict with all three countries – whether it is the annexation of Crimea, the occupation of Abkhazia and South Ossetia, or when it comes to Transnistria. But regardless of sanctions, a trilateral EU-Ukraine-Russia dialogue is necessary. I hope that the upcoming referendum in the Netherlands will not further complicate Ukraine's already difficult enough European path.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. No one doubts that Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova are European countries, that they have been and are an important part of the community of values that underpins the European Union. Deepening the link between these countries and the Union is not only a matter of pragmatism, but to a large extent our historical duty. Association and in-depth cooperation agreements are an important step towards closer integration and it is welcome that their implementation is successful. Of course, we cannot rule out errors, delays, but this process in the current difficult international situation in eastern Europe is too important for small shortcomings to change the direction taken by these countries. The actions taken by the Russian Federation to torpedo the modernisation of economies in Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova, in particular the suspension of the free trade area between these countries against Kiev, is further evidence that Moscow is not interested in cooperation, but in constant confrontation. Such actions should only mobilise us to increase our efforts and support our eastern partners.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, honourable Members, first of all, we must note the progress made by all countries and welcome georgia, Moldova and Ukraine's desire for close association with the European Union. The implementation of the agreements undoubtedly has a positive impact on trade, stimulating reforms and economic growth.  Of course, the European Union must not stop there. Eastern Partnership policy has proven not to be a geopolitical threat to third countries, but a long-term strategy in favour of stability, prosperity and democracy on the European continent.  We therefore need to continue to support all three countries. Let's end visa liberalization with Georgia and Ukraine. Let's pay deeper attention and diplomatically to seek a solution to the frozen conflicts in the Eastern Partnership countries. Last but not least, to continue monitoring compliance with the principles of democracy, which will be a guarantor of further reforms by Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I am very grateful to the European Commission, and also to you, Commissioner Hahn, for negotiating these very good agreements in recent months. What is particularly close to my heart is that states have negotiated agreements with us voluntarily, on their own own, and no one has forced them to do so. But it must not prevent anyone from making agreements with us in the end. When I look at the fact that, for example, in the field of foreign trade, we have also taken a great deal of consideration, that we have also proved, by the example of Ukraine, that we are not simply trying to do things through, as we as the European Union and Ukraine could have done together, that we have taken another year to talk to Russia. Negotiating how to put this agreement into force, how to overcome possible difficulties between Europe, Ukraine and Russia in advance, was certainly exemplary. I very much regret that Russia has not taken the opportunity. I very much regret that, at the beginning of the year, we now have to see again that Russia has de facto reintroduced additional difficulties against Ukrainian products. I would be very grateful if we could maintain the thread of conversation here. It must be possible for countries in Europe to be able to do so in 2016 with the countries with which they want to cooperate and to conclude contractual agreements, without any third party interfering and trying to prevent this. I therefore call, in particular, on the Russian Government and the Russian President to remember their responsibilities.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, the last decade has undoubtedly proven difficult for Georgia. The August 2008 war severely worsened relations with Russia and these have only recently started to recover from economic difficulties. Yet despite all this Georgians have achieved the almost impossible: numerous successful reforms, especially of the judiciary, the strengthening of democracy, economic development – all of which contributed to the eventual conclusion of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement and will soon result in the finalisation of the visa liberalisation dialogue. The fact that some of my colleagues regularly criticise Georgia, often on issues which have actually long been resolved, is most regrettable. The same applies for our resolutions, colleagues. What in the world has happened to quality writing? We purport to be the citadel of democracy, yet whom are we trying to lecture here? Georgia, which is the cradle of European civilisation, with its millennia-old traditions and statehood? If we really are who we purport to be, a standard of proper conduct has to be upheld in everything we do here in Parliament.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Why should the European Union pursue Eastern politics? What is the point of Eastern politics? This is it – the European Union has good neighbours in the East, it has Ukraine and Moldova, societies that want to live in law, freedom and justice, who want to build close economic and political ties with a united Europe, who want to pay the difficult price of freedom that Ukrainian society has paid for Maidan. Finally, contrary to what colleagues are saying, perhaps in the interests of the Russian Federation, European politics, European Union policy, gives peace and stability in this area. Peace and stability are threatened by Putin's imperialism, not by the european Union's tenacious policies. I am not only in favour of association agreements, but also in favour of their implementation, as intense as possible.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Madam President, I would first like to welcome the entry into force on 1 January 2016 of the Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Agreement between the European Union and Ukraine. On the other hand, I would like to welcome the progress that both Ukraine and Georgia have made in implementing the action plan for visa liberalisation. We are all waiting for a very clear message from the Union on visa liberalisation.  I would like to say a few words about Moldova in my time. When we talk, the Moldovan Parliament is occupied by protesters. They are protesters mobilized by two parties entirely controlled by Moscow. This is after a vote was hardly successful for a government that is, in turn, the product of an oligarch who is Moscow's creation. We must say that, at the moment, unfortunately, we are facing a confrontation between parties which still claims from a European identity and a pro-European plan, but which are under the control of pro-Russian oligarchs, and parties directly controlled by Moscow and who want early elections. We are in a dead end, it is a very serious crisis and the results of this confrontation will probably be more serious, I fear, than what happened in Ukraine two years ago. The Union has done everything possible: we supported the projects that were linked to the European road, but we are, at the moment, in a game that is unfortunately controlled by Moscow.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: – Madam President, by signing the Association Agreements, Moldova, Ukraine and Georgia have chosen a path of close political association and economic integration with the EU. As Chair of the EU-Moldova PAC, I see the value and political significance of this resolution, not only in the implementation assessment, but especially in its clear message on the way ahead. Moldova has gone through an unprecedented political period since the last general election. The new prime minister and his parliamentary majority have the unique opportunity and responsibility to finally provide the country with a stable and predictable political process. Such an environment is a precondition for any thorough reform ambition conducive to genuine and profound progress. By conforming to the European path and implementing the association agenda, I am certain that the country’s pressing issues will finally be addressed – but the most difficult political effort for the incoming executive will be that of regaining the citizens’ trust.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab As a representative of Polish, with experience also in the Polish Parliament, involved in the integration process, I know how challenging it is to carry out the necessary, often very difficult adjustment reforms, and at the same time how difficult it is to maintain public support in these adjustment processes, especially in countries such as Moldova, such as Ukraine, such as Georgia. We, of course, expect this effort in line with the commitments made, but we must also do everything we can to support these countries, as well as their societies, to persevere in this effort. I therefore welcome the progress made through visa liberalisation. Moldova is the leader here. But they also enjoy the criteria confirmed by the European Commission for Ukraine and Georgia. Because time is running out, I want to pick up one thing. What is worrying is the referendum announced in the Netherlands on the approval of the Association Agreement with Ukraine. I think we should make a great effort to help Ukraine make this referendum a positive one.

name: Joachim SCHUSTER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Since 1 January, the free trade agreement with Ukraine has finally been in force, and that is a good thing.  Nevertheless, the economic situation in Ukraine is of great concern. The country is in a deep economic crisis, the social division is deepening, and around a third of its population now lives there at or below the poverty line. I am convinced that this social explosive must be defused as a matter of urgency. I believe that our policy of support to date, as well as the orientation towards free trade, is not enough for this alone, but that additional efforts are needed. Complementary efforts on the ground to promote domestic development, complementary efforts to stimulate investment in infrastructure and in the competitiveness and modernisation of the economy, and also efforts to cushion the social hardships of structural reform, such as the increase in energy prices. The EU must face up to these challenges, together with the Ukrainian Government, so that the process of Bringing Ukraine closer to Europe benefits all people and does not fail because of social intensification. In essence, we need a fundamental reform of the economic components of the European Neighbourhood Policy.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, Association Agreements (AA) and the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Areas (DCFTA) are one of the most advanced tools we have at our disposal to promote closer cooperation with our neighbours. In the case of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, we made an important political choice to strengthen our ties and bring them closer to the EU. These agreements were partly a response to the aspirations of those countries and their citizens to put their relations with the EU on a higher level. In the situation in which the countries are juggling different internal reforms and external pressures, the AAs and DCFTAs should stimulate reform processes and economic growth. We have to be supportive of the reforms, but also demanding, especially when it comes to consolidating democracy, eradicating corruption and strengthening the rule of law. These are the values which are associated with the EU. Delivering on them is a crucial test for our partners but also for the EU’s image and credibility in the neighbourhood.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – These treaties signed by the European Union with Georgia, Ukraine and Moldova are the most ambitious of their kind and these association agreements should ensure greater stability, democracy and prosperity across the continent, including in our interest. Many difficult reforms have already been implemented in these countries over the past year. But if you look, you can see that there are still three persistent problems. One is corruption. The fight against corruption must be the basis for all progress. Moldova and Ukraine in particular are still struggling with this problem. There is still a real shift to be made in the legal sector and unfortunately, the winner takes all mentality continues to dominate in these three countries.  Another thing they have in common is the threat and aggression of their large neighbour Russia. It is good that the EU is making these ambitious treaties with these three, which are not about membership, but about intensive cooperation. And I hope that on 6 April the majority of the Dutch population will say yes to the association agreement with Ukraine.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, obviously all three countries, Georgia, the Republic of Moldova and Ukraine, benefit from the Association Agreement and the Free Trade Agreement. However, despite the potential, we see, in the Republic of Moldova, the situation has worsened over the last few months. Political instability has led to economic instability. Inflation is at its highest level in seven years, the national currency is losing value and foreign investment is falling, which means less economic growth, higher unemployment in the coming period.  Based on this situation, people are obviously slight victims of pro-Russian propaganda and I believe that we cannot assist carelessly. That is why I think it is important to do the following two things in the following period: 1) the European Commission to send a joint team together with the International Monetary Fund immediately now, after the establishment of the government - a joint team to examine how the Republic of Moldova can be helped financially and 2) senior European officials to participate actively in the drafting of the work programme of the future government and in the necessary reforms in that country.

name: Clare MOODY
text: – Madam President, I am delighted this resolution welcomes the efforts that Georgia has made to implement the Association Agreement with its DCFTA. I also welcome the fact that, since this agreement, trade between the EU and Georgia has significantly increased. But this agreement is about far more than trade. It is about shared values and deepening our long-standing relationship. We need to support the work that has been done, and is being done, to develop a free and open political environment and to achieve social cohesion. The social dimension of these agreements is vital to building and maintaining the confidence of citizens in our shared values. There is still work to be done, but without doubt, progress is being made, in particular through dialogue and reconciliation. Finally, I welcome the Commission’s progress report on the visa liberalisation action plan and look forward to the related legislative proposals and approval.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Madam President, it is very interesting to listen to the voices of Putin in this chamber, because this defines very much what this issue is about. They dislike and do not want to express respect for the territorial integrity of these countries. They do not want to support the independence and national sovereignty of these countries. They are against free trade and open markets and transparent energy trade. They are against visa liberalisation. They are against cooperation in the fight against corruption and bureaucracy and disrespect for the rule of law. They are defending the interests of Putin in Europe, and it is shameful. It also reminds us what this is about: defending an open Europe, ensuring that European values are strong, and doing what we can in order to support the citizens of these countries.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Madam President, I am very happy that today we can discuss the resolutions on Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova in their efforts to deepen cooperation with the European Union. It is important to say that this is an effort that they have chosen freely and that has not been made to them by anyone. The European Parliament has already shown its willingness several times to support not only the governments of these countries, but also civil society in all its forms. Aid is thus not just in the economic ser area, because we will best support civil society there by ensuring free dissemination of information and free dialogue. I am therefore happy and would like to thank the European Commission and, in particular, Mrs Mogherini, for the StratCom service, which is trying to combat the propaganda of the current Russian regime. I believe that these efforts should continue and be made, and I hope that the Commission will do so.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab January 2016 is a breakthrough or the next stage in the beautiful and good path of moldova, Georgia and Ukraine to be in the family of democratic states of Europe, but we must remember that everything that is happening between the European Union and these countries takes place on two levels. One is the great one that allows these countries, and their peoples in particular, to follow the path of economic development, which also includes increasing prosperity, increasing jobs, reducing social exclusion. But on the other hand, we are dealing with an aggressive attitude, especially of the Russian Federation, but not only – also of the states that want to block, to hinder the aspiration of these free nations and democratically developing states for freedom. We, as Europeans, should support them on this path.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: " Officer, I'm sorry. Ukraine has come a long way to break with the post-Russian system and start reforms with a European spirit. This process has not yet been completed and, with the Association Treaty with the European Union and the entry into force of the FtA on 1 January, Ukraine has been given new opportunities for development. This treaty will cut tariffs and provide access to a new market of 500 million people, which will give the economy a pulse by expanding trade relations. These opportunities should also be exploited at regional level, so it would be important, for example, to re-create the Transcarpathian Free Economic Zone, which was successfully operating in the early 2000s, and the like. This would provide a framework for attracting foreign entrepreneurs and capital to the county, deepening relations between domestic and foreign enterprises, and economic integration of Transcarpathia and its neighbouring countries and regions. This would create many new jobs, which would improve the economy, infrastructure and the standard of living of the population. It would therefore be desperately necessary to restore this special economic zone, since the investments flowing there would enable the development of industry, the modernisation of educational, cultural, touristic and sporting facilities, the development of border crossings and the road system.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: You are the most authentic know-it-all of the events in Ukraine.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, first of all, the European Union must ensure that the right of these three countries, the Republic of Moldova, Ukraine and Georgia, to choose their own path, is respected. Your own path to freedom, democracy, the market economy, respect for human rights, respect for the media, independence of justice and not to an autocratic, dictatorial system that is embraced by the power of the east, who all know who it is, Russia. And this is about the Russian leadership, not the Russian people for whom we have all the esteem and respect. The confrontational policy promoted by Russia does not benefit either Europe and the countries of Europe or Russia. Everybody gets hurt. A united Europe, we must tell the Russians, is also in Russia's interest. And finally, and i finished Madam President, I want to tell our colleagues who support the Russian leadership that if all these three countries...  (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the European Union's agreement with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine signed in 2014 provides for the abolition of most of the customs restrictions between the European Union and these countries, resulting in the agricultural products of these countries flooding Europe at a time when Greek and other European farmers are facing enormous economic problems as a result of the crisis and the Russian embargo. In addition, the free trade agreement to be implemented from 2016 will strengthen large enterprises at the expense of small and inefficient enterprises in these three countries. We are also concerned about corruption in these countries, where the rule of law does not work. Finally, I wonder what the fate of this agreement would have been if the Greeks, Italians and other citizens had been called upon to decide in a referendum, as is now the case with the Dutch referendum.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, I strongly support this agreement with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine for a simple reason – because these countries, these peoples, all its citizens are very much entitled to a European perspective. That's why I think, Mr. Commissioner Hahn, you've done a good job. You have done a good job in our eastern neighbourhood and I believe this perspective that opens up to the citizens of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine will be exploited. However, the prospects being opened must, of course, be used to introduce the right European values in that country. And not only because of them, but also because of us and our credibility that these agreements are not misunderstood, because they are neither against Russia nor against any other state, but are for the benefit of the citizens of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine and democracy on the European continent.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – Madam President, I reject some agreements which will allow European multinationals to take ownership of the rich lands of Ukraine, its minerals or its waters, or the iron of Georgia, the timber, the hydropower, and also benefit from their situation as a Europe-Caucasus-Asia transport corridor.  The Commissioner has already told us about the interest in his millions of consumers. But these peoples must also know what the situation of the peoples of southern Europe is, after European multinationals have taken ownership of our resources and occupied our markets.  We must also tell these peoples that, with the implementation of the austerity policy, in Galicia, in my country, after 30 years of the European Union, we have been hungry again. More than 50% of young people are unemployed and more than 22% of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion. Many thousands of farmers have disappeared and many businesses have been closed. This is the model of the European Union that we offer them.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – Thank you, Honourable President, Commissioner, colleagues, free trade agreements and their other level– association agreements – are among the few effective instruments of the European Union's external relations. The European Union is committed to expanding the area of freedom, democracy and good governance worldwide in its founding treaties. In exchange for this, we offer great opportunities for trade with the European Union. I recall that Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine are very close neighbours. Their stability and well-being are one of the conditions for peace across Europe. At the same time, colleagues, I would like to call for a more lenient look at the efforts of partner countries, and I would like to ask the Commission to do more to act as an aide to the partner countries to achieve their objectives, rather than rushing to punish the slightest mistakes.

name: Tim AKER
text: – Madam President, thanks to UKIP, this year, or maybe next year, the United Kingdom will have its referendum on our membership of the European Union. But we are not alone. This year, in April, the Netherlands will vote on its accession deal with the Ukraine, and my plea to Dutch patriots across the pond is: put a spanner in the works. Say ‘no’ to this institution; say ‘no’ to this Union that disrespects your democracy.
