It was not so long ago that you said ‘no’ to the European Constitution, but this place decided to ignore that, dump the constitution and rebrand it as the Lisbon Treaty. A ‘no’ vote in the Netherlands means that the United Kingdom has a fillip going into its referendum. My plea to the British people watching this now is: ‘we are not alone’. Millions of people across this Union, across this continent, are sick and tired of this place, this institution. We yearn for our democracy back; we yearn for our borders to be returned and we yearn for the peoples of our nation states to be in control. We are public servants and it is time the people had the final say.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Madam President, the European Union is pushing for the implementation of association agreements and free trade agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. However, these agreements create problems in some Member States. In particular, the Free Trade Agreements create conditions of unfair competition for agricultural and livestock products in the countries of the European South to which Greece belongs. In addition, they also create political problems. Moldova, for example, has bilateral relations with the pseudo-state of Turkey-occupied Northern Cyprus. Moldovan nationals can therefore go to this area without a visa. However, this violates international law prohibiting the de facto recognition of occupied areas. At the same time, it also offends Cyprus, which is a member of the European Union. Given this, how do you ask us to approve these agreements?

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, honourable Members, first and foremost I would like to thank you, Madam President, for your very clear statement concerning President Juncker. On Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova, these three partners have made a courageous choice to align themselves more closely with the European Union by undertaking ambitious and far-reaching reforms. They do this in the face of significant challenges coming both from within their countries and from the outside, and unlike some of their predecessors, they do this without the firm promise of EU membership at the end of the process. So we owe our partners our full and unwavering support as they travel on this road. The EU will offer them support, whether it is financial, technical or political. We have every interest in ensuring that our partners succeed in these efforts, because their success will also be our success and their failure would be our failure. But ultimately, this process must be one that is owned by our partners and done because it is the right thing for them to do, not because we asked them to do it. This is the message which I gave clearly to the Ukrainian and Georgian Governments when I visited Kiev and Tbilisi last November, and I believe their actions demonstrate that they fully understand this. On Moldova and the very recent events: the situation is tense, no doubt, and I appeal to everybody, to every party inside and outside the Parliament, to have a peaceful political debate and to refrain from any kind of violence. I can reassure you that the High Representative, Federica Mogherini, and myself are in permanent contact with our delegation on the ground to contribute to a peaceful solution of the situation and to help the country. Having said that – and this is another example – political association and economic integration of our Eastern partners will be a marathon, not a sprint, and it will require the active and sustained support of this House. My colleagues and I will continue to keep you fully informed of developments in the coming months and years, and I thank you for this very lively debate.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Six motions for resolutions were sent to me to conclude the debate. The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, 21 January 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I support these motions for resolutions because, as a member of the delegation to Georgia, I welcome the closer cooperation that is important for the region. I also see the agreements as the right way forward for closer political and economic integration with the European Union. I regret Russia's reaction and its unilateral lifting of its free trade agreement with Ukraine at the time when the EU-Ukraine Free Trade Agreement entered into force. These trade restrictions affect ukraine's economy and financial situation.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European aspirations of Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine are very important, but apart from the obvious course towards the EU, they are linked by another very important element, the common denominator, which must not be forgotten in the context of these three countries. It is Russia. Russia, which still regards it as its exclusive zone of influence and plays a very destabilising role, waged an active war in eastern Ukraine, annexing Crimea, occupying the Georgian territories of Abkhazia and South Ossetia and preventing the resolution of the frozen conflict in Transdistrian. When we talk about these countries, about the necessary reforms, about their aspirations and aspirations, we must not forget Russia. In this context, we must always and unconditionally provide Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine with all the support we can afford. As the situation of Crimea has shown us, lugansk and Doneck's Russians will not back down from anything to keep these countries in their zone of influence. It is often said in such debates that, since we are talking about these countries, we should focus only on the internal situation, the fight against corruption and the changes that are being made. That is not true. When talking about them, we must always remember those forces that look at any changes very reluctantly, and which lurk at every stumble of the authorities in Tbilisi, Kiev and Chisinau.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the Recommendation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement (10725/2/2015 - C8-0328/2015 - 2015/0094(NLE)) (Rapporteur: Lunacek Ulrike) (A8-0372/2015).

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, as Vice-President of this Parliament in charge of the Sakharov Prize network I would like to start before going into details of the SAA with commemorating the Sakharov Prize laureate from 1998, Ibrahim Rugova, who died just 10 years ago on 23 January 2006. He is still the symbol of Kosovo independence, a symbol of nonviolent struggle, a great poet and leader of Kosovo-Albanians whom I would like to commemorate here at the start of this debate.  I now come to the EU-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA). It was negotiated between October 2013 and May 2014; it was initialled in July 2014; the Council agreed to its signature on 22 October 2015 and then it was signed here in Strasbourg on 27 October by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy Federica Mogherini and by Commissioner Johannes Hahn, on behalf of the EU, and also by the Republic of Kosovo’s Prime Minister Isa Mustafa and the Minister for European Integration Bekim Çollaku. The Kosovo Assembly ratified it on 2 November 2015. Now it is up to us here tomorrow to vote for this Stabilisation and Association Agreement of the European Union with Kosovo and afterwards it can enter into force.  This is a historic moment for Kosovo because for the first time the EU and Kosovo will have contractual relations. It is the first official formal step on the way to full EU integration and to becoming a member of the European Union. Yes, it has taken some time because of Kosovo being a new country, its independence was just eight years ago, and in the Council too it took some time, but let me express my welcome for the fact that the five Member States who still have not recognised Kosovo have also given their consent.  This is a big step forward and I would just like to urge them to move forward on that and go on to recognise Kosovo. Some of these countries have ministers visiting Kosovo, meeting with government officials, so please just go ahead and recognise Kosovo, this youngest republic in the European Union. I can tell you that it does not hurt. It would just help people.  So what is this SAA about? As I said, it introduces contractual relations for the first time. It provides for enhanced political dialogue, trade integration and new forms of cooperation. It covers numerous sectors, be they strengthening of democratic principles or human rights, but also a framework for cooperation on sectors such as education, energy, environment, justice and home affairs and many more. It also sets out rights and obligations and it provides a powerful incentive for the implementation and institutionalisation of reforms, because Kosovo still needs reforms and there the government has to move on.  It also creates opportunities for investment but at the same time good governance is required through the application of European standards and approximation to European Union laws. Furthermore it creates great opportunities for enhancing contacts between people, between experts, between citizens, in sectors such as education, environment and culture, but also of course on combating crime and trafficking, and it foresees further strengthening of relations and cooperation with neighbouring countries, thus contributing also to stability in the region.  But of course this exchange between people, between citizens, also needs both Kosovo and the European Union to move ahead with visa liberalisation. Kosovo is the only country in the region where citizens still cannot travel freely. They feel locked in. So this SAA is a very important step but visa liberalisation has to come. The best would be now in the next couple of months.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start by thanking you for your support for the continuing development of EU-Kosovo relations. I also want to thank the Foreign Affairs and International Trade Committees and rapporteurs – Ulrike Lunacek in particular – for their support. Tomorrow’s vote on the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, renegotiated with Kosovo, is testament to this focus. The SAA is a milestone in EU-Kosovo relations and of critical importance for the future of Kosovo and the whole Western Balkans. The agreement is the first formal contractual relationship that ties the European Union and Kosovo together. It allows Kosovo to join the rest of the region, sharing the benefits of deepening political and economic interdependence and sharing in the common European perspectives that make peace, stability and prosperity our joint goal. The agreement will help Kosovo with much-needed economic reform underpinned by the rule of law. This should ensure a more predictable business environment, leading to much-needed growth and jobs. The agreement helps establish a stable legal framework and gradual approximation with EU laws and standards. It also promotes the free movement of goods, services and capital and envisages higher standards and increased choice and lower prices for Kosovo citizens. It should stimulate Kosovo’s progress in the area of transport and energy as it foresees the gradual integration into Europe’s energy markets and the development of quality infrastructure. The agreement should also strengthen regional cooperation. Under its terms, Kosovo commits itself to a visible and sustainable improvement in relations with Serbia. This is an essential principle of our agreement. The continuation of the EU-facilitated dialogue with Serbia is therefore a legal obligation. Kosovo will need to implement the agreements it has reached and continue to work towards further agreements. As we have seen over the last few months, this sometimes involves taking difficult decisions and the need for compromise. Finally, I want to underline that the agreement includes provisions that commit Kosovo to high international standards in terms of respect for democratic principles. This is of particular relevance to the challenges Kosovo is facing at the moment. It means that the institutions set up to ensure democratic government and the rules that allow these institutions to do their work should be respected. It also means there can be no obstruction to free and transparent political discourse. Obstruction and violence have no place in a democratic system. Allow me to use this opportunity to call on Kosovo’s politicians to engage in a free political exchange to solve the differences in a way that is worthy of the country’s European perspective: without obstructions, without violence and without threats and intimidation. Allow me to thank you once more for your support, and I look forward to the debate.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: draftss author of the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Trade. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Dear! On behalf of the European People's Party, I want to unequivocally support the implementation of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo. Kosovo is a small country in the western Balkans, but we must also remember that this is the last country among all those with which we sign these agreements. The most important thing is what the Commissioner has already presented. This agreement brings with it many good solutions for the European Union and, above all, for this small country and for this small nation, which is suffering poverty, perhaps the largest of all the peoples of Europe. So here we have a chance to support and support Kosovo. On the other hand, however, it will also benefit the European Union, if only in terms of migration, which is a very big problem and challenge today.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for It is a pleasing and historic event when the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Kosovo is now becoming a reality. The agreement is a milestone for Kosovo and offers, among other things, new opportunities for its economy. Troubling obstacles to the internal market are disappearing and the agreement confirms that Kosovo's future is European. At the same time, we can see that European integration cannot be taken for granted. It requires political will and requires political decision-making. It is not least a question of implementing agreed reforms. In this context, I note that Parliament's rapporteur, Mrs Lunacek, has stressed the importance of stepping up efforts to combat corruption. This is central. Corruption is a crucial obstacle to Kosovo's further development.  The political will must also include the implementation of agreements which may be unpopular with their own electorate but which, at the same time, are crucial for the normalisation of relations with the neighbouring country. This is a responsibility that is the responsibility of the government, but also the representatives of the opposition. Finally, I would like to express my support for this historic first formal agreement between the EU and Kosovo.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this Association and Stabilisation Agreement with Kosovo is an important step because it can create the conditions for the progress of the process of rapprochement with the European Union. It is an agreement, as I have said, establishing contractual relations that guarantee greater political dialogue, further trade integration and new forms of cooperation in the various sectors.  Of course, this agreement is important, but it is not a solution. The situation in Kosovo is still very problematic, as we have seen in recent serious demonstrations, and the need for democratic consolidation of Kosovo's institutional structures is a fundamental issue in order to ensure a positive perspective for the country and the Balkan region. Above all, we need it at this stage, which is characterised by enormous problems, such as migration, which make the Balkan region and Kosovo an extremely delicate crossroads on which we must pay close attention, because it is clear that it can also cause major problems with regard to the European Union.  For these reasons, in giving our full support to the Association and Stabilisation Agreement, we believe at the same time useful to call on the European Commission to accompany Kosovo towards more advanced objectives. We absolutely need this country to embark seriously on the road to reform and democratic consolidation.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam Presidencies, honourable members, my EQF Group welcomes kosovo's Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the European Union. I welcome and congratulate Mrs. Lunacek on the preparation. Kosovo is in an extremely difficult situation – institutions and independent regulators are highly politicized, the judiciary is not functioning properly, there is no progress in the fight against organised crime and corruption, and the economic environment and high unemployment are causing people to flee the country.  Integration is vital for Kosovo because the country needs help in building its statehood and institutions, and kosoors need jobs, business development, economic growth and rising living standards. I hope that the Agreement will stabilize the country and help establish ethnic peace in the country. There is no other region in Europe, such as the Balkan Peninsula, where ethnic understanding influences the very existence of countries so much.  In order to avoid tensions and conflicts on an ethnic basis, we should not turn a blind eye and downplay violations of the rights of ethnic communities, both in Kosovo and in other countries in the region and the pre-accession package. I am talking about the Bulgarians in Macedonia, the Bulgarians and the Forest in Kosovo, the Croats in Serbia and many other national communities, the Bulgarians in Serbia too, who remained outside the borders of their countries after the devastating wars at the end of the last century.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, on behalf of the ALDE Group, I give my full support for the signing and imminent entry into force of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with the Republic of Kosovo and I also expect that a framework agreement on Kosovo's participation in the European Union programmes will be signed soon. Kosovo is a country facing internal difficulties, instability in an equally volatile region. It should be known that the two countries in Southeast Europe, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina have not recognised Kosovo. There are a number of open, mutual issues, some political forces do not want, do not recognize de facto, hidden or not, the countries in which they live, hint at boundary changes that in this area probably or almost certainly would not pass without new conflicts.  That is why it is important that this Agreement is fully applied very ambitiously. It's not just an economic agreement, it's an agreement that includes building democratic institutions, building an entire society, strengthening the judiciary, so it's very important that these components of this agreement are used very ambitiously and very committedly. This is in the interest of the European Union. This is equally in the interest of the people of Kosovo, because only in this way will we get Kosovo, which will be able to apply for membership of the European Union very soon and thus join other countries of the region in order to get a country that will be stable and a region that will be stable in such a way, with the help of this way to the European Union, because it is a space located within the European Union. , and of course the interest of the European Union, not only the citizens of Kosovo and other countries, is to make this process of joining the European Union as high quality and as fast as possible.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, in our group we have not changed our position on Kosovo, which we consider to be a purported State, imposed outside the community and international law. In fact, the self-proclaimed Republic of Kosovo does not belong to the United Nations and is not recognized by more than half of its members, including my country. United Nations Resolution 1244, which must oversee Kosovo's self-government institutions pending political agreement, is still governing. And to this day, neither the Government of the Republic of Serbia nor the provisional authorities of self-government have yet concluded a political solution other than the current status quo. Behind some positions of support for Kosovo, more than international law is Camp Bondsteel, the second largest U.S. military base in the world, close to the Middle East, the Caucasus, Russia, which allows control over vital pipelines and energy corridors.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Madam President, imperialist contrasts are dangerously exacerbated in the Balkans because of their geostrategic position next to areas torn by competition and wars and which are a passage of refugees and energy pipelines, being a field of great investment and a bridge of the European Union and NATO in areas of great interest to the Russian bourgeoisie. The European Union and NATO war intervention brought the break-up of Yugoslavia, set up protectorates and cultivated ethnic and religious divisions among the peoples to serve Euro-Nato interests and local urban classes. The association agreement under discussion de facto recognises such a protectorate, Kosovo. The Greek government, which is doing the same, has enormous responsibilities. It triggers nationalisms, altruisms, territorial claims and promotes border changes, such as the officially threatened union of Albania and Kosovo in a single state that will have aspirations against neighbouring countries such as the F.B.I. and Greece. A similar resurgence of nationalism is also served by the unacceptable establishment of a group of MEPs' lobby called 'Friends of Macedonia'. The people must be vigilant. Their interest is to fight imperialist plans and overthrow capitalism that sows wars and misery and refugees... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate Kosovo’s government and parliament on finalising and adopting this agreement – it is a milestone in our relations with Kosovo. Establishing contractual relations will open new opportunities on the road to closer integration between Kosovo and the EU. The agreement provides an incentive for the implementation of reforms in Kosovo. As one of the poorest countries in the region, Kosovo should take this agreement as an opportunity for economic and social growth, but also as a chance to make substantial political and institutional reforms. The EU shares responsibility for development in this region. We therefore have to tighten our relations with these countries and their citizens. The SAA with Kosovo is a step in this direction. The next step should lead to visa-free travel for Kosovars. This will be crucial to enable Kosovo businesses and people to fully benefit from the SAA. In other words, with the SAA we have taken an important step, dismantling barriers in our relations with Kosovo. We should be ready to take the next step, dismantling the barriers in our relations with the Kosovan people.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Madam President, I welcome the signing of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Kosovo after less than a year of negotiations. As head of the Delegation for Relations with Kosovo, I believe that the European Parliament will give its consent to its conclusion tomorrow. It is a kind of recognition of Kosovo's commitment to full membership and Europe's future as key goals. At the same time, this completes the process of establishing contractual relations with the Western Balkan countries. This agreement is an important step because it can create opportunities for investment, growth and financial development through the application of European and European Union standards and laws. But further progress will depend on constructive cooperation between all political stakeholders, which is not yet the case. Again, unfortunately, the regional problem of opposition obstruction in Parliament and the violent reaction of the authorities is happening again. The ugly scenes we've been witnessing lately are really inappropriate for a country that has European aspirations. The fight against terrorism and radicalisation, measures to reduce the number of illegal migrants and asylum seekers in the EU, but also work to reduce the high unemployment rate, which is a key precondition for the success of these efforts, should be continued. I hope that the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, as the first treaty between Kosovo and the European Union, will be an incentive for so many institutional and legislative reforms that Kosovo needs to adopt and implement. It would, of course, be great if the youngest European country received undivided European support as soon as possible.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam President, the efforts undertaken by the Kosovo authorities to reach the signing of this agreement are the best guarantor of Kosovo's European perspective. This is a young democracy with many more challenges and serious tasks, so it is extremely important that the authorities are truly committed to the Process of Euro-Atlantic Integration. This process is a great test for the state of Kosovo, but also for the European Union, which must show leadership and the optimal level of common vision of the Member States when it comes to our European backyard. In the context of Kosovo, I think primarily of international recognition. How honest are we with Kosovo when it comes to their European perspective if some of us still do not recognise the very existence of this country? The Stabilisation and Association Agreement is neither the first nor the most important step on Kosovo's European path. This key step is international recognition by all Member States, so I hereby urge those who have not recognised Kosovo so far to finally do so.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Madam President, on 10 June 1999, the UN Security Council placed Kosovo under transitional leadership, creating a state within Yugoslavia and later Serbia. Kosovo, under historical, geographical, spiritual and moral reality, is the heart of Serbia and the soul of the Serbian people. Seventeen years later and a total of 627 from the Battle of Kosovo between the United Serbs, Bosniaks and Croats against the Ottoman Turks, which stopped their advance in Western Europe, some unspeakable and naïve politicians are promoting the European Union-Kosovo Stabilisation and Association Agreement. That's a crime. Kosovo is not a state, nor is there a Kosovar Nation. We must not forget the crimes of Tito's communists who transformed states and literally raped the historical truth, creating Macedonian dreams and Kosovar abortions. Kosovo's accession will be an acceptance of the by force of changing the borders of a state with unilateral secession of Serbian territory, based on the ethnic motives of the Albanians – just as you all seek to happen with the Turkish invasion and occupation of the northern part of Cyprus.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, all these countries from Eastern Europe have to and will join the European Union one day. It is in the interests of Europe and of all these countries. I would like to congratulate Ms Mogherini for the historic agreement that she brokered in August last year between Serbia and Kosovo, working towards the complete normalisation of relations between Belgrade and Priština. However, Belgrade did not recognise the independence of Kosovo, and there are five European Union countries that have still not recognised Kosovan independence. So this mechanism which we are now implementing is a sui generis mechanism to bring Kosovo closer to the European Union. Probably the Commission and the Member States will have to find a way for this country to start accession negotiations with the European Union without it having been recognised by all Member States. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I have listened to the debate, a very mature debate, where most were in favour, some against this SAA. Obviously being in the EPP Group and on the Committee on International Trade, I am very much in favour and I look forward to Kosovo developing and in particular to its people enjoying a higher standard of living and greater confidence as this agreement comes into being, creating more trade and more jobs and a higher standard of living. Also I would say that I look forward to the day when Kosovo will become a full member of the European Union.  Coming as I do from the other side of Europe, Ireland, a small country off the west coast of Europe, that joined in 1973 and has benefited enormously from EU membership ever since, I can say that we  would not dream of leaving the European Union, whatever our friends from the United Kingdom might do. I think the same will probably apply to Kosovo and other countries in that region because they have a lot to offer in terms of creating stability for us, a better neighbourhood and of course internal reforms which will be needed as well.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Stabilisation and association agreements can now be classified as proven effective instruments of the European Union's enlargement policy in the Western Balkans. In order to ensure stability and democratic development in the region, it is high time that Kosovo could also benefit from closer cooperation with the Union, including the perspective of visa-free travel. I regret or regret that the completeness of this process continues to be hampered by the fact that five EU Member States continue to do not recognise kosovo's independent statehood. Perhaps the entry into force of this Convention may be a good opportunity for these Member States to correct the legally and politically advanced situation. I believe that this would also improve the political conditions for the dialogue between Pristina and Belgrade, and not to mention indirectly for the Serbian accession process.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: – Today's report by Mrs Lunacek is about an important stabilisation and association agreement. This is a first and a very important step towards a further rapprochement with the European Union. It therefore deserves our full support. We will also vote on the 2015 progress report shortly. If it goes well, it can be said. There's progress. We must fully support Kosovo to become a society of freedom and progress.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Lunacek, for her excellent work and for all the effort she has put into the content of this report. I believe that the Association Agreement is crucial and it is actually a window into the world for Kosovo, which has lived one difficult period in recent years, decades. In fact, this agreement means an open door for the free movement of goods, people, goods, even enforcement, finally, the so-called visa regime. And, of course, this agreement also provides a great deal of space in the area of energy, infrastructure development and, of course, also opens up the possibilities for addressing environmental challenges, which are not insignificant in Kosovo. Above all, we must be careful: Kosovo also plays an important role in ensuring stability in the region, and that is also the responsibility of the European Union.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is no secret that the majority of our citizens currently see militant Islam as the greatest threat to Europe. If we were to take these fears of the people seriously, then an EU course of Kosovo would probably not be an option either. But this is exactly the course our report maintains. This is despite the fact that the Swiss newspaper "Blick" today raised the question: "Will Kosovo become the first Islamic state in Europe?" This article points out that the Saudi Arabians finance the majority of mosque construction there. As a reminder, Saudi Arabia is the country where the torture of Raif Badawi was carried out only last year, as the rapporteur rightly denounced, and where serial beheadings take place. For the Saudi Kingdom, Kosovo would be a perfect Trojan horse in the Union. You don't have to be a clairvoyant or a cassandra to see this danger clearly. For me, therefore, association or even membership is unrealistic and highly dangerous.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Union and Kosovo is an important step on Kosovo’s European path. It is a key contribution to the Union’s Stabilisation and Association Process for the Western Balkans. It allows Kosovo to join the mainstream with the rest of the region, sharing the same perspective, the same vision and the same future. This includes, by the way, a clear European perspective given that a possible future Member of the European Union has to share European values, and this includes, for example, a clear division between the state and religion. So this is something we should keep in mind. But the next challenge is implementation. The agreement will need time to kick in, it will not show results immediately. The agreement needs to be implemented in the manner and on the base that was agreed. It is not a magic cure that can fix all of Kosovo’s problems. However, I have no doubt that the agreement will help foster a sense of belonging; that it will provide a structure that is shared by others in the region; that it will offer a framework that supports Kosovo in its efforts to meet the aspirations of its citizens, a framework of peace, stability and prosperity. Let me also take the opportunity of this debate to once again call on the government and the opposition in Kosovo to get around the table and discuss their differences. The political crisis Kosovo is facing has already taken far too much time, time that Kosovo can ill afford. Kosovo’s politicians owe it to the people to find solutions urgently. Kosovo’s citizens deserve nothing less. I continue to count on the support of this House to help Kosovo in its efforts to get closer to Europe.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, I would like to thank you all – even those who are for not recognising countries – for your support for this report on the Stabilisation and Association Agreement. This is a very important step, as I have already said.  I just want to refer to one of the non-supporters from GUE. I need to correct him, because more than half of the UN member states (111) have already recognised Kosovo. So it would be high time for Kosovo to become a member of the United Nations and its organisations. Since all of the arguments have been exchanged now, I would like to end with two things. I would like to go back to commemoration of Ibrahim Rugova that I started with this evening, because he is a strong symbol of non-violent struggle. I would like to use that in order to urge the opposition parties in the Kosovo Assembly to follow Rugova’s example and to return to work in the assembly that they were elected to and not keep blocking the parliament’s work, because violence should not have a place in this youngest republic’s parliament – in the parliament of this youngest republic on this European continent. And now to finalise, let me just mention something very different, which is very positive news for Kosovo. Last Thursday, a Kosovo short film – the first ever produced in Kosovo – was nominated for the Academy Awards for the best live action short film. It is called Shock. It is about friends. It is about two boys living during the war, which has already been over for a long time. I would really love to see this Kosovo film awarded an Oscar for best short film on 28 February 2016. It would be a great boon for this young country.  (Applause)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 21 January 2016. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. – I have already stated that I will open the biggest champagne when the last country from the Balkans becomes a member of the EU. It will probably be Kosovo. The Kosovo Marathon towards the EU begins today. I will celebrate because I believe that EU membership of all countries from the Balkans will provide peace and stability, after many centuries, to all citizens of the Balkans. We must clearly tell the people of Kosovo that the emerging extremism will not contribute to the Europeanisation of Kosovo. It is necessary to clearly state that Kosovo must establish partnership relations with Serbia and, in particular, create mechanisms for the protection of the Serb community in Kosovo. For these reasons, I support all that Serbian Prime Ministers Vucic and Albania Rama are doing at the moment. This is a great precondition for the long-term stabilisation of the Balkans. I also call on the 5 EU countries that have not recognised Kosovo to do so in favour of peace in Europe.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – The agreement is a major step towards Kosovo's approach to the EU and should have a positive impact on kosovo's economy as a whole. The agreement will intensify the political dialogue between the EU and Kosovo, boost economic relations and opportunities for cooperation between several sectors. However, achieving economic and political stability in Kosovo will certainly also contribute more broadly to the stability of the whole region.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the systematic mass murder of religious minorities by ISIS (2016/2529(RSP)).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I apologise but it is dealing partially with what was discussed before on Moldova.  Let me first of all say that this debate touches on something that is particularly relevant and very much linked to other debates we held last night: the situation in the Middle East and sectarianism is one of the diseases of our age. For centuries, countless faiths and ethnicities have lived together in the Middle East – more than in any other parts of the world. Of course, sectarian conflicts have always existed, but the diversity of the Middle East has never ever been as vulnerable as it is today. For too long, too many actors have fostered sectarian divisions in a struggle for regional power and this is what we are seeing now. Today, we see the devastating effects of such behaviour. Daesh has turned sectarian strife into a core theme of its propaganda and of its actions. They have used it as a tool for recruitment and as an excuse for claiming oil rich lands – not much to do with religion, but a lot about power. Before I go into more detail on how to tackle the mass murder of minorities, let me be clear on one important thing: Daesh is not just a threat to minorities. A few days ago we learned that Daesh has allegedly killed more than 100 people and kidnapped hundreds in the Syrian city of Deir al—Zor. According to the first reports, all of them were Sunni Muslims. If you look at the numbers of victims in the current conflicts, the vast majority of them are Muslims. This is true in Syria and Iraq, as well as in Nigeria or in Pakistan, and also in Europe we have Muslim victims of terrorist attacks. All faiths, all peoples are victims and united in the fight against terror. This is I think the first duty we have: to send a signal, to send this message. We are all in this. We are all united in this.  Still, we cannot ignore that the plight of individuals belonging to religious minorities, including Christians, in Daesh-controlled areas of Syria and Iraq is dramatic. Christian communities, Kurdish cities, the enslavement of Yazidi women, Shabaks, Druze, Assyrians, we can forget none of them. Faced with terrible atrocities, we need more than condemnation. You can imagine my frustration every time that we come out with a statement condemning – we have to do that because it is a sign of constant attention, which these communities need. But on the other side, we all know very well that condemning is not enough. We need concrete support for these people, so let me focus on actions we have taken in defence of minorities in the Middle East.  First, financial support: we are providing very concrete financial support. The European Union and the Member States are the leading donors for Syria with over EUR 5 billion in assistance. We have been among the first to provide assistance to the Yazidis and Christians in Iraq – I visited some of them exactly last year at Christmas – and to the Kurds in Kobane.  The EU also remains the second largest donor to Iraq. Our funds are helping to bring life back to the regions liberated from Daesh, and we all know that this is central for making it possible for the pluralism of this society to survive. When we say that we must help minorities stay in their land, in the lands where they have lived for centuries, that is exactly what I mean. The European instrument for democracy and human rights supports civil society projects promoting freedom of religion or belief. This goes together with implementing legislation that safeguards the rights of persons belonging to minorities in both Syria and Iraq. As the war still goes on, it can be difficult to look at the future and work on a post-war Middle East. I know that very well. Still, we need to always keep in mind that our long-term goal is that of a peaceful and inclusive democracy. We need to start investing in a peaceful future today if we want tomorrow to be a better one. Let me be completely sincere on this: the resources we have invested, although very important ones, are far from sufficient. Humanitarian response plans for Syria and Iraq were under-funded in 2015. This needs to change under the new humanitarian response plans for 2016, and we have worked on this. The European Union continues to contribute to humanitarian aid, and let me say I count very much on this Parliament’s support for our action to be strengthened this year. It will be important to commit to a strong pledge at the upcoming London Conference of Donors for Syria that will be co-hosted by the UK, Germany, Norway, Kuwait and the United Nations on 4 February this year. Apart from financial support, we have other fields of action. The second one is guaranteeing that justice will be done – accountability. This is a crucial step towards peace and national reconciliation. This is why the European Union supports the Independent International Commission of Inquiry on Syria, which collects evidence on the violations committed in view of future legal action. The EU also provides political and financial support to efforts from civil society to promote accountability in Syria. Our European Union has called for the UN Security Council to refer the situation in Syria to the International Criminal Court. As for Iraq, we are aware that minority groups, in particular the Yazidis, have demanded that the crimes committed against them by Daesh be considered genocide. Third field of action – we are seeking the broadest engagement of relevant regional actors and of international organisations. This is because we believe that it is, for sure, a task for the European Union – but not for the European Union alone – to protect minorities in the Middle East. Since the beginning of the crisis, we have sought to involve our Muslim partners first and foremost on the solution of it. We are part of the global coalition countering Daesh and contribute to its objectives with non-military means, as you know.  Let me also stress that our condemnation of the crimes of Daesh will never be as powerful as those of the Muslim religious authorities. They are our best allies in this fight. We have, in particular, cooperated with the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation an engagement which led us to the consensual adoption of a UN resolution on fighting religious intolerance. I have, in particular, in the last months upgraded our cooperation with the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation. The EU also supports the proposal by France and the Accountability, Coherence and Transparency Group that the Security Council develops a code of conduct whereby permanent members agree to refrain from using their veto with respect to those mass atrocities which the responsibility to protect seeks to prevent. We are happy to see that this proposal is gradually gaining more support within the larger UN membership. The fourth field of action, maybe the most urgent one: we are on the front line of all diplomatic efforts to find a political solution to the war in Syria and join forces against Daesh and, let me add, supporting the work of the Iraqi authorities towards national inclusion and reconciliation. We are finally getting to a stage in Syria where the Syrian parties can finally, hopefully, sit together and try to find their own way out of the war. After five years of bloodshed, reconciliation and peace will not be easy for sure, but is it possible – and more than possible, necessary. There is no other way to preserve the incredible diversity of the Middle East. Building up strong and inclusive societies – strong and inclusive democracies where all people have a say, where all rights are guaranteed, where living together is possible and it is safe and good for all. Despite the hardships, minorities in the Middle East have not lost hope. Just one month ago, the Catholic community in Aleppo celebrated the beginning of the Catholic jubilee of mercy. They did so by opening a holy door in the local church of Saint Francis. Life goes on, faith goes on, and it is a powerful symbol of forgiveness, of faith and confidence in a better future. In a recent interview, the Catholic Bishop of Aleppo quoted an Islamic proverb which goes this way: ‘Allah provides even for a black ant on a black rock crawling in a dark night,’ and he continued, ‘we are not alone and the bells of our churches will keep tolling’. These people have not lost hope. Personally, I am not a believer, but I am a strong believer in the rights of all to live in peace and respect. I am a strong believer in the value of diversity, in the richness of different communities sharing their identities, their stories, their wisdom, their past and their future, the hopes and aspirations, their lives. That is the strength of open societies: the capacity to live together, and this has been and is the strength of the European Union and of the Middle East. We cannot let them down, and the only way to make sure we do not let them down is to obstinately push for a political solution to the current crisis. We have discussed that yesterday night in this room – to reject all sectarianism, to keep working for a regional settlement of all disputes and for national reconciliation.  Our friends in the Middle East have not lost hope. If we care about them, we have to keep working for peace and let us not lose hope either. (Applause)

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, let me begin by thanking the High Representative, Ms Mogherini, for her important statement. Christians in Iraq and Syria are, on a daily basis, abducted, raped, tortured and forced to flee their homeland. The total number of Christians has dropped dramatically. Christianity, and its individuals, traditions and historic sites, are being wiped out. Let us be clear: it is absolutely imperative to stop Islamic State. For some time, it has been reported that crimes against humanity are going on. Sadly, the situation is worse. ISIS is guilty of the most detestable, cruellest crimes defined in international law. A great number of the world’s leading lawyers affirm that the ongoing persecution is met by the strictest definition of genocide. In December, the President of this Parliament, Mr Schulz, said that the persecution of Christians is undervalued and has not been properly addressed. We have to change that. For the sake of the victims, for the fundamental right of restitution and reconciliation, we have an historic obligation to call these evil …  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the In this House we have often dealt with Da'esh, this culture of death, which is not sacred. Da'esh fights radically and totally against everything that does not correspond to his rigid postulates: infidels, Shiites, Sunnis, Alevis, Christians and Yazidis. In two resolutions, this House has already dealt with Yazidi women and with Assyrian Christians. Just today we learned that Da'esh had razed a 1400-year-old monastery, St. Elias, near Mosul. We must continue to fight this fight, consistently and relentlessly. We need to work out the causes and backgrounds, because we need to create conditions under which democracy, religious freedom and human rights will be possible again in the future. We must start work on reconciliation now in order to lay the foundations for future development. Above all, however, we need our support for those people who are still held hostage by the terrorists: hundreds of Christians, thousands of Yazidi women. They suffer and they are treated like commodities, they are a source of income for Da'esh. Yazidi women are also sold to countries with which we have economic relations, such as Saudi Arabia. For the Assyrian Christians, a ransom of 25 million dollars is demanded, and this is to be handled through banks that .... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I am very disappointed that this Parliament has opted to use the title ‘systematic mass murder’ in what is clearly genocide. Last year I visited the Kurdistan region of Iraq and met with Iraqi Christian refugees. Their plight as well as that of the Yazidis and other minorities is clearly due to a concerted campaign by ISIS to systematically rid Iraq and the wider Middle East of all non-Sunni Muslims. Religious minorities have seen their communities in the areas controlled by ISIS or Daesh destroyed, as men have been systematically executed and women have been captured as sex slaves.  Yesterday’s report by the UNHRC highlighted these details in no uncertain terms and noted that such crimes, and I quote: ʻmay in some instances amount to war crimes, crimes against humanity and possibly genocideʼ. It is time for us now to take action that will remove such equivocation of labelling these crimes as such and put pressure on the UNSC and the P-5 to refer ISIS and its leadership under the terms of command responsibility to the ICC. I understand from my meetings with a KRG that the Iraqi Government is... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Tannock... (Mr Tannock continues speaking) Colleague... (Mr Tannock: ‘You cut me off every bloody time, Mr President, what’s wrong with you?’) Mr Tannock, there is nothing wrong with me but every time the interpreters ask you to slow down, and I try to give a sign (bangs desk with gavel) – not to interrupt you – but you simply do not react; you even increase the speed. It is not possible to read out speeches where normal people need four minutes and you want to do it in two minutes. It is not possible to keep up the order in the House, otherwise the booths stop the service. If you do not check your speed, I will take the floor off you.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Mr President, you are abusing my privilege as an MEP to speak at the velocity I wish to speak at and deliver my speech in. I am very sorry, that is not your prerogative and I wish to appeal to President Schulz. It is the second time you have stopped me mid-track while I have been speaking on a very important topic. Most people here can perfectly well understand my English. Can I please complete my speech?

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Tannock, I will interrupt you more often if you want, and it is not true that you can speak as fast as you like. In the rules it is clearly laid down that if a booth stops interpreting then the whole session has to be interrupted and this is why you cannot speak as fast as you want. (Mr Tannock: ‘There is no such rule, Mr President, you made it up!’)

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, it is impossible to understand the Middle East without the presence of different communities. It is impossible to understand the Middle East without the presence of the Jewish community, which has already disappeared, without the presence of the different Christian communities—Caldeas, Assyrian, Syrian, Catholic, Maronite. The problem is not simply what is happening with the Islamic State. Christians in Iraq began to leave massively after the U.S. invasion.  In Israel and occupied Palestine fewer and fewer Christians remain, so that Bethlehem, which was mostly Christian, now has a rigorous Christian minority. They're leaving. And they leave because life is impossible to live and because different communities need to protect themselves in enclosed spaces. And in this way we find how the Druze defend themselves from others; how Yazidi have to self-offend; how Shiites, how Sunnis, Alawites, Maronites, different communities become watertight islands. And this is a tragedy.  Because there is a need for Europe. If we don't have a spirit of solidarity, at least let's have healthy selfishness. Our need is that in the Middle East there is a powerful Christian community, because historically it has existed and because it means the best reference and the best bridge of communication. We have already destroyed an exemplary Islamic community in Bosnia for abandoning it and have now abandoned the different communities: Yazidi and Christians. Let's stop rhetoric, they need active defense, not just a metaphysical condemnation. We haven't given them anything, not even hope.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, this is the second time you have disrespected my colleague and interrupted him during important speeches. I demand that you apologise to him and I will inform the Presidency of this tendencies policy you are making towards my colleague.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: You do not need to inform the Bureau, I will do that. There is a long history in this story and I always try to make Mr Tannock aware by this sign (the President is hitting the desk with his hammer) that he is speaking more slowly. There is an emergency button here, which lights up whenever the cabins are too fast. This is not a tendentious decision. If Mr Tannock does not respond to this matter, I shall interrupt him, and having done so and not even listening, I have completely withdrawn his word.  This is fully in line with the Rules of Procedure and I stand by every Bureau decision. Mr Le Hyaric is now speaking. (Interjections from Mr Tannock) I will no longer discuss this point, the Rules of Procedure, with you this evening. I shall refer this matter to the Bureau.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Daesh and those associated with it are the figure of the violent and criminal rejection of all human values, of all thoughts, of thought itself, camouflaged behind the screen of a religion that they smear by torturing, butchering, killing, beheading everything that does not resemble them: the democrats, the young, the creators, the musicians, the Kurds, the religious minorities living under their heels of iron and blood.  Christians, Yezidi, Alawites, Copts from Libya... Let us not forget that the main victims of these fascist mercenaries are Muslims. We must therefore fight mercilessly these monsters, which should not exempt us from a reflection on the sources that made this terrorism-fascism: a certain Western morgue, the culture of the law of the strongest, the smell of oil and money, which Daesh loves above all else, and wars.  Institutions must act without weakening to protect religious minorities, to roll back the criminal nihilism of Daesh and to really help peoples to get out of their difficulties, from poverty, by seeking a new framework of Euro-Mediterranean partnership for human co-development.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Attacks on religious minorities in the world have increased markedly recently – against Christians, against Shiites, against Yazidis and against other religious groups. Daesh blindly attacks anyone who doesn't believe in the same as them. Most of the victims are Muslims, but Daesh has also killed thousands of Christians and forced hundreds of thousands to flee their homes. They have destroyed over a hundred Christian cultural and religious cultural heritage, including in Nineveh and Palmyra. In Sweden there is today one of the world's largest diasporas of Assyrians, Syrians and Chaldeans, and it has grown rapidly as a result of Daesh ethnic cleansing in the Middle East. One hundred years after the genocide of 1915, we see history repeatwhen the same people are once again expelled and murdered. Syria's Christian population has fallen to less than a tenth and is therefore a religion that has existed in the region for over 2,000 years under serious threat.  It is therefore important that we call what is happening today as an ongoing genocide and crimes against humanity and it is extremely important that we act before they are completed. Because past wars in the name of religion have been devastating for our region, and I believe that europe can and should do even more to put an end to the famine tactics that we are seeing – we have seen horrific images being hijacked in the media recently – but also to lift the blockade of humanitarian aid to northern Syria, where various religious and ethnic minorities live. All religious and ethnic minority groups should have the right to live in their historical and traditional home countries in dignity, equality and security.

name: Margot PARKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I would like today to raise the tragic issue of the persecution of Christians in refugee camps. After escaping the horrors most people only see on their TV screens, many Christians face targeted persecution because of their faith in UN-registered camps right across the Middle East. Perhaps even more shockingly, this behaviour has been witnessed in Germany, with families returning to Iraq rather than suffer the continued persecution they face by radical Islamists here in Europe. This is for those Christians that are lucky enough to make it to Europe. The persecution in these camps means that many Christians are forced to leave. It is from these camps that legitimate refugee cases are processed. The situation they face is so bad that only a tiny percentage of Christians are processed by the UN. This is scandalous at a time when they are at their most vulnerable and are supposed to actually be in a safe haven; surely these people should not have to continue to suffer in this way.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Almost every day we are already heard atrocities by ISIS, and we are discussing ISIS here, I do not know for how many times. I can only tell you that the terrorists are laughing at the discussions that we are having here. We are discussing this without really having anything in our hands, without really being able to help the people who would need help on the ground. Just a few days ago, 300 people were killed in Dair az-Zaur. But it is not only murder that is on the agenda of these terrorists, systematic rape and enslavement of people are also part of their tyranny. And it hits particularly hard – and this is the issue – of other believers who are exposed to this terror without protection. Mosul, for example, a city with a 1,600-year-old Christian tradition, has been Christian-free since 2014. This is also a good way to boast on the ground. This has happened through the murder and expulsion of the resident Christians. Let us not be under any illusions, ladies and gentlemen: ISIS will not stop at Europe either. Nor has he stopped at Europe, as the past year has shown us. His stated goal is to make the West Christian-free. We must confront this mass and genocide with the utmost rigour. Words alone will not suffice.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, I welcome this debate in the House tonight. It is absolutely right that we in this Parliament, who enjoy the benefits of peaceful representative democracy in our Member States, should stand united in condemning the mass murder of religious minorities by Daesh. Weekly, we here often see images of mass killings, beheadings, gang rapes, hangings, and endless other barbaric acts perpetrated by fanatical jihadists.  However, this Parliament should go further and recognise this barbarity for what it is: genocide and war crimes directed against Christians and other religious minorities. This afternoon I was pleased to attend the presentation by Open Doors of their watch list of those countries where Christians are most persecuted. I was struck by the simple fact that persecution against Christians is rising year—on—year. They estimated that, before the war in Syria, 400 000 Christians were in Aleppo. Today there are 6 000 …  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Michèle ALLIOT-MARIE
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, in the convention of 9 December 1948, the United Nations classifies all acts committed with the intention of destroying, in whole or in part, a national, ethnic, racial or religious group, as genocide. We are indeed, with the crimes that are committed against Christians, not just Christians, I agree with you, but against Christians in particular, in the context of genocide. It is essential that our Parliament asks the United Nations for this to be recognised. Why, you'll tell me? It is not a word like any other: genocide is a word that has legal significance and legal meaning, and at the same time it is a word that has an important psychological and diplomatic significance. That is why it is essential that we take this initiative. Today, of course, it is not simply by law that we can fight Daesh. We need weapons and diplomacy, but we also have to use the law. This is a strong signal to Christians and to all minorities, but especially to Christians, because, let us not forget, they are very lonely. And we, who claim the Christian roots of Europe, have a special duty towards them.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: – Mr President, let me start by thanking the High Representative for her statement in this matter. People in Iraq and Syria are consistently being raped, tortured or killed on a daily basis by the so-called Islamic State. According to the Qur’an, ‘whosoever kills a soul, it shall be as if he had killed all humanity and he who saves a life, it shall be as if he had given life to all humanity’. ISIS destroys places of worship, mosques, churches and other places of cultural heritage, but the Qur’an teaches that the places of worship are supposed to be not only respected, but protected and defended. ISIS eradicates the ethnic and cultural minorities who have coexisted for centuries, as they do not subscribe to their twisted beliefs. While the Qur’an reads that there is no compulsion in faith, the Islam that I and the millions of Muslims in Europe and around the world follow rejects the inhumane methods of ISIS. But rejecting it is not enough. We must act. Whether in Europe or the Middle East, communities are stronger when they work together to combat terrorist propaganda and to administer programmes that celebrate diversity and empower minorities. Everyone has a right to fundamental freedoms and respect of their human rights, regardless of their beliefs or ethnicity. It is our duty to stand in solidarity with the oppressed.

name: Ryszard Antoni LEGUTKO
text: – Mr President, the concept of systematic mass murder is suitable in journalism, not in official political statements. The right word is genocide. The law does not know the concept of systematic mass murder, whereas genocide is a clearly defined concept in law; it has legal weight. So use this concept, Madam High Representative: if you use it once, use it more often, use it all the time in this context. Who are the victims of the genocide? Yes, religious minorities – Muslims to be sure – but primarily Christians. Why not say it over and over and over again, Madam High Representative? Many thousands of Christians are being murdered every year. There have been several genocides in the past. The amazing thing is that each time they were perpetrated they were not called genocide out of fear of political expediency – the identification came later, and that is a shame. Are we going to do this shameful evasion today? Yes: there is genocide of Christians today.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Mr President, ISIS’s genocide of religious minorities raises two questions: why, and what can be done about it? The cause is ideological. Some say that ISIS represents a perversion of Islam. In fact, it represents a literalist interpretation of the Qur’an. The Qur’an speaks of making war on infidels, killing infidels and striking terror into the hearts of infidels. The Qur’an endorses beheadings, crucifixions and slavery. Even the systematic rape of non-Muslim women is justified by the verse that says: ‘Those you have taken with your right hand you may possess’. ISIS represents a revival of the original ethos of the Mohammedan cult that conquered its way up to France before being driven back in the 8th century. Thank God, not Allah, most Muslims do not follow this literalist interpretation.  How can ISIS be defeated? A military defeat needs a coalition between the West and those Islamic countries that do not want to live under the barbarism of ISIS. ISIS’s funding and supply lines must be terminated. The civilised world has to realise that literalist Islam has no place in liberal democratic society. We should end mass immigration from Islamic countries and set about integrating those Muslims already here. And why do the leaders of the Christian churches not recognise a recruitment opportunity and launch an ideological crusade to convert European Muslims to Christianity?

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I have spoke many times about persecuted Christians. According to Open Doors, more than 100 million Christians are persecuted worldwide because of their faith. Between 105,000 and 170,000 Christians per year are killed. These figures give rise to the claim that christians are the most persecuted religious group in the world, although other minority figures are also killed, but the situation has become even more cruel with the outbreak of atrocities by Daesh and other extremist groups in the Middle East as well as in Africa. We cannot talk about persecution here, we must already talk about genocide. Christians are under attack. Their property, their places of worship, is destroyed. They are mutilated and forced to change their religion. They are also traded. Their organs are used in trade. That's the information we get from there. This information is also subject to registration by various organisations, including ecclesiastical and non-governmental organisations. It is difficult not to call this situation by name, that it is simply genocide. But other religious minorities also suffer: Muslims, Muslim minorities, Yazydi and other minorities. We need to do more on this than we have done so far. It is necessary. This is the duty of the civilized world.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, numerous reports indicate that violence against religious minorities in Iraq and Syria, Christians, Yazidis, Turkmens and other small communities, has increased dramatically in areas under Islamic State control. In the territories occupied by Isis, these endanger the very existence of people belonging to minorities who have become victims of mass murder, rape, slavery and organ trafficking. In order to protect their lives and not have to convert to Islam, those who manage to avoid mass killings decide to flee. Mass killings and escape attempts are putting the most fragile groups at risk of extermination, and I do not think it was wrong to use this term, even with the consequences it can have in international law. The European Union must continue to condemn the Islamic State's human rights violations against iraqi and Syrian religious minorities. It is also necessary for the Commission to step up its humanitarian efforts in response to the crisis and to contribute to raising awareness of this issue. As you said, Mrs Mogherini, violence against religious minorities can also be adequately addressed in the same way as migration processes if the conflicts that are now open in the Middle East region are met with a unified and unambiguous response and a common commitment on the part of the European Union and its Member States. In anticipation of this, however, everything possible is being done to really defend minorities.

name: Bas BELDER
text: – Currently, the Christian Syrian city of Sadad is directly threatened by IS. So the men left behind are defending this city today. They and other Christian self-defence units in the region - it also happens in other places - deserve all, indeed all concrete European support, including to train them militarily. Sadly, the city of Sadad is learning another lesson. Years earlier, in October 2013, the fighters of the Free Syrian Army and Jabhat al-Nusra were among the inhabitants of Sadad. Dozens dead, not to mention torture. In short, religious minorities in Syria are regarded by all militias as supporters of Bashar al-Assad and are therefore not sure of their lives. It is more than time that the EU and its Member States are concerned about the plight of religious refugees, in the region itself and within its own borders. Christian assistance will not be lacking there and here.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: The question is, what can we do? The question is what we can do, and if we ask that, we need to answer it immediately. It has to be based on reality, reality, and the reality is that this is genocide. We have to learn that, unfortunately we have to accept it. But this has to set me up to act. I am– I can honestly say – I am tired of dealing with the affairs of Christian and other minorities more than 10 times in the last period, and we have made various submissions, but the actions, as much as there is a problem, have not been followed at all. I therefore consider it very important, and I myself have seen in Iraq, that the Union, with its humanitarian programmes, is exemplary in its support for the persecuted. And I'll tell you honestly, your honesty was very capive. Yet I ask the Commission today: how can we work better together for local solutions? What steps does the Commission intend to take to keep the remnants of a 2,000-year-old indigenous Christian community? We're talking about leftovers, since practically a million people are missing. What are the strategic plans to stop the exodus? We talk a lot about money, but in the meantime we forget that representatives of different churches and denominations cannot directly access EU funds today. Every single visit I made in the area confirmed that there was nothing else. We need real-world European action. In this we call for the Commission's involvement and partnership... (The President has withdrawn the floor from the Member.)

name: Ana GOMES
text: – International inaction in Syria, Iraq and Libya has left Yazidis, Christians, Kurds, Shiites, Sunnis, Amazighs, Tubus and other religious and ethnic minorities completely at the mercy of the barbaric violence of Daexe and other terrorist organisations. Nothing cost me more than to listen, in Iraqi Kurdistan, young Yazidis who had managed to escape daexe and needed help to recover and to free the more than 4000 still enslaved by this murderous band.  It is incomprehensible that the European Union has not yet taken the initiative to ask the UN Security Council to refer to the genocide of the Yazidis and other crimes of the Daexe against humanity to the International Criminal Court, as the Iraqi Kurdistan government requests. But as the Christian patriarchs of Dohuk and Erbil told us, if we want to defend the pre-Islamic cultures and minorities in the Middle East, we must help them to be safe enough to stay in their homes and lands, not to flee to Europe. We must do more and better by articulating humanitarian aid and development so that they can stay and survive. But above all we have to organise and coordinate in the fight against Daexe and other heads of the terrorist hydra, and against those who support it in the neighbourhood, in our neighbourhood, and also within the European Union itself.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This tragedy would not have been, or would have been much smaller, if we had remembered for years the simple principle that the security and freedom of Christian communities in the Middle East should be a fundamental premise of our policy. Perhaps not the only one, but one that we always take into account when making decisions and when defining opponents and allies. Of course, as far as the Syrian-Iraqi border is concerned, at the moment we are seeing this drama in which we must apply humanitarian aid and all the measures that we have talked about today. On the other hand, we can draw conclusions. I strongly support the proposal, which Lars Adaktusson first reported, to recognise as genocide what is happening there. I also call on us to start condemning anti-Christian hatred and anti-Christian contempt, which silences acts of anti-Christian hatred.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, last year more than 7 000 Christians were murdered purely because of their belief. Two years ago this number was 2 000. The Iraqi Christian population has declined fourfold in 12 years. Christians are clearly the most persecuted and devastated religious group in the world. Last year can be seen as a year of spillover, in which a trend of dominating intolerance has become central. We have to face this intolerant racism which refuses to co-exist and whose acts need finally to be qualified not only as terrorist deeds, but as crimes against humanity and, on several occasions, as genocide. What has to be done? First, we must actively mainstream freedom of religion in relations with third countries and, through EU Member States and the UN, refer crimes against Christian and other religious minorities to the International Criminal Court. Second, EU foreign policy needs a crucial change of attitude. We need to understand that safeguarding freedom of religion in real terms brings about an added value because freedom of religion in action is a powerful contribution to neutralising extremism. Third, EU foreign policy in the Middle East should stress above all religious equality. This will pave the way to a solution in which the EU is interested. Return home the masses...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is true that today in the territories occupied by Daesh we are witnessing a sequence of systematic mass murders and persecutions, but towards Christian communities in Syria, Iraq, Gingeria and other countries this is a real crime of genocide, as defined by the UN, because Christians constitute the most persecuted religious group. , as has been mentioned, with almost 100 thousand victims every year and the flight of millions of Christians from certain African and Middle Eastern countries. We must recognise this officially in the UN and demand consistency from the international community. There is a tragic consistency between these mass murders and the systemic relentlessness of Daesh terrorists against the symbols of cultural and religious heritage in Syria and Iraq. Lastly, the Monastery of St. Elijah in Mosul, which represents a real cultural genocide, as has been said. I recognise, Mr Mogherini, your strong, consistent commitment to concrete humanitarian aid, to the dialogue you are promoting, to prevention and to the possible – as it were – restoration of conditions of pacification, but I think that we must defend the right of religion as well as the right of religion more everywhere.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, today we are focusing again on the systematic mass murder of religious minorities by ISIS. Why do we not call it what it is: a genocide? This is the same question as my colleagues have asked. Christians in Syria are killed or displaced because of their faith. Only half of the 1.25 million Christians remain, and in other regions 80% or more have been eradicated. Without action, no Christians will remain there, and situation of Yazidis is very similar. Many churches are destroyed or turned into mosques. This happens in Syria and Iraq, but also in Turkey. I call upon you, Madam High Representative, to present concrete steps that the Commission will implement to stop this. Moreover, this threat is here in the EU as well. We have seen Christians in the refugee camps in Europe being attacked by other refugees because of their faith. What action will the Commission take? If we want to stop this systematic mass murder and give these religious groups hope, we must recognise them as genocide and help the democratic self—administration in northeastern Syria, in the Rojava canton, with both weapons and aid.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the forecasts tell us that in 2020 there will be no More Christians in Iraq and Syria, nor will there be any more Yazidis. We cannot remain indifferent to what is happening, the former US Secretary of State, Hillary Clinton, is right when she talks about genocide. We, as Europe, cannot fail to associate ourselves with the position taken by one of the major players in American politics, which is likely to be the future president of the United States.  Europe has a duty to make its voice heard. All humanitarian initiatives are welcome, all support for those who are suffering at the moment is welcome, political initiatives are welcome, but Europe must make its voice heard loudly.
