Violence is reacted to by force! The defence of our values is at stake!  Europe exists because it believes in the centrality of the person, in religious freedom, in freedom of expression. It is the Treaty that requires us to defend our values beyond the borders of the Union. And defending religious freedom, calling persecution of Christians and Yazidis every day, in that part of the world, must be a priority, because, I repeat, it is a question of defending the founding values of our Union. If we give up the defence of values, we will have a Europe that is increasingly weak and limited to dealing with banks and little else.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, Daesh has been systematically killing, torturing, kidnapping and sexually enslaving members of minority groups, including Christians and Yazidis, in Iraq and Syria. Only this week, 400 people were killed or kidnapped by them in Syria, and today it was confirmed that the oldest Christian monastery in Iraq was razed to the ground. But we should also have other areas – like Pakistan and Afghanistan, where the Taliban have been rebranding into Daesh – on our radar. The EU and the UN must take urgent action to protect the Shias, Sikhs, Hindus, Muslims, Christians and other minority groups there from extremist attacks. My West Midlands colleague Rob Flello MP has been pressing the UK Government to call on the UN to treat the Daesh atrocities against religious minorities as a genocide. I urge you, High Representative, to back this initiative. Many voices at the UN speak louder than one, and this will help send a clear message to members of Daesh that they will face justice for the atrocities that they are committing now.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Christians are the most persecuted religious minority in the world. As noted in last year's European Parliament resolution, more than 150 000 Christians are murdered every year. For a long time, christians have been systematically and plannedly murdered by Islamic State militants, who also destroy their temples, cut off Christians' heads, smoke alive or melt. Isis's actions can be described as genocide. As early as last year, many congressmen in the United States claimed the murder of Christians by ISIS as genocide. However, this initiative is stuck. After today's debate, it is clear that there are Members in the European Parliament, from the largest political group, who would like us to be the first to call the crimes of the Islamic State by name, namely genocide. And I think that's what we should do.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, in 2015 this Parliament has already ruled several times on the cruel attacks on religious minorities in the Middle East and Africa. Our resolution last April said that Christians are today the most persecuted religious collective in the world, which was also repeated at conferences held in this House in July and December. In all European institutions we must pay particular attention to the dramatic situation of Christians and help them. And especially serious, as has been said, is the cruel behaviour of the Dáesh and other terrorist groups with Christians and other religious minorities. We are well aware of the allegations of the Archbishops of Mosul, Kirkuk and Baghdad about the persecution of Christians in Iraq and the destruction of their churches and places of worship. Today we have learned of the destruction of the monastery of St. Elijah, next to Mosul. One fact that seems eloquent to me about the decline of Christians in the region is that they currently account for 4% of the population of the Middle East, while a century ago they were around 20%. Logically, the defeat of the Dáesh and the resolution of the Conflict in Syria would contribute to improving this state of things. In recent months, many voices, Mrs Mogherini, from many different and prestigious instances, demand that these actions of violence be classified as genocide. I would like to know your point of view and that of the Council, or if you have not spoken out, or if you are going to do so. In any case, I believe that the crimes of the Dáesh cannot go unpunished and that we must demand that the United Nations be very actively involved in this issue.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we must recognise that today forms of Islamic totalitarianism have taken over. In so many places in the world for Christians the choice is between converting, being put to death or running away. In Syria alone, 700,000 Christians have left their country. It means that 56% of Christians have left Syria, and in Iraq too they have more than halved. Only small and few data because all the data are unique in tell us that Christians are the most persecuted community in the world. In some regions, as has already been mentioned, UN aid does not reach Christians either, because refugee camps, where UN aid is available, are avoided by Christians who are afraid of even going to refugee camps run by the United Nations. We have all been shocked by the images of the beheadings of Coptic Christians by Isis, but we continue to underestimate this genocide. And what do we have to call it? What do you want to call persecution of this size, so that, in Bosnia, for example, the number of Christians has fallen by 92.2% in ten years? And look at the fact that genocide – asking this issue is not a linguistic issue – has already been said, but above all when we talk about genocide, we place the phenomenon in a stronger legal framework, which provides for a much stronger international strategy of action.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Several colleagues have already mentioned the destruction by Islamic State jihadists of another cultural monument – the 6th century Monastery of St. Elijah in Mosul. The so-called Islamic State is responsible for destroying hundreds of religious objects and monuments. ISIS destroys everything it considers contrary to their interpretation of Islam. Ethnic and religious minorities in the areas they control are gradually being annihilated. Christians are tortured and murdered. Their cultural heritage is being destroyed. They are taken away from their entire belongings. This situation leads to a dramatic decrease in the number of Christians who have lived in these areas for centuries. From about 2.5 million, their number fell to 800,000. Within a few years, this minority could be completely extermined. Acts of violence are also directed against others: Yazyds, Turkmens or Kurds. The international community must take decisive steps. The right to freedom of religion, to have one's own worldview and to cultivate one's own culture must be respected, and the acts committed by ISIS should be dealt with in terms of crimes against humanity and genocide.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: – Mr President, persecuted minorities also need justice and reparation. On Tuesday, the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights identified these crimes as genocide and, as in the public domain, are clearly typified in the Statute of the International Criminal Court.  That is why, Mrs Mogherini, I share the four actions to which you referred in your speech: funds, justice, international commitment and diplomacy. But in my view, in addition to reparation, justice is the "A" of this alphabet. Why? Because when the terror is over, and it will end, there can be no impunity and the terrorists must know that they will be persecuted by the International Criminal Court, that they will be tried and that they will be convicted of their crimes. That is also your task, madam: to promote the action of the International Criminal Court.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Mr President, the genocide against Christians, Yazidis and other minorities by The Islamic State in Syria and northern Iraq led to the expulsion of hundreds of thousands during the so-called Islamic State. "campaign to impose Islam". At the same time, in Iraq, due to the repression and killings since 2003, the Christian population has decreased six-fold – to 275,000, and in Syria since 2011 two-thirds fewer – to 500,000.  The answer and responsibility for the terrible situation, which is carried by not only the Syrian government, but also the international community, which in the Security Council has failed to agree on a timely intervention in the country. This could also limit the mass desire to relocate to European borders from the regions concerned. Mrs Mogherini, in order to successfully tackle terrorism, the migrant crisis, radical Islam, member states must first fulfil their commitments, which they do not meet, especially financial ones. Secondly, European cooperation in the field of security and defence must be strengthened by establishing a European intelligence and defence structure. It's in the best interests of the people there, but it's also in our interest to stop the barbarians.

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: – Mr President, I would first like to congratulate my colleague, Mr Adaktusson, and thank Commissioner Mogherini for her support on this. I shall now switch to my own language. Mr President, atrocities are being committed throughout the territory controlled by Daesh that target Yazidi, Shiite and Christian minorities. Killing them, sexual slavery and torture are realities experienced by religious minorities and are crimes against humanity that must be declared as genocide. We must not be afraid to accept reality. From al-Baghdadi's statement that coexistence with Jews and Christians is impossible, to graffiti in Sweden that threatens:"Convert or die!", Daesh's actions show a clear intention to destroy, in part or in full, an ethnic, racial or religious national group. In Iraq, the number of Christians has fallen from 1,400,000 to 275,000, and in Syria by more than 50% in the last 5 years.  Official recognition of the genocide, together with the legal implications, will lead to stronger action by the international community. After the recognition of the Srebelica genocide, when the death toll was 20%, the international community promised: Never again! What are we waiting for?

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: – Mr President, in this Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, our mouths are filled when it comes to talking about all kinds of freedoms, but I would like to hear more voices speaking loudly and clearly about religious freedom. Freedom to believe, to be able to make the sign of the cross and not die for it. I speak not only as a Christian, that I am and am proud to be, but as a human rights defender who can no longer tolerate the systematic killings of Christians in the Middle East at the hands of Islamic State terrorists. Here are the prices of Yazidi and Christian prices that are sold: women sell for fifty euros; ten-year-old girls, for a hundred euros. Christians have only three outings: convert, flee or die. I do not want to be part of this complicit silence and I ask the Commission, this Parliament, the United Nations, to do what is possible and the impossible to stop this genocide. Victims look at us and we have to act for them. And let's do it now!

name: Marijana PETIR
text: "Mr. President, murder, torture, persecution, prohibition of Christian symbols, destruction of churches... Christians in the Middle East face one choice: remain Christians and question their lives or renounce Christianity in order to survive. Christians are being crimed against all crimes. But should Christians disappear completely from Middle East territory to agree that ISIS is carrying out genocide against them?  Before January 1st, 2009, the 20% of Christians in the Middle East. Today there are only 4%. Over the past 10 years, the number of Christians in Iraq has fallen from 1.4 million to about 300,000 while in Syria it has fallen from 1.25 million to 500,000. There are no more Christian churches in Mosul. About 140 churches have been destroyed in Syria.   Iraq's oldest Christian monastery survived 1,400 years to become a pile of dust. In the central part of Syria, a 5th century monastery was destroyed by a bulldozer. Christians are killed and persecuted with the intention of destroying an entire religion altogether.  How else to understand the warning of ISIS: "We will conquer your Rome, we will destroy your crosses and imprison your women. If that doesn't work for us, it will work for our children and our children's children and they will sell your children into slavery." Those are the words of ISIS. Christians are the most provoked religion in the world.  Genocide is being carried out against them. Let us be brave to admit this and do finally do something to get this terrible crime (the chairmen took the word)

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I think that the debate has shown that this is indeed an issue that deserves our focused attention. I would like to point out in my speech that religious minorities often do not only have a chance to lead a satisfactory life, but indeed often do not even lead their existence, to live their lives. In China, for example, Christians are currently facing significant discrimination. Nor can we ignore the fact that, in Europe, for example, the Jews here feel very uncomfortable. The fact that there is information that Jews are leaving Europe is also not a good business card. But nowhere is the nature of these interferences in the lives of religious minorities as obvious, and it has such a genocidal character as in da'ish-controlled territory. I believe that the violence that is being permeate victims because of their religious beliefs is rejected by all of us here, which has resulted from the debate. And I would like to highlight the model that our civilisation has worked on, that is, tolerance, non-discrimination, the possibility of peaceful coexistence of religiously different cultures. In the name of these principles, but also in the interests of international justice, we must condemn what is happening in the Middle East, but not only that, we should consistently support the continuation and deepening of the action of the international community. If the designation of atrocities committed by Da'ish as genocide helps, that designation has my support.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: We now come to the catch-the-eye procedure.  Ladies and gentlemen, we are considerably too late and I have twice as many speeches as I can take into account. I have now decided to do so in such a way that I take a colleague from every group from which colleagues have come forward, taking into account those who, even after the information provided by the services, have not spoken so often. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – What Daesh is doing must be officially called genocide by both this Parliament and the European Commission. At the same time, we must strongly demand that the UN Security Council adopt a resolution so that the violent acts of terrorists of the so-called Islamic State are not the same as those of terrorists. The Islamic State has been dealt with by an international criminal tribunal.  The killings and violence targeting Christians and other religious minorities taking place on the territory of Iraq and Syria are comparable to those in Srebrenica and Rwanda. The Christians who live here are waiting for international recognition of their suffering, they are expecting solidarity and justice from us. At the same time, if we truthfully name these horrific acts as genocide, we will also be able to better protect Syrian and Iraqi Christians from the violence perpetrated by radical Salafists directly in European refugee camps.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, honourable Members, Honourable Commissioner, there is no doubt and it is indisputable that Islamic State is killing tens of thousands of Yazidis, Christians, Kurds and representatives of Shiite minorities in northern Iraq and Syria. We all know that, and it's been said many times in this room for at least a year. But of all the statements in this chamber in this year, absolutely nothing came of it. I want to share with you the following reasoning: "Islamic State" does not fight declarations, does not fight debate, does not fight many vitievates, but at the expense of this empty talk. Don't fight to get around the problem. Do not struggle when we seek to avoid the word "Islamic", we explain how one religion was peaceful and another was not. She doesn't fight when we try to disguise the fact that our neighboring country, Turkey, is supporting Islamic State by funding it, organizing it, treating it, supplying it with weapons. All these things have to be said, to be clear, because otherwise we will not achieve any of what we are talking about. What needs to happen, Dear Mrs Mogherini, is to reach an agreement with the entire international community on a land operation.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the tragic situation created by the constant killings and mass killing of members of religious minorities by ISIS is taking on uncontrollable proportions. Christians, Yazidis, Drussos, Assyrians, members of other religious minorities are threatened every day. ISIS aims to wipe them out. We're talking about genocide. That's why wishful meals aren't enough. We need to speak honestly and take decisive action. The European Union is not without responsibility for what is happening. With the tolerance of the European Union, both France and Germany have equipped the jihadists, while to this day the Union remains a leader of the United States and its plans to re-chart the borders of the wider Middle East, thus contributing to the destabilisation of the region. That's enough hypocrisy. It is imperative that the causes created and reinforced BY ISIS are addressed immediately, that foreign interventions and wars in the Arab world are ended and that we support practical initiatives for peace in the Middle East.

name: Tim AKER
text: – Mr President, I wish we could discuss blasting ISIS back to the Stone Age where their barbaric ideology belongs, but instead we are reaping the consequences of a shocking foreign policy. We are left with harmful Tory government defence cuts from an administration that prefers foreign aid to strong armed forces, and we have a leader of the Labour Party who would negotiate with these ISIS animals. Britain can do so much better than this, and it is time for us to reassert ourselves and say to these animals who threaten our freedom and our way of life: you will never win.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I have a fundamental question as to how I can interpret you in the future, with all the appreciation of your otherwise very good presidency. You have just said – and I still have this in my ear – that every group will be taken into account. I do not see anyone in my group who has spoken. Of course, you also have the problem that a non-attached Member has asked to speak. I do not therefore understand that you are announcing something that you, as President of the sitting, do not think. I would ask you to continue to apply your traditionally very correct management and to see if anyone has spoken. Otherwise, you cannot understand what you are announcing.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Mr Obermayr. I think I have behaved correctly this time too. You have come forward and I thought you wanted to show a 'blue card', when I pointed out: no blue cards. (Interjections from Mr Obermayr) Mr Obermayr, I give you the floor.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to join in many respects.  It is particularly important that today we discuss and address these mass murders of Christians and Yazidis and the crimes of ISIS. Unfortunately, words remain a lot, and that is not enough. However, we must also remind you that the attacks against the affected population, this religious group, unfortunately also continue in our reception centres, and there is a special solidarity on the part of the receiving countries. It is, and has already been said today, genocide. It also means, of course, that Europe is called upon to hold the countries that tolerate, encourage or look away accordingly. I am thinking of Saudi Arabia, I am thinking of the Emirates, which have obviously been watching here for a long time and perhaps still watching. We must not be mocked in Europe. We have to do something about it. The West must be on the side of the oppressed, and especially of our Christian brothers.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, let me start with the issue of the definition of genocide. It was not through reticence that I did not address this issue in my opening remarks, but because a definition of genocide depends on very precise legal criteria. This work is ongoing in the competent institutions, namely in the United Nations in the appropriate framework. The only reference so far to genocide in UN documents is the one made on 13 March 2015 in the report of the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) on the human rights situation in Iraq and in the light of abuses committed by the so-called Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant, and associated groups. This report compiles information about acts of violence perpetrated against civilians on account of their affiliation, or received affiliation, to an ethnic or religious group. This report concludes that some of this violence, considering the overall information, may constitute genocide in the case of the Yazidis, and other violence may amount to crimes against humanity and war crimes in relation to Christians, Turkmen, Sabaean Mandaeans, Kaka’e, Kurds and Shia. This is – if we want to be precise and consistent with the legal framework we are dealing with, because many of you made reference to the fact that it is not just a word but has legal implications – this is the legal framework in which we are acting. You can be sure that we are working – as you know very well, the European Union as such does not have a seat in the United Nations, but we can open this debate next time if you want to – and following these developments within the appropriate frameworks, which are those of the United Nations. But let me also stress that, in parallel to that, we have to act concretely and not just take a principled approach: that is indeed extremely relevant because the region is looking to us and the minorities are looking to those who can defend them with words, which are important, but also with acts. Let me start with something that was mentioned in a very concrete way by one of you, namely the issue of justice and accountability. As I mentioned before, but let me underline it again, the European Union supports the Independent International Commission of Inquiry on Syria, which collects evidence on the violations committed. This is extremely relevant in view of future legal actions, and the European Union – as was underlined by one of your interventions – has indeed called for the UN Security Council to refer the situation in Syria to the International Criminal Court. Let me make these two points very clear. And let me also stress in conclusion – because I am also aware that we are running late, and I do not want to contribute too much to us being even later – that there are three or four things that are absolute a priorities for us to do in order to protect religious minorities in the Middle East. First, liberate the areas that have been occupied by Daesh in Iraq and Syria in particular, and make them safe, returning these areas to normal life. This is where our humanitarian assistance comes in – in Iraq because we have more access and we can support more access there and, hopefully more and more, in Syria. Second, create the conditions for inclusive communities and societies in these countries. I would say recreate the conditions, because we are talking, as many of you have underlined, of societies that for centuries, if not thousands of years, have been living together in peace and understanding, living together, finding their differences as a source of the richness of their societies. And this is a point that is particularly relevant to me, more so even than from a political point of view, but from a human point of view – and I am surprised this did not come up today in the debate because this is, as far as I have heard, for instance from the Christians in Erbil last year, the issue that they are debating the most – which is whether it is safer and better for us to stay in the Middle East or to leave, with all the debates about preserving or recreating the plurality in the societies of the Middle East. This is a debate that in particular the Christian communities in the regions that were occupied by Daesh in Iraq are posing themselves. This is a debate that I believe we have first of all to respect and to follow carefully in our own debate, but I believe that we also have the duty to offer them the possibility to have the option to create safe conditions to leave these areas. This goes back to what some of you have underlined, namely to support refugees – all refugees, including the ones from minority backgrounds – and to protect their rights, wherever they are, in whatever place in the region they are, and also to create the conditions for them to stay or to return to their communities if they wish to do so in order to preserve or restore the plurality of societies in the Middle East. I personally believe that this is in itself a value because that is one of the places in the world where different backgrounds, different religions, different communities and different ethnicities have been living and showing the world how it is possible to live together. Then we have to do the big thing: end the conflicts. Because at the end of the day that is what allows minorities to go back. An additional point concerns what comes afterwards, and sometimes also not in places where conflicts are but in places that are on the verge of major crises, which means investing in the openness of societies, in the democracy of the institutions, in the respect for human rights and the rule of law, and in pluralism and inclusiveness in countries all around the world , not only in the Middle East. Now we are talking about a specific case, that of Daesh, but, as many of you mentioned, this is something that is happening everywhere in the world – in Africa and Asia, and not forgetting Libya, where we had victims who were Christians of different origins, in Ethiopia and Egypt where people were killed only recently. We have to look at the bigger picture and act immediately with first of all our humanitarian support, work on the conditions for the respect of minorities and pluralism and inclusiveness in the immediate term and in the long term, and put all our diplomatic efforts into putting an end to the crisis and defeating what in this case is the great source of problems for the religious minorities in the Middle East , namely Daesh.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place during the next part-session. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. – All around the cradle of Christianity, the Middle East, Christians have for long been facing continuous persecution, the result of which is that Since the beginning of the 20th century until today, the Christian population of the Middle East has dropped from approximately 14% to 4% today.  However, the violence, mass killings and executions carried out by the Islamic State in the last years go beyond what we ever thought could be possible. In Syria IS systematically abducts hundreds of Christians, demands exorbitant ransoms for the prisoners or executes them. In Northern Iraq – in former times home to tens of thousands of Christians – Christians who do not convert or flee also face the threat of execution. In 2014 Mosul was already cleared of Christians, now there is a threat that they may disappear altogether from the country. This barbaric onslaught claiming thousands of innocent lives and erasing the region’s diverse heritage is nothing short of genocide and we are not doing what we could and should to stop it.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the assistance clause (Article 42(7) TEU) (2015/3034(RSP)).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: vice-présidente de la Commission. – Monsieur le Président, ce n'est pas un temps ordinaire pour l'Europe, c'est clair. Nous faisons face à des défis sans précédent. Nos citoyens nous demandent quel est le sens de notre Union. D'aucuns prétendent que l'Union à 28 est trop complexe et trop plurielle pour prendre de bonnes décisions au cours de cette époque difficile. Je pense que notre réponse, face aux horribles attentats de Paris, a surpris beaucoup d'observateurs. Certains d'entre eux avaient prédit qu'à l'heure la plus sombre, l'Europe aurait été divisée et déchirée par des luttes intestines. J'ai participé à tous les Conseils et à tous les sommets européens après le vendredi 13 novembre. Laissez-moi donc vous dire qu'à partir du premier jour, la réponse de l'Union européenne a été celle d'une vraie Union. Comme vous le savez, après les attaques terroristes de Paris, la France a demandé le soutien des autres États membres comme cela est prévu à l'article 42, paragraphe 7, du traité sur l'Union européenne. Lors du Conseil des ministres de la défense, le 17 novembre, les États membres ont envoyé un message très fort d'unité et de solidarité à la France. Beyond the political message, Article 42(7) of the Treaties contains concrete obligations for Member States. Indeed, the Member States have an obligation to – ‘shall’ – provide aid and assistance to the Member State under attack with all the means in their power. This formulation is usually understood as referring to the use of military means, but no doubt Article 42(7) also covers assistance through other instruments or means of support of a non-military nature. The article expresses a high level of commitment. It is up to each Member State to determine the exact nature of the aid and assistance it will ultimately provide, but the framework is European. The core principle is ‘unity in diversity’. France asked for the support of the European Union and the European Union replied in a united way. The French Minister of Defence presented two specific requests to the Ministers. First, to support any operations that France would be conducting against Daesh in Syria and Iraq, and second, to backfill any lack of resources that may occur in international military missions or operations as a result of French redeployments to fight Daesh. France has approached Member States bilaterally with specific requests, following the European Council in its defence composition, with the constant involvement also of the EU crisis management structures and my personal constant updates. There are no specific procedures, as you know, for the implementation of Article 42(7) and, as you know, the article has never before been invoked in our European history. The implementation can therefore be adapted to the specific circumstances. While Article 42(7) does not specifically provide for a role of the European Union structures, its instruments and mechanisms may be used in countering the threats to Member States. And as I said, even if this is not specifically provided for in the wording of the Article of the Treaty, we in the Council, at the request of France, agreed on involving the European Union structures all along the path towards the implementation of the provisions. At the Council meeting I offered EU support from the outset, including, for instance, in coordinating any request that might have had an impact on EU CSDP missions or operations. Accordingly, France provided information on the implementation process both in the Political and Security Committee as well as in the Military Committee. Let me add that until now, French engagement in the fight against Daesh has not had any consequences for the EU missions and operations where France is active. The flexibility of Article 42(7) would also allow any state invoking it to also have recourse to other complementary international security arrangements. The Article itself refers explicitly to the fact that, ‘commitments and cooperation in this area shall be consistent with commitments under the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation for those states which are members of it.’ The mechanism to transform political solidarity into concrete, real action is strong and I think today we all realise that there is no nation state that can stand alone against the threats we face, and that it is our unity, also in this field, that is our strength. The diversity of our defence assets, the specific character of our foreign policies, is far from being a liability. It constitutes the strength of our Union. No other power in the world can mobilise such a variety of foreign policy and defence instruments all together. Unity in diversity, that is our strength. We can use it without being scared to use all the provisions of the Treaty if and when they serve a national and/or a collective interest. We often complain about our divisions. Let me say that it is also a case of being proud of our unity and strength where we find it.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the France was the first country to apply the Article 42(7) assistance clause following the despicable attacks in Paris. We in Parliament and we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats welcome the unanimous support of all Member States in response. However, we are also aware that this article is also primarily a political matter and that the situation is not particularly convenient for the country that first set this precedent.  So France had to take care of itself to define what it needs, and then go from one Member State to another to get help. As a Parliament, we had already called on your predecessor, i believe it was in 2012, to propose practical measures and guidelines in the event that this article is applied, and also to examine how to react in concrete terms and who would be responsible for what. Unfortunately, this has not yet happened. You said that.  Once again, we have seen a situation where the boundaries between internal security and external security are blurred. That is why it would be so important for us to really activate all the possibilities offered by the Treaty. In the area of internal security, it is clear that the police authorities, the border guards, including the domestic intelligence services, share the information they have, that they inform each other that they are not waiting for something to happen. In the area of external security, we remain convinced that those Member States that want to work more closely together, who want to engage more together, can also ensure that the activation of permanent structured cooperation enables better planning and better implementation of joint actions.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I forgot to say at the beginning – colleagues have changed since the last debate – that we are so far behind schedule that no 'blue card' will be allowed in this debate either, as in the previous two debates.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, after hearing what has been said I can only regret that the report I prepared in 2012 was four years too early. I will not repeat what we asked in that report but received no answer to; there are people here, such as Geoffrey Van Orden, who know the history of this report. Sadly the invitation, as I say, was ignored. Consequently since France has invoked Article 42(7), instead of Article 222 which deals expressly with terrorism, we need to improvise setting a precedent for all future similar situations. As a former Defence Minister I can see value in sailing in uncharted waters, but who is to guarantee that today’s precedent will prove enough tomorrow? The situation is one more illustration that the EU is in danger of drifting towards a world of its own, more and more divorced from reality. As we did not assume Article 42(7) would never be invoked, we did not exercise our preventive diplomacy tools when possible, having now to have recourse to crisis management, and even conflict resolution, much more costly solutions, in dealing with the conflicts on our doorstep. In a world dominated by power politics, the EU cannot rely on the moral superiority of not using military force in its defence. The truth is that the EU is under assault without having solved its internal problems, and its response cannot rely exclusively on soft power. If the EU does continue to ignore the realities surrounding us, I am very much afraid it will suffer the same fate as the League of Nations at the end of the 1930s –  something which we all want to avoid.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, at this moment we should be focused on combating a real terrorist threat and, in particular, on assisting France and other close allies that have been under recent terrorist attack, not trying to advance misplaced EU defence ambitions by federalists in this House. The ECR Group therefore strongly opposes the joint resolution calling for permanent structured cooperation in defence, the establishment of a permanent EU headquarters to plan collective defence, and movement towards an autonomous European Defence Union, by definition separate from NATO. This is dangerous nonsense, as realists understand only too well.  We have long warned about the dangers of EU meddling in defence, which can only be at the expense of our national sovereignty and of NATO, the indispensable alliance credible to our potential enemies and deeply reassuring to our allies. Many were dismayed when the Lisbon Treaty included a mutual defence clause – a cosmetic imitation of NATO’s Article 5 but with no foundation. The EU itself has no capability to provide collective defence. In any case, 22 EU countries are NATO members, and the small remainder, with just one exception, have participated in some way in NATO activity. There is no excuse for the inclusion of Article 42(7) in an EU treaty and certainly not for its invocation, unless of course your aim is to be provocative or you want deliberately to see NATO sidelined.

name: Urmas PAET
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the activation of the mutual defence clause by France has given us an opportunity, and also an obligation, to define its purpose and benefits. The mutual assistance clause gives us a singular opportunity to establish the grounds for a strong and sustainable European Defence Union, to be ready to face the security threats and challenges. So far, it has been interpreted as a bilateral obligation for states to help the one that needs it.  However, we must make sure that the correct action plan is put in place so that everybody understands their obligations when a state decides to invoke this article. A state in need must be able to get comprehensive help very fast from all Member States. Time is of the essence in these cases. We must also keep in mind that this is not a substitute for NATO Article 5, which has the task of coordinated response to a threat against one Member State. The new paradigm we are facing with increasing terrorist attacks forces us to deal with many aspects that have so far either been left unnoticed or simply ignored. The Schengen system is getting its share right now, with states closing their borders and threatening to demolish the free movement principle that the EU is built upon.  Europe’s internal security must be strengthened and intelligence information shared to fight terrorists and avert terrorist plots. For the intelligence network to be fully functioning and operative we should consider creating a European Intelligence Agency, or at least enable Europol to have more competences to be able to implement, de facto, a transversal intelligence network within the Member States. A proper legal framework to constrain and control arms and ammunitions on the EU market must also be established, as well as tightened export rules.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Madam High Representative, we reject the activation of this mutual defence clause because it involves misresticing the answer. Instead of solving, it stokes fire and turns the European Union into a military alliance.  We totally disagree with the interpretation given by France. As much as they are committed, a terrorist attack is not an act of war. This interpretation is a fraud of international law. It is to return to the logic of the war on terror where only civilian responses can be possible: police action, intelligence, cutting funding, cutting off international support, and always within the rule of law. We can't lose our freedoms. We can't kill flies with cannonballs. Thirteen years and the war on terror has been a failure: it has destroyed secular states, caused millions of dead and hundreds of thousands of refugees, and created a monster like the Islamic State. Not everything goes, it seems like a shortcut but it is a maze because, moreover, being an intergovernmental bilateral agreement does not help parliamentary control in the activation process.  Let us return to the most patient ways, to respect for international law, to the Charter of the United Nations, to non-intervention. Let us help States, attack asymmetry and poverty and make an arms embargo.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr First of all, I would like to send a thought once again to all the victims and their families who were affected by the terrible terrorist attacks in Paris and elsewhere around the world. Terrorism must, of course, be combated, but the most important thing is to prevent it and it is important that we use the right tools.  Today we are discussing a resolution with both good and bad elements, and it is, after all, a response to President Hollande's decision to invoke the so-called mutual assistance clause. Hollande called the attack on Paris an act of war and then declared war on terrorism, just like Georges W. Bush after 9/11. Bush's war on terrorism has been going on for many years, but with hindsight, we know that it has rather led to increased contradictions and more terrorism.  In Paris, the terrorist attack was perpetrated by EU citizens who had grown up here. The attack was a heinous crime but not an attack by a foreign state. Daesh is not a state and therefore the attack should be met with police methods. We believe that it is a dangerous development if we create a practice in which crimes are prosecuted by the military instead of the police and in a way that all Member States are drawn into this so-called war. Instead, we should have used Article 222, which is de facto about, among other things, terrorist attacks.  We are happy to discuss how the EU should develop its common security and defence policy, but we do not want it to be confused with a home-grown terrorist attack here in Europe. We do not want to see greater militarisation of the EU in the way that we believe that the resolution advocates, and that is why we have chosen not to support the joint resolution, but to stick to the one we have written ourselves and which more reflects our green values.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, in the UK we are always being told that we will not have an EU army, but the aftermath of the Paris attacks removed any last traces of doubt anyone might have over where we are heading. Even Tony Blair is now openly calling for an end to national sovereignty by giving control to Brussels of the troops that he, more than any other Prime Minister, sent to war. Personally, whenever Tony Blair says something – particularly about the military – I think that the best advice is to do the opposite. Unlike Mr Blair, I took the oath of allegiance to Her Majesty the Queen when I was a serving soldier. I think you would be hard pressed to find anyone who would do the same for Mr Juncker. We already have the foundations with a mutual defence clause, but what would happen should we have another conflict where Europe is divided? What if Argentina, drunk on the support of Jeremy Corbyn, decided to attack the Falkland Islands again? Would France stop all defence sales and join in a UK-led defence of the islands? The most important role any government plays is to protect its country. That is why, with their support of the Lisbon Treaty, UK MPs did the British people a huge ....  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the As an Austrian, I am proud of the armed neutrality of my home country. Like the majority of my compatriots, I do not understand when steps taken by our Heads of Government, whether red or black, gradually undermine our military independence. By underprising the EU Treaty's obligation to provide assistance, Austria indirectly becomes a NATO member – simply because of the strategic partnership that has been in place since 2003 – without having a say, but with support obligations. So it is no surprise that Austria is now almost naturally part of the so-called EU Battlegroup. So much for the analysis of the assessment of the situation. However, solidarity, while respecting national characteristics, is, in my view, a foundation of Europe in this threat situation. Accordingly, this duty of assistance must not in any way lead to a military partnership through the back door. Nor, if it is a transatlantic military partnership.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). Mr President, the Communist Party of Greece condemns the joint resolution providing for the creation of a permanent civil-military operations headquarters under Article 42 of the Euro-Treaty. Both the establishment of this new European Union Headquarters and the very activation of the so-called mutual defence clause mark an escalation of imperialist intervention in Syria and the wider region with civilian casualties. They are a strengthening of the militarisation of the European Union in the direction of establishing a Euro-army in association with NATO. You are blooding the people about whether the Qatar pipeline - a plan of the United States and the European Union or the Russian one from Iran - will pass through Syria. Didn't you do the same in Libya or Iraq and Afghanistan? The pretences and declarations of solidarity between the United States, the European Union and NATO and their governments are unconvincing. Their imperialist plans also have the active support of the SYRIZA/ANEL government. The Greek people must oppose the imperialist wars by demanding that there be no involvement of Greece in them. Wealth belongs to the peoples, they alone can and must reap it.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I believe that it was an inescapable act of solidarity to follow the wishes of the French, who have taken Article 42(7) as their legal basis. I think that is also the right article. I do not think it would have been right to take Article 5 of the NATO Treaty, because this would have been a confrontation between the West and the Islamic world and we need to take this approach much more broadly. Article 222 is terrorism within the European Union. But here is the war outside the European Union. But we have to say that this is, of course, a question of cooperation between the Member States – not a European operation of the European Union. But what we need to do here is whether we can be service providers here. Service providers that cooperate in a reasonable way: one does this, the Germans send observation aircraft, the Danes send seven fighters. Who organises this? I believe that it would be important for us to prepare common strategies for just one case on such issues, for us to have headquarters, to carry out coordination tasks in services to the nation states, in order to be able to act more quickly in this way, to be able to act more efficiently, to be able to act with less risk for our soldiers and to be able to respond more quickly to the goal of ending a war here. That is what it is all about. A war in the Middle East that is dangerous for all of us.  We must see that the link between war in the Middle East and international terrorism is a completely new dimension here. We no longer have a classic war between states, we have war for territories, and at the same time, in our territories, parts of these forces are waging war with a different form of terrorist acts. So far, we have no way of dealing with NATO's classic responses. I believe that this is a reference, Mrs High Representative, to bring to the fore the issues of headquarters, permanent structured cooperation, and such issues. Not to have more competence, but to act as a service provider.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – (20) Mr President, the mutual defence clause invoked by France after the last terrorist attacks in Paris opens the challenge of moving from words to acts in the common security and defence policy. Just visit one of the front lines against Daexe in Iraqi Kurdistan and see the misfortune that European countries do not even articulate in supporting pesmerga fighters.  The terrorist threat has never been felt more by our citizens and globally. It requires member states, under the strategic guidance of the High Representative, to take specific procedures to implement the mutual defence clause, to gather resources and coordinate for the security of citizens and to defend the strategic interest of a world governed by the rule of law.  It is of no use to declare an obligation of solidarity if our governments do not go beyond obsolete concepts of sovereignty, if they do not adopt specific procedures to implement the mutual defence clause and to advance security and defence policy, which is a crucial instrument, among others, to be effective in combating terrorism in Europe and globally.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by To the surprise of observers and lawyers after the Paris attacks, France invoked Article 42(7) instead of Article 222 for terrorist attacks. In expressing its willingness to negotiate bilaterally with the Member States for such a procedure, the Council expressed its unanimous support for France. Any further action – and we can already see from this debate that there may be some trouble involved – also requires a unanimous decision by the Council.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: – This is the first time that a Member State has invoked Article 42(7). It is also unique that it has received a unanimous yes from the 27 countries.  I would like to raise two points: 1. Would it not have been better for the European Union itself to invoked this article, that you yourself had taken the initiative in this? Wouldn't we have had a more real European reaction? Are you thinking of deitiing a procedure so that next time the European Commission can take its own steps on this if necessary? 2. Mrs Mogherini, for me it is really a momentum, a catalyst moment. If, after these events, we cannot now take steps forward in the development of a European defence, a true European force, Then I do not know when it will happen again. So very specifically, how are you going to use this momentum to build a real defence union?

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, for the first time we have activated the mutual assistance clause. It has been said that the values of the European Union are under attack and that the security of European citizens is under threat and that solidarity is required for all, undivided and generous, because human values do not have a national identity. But who is the enemy, ladies and gentlemen? "Hell is the others," said Jean-Paul Sartre, and that is the danger: the way in which we defend human values discredits them and becomes the feeder of this hell. Who and why has bombed and destroyed these countries and is thousands of refugees drowning in the Mediterranean today? Who equipped the jihadists? Is there anyone who believes that the obligation to provide military aid and assistance will reduce or stop this situation? A change in policy is needed, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Mogherini. A change that completely excludes political interventions and exclusions and is geared solely to the use of civilian measures to reduce poverty, social and economic development and symmetrical cooperation.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Mr President, after the emotion of the attacks and the fine words agreed upon, the reality of our collective inability to fight terrorism on a sustainable and effective scale is catching up with us.  This mutual defence clause, based in particular on Article 42, paragraph 7, of the Treaty on the European Union, is being used in a new and exceptional way and endangers the development of a genuine common security and defence policy, which many of us are calling for, across all political parties. The use of this clause is all the more irrelevant because the terrorists who struck France came from our country, and we would do better to be concerned about the solutions to be made in Europe to combat the disintegration of social ties and living together.  This debate in Parliament this evening is not up to scratch. We are not involved in decisions, particularly with regard to this article, nor is the High Representative, Mrs Mogherini. This clause is the very symbol of the regression of European integration. It favours a bilateral logic within a community organization. So there is an urgency and, really, France, which has worked for the construction of a European defence, and I, as a Frenchwoman, do not understand at all this article which goes against this European defence.

name: Michèle ALLIOT-MARIE
text: Mr President, I would like, on behalf of the French people, to thank first of all the countries that have supported this clause. I would like to thank them, of course, for what some have done very concretely and, in general, for the message of solidarity that was launched on this occasion. At the same time, Madam High Representative, it is true that the questions about the implementation of this clause also raise the question of what we are capable of doing to defend ourselves, because, I repeat, all countries, ladies and gentlemen, are likely to be hit by terrorism. Some have already been and others will unfortunately be. And it is not NATO that can answer that. As a former defence minister, I have worked extensively inside and outside NATO. The latter is not the proper structure for this. We need to defend our fellow citizens. It is the first duty of a state, and a state alone today cannot do so. Whatever the actions, they are all international. It is not a renunciation of sovereignty, it is a practical organization. So, High Representative, we do need to move Europe forward in defence very concretely. You have spoken to us about it and you have affirmed your conviction in this matter. We must now move forward and clarify what the timetables will be. First, the timetables for the implementation of a permanent headquarters: we need to anticipate, anticipate and be able to react right away. Today, we are not so much that we do not have that permanent staff. Secondly, it is true that there is a great unity in diversity or a great diversity in unity. This means, in particular, that permanent structured cooperation needs to be developed. We can do it. It is also pragmatic and concrete. Madam High Representative, I am waiting for your answers.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, after the terrorist attacks of 13 November 2015, French President François Hollande invoked Article 42, paragraph 7 of the Treaty on the European Union in his speech to the French Parliament in congress on 16 November 2015.  In the face of barbarism, in the face of abject crimes, in the face of the desire for death on our territory, European solidarity was the only response. Today, this solidarity is symbolized by Article 42, paragraph 7, of the Treaty on the European Union. Yes, France needs mutual assistance from Europe, because it is often alone to fight the very people who are attacking us. Many Member States very quickly responded positively to the invocation of this article. I welcome these decisions, their decisions. While you must communicate a new comprehensive foreign and security policy strategy for the European Union by June 2016, High Representative, it is important that This invocation by France of the mutual defence clause can take on an operational dimension. This is the first time a Member State has used this clause. So let's give the test shot a masterstroke, let's relaunch the European defence yard, as a number of colleagues have just indicated. We can no longer hide our faces. Europe has security challenges shared by all its Member States in its immediate vicinity: Sahel, The Near East, the Middle East. The conclusion is simple: our security is common, it is regional, it cannot be dispersed. Faced with this situation, only a true Defence Europe will be up to the task. Europe cannot rely solely on a country like France, and France will not be able to reasonably deal with the security of Europe alone. Let us not be afraid to tell those who always want less Europe that they are completely wrong and that, on the contrary, it is only by more Europe that we will be able to control and fight these terrorisms in this war that concerns us. This is the reality, this is our major political project that will restore Europe to the prestige it has lost in these years of crisis.  Thank you, High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, for your attention. I believe that this is a major debate and that we must today, in our debate in the European Parliament, in relation to you and the European Council, provide the answers that await not only the French, but also the 500 million Europeans.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which It is quite clear that France deserves the support, solidarity and active assistance from all the Member States of the European Union in defending against the terrorist threat to which France is exposed and to which we too are exposed. However, it is inappropriate that the majority groups in this Parliament, the Social Democrats and the Christian Democrats, are now using this as an opportunity to establish a European defence unit, the precursor to a European army, so to speak. It is not the case that we need a European army because France is under attack from terrorism. It is simply the case that we have a functioning defence and security system with NATO, and within NATO we should address all military threats. The solidarity of the Member States is demonstrated by the voluntary action by offering France its support with its national armed forces, with their military capabilities. More than that is not needed.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Paris attacks sought to establish a climate and a regime of terror among the population, erecting walls of suspicion and hatred among neighbours. If the answer to barbarism is to suspend rights, cut liberties and lock us up at home, the victory of terrorism will be total. The problem is that Hollande and the European Union are re-editing the Bush Administration's militaristic strategy when it declared the global war on terror. Let's draw lessons from the catastrophe involved in the invasion of Iraq. Fourteen years later, the bombs have only managed to bring in more bombs. We therefore reject the activation of Article 42(7) which makes the European Union a military alliance. We fight fanaticism, we fight barbarism, we fight fascism with more democracy, refusing to participate in the false marketing between rights and security.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, thank you, Mrs Mogherini, for your comments and explanations on the application of Article 42(7) and the institutions of the Union. Of course, the terrorist attack that led to the implementation of the above clause was an attack on all Europeans and we must all deal commonly with the jihadist threat. I welcome the solidarity unanimity of european defence ministers when they met a few days after the attacks. Coordination and cooperation between Member States, as well as with our international partners, including those in the Arab world, is essential.  Today, the main thing is the fight against the Dáesh, and also the resolution of the conflict in Syria. The international coalition is doing an important job there, but the military route is not enough either. I hope that the January 25 meeting will serve to move forward, despite recent tensions between Saudi Arabia and Iran.  But alongside Syria there are a number of scenarios in which together we must continue to fight terrorism. I am referring to Iraq, Yemen, Libya, the Horn of Africa, the Sahel; in other words: to our immediate neighborhood and to the neighbors of our neighbors. There terrorism is finding spaces to develop its capabilities, thus jeop for local and regional security and stability and, finally, our own European security.  And I conclude with one last comment: the various attacks on European soil and the increase in tension and conflict in our neighbourhood are a reason to move forward – as has already been said – in deepening the European dimension of defence and in the implementation of the various mechanisms envisaged by the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Mr. President, Madam High Representative, following the terrorist attacks in Paris last year, the French Minister of Defence invoked Article 42(7) of the European Convention on Human Security for the first time in history. the Treaty on European Union and because of the "armed attack on the territory of France" asked all member states for "all assistance and support, as far as possible". Many misinterpret this part of the Lisbon Treaty as a kind of counterpart to Article 5 of the Lisbon Treaty. The North Atlantic Treaty Agreement, which, in the event of an attack on a member of the Alliance, obliges everyone else to come to her aid. The European partners are virtually unusable to reject the French application, as this would not stand in solidarity. And many have indeed answered yes. The truth is that France can be helped in different ways and it is not necessary for this support to be military. But again, many questions are being asked even more sharply about the internal security of the European Union that go beyond the protection of national states. The best answer would be if the common security and defence policy ceased to be the weakest link in European integration.  The proposal for a Joint Defence Force first went public in 2014 when we heard that the European Union could save between €21 billion and €60 billion through greater synergies between defence policies and the introduction of a single defence system. However, the development of a common security and defence policy very often raises more questions than it answers. Perhaps it should start from the question that it is not even unified among the general administrations of the European Commission.

name: Nikolay BAREKOV
text: – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, terror is among us because there is no one to stop it at the border and not because we do not have a common army. Instead of a single army, someone has to guard Europe's borders. Europe faces the greatest danger of preserving peace since the European Union exists.  The criminal methods of daesh zombies threaten every member state of the European Union. European governments are compelled to wage a war that requires enormous financial resources. As a representative of the Republic of Bulgaria, which is an external border of the European Union with Turkey and the economically weakest country in Europe, I urge my country to receive equal defence opportunities with those of western European partners. The European Union must not duplicate US. Because my homeland is the place of hybrid warfare of two former empires, such as Russia and Turkey. Instead of a single European army, the European Union is obliged to pay and provide security at its eastern border by financially supporting Bulgaria. Let's not rely on Turkey and Islam to protect us from themselves.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: – Mr President, our debate today is a stark reminder that, six years after the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, there are still no implementing arrangements for the mutual defence clause and its invocation has largely been symbolic and political rather than practical. Unlike for Article 5 of the North Atlantic Treaty, there is no contingency planning and no structures at the European level for the implementation of the clause.  The response to attacks in Paris and the whole developments of the last few years have proven that we do need a European Defence Union, which would include countries that wish to cooperate closer on defence matters, to move ahead on the legal basis of permanent structured cooperation. We also need a permanent European civil military headquarters tasked with contingency planning, including for collective defence, in close cooperation with NATO. In fact, closer EU-NATO cooperation is key to defending our States, societies and infrastructures in the future. We do not need to reinvent the wheel, but jointly prepare for all kinds of attacks, be they traditional military or highly sophisticated non-military. This is exactly where the EU has a key role to play.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, this is, as you know, the first time the mutual defence clause is being invoked, and how we deal with it will serve as a precedent. We need to take a long-term view and develop concrete guidelines that will allow us to respond fast and effectively in the future. Let this also be an opportunity to strengthen cooperation on defence and intelligence- sharing. It is difficult to justify to our taxpayers that EU Member States collectively spend many times more on defence than any other major powers, yet are militarily less effective, simply because we do not work together. How can we justify terrorists slipping under the radar because we failed to share life-saving information? How do we tackle the flow of firearms on the black market without blocking cross-border circulation vital to our economy? EU cooperation provides the answer. This does not mean taking sovereignty away from national governments, nor stepping aside of NATO – a point made very clear in article 42(7). It means being smart: supporting clusters, role specialisation, joint research and procurement, increasing market integration. I urge the Council to make defence cooperation a priority.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: – Mr. President, respected High Representative Mogherini, following the brutal terrorist attack in Paris, France has decided to invoke the mutual defence clause referred to in Article 42(7) of the EIA. the Treaty on European Union for the first time and thus put into focus the willingness of the European Union and the Member States to put into practice the provisions that the Lisbon Treaty allows us to do.  I saw this choice as a way to primarily accentuate bilateral cooperation and member states' contributions, as evidenced by information on the strong engagement of a number of members to help France, and to relieve France of some other important military operations around the world.  It is up to us to see on the basis of the resolution and today's debate how we can reinforce the mechanisms of continuous cooperation that will include the institutions of the European Union in the context of the broader efforts that you, the High Representative, are working on this year, namely the development of the European Union's global strategy for foreign, security and defence policy. In view of this, I am interested in how we will implement Article 42(7) of the EIA, bearing in mind both Article 222 and Article 5 of the EIA. The North Atlantic Treaty Agreement and Article 51 of the Treaty of The Hague United Nations Charters, put in the context of our efforts to make the European Union more credible in the field of defence as well. Therefore, the Defence Action Plan and the Defence White Paper are certainly one of the priorities we will have these six months and at the time of the Dutch Presidency.

name: Boris ZALA
text: – Our resolution rightly calls for the same security guarantees for all citizens of the European Union and also rightly calls for a place of the European Union in the UN Security Council. But both of these requirements and France's request under Article 42 of the Treaty of Lisbon cannot be fulfilled bilaterally. Both of these requirements – security guarantees to citizens and the EU's place in the UN Security Council – can only be made possible by the existence of a European command and a common European army. Small, operational, but at the disposal of the European Union as a whole. And that is not all, so do we need European intelligence. Without these two joint command and European intelligence bodies, the tasks required by the Treaty of Lisbon to protect our citizens cannot be fulfilled.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, the challenge presented by Islamist terrorists is a shared programme for every EU Member State and every citizen. That is why it calls for solidarity and mutual assistance. The Paris attacks and the French invoking 42(7) can be seen as a wake-up call or catalyst for conducting more active and much more coordinated security and defence policies. The point is now to discover and exhaust all security related potential involved in the Treaty on the European Union. The fact is that this potential is still more on a theoretical level. The question is also whether Article 222 TFEU should be used in parallel to 42(7), because this would allow us to put all relevant EU means at the disposal of the victims. There is an urgent need to strengthen EU cooperation with NATO to make both sides’ respective security and defence arrangements compatible, especially in cases of armed aggression on the territory of a Member State. A last practical conclusion: to efficiently use the EU existing capacities, the EU needs a permanent Syrian military headquarters, at both strategic and operational levels. It needs a centre which has to deal with contingency plans.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, the terrorist attacks that have savagely hit France have not only affected the French, but also all Europeans. The only possible action to combat terrorism effectively must therefore be a European solution. The mutual defence clause is a first step in this European response. This is a crucial provision in our solidarity system. This obligation of solidarity is also a strong political act in these times of crises and direct threats to our territory. Several countries have responded positively to France's call, and I would like to welcome the responsiveness and commitment of some Member States. The actual investment of European countries is, of course, very diversified, and promises must be followed by concrete actions, but even if individual contributions may seem limited and added together, they are far from negligible. The activation of the mutual defence clause provides an excellent opportunity to strengthen defence and security policy. We must seize this opportunity to define a clear defence strategy. Mutualizing our strengths and resources is no longer an option, it is an absolute necessity. We can no longer afford to act on our own, according to our convictions and priorities, the priorities being now common: fighting Daesh, ending the war in Syria and stabilizing Libya. The Union must act as one block to make a difference.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, European citizens are asking us for quick and effective solutions because the danger is here with us. Each Member State must jointly help with what it can, and in the current crisis, together with the US, Arab countries, Iran and under the auspices of the UN and the Vienna process under way, we must ensure a workable solution for the peaceful future of Syria and Iraq where migrants now on European Union territory can return. Mrs Mogherini, france's activation of Article 42(7) let us use as a catalyst and lay the foundations for a strong and sustainable European defence capacity, including a European intelligence service, a European army and external border guards, so that we can meet the many external and internal threats to the European Union. As a first step in this direction, a permanent European civilian-military headquarters should be set up at strategic and operational level to coordinate both the implementation of contingency plans as well as the current as well as future operations for the activation of Art. 42(7) and Art. 42(2) Of course, in close coordination and cooperation with THE STRUCTURES OF THE UNITED STATES and in no case duplication, but complementing those structures. Last but not least, the successful resolution of problems such as migration, the fight against terrorism and radical Islam implies the fulfilment of the commitments made. It is a shame when leaders in Brussels make decisions and then, returning to their capitals, do not implement them, especially when it comes to financial commitments.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. President, I believe it is clear to anyone reasonable that this terrorist threat cannot be self-removed by any Member State and that we need a coordinated approach. France needs our help and we must provide it, not because we are bound by Article 42.7 of the Treaty on European Union, but because it is right and in the interests of all of us.  However, I am not sure that the activation of the article on mutual defence is the best way, as this recognises that France is a victim of armed aggression and can only be carried out by another country. Thus, we would practically grant the Islamic State the status of a state ourselves, which is completely contrary to our approach so far. Despite the efforts of terrorists to provide statehood, we should continue to treat the Islamic State solely as a terrorist organization. I therefore consider that the activation of the article on mutual defence is not in the interest of the Union and its allies, which by no means precludes the necessary assistance of member states to France on a voluntary basis.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, (Mr President, excellent Italian) the government's request by the French government to activate the mutual assistance clause provided for in Article 42(7), while it is acceptable, at least in principle in view of the tragic events in Paris, is certainly a missed opportunity and perhaps a legal error.  In this respect, Article 222, which expressly regulates the case in which a Member State is the victim of a terrorist attack, certainly appeared and appears more correct to invoke. ISIS, in fact, cannot be considered a state that is the only entity that can carry out an armed attack unless it legitimizes it as such. Without considering that this choice establishes the predominance of the intergovernmental method over the Community method. What has happened, in fact, is that France has unilaterally begun to bomb Syria and the various European states have been called upon individually to help it. Europe, on the other hand, has not been involved, it has not been able to give a single and coordinated response. A missed opportunity to demonstrate European unity, especially in the fight against terrorism.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, in accordance with the mutual defence clause set out in Article 42(7) of the Treaty and Article 222 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, it is expressly provided that actions to support a Member State which has been attacked by a terrorist attack concern only its territory, at the request of its political authorities. We therefore stress that this clause cannot be used to violate the sovereignty of any State. France's request for support for military missions in Africa and the Middle East is therefore legally unfounded. It should be noted here that these military missions are at best random and do not in any way assist in the fight against terrorism, as was clearly demonstrated in the Syrian crisis in 2011. After all, as an independent think tank investigation points out, and as is constantly confirmed by information leaked to the press, in addition to Daesh, a large part of the Syrian armed opposition that the French Republic strongly supported is made up of Islamist groups, which shows who these organisations are and which european governments pretend to ignore. Member States must stay away from external interventions and imperialist wars.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, Article 42(7) of the Treaty on European Union on the mutual defence clause is a high-level commitment by the Member States to support another State which, whether it is attacked on its territory at present or threatened with future military aggression. This is a very nice decision which means the European Union's determination to show solidarity with its Member States. But how much do we really believe in this commitment? For many years now, as you are well aware, Turkey has been threatening Greece, a member of the European Union, with war (casus belli) if it exercises its legal rights. Turkey also does not recognise the existence of another Member State of the European Union, Cyprus, and threatens it accordingly. What is the attitude that the European Union has shown towards this insult? Has it demanded that Turkey stop behaving in this way? If in this simple case the European Union has not been able to show determination, how do we expect it to show determination when things are difficult and require military intervention?

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, let me first start by saying that here we are clearly facing a kind of threat that probably was not clearly perceived or conceived of even six years ago with the Lisbon Treaty, because it is quite clear that we have an internal threat – let us remember that the terrorists had EU nationalities in this case – but with a clear external link, because there were references, links, training, resources, support that were linked with what is happening in Syria and Daesh. Clearly the line between the external and the internal even only six years ago was much better defined than it is today.
