So this is the nature of the threats – and let me underline that this is also a reply to those of you, a couple if not more, who referred to the need to defend our borders. Let us remember that the attacks in Paris were unfortunately perpetrated by people who hold EU passports. So it is not just a matter of defending the territory from the outside, it is also a much more complex issue of how we secure our citizens, how we guarantee the safety of our citizens from a threat that is at the same time internal and external, and we have to put together different kinds of measures there. I think and hope that the global strategy we are working on will also help us to redefine a common direction on how to guarantee the security of our citizens in these times – times that are themselves new and different. Having said that, let me reply to some specific points that were raised. First of all, the use of Article 42(7) rather than Article 222. Obviously it is for single Member States to take the political decision as to which article they want to invoke in terms of asking for assistance from other Member States. But let me clearly compare the two articles in question. Article 42(7) refers to ‘armed aggression’ or ‘armed attack’ – we have different linguistic versions in different languages – on the territory of a Member State, while Article 222 refers to a terrorist attack or a natural or man-made disaster. In terms of obligation, in both cases Member States have an obligation to act. In terms of contributions, in the case of Article 42(7) assistance comes from individual Member States while, as some of you have underlined, Article 222 also calls for mobilising EU instruments. In terms of implementation – and here comes what is I think the most interesting point for our debate in the future – Article 42(7) leaves the implementation process open. Here I observe that the guidelines you were somehow indicating would have been useful in 2012 were not produced. I believe that today we are seeing the implementation of this article, putting together all our resources, all our services and intelligence. This is something that we managed somehow between the decision that we shared with the French Government to use Article 42(7) and the moment when this decision was shared with the Member States in the Defence Council, a period of more of less 24 hours – it was certainly a quick reaction from the European Union services that we were able to gather at very short notice, but I believe the work that both our legal services and our structures that handle this level of assistance worked extremely well, as did the coordination between Member States. But coming back to implementation, Article 222 on the contrary foresees that the European Union has a coordinating role because of the potential involvement of European Union instruments. But let me say something that I underlined in my introductory remarks: even though the wording of Article 42(7) does not call for any kind of specific role for the European Union in terms of implementation, we decided jointly with France and all the Member States during the Council meeting of 17 December, if I remember correctly, to have all the relevant EU structures and institutions, including myself, directly involved at all stages of implementation. That was a political choice and I believe this political choice demonstrated the willingness of all of us to use this article as a way of strengthening the role of the European Union in this field. There is one element that might seem technical but is, I believe, important. Elmar Brok mentioned this, namely the location of the requested action is different when it comes to Article 42(7) compared with Article 222, because in the case of Article 222 assistance is in principle provided inside the territory of the Member State to reinforce its capacities during the crisis, while in the case of Article 42(7) France was clearly requesting assistance in external theatres. So I believe this was an element that was considered during those hours. Indeed, there were other articles that could have been used apart from these two, because you all know very well that we have Article 44 that has never been used and that would have implied EU-CSDP action – a military mission, with some Member States, the ‘willing’ Member States the article says if I remember correctly, taking the responsibility in conjunction with the Council to lead, on behalf of the European Union, a CSDP mission or operation. My political assessment has always been and still is, and I believe the Council strongly supports this vision, that it is not and it would not be appropriate for the European Union as such to have a military operation or mission against Daesh. This is a political choice. This is not a technical use of the treaties, and I believe that also in this House most of you would agree with me in saying that at the moment – and the situation might change or might have changed years from now – I would not see a CSDP role for the European Union for a military intervention against Daesh in Syria and Iraq. Not while we have other forms of engagement of the European Union, such as the implementation phase of Article 42(7) in all stages, which is somehow an upgrade of the role of the European Union institutions and structures compared with the wording of the article, which is a political sign. And on the other side, as you know very well, we have the diplomatic and humanitarian work and the work of the European Union within the anti-Daesh coalition when it comes to our global commitment against Daesh and against terrorism. When it comes to the NATO issue, let me say that for those Member States who are also members of NATO, EU mutual assistance is a complementary element to NATO’s collective defence. This is clearly stated in Article 42(7) which says that commitment and cooperation in this area shall be consistent with commitments under the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation for those states which are members of it. So no overlapping, no competition, no distance or divergence, simply a complementary possibility. And let me also add in more general terms that in this first year and a couple of months that we have been together in office, in parallel, I as High Representative of the European Union and Jens Stoltenberg as Secretary General of NATO, we have strengthened the cooperation between NATO and the European Union in a very significant way. I would expect this to take even more concrete form as we develop our strategy from now until June, and as NATO prepares for the NATO summit at the beginning of July. The two processes run in parallel. Obviously we have completely different paths, but these are communicating paths, and we exchange views, especially on those fields where our cooperation can be complementary for the benefit of all – for instance, in those fields where the European Union has a clear and specific added value when it comes to cyber threats or cyber security. So there are fields of cooperation that are growing stronger and stronger. The French decision that the Council has shared to call for Article 42(7) was and is a clear sign, first that the European Union can and should be seen as an effective security provider, first and foremost by its Member States. Second, it is a sign that solidarity is indeed part of our Union. Third, that all articles of the Treaties can be used. And let me say on this that we do not need ideological debates or theoretical debates: first of all, we cannot afford theoretical debates at this time when the security of our continent is at stake; but we do not need ideological debates either, we need to put in place and use the instruments we already have, and we need to create the political conditions for doing this together, united, highlighting the added value of the European Union also in the security and defence dimension where it can be an increasingly precious and vital tool to serve national interests , in some cases in a more effective way than a purely national approach. The European Union has an added value in this respect. Let me mention the 17 missions and operations we already have around the world that are an instrument and a tool for all the Member States together to act in different theatres where, together, we work better than we would do alone or through other means. Because there are specific dimensions where the EU instruments work better than a NATO instrument or a UN peacekeeping mission or other kinds of missions. This is already something that the European Council unanimously recognises. Both the European Council conclusions, of December 2015 and June 2015, indicate clearly a sense of direction towards investing more in the dimension of CSDP, and I am confident that also with the help of this House the necessary work, the political work we need to prepare, is going to be done to achieve the implementation of the treaty provisions fully and successfully and , let me say, for the safety, the security and the benefit of all European citizens.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I have received seven motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 21 January 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. – Mr President, colleagues, the European Union is going through an extremely difficult period. The uncontrolled flow of immigrants, the radicalisation of EU citizens, terrorist attacks and the constant threat of terrorist attacks require a new and decisive approach to European security. For the first time in the history of the EU, Article 42 of the EU Treaty has been used to ask for military assistance, but as we can see, there is no clear procedure in the European Union on how to apply the provisions of this article. The European Union must take action as soon as possible in the area of the common security and defence policy. We need a very clear military structure at EU level that has clear strategic tasks and the right capacity to ensure collective defence.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. – For the first time, the mutual defence clause was invoked after the horrendous attacks by Daesh in Paris. Looking into the future, this case must be invoked in all in-depth political discussions on the multidimensional nature of European security and defence. I also welcome the invitation to the VP/HR of the EU for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to propose a clear structure for ensuring an effective response in the event that a Member State calls upon the mutual defence clause.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The unanimous and full support expressed to France by all EU Member States in the face of the tragedy that forced the country to invoke the mutual defence clause is encouraging. The reference to Article 42(7) of the TOU is primarily a political act and the European Council and the European Parliament are places for political debate. Each first use of the clause requires the knowledge that it will be applied in different situations in the future. It is therefore essential that the current situation sets a precedent, but, on the other hand, that it sets procedures for its application on a case-by-case basis. Since no analysis or guidance was available at the time of the activation of Article 42(7) of the TOU by France, ad hoc action was necessary. However, it is clear that practical steps, guidelines and procedures are needed to ensure a common and effective response when a Member State invokes the mutual defence clause.  The role of the EU institutions in this procedure should be strengthened and include, in particular, the coordination of the assistance provided. To this end, the EU needs a permanent civilian-military headquarters at operational and strategic level, taking into account the existing capabilities of the Member States. This structure would have the task of strategic and operational planning, including mutual defence, in accordance with Article 42(7) and Article 42(2) OF the TOU and their future applications in close cooperation with the relevant NATO structures.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on EU priorities for the 2016 UNHCR meeting.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, as you know, I have spent the most part of this year in office travelling the world, and in doing so I have had the chance to look at Europe and our European Union through the eyes of our friends and partners. When they look at us, they immediately think of two things: our economic strengths – even after the crisis, hoping the crisis is actually passed – and our work for human rights. Let me take this debate not just as an opportunity to list the priorities we have at the UN Human Rights Council in 2016. Let me also say a few words on how we wish to promote human rights all around the world, and what human rights are to us.  I believe the main tools we have to support human rights worldwide are multilateralism and engagement with all the relevant actors and stakeholders. This is why the Human Rights Council is so central. It is the place where resolute action can be agreed against grave humanitarian rights violations, and it is also the UN central venue for forging new partnerships to advance human rights around the world. It is where we seek to promote justice and equality, as well as collaborative and inclusive approaches in the face of discrimination, repression and violence. As such, at HRC31 we will be prioritising two of the worst cases of human rights violations and abuses: the DPRK, which you will be discussing tomorrow in this hemicycle, and Syria, which we discussed yesterday. The DPRK continues to be one of – if not the – most oppressive States in the world. The freedoms of expression, religion and movement are almost non—existent. Hundreds of thousands of people remain detained in political prison camps and other detention facilities. Many of these people have not been convicted of any internationally recognised crime. At HRC31, we will be co-presenting with Japan a strong resolution addressing this grave human rights situation. The resolution will call for accountability and extend the mandate of the Special Rapporteur. It will also press for effective follow-up by the DPRK to the universal periodic review process and for a resumption of reporting to Treaty monitoring bodies.  Closer to us, Syria is by far the world’s largest humanitarian disaster, with no parallel in recent history. Our first priority in the current political talks is to allow humanitarian access to the largest part of the country. Such focus will be reflected in the resolution on Syria. The recent axis of aid in Madaya was a positive step, but it is just a first step that needs to be followed by many others, and relevant ones. In the long run, peace in Syria will require justice and accountability for all. Putting together the pieces of Syrian society will not be easy. Reconciliation will need, first of all, recognition of the immense suffering of the Syrian people. To this end, we will support further extension of the Commission of Inquiry’s mandate, which we also discussed in a previous debate this evening, as this remains the sole evidence—gathering tool in support of potential future justice mechanisms.  The Human Rights Council is also a place where positive developments can be recognised, so our other country-specific priority will be on Myanmar/Burma, whose historic elections in November are a much welcome step forward.  We still have ongoing concerns, in particular with regard to ethnic and religious minorities. We will then present a resolution which recommends to the new government that takes office in April to take swift and bold action to address these issues, and which ensures continuing UN scrutiny of the developments in the country. We will also be presenting two thematic resolutions: one on freedom of religion or belief to underline EU support to the fight against the religious intolerance in all forms and expressions – and again, we come back to an issue we discussed a few hours ago – and one jointly with a Latin America and Caribbean group on the rights of the child. On freedom of religion, we will also be organising a side—event where the Special Rapporteur will present the key findings in his report with the participation of civil society. This is in line with our belief that we could not discuss basic human rights without civil society representatives. Throughout the whole year, the European Union will keep working with partners to promote and protect the space of civil society and – let me stress this – the role of human rights defenders in UN proceedings and in all countries. Before closing, let me mention two further issues of particular importance for our work on human rights: the credibility of the UN Human Rights Forum, and our own credibility. The first lies primarily in the independence, integrity and effectiveness of the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights. The EU has been, and will remain, an important partner in staving off attempts to place its activity under the scrutiny or guidance of UN Member States. This is essential to preserve its credibility.  The European Union has also extended concrete cooperation to help the Office of High Commissioner perform its vital task, that is, to service all the HRC-endorsed mechanisms and provide meaningful assistance for the implementation of international human rights agreements. This includes political backing and financial support under the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights.  Let us come to ourselves. Worldwide, we are perceived as a champion of human rights, and rightly so. Sometimes this is a good perception, while some other partners have some doubts about our role, but this does not stop us. On the contrary, this motivates us even more. Let me tell you that, over the past year, this perception has been challenged. The current events are putting us to the test. It is not just the refugee crisis, it is also the long-term effects of the economic crisis and the growing sense of instability for our citizens. They need to find a way out of the past crisis with a shift in policies that is significant and visible.  These are clearly not easy times, but if we lose sight of fundamental rights for all inside Europe, all can be lost before we even realise it. You, here in this Hemicycle, represent half a billion European citizens. There are very few of you right now, but still. Our entire political class faces a tough challenge: to make our politics reflect what is best in us – what is best in Europe – and we have a choice. We can focus on our fears, foster them and let them tear this Union apart, or we can bet on the values that made us strong, on our diversity, on our solidarity, and restart the engines of this European Union. It is clearly no easy task, but it is one we definitely cannot fail.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by High Representative, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. Firstly, I would like to thank everyone involved in the negotiations of this year's resolution on the European Union's priorities for the United Nations Human Rights Council. Firstly, it is good news that this year we are adopting our resolution in time before the final priorities of the European Union are adopted, and at the same time I thank the High Representative here for her openness and willingness to debate with us, which I hope provides a broader view of the priorities identified by Parliament in the position with which the delegation will go to the session beginning at the end of February.  I would also like to emphasise what the High Representative said, that multilateralism and commitment to human rights are such an important element of this European commitment.  Secondly, in this year's position we meet a very wide catalogue of issues relevant to respect for human rights. These include, inter alia, improving the functioning of the Council itself, including the functioning of the International Criminal Court, civil and political rights, the question of the permanent point of abolition and reduction, or the moratorium on the execution of the death penalty, religious freedom, the situation of human rights defenders, social and economic rights and business and human rights relations, which play an increasingly important role in the world. Of course, the issue of the migration crisis, which is largely linked also to the humanitarian crisis, counter-terrorism and human rights in various aspects of the climate or in the context of sporting events.  Thirdly, we emphasise that religious freedom is a fundamental human right, in accordance with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights guaranteed by the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.  Last sentence, Mr President, we are referring to perhaps the biggest migration crisis in decades. We stress that it is not only European, but above all international, global in nature and multilateral action is needed here.

name: Soraya POST
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Thank you to the High Representative for a good speech that shows clear respect for human rights. I would also like to thank the colleagues who have been involved in the negotiations for producing this resolution and colleagues who have also shown, with great respect, the importance of this resolution. It is a very important resolution for the work on respect for human rights, on which we are to vote tomorrow. It is a resolution that the European Parliament will take with it to the UN Human Rights Council at its next meeting in Geneva in March. We demonstrated in this resolution that we are closely monitoring the situation of respect for human rights in the world and that human rights work is a top priority in our foreign policy. And it demonstrates the European Parliament's priorities for the UN Human Rights Council.  I would say that it is precisely in time of conflict and crisis that we must not waver, but it is particularly important that we maintain and stand up for human rights at that moment, both within the EUROPEAN Union and in our foreign policy. Human rights are the basis of a democratic society. In the resolution, we touch on several important areas: respect for human rights with regard to refugees and migrants, where humanitarian corridors and humanitarian visas are important for the protection of the human rights of those fleeing war and persecution. It also recalls the continued current work on the implementation of the Beijing Platform and the right to education and health as fundamental human rights and the importance of women's participation in peace and conflict resolution, as well as the equal representation of women at all levels of decision-making. The resolution also concerns children's rights, climate refugees and LGBTQ rights, where we are unfortunately seeing a worrying development of an increase in violations. The resolution also includes, as a priority, a selection of countries in which we draw attention to the human rights situation. In addition to these, we have also included the Conclusions of the European Council on peace processes in the Middle East, which is particularly important in view of the current situation. I am also pleased that here in the resolution we draw attention to the denial of the entry of the UN Special Representative for Human Rights into the occupied territories of Palestine, which imposes serious restrictions on the possibility of monitoring the situation and makes it impossible for the UN to work there.  The resolution also draws attention to the situation of human rights defenders, as we see that their room for manoeuvre is increasingly limited in several places in both Europe and the world. Despite death threats and reprisals, many activists work continuously for human rights.  I hope that tomorrow we will send a strong signal to those gathering in Geneva next month. It is more important than ever that the EU can show political leadership in respect for human rights. The EU is and should be a strong player in international cooperation for the promotion and respect of human rights.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Here in Parliament's empty plenary, we are discussing the European Union's priorities with the United Nations Human Rights Committee. We then pretend that the European Union is a sovereign, independent state with an independent foreign policy, which it is not. That is why the debate is a bit lopsided in its approach. However, now that you are here, I would ask you, Mrs Mogherini, as external representative, to make the persecution of Christians, the persecution and murder of Christians in the world a top issue of the United Nations. We are loud and protesting from all the other minorities. But the issue of the persecution of Christians must be at the top of the agenda before it is too late. Get involved, please!

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, thank you for your clarity and determination. I would also like to begin by thanking the political groups in Parliament which endorse this joint motion for a resolution and, in particular, the rapporteur, Mr Grzyb, for the extraordinary work of seeking consensus and prioritizing shared values. Only in this way can we respond to the mandate given to us by the citizens. In order to be a member of the United Nations Human Rights Council, the General Assembly must take into account the contribution to the promotion and protection of human rights by the candidate countries. Once these are elected, members undertake to defend for a period of three years the levels required in this area. Any citizen who hears this and finds that countries such as Venezuela or Saudi Arabia are part of the Council will most likely not give credit and wonder how it is possible for countries that systematically violate human rights to help other States meet their obligations in this regard. Will Venezuela teach other countries how to deal with freedom of expression, judicial independence or the rule of law, with seventy-four imprisoned political prisoners whose only crime is to think differently from that of Mr Maduro's government? Or is Saudi Arabia going to show the rest of the world the way to end the death penalty — one of the European Union's priorities, by the way — when in 2015 it has broken its record for executions over the past twenty years? The United Nations General Assembly has the right to suspend a member of the Council if it considers that it is committing human rights violations during its membership period. On this point, this citizen will surely wonder what the General Assembly expects to proceed with the suspension of Venezuela and Saudi Arabia. We cannot allow these countries to undermine the credibility of the institutions that monitor human rights in the world. The first step must be by us, the whole of the States of the European Union. How? For example, by not voting, in any case, in favour of the choice of countries that do not meet the fundamental requirement established and, of course, making their vote public.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, I do not like the way we work on these subjects in this house. Usually, we vote resolutions without taking into account the HRC's agenda, even though its session work has already begun. This time, the European Parliament is actually voting on a resolution earlier, so much the better. But we do not take more account of the HRC's priorities. This approach is not effective, we cannot work in the UN bodies without regard for the work of the institution. And it is not you, Madam High Representative, whom I am questioning. On the contrary, I thank you for your intervention. Yes, Member States would benefit from careful consideration and, even better, to implement the HRC's recommendations, including on housing, debt, women's rights, and economic and social rights. Yes, the European Union loses credibility in these areas when it cannot continue to ask third countries to comply with rights that it is less and less respecting itself. So, for all these reasons, the GUE/NGL has chosen not to join this resolution and will abstain on its vote.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, High Representative, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Our resolution on the March meeting of the Human Rights Council in Geneva is ready in time and I hope that the EU delegation will take the recommendations and demands into account in its prioritisation and negotiations. The UN Human Rights Council is the central global human rights body, and the EU, as a regional organisation, is well advised to actively interfere in the work and debates there, whether on country situations and on thematic developments. We also call for the EU to continue to provide financial support for the work of the Human Rights Council and to act politically to ensure the independence of this body. Unfortunately, this body also includes governments with a proven disastrous human rights record. It would therefore be important for EU Member States to take a firm position against the election of such states to the Human Rights Council. In all multilateral for a, the EU can gain influence by speaking with one voice. Time and again we hear the accusation that human rights are instruments of so-called imperialist interference in internal affairs. This is another reason why it is important for the EU to actively try to get resolutions in place together with governments in the global south, such as the resolution on the human right to clean drinking water and sanitation. I therefore deplore the negative vote of EU Member States on issues that are particularly important for countries in the global south, such as the resolution on illegal financial flows, external debt and the right to education. Finally, I would like to say that the resolution is a very good basis for the EU's position in the Human Rights Council. I too would like to thank Mr Grzyb for his very good conduct in the negotiations.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, well, today's debate gives us the opportunity to take stock of respect for human rights in the world, and it is a great pity that there are so few of us, not least because we could have talked about the responsibilities to be taken as Europeans. The resolution is positive and we will support it, it contains our comments on the protection of indigenous peoples and the fight against the criminal phenomenon of land grabbing. We are also delighted at the recognition of the right to a dignified economic and social situation. However, we are very concerned that the members of the Council are often chosen from states that most violate fundamental rights, such as China, Russia, Saudi Arabia and Ethiopia. Threats to fundamental rights are widespread on a very large scale and not only because of the very serious acts of terrorism and related phenomena. We need only think of the resurgence of executions, the attacks on international co-operatives and activists, the arrests of political opponents, the very serious violations against migrants throughout their journey, the effects of climate change, which are included in this resolution. With this resolution, we are calling on the Human Rights Council and the United Nations to be increasingly up to the task entrusted to it every day, hoping that 2016 will be a more positive year than 2015.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – As the very last subject in a very busy day, a few moments before midnight, with 15 of the more than 741 Members in this House, we are going to debate human rights. If I was of bad will, I would almost say that we can deduce from this what the place of human rights is in the European Union. However, I am not of bad will, I am only here to remind you of and to link the issue of human rights with immigration and the way in which in 2015, under the impetus of EU politics, it got completely out of control because of a misinterpretation of Schengen, by a misinterpretation of the Geneva Convention and by the open borders of the European Union.  Human rights need a stable environment and your immigration policy has destroyed that stable environment in Europe. We have seen this in a horrifying way in Cologne, where, for the first time, human rights have been massively violated on European soil. When you continue to organise immigration, you must also keep in mind that human rights are not simply given free of charge. Human rights, this requires a stable environment and not the watered-down cultural environment that is being opened up to far too much of our deviant culture.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, the European Union is one of the greatest players on the world chessboard with potential that has a significant impact on international developments. It must therefore work closely with the UN to deal with the serious issues of concern to the international community. One of them, the most serious and urgent, is immigration. In order to solve this problem we need to look at it with a pragmatic approach. We cannot try to accommodate migrants in Europe and at the same time not try to eliminate the causes of migration in order to stop it. We must not only care about the human rights of migrants and then allow them to have delinquent behaviour in the countries in which they are hosted. Moreover, we do not gain anything if we condemn the illegal movement and trafficking of human beings, but we leave illegal traffickers unchecked. Finally, we show neither seriousness nor determination when we allow Turkey to play the European Union, pretending that it wants to contribute to the resolution of migration, and when we tolerate being blackmailed into speeding up its integration processes.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, I would first like to point out that a month ago we debated and adopted by a large majority here the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and the Union's policy on human rights and democracy in this area. Therefore, it is very difficult for me to understand why we will, so soon after, vote for a text which is, to a certain extent, similar to the annual report. Indeed, in this resolution, which is supposed to express Parliament's position on the EU's priorities at the UN Human Rights Council, all subjects with any relationship to human rights are discussed: from women to drones, from sport to trade. I believe that, by this resolution, we are completely distorting the meaning of the term 'priority' and we are repeating a work already done. It is essential to me that next year Parliament's resolution on this issue be shorter and more in line with its objective. We could, for example, pick five priorities and stop there. For Parliament's positions on all other human rights issues, we have the annual report. The second point on which I would like to dwell concerns the second part of the text which theoretically covers the list of countries under universal periodic review, because there is a glaring inconsistency here, following the insistence of the left, which wanted, and this is not the first time, to target and stigmatize Israel. The respective list, I quote, is "Middle East Peace Process" in the respective list, which is paragraph 89. It goes without saying that this is not a country and that the universal periodic review has nothing to do with it. If we want to be taken seriously as a Parliament, we must avoid this kind of inconsistency. That is why the EPP Group has decided to introduce a separate vote on this paragraph, and if it is not eliminated, we will vote against the resolution.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Mr President, as the rapporteur on corporate responsibility, I hope the forthcoming session of the UN Human Rights Council and this Parliament’s delegation to it will continue to advance the priority given to business and human rights. As paragraph 28 of our resolution makes clear, this Parliament believes the European Union and its Member States should engage constructively in the intergovernmental working group on a legally-binding instrument. Previously the EU left the room after the first day, which I understand may be subject to some criticism in the report of the UN working group, which is due to be presented in March. Preventing and boycotting a human rights mechanism is not where Europe should be. Our resolution makes clear that taking part in what is an open-ended working group is not an alternative to the Accountability and Remedy Project of the High Commissioner on domestic law remedies, nor is it an alternative to promoting the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, to which the EU Member States could demonstrate their commitment by completing the process and agreeing national action plans. I understand the EU may even be considering a resolution in Geneva criticising the UN working group. This is the path of confrontation with which this Parliament cannot agree.  For my Group, I do not agree with all of the proposals being discussed in the working group. For example, I believe human rights should apply to all business and not just the transnational corporations. But surely Europe must be in the room to diplomatically express our disagreement and to demonstrate to others what we so often say to them: to be prepared to listen to different views. And the final part of what I want to say: I will respond to what my friend and colleague, Mr Preda, says about paragraph 89. He makes it a key vote, and his Group says they will vote against the resolution if it fails. What does that paragraph say? It supports compliance with international humanitarian law and international human rights law; it calls for the viability of the two-state solution; and it calls for support for the special rapporteur on the situation of human rights in the Palestinian territories. I say to him and his Group, in all truth: we have a consensus about moving forward on Middle East peace. We believe that voting for those principles is right to get peace between Israel and Palestine. If he and his Group choose to disagree on that in the course of this resolution, they are wrong.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Mrs Mogherini, it is late at night and we are still here with very few people in the Chamber, but we are talking about very important things. We are going to vote on the resolution later, tomorrow, to set priorities.  I point to three, four points briefly. 1. We are right to talk about women's rights. As an ALDE member, I am very proud that we also talk about sexual and reproductive rights and health. For me, that includes abortion, especially after sexual violence. I know, Mrs Mogherini, that you also share that view, 'boss in his own belly'.  2. Children's rights, we talk about this very often. Today Unicef is making a save the children appeal. Thousands of children walk in the cold on those escape routes. We have to make sure we don't freeze children to death right now on those escape routes.  3. Reference is made to Burundi. In March, I pointed out that there is a genocide going on and I advocated doing something. I want to repeat this here today. 4. Finally: Israel, Palestine. Israel is not being pointed the finger as a country, but we would like to remind us of the conclusions of that important council.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: – Mr. President, I support what my colleague Preda said and, indeed, it would be a pity if the European People's Party Club had to withhold support for this resolution because of the unbalanced text when it comes to the Process in the Middle East. Because otherwise this resolution has really good, high-quality parts. I will highlight here paragraph 9 of the resolution, which tosses on the increasingly frequent revisions of the constitution in developing countries, especially Africa, so that the ruling structures there circumvent the constitutional limits placed on the duration of the president's term. Such actions often result in civil uprisings, violence. We have discussed this several times in this house, e.g. when we had a resolution on Burundi. But this is not the only example.  Unfortunately, we can note that there is a trend of backslide in the democratisation process in many African countries, which unfortunately also leads to systematic human rights violations. It is true that elections are held in these states, but it is an insiaries in which the ruling party wins all elections with more than 80% of the vote. In addition to the European institutions, our European political groups should also take more account of this, in cooperation with such African parties and movements. The importance of good governance is something the UN recognises in the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, especially with the development objective of 16, and I think this should be a priority for our foreign development policy and thus a priority in the work of the UN Human Rights Council.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: – Sur President, ma hemmx dubju li d-drittijiet tat-tfal jixirqilhom attenzjoni partikulari. Għalkemm il-Konvenzjoni dwar id-Drittijet tat-Tfal hija fost l-aktar ratifikata, l-implimentazzjoni tagħha tfalli f'divers setturi. Il-politika, bħas-so大jetajiet li tirrifletti, mhux dejjem tagħraf il-qofol tal-aħjar interess tat-tfal. Huma membri sħaħ tas-so大jetà, li l-vulnerabilità tagħhom iġġibhom vittmi tal-aġir tal-aġir tal-adulti ta' madwarhom, isofru l-effetti ta' ambjent imniġġġ b'povertà, vjolenza, diskriminazzjoni, u sfruttar ieħor. Huwa għalhekk meħtieġ li l-Unjoni Ewropea tkompli fil-ħidma tagħha sabiex tassigura li l-Konvenzjoni ma tkunx biss fost l-aktar Konvenzjonijiet ratifikati, iżda tkun l-aktar Konvenzjoni implimentata. Rajna r-reazzjoni tan-nies għal ritratt ta' kadavru ta' tifel li għereq fil-vjaġġ tiegħu lejn ħajja aħjar. Kemm hemm tfal li mietu f'dawn il-vjaġi li ma nafux bihom, u kemm hemm tfal li qegħdin isofru ħruxija li i narawx ritratt tagħhom? Huwa l-obbligu tagħna, l-Unjoni Ewropea, li nikxfu l-nikħxija li jbatu dawn it-tfal u nassiguraw li qed nagħmlu kollox biex inwaqqfuha.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: – Mr President, the defence of human rights is a hallmark of the European Union, which, together with the United Nations Human Rights Council, puts the spotlight where it is necessary to defend those suffering persecution and lack of freedom by reviewing a number of countries, including This year's Venezuela.  Although this Parliament banned the observation mission to this country, the People's Group allowed three of my colleagues and I to accompany the Venezuelan people at that historic time when those who defended freedom managed to democratically defeat an un democratic government.  But all this flow of hope can be left on wet paper if the President of Venezuela ignores the will of the people, for example by opposing the Amnesty Act calling for the immediate release of all prisoners who are in prison for reporting violations of the human rights of the Venezuelan regime.  I call on the Commission and this Parliament to strongly demand the release of political prisoners from the Venezuelan authorities. How long can Maduro still not want to hear the cries of his people crying out for freedom?

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – This year we face many challenges closely linked to the human rights agenda. For these reasons too, human rights issues will become increasingly pressing. It is therefore necessary to set our priorities correctly for this year in the UN Human Rights Council. Human rights form the basis of modern Europe. We should therefore be a leader in promoting this agenda at the UN. We should therefore also focus more closely on the human rights agenda in relation to migration. Strengthening humanitarian and development aid and contributing to poverty reduction in critical regions of the world should therefore be paramount. However, there is also a need to face up to the consequences and to strengthen international cooperation and other steps leading to the fight against international trafficking networks in human beings, but also to the agenda of strengthening the protection of women's and children's rights.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by High Representative, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. The UNHRC has a unique mandate from the international community, including the Union, to promote and protect human rights worldwide. It is important that the members of this body are chosen from among the states that respect these rights. Unfortunately, the criteria for membership in this area remain unregulated, which poses a threat to the effectiveness and impartiality of this board. The UN Human Rights Council's general periodic reviews of individual countries are a necessary mechanism, but there is a need to include different interest groups, in particular civil society organisations. The recommendations contained in the review are also a signal to other countries and should translate into cooperation and effective solutions at national and regional level. Human rights should also be respected in the business world. Both the Union and the UN should make efforts to set standards for businesses and Member States in terms of decent working conditions and to promote the development of local communities. I hope that the Union will actively participate in the sessions of the Human Rights Council, including through interventions on human rights issues and the enforcement of responsibility for their violations.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, human rights violations in Turkey and Skopje must be included in the priorities of the European Union. I would like to take this opportunity to stress my complete and vertical opposition to the initiative of Croatian MEP Marijana Petir to set up an informal friendship group called 'Friends of Macedonia' and with a view to supporting Skopje.   We remind this MEP that Skopje is recognised by the European Union under the provisional name YROM and by no other name. This MEP must be aware that we will not allow Skopje and all their companions to take ownership of the name of our Macedonia.  I therefore denounce before this House the provocative and at the same time illegal creation of the Pro-Macedonian group entitled 'Friends of Macedonia' and I call on the President of the European Parliament Martin Schulz to take appropriate action to fully implement in this case the UN resolutions relating to the name of Skopje. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: question by raising the blue card. "Mr. Marias, do you know that such an informal group has existed before, and therefore nothing new has happened? And the second question, what does what what you said have to do with the theme we're discussing today?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), "blue card" answer. Mr President, I would like to address my colleague and tell him that I have raised a serious issue: Skopje; Illegally you use the name Macedonia. You should be aware, those who created this group, that what you are doing is also a violation of the way the European Union recognises Skopje under the name YROM. Understand that once and for all.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I will not prolong much longer our stay in this Hemicycle. I would just like to thank you all, especially those who stuck to the actual topic of our debate, which has shown a joint commitment of all Groups to our work on human rights. As many of you have said, this is not only a clear principle and value of the European Union, this is also our mission to protect and promote – neither one of these by itself is enough – to protect and promote human rights both inside and outside the Union. Let me say that, in this work, the support and also the guidance of the European Parliament is crucial. We try to do all that we can to use our external action instruments together, jointly, to fulfil this mandate, to be a relevant player on human rights, with some concrete results on the ground. Sometimes this is evident, sometimes this is less evident. In most cases this happens and in most cases around all our human rights priorities, whether it is concrete single cases of human rights defenders, or whether it is the big issues around which we mobilise our work, such as abolition of the death penalty or economic and social rights – the list is long – in all these cases either it is the European Union making the difference, with the European Parliament, with the Member States, with all our tools, or the situation is more difficult. So we know we have not only some values, some principles, but I would say also some interests, because defending and promoting human rights around the world is also responding to a direct interest in stability and security worldwide, because there is no possibility of a stable environment if there is no respect for human rights. This is something that, again, is not only a value and a principle, but also a clear responsibility that we have – inside our borders and outside them. I would like to thank this Parliament for the continued support it gives to our action in this respect, and also let me personally thank the EU Special Representative for Human Rights, Stavros Lambrinidis, who knows this Hemicycle very well, for the excellent work that he is doing to support this mission that we are all together taking forward.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 21 January 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I would point out that the UN Charter has not yet been revised and, notwithstanding the coordinated position of the EU Member States, each has the opportunity to express its views on serious human rights violations in the world. The report omits such cases taking place in Crimea after the Russian Federation seized this territory of Ukraine. Nadia Savchenko is still in custody. This subject has not been included in the Human Rights Council. Recently, there have been a series of suspected deaths of senior russian special services representatives, as well as long-time democratic opposition activists (Boris Nemtsov, Vladimir Priskovsky). A report on the circumstances of Litvinenko's death will also be released.  All these events require us to look at the dramatic human rights situation in Russia, despite its commitment to dialogue in other areas. Similar comments relate to China. Nor are there any cases related to the permanent violation of the fundamental rights of individuals and entire groups in Iran, including public executions. Unfortunately, none of the EU institutions has drawn attention to these shortcomings. Nor does the EP resolution contain such elements. I am pleased that the issue of Crimea has been discussed in the US Congress, the Council of Europe and the UN in New York. One Polish NGO, PAUCI, has also produced a shocking report on the matter.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. – The situation in Burundi is extremely serious. Violence is escalating inside the country and there is growing evidence of arms being distributed among some of those living in refugee camps in neighbouring states. Given the situation in Burundi and the implications for the wider East African community if the situation does not improve it is vital that the EU makes this a priority for UNHCR sessions this year.
